Also, it requires only 0.52 seconds to process an image of 1-MP.

title: Analysis of Sensitivity Function-Based Robustness Constraints in Decentralized PID Controller Design for TITO Systems
authors: S. Madrigal, O. Arrieta, A. Visioli, M. Meneses, R. Vilanova
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: In the design of Multiple-Input-Multiple-Output (MIMO) control systems, one of the most critical considerations is system stability. This is typically addressed in the controller design process through the incorporation of a stability index, often based on frequency domain analysis, to quantify system robustness after controller implementation. This work focuses on analyzing the design of Decentralized Proportional-Integral-Derivative (PID) controllers for Two-Input-Two-Output (TITO) processes, which are among the most common multivariable systems. The proposed approach evaluates stability margins using the maximum of the sensitivity function, despite robustness also being measurable through the maximum of the singular values. By utilizing the equivalent sensitivity function for multivariable systems, the method provides a direct means of assessing robustness once decentralized controllers are implemented. The feasibility of this approach is examined for a specific level of robustness and is validated employing two benchmark processes.

title: DERMIS: End-to-End Design of a Fully Integrated Large-Area Grasp-State-Adaptive Tactile Sensor System on a-IGZO TFT
authors: Mark Daniel Alea, Maria Atalaia Rosa, Michael Kraft, Kris Myny, Georges Gielen
publish: IEEE Transactions on Biomedical Circuits and Systems
abstract: This paper presents the design of a high-resolution fully-integrated tactile sensor system, called DERMIS, implemented in a flexible thin-film transistor (TFT) technology for large-area electronic skins. It discusses how an end-to-end design strategy – from the sensor to the readout and to the on-chip feature extraction – enables efficient system reconfiguration to implement a first-of-its-kind and biologically-inspired grasp-state-adaptive tactile sensor. In contrast to existing tactile sensors that only detect slip, the DERMIS system also measures key contact cues, including friction, contact onset/offset, and lift-off onset/offset, enabled by a novel differential capacitive sensorstructure that independently senses shear and normal forces and a co-designed front end that directly extracts both components at the analog domain. Furthermore, due to the analog-based encoding of these grasp-state-dependent contact parameters, the system avoids the use of complex offline slip-extraction algorithms. The per-taxel (tactile pixel) readout consumes a state-of-the-art 72 µW power consumption and occupies 0.36 mm2 area while achieving a human-like 2 mNRMS force resolution at 0.6 mm pitch. This work demonstrates our solution for the first time in a true large-area prototype of 9×4 mm2.

title: The Spread Pattern of Loneliness in Social Networks Using an Empirical Analysis Based on Spark GraphFrames
authors: Yuxin Cao
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Digital Society and Intelligent Systems (DSInS)
abstract: Loneliness, as an important psychological state, may spread in modern social networks in a manner similar to an infectious disease. Based on Apache Spark GraphFrames, this study constructed a loneliness propagation model in large-scale social networks, simulated its dynamic propagation process using the Susceptible-Infectious-Susceptible model, and analyzed its propagation patterns through multiple parameter experiments. The experimental results show that the speed of loneliness transmission is highly correlated with the transmission probability and the increase in the recovery probability can significantly inhibit the spread, but the inhibitory effect decreases after the recovery probability under 0.8. Also, under the condition that the recovery probability is fixed at 0.9, the spread shows a three-stage characteristic.

title: Positive Body Image Formation Software Algorithm: Innovative Path Research Based on Multimodal Data Fusion and Deep Learning
authors: Haiyan Xv, Ming Yi, Yuxin Chen
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Digital Society and Intelligent Systems (DSInS)
abstract: This paper proposes a positive body image generation algorithm based on multimodal data fusion, which integrates computer vision, deep learning and positive psychology theory, and guides users to turn their attention to the advantages and functions of their own body through three core steps: nonjudgmental perception of human images, recognition and highlighting of individual body advantages, and generation of personalized positive feedback, so as to gradually cultivate positive body image. The experimental results show that the algorithm can extract body features effectively and generate positive feedback that matches users 'individual characteristics. This study not only provides a new technical means for positive body image intervention, but also provides a new perspective and methodology for interdisciplinary research, especially for the integration of psychology and artificial intelligence. Future work will further improve the generalization ability and user experience of the algorithm.

title: Deep Learning in Palmprint Recognition: A Comprehensive Survey
authors: Chengrui Gao, Ziyuan Yang, Wei Jia, Lu Leng, Bob Zhang, Andrew Beng Jin Teoh
publish: IEEE Transactions on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics: Systems
abstract: Palmprint recognition has emerged as a prominent biometric technology, widely applied in diverse scenarios. Traditional handcrafted methods for palmprint recognition often fall short in representation capability, as they heavily depend on researchers’ prior knowledge. Deep learning (DL) has been introduced to address this limitation, leveraging its remarkable successes across various domains. While existing surveys focus narrowly on specific tasks within palmprint recognition—often grounded in traditional methodologies—there remains a significant gap in comprehensive research exploring DL-based approaches across all facets of palmprint recognition. This article bridges that gap by thoroughly reviewing recent advancements in DL-powered palmprint recognition. This article systematically examines progress across key tasks, including region-of-interest (ROI) segmentation, feature extraction, and security and privacy-oriented challenges. Beyond highlighting these advancements, this article identifies current challenges and uncovers promising opportunities for future research. By consolidating state-of-the-art progress, this review serves as a valuable resource for researchers, enabling them to stay abreast of cutting-edge technologies and drive innovation in palmprint recognition.

title: Autopilot Design for Agile Initial Pitch-over Maneuver Using Schmitt-trigger
authors: Ju-Hyeon Hong, Gwanyong Moon
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: The proposed autopilot employs a skid-to-turn scheme to achieve a faster time response. The pitch and yaw channel autopilots utilize a two-loop design, incorporating a PI (Proportional-Integral) controller in the inner loop to track the angular rate command and a Schmitt trigger in the outer loop. The Schmitt trigger determines the direction of rotation for rapid attitude changes. A precomputed table generates the maximum normal acceleration, which defines the amplitude of the angular rate command. This combination of the Schmitt trigger and the maximum trim command ensures stability and maximizes maneuverability during the initial pitch-over phase. Although the skid-to-turn approach may result in larger tracking errors compared to bank-to-turn methods, it still achieves the primary objective of a fast time response during the initial pitch-over phase. The effectiveness of the autopilot is validated through non-linear 6-DOF simulations and Monte Carlo simulations that account for aerodynamic uncertainties.

title: Conducting Gel-Assisted Triboelectric Sensor Array for Self-Powered Wireless Pressure Distribution and Emergency Alert System_supp5-3651863.mp4
authors: Dr. Ranbir Singh
abstract: Triboelectric nanogenerators (TENG) is a promising and sustainable solution for converting mechanical energy into electrical energy, as well as utilize for energy harvesting and sensing applications. However, TENG devices inherently suffers from limited electrical conductivity, which limits output current from dielectric triboelectric layers despite their high voltage generation. To address these challenges, this work presents the development of high-performance polyvinyl alcohol/silver nitrate (PVA/AgNO<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sub>) conducting gels, engineered to be flexible, stretchable, and employed as an electropositive intermediate dielectric layer embedded within the TENG architecture to facilitate efficient charge generation and transfer. Synthesized PVA/AgNO<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sub> conducting gel exhibits improved electrical conductivity, tensile strength, and compressive strength of 32.8 S/m, 0.5 MPa, and 0.6 MPa, respectively. Further, conducting gel was employed to fabricate a triboelectric nanogenerator (CG-TENG), delivering an output voltage of 27.6 V and a current density response up to 0.4 μA/cm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>, which is a threefold increment compared to reference conducting gel free-TENG. The CG-TENG efficiently produces a maximum power density of 0.16 mW/cm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> across a 1 kΩ load resistor. Additionally, a 2 × 2 self-powered pressure sensor array prototype was fabricated using CG-TENG to demonstrate spatially resolved pressure sensing, where each pixel generated distinct electrical signals under mechanical stimulation. The prototypes successfully demonstrate emergency alert messages on OLED, wirelessly visualize pressure sensing and distribution on the graphical user interface (GUI).

title: Noise-Resilient Protection Algorithm in Renewable Integrated Microgrid Based on Zero-Sequence Current Detection, Differential Faulty Energy, VMD, and SVM
authors: Julius N Nteh, Hossein Dehghani Tafti, Munira Batool
abstract: The integration of renewable energy sources into microgrids introduces significant challenges in protection, stability, and reliability. Reliable protection of renewable integrated microgrids remains a major challenge due to the presence of harmonics, switching transients, and noise contamination that compromise conventional fault detection schemes. The work in this paper suggests the integration of zero sequence current (ZSC) detection, differential faulty energy (DFE), variational mode decomposition (VMD), and support vector machine (SVM) classification into a novel network fault current signal protection algorithm. The values of the ZSC and DFE indices offer fault signatures and noise, while VMD efficiently decomposes the signals under noisy conditions to extract robust features. These features are further analysed using an SVM supported supported classifier for fault analysis under diverse conditions. Simulation research is performed on a renewable integrated microgrid model with diverse fault scenarios and noise levels. The outcome indicates that a novel scheme provides excellent detection performance, robustness to noise, and better reliability, accuracy, and classification efficiency than typical approaches. The simulation results of the proposed framework show that the proposed scheme achieves 97.2 % fault classification accuracy, detects ground faults down to 0.7 A zero sequence current, and remains robustness at noise levels as high as 39 dB, providing a 20 % improvement in noise-resilient detection performance compared to conventional approaches.

title: AI-based prediction of Chronic Kidney Disease using Health Records
authors: SasiKumar.S, Muthukumar.R
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Automation, Computing and Renewable Systems (ICACRS)
abstract: Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD) is becoming an ever-growing global health challenge, often without specific symptoms until it is quite advanced and thus, early stratification of the risk of developing it becomes critical to take immediate action. The study develops and validates a predictive pipeline based on structured electronic health records (EHR) data (e.g. demographics, comorbidities, laboratory trajectories, e.g. eGFR, serum creatinine, albuminuria; and longitudinal clinical events) to predict incident CKD-risk and short-to-medium term progression-risk. The missingness is treated, the class imbalance is handled, and feature selection is processed with accuracy in retaining the presented clinically relevant predictors including hemoglobin, serum creatinine, albumin, and blood pressure by resorting to recursive feature elimination and feature selection that is based on stability . We contrast temporally conscious ensemble algorithms (temporal-enhanced gradient boosting against that on static tree-based ensembles and deep neural networks and use SHAP, LIME to match model explanations with nephrology knowledge. Evaluation of Model performance encompasses discrimination (AUC), calibration (Brier score and calibration plot) and decision based measures (precision, recall and F1), alongside temporal stability over a risk horizon of 1-3 years. In retrospective cohorts of EHRs, temporally enhanced gradient boosting and clinically tuned ensembles provided high discrimination and optimal calibration compared with KDIGO-based risk stratification, and corresponding explain ability analyses consistently suggested eGFR decline, albuminuria, hypertension, and metabolic markers as the significant models . The application of such AI tools in the workflow of EHR may allow prompt nephrology consultation and selective screening and risk-stratified management to limit CKD progression and rationalize resource utilization.

title: Some applications of new results in stochastic approximation with discontinuous drifts
authors: Quoc Le, Nhu Nguyen, George Yin
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: The paper is concerned with stochastic approximation algorithms. Our main effort is focused on recently developed set-valued stochastic approximation methods. We begin with a brief introduction on stochastic approximation. Next, recent results are reviewed. Then the rest of the paper concentrates on applications of stochastic applications of set-valued problems.

title: SaneKV: A Swift-Adaptive and NUMA-Enhanced Persistent Key-Value Store
authors: Shengquan Yin, Yili Ma, Jing Xing, Zheng Wei, Dingwen Tao, Guangming Tan
publish: 2025 IEEE 31th International Conference on Parallel and Distributed Systems (ICPADS)
abstract: Key-value (KV) storage is widely used in domains such as big data analytics, AI training, databases, and distributed file systems. Traditional KV systems built on DRAM or disk-based architectures struggle to meet the dual requirements of high throughput and strong data persistence demanded by modern applications. Non-Volatile Memory (NVM), with its combination of high bandwidth and persistence, offers a promising foundation for building high-performance, persistent, and largescale KV stores. Consequently, NVM-based KV storage has gained substantial research and industrial interest in recent years. However, directly porting DRAM-or disk-oriented KV designs to NVM devices often yields suboptimal performance. In Non-Uniform Memory Access (NUMA) architectures, frequent NVM persistence operations and high cross-NUMA access latency significantly limit I/O efficiency. To address these challenges, we propose SaneKV, an NVM-optimized KV store. SaneKV introduces a metadata asynchronous persistence mechanism that reduces I/O latency by aggregating metadata write-back operations, and an adaptive NVM data allocation policy to improve throughput. Experimental results show that for small-sized KV workloads, SaneKV achieves up to 75 % higher write throughput and 40 % higher read throughput than state-of-the-art NVM-based KV stores. For large-sized KV workloads, SaneKV achieves comparable peak throughput while requiring up to 40 % fewer threads to reach saturation and delivers over <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2 \times$</tex> higher overall performance than prior NVM-based designs, demonstrating superior scalability and resource utilization.

title: Statistics of Higher-Order Modal Dispersion in Multi-Mode Fiber with Strong Mode Coupling
authors: Anirudh Vijay, Nika Zahedi, Oleksiy Krutko, Rebecca Refaee, Joseph M. Kahn
abstract: The effects of mode coupling and first-order modal dispersion in mode-division multiplexed multi-mode fiber systems are well studied. However, when modal delays become frequency-dependent, higher-order modal dispersion effects, such as mode-dependent chromatic dispersion, must be incorporated into propagation models. This work investigates the statistical properties of first- and second-order group-delay operators under strong coupling conditions using a multi-section random matrix model, accounting for both intrinsic (uncoupled) group delays and mode-dependent chromatic dispersion. We show that the asymptotic distributions of these operators are determined by the number of sections, the delay spreads of the uncoupled delays, and mode-dependent chromatic dispersion. For typical graded-index multimode fibers, the uncoupled group delays have a significantly greater impact than the mode-dependent chromatic dispersion. As a result, the complexity of digital signal processing is ultimately dictated by the statistics of the first-order group-delay operator. Additionally, we derive analytical expressions for the expected intensity pulse response to provide a time-domain perspective on the higher-order effects.

title: Teratronics in the quantum flatland
authors: Denis Bandurin
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: Since the isolation of graphene, devices based on novel low-dimensional materials and their heterostructures have unlocked vast opportunities for exploring new fundamental phenomena. Reduced dimensionality, unique band structures, quantum geometry, and strong quasiparticle interactions collectively shape the response of these materials to external fields, offering a powerful platform to probe novel light-matter interactions and prototype future optoelectronic technologies. In this presentation we will discuss some of these effects.

title: Terahertz Dosimetry in European Honey Bees
authors: Fawad Sheikh, Pieterjan De Boose, Felipe Oliveira Ribas, Andreas Prokscha, Arno Thielens, Thomas Kaiser
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: Reliable environmental monitoring, particularly for small creatures like insects, must balance precise pollinator and pest identification with minimal habitat disruption while adhering to biosecurity considerations. Future miniaturized mobile terahertz (THz) systems designed for tracking sub-millimeter targets must operate within strict power limits to ensure safety and compliance with regulatory standards. This study predicts electromagnetic (EM) exposure at 300 GHz, analyzing a European honey bee (Apis mellifera) in various orientations under both near-field and far-field conditions of a state-of-the-art horn antenna modeled at this frequency. The frequency-dependent heterogeneous material properties of the European honey bee at 300 GHz have been derived from our ongoing research on a real honey bee. A comparative analysis between a simplified homogeneous model and a more realistic heterogeneous honey bee model demonstrates that the homogeneous approximation can lead to either overestimation or underestimation of power absorption, depending on the specific body region analyzed.

title: Perception and Comprehension of a Humanoid Robot by Older Adults with Dementia: Evidence from a Nursing Home Study in Japan
authors: Toshimi Ogawa, Kazue Matsuno, Ai Abe, Mika Ishikawa, Naoko Konosu, Yegang Du, Rainer Wieching, Yoshio Matsumoto, Yasuyuki Taki
publish: 2025 IEEE Cyber Science and Technology Congress (CyberSciTech)
abstract: This exploratory study investigated how older adults with dementia perceive and understand speech from a humanoid robot (Android) in a nursing home setting. Twelve residents participated in both free conversation and story comprehension tasks, with participants divided into two groups based on cognitive function (MMSE score of 23 or higher vs. 22 or lower). While overall impressions of the Android were positive—especially among individuals with lower cognitive function—comprehension of robot-delivered speech was significantly lower in the more impaired group compared to speech delivered by a human (p< 0.05). Notably, some participants mirrored the robot’s facial expressions, such as smiling in response, suggesting emotional resonance. These findings indicate the potential of humanoid robots for social engagement in dementia care, while also highlighting the need for improvements in speech delivery to accommodate individuals with more severe cognitive decline.

title: Revealing hidden layers through THz fingerprints in Cultural Heritage materials
authors: C. Moffa, D. Francescone, A. Curcio, A.C. Felici, M. Petrarca
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: Terahertz (THz) radiation allows for non-invasive, depth-sensitive examination of layered artworks. This research highlights the effectiveness of THz multispectral imaging in uncovering obscured text beneath simulated pictorial layers, reconstructing hidden content at different depths using frequency-domain analysis. Additionally, it identifies pigment distribution, offering essential materials insights. By demonstrating its ability to probe complex material structures, this study positions THz multispectral imaging as a powerful technique for revealing concealed details in Cultural Heritage artifacts.

title: Accurate Table Integration via Schema and Row Matching
authors: Jingya Huang, Haoyang Zhang, Xiao Pang, Jingwen Pan, Aoqian Zhang, Lianpeng Qiao
publish: 2025 IEEE 31th International Conference on Parallel and Distributed Systems (ICPADS)
abstract: Table integration is a critical yet challenging task in data management, requiring the alignment of tabular sources through schema matching and row matching. Existing approaches often struggle with schema diversity, semantic ambiguity, and computational inefficiency, especially in real-world scenarios involving non-English or structurally complex data. To address these challenges, we formally define the two core subtasks and propose the HMSTC algorithm and CBNet architecture. HMSTC combines semantic similarity, data type consistency, and the Hungarian algorithm to achieve globally optimal matching. CBNet is a dual-branch neural network that integrates self-attention and cross-feature interactions with cross-attention concentration to generate compact representations for accurate row matching between tables. Experiments are conducted using public datasets and a custom Chinese dataset. Results show that our approaches achieve high matching accuracy and perform well across different datasets, with HMSTC also demonstrating strong runtime efficiency.

title: A Fully-Integrated Near-Field Sensor for Permittivity-Based Imaging
authors: Hamadi Sadkaoui, Xinpeng Du, Philipp Hillger, Hafiza Misbah Younis, Marcel Andree, Connor D. W. Mosley, Adam G. Metcalf, Pietro Valdastri, John E. Cunningham, Ullrich Pfeiffer
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: This paper presents a fully integrated near-field sensor for permittivity-based imaging. The sensor comprises a 32×32 pixel array, with each pixel integrating a free-running 320GHz oscillator, a split-ring resonator (SRR), and a power detector. We demonstrate, for the first time in the terahertz regime, the sensor’s ability to distinguish between tissue types in heterogeneous samples (e.g., lean muscle and fat), as well as to perform real-time dielectric fingerprinting of homogeneous materials without the need for raster scanning.

title: Drones Identification and Classification using Fingerprints in Spectrograms
authors: Rovell Fernandes, Adolfo Perrusquía, Weisi Guo
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: The rapid proliferation of drones and Wi-Fienabled devices has revolutionized various sectors, including agriculture, entertainment, security, and surveillance. However, this also has magnified the threat space in terms of security, privacy, and efficient spectrum management. Detecting and classifying these devices accurately is crucial to address potential threats to public safety. To alleviate this issue, this paper proposes an advanced signal classification framework to identify drones base on their unique fingerprint. This is done by using spectrogram images of different drones and Wi-Fi devices operating within the 2.4 GHz spectrum which give unique patterns to identify drones fingerprint. The approach combines the features generated by Principal Component Analysis (PCA) with a modulation index to enhance classification accuracy and robustness of different machine learning classifiers. Two tasks are considered in this paper: i) multi-class classification of different drone models and ii) binary classification of drones and Wi-Fi signals. The proposed framework is rigorously tested and challenged using different hyperparameters configurations and ablation studies. The results demonstrate the robustness of the proposed approach in identifying drones accurately.

title: Hit-and-Run Vehicle Identification using YOLO-Based Multi-Task Deep Learning with Simulated Surveillance Footage
authors: R. S. Amshavalli, Dhinagareshwar G G, Dhivakar M, D.Devi, J.Karthika
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Automation, Computing and Renewable Systems (ICACRS)
abstract: Hit-And-run accidents pose a major challenge to modern traffic law enforcement due to the rapid disappearance of suspect vehicles and the limitations of manual surveillance analysis. This project introduces an automated deep learning system that identifies vehicles involved in hit-and-run incidents using a YOLO-based multi-task framework. The model performs real-time detection, attribute classification, and license plate recognition in a single unified process. To compensate for the lack of publicly available datasets, synthetic surveillance videos are generated through simulation environments, allowing the model to train under varied conditions such as lighting, weather, and traffic density. The system also integrates vehicle tracking and behavioral analysis to identify suspicious trajectories, enabling faster and more reliable identification of offending vehicles. Designed to be lightweight, scalable, and deployable in real-world surveillance networks, this approach enhances urban traffic monitoring, supports forensic analysis, and contributes to safer and smarter cities through AI-driven automation.

title: Advanced Non-Volatile Memory Technologies for Military Robotics: Architecture, Applications, and Future Trends
authors: Azamat Baibussinov, Kaisarbek Yesbergenov, Gulnara Abitova
abstract: This study presents a comparative analysis of current non-volatile memory technologies—namely flash memory, solid-state drives (SSDs), hard disk drives (HDDs), optical media, and cloud storage—in the context of military robotic systems. The evaluation is based on five key performance metrics: data access speed, shock resistance, energy efficiency, write endurance, and compliance with military standards. Using technical documentation, academic literature, and defense guidelines, the research identifies flash memory and SSDs as the most suitable options for deployment in dynamic and high-risk operational environments. The findings indicate that these technologies offer a superior balance between performance and resilience, enabling longer mission duration, improved autonomy, and higher data integrity in hostile field conditions. The paper concludes with recommendations for the integration of adaptive memory architectures and hybrid storage solutions in next-generation military robotics.

title: Machine Learning-Based Fault Detection Technique for BLDC Motor
authors: Pratik Mohanty, Rudra Narayan Dash, Subhashree Kundu, Pradeep Kumar Sahu, Srinibasa Padhy, Sarat Chandra Swain
publish: 2025 5th IEEE International Conference on Applied Electromagnetics, Signal Processing, &amp; Communication (AESPC)
abstract: This paper presents a mathematical model and simulation of a Brushless Direct Current (BLDC) motor, which is renowned for its high efficiency, power output, and low maintenance requirements. These advantageous features make BLDC motors prevalent in various advanced industries. However, faults or damage can degrade the motor’s performance. The studies focuses on the motor’s behaviour in both normal operation and under short-circuit fault conditions. A detailed comparison is made of the stator current and speed characteristics across the three phases, with the objective of assessing the motor’s performance under different shortcircuit fault scenarios and also This study implements machine learning algorithms to enhance the accuracy and reliability of short circuit fault detection, mitigating the inherent limitations of conventional diagnostic approaches

title: Retraction Notice: Object Detection and Recognition using Amazon Rekognition with Boto3
authors: Vivek Sharma
publish: 2022 6th International Conference on Trends in Electronics and Informatics (ICOEI)
abstract: In Image Processing, the problem of Object Recognition is regarded as difficult. It's an important aspect of PC vision because so many PC vision programmes rely on it for effectiveness. To address this issue, a number of identifying terminology and frameworks have been discussed for quite some time. The purpose of this paper is to give a briefoverview of a range of platforms in the field of computer vision and object recognition. For the most part this paper covers a relatively mature service from AWS(Amazon Web Services), Amazon Rekognition which is easy to integrate into other services like Lambda, providing huge volume of details in its analysis. The paper incorporates different viewpoints that have been utilized by various analysts for object spotting and recognition. Rekognition is able to recognise objects and scenarios within photographs in this article, returning a confidence measure ranging from 0 to 100% for each label returned. It accomplishes this by using AWS’ Python client Boto3 and the detect labels method. This works by supplying an image, a limit on the number of labels to return, and a confidence level for filtering out ambiguous results.

title: A Hybrid Transformer with Artificial Protozoa Optimizer Approach for Efficient Energy Management in FCHEVs
authors: Jarin T, Antony Joseph, Jyotsna E, Siddarth Rajesh
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Automation, Computing and Renewable Systems (ICACRS)
abstract: Energy Management Strategy (EMS) is important to enhance the performance, fuel economy, and lifetime of Fuel Cell Hybrid Electric Vehicles (FCHEVs). Conventional rule based and neural network based EMS fails with dynamic driving cycles, high cost of computation, and less adaptability. To address these limitations, this work presents a EMS model that integrates a Transformer model with the Artificial Protozoa Optimizer (APO). The Transformer is presented for energy demand pattern prediction by capturing long-range temporal dependencies in driving cycles and the APO is exploited for optimizing control parameters for better power allocation among the fuel cell and battery. This hybrid approach increase adaptability under uncertain traffic conditions, reduces unnecessary fuel cell load fluctuations, and improves battery life. The experimentation on standard driving cycles show that the proposed Transformer-Apo achieved superior fuel economy, improved energy utilization, and reduced error compared with existing methods. The outcomes validated that, this approach provides a robust EMS for FCHEVs and supporting the goals of sustainable and eco-friendly transportation.

title: A Bit Level Weight Reordering Strategy Based on Column Similarity to Explore Weight Sparsity in RRAM-Based NN Accelerator
authors: Weiping Yang, Shilin Zhou, Yujiao Nie, Qimin Zhou, Hui Xu, Zhiwei Li, Changlin Chen
publish: 2025 IEEE 31th International Conference on Parallel and Distributed Systems (ICPADS)
abstract: Compute-in-Memory (CIM) and weight sparsity are two effective techniques to reduce data movement during Neural Network (NN) inference. However, they can hardly be employed in the same accelerator simultaneously because CIM requires structural compute patterns which are disrupted in sparse NNs. In this paper, we partially solve this issue by proposing a bit level weight reordering strategy which can realize compact mapping of sparse NN weight matrices onto Resistive Random Access Memory (RRAM) based NN Accelerators (RRAM-Acc). In specific, when weights are mapped to RRAM crossbars in a binary complement manner, we can observe that, which can also be mathematically proven, bit-level sparsity and similarity commonly exist in the crossbars. The bit reordering method treats bit sparsity as a special case of bit similarity, reserve only one column in a pair of columns that have identical bit values, and then map the compressed weight matrices into Operation Units (OU). The performance of our design is evaluated with typical NNs. Simulation results show a 61.24 % average performance improvement and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1.51 \times-2.52 \times$</tex> energy savings under different sparsity ratios, with only slight overhead compared to the state-of-the-art design.

title: Research on DDoS Attack Detection Based on Graph Convolutional Networks
authors: Cuiyu Zhao, Qingyan Zhang, Tingting Wang, Zhihao Geng
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Automation, Electronics and Electrical Engineering (AUTEEE)
abstract: Expanding Internet/IoT deployments are producing traffic that is larger in volume and more diverse in behavior, which increases the operational risk posed by DDoS flooding and bursty attack patterns. In practice, detectors built mainly on handcrafted statistics or end-to-end neural classifiers can be sensitive to feature shifts and may underuse the relational information among traffic records. This work therefore builds a two-stage detector that couples graph representation learning with gradient-boosted decision trees: traffic samples are organized as a similarity graph, node features are updated through graph convolutions, and residual links plus a local attention unit are added to reinforce informative neighborhood signals while reducing noise propagation. The pooled graph representation is finally classified by LightGBM to obtain fast and interpretable decisions. Results on public benchmarks confirm consistent gains over common ML/DL baselines across multiple criteria, supporting the use of the proposed GCN - LightGBM design for robust DDoS detection under evolving traffic conditions.

title: Informer-BiGRU: Ultra-Long Sequence Prediction Model of Transformer Oil Temperature in New Power Systems
authors: Xinzhu Cao, Yapeng Xu
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Automation, Electronics and Electrical Engineering (AUTEEE)
abstract: With the increasing demand for ultra-long sequence operation of high-proportion renewable energy in new power systems, this paper proposes an Informer-BiGRU hybrid model focused on predicting the top oil temperature of transformers. The Informer module utilizes sparse self-attention to extract ultra-long historical features, addressing gradient vanishing and serial processing bottlenecks in RNNs. The BiGRU module bidirectionally refines abrupt change segments, suppressing phase lag in oil temperature jumps. A zero-masking weighted subnetwork filters out cooling intermittent noise. Results show that the model achieves an MAE of 0.084 and SMAPE of 0.128, comprehensively outperforming baseline methods. In local abrupt change segments, the MAE is 0.431 lower than that of LSTM, experimentally confirming the stronger error suppression and curve tracking capability of the proposed method in large fluctuation scenarios. This approach provides a new perspective for ultra-long sequence oil temperature prediction.

title: Concept Drift in Industrial Material Processing
authors: Pascal Marijan, Sebastian Igel, Tatjana Legler, Achim Wagner, Martin Ruskowski
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: Process optimization is crucial in industries with high energy demands like industrial material processing. Neural networks are commonly used for this purpose, but their performance deteriorates over time due to material wear and changes in data distribution. This study addresses these challenges by enhancing modeling, prediction, and optimization through continual learning techniques that detect and adapt to concept drift. This approach maintains model performance despite changing conditions and represents the first contribution to adaptive optimization in industrial material processing. The methodology’s effectiveness is validated with real-world data.

title: GCP-LP: A GPU-CPU Collaborative Framework for Accelerating Large-Scale Sparse Linear Programming
authors: Zi-Rui Huang, Yi-Xiang Hu, Feng Wu, Xiang-Yang Li
publish: 2025 IEEE 31th International Conference on Parallel and Distributed Systems (ICPADS)
abstract: Large-scale sparse linear programming (LP) underpins critical applications in logistics, manufacturing, and scientific computing. However, conventional CPU-only solvers often fail to meet real-time performance demands as problem sizes reach millions of variables and constraints. This paper presents GCP-LP, a GPU-CPU collaborative framework that accelerates the COIN-OR Linear Programming solver by offloading key computational bottlenecks-including sparse matrixvector multiplication (SpMV), pivot selection, and Cholesky factorization-to GPUs while retaining sequential control flow on the CPU. By combining asynchronous data transfer, GPUoptimized memory layouts, and adaptive load balancing, GCPLP achieves up to 10% module-level and 5% overall runtime reductions on NETLIB and Mittelmann benchmarks.

title: ANF-Based Satisfiability for Weil-Descent Cryptographic Attacks
authors: Anthony Blomme, Sami Cherif, Sorina Ionica, Gilles Dequen
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: In recent years, SAT solvers have been increasingly used in cryptanalysis, for performing attacks both on symmetric and asymmetric schemes. More specifically, they are employed whenever one needs to compute a valid assignment for a logical formula when running the attack. Most often, these formulae are initially represented in Algebraic Normal Form (ANF). Solvers dedicated to solving such instances translate the input formulae into a conjunction of CNF and XOR clauses and use different techniques such as XOR recovery and manipulation and Gaussian elimination. In this paper, we aim to build a solver able to reason directly on ANF formulae derived from attacks using Weil descent on Semaev polynomials of elliptic curves, while integrating dedicated lazy structures inspired from SAT solvers.

title: FedTeddi: Temporal Drift and Divergence Aware Scheduling for Timely Federated Edge Learning
authors: Yuxuan Bai, Yuxuan Sun, Tan Chen, Wei Chen, Sheng Zhou, Zhisheng Niu
publish: 2025 IEEE 31th International Conference on Parallel and Distributed Systems (ICPADS)
abstract: Federated edge learning (FEEL) enables collaborative model training across distributed clients over wireless networks without exposing raw data. While most existing studies assume static datasets, in real-world scenarios, clients may continuously collect data with time-varying and non-independent and identically distributed (non-i.i.d.) characteristics. A critical challenge is how to adapt models in a timely yet efficient manner to such evolving data. In this paper, we propose FedTeddi, a temporal-drift-and-divergence-aware scheduling algorithm that facilitates fast convergence of FEEL under dynamic data evolution and communication resource limits. We first quantify the temporal dynamics and non-i.i.d. characteristics of data using temporal drift and collective divergence, respectively, and represent them as the Earth Mover's Distance (EMD) of class distributions for classification tasks. We then propose a novel optimization objective and develop a joint scheduling and bandwidth allocation algorithm, enabling the FEEL system to learn from new data quickly without forgetting previous knowledge. Experimental results show that our algorithm achieves higher test accuracy and faster convergence compared to benchmark methods, improving the rate of convergence by 58.4% on CIFAR10 and 49.2% on CIFAR-100 compared to random scheduling.

title: Blockchain-enabled AI Collaboration
authors: Jiashuo Zhang, Yuqi Zhang, Ting Zhang, Jianbo Gao, Zhong Chen
publish: 2025 IEEE Cyber Science and Technology Congress (CyberSciTech)
abstract: As artificial intelligence (AI) systems continue to evolve, effective collaboration among data providers, model trainers, and model users has become essential for building larger-scale and more advanced AI systems. However, despite its great potential, such collaboration involves multi-party and untrusted operations in data sharing, model training, and model deployment, which inherently introduce real-world security and privacy challenges. This position paper argues that blockchain technology brings new opportunities for collaboration in AI. We first identify and characterize three key challenges in AI collaboration: secure training data sharing, trusted and incentivized model training, and traceable and accountable model distribution. We then examine how blockchain techniques, including both on-chain and off-chain approaches, can be leveraged to address these challenges. Furthermore, we discuss current practices in this emerging field and introduce open challenges for future research and real-world deployment.

title: A Study on the Impact of Ambient Light on Driver Fatigue Based on Eye-Tracking Data
authors: ChangLong Xu, Bo Wu, Hang Yi
publish: 2025 IEEE Cyber Science and Technology Congress (CyberSciTech)
abstract: Driver fatigue is one of the leading causes of traffic accidents. Among many factors that induce fatigue driving, ambient lighting is an important environmental variable. However, current research on driver fatigue mainly focuses on detection methods, and there are relatively few studies specifically investigating the relationship between ambient lighting and driver fatigue. Therefore, this study employed eye-tracking technology to explore the changes in driver fatigue states when performing simulated driving tasks under different combinations of color temperature and light. We objectively analyzed the effects of high and low illuminance, as well as high and low color temperatures, on driving fatigue through eye-tracking data, concluding that different illuminance conditions significantly impact driving fatigue. The findings provide scientific evidence for the optimization of in-vehicle lighting design, hoping to contribute to reducing the probability of traffic accidents.

title: Joint Optimization of Resource Consumption and Latency in Split Learning for Internet of Vehicles
authors: Guoli Yu, Zhou Su
publish: 2025 IEEE Cyber Science and Technology Congress (CyberSciTech)
abstract: With the integration of IoV and edge intelligence, balancing privacy and resource efficiency in dynamic environments remains a challenge. To address high latency and energy consumption in split learning caused by device and channel heterogeneity, this paper proposes a dynamic collaborative learning framework using proximal policy optimization (PPO). By formulating a multi-agent Markov decision process (MDP), it jointly optimizes model splitting, computational load allocation, and communication resource scheduling to balance latency and energy goals in time-varying scenarios. Simulations demonstrate that the approach enables efficient collaborative training among vehicles, significantly reducing latency and energy use while improving overall system performance.

title: Cauchy kernel-based maximum correntropy Kalman filter for measurement packet dropping systems
authors: Wenyan Wang, Guoming Liu, Min Zhang
publish: 2025 IEEE Cyber Science and Technology Congress (CyberSciTech)
abstract: During the data transmission process of unreliable communication networks, the measurement data of the system may be lost in the transmission process, which influences the accuracy of system state estimation and system performance. Meanwhile, in practical applications, the system is often disturbed by non-Gaussian noise, e.g., heavy-tailed impulsive noise. This paper studies the Kalman filtering problem of a class of linear discrete stochastic systems affected by the loss of system measurement quantities and non-Gaussian noise. For the state estimation using the real-time known characteristic of the packet dropping variable, Kalman filter with measurement packet dropping can be successfully derived by designing a coefficient matrix. In this study, a random variable obeying the Bernoulli distribution with a known conditional probability is introduced to describe the randomly occurring phenomenon of the loss of system measurement quantities, and the maximum correntropy Kalman filtering algorithm based on the Cauchy kernel is adopted for state estimation. Finally, the effectiveness and robustness of the proposed algorithm are validated by the simulation results of vehicle tracking.

title: Fine-Grained State Sharding and Communication Pipelining for Partially Sharded Data Parallelism
authors: Weimin Li, Yuzhong Sun, Lin Meng
publish: 2025 IEEE 31th International Conference on Parallel and Distributed Systems (ICPADS)
abstract: Partially sharded data parallel (PSDP) reduces GPU memory footprint in data-parallel training without incurring additional communication overhead. Existing work on PSDP has primarily focused on minimizing memory consumption, such as by offloading model states to CPU, while not enough attention has been paid to poor communication performance. We observe that the imbalanced distribution of model states across GPUs and inter-layer data dependencies lead to severe underutilization of network bandwidth and poor scalability of the current PSDP system. To address these issues, we present Chimera, a system that enhances the communication efficiency of PSDP in both offloading and non-offloading settings. First, Chimera introduces a fine-grained state-sharding strategy to balance both model state and communication load across GPUs, while leveraging tensor fusion to amortize communication launch overhead. Second, we design a multi-stage, fine-grained communication pipelining mechanism that decouples inter-layer dependencies, thereby improving bandwidth utilization. Finally, we develop a practical auto-tuning tensor fusion algorithm to adaptively optimize fusion decisions for end-to-end training performance. We evaluate Chimera on cloud GPU clusters using representative large language models. Experimental results demonstrate that Chimera improves training throughput by <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1.1 \times$</tex> to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1.8 \times$</tex> over state-of-theart PSDP systems.

title: Multi-UAV Smoke-Screen Scheduling Optimization: A Simulation-Based Framework Integrating Coarse-to-Fine Search and Genetic Algorithms
authors: Jiahao Kong
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Automation, Electronics and Electrical Engineering (AUTEEE)
abstract: This paper presents a simulation-based decision optimization framework for smoke-screen munition deployment that maximizes effective occlusion against an incoming missile. The method integrates a three-phase kinematic model, a missile-centric coordinate transformation, and a geometry-aware occlusion test based on projection–inclusion with ray-gridded silhouettes and time discretization. Strategy synthesis is cast as optimization: a coarse-to-fine grid search solves the single-UAV/single-munition case, while a decoupled genetic algorithm addresses multi-UAV coordination under high-dimensional coupling. Across representative scenarios, the framework achieves effective occlusion times of 1.392 s (baseline), 4.60 s (optimized single munition), 6.24 s (single UAV with three munitions), and 10.518 s (three UAVs, one munition each), demonstrating efficiency, robustness, and interpretable schedules. The resulting approach provides a generalizable, simulation-ready tool for time-critical countermeasure planning and cross-scenario deployment.

title: A Universal and Dynamically Aware Multi-Attack Adversarial Patch Generation Framework
authors: Yiwen Wang, Sheng Cao, Xiaosong Zhang
publish: 2025 IEEE 31th International Conference on Parallel and Distributed Systems (ICPADS)
abstract: The security of vision-language pre-trained models (VLMs) has become an increasingly critical concern, particularly due to their vulnerability to adversarial attacks in open environments. Most existing methods focus on image perturbations, ignoring image-text structural relationships and the need for dynamic, semantics-aware attack strategies. To address these limitations, we propose a dynamically adaptive framework for generating multi-behavior adversarial patches. A topological neighborhood graph models cross-modal semantic structures, while a lightweight text classifier detects sensitive or jailbreak instructions to switch attack strategies. A two-stage optimization-semantic stripping and target binding-precisely controls perturbations for target-specific outputs. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method achieves high attack success rates across a variety of tasks, including image-text retrieval, image classification, and multimodal question answering. Moreover, the approach exhibits strong robustness and adaptability, exposing critical security vulnerabilities in current VLM systems and offering valuable insights for future research on the defense of multimodal models.

title: Solving the time-optimal control problem for nonlinear non-autonomous linearizable systems*
authors: K. V. Sklyar, S. Yu. Ignatovich, G. M. Sklyar
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: We present conditions under which the time-optimal control problem for a nonlinear non-autonomous linearizable system can be solved by the method of successive approximations, at each step of which a power Markov moment min-problem is solved. The proposed method can be efficiently implemented by use of symbolic and numerical calculations.

title: Comparative Analysis of Sawtooth and Triangular PWM Techniques for Buck Chopper Applications
authors: Fezazi Omar, Jaouher Chrouta, Aymen Lachheb
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: A detailed comparative analysis of sawtooth and triangular carrier pulse-width modulation (PWM) techniques for buck chopper systems is presented in this study. The research addresses the need for empirical performance evaluation in motor control applications by systematically examining critical operational parameters, including speed regulation, torque stability, and current dynamics. MATLAB/Simulink is employed for system modeling and simulation, while real-time validation is conducted using RTLAB to ensure practical applicability. The results demonstrate that both techniques achieve fast dynamic response, with overshoot limited to less than $\mathbf{1 6} \boldsymbol{\%}$ and settling time maintained below 0.2 seconds during speed transitions. However, distinct performance characteristics are observed. Superior steady-state performance is exhibited by the sawtooth carrier method, with current oscillations reduced by approximately 30% and torque ripple lowered by 25% compared to the triangular approach, making it particularly suitable for precision applications. In contrast, marginally faster transient response is provided by the triangular carrier, though higher electromagnetic interference is generated due to more pronounced current fluctuations. These findings offer clear selection criteria for engineers based on application priorities, whether for high-precision systems requiring smooth operation or scenarios where rapid response is prioritized. The study contributes to power electronics optimization by establishing validated performance benchmarks and practical implementation guidelines for buck chopper control strategies.

title: Illumination Robust UAV Object Detection via Noise Aware Downsampling and Contextual Feature Fusion
authors: Xinyue Cai, Kang Li
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Automation, Electronics and Electrical Engineering (AUTEEE)
abstract: Object detection in Unmanned Aerial Vehicle (UAV) imagery remains challenging under nighttime conditions due to severe illumination degradation, low contrast, and dense small objects. To address these issues, we propose a framework specifically designed for nighttime UAV object detection. Instead of relying on separate image enhancement stages, the proposed framework enhances feature robustness and multi-scale consistency directly within the detection pipeline. We introduce a Denoise Downsample Layer (D2L) that adaptively suppresses illumination induced noise while preserving fine structural details and a Global Spatial Attention Fusion (GSAF) module that integrates hierarchical features through global contextual and spatial modeling. These designs jointly improve the discriminability of object features and the stability of detection under complex low-light conditions. Extensive experiments on the VisVehicle dataset demonstrate that our method achieves superior detection accuracy with minimal computational cost.

title: Few-Cycle Pulse Driven Terahertz Generation in Organic Crystals for THz–XUV Pump-Probe
authors: Abhishek Gupta, Tianmio Zhang, Prabhash Prasannan Geetha, Balázs Nagyillés, Balázs Farkas, Andor Körmöczi, Szabolcs Tóth, Vineet Gupta, Ashutosh Sharma, János Csontos, Zsolt Divéki, József A. Fülöp
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: Here, we report THz pulse generation in the organic crystals MNA and BNA in a previously unexplored regime with few-cycle near-infrared pump pulses. Fourier limited pump pulses of 13 fs duration generated the largest bandwidth of 5.5 THz. Negatively chirped pump pulses with a group-delay dispersion of −1200 fs<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> (MNA) and −800 fs<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> (BNA) gave the highest THz pulse energies, 2 to 3 times higher than the Fourier limited pulses. The THz source is scalable to multi-MV/cm extreme field strengths and can be implemented in attosecond XUV beamlines for a new class of pump-probe studies.

title: Lorentzian-Constrained Holographic Beamforming Optimization in Multi-user Networks with Dynamic Metasurface Antennas
authors: Askin Altinoklu, Leila Musavian
abstract: Dynamic metasurface antennas (DMAs) are promising alternatives to fully digital (FD) architectures, enabling hybrid beamforming via low-cost reconfigurable metasurfaces. In DMAs, holographic beamforming is achieved through tunable elements by Lorentzian-constrained holography (LCH), significantly reducing the need for radio-frequency (RF) chains and analog circuitry. However, the Lorentzian constraints and limited RF chains introduce a trade-off between reduced system complexity and beamforming performance, especially in dense network scenarios. This paper addresses resource allocation in multi-user multiple-input-single-output (MISO) networks under the Signal-to-Interference-plus-Noise Ratio (SINR) constraints, aiming to minimize total transmit power. We propose a holographic beamforming algorithm based on the Generalized Method of Lorentzian-Constrained Holography (GMLCH), which optimizes DMA weights, yielding flexibility for using various LCH techniques to tackle the aforementioned trade-offs. Building upon GMLCH, we further propose a new algorithm i.e., Adaptive Radius Lorentzian Constrained Holography (ARLCH), which achieves optimization of DMA weights with additional degree of freedom in a greater optimization space, and provides lower transmitted power, while improving scalability for higher number of users. Numerical results show that ARLCH reduces power consumption by over 20% compared to benchmarks, with increasing effectiveness as the number of users grows.

title: High-harmonic emission from infrared free-electron laser FELBE
authors: Alexej Pashkin, Xiaoxiao Sun, J. Michael Klopf, Ulf Lehnert, Stephan Winnerl, Manfred Helm
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: We report high-harmonics in the emission spectrum of an infrared free-electron laser. For the fundamental frequency of 16.5 THz harmonics up to 28th order are detected. Interestingly, in addition to integer odd and even harmonics of n<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">th</sup> order we observe fractional harmonics. Operation at 5.4 THz produces harmonics up to 75<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">th</sup> order.

title: Near-Field Radiated from an Overmoded Corrugated Waveguide
authors: D. Wagner, F. Leuterer, H. Schütz, J. Stober, M. Thumm
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: Modern Electron Cyclotron Resonance Heating (ECRH) systems in Nuclear Fusion Devices employ high-power gyrotrons operating in the millimeter wave frequency range. Typical output powers are at or above 1 MW with pulse lengths of several seconds up to continuous wave (CW). Low-loss transmission can be achieved by optical transmission via reflecting metallic mirrors or with corrugated waveguides employing the low-loss HE<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">11</inf> mode. In case of waveguide transmission lines, the Gaussian-like beam ejected from the gyrotron is coupled to the waveguide via a set of beam conditioning mirrors. Similarly, at the output of the transmission line, the beam is radiated from the open-ended waveguide via focusing mirrors to the launching antenna. This is possible due to the excellent coupling of the HE<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">11</inf> mode to the Gaussian free-space TEM<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">00</inf> mode. However, near field focusing effects cannot be neglected, since the applied quasi-optical mirrors are all placed within the near field region. This holds especially for CW systems, where cooling of mirror surfaces can become critical. Near-field focusing effects are investigated both numerically and experimentally.

title: Research on Deep Learning-Based Methods for Pharmaceutical Packaging Classification and Detection
authors: Dongliang Fang, Xinliang Ye, Liguo Dong, Peng Zhao, Enze Zhang
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Big Data, Artificial Intelligence and Internet of Things Engineering (ICBAIE)
abstract: With the rapid increase in the variety and volume of pharmaceutical products, along with rising standards for medical service quality, traditional drug management approaches have become insufficient to meet hospitals’ demands for dispensing efficiency. To address this limitation, this paper proposes a deep learning-based method for drug package classification and detection. First, through a comparative evaluation of two classical models–ResNet and VGG–and in consideration of the project’s specific requirements, ResNet was selected as the core model due to its compact architecture, faster training convergence, and superior recognition accuracy. Subsequently, the model was deployed locally and integrated into a graphical user interface (GUI) to enable intuitive visual interaction. Finally, the proposed method was validated using both static images and dynamic video streams under local testing conditions. Experimental results demonstrate that the approach can accurately identify and classify multiple common types of medications. It offers user-friendly operation, stable recognition performance, and adaptability to diverse application scenarios, highlighting its significant practical potential.

title: Interface Segmentation Approach (InSeAp) on TCAD for Statistical Analysis of Interface Trap Spatial Variations in TFETs
authors: Anirudh Koteshwar, Shanidul Hoque, Deepjyoti Deb, Rupam Goswami
abstract: This work proposes a methodology to conduct statistical analyses of variation in spatial location and concentration of gate oxide/ semiconductor interface traps taking the example of a p-i-n silicon-on-insulator (SOI) tunnelling field-effect transistor (TFET). The methodology involves simulation of a total of 800 instances of devices leading to evaluation of variability in key electrical metrics, such as ON and OFF current, maximum band-to-band tunneling (BTBT) rate, maximum electron velocity, and threshold voltage. The approach uses an interface segmentation approach (InSeAp) on TCAD tool using which the trap placement at the oxide/ semiconductor is localized to 2 nm segments. Such segments are then assessed based on their placement in (a) within the high BTBT region, and (b) outside the high BTBT region. The methodology is validated using parametric and non-parametric statistical tests (two-sided paired t-test, Wilcoxon signed-rank test, two-sided binomial test) along with coefficient of variation (CoV).

title: High-throughput extraction of refractive indices in THz reflection imaging
authors: Sen Mou, Shreeya Rane, Rayko I. Stantchev, Xiangyu Guo, Huiliang Ou, Sonal Saxena, Sophie L. Pain, John D. Murphy, Euan Hendry, James Lloyd-Hughes, Emma Pickwell-MacPherson
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: Terahertz (THz) light holds significant promise for the nondestructive spectroscopy of biological tissues. Recent advances in THz single-pixel imaging have further enhanced this potential, paving the way for applications that evaluate in real-time. Here we show how reflection spectroscopy can be combined with THz total reflection single-pixel imaging to achieve fast refractive index mapping. This innovation opens up new possibilities for extracting detailed images of biological tissues in the reflection geometry.

title: Optimizing Emergency Department Patient Flow Forecasting: A Hybrid VAE-GRU Model
authors: Amel Zidi, Rayen Jmili, Issam Nouaouri, Ines Ben Jaafar
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: Emergency departments (EDs) face increasing patient demand, leading to overcrowding and resource strain. Accurate forecasting of ED visits is critical for optimizing hospital operations and ensuring efficient resource allocation. This paper proposes a hybrid model combining Variational Autoencoder (VAE) and Gated Recurrent Unit (GRU) to enhance patient flow predictions. The VAE extracts meaningful latent features while handling missing data, whereas the GRU captures complex temporal dependencies, improving forecasting accuracy. Compared to traditional models such as LSTM, GRU, and 1D CNN, our hybrid VAE-GRU model demonstrates superior predictive performance. Experimental results, based on real-world hospital data, highlight the model’s effectiveness in reducing prediction errors and improving decision-making in dynamic ED environments. Additionally, we compare the proposed model with ARIMA-ML, emphasizing the tradeoffs between computational efficiency and prediction accuracy. The findings suggest that hybrid deep learning approaches can significantly enhance healthcare resource management, reducing patient waiting times and improving overall hospital efficiency.

title: Novel Approximate Data Bus Inversion Design with Enhanced Majority Detection Accuracy
authors: Raein Lee, Yeongkyo Seo
abstract: Data bus inversion (DBI) reduces energy consumption by minimizing data transitions between the current and previous data. However, conventional DBI tends to cause significant hardware overhead, primarily due to the complex majority voter in the DBI encoder. In low switching cost applications, the energy overhead caused by high hardware complexity can exceed the energy savings achieved by the DBI technique. To reduce high hardware complexity for enabling the use of DBI even in applications with low switching cost, a DBI encoder employing the AOI-AOI approximate majority voter has been proposed. However, AOI-AOI suffers from low accuracy in determining the majority decision. To address this issue, we propose a novel approximate majority voter which improves the accuracy of majority decision while maintaining low hardware complexity. As a result, our proposed DBI encoder with the improved approximate majority decision achieves a higher switching activity reduction of 10.75% than that of AOI-AOI (10.39<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">%</sup>). In addition, compared to the accurate DBI encoder, the proposed encoder reduces delay by > 31 %, area by > 17%, and power consumption by > 32%.

title: Mini CAM-Based Redundancy Architecture for Reducing Area Overhead
authors: Junwoo Gwak, Hayoung Lee
abstract: This paper proposes a mini-CAM-based memory repair architecture that reduces fault analysis time and hardware overhead while maintaining a high repair rate. By compactly storing fault data and distributing CAM entries across memory blocks, the proposed approach minimizes contention and supports a scalable design. A priority-based spare allocation algorithm further improves the overall repair rate by utilizing spatial fault locality.

title: A Precompensation-Based Active Disturbance Rejection Control Design for a Class of High-Order Plus Time-Delay Processes
authors: Zhenlong Wu, Zihao Li, Yanhong Liu, Sen Chen, YangQuan Chen
abstract: For high-order plus time-delay (HOPTD) processes characterized by the <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\boldsymbol{K{{e}^{-\tau s}}/{{\left(Ts + 1\right)}^{n}}}$</tex-math> </inline-formula>-type high-order dynamics, active disturbance rejection control (ADRC) frequently encounters numerous limitations in control performance and parameter tuning. To overcome these challenges, this article proposes a precompensation-based active disturbance rejection control (PADRC) design method. PADRC enhances the regular ADRC structure by feeding the control signal into the controlled plant through a precompensation part. The stability of the proposed PADRC is theoretically analyzed, and it is demonstrated that the estimation error of the designed extended state observer (ESO) and the regulation error of the proposed PADRC exhibit bounded characteristics. To enhance the convenience and operability in practical engineering applications, the quantitative parameter tuning rules of the proposed PADRC for <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\boldsymbol{K/{{\left(Ts + 1\right)}^{n}}}$</tex-math> </inline-formula>-type high-order processes are elaborately derived. Subsequently, the quantitative parameter tuning rules of the proposed PADRC for HOPTD processes are further extended. Comparative simulation experiments indicate that the proposed PADRC exhibits the optimal control performance with superior robustness. Ultimately, field tests conducted on the reheat steam temperature (RST) process of the power plant further corroborate its practical value and potential.

title: Distributionally Robust Control with Constraints on Linear Unidimensional Projections
authors: Alexandros E. Tzikas, Lukas Fiechtner, Arec Jamgochian, Mykel J. Kochenderfer
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: Distributionally robust control is a well-studied framework for optimal decision making under uncertainty, with the objective of minimizing an expected cost function over control actions, assuming the most adverse probability distribution from an ambiguity set. We consider an interpretable and expressive class of ambiguity sets defined by constraints on the expected value of functions of one-dimensional linear projections of the uncertain parameters. Prior work has shown that, under conditions, problems in this class can be reformulated as finite convex problems. In this work, we propose two iterative methods that can be used to approximately solve problems of this class in the general case. The first is an approximate algorithm based on best-response dynamics. The second is an approximate method that first reformulates the problem as a semi-infinite program and then solves a relaxation. We apply our methods to portfolio construction and trajectory planning scenarios.
