title: Deep Orientational Representation Learning for Ordinal Regression
authors: Gengyun Jia, Xin Ma, Bing-Kun Bao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Pattern Analysis and Machine Intelligence
abstract: Ordinal regression aims to predict ordered classes. Existing methods mainly focus on label distribution shapes and feature distance relationships, while the directional characteristics in the representation space remain underexplored. In this paper, we propose deep orientational representation learning (ORL), aiming to ensure the trajectory of features sequentially connected by ordinal categories approximates a geodesic. We treat the output layer weights as ordinal prototypes and introduce two constraints, the co-directional constraint and the counter-directional constraint. They operate by constraining the angles between pairs of vectors. The former minimizes the angle between vectors with matching start and end categories, while the latter maximizes the angle between vectors whose start categories are the same but whose end categories are on opposite sides. The two constraints optimize the representation from different ordinal directions. ORL is extended to a multi-prototype setting (MORL) to mitigate misalignment between features and oriented prototypes caused by large intra-class variations. Theoretical analysis links ORL to distribution unimodality and distance orderliness, highlighting its advantages. The effectiveness of ORL (MORL) is demonstrated on various tasks including facial age estimation, historical image dating, and aesthetic quality assessment.

title:
Neuroidentifier for a class of nonlinear systems: A Sliding Modes approach
                    <sup>*</sup>
authors: Alejandro Guarneros-Sandoval, Mariana Ballesteros, Isaac Chairez
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: This article focuses on designing a neural identifier for non-linear systems using an Integral Sliding Mode (ISM) approach. A Differential Neural Network (DNN) structure identifies a non-linear system; meanwhile, the learning laws for stabilizing the identification error are obtained from the Lyapunov Stability analysis. An integral sliding surface is proposed to provide the convergence of the system identifier weights to the ideals to approximate the non-linear system. The results for identifying the Van Der Poll Oscillator and the Inverted Pendulum show better identification error reduction performance than a traditional DNN.

title: An Integrated Machine Learning Pipeline for Time-Critical Decision Making and Anomaly Detection
authors: Jiajia Ma
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Automation, Electronics and Electrical Engineering (AUTEEE)
abstract: This paper proposes an end-to-end, modular, and scalable machine learning computational framework/pipeline for selecting specific indicators at specific points in time and identifying anomalies. It supports decision optimization and precise identification through algorithmic integration and process-oriented design. The framework is organized as follows: "data preprocessing—nonlinear effect modeling—population stratification—two-stage temporal optimization—anomaly detection and interpretation": First, Spearman's rank correlation analysis validates variable relationships. Subsequently, generalized additive models (GAMs) employing thin-plate regression splines and generalized cross-validation are constructed to capture nonlinear and interactive relationships among key factors, yielding significantly improved model fit compared to linear regression. Second, a two-stage strategy is adopted for rational grouping and optimal timing determination: K-Means was first applied for unsupervised grouping of key features (cluster number determined via the elbow method). Within the candidate time window, a risk-weighted decision criterion was constructed to compare expected risks across different time points and examine the impact of detection errors on timing stability. Subsequently, random forests were introduced to quantify multi-factor importance, combined with hierarchical clustering to refine groupings, thereby enhancing the interpretability and consistency of timing decisions. Experiments validate the framework's effectiveness using fit and classification metrics (R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>, AUC, ROC curves, confusion matrices) under unified data partitioning and evaluation protocols, while identifying primary influencing features. Results demonstrate that this pipeline provides an integrated, reusable computational pathway for timing selection and anomaly detection under heterogeneous and nonlinear conditions.

title: Real-Time Arterial PPG-Waveform Quality Assessment Using FPGA-Based 1D Depthwise Separable CNN
authors: Se-Hwan Yang, Dae-Il Kim, Ji-Yong Um
publish: 2025 IEEE Biomedical Circuits and Systems Conference (BioCAS)
abstract: This paper presents a real-time quality assessment system for arterial photoplethysmography (PPG) waveforms using a hardware-efficient 1D convolutional neural network (CNN). Carotid PPG signals are highly sensitive to sensor placement, often leading to morphological distortions and degraded signal quality. To address this issue, a depthwise separable 1D CNN was designed and implemented on an FPGA to classify signal quality in real time. The model architecture was optimized through grid search, and fixedpoint quantization was applied to minimize memory usage. Additionally, sequential accumulation techniques were employed to reduce computational overhead. The analog frontend was constructed using commercial components, while the digital inference machine was implemented in Verilog HDL on an FPGA (Artix-7, Xilinx). Experimental results show an inference accuracy of 94.8% and an $F 1$-score of 94.6%, with 50.3% DSP utilization. Real-time tests confirm the system’s ability to adaptively assess signal quality in response to sensor positioning. The proposed system offers a compact and intelligent solution for reliable PPG acquisition and supports future applications such as carotid arterial compliance estimation.

title: Smart Crop Guard: AI-Enabled Wildlife & Adaptive Deterrence System for Agricultural
authors: Bhargav Prajwal Pathri, Praveen Kumar Akula, Krishna Vamshi Ganduri, Nikhith Reddy Shivaramanagari, Ganesh Naik Lakavathu, Rishiraj Kagitoju
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Automation, Computing and Renewable Systems (ICACRS)
abstract: This paper presents an innovative automated animal deterrent system designed to mitigate the multifaceted challenges posed by wildlife intrusion in agricultural and protected areas. Animal intrusion extends beyond mere crop damage, encompassing critical issues such as food safety risks from fecal contamination, predation on livestock, and the potential for disease transmission between wildlife, domestic animals, and humans. Traditional deterrent methods often prove inadequate due to animal habituation and can pose environmental hazards. The proposed system employs a sophisticated multi-sensor architecture, integrating radar for initial wide-area motion detection and thermal imaging for precise animal verification. A Raspberry Pi serves as the central processing unit, leveraging artificial intelligence (AI) for real-time data analysis and orchestrating adaptive, targeted deterrence responses using acoustic and visual stimuli. Designed for energy independence through solar power and battery storage, the system is suitable for remote deployments. This report details the system's architecture, operational flow, and addresses key technical considerations, including strategies to overcome animal habituation and minimize false positives, thereby promoting effective human-wildlife coexistence through non-lethal means.

title:
Emission of Terahertz Radiation by Optically Excited Infrared-Active Phonons in Layered Compounds MRe(MoO
                    <sub>4</sub>
                    )
                    <sub>2</sub>
authors: Dmytro Kamenskyi, Kirill Vasin, Lilian Prodan, Khrystyna Kutko, Volodymyr Khrustalyov, Sergey G. Pavlov, Heinz-Wilhelm Hübers
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: The generation of monochromatic terahertz (THz) electromagnetic radiation remains a critical task for many current and future THz applications. Recently, we have demonstrated the emission of monochromatic sub-THz radiation by optical phonons in the dielectric material KY(MoO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">4</inf>)<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>. We are now extending our study to other materials in the MRe(MoO4)2 family, where Re stands for rare earth ions and M for an alkali ion.The layered crystallographic structure of these materials causes infrared-active lattice vibrations with the energies below 3.7 meV, corresponding to frequencies below 900 GHz, where solid-state monochromatic radiation sources are rare. Changing the Re<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3+</sup> in the chemical composition enables more than 10 percent tunability of the optical phonon frequencies.After broadband excitations by 5 ps THz pulses, infrared active optical phonons in MRe(MoO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">4</inf>)<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> emit narrowband sub-THz radiation as a time-varying dipole for tens of picoseconds, which is exceptionally long for oscillators with frequencies below 1 THz. Such a long coherent emission allows the detection of more than 50 periods of radiation at frequencies of 568 and 860 GHz. The remarkably long decay time, together with the chemical stability of materials used, suggest a variety of possible applications in THz technology.

title: Frame Generation in the Web Browser for Alternative Object Angles
authors: Victor Vlad, Sabin C. Buraga
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: Modern Web development, particularly in the domain of multimedia processing and video analysis, increasingly emphasizes leveraging general JavaScript programming and, more specifically, the TensorFlow platform to transition traditionally server-based machine learning applications to the Web browser. This approach places a strong emphasis on optimizing real-time performance and front-end responsiveness. The research presents a pipeline that recognizes objects in video footage and seamlessly replaces them with corresponding 3D objects, enabling the scene to be efficiently re-rendered from alternative angles. Additionally, performance considerations are discussed.

title: A 220GHz-band Multi-beam Phased Array Antenna
authors: Zhu Zhongbo, Hu Weidong, Li Sheng, Shao Wei, Wang Caixia
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: Terahertz (THz) technology can provide high-speed communication capabilities, making it one of the most promising candidates for future mobile communications. However, due to limitations in multi-beamforming capabilities, it currently cannot achieve multi-node networking and interconnection, significantly restricting the application of THz-based network communication. This paper presents a 220GHz-band multi-beam phased array antenna capable of simultaneously providing three communication beams. Utilizing this antenna, the authors successfully demonstrated terahertz networking communication among four nodes, achieving a data rate of 25 Gbps and enabling real-time transmission of high-definition video.

title: Surface Wave Source with a Multistage Depressed Collector - Designing a High-Power THz Source
authors: I.V. Konoplev, A.J. MacLachlan, L. Zhang, L. Young, C. Rowley, E. Bartley, K. Ronald, A.D.R. Phelps, H. Lewtas
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: Terahertz (THz) radiation, encompassing millimetre/submillimetre wavelengths (0.3THz-10THz), is one of the most desirable ranges of electromagnetic (EM) radiation. While sources capable of generating coherent THz radiation are continuously developing and subjects of exciting R&D programs, a significant frequency band from approximately 0.5THz to 5THz is still practically unbridged, with only occasional "steppingstones" appearing to support a limited number of research and industrial applications. This is specifically true for high power (>100W) compact and energy efficient (> 10%) sources of THz radiation. The project, stimulated by market research conducted and led by UKAEA, is to explore opportunities to construct high efficient (>10%) THz source potentially capable of generating >100W of coherent THz radiation (0.5 THz to 5 THz) in pulsed and CW regimes. The results of the market research based on more than 20 interviews will be also presented and discussed.

title: The cybernetics between IRMMW-THz Science and IRMM-THz Astronomy
authors: Mattheus Thijs de Graauw
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: Fifty years ago, the IR to MM wavelength range was the last remaining part of the electromagnetic spectrum to observe the universe. The technology available at that time was modest, but sufficient to allow initial observations, the results of which encouraged further development. Since there were few practical/commercial applications, funding was scarce and initially had to come from the budgets of the interested scientific fields. They took advantage of every result of the scientific and technical developments and in turn stimulated them by giving directions and goals. Here I report on a science driven project where the creative efforts of an outstanding set of engineers and scientists managed to develop in a short period, a variety of technologies, from a proof-of-concept level to space qualification, resulting in a world-class instrument that produced a wealth of scientific results.

title: A comprehensive review of Network Design in a Sustainable Supply Chain: Focus on the social dimension
authors: Yves Gouret, Ilhem Slama, Evren Sahin, Zied Jemai
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: Amid growing concerns over the environmental and social impacts of supply chains, sustainable network design has become a key focus in both research and practice. This paper presents a comprehensive review of 184 publications on network design in sustainable supply chains. We explore how sustainability dimensions, especially the often-overlooked social aspect, are integrated into network design decisions. The review categorizes the main modeling approaches, objectives, and uncertainty considerations, and highlights emerging trends such as circular economy and responsible sourcing. Finally, we identify research gaps and outline future directions, with a particular emphasis on enhancing the social sustainability of supply chain networks.

title: AETNet: A lightweight CNN-Transformer hybrid architecture for the diagnosis of eight ophthalmic diseases from fundus images
authors: Weiju Huang, Ming Zhang, Qi Chen, Jia He
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Big Data, Artificial Intelligence and Internet of Things Engineering (ICBAIE)
abstract: The automated detection of ophthalmic diseases from analyzing fundus imagery is essential for timely diagnostic processes and intervention to prevent vision loss. To address the challenges of multi-class disease diagnosis, this paper proposes AETNet, a novel lightweight and efficient hybrid architecture, evaluated on the ODIR-5K dataset. The model utilizes EfficientNet-B0 as its backbone, integrating an Atrous Spatial Pyramid Pooling (ASPP) module to derive features across multiple scales. The Efficient Channel Attention (ECA) module for channel-wise feature refinement. Its core design enhances the features from EfficientNet-B0 using the ASPP and ECA modules, then transforms them into sequential input for a lightweight TinyTransformer encoder. This process achieves a deep interaction between local textures and global context. For the eight-class classification task on the ODIR-5K dataset, AETNet achieved performance metrics of $97.71 \%$ for accuracy, $94.97 \%$ for sensitivity, $96.48 \%$ for specificity, and an AUC of $88.93 \%$.The proposed model significantly outperforms several baseline CNN models, demonstrating the effectiveness and advanced performance of this hybrid architecture for complex, multi-class classification of ophthalmic images.

title: Optimized SEC-OLS Code Architecture for Enhanced Area, Delay, and Power Efficiency
authors: Sayan Tripathi, Jhilam Jana, Jaydeb Bhaumik
publish: 2025 5th IEEE International Conference on Applied Electromagnetics, Signal Processing, &amp; Communication (AESPC)
abstract: The implementation of error detection and correction mechanisms play an important role for preserving data integrity in storage systems requiring high operational reliability. This work introduces a novel $(24,16)$ Single Error Correction OLS (SEC-OLS) code based on optimized H-matrix construction that simplify encoding and decoding while enhancing efficiency. ASIC synthesis results show that proposed scheme achieves up to 30.37% area, 24.18% delay, and 12.07% power reductions compared to Demirci et al., along with improvements of 26.27% in area, 14.15% in delay, and 2.24% in power over Tripathi et al.. Our scheme also outperforms Xiao et al. across all metrics. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed SEC-OLS code provides an effective trade-off between fault tolerance, hardware efficiency, and energy savings, making it highly suitable for next-generation memory and storage systems.

title: Spintronic Terahertz Emitters with Integrated Metallic Terahertz Cavities
authors: M. Mičica, A. Wright, P. Koleják, G. Lezier, K. Postava, J. Hawecker, A. De Vetter, J. Tignon, J. Mangeney, H. Jaffres, R. Lebrun, N. Tiercelin, M. Vanwolleghem, S. Dhillon
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: To enhance the THz efficiency of ferromagnetic/metal spintronic emitters on a selected THz spectral range, FM/HM structures are realized on ultra-thin sapphire substrates with a metallic mirror to create λ/4 THz resonant cavities. Emission time domain terahertz spectroscopy of these Spintronic emitter/sapphire/mirror heterostructures, with sapphire thicknesses ranging from 100 to 25 μm, shows enhancement of the emitted THz field that fits the λ/4 cavity resonance and simulations of the temporal response.

title: Precision Optimisation of Optimal Detection Timing for NIPT Based on the KMEP-KAP-MCS Algorithm
authors: Zhicai Li, Yuzhe Sun
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Automation, Electronics and Electrical Engineering (AUTEEE)
abstract: Non-invasive prenatal testing (NIPT) serves as the gold standard for preventing births of fetuses with chromosomal abnormalities. The precision of the testing window directly impacts diagnostic accuracy—adopting a fixed testing window that disregards individual variations in maternal BMI and age may lead to missed diagnoses, resulting in births of fetuses with chromosomal abnormalities and imposing significant physiological, psychological, and financial burdens on families. To address this issue, this study proposes the KMEP-KAP-MCS algorithm (where KMEP denotes the optimized K-means clustering algorithm, KAP employs linear Kaplan-Meier survival analysis, and MCS refers to Monte Carlo sensitivity analysis). This algorithm constructs a three-tiered ensemble framework of ‘grouping-Optimisation-validation’ to achieve precise and personalized timing of testing. By weighting the K-Means algorithm with probability distributions and integrating core features—BMI (weight 0.6), age (weight 0.4), and WHO weight classification standards—pregnant women are stratified into four categories, achieving high-quality stratification. For each group, a ‘gestational week versus cumulative pass rate’ model is established to determine optimal individualized testing timepoints across different BMI cohorts, achieving 100% event detection rates across all groups. Under dataset constraints, the three-group classification model underwent validation through 5,000 Monte Carlo simulations. Results confirmed the algorithm's robustness, providing reliable technical support for personalized non-invasive prenatal testing tailored to maternal weight and age.

title: Conceptualization, modeling and simulation for 3D printed modular hand prosthesis
authors: Vasil Lozanov, Radoslav Vasilev, Maya Staikova, Nayden Chivarov
abstract: A way to design, model and simulate stress in wrist prostheses is presented in our study. Large-Scale computational modeling was performed to predict the mechanical performance of parts under different loading conditions, modeling different use cases. Virtual stress testing commonly identifies failure points during simulation. Data captured during a test like this, can be used by designers to perform follow-on design changes, material selection choices, and structural tuning. This method could help a great deal with the creation of less expensive prostheses that were more durable and functional than typical manufacturing. The final design balances performance demands and accessibility, which may extend prosthetic accessibility in underdeveloped areas. The material was the most difficult thing to decide on because everything seemed more important than anything else.

title: Real-Time, Mobile Terahertz Computed Tomography
authors: Marcel Andree, Miguel Heredia Conde, Ullrich Pfeiffer
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: This paper presents the comparison of three different algorithms used for data evaluation in a real-time terahertz computed tomography system (THz-CT) for volumetric THz imaging. The imaging system comprises a source array operating at 420 GHz with up to 20 mW output power and a compact, battery-operated, hand-held THz camera, which are arranged in a transmission mode imaging system with a 29 mm × 29 mm object plane and a resolution < 1.5 mm. 3D image reconstruction has been performed after measuring the sinogram of a custom-made G1/4″ Whitworth pipe thread metal nut during a continuous 180° rotation. A filtered back-projection algorithm (FBP) and regularized least squares algorithms using elastic net (EN) and total variation (TV) penalty functions have been used for data postprocessing, demonstrating reconstruction times of 65 ms (FBP), 280 ms (EN) and 1.64 s (TV). To the best of the author’s knowledge, this is the first time a hand-held terahertz computed tomography system offers real-time operation with a sub-second 3D-image reconstruction time combining 677 ms acquisition and 65 ms postprocessing time.

title: Old Photo Restoration with Diffusion Models via Contrastive Learning
authors: Weiguang Lv, Hao Wu, Guowu Yuan, Dirui Ming
publish: 2025 IEEE 31th International Conference on Parallel and Distributed Systems (ICPADS)
abstract: Old photo restoration is a challenging task due to diverse and compound degradations, complex structural damage, and the lack of real paired training data. To address these issues, we present a novel diffusion-based framework that integrates contrastive learning and frequency-aware modeling to effectively restore old photographs. Specifically, we design a category-guided contrastive encoder to align the latent distributions of synthetic and real old photos, effectively bridging the domain gap. Based on this aligned latent space, a diffusion model is employed to iteratively generate high-quality restorations with strong semantic and structural consistency. Additionally, we introduce a Discrete Cosine Histogram Attention (DCH) block to jointly capture structured (e.g., holes, scratches, blotches) and unstructured (e.g., noise, blur, fading, low resolution) degradations in the frequency domain. Without relying on real paired data, our method generalizes well to real-world old photos. Extensive experiments demonstrate that our approach consistently outperforms state-of-the-art methods in both synthetic and real-world scenarios. The code is available at https://github.com/Marvel-LG/Code.

title: BTune: Bottleneck-Centric Configuration Parameters Tuning for Mixed Workloads
authors: Qinwen Shi, Yuwan Li, Yubo Deng, Yida Wang, Yuanchao Xu
publish: 2025 IEEE 31th International Conference on Parallel and Distributed Systems (ICPADS)
abstract: Many applications rely heavily on configuration tuning to improve throughput and reduce latency. The existing state-of-the-art methods still have some limitations. First, application-centric tuning makes it difficult to generalize to dynamic or mixed application scenarios. Second, they exhibit limited efficacy in high-dimensional parameter space exploration and are susceptible to local optima entrapment. To overcome these issues, this paper introduces BTune, a novel bottleneck-centric configuration parameters tuning method. By dynamically identifying bottlenecks and adjusting relevant parameters, it avoids the inefficiency of blindly tuning all parameters. In addition, inspired by mixture of expert, we present a modular neural architecture that decomposes tuning tasks into specialized subspaces. Each expert module focuses on a subset of parameters relevant to a specific resource bottleneck, while a gating mechanism dynamically routes tuning decisions based on observed system state. Experimental results show that, compared with OPPerTune, BTune not only demonstrates accelerated discovery of near-optimal parameter configurations in singleapplication scenarios, but also achieves much higher optimization efficacy in mixed-application scenarios.

title: Unifying Quantum-Well and Collector Space-Charge Dynamics in Resonant-Tunneling-Diodes: Impact on Maximum Oscillation Frequency
authors: Petr Ourednik, Gabriele Picco, Michael Feiginov
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: We present a simple and general model for a small-signal admittance of double-barrier resonant-tunneling-diodes (RTDs). The model accounts for both the effect of traveling electrons in the RTD collector spacer and the dynamics of the electron charge in the RTD quantum well. Using the model, we evaluate how the electron travel time through the collector influences the maximum oscillation frequency of state-of-the-art RTDs. The analysis shows that the impact of the traveling electrons is more pronounced in RTDs with high current density, and that a shorter collector spacer is advantageous for high-frequency RTD oscillators. However, if electrons travel ballistically through the spacer, their effect is nearly negligible.

title: Splitting-ratio enhancement for wideband guided-wave dielectric half-mirror via metallic evanescent loading
authors: Daniel Headland, Guillermo Carpintero
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: There is a need to enhance the bandwidth of compact guided-wave devices for reflection-mode applications of terahertz waves including radar, imaging, near-field imaging, reflectometry, and duplex communications. Fundamentally, any reflection-probing device demands a suitable directional coupler, and so the bandwidth of the above-given applications is intrinsically constrained by that of the directional couplers that are available. To this end, we have recently introduced broadband all-dielectric guided-wave quasi-optical directional couplers that are enabled by elementary ray tracing principles. However, the splitting ratio becomes increasingly uneven at lower frequencies. Here, we explore a viable external-loading approach in order to divide power more evenly across the directional coupler’s operational bandwidth.

title: A THz modulator for pulse train driven THz generation
authors: Christian Rentschler, Nicholas H. Matlis, Umit Demirbas, Zhelin Zhang, Mikhail Pergament, Franz X. Kärtner
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: As the pulse energy of laser-generated multicycle THz radiation is pushed towards the mJ-range, the low optical-to-THz conversion efficiencies call for sources of femtosecond laser pulses with Joule-level energy, which are not easily accessible. We demonstrate an alternative way to create suitable laser drivers with ultrashort pulse duration via electro-optic modulation of a Joule-class nanosecond laser induced by strong THz fields at 0.35 THz. The created pulse trains with THz intraburst repetition rate are employed for efficient multicycle THz generation.

title: Manimatic: An AI-Powered Framework for Automated Physics Animation Generation using Deep Learning and Programmatic Visualization
authors: Gnanakumar D, Sainath Reddy C, Naga Purna Sekhar D, Hemanth Kumar B, Tarun Kumar Reddy D
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Automation, Computing and Renewable Systems (ICACRS)
abstract: This paper presents Manimatic, an AI-powered framework that automates physics animation generation by converting natural language descriptions into executable Manim code and rendered visualizations. The system leverages domain-specific fine-tuning of transformer-based code generation models on a curated dataset of 1,050 physics-specific prompt-code pairs spanning mechanics, waves, optics, and electromagnetism. We employ a fine-tuned CodeGen-350M-mono model achieving validation loss of 0.21, integrated with preprocessing, code generation, validation, and rendering pipelines deployed through FastAPI and Next.js interfaces. Evaluation demonstrates 96.5% syntax validity, 94.2% execution success rate, and 91.7% visual accuracy as rated by physics educators. The system successfully generates animations for diverse physics phenomena with end-to-end latency of 18-35 seconds, enabling educators to create custom instructional animations without programming expertise. This work bridges the gap between theoretical physics education and dynamic visualization, demonstrating practical viability for educational deployment.

title: TS CleanNet: A Time Series Data Cleaning and Decision Optimization System Based on Clustering and Model Fusion
authors: Xuefei Hou, Can Zhou, Haokun Yi, Yutong Zhao, Dingwen Ran, Xiangjun Kong
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Automation, Electronics and Electrical Engineering (AUTEEE)
abstract: Addressing the systemic bottlenecks in traditional multi-source time-series data processing—namely "monolithic cleaning modes, insufficient model collaboration, and missing decision-making loops"—this study proposes TS-CleanNet, an integrated solution that fuses K-Means clustering with ARIMA/LSTM time-series models. This achieves end-to-end performance enhancement from data preprocessing to decision optimization. TS-CleanNet constructs a three-tier collaborative architecture: First, a hierarchical data preprocessing module repairs data gaps via linear interpolation, reduces noise through moving average smoothing, and detects anomalies using multi-strategy anomaly detection. Combined with k-nearest neighbor interpolation, it standardizes irregular data into hourly-level sequences, solidifying the data foundation. Second, a multi-model collaborative analysis module employs least squares regression models optimized by gradient descent to correct measurement biases. K-Means uncovers multidimensional data correlations, while ARIMA/LSTM hybrid models deliver precise trend forecasting and early warnings. Simultaneously, differential calculations quantify dynamic change indicators. Third, the closed-loop decision optimization module integrates dynamic computation, loss assessment, and multi-objective optimization algorithms to determine optimal processing cycles. This forms a complete "preprocessing-analysis-decision" technical chain, minimizing overall processing costs. This research overcomes the fragmented limitations of traditional methods, establishing a systematic new paradigm for multisource time-series data processing. It provides critical technological support for efficient data management and scientific decision-making across multiple domains.

title: Optimal Power Allocation for Fleet-Level Bidirectional EV Charging with Market Participation
authors: Jonas Hellgren
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Automation, Computing and Renewable Systems (ICACRS)
abstract: This paper presents a method for optimizing power allocation within a fleet of Electric Vehicles (EVs), addressing the challenge of achieving cost-effective fleet charging. The proposed Quadratic Programming (QP)–based power splitting approach can handle bidirectional charging (V2G). The QP formulation prioritizes EVs according to their required charging power, defined as the ratio between remaining energy demand and available charging time, while also enforcing power capability constraints at both the system and vehicle levels. As a case study, the method is applied to a fleet of electric city distribution trucks. The fleet is assumed to generate revenues from two Nordic electricity markets: the Day-Ahead (DA) energy market and the Frequency Containment Reserve (FCR) balancing market, where compensation is proportional to the power capacity offered. Revenues from DA and FCR are assessed in parallel. The results indicate that bidirectional charging offers significant economic potential compared to unidirectional charging.

title: PERec: Prompt-Enhanced Semantic Modeling with Large Language Models for Long-Tail Recommendation
authors: Han Han, Chengkai Wang, Yiru Zhou, Tingting Ma, Baisong Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE 31th International Conference on Parallel and Distributed Systems (ICPADS)
abstract: Sequential recommendation systems aim to predict users' future interests based on their historical interactions and are widely applied in domains such as e-commerce and social media. However, in real-world scenarios, recommendation data often exhibits a long-tail distribution, resulting in extremely sparse interactions for a large number of users. Traditional methods face significant challenges in modeling such user preferences, thereby compromising recommendation performance and personalization. In recent years, Large Language Models (LLMs) have shown great promise in sparse scenarios due to their powerful language understanding and generation capabilities, offering new opportunities for user interest modeling. Nevertheless, existing approaches often rely on a single prompt or focus solely on item-side semantic information, neglecting users' multi-interest structures and collaborative behavior signals, which limits the reasoning potential of LLMs. To address these issues, this paper proposes the PERec (Prompt-enhanced Semantic Modeling with Large Language Models for Long-tail Recommendation) framework, aiming to enhance semantic modeling and recommendation performance for long-tail users. PERec builds a prompt-driven multi-interest semantic enhancement structure. Specifically, it first generates multiple personalized prompts from users' behavioral histories to guide LLMs in learning diverse preference-aware semantic representations. It then constructs semantic and collaborative dual-view representations and employs a contrastive alignment mechanism to enhance inter-view consistency. Finally, a view fusion strategy is used to generate robust user representations, thereby improving recommendation performance in sparse longtail scenarios. We conduct empirical studies on three real-world datasets-Amazon Beauty, Amazon Clothing, and Yelp. The results demonstrate that PERec significantly outperforms representative baseline methods in both overall recommendation performance and long-tail user accuracy, verifying its effectiveness and practical value in sparse recommendation settings.

title: Step-Level Evolutionary Reasoning: Enhancing Mathematical Reasoning in Large Language Models via Genetic Algorithms
authors: Ji Feng, Yongqiang Xu, Qingjun Zhang
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Big Data, Artificial Intelligence and Internet of Things Engineering (ICBAIE)
abstract: Large Language Models (LLMs) exhibit considerable potential in mathematical reasoning, yet they encounter persistent challenges in solving complex problems requiring precise logical structures, including limited generalization and error propagation. Although recent approaches have enhanced problem decomposition and structural guidance, they lack fine-grained control over reasoning dynamics and optimal path selection. In response to these constraints, we introduce a novel framework named Step-Level Evolutionary Reasoning (SER), which leverages genetic algorithms to enhance the reasoning capabilities of Large Language Models. SER enhances step-level reasoning by representing fine-grained reasoning steps as genes in an evolvable population, enabling genetic operations (e.g., mutation and crossover) to optimize reasoning paths. Experiments demonstrate that SER significantly improves performance across multiple mathematical benchmarks. On GSM8K, SER@4 boosts the zero-shot accuracy of LLaMA3-8B-Instruct from 79.1% to 97.0%. For Olympiad-level problems (e.g., OlympiadBench), SER achieves 54.0% accuracy, outperforming strong baselines by 22.8%.

title: Towards Affordable Smart Aquaponics: A Review and Proposal for Low-Cost Nutrient Monitoring
authors: Russell Len Chyuan Tzen, Christopher Lazarus, Yiqi Tew
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Digital Transformation and Applications (ICDXA)
abstract: Smart aquaponics integrates Internet of Things and artificial intelligence technologies for sustainable food production. Current implementations that rely on Ion-Selective Electrodes (ISEs) for nutrient monitoring face high costs and maintenance, limiting adoption in non-commercial and smallscale setups. This paper reviews these limitations and proposes an alternative: automated colorimetric testing using low-cost sensors or cameras with commercially available freshwater test kits. The approach provides affordable nutrient estimation with acceptable accuracy, though resolution is lower, results are slower than ISEs, and reagents must be periodically replenished. The reduction in cost and maintenance justify this trade-off for general monitoring in compact systems. Implementation considerations, including sensor configuration, lighting, and reagent dispensing, are discussed. The proposed method advances accessible smart aquaponics and supports broader adoption and food security.

title: Towards solving the Cold Start and Explainability Challenges in Recommender Systems Using Knowledge Graphs and User Demographics Data
authors: Nadia Ben Hadj Boubaker, Nadia Yacoubi Ayadi, Zahra Kodia
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: Recommender Systems (RS) play a crucial role in helping users navigate vast amounts of digital information. However, these systems face persistent challenges, particularly the cold start problem and the lack of explainability in recommendations. This paper introduces X-KAREN-D, an eXplainable Knowledge-based ATtention ensemble REcurrent Network with Demographics, designed to address these issues. X-KAREN-D incorporates user demographic information to mitigate the cold start problem, improving personalization and recommendation accuracy. Additionally, it enhances explainability by leveraging a knowledge graph (KG) structure to provide path-based explanations, allowing users to understand the rationale behind recommendations. Through extensive experiments, we evaluate various Knowledge Graph Embedding (KGE) techniques to assess their impact on recommendation accuracy. Our results demonstrate that the proposed model outperforms the state-of-the-art baseline, achieving an MAE of 0.030 and an RMSE of 0.041. These findings highlight the significance of incorporating structured knowledge and user demographic data to improve both the performance and interpretability of recommender systems.

title: A deep opto-electronic neural network for high-quality terahertz imaging
authors: Jingzhu Shao, Ping Tang, Wei Wei, Chongzhao Wu
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: A novel hybrid neural network framework consisting of both intelligent optical modulator and electronic processing is introduced to facilitate the high-resolution and high-quality terahertz imaging. The proposed framework shows promising reconstructions of imaging target with higher spatial resolution and peak signal-to-noise ratio compared with the conventional refractive lens imaging and the pure post-processing methods. The proposed framework opens up a new approach to achieve high-quality terahertz imaging by the deep co-design of optics and post-processing, which would be inspirational in a wide range of applications, not only targeting at the wavelength of terahertz, but also at other frequency bands, such as visible and infrared wavelength.

title: Terahertz frequency combs in quantum cascade lasers with frequency dependent feedback
authors: Carlo Silvestri, Xiaoqiong Qi, Thomas Taimre, Jari Torniainen, Puspita Chanda, Aleksandar D. Rakić
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: We investigate the impact of optical feedback from a frequency-dependent reflector on a terahertz frequency comb emitted by a quantum cascade laser (QCL). Our results show that the relative position of the high-reflectivity region with respect to the material gain peak plays a key role in determining the emission regime of the QCL. This study is crucial for both advancing the fundamental understanding of feedback effects in THz frequency combs and practical applications involving real-world targets with frequency-dependent reflectivity.

title: UniMGS: Unsupervised Multimodal Guided Segmentation for High-Resolution Remote Sensing Images
authors: Nan Wang, Fukun Bi, Dehao Zhou, Jianhong Han, Wenkai Liu
publish: IEEE Geoscience and Remote Sensing Letters
abstract: Generating pixel-level annotations for the semantic segmentation of high-resolution remote sensing images is labor-intensive and time-consuming. To address this issue, numerous studies attempt to generate pixel-level annotations through automatic or semi-automatic labeling strategies. However, due to the inherent complexity of remote sensing imagery and the presence of unseen classes, achieving both accurate foreground segmentation and precise class labeling remains highly challenging. In this paper, we propose an Unsupervised Multimodal Guided Segmentation (UniMGS) framework that generates pseudo-labels for remote sensing images without requiring any ground-truth annotations or additional prompts. Specifically, We propose a Mask Purification Module (MPM) that refines class-agnostic segmentation masks by applying an area filter and a ring-merging strategy to remove noisy masks and merge over-segmented regions. To assign precise categories to class-agnostic segmentation masks, we propose a Text-Driven Classifier (TDC) module. This module constructs an intra-class maximum spanning tree from a similarity matrix and incorporates cluster size constraints together with a confidence scoring mechanism, ultimately achieving precise class labeling. Experimental results on multiple remote sensing datasets demonstrate that UniMGS outperforms existing state-of-the-art methods. Our source code is available at https://github.com/nanwang0511/UniMGS.

title: Improving Anomaly Detection in Industrial Time Series: The Role of Segmentation and Heterogeneous Ensemble
authors: E. Mastriani, A. Costa, F. Incardona, K. Munari, S. Spinello
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: Concerning machine learning, segmentation models can identify state changes within time series, facilitating the detection of transitions between normal and anomalous conditions. Specific techniques such as Change Point Detection (CPD), particularly algorithms like ChangeFinder, have been successfully applied to segment time series and improve anomaly detection by reducing temporal uncertainty, especially in multivariate environments.In this work, we explored how the integration of segmentation techniques, combined with a heterogeneous ensemble, can enhance anomaly detection in an industrial production context. The results show that applying segmentation as a pre-processing step before selecting heterogeneous ensemble algorithms provided a significant advantage in our case study, improving the AUC-ROC metric from 0.8599 (achieved with a PCA and LSTM ensemble) to 0.9760 (achieved with Random Forest and XGBoost). This improvement is imputable to the ability of segmentation to reduce temporal ambiguity and facilitate the learning process of supervised algorithms.In our future work, we intend to assess the benefit of introducing weighted features derived from the study of change points, combined with segmentation and the use of heterogeneous ensembles, to further optimize model performance in early anomaly detection.

title: Waveguide resonant tunneling diode injection locking amplifier
authors: James Greenberg, Brendan M. Heffernan, William F. McGrew, Antoine Rolland
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: Photomixed terahertz (THz) sources currently produce the most spectrally pure waves for frequencies spanning 300 GHz to 3 THz. This level of performance is crucial for enabling THz applications like high-speed wireless communications and molecular rotational spectroscopy. However, continuous-wave (CW) photomixed sources generate diminishing power above 300 GHz, which limits their practical utility: dropping from ~100 μW to ~10 nW at 1 THz. Resonant tunneling diodes (RTDs) offer a compact and energy-efficient alternative to photomixed THz sources, spanning the same frequency range. RTDs can generate milliwatts of THz power but are limited in application by a broad linewidth (poor spectral purity), limiting their use in applications requiring high coherence. A hybrid THz source combining the purity of photomixing and the power of RTDs can be realized via injection locking. Here we demonstrate injection locking of a waveguide-coupled RTD to a photomixed source. We characterize the residual phase noise of the injection locking process, the bandwidth limitations of injection locking, and show small-signal amplification of 40 dB. These measurements show a combined photomixed oscillator and waveguide injection-locked RTD amplifier at 260 GHz with state-of-the-art spectral purity. We anticipate these methods will be effective up to 1 THz.

title: Using Software Solution for Quality Assessment in School Education
authors: Silvia Gaftandzhieva, Rositsa Doneva, Mariya Docheva, George Pashev, George Totkov
abstract: Quality assurance in educational institutions is often achieved through complementary internal and external control and evaluation systems. Based on an in-depth analysis of existing models for quality assessment and consultations with school leaders and teachers, this paper presents a model for comprehensive quality assessment and a corresponding software tool SchoolQA, which offers a platform for experts to streamline external evaluations. It allows stakeholders to oversee a school's progress, find opportunities for improvement, set future goals, and measure its performance against other institutions. The experimental implementation of SchoolQA in two Bulgarian schools proved its applicability and effectiveness for quality assessment in school education.

title: Structural Analysis of a Smart Home System in Accommodation Residence
authors: Desislava Mihaylova, Miroslav Akbatirov
abstract: This report examines a smart system designed for implementation in hotel conditions. Apart from the problem of choosing technical means for the execution of the project, the posed task here is to present an original solution about the working principle of the system and to describe it by using the automation theory. Hotel room conditions propose that the "smart" system would be responsive to customer presence and actions. The number of states when the system waits for incoming signals from different sensors or direct impact upon input devices is a comparative criterion about the complexity of similar projects. Consequently, an optional algorithm is presented, and automaton is created referring to the general states of a group events. It facilitates the assessment of the logical composition in terms of coding constraints.

title: HIPS : Hierarchical Decision-Making Pathfinding Based on Social Value Orientation
authors: Haoxiang Zhao, Mengwei Li, Weizhen Han, Enshu Wang, Bingyi Liu, Libing Wu
publish: 2025 IEEE 31th International Conference on Parallel and Distributed Systems (ICPADS)
abstract: The multi-agent pathfinding problem seeks to generate low-cost paths for agents to reach their targets, playing a crucial role in advancing the development of smart warehousing. Traditional methods do not utilize neural networks, resulting in high computational costs and poor scalability. In contrast, learning-based approaches leverage reinforcement learning to handle large-scale scenarios more effectively. However, they often depend heavily on expert demonstrations, and their plain reward structures can lead to suboptimal path planning. To address these challenges, we propose a novel multi-agent reinforcement learning framework: Hierarchical Decision-making Pathfinding Based on Social Value Orientation (HIPS). Specifically, HIPS adopts a hierarchical decision-making structure in which the lower-level interaction policy generates actions to interact with the environment, guided by egoistic rewards to promote low-cost path planning. Moreover, the upper-level policy is environmentoriented, learning dynamic social value orientations that enable agents to plan paths while accounting for interactions with other agents, thereby achieving an adaptive balance between individual self-interest and long-term team benefits. Extensive experimental validation demonstrates that HIPS increases the number of finished targets by at least 6% compared to existing methods without relying on expert experience.

title: Learning-Based Hybrid Needle Tip Tracking and Visualization Framework for Robotic Ultrasound-Guided Interventions
authors: Junling Fu, Zijian Cai, Runing Xiao, Giancarlo Ferrigno, Alberto Redaelli, Elena De Momi
publish: IEEE Transactions on Medical Robotics and Bionics
abstract: Ultrasound (US)-guided needle-based interventions have been extensively employed in clinical practice for biopsies, regional anesthesia, and tumor ablation, considering the advantages of real-time imaging, portability, and non-ionizing radiation. Precise localization and tracking of the needle tip are critical for ensuring the successful needle placement while minimizing the risk of injury to surrounding anatomical structures. However, achieving real-time and reliable needle tip tracking remains challenging due to the inherent properties of US images, such as low spatial resolution, speckle noise, and imaging artifacts that obscure the needle tip. This study proposes a hybrid learning-based framework for accurately and robustly localizing the needle tip within the US image plane during robot-assisted interventional procedures. The framework comprises a dual-branch template matching-based detection module, a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN)-based detection module, and a “dynamic template selection and updating" mechanism to enhance overall tracking performance. Additionally, to recover the needle tip invisibility caused by unanticipated movements, an active exploration strategy based on a Gaussian Process (GP) model and Bayesian Optimization (BO) is proposed for efficient and accurate robotic US probe pose adjustment. The effectiveness of the proposed method for needle tip tracking performance has been evaluated through a series of experiments conducted on ex vivo porcine liver samples under varying insertion angles and velocities. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed framework achieves a maximum median localization error of 1.17 mm and an Interquartile Range (IQR) of 1.28 mm across all test conditions. Furthermore, in scenarios requiring needle tip visibility recovery, the proposed BO-based strategy achieved a median localization error of 1.52 mm and an IQR of 0.95 mm.

title: DSE-TV: Dynamic Strategy Ensemble with Threshold Voting for Female Fetus Chromosomal Anomaly Detection in NIPT
authors: Zhengtao Li, Chongzhi Wu, Qingxiang Huang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Digital Society and Intelligent Systems (DSInS)
abstract: Non-Invasive Prenatal Testing (NIPT) provides critical screening for chromosomal aneuploidies, but detecting anomalies in female fetuses remains challenging due to the absence of Y-chromosome quality markers and severe class imbalance in anomaly detection. Existing methods relying on indirect indicators achieve suboptimal recall rates, leading to unacceptable false negative risks in clinical practice. Recent advances in computer technology, such as ensemble learning and adaptive optimization, offer new avenues for analysis, but existing methods have not yet effectively integrated these techniques to overcome the specific challenges of female fetus NIPT. To address this gap, we propose DSE-TV, a Dynamic Strategy Ensemble framework that capitalizes on these advances by integrating heterogeneous machine learning algorithms through computational optimization, addressing these challenges through a two-stage optimization approach: recall-weighted hyperparameter tuning for heterogeneous base learners, followed by adaptive fold-specific ensemble strategy selection using clinically-driven composite scoring. Our framework exploits female-specific biological features including X-chromosome patterns and multi-chromosomal correlations through systematic feature engineering. Evaluated on 597 female fetus samples with 7.71 percent anomaly prevalence via 5 fold cross-validation, DSE-TV achieves 0.589 recall, representing a 12.3 percent improvement over the best individual baseline (0.524), while maintaining competitive precision and the highest F1-score (0.378). This translates to detecting approximately 6 additional anomalies per 100 cases, significantly enhancing prenatal screening effectiveness for female fetuses where missed diagnoses carry severe clinical consequences.

title: A Multi-mesh Approach for Three-dimensional Arbitrary Anisotropic Inversion of Direct Current Resistivity Method_supp1-3653972.docx
authors: Handong Tan
abstract: The three-dimensional arbitrary anisotropic inversion algorithm for direct current (DC) resistivity method is developed based on unstructured meshes and L-BFGS optimization, enabling the simultaneous recovery of all independent anisotropic parameters. To enhance robustness and decrease inversion non-uniqueness, distinct meshes are employed for forward modeling and inversion. A novel mesh-assignment strategy is introduced, where inversion meshes for individual anisotropy parameters are aligned specifically with the directional resolution inherently provided by the surficial data. This approach eliminates the conventional requirement for symmetric surficial configurations in three-dimensional DC resistivity anisotropic inversion based on unstructured meshes. Furthermore, to stabilize inversion updates, a volume-weighted method is implemented to compute the objective function gradient on the coarse inversion mesh by aggregating contributions from the finer mesh. This prevents the gradient of one particular parameter from dominating the optimization process due to unbalanced accumulation, a common issue in traditional direct summation strategy, resulting in a more reasonable update of anisotropy parameters and ensuring the reliable recovery of principal resistivities and orientation angles. Five anisotropic inversions with distinct mesh strategies were performed for each model. Comparative analysis based on synthetic data confirms the effectiveness of the proposed approach in improving anisotropic inversion accuracy and resolution, especially in distinguishing between principal resistivities and angle. These results validate both the practicality and reliability of the proposed approach.

title: Hidden-Void and Skin-Burn Imaging with a Coherent 94-GHz Reflectometer
authors: W-D. Zhang, E.R. Brown
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: A non-contact imager is demonstrated based on an open-ended, rectangular-waveguide coupler, and a coherent 94-GHz reflectometer. The range between the coupler and target is set to operate in the radiative near field, where the spot diameter is measured to be ≈ λ/4 in free space at ~1 mm range.

title: GWO-Based Resilient Adaptive Event-Triggered Control for Networked Power Systems Under DoS Attacks via a Matrix-Separation-Based Inequality
authors: Wen-Hu Chen, Chuan-Ke Zhang, Li Jin, Jian Chen, Yong He
abstract: This article investigates resilient adaptive event-triggered (RAET) control for networked power systems under the influence of aperiodic denial-of-service (DoS) attacks. The primary objective of this article is to achieve better control performance while reducing communication load. First, a switched networked control system is established to characterize the effects of aperiodic DoS attacks on networked power systems. Second, a grey wolf optimizer (GWO)-based RAET control scheme is developed to mitigate the impact of DoS attacks and minimize unnecessary transmissions, with an adaptive threshold tuned based on control performance. Third, a matrix-separation-based inequality is developed, enabling a less conservative and computationally efficient co-design of the RAET parameters and control gain. Finally, case studies are carried out to demonstrate the efficacy and scalability of the design methods.

title: A comparative study between flatness-based control with an exact observer and functional observer-based feedback control
authors: Safa Amara, Mohamed Ben Abdallah, Meriem Hamdoun, Mounir Ayadi
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: This paper presents a comparative study between flatness-based control and functional observer-based feedback control, with a focus on how each method addresses control tasks in systems with complex dynamics. Both control strategies are widely utilized in applications such as robotics, aerospace, and automotive systems, where efficient and reliable control is essential. The paper explores the key principles, advantages, and limitations of each approach, providing a detailed comparison of their applicability, design complexity and robustness. Our paper builds on our previous work [11] which focused exclusively on flatness-based control for the Ball Balancing Table (BBT) and its simulation results. We now extend this by comparing it with a functional observer-based feedback controller for the same system.

title: A Hybrid Framework for Analyzing and Detecting Phishing and Fraudulent Domains
authors: Kritika, Dharmveer Jangid, Tanuj Yadav, Vyom Sharma, Vansh Sharma, Saksham Garg
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Automation, Computing and Renewable Systems (ICACRS)
abstract: The continuous expansion of the internet and large number of online services has made the digital world more connected but also unsafe. Every year thousands of users lose their money and personal data because of phishing and many fake websites which look almost like real ones. Attackers keep improving their tricks by making small changes in domains and email structures to fool users. This study presents a simple but useful hybrid setup that combines both data study and checking to understand and detect such attacks. The idea is to make one system that helps both in learning and real protection. The first part of the system uses Power BI to study a cybercrime dataset which contains global information on attacks from different years and sectors. This part help to see patterns, like which countries faced more phishing and which sectors are most affected. The second part is a python based tool named MailGuard that allows a person to check if an email if an email or domain is safe or not by using WHOIS lookup, DNS record check, SPF and DMARC verification, and pattern matching through regular expression. Both parts are made to work together so that one side shows the large picture of global cybercrime and other side checks individual domains in real time. The experiment results show that this mixed setup is easy to use, and gives correct results. It also helps people understanding phishing and improves awareness of cyber threats.

title: Anisotropy of Beta-Gallium Oxide Epilayer Evaluated by Temperature-Dependent Terahertz Time-Domain Spectroscopy
authors: Shuang Liu, Verdad C. Agulto, Toshiyuki Iwamoto, Kosaku Kato, Thanh Nhat Khoa Phan, Yoshinao Kumagai, Hisashi Murakami, Makoto Nakajima
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: In this study, we investigate the anisotropic properties of β-Ga₂O₃ epitaxial layer along the a-axis [100] and baxis [010] directions using terahertz time-domain spectroscopy (THz-TDS). The THz response spectra were measured over a frequency range of 0.2 - 3 THz and at temperature range of 90– 400 K. By employing a Drude-Lorentz model, we extracted the anisotropic transport parameters. Our findings provide fundamental insights into the anisotropic behavior of β-Ga₂O₃, offering theoretical support for its optimization in high-frequency electronic and optoelectronic applications.

                    : Angle-dependent Resonance and Birefringence Studies
authors: Vibhavari Parkar, Snehal Haldankar, Maneesha Narayan, Arumugam Thamizhavel, Arnab Bhattacharya, Shriganesh Prabhu
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: Terahertz birefringence studies provide critical insight into the anisotropic optical behavior of doped wide-bandgap semiconductors. Here, we investigate angle-dependent birefringence in Nickel (Ni)-doped β-Ga<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">₂</inf>O<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">₃</inf> using terahertz time-domain polarimetry (THz-TDP). The crystal was rotated from 0° to 360° in 10° increments, with the 0° orientation defined as the b-axis parallel to the incident THz polarization. Our measurements reveal distinct resonance features at 0.83 THz and 2.16 THz, observed at angles 50°, 140°, 230°, and 320°. A periodic delay pattern with 180° repetition confirms the crystal’s C2 symmetry. Additionally, the birefringence (Δn) at 1 THz was found to be 0.295±0.02, demonstrating strong optical anisotropy. These results expand our understanding of resonance and anisotropy in doped β-Ga<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">₂</inf>O<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">₃</inf> and have potential implications for polarization-sensitive THz devices.

title: Hydrogen bond breaking dynamics in water clusters: Terahertz VRT spectroscopy of the 20 μm out-of-plane libration
authors: Richard J. Saykally
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: THE out-of-plane librational band is the most prominent feature in the intermolecular vibrational spectrum of bulk water, and has vital consequences for hydrogen bond dynamics. Excitation of this vibration, which occurs in the 500-800 cm 1 region, has been shown to comprise motions that break and reform hydrogen bonds, and the hydrogen bond breaking process has been shown to be highly local, and largely unaffected by hydrogen bond order. Thus, water clusters present a convenient route for examining details of these hydrogen bond dynamics. Additionally, analysis of the many-body expansion of the water-water interaction potential has shown that the most significant terms are the 2 and 3 body terms, which comprise ∼99% of the interaction energy. Towards the development of improved water models, terahertz vibration-rotation-tunneling (VRT) experiments on water clusters have been shown to accurately probe the short-range interactions. The key distinctions between water clusters and the bulk are the free hydrogens of the clusters. These hydrogens are predicted to have little effect on the librational motions, as evidenced by low-resolution spectroscopy studies of small clusters (n = 10-100). Here we report the high-resolution terahertz VRT spectra of a librational vibration near 15 THz for the water dimer, trimer, pentamer, and hexamer, measured with a far-IR lead-salt diode laser spectrometer employing supersonic beam production of water clusters.

title: Adaptive Multimodal Fusion with Modality-Aware Feature Selection for Malware Classification
authors: Fanqi Meng, Huimin Li, Jingdong Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE 31th International Conference on Parallel and Distributed Systems (ICPADS)
abstract: The rapid evolution of malware variants and imbalanced family distributions pose significant challenges to accurate classification and system security. This paper introduces an adaptive multimodal learning framework for robust malware family classification. The key innovation lies in a Modality-Aware Feature Selection (MAFS) mechanism that dynamically selects the most discriminative features from byte-level, structural, and semantic modalities. Coupled with an adaptive fusion strategy, our approach effectively addresses feature redundancy, modality heterogeneity, and missing data scenarios. Extensive experiments on 5,841 samples from 10 families demonstrate state-of-theart performance, with 99.87% accuracy, 99.82% macro-F1, and 0.0175 log loss, significantly outperforming existing methods in handling both feature loss and class imbalance.

title: A Resource Efficient Approximate MAC using Hierarchical Compressors with Balanced Error Control
authors: P. Balasubramani, Arthi D R
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Automation, Computing and Renewable Systems (ICACRS)
abstract: A novel approximate computing approach has been developed to achieve energy efficient Multiply Accumulate (MAC) operations for error tolerant applications. The proposed architecture employs an interleaved structure of approximate compressors to counterbalance positive and negative errors during accumulation, thereby minimizing cumulative error propagation. In the least significant bit (LSB) region, custom-designed approximate 4:2 compressors are utilized to generate complementary error patterns that maintain balanced accuracy while reducing hardware complexity. To further enhance power efficiency, 5:2 and 7:2 compressors are incorporated in the partial product reduction stage, effectively reducing the number of logic level and overall switching activity. A statistical error modeling technique is applied to optimize the placement of positive and negative compressors, ensuring consistent computational accuracy across all MAC operations. As a result, the proposed design archives over 35% reduction in processor level power consumption compared to existing multiplier architectures. Simulation and synthesis results confirm that the architecture maintains high computational stability and accuracy, making it suitable for applications such as image processing, neural network computation, and digital signal processing. Overall, the proposed interleaved compressor-based MAC unit provides an effective, scalable, and low-power solution for next-generation approximate computing systems, offering an excellent balance energy efficiency and computational precision.

title: Design and analysis of L-shaped slot CPW-fed Microstrip antenna for Multi-band applications
authors: Subrat Maharana, Sangita Lenka, Somya Ranjan Mohapatra, Naresh Chandra Naik
publish: 2025 5th IEEE International Conference on Applied Electromagnetics, Signal Processing, &amp; Communication (AESPC)
abstract: This work focuses on the design and analysis of a CPW-fed slotted microstrip antenna for next-generation wireless, radar, and satellite applications. Embedded L-shaped slots are made on the patch over an FR-4 substrate. The proposed antenna mainly resonates in the multiple frequency bands S-band (2.41$2.86 \mathrm{GHz}, 3.07-3.52 \mathrm{GHz}), \mathrm{C}$-band ($5.35-7.79 \mathrm{GHz}$), and X-band $(9.25-9.77 \mathrm{GHz})$. The proposed antenna gives a return loss of $-19.23 \mathrm{~dB},-19.43 \mathrm{~dB},-23.22 \mathrm{~dB}$, and -27.69 dB in the respective frequency band. The proposed antenna gives a max gain of 2.2 dBi at a 6.87 GHz resonating frequency. All the designs are simulated in CST microwave studio software, and the results are analyzed.

title: Fröhlich condensates and electrodynamic forces among biomolecules probed by THz-spectroscopy
authors: E. Perez-Martin, S. Ruffenach, L. Bonnet, F. Teppe, D. Marguet, M. Pettini, J. Torrès
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: We review THz-spectroscopy experimental findings highlighting the activation of out-of-equilibrium collective oscillations in macromolecules, similar to semi-classical phonon condensation. This phenomenon is examined using proteins like R-phycoerythrin (R-PE) and bovine serum albumin (BSA) as model proteins. The study demonstrates that both laser illumination and temperature changes, acting as external energy sources, can trigger these collective oscillations and activate long-range ED interactions among biomacromolecules.

title: A Self Attention Mechanism based Framework for the Detection of Stroke and Traumatic Brain Injury
authors: Gayathri D, Shanthi T, B.Ramasubramanian
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Automation, Computing and Renewable Systems (ICACRS)
abstract: Rapid and accurate detection of Stroke and Traumatic Brain Injury (TBI) plays a key role for reducing mortality rates and improving patient recovery. Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI), for its high soft – tissue contrast, is widely preferred as the optimal imaging technique for brain disorder assessment. Manual assessment is time consuming and often suffers from variability between observers. In this study, we present a Deep Learning framework based on the Vision Transformer (ViT) for automated detection of stroke and TBI using MRI images. By utilizing self-attention mechanisms, the ViT model effectively captures both local and global dependencies across MRI slices, allowing better detection of subtle pathological features often overlooked by traditional Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs). The model was trained on BraTS2020 and Figshare dataset that includes healthy, stroke, and TBI cases. The dataset for our experiment is selected demonstrated that the proposed ViT model achieved an accuracy of 96.4%, sensitivity 0f 95.8%, specificity of 97.2%, and F1 score of 96.0%, which are comparatively high with CNN models. These results demonstrates that transformer based DL methods hold high potential for Computer-Aided Diagnostic (CAD) systems, offering clinicians with an efficient and effective tool for early detection and developed treatment planning in critical brain disorders

title: A Reconfigurable Modular Microelectrode Array Platform for Fast Prototyping of Implantable Closed-Loop Neuromodulation Medical Devices
authors: Mustafa Kanchwala, Vijithan Mangaleswaran, Gerard O’Leary, Iouri Khramtsov, Rakshith Ramesh, Homeira Moradi Chameh, Roman Genov, Taufik A. Valiante
publish: 2025 IEEE Biomedical Circuits and Systems Conference (BioCAS)
abstract: Developing implantable, closed-loop neuromodulation devices demands seamless integration of neuroscience discovery, algorithm design, and ultra-low-power hardware-an effort that traditionally stretches across many years and multiple specialist teams. Existing commercial or open-source electrophysiology tools do not offer the broad flexibility desired to enable rapid testing of custom stimulation paradigms and closed-loop algorithms, slowing the path from bench-top insight to patient-ready silicon. To address this we present a flexible platform that integrates four interoperable modes: (1) Experimental validation - for neuroscientists to explore new stimulation protocols and test their efficacy; (2) Software development-to enable realtime closed-loop algorithm testing; (3) Hardware development for translation of proven software code into FPGA-accelerated, power-efficient hardware; (4) ASIC validation - for post-silicon performance testing before deployment in chronic studies. This modular architecture enables parallel, cross-functional collaboration, reduces design spins, and lowers entry barriers for labs lacking end-to-end neuromodulation infrastructure. Preliminary in-vitro results from human brain tissue using microelectrode arrays demonstrate reliable operation, validating the system. By streamlining the transition from neuroscience insight to implant-grade ASIC, our system accelerates therapeutic device development and opens new avenues for fundamental investigations of brain function.

title: A Multiply-and-Accumulate SAR-ADC-Based Hybrid Slepian Beamformer
authors: Zhengqi Xu, Zhiyuan Zhao, Michael A. Laun, Coleman DeLude, Justin Romberg, Michael P. Flynn
abstract: This article introduces a hybrid Slepian beamforming receiver architecture with low power and area costs. Traditional large-scale true-time-delay (TTD) beamformers for wideband wireless communication suffer from high power consumption and high hardware costs. As an alternative, the Slepian beamforming approach reduces the number of analog-to-digital conversions (ADCs) and delays for TTD but retains the digital delay advantage of digital beamforming. The proposed architecture further improves energy efficiency by implementing charge-domain complex multiply and accumulate (MAC) inside successive approximation register (SAR) ADCs. The beamformer has eight intermediate frequency (IF) inputs, two simultaneous digital baseband outputs in phased mode, or one wideband output in TTD mode. The prototype is fabricated in 28-nm CMOS, consumes only 17 mW, and occupies 0.035 mm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>. Measurements show error vector magnitudes (EVMs) better than −30 dB for quadrature amplitude modulation (QAM)-16 and QAM-256. In tests, beam squinting errors are not observed up to a steering angle of 60°.

title: Construction and Research of a Dynamic Threshold Collaborative Archive Classification Model Based on DS14B-BertCNN
authors: Tao Chen, Wei Fang, Liang Yuan, Xuan Liu, Hongping Li, Qicheng Zhang, Hui Wu
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Machine Learning, Big Data and Business Intelligence (MLBDBI)
abstract: Against the backdrop of digital government construction, archival management faces challenges hindering accurate, efficient classification: significant semantic gaps in cross-period archives, superficial traditional methods, lightweight models' poor multi-dimensional classification ability, high LLM deployment costs, and the “lightweight model initial screening + LLM verification” paradigm's flaws. This paper proposes a DS14B-BertCNN-based dynamic threshold collaborative method: a cascaded architecture with Bert-CNN for real-time initial classification and fine-tuned DeepSeek-R1-14B for in-depth verification, plus dynamic thresholds and optimization via feedback loops/archival knowledge injection. Experiments on 25,000 Hubei Provincial Archives showed “DS14B extraction + BertCNN + DS14B classification” performed best: 93.68% precision, 94.51% recall, 94.09% F1-score. The dynamic threshold worked stably for small samples, correcting biases. Though inference time rose <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{2 0 \%} \boldsymbol{-} \mathbf{3 0 \%}$</tex>, delay was controllable via optimization. Practical use improved accuracy by 2.7% and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$F 1$</tex> by 3.3 %, verifying effectiveness.

title: xHyperG: A Hypergraph Analytical Framework on GPUs with Scalability
authors: Shang Wang, Yansong Dong, Kaifan Jia, Haonan Zou, Heng Zhang
publish: 2025 IEEE 31th International Conference on Parallel and Distributed Systems (ICPADS)
abstract: Hypergraph analysis is widely used in many domains, and real-world hypergraphs often follow power-law degree distributions, a structural pattern that can strongly benefit from the massive parallelism and high bandwidth of GPUs. Although a prior GPU-based framework has demonstrated the feasibility of accelerating hypergraph analytics, they lack optimizations for the structural characteristics of hypergraphs on modern GPU architectures. Meanwhile, the irregular connectivity of hypergraphs presents challenges such as load imbalance, inefficient memory access, and idle SMs. To address these challenges, we propose xHyperG, a GPU-native framework that incorporates a hierarchical workload balancing strategy for redistributing high-degree nodes at runtime, a multi-pipeline execution design that overlaps computation with data movement, and an atomic-centric programming approach that leverages GPU primitives to optimize hypergraph algorithm migration. Evaluations on five real-world datasets show that xHyperG achieves <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{1 9 - 3 2} \times$</tex> the throughput of state-of-the-art CPU systems (Hygra and NWHy) on a 36-core CPU, highlighting the potential of GPUs for large-scale hypergraph analytics.
