title: Range Image-Based Implicit Neural Compression for LiDAR Point Clouds
authors: Akihiro Kuwabara, Sorachi Kato, Toshiaki Koike-Akino, Takuya Fujihashi
abstract: This paper presents a novel scheme to efficiently compress Light Detection and Ranging (LiDAR) point clouds, enabling high-precision 3D scene archives, and such archives pave the way for a detailed understanding of the corresponding 3D scenes. We focus on 2D range images (RIs) as a lightweight format for representing 3D LiDAR observations. Although conventional image compression techniques can be adapted to improve compression efficiency for RIs, their practical performance is expected to be limited due to differences in bit precision and the distinct pixel value distribution characteristics between natural images and RIs. We propose a novel implicit neural representation (INR)–based RI compression method that effectively handles floating-point valued pixels. The proposed method divides RIs into depth and mask images and compresses them using patch-wise and pixel-wise INR architectures with model pruning and quantization, respectively. Experiments on the KITTI dataset show that the proposed method outperforms existing image, point cloud, RI, and INR-based compression methods in terms of 3D reconstruction and detection quality at low bitrates and decoding latency.

title: Understanding Climate-driven Migration: A Nonlinear Machine Learning Approach
authors: S. De Nardi, C. Carnevale, G. Piccoli, S. Raccagni, L. Sangiorgi
abstract: The relationship between climate change and migration has gained significant attention in recent years, particularly regarding its impact on vulnerable regions. This study proposes a novel modeling approach to climate-induced migration by systematically comparing traditional statistical models and machine learning techniques. While most existing research in this field relies on linear models or case-specific analyses, our work explicitly models complex non-linear and multidimensional relationships among environmental and socio-economic drivers of migration. By comparing autoregressive, polynomial, and logarithmic models with a Random Forest model, we demonstrate the added value of machine learning in capturing complex patterns that conventional models often fail to detect. Furthermore, we analyze how variables such as temperature anomalies, the Human Development Index (HDI), water stress, and the agricultural sector’s contribution to the Gross Domestic Product influence migration. This framework is applied to data-scarce and climate-sensitive regions, namely North Africa, Sub-Saharan Africa, and Southeast Asia, where robust modeling remains both challenging and urgently needed. Model performance was systematically evaluated through multiple metrics, including correlation, Mean Error (ME), Mean Absolute Error (MAE), and their normalized forms (NME and NMAE). Results show that while simpler models exhibit limited explanatory power, the Random Forest model substantially improves predictive accuracy, achieving correlation = 0.81, MAE = 0.95, NME = –0.009, and NMAE = 0.25. These findings demonstrate the model’s effectiveness in capturing migration dynamics, and also provides a replicable methodology that can support targeted adaptation strategies, effective migration management, and climate policies, particularly relevant for data-scarce regions of the Global South.

title: Leakage-Based Temperature Sensor with Incremental Analog-to-Digital Converter
authors: Yeonsu Kim, Myunghyun Jeon, Su-Hyeon Kim, Jae-Won Nam
abstract: Ahstract-A complementary metal-oxide-semiconductor (CMOS) temperature sensor employing the drain-induced barrier-lowering (DIBL) effect with an incremental analog-to-digital converter (ADC) is presented. The proposed sensor features a compact size and achieves low-power operation utilizing a linearized leakage-current-to-temperature relationship. The incremental ADC is designed for digital readout in real-time.

title: Battery Abnormal Diagnosis of Electric Loader Based on Data Mining
authors: Qiang Zhang, Muxin He, Ni Lin
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Automation, Electronics and Electrical Engineering (AUTEEE)
abstract: In order to address battery degradation and inconsistency in electric loaders, this study proposes a data-driven fault diagnosis method based on cloud platform data. The approach combines t-SNE for dimensionality reduction, K-means for clustering, and a 3σ-MSS multi-level screening strategy to identify abnormal battery cells. Short-term and long-term deviation analyses were conducted. Results show that the proportion of deviated voltage is below 6%, which can be mitigated via balancing charging. The method supports early fault warning and maintenance intervention.

title: Modulation of THz transmission in AlGaN/GaN-based plasmonic crystals
authors: P. Sai, M. Dub, V. V. Korotyeyev, S. Winnerl, M. Mittendorff, W. Knap
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: We investigate two-dimensional (2D) plasmon resonances in AlGaN/GaN grating-gate plasmonic crystals under both linear (electric field of incoming radiation E<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">0</inf> < 0.1 kV/cm) and nonlinear (E<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">0</inf> ≈ 1–5 kV/cm) excitation regimes. THz Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy demonstrates that in the linear regime, THz transmission spectra can be electrically modulated by the excitation of different plasmon resonance modes. We identify delocalized plasmon (DLP) and localized plasmon (LP) modes, which arise under weak and strong modulation of the 2D electron gas (2DEG) concentration profile, respectively. Both modes are electrically controllable by gate voltage applied to the grating electrode.In the nonlinear regime, we observe a strong optically selfinduced modulation of THz transmission, with a maximum relative transmission change of 45% at a pump fluence as low as 350 nJ/cm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>, occurring under resonant excitation of the LP mode. This modulation exhibits an ultrafast relaxation time of ~15 ps. Our experimental results are supported by electrodynamic modeling, which takes into account the near-field localization under the grating electrodes, 2DEG heating, and the temperaturedependent effective electron mass. These findings provide insight into the fundamental nonlinear dynamics of plasmonic crystals and their potential for ultrafast THz modulation applications.

title: Physics-Informed Loss Functions for Enhancing Concrete Compressive Strength Prediction with Neural Networks
authors: Oğuz Akif Tüfekcioğlu, Mehmet Önder Efe
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: This study investigates the application of physics informed loss functions in the prediction of concrete compressive strength using neural networks. By integrating domain knowledge about monotonic relationships and other constraints into the loss calculation, we demonstrate improved model performance under data-scarce conditions. Comparisons are drawn against baseline neural networks to highlight the effectiveness of the physics-informed approach.

title: Leveraging Machine Learning and Optimization in Home Health Care: Emerging Trends and Future Opportunities
authors: Ghofran Massaoudi, Abir Chaabani
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: Home Health Care (HHC) delivers medical and personal care in patients’ homes, offering an alternative to hospital treatment. Growing demand due to aging populations and chronic diseases creates challenges in caregiver assignment, scheduling, and demand forecasting, leading to higher costs, caregiver burnout, and reduced patient satisfaction.To address these challenges, advanced computational approaches are increasingly explored. In particular, the integration of Machine Learning (ML) and Optimization (OPT) enables adaptive, data-driven solutions. This article explores traditional, metaheuristic, and hybrid methods to improve efficiency, analyzing current methodologies, challenges, limitations, and future research directions.

title: Multi UAV Collaborative Smoke Screen Planning under Full Occlusion Constraints: A Hybrid PSO Bayesian and ILP Computational Pipeline
authors: Kexu Yan, Junjie Zhai
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Automation, Electronics and Electrical Engineering (AUTEEE)
abstract: This paper addresses a decision-optimization problem for maximizing missile-target obscuration using UAV-deployed smoke screens in a simulation-based air-defense setting. A computational framework is proposed that couples a geometric visibility model (point-to-segment distance on missile–target sightlines with time discretization and cloud sinking dynamics) with trajectory–timing decision variables for single and multi-UAV deployment. The method integrates a hybrid search (particle swarm global exploration followed by Bayesian optimization refinement) for single-UAV scheduling and a discrete candidate–based integer linear program with constraint compression and set-cover structure for tri-UAV coordination. The objective function is evaluated via vectorized distance computations and adaptive time stepping; the perevaluation complexity is O(NI) for N time steps and I target samples, while the tri-UAV ILP is built on a reduced constraint family to curb combinatorial growth, yielding practical solve times with Top-K candidates per UAV. Experiments demonstrate extended full-occlusion duration over baselines while maintaining low runtime and memory footprint, underscoring robustness and deployability. The study contributes an efficient, scalable computational pipeline for smoke-screen path planning and timing under strict full-occlusion criteria.

title: On the Implementation of de Bruijn Sequence Generators with Higher Linear Complexity
authors: Suman Roy, Arighna Deb, Ujjwol Barman, Pradipta Dutta, Trupti Mayee Behera, Poulomee Ghosh
publish: 2025 5th IEEE International Conference on Applied Electromagnetics, Signal Processing, &amp; Communication (AESPC)
abstract: This paper presents a method for generating de Bruijn sequences with enhanced linear complexity using a word-based primitive $\sigma$-LFSR integrated with a nonlinear substitution box (S-box). Conventional $\sigma$-LFSRs, though efficient for hardware implementation, exhibit limited linear complexity, making them susceptible to cryptanalytic attacks. The proposed approach extends traditional LFSR-based de Bruijn sequence generation to a vectorized multi-input multi-output (MIMO) framework capable of exploiting the parallelism of modern processors. By inserting an all-zero vector into the state cycle of a primitive $\sigma$-LFSR and applying nonlinear bijective S-box transformations, the resulting vectorized de Bruijn sequence generators (DBSGs) achieve significantly higher linear complexities. Simulations validate the effectiveness of the proposed scheme, demonstrating that the component sequences are no longer cyclic shifts of one another, thereby increasing the overall linear complexity. The method offers a simple yet efficient architecture for generating high-complexity pseudorandom sequences suitable for cryptographic and communication applications.

title: Research on an Adaptive Task Offloading Model for Edge Nodes Based on Deep Reinforcement Learning
authors: Zhao Wanfang, Zhao Yan, Xu Jianghong
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Automation, Electronics and Electrical Engineering (AUTEEE)
abstract: To address the decision redundancy and poor adaptability of traditional algorithms for edge computing task offloading, this paper proposes a dynamic priority-layered deep deterministic policy gradient (DP-HDDPG) algorithm and constructs a "perception-decision-execution-feedback" adaptive task offloading model. This algorithm quantifies the matching degree between tasks and nodes through a dynamic priority evaluation system. It combines a two-level decision-making mechanism of "task layering-node matching" to reduce the decision space and optimize experience replay to improve training efficiency. A simulation platform built with NS-3 and TensorFlow is used to compare the performance with DDPG, Q-Learning, and a greedy algorithm based on 200 sets of multimodal experimental data (5-15 edge nodes, 10-50 task rates/second). Results show that under a high load of 50 tasks per second, the average latency of DP-HDDPG tasks was 82ms, a 23.1%, 36.0%, and 41.5% reduction compared to DDPG (106.6ms), Q-Learning (128.3ms), and the greedy algorithm (139.8ms), respectively. The system's total energy consumption was 12.3J (a 40.6% reduction compared to the greedy algorithm), and the task completion rate was 98.2% (3.1 percentage points higher than Q-Learning). During a two-hour stability experiment, latency fluctuation was only 7.7%, and the load balancing degree remained stable at 0.22-0.28, validating the algorithm's efficiency and stability.

title: Retraction Notice: IOT Security and Machine Learning Algorithms: Survey and Analysis
authors: Rachakonda Venkatesh, N. Malarvizhi
publish: 2023 7th International Conference on Trends in Electronics and Informatics (ICOEI)
abstract: The Internet of Things (IoT) establishes a web extension by combining physical components to arrange them self into shared objects. This creative observation can be utilized to transform a physical object mean something in the computerized world. The Internet of Things consists of devices that are constrained inside a resource such as rechargeable batteries, memory, as well as managing ability, and so forth. The Internet of Things aims to transform physical reality into artificially intelligent objects in the coming years. The Internet of Things (IoT) aims to combine all of that in the surroundings underneath a single infrastructure, giving us access to the objects around us maintaining us kept up-to-date on their situation. IoTs have a number of problems, including fading, energy use, data security, network security, etc. Machine Learning (ML) has also made substantial technological advances, opening up numerous study possibilities to address the present and future security challenges in IoT. ML is employed as a powerful tool to accomplish this objective, detecting threats and identifying abnormal behavior of intelligent networked devices. Following a thorough examination of the literature on IoT attacks and different machine learning methodologies, this survey article addresses the architecture of the IoT.

title: Explainable AI Planning:literature review
authors: Ali Abdelghafour Bejaoui, Meriam Jemel Hachicha, Nadia Ben Azzouna
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: Explainable AI Planning (XAIP) is a pivotal research area focused on enhancing the transparency, interpretability, and trustworthiness of automated planning systems. This paper provides a comprehensive review of XAIP, emphasizing key techniques for plan explanation, such as contrastive explanations, hierarchical decomposition, and argumentative reasoning frameworks. We explore the critical role of argumentation in justifying planning decisions and address the challenges of replanning in dynamic and uncertain environments, particularly in high-stakes domains like healthcare, autonomous systems, and logistics. Additionally, we discuss the ethical and practical implications of deploying XAIP, highlighting the importance of human-AI collaboration, regulatory compliance, and uncertainty handling. By examining these aspects, this paper aims to provide a detailed understanding of how XAIP can improve the transparency, interpretability, and usability of AI planning systems across various domains.

title: PEC-GAT: A Context-Aware Gated Transformer for Intelligent Bearing Life Prediction with Multi-Scale Position-Encoded Convolutions
authors: Xing Xiong, Junxiao Ren, Qiang Li, Chengxi Cao
publish: 2025 IEEE 31th International Conference on Parallel and Distributed Systems (ICPADS)
abstract: Accurately predicting the remaining useful life of a bearing is essential for predictive maintenance of industrial apparatus. Conventional Transformer models struggle to capture the local temporal relationships and essential time-step information present in vibration signals. This research introduces the PEC-GAT Transformer model for predicting the remaining useful life of bearings, which combines multi-scale positional encoding convolutions with a gated attention mechanism to tackle these issues. Multi-scale 1D convolutions capture local temporal data across diverse ranges, while trainable position embeddings and global scaling factors provide adaptive position encoding. A dual-gate attention mechanism amalgamates fundamental traits with overarching contextual information, dynamically modifying attention weights. Experiments demonstrate that the PEC-GAT method significantly improves the accuracy of predicting the remaining useful life of bearings and effectively overcomes the limitations of conventional Transformer models. This methodology offers a comprehensive and efficient intelligent prediction system for the control of industrial equipment health.

title: GeSn Terahertz Photomixer
authors: Wen-You Wang, Seyed Mostafa Latifi, Pouya Torkaman, Shang-Hua Yang
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: In this research work the terahertz (THz) emission characteristics of a GeSn THz photomixer are investigated. The device features a GeSn active layer, with lattice defects introduced by ion implantation to reduce the carrier lifetime to approximately 1 ps. Optical absorption and carrier collection are enhanced by plasmonic grating, leading to an improvement in THz generation efficiency. A heterodyne detection scheme is employed, and a dynamic range close to 45 dB is exhibited by the device. The potential of CMOS-compatible GeSn photomixers for scalable and cost-effective THz technologies is highlighted by this study.

title: GaAs Terahertz Extremely-Large-Area Emitter
authors: Seyed Mostafa Latifi, Yi-Jie Wang, Pouya Torkaman, Shang-Hua Yang
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: In this work, a Terahertz Extremely-Large-Area Emitter (THz ELAE) with a 1 cm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> active area is implemented to address directivity, tunability, and power limitations in conventional photoconductive antennas (PCAs). The enlarged active area of the device allows implementation of patterned optical excitation that enables control over the THz radiation characteristics in the spatial, temporal and spectral domains. The device was fabricated using i-line photolithography and a maximum peak-to-peak amplitude of 330 mV with 1.8 THz bandwidth was successfully measured using a THz time domain spectroscopy system when a bias voltage of 8 V and optical excitation of 200 mW was applied to the device.

title: ANGraph: A GNN-Based Performance Prediction Framework for Asynchronous Neuromorphic Hardware
authors: Yuan Hua, Jian Zhang, Jilin Zhang, Xiang Zhang, Hong Chen
abstract: Design space exploration (DSE) through system-level simulation is essential for designing energy-efficient asynchronous neuromorphic hardware, which is increasingly promising in edge AI applications. However, there are significant mismatches between system-level predictions and gate-level simulations, resulting in low precision when predicting performance during the DSE process for asynchronous neuromorphic hardware. To address this issue, we put forward ANGraph, a graph neural network (GNN)-based performance prediction framework for asynchronous neuromorphic hardware. In the ANGraph framework, we transform the intermediate representation of systemlevel simulations into graphs, collect gate-level circuit simulation results to build benchmarks with over one million samples, and train a GNN model to predict hardware latency for asynchronous neuromorphic hardware. Additionally, we use a residual network (ResNet)-based method to predict the power consumption of asynchronous neuromorphic hardware. We evaluate these two models on additional datasets without extra training across different scales, process nodes, and traffic patterns of input data. Compared to the latency predictions from the state-of-the-art simulator, we improve the R -square score by 0.69 and reduce root mean square error (RMSE) by 76% on average across all datasets. We also achieve an R-square score of 0.98 and a mean absolute percentage error (MAPE) of 0.88% for the power consumption prediction task. The benchmarks and models are available at https://github.com/HuaGuaiGuai/ANGraph.

title: IoT Cloud based Smart Agriculture Monitoring System with Mobile Application
authors: Yogeshwaran. A, Suriya Prakash T, Nandha Kumar R, Ragavendra A, Tamilarasu P
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Automation, Computing and Renewable Systems (ICACRS)
abstract: Agriculture is the backbone of the world economy, and improving the productivity and sustainability requires a consistent technological transformation. The smart system of the monitoring of agricultural parameters based on the Internet of Things (IoT) is the automatization of the acquisition of and monitoring of vital parameters of agriculture in real time. The ESP32 controller has sensors that constantly monitor the moisture levels in soil, temperatures, humidity, and pH levels of soil. Data obtained is sent to a cloud platform through Wi-Fi allowing farmers to view real-time analytics using a mobile application like Adafruit to make effective decisions. It also involves an automated irrigation mechanism that maximizes the use of water, saves on labour and increases crop production. The proposed system will embrace data analytics, cloud computing, and renewable energy in real-time so as to enhance the use of resources and sustainability unlike the earlier models that could not achieve this with lack of cloud computing and real-time data analytics. Experimental study indicates that the given framework has the possibility to boost productivity and minimize waste in small-scale farms. Therefore, the system suggested is an intelligent, stable and sustainable solution to the contemporary agricultural management.

title: Research on a Cross-Domain Diagnosis Method for Interturn Insulation Condition of Dry-Type Reactors Based on Deep Transfer Learning
authors: Minhu Xu, Chengnan Cui, Yun Guo, Liang Zhang, Zhongyuan Li, Limin Qu
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Automation, Electronics and Electrical Engineering (AUTEEE)
abstract: Dry-type reactors are core components of power systems. Interturn insulation defects in dry-type reactors can easily lead to partial discharge and even insulation breakdown, posing a serious threat to power grid security. However, cross-domain diagnosis challenges caused by different models and complex operating conditions, as well as the small sample size problem in the target domain, restrict the performance of traditional diagnostic models. To address this issue, a dual-branch attention transfer network (BAN-TL) is proposed: the feature extraction branch is based on an improved ResNet-18 and embeds a frequency-domain attention module (FAM). This improves feature recognition by enhancing the 500MHz-1GHz fault frequency band and suppressing the interference frequency band. The domain adaptation branch employs a three-layer fully connected domain discriminator and combines an improved MMD with a center loss to construct a hybrid loss function, balancing cross-domain adaptation and fault classification. The two branches form a collaborative optimization closed loop through a feature interaction layer. A dataset was constructed based on three source domain models (10kV/20kV/35kV, 240,000 data sets) and two target domain models (15kV/25kV, 32,000 small sample sets) to compare the TL-ResNet, DAN, and JAN algorithms. Simulations show that BAN-TL achieves an overall accuracy of 96.2%/95.8% in the 15kV/25kV target domains, a 12.3%/11.7% improvement over TL-ResNet (83.9%/84.1%). The accuracy of local aging conditions reaches 94.1%/93.8%, 15.8%/15.3% higher than TL-ResNet. Even at a noise intensity of 0.2, the accuracy remains at 90.3%/89.7%, with a cross-domain feature distance of only 3.1-3.2. This effectively solves the challenge of cross-domain small-sample diagnosis of dry-type reactor interturn insulation, providing technical support for the safe operation of power grids.

title: Research on Data Fusion Intelligent Decision Models in Software Engineering
authors: Nan Li, Zhigang Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Automation, Electronics and Electrical Engineering (AUTEEE)
abstract: This study designs a fusion framework adapted to multi-source heterogeneous data and proposes a dynamic weighted data fusion decision algorithm (DW-IAM) based on an improved attention mechanism. This algorithm addresses the static limitations and noise robustness of traditional algorithms through a data quality assessment module (quantifying completeness, relevance, and timeliness), an improved attention weight module (implementing quality-driven dynamic weight allocation), and an adaptive noise filtering module (using a dynamic threshold to eliminate low-quality data). Experiments were conducted using the NASA MDP defect dataset (1089 modules) and the REPOS requirement dataset (238 requirements), comparing the traditional weighted average (WAA), fixed-attention (Fixed-Att), and Bayesian reasoning (Bayes-F) algorithms. Results show that DW-IAM achieves 88.6% accuracy on the full NASA MDP data set, a 6.1 percentage point improvement over Fixed-Att. Its F1 score on the REPOS dataset remains at 76.9% even with 20% noise, and its decision latency is less than 20ms, meeting real-time engineering requirements and forming a practical "data fusion - intelligent decision-making" solution.

title: A lexicographic bi-objective approach to fleet sizing and routing for service vehicles in a real-world passenger transport system
authors: Bouchra Z. Ben Messabih, Walid Behiri, Sana Belmokhtar-Berraf, Tesseda Boukherroub, Abderrahim Sahli, Iskander Zouaghi
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: The Société de transport de Montréal (STM), a public transport agency in Montreal (Quebec, Canada), has committed to electrifying its entire vehicle fleet as part of its broader sustainability initiatives. This research addresses a critical challenge that arises from this commitment: optimizing the deployment and dispatching of electric service vehicles assigned to operations supervisors to ensure minimal disruption to the bus network. The problem is formulated as a mixed-integer linear program that minimizes the number of deployed vehicles and total response time using a lexicographic approach. The effectiveness of our approach is evaluated through computational experiments using the commercial CPLEX optimization solver. This research provides the STM with a valuable strategic and operational decision-support tool, aimed at optimizing the size and deployment of its new electric vehicle fleet, therefore supporting its sustainability objectives.

title: Entropy-Aware AI-Powered Ransomware Detection Using IBM FlashCore Module 4 in SAN Environments
authors: Genka Slavova-Torres
abstract: Ransomware poses a critical risk to storage networks, demanding fast and accurate detection. This work presents an entropy-aware, AI-powered method for identifying ransomware in SAN environments using IBM FlashCore Module 4. By analyzing data entropy in real time, the system detects anomalous write patterns while leveraging FlashCore Module 4’s high-speed processing for low-latency response. The study demonstrates the potential of combining computational storage and intelligent analytics to enhance enterprise-level ransomware defense.

title: Intelligent research and design of sound control switch
authors: Huiqin Lu
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Automation, Electronics and Electrical Engineering (AUTEEE)
abstract: Traditional voice-controlled switches have disadvantages such as being affected by the environment, limited by voice, safety hazards, and high costs. In order to address these issues, this article aims to research and design an intelligent voice-controlled switch to facilitate people's lives. This switch uses sound and light control and human body sensing technology to automatically control the on/off of the light bulb based on people's voice and movements. The article first introduces the basic principles and applications of sound and light control and human body sensing technology, and then elaborates on the design and implementation process of this intelligent switch in detail, including hardware design and software programming. In terms of hardware design, a PCB board and a series of sensors and actuators are used to achieve the functions of sound and human body sensing. In terms of software programming, the program is written in C language to achieve automatic control and status display of the switch. To meet practical needs, the STC89C52 microcontroller is used as the central device of the intelligent switch. The microcontroller has programmable advantages, and by using control circuits such as sound and light control and infrared detection, the intelligent research and design of the voice-controlled switch is finally achieved. Finally, this article tests and evaluates the performance of the intelligent switch, and the results show that the switch has high reliability and stability, and can effectively improve people's quality of life.

title: Advances in personalised nutrition for older adults the potential for AI in preventing and treating malnutrition
authors: Marion Hetherington
publish: 2025 IEEE Cyber Science and Technology Congress (CyberSciTech)
abstract: The increase in population ageing with increasing lifespan and falling birthrates has produced a demographic shift worldwide. This highlights the need to enhance the number of additional years of life free from chronic disease and disabilities of aging (called "health-span"). An important contribution to health and wellbeing is optimal nutrition, but older adults experience anorexia of ageing, causing low food intakes, poor dietary quality, leading to malnutrition. As nations contend with ageing populations, potential AI solutions have been developed for prevention and treatment of malnutrition in old age. This offers pathways to extend health-span as lifespan increases globally. However, adoption of AI solutions is challenging for older adults and their caregivers. The availability and functionality of smart technology are far greater than the evidence base to support user-sensitive design options. AI solutions can play a valuable role in preventing malnutrition among older adults through early detection, personalized nutrition, and remote care coordination. They can also contribute to treatment, with specific interventions, meal planning and medical monitoring but evidence of efficacy is at an early stage. Similarly, our understanding of the social, psychological and biological factors underpinning the anorexia of ageing requires further investigation. As crosstalk between nutrition and computing science improves so the development of AI aids to enhance health-span will increase.

title: High-purity generation of terahertz vortices with the high-order topological charge utilizing soft-aperture DFG
authors: Mizuki Adachi, Yuzuru Sakai, Hayato Fujishiro, Katsuhiko Miyamoto
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: We demonstrate high-purity orbital angular momentum terahertz (THz) vortex generation based on soft-aperture difference frequency generation (DFG) with an organic 4-N, N-dimethylamino-4’-N’-methyl stilbazolium tosylate (DAST) crystal. This system enables the generation of THz vortices with the topological charges of ℓ = ± 3 and ±4 while operating within a frequency range of 3 – 6 THz. The relative intensity for the soft-aperture DFG method exceeds 80%, which indicates high-purity THz vortices compared to the conventional approach with a spiral phase plate.

title: A Hybrid Optimization Framework for Dynamic Multi-Objective Problems Using NSGA-II and Deep Reinforcement Learning
authors: Xinqi Wang, Yuxin Tang, Xuetao Cui
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Automation, Electronics and Electrical Engineering (AUTEEE)
abstract: Dynamic multi-objective optimization problems (DMOPPs) are prevalent in complex engineering and management systems, where decision-makers must balance conflicting objectives under dynamically changing conditions. Existing methods often struggle to simultaneously achieve global search capabilities and real-time adaptability. To address this challenge, this paper proposes a novel hybrid optimization framework that synergizes the strengths of evolutionary algorithms and deep reinforcement learning. The framework is structured around three core components: a multi-objective optimization model to define the problem space, a multi-agent game-theoretic model to capture strategic interactions between system entities, and a spatial-aware resource allocation module. We employ the Non-dominated Sorting Genetic Algorithm II (NSGA-II) to explore the global Pareto-optimal solution space in an offline stage. Subsequently, a Deep Deterministic Policy Gradient (DDPG) agent, a form of deep reinforcement learning, is utilized for online, fine-grained policy adjustments in response to real-time system feedback. The framework's efficacy is validated on a complex system simulation, demonstrating its ability to effectively manage system trade-offs, mitigate negative externalities (e.g., congestion or resource depletion), and maintain high operational efficiency. This work provides a robust and generalizable paradigm for solving a significant class of DMOPPs.

title: Fundamental Study of a Terahertz Scanner Using Parametric Wavelength Conversion
authors: Kouya Tsubota, Sota Mine, Kodo Kawase, Kosuke Murate
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: We conducted a fundamental study on a terahertz scanner capable of imaging in a single scan using an injection-seeded terahertz parametric generator (is-TPG) and terahertz-wave parametric detection. Imaging of samples with millimeter-order resolution was demonstrated.

title: Comparative Study of Web Attack Detection on WAF: Gradient Boosting and Neural Networks for HTTP Traffic Classification
authors: Cristian Chindrus, Constantin F. Caruntu
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: As cyber-attacks on web applications evolve, machine learning models for Web Application Firewalls (WAFs) should become more sophisticated. Gradient Boosting and Neural Networks are applied to a dataset of HTTP traffic (CIC-IDS2017), which includes features such as request methods, timestamps, response codes, and user agents, extracted for anomaly detection. Gradient Boosting, an ensemble method that builds sequential decision trees, effectively handles class imbalance and complex patterns in the data. Neural Networks, while highly flexible and capable of capturing complex relationships, face challenges with overfitting due to the relatively small dataset. The performance of these two advanced methods is compared with previous results from Random Forest and Support Vector Machines, demonstrating clear improvements in accuracy and F1-score with Gradient Boosting, while Neural Networks demonstrate potential, especially with access to larger datasets. This study highlights the benefits of using more advanced techniques for HTTP traffic analysis and provides a comparison framework to guide future WAF model development.

title: Integrating Large Language Model and Lightweight Network for Robust Multimodal Fault Diagnosis in Wheeled Robots
authors: Tianyi Ye, Xianfeng Yuan, Jianjie Liu, Xiaoxue Mei, Xiaoru Niu, Yong Song, Fengyu Zhou
abstract: As robots are increasingly integrated into industrial applications, robust fault diagnosis is becoming increasingly crucial to ensure operational safety and minimize unplanned downtime. Graph neural networks have emerged as a promising solution for handling multisensor fault diagnosis tasks, but conventional approaches for constructing spatial–temporal graphs from robotic sensor data tend to rely on either static physical knowledge or purely statistical relationships, each with inherent limitations in changing operational contexts. To address these challenges, this article proposes a novel hybrid architecture driven by large language model (LLM), which integrates global physical knowledge with localized statistical patterns to guide the dynamic construction of spatial–temporal graphs. A concrete operational method is further proposed to structure textual inputs for the LLM, allowing it to integrate domain knowledge, task objectives, and fusion logic into graph representations that are physically grounded and responsive to real-time conditions. Building on the outputs of this LLM-driven process, we design a lightweight spatial–temporal graph network that incorporates the dynamically generated graphs into fault inference. Finally, we validate our approach on two real-world robot platforms, and demonstrating notable improvements in diagnostic accuracy, adaptability, and robustness compared with existing state-of-the-art methods.

title: A Hybrid Statistical and Web-based Framework for Accurate Sales Forecasting using SARIMAX
authors: Rajasathiya K, Palanikumar R, Elango R, Brindha G, Sudha Juliet P, Ramya R
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Automation, Computing and Renewable Systems (ICACRS)
abstract: This paper presents an intelligent, data-driven forecasting system based on the Seasonal AutoRegressive Integrated Moving Average with Exogenous Variables (SARIMAX) model. The proposed system integrates machine learning algorithms with modern web technologies to create an end-to-end forecasting platform that is accurate, scalable, and user-friendly. The system utilizes the seasonal autoregressive moving average model to capture both seasonal trends and external factors influencing sales. The optimal parameters are auto-tuned using AIC minimization, and the model generates future sales forecasts with confidence intervals indicating prediction reliability. Through this implementation, the system demonstrates how statistical forecasting techniques can be combined with modern Web frameworks to provide practical, explainable, and efficient business intelligence tools.

title: Cryogen-Free High-Heat-Load Packaging of a surface emitting THz QCL
authors: Léo Hetier, Sebastian Gloor, Adrian Weisenhorn, Mattias Beck, Jérôme Faist, Giacomo Scalari, Richard Maulini
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: We present a high-heat-load (HHL) packaged terahertz quantum cascade laser (THz QCL) designed for cryogen-free operation. Using a four-stage Peltier cooler, we achieve stable laser operation at 185K, eliminating the need for liquid nitrogen or Stirling coolers. The QCL features a planar patch array antenna, reducing beam divergence, and is enclosed in an HHL package with a CuW insert and an AR-coated silicon window. Output power, emission spectra, and beam profiling confirm the device performance. This work demonstrates the feasibility of compact, cryogen-free THz QCL systems targeting real-world applications.

title: Priority-Based Fault Reordering for Reducing Memory Repair Time
authors: Siyeong Park, Hayoung Lee
abstract: As semiconductor memory densities continue to increase, the number of faulty cells has risen sharply, causing repair times in ATE-based redundancy analysis to grow significantly. This paper proposes a fault-reordering technique that classifies in-group faults into bi-directional sharing faults (Bi-D) and single-axis sharing faults (Si-A), then iteratively applies a Bi-D filtering stage to optimize the DFS search order. The proposed method achieves approximately a 5% reduction in repair time compared to conventional redundancy analysis algorithms. By following a Fail-First heuristic that front-loads the highest-constraint faults, it demonstrates consistent reductions in backtracking cost across a variety of parameter settings.

title:
Generalized Predictive Proportional Integral Controller Robust Stability Design
                    <sup>*</sup>
authors: Alejandro Rojas, Pedro Muñoz, Hugo Garcés
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: This work tackles the challenge of ensuring closed-loop stability for discrete-time first-order plant models with significant time delays, regardless of their stability, amidst uncertainties in plant gain, pole, or time delays. We propose a generalized predictive proportional integral (GPPI) controller designed specifically for these discrete-time plant models. Our primary objective is to ensure robust stability in the face of uncertainties related to plant gain, pole, and time delay. The design of the GPPI controller is founded on a complementary sensitivity approach, and when necessary, it is further developed into a two-degree-of-freedom controller to separate reference tracking from the design aiming for robust closed-loop stability. We validate the effectiveness of our robust stability design through simulations that include both stable and unstable plant models with considerable time delays.

title: Continuous-Wave Terahertz Imaging of Embedded Multi-Dimensional Codes in 3D-Printed Polyamide Components
authors: J. Kutz, N. Vieweg, M. Naftaly, K. Wenzel, R. B. Kohlhaas, M. Schell
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: For the first time, we demonstrate the use of continuous-wave terahertz imaging for code identification in 3Dprinted samples for applications such as quality assurance, anti-counterfeiting and supply chain management. We embed invisible coded structures within the body of 3D-printed polyamide components using selective laser sintering. While the plastic component is built up by sintering polyamide powder, the code is formed in-situ by leaving cavities of unmolten powder. These codes are non-destructively identified using continuous wave terahertz imaging. Various multi-dimensional codes are examined. We vary the type of the code and the depth of the structure beneath the surface and make use of the depth resolution, a unique feature of our terahertz instrument. All embedded features can be clearly identified.

title: How do objects in the beam affect terahertz communication channels?
authors: Felix Gorka, Martin Koch, Daniel M. Mittleman, Enrique Castro-Camus
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: We present broadband THz-TDS measurements with a highly defocused beam to investigate shadowing and scattering effects in LOS communication channels. A custom-made segmented spherical mirror of 0.6 m diameter is utilized for refocusing the divergent THz beam after a total of 3.5 m propagation in air and the attenuation caused by everyday objects in the beam is measured. To investigate the deviation of simple geometric shadowing by the objects, we employ Fresnel’s diffraction theory. Consequently, we aim to test the limits of geometric optics in the description of THz beam propagation in LOS communication channels.

title: Gain-Switching UIO against Disturbance with Lossy Multiple Measurement
authors: Kenji Sugimoto, Toshimitsu Ushio
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: This paper studies a switching state estimation technique to address temporary measurment signal loss. Under certain conditions on system matrices and a signal loss pattern, we propose a UIO (unknown input observer) with gain switching against unknown disturbance input and lossy multiple output, provided that the signal loss is detected in the local side in real time. It turns out that by the proposed method a weighted square norm of the estimation error converges to zero for any such disturbance and observation signal loss. The switching gains are designed by solving LMIs (linear matrix inequalities) simultaneously. Numerical simulation has been carried out to evaluate the proposed method in comparison with a DO(disturbance observer) with gain switching.

title: Prompt-Guided Large Language Models for Scheduling Optimization: A Comparative Study with Metaheuristics
authors: Yuqi Han, Shengluo Yang, Shuoxin Yin
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Big Data, Artificial Intelligence and Internet of Things Engineering (ICBAIE)
abstract: This paper presents a hybrid framework for job shop and flow shop scheduling that combines constraint-aware prompting with Large Language Models (LLMs) and a lightweight Genetic Algorithm (GA) refinement. The prompt template encodes precedence and machine constraints in natural language and requests the model to generate complete schedules. The GA module corrects infeasible outputs and improves solution quality. Experients on six benchmark instances compare the method against metaheuristics, hybrid baselines. Results show that the proposed LLM+Prompt* approach consistently outperforms unconstrained LLMs and achieves performance competitive metaheuristics, demonstrating the potential of LLMs as heuristic generators for combinatorial optimization.

title: Analysis and Investigation of Tunnel Monitoring Data by Wavelet Transform Modulus Maxima
authors: Xiangxing Kong
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Big Data, Artificial Intelligence and Internet of Things Engineering (ICBAIE)
abstract: Wavelet analysis has become an indispensable methodology in interdisciplinary domains encompassing signal analysis, feature identification, and structural integrity surveillance. This research undertakes a systematic performance comparison among three wavelet-based noise suppression methodologies: modulus maxima, wavelet packet decomposition, and coefficient thresholding. By conducting an in-depth examination of their operational characteristics and implementation frameworks, distinct application domains for each technique are delineated. Experimental validation is performed utilizing synthetically generated signals contaminated with Gaussian noise to fine-tune pivotal parameters within the modulus maxima framework. The optimized methodology exhibits outstanding efficacy in processing shield tunnel monitoring datasets, successfully isolating structural response signatures while attenuating instrumentation noise. The refined data outputs furnish dependable foundations for subsequent tunnel integrity evaluations, thereby affirming the engineering viability of the proposed approach.

title: Domain Adaptation of Large Language Models for Biodiversity Information Extraction
authors: Lianjie Li, Bingbing Ding, Lisha Liang, ZhaoYi Chen, Yue Lin, Jinji She
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Big Data, Artificial Intelligence and Internet of Things Engineering (ICBAIE)
abstract: Biodiversity conservation critically depends on timely and accurate access to ecological knowledge, much of which exists in unstructured text such as assessment reports, policy documents, and scientific literature. While large language models (LLMs) have achieved impressive general-purpose natural language processing performance, their effectiveness in specialized environmental domains remains limited. In this paper, we present a domain adaptation study of Qwen-7B for biodiversity information extraction using data from the IUCN Red List. We construct a high-quality dataset by preprocessing and annotating species assessment records into four target categories: species, threats, locations, and conservation measures. The model is fine-tuned with parameter-efficient strategies (LoRA and QLoRA) on this dataset, enabling efficient training on A100 GPU. Experiments show that the fine-tuned model significantly surpasses the baseline, with an F1 gain of more than 18 points under the standard threshold. Case analyses further indicate enhanced semantic accuracy, particularly in species identification and threat extraction. Overall, the results underscore the value of domain-adapted LLMs for biodiversity monitoring and conservation decision support.

title: Physics-Informed Token Prediction Based Dynamic Modeling and High-speed Feedforward Tracking Control of Dielectric Elastomer Actuators
authors: Xingyu Chen, Xiaotian Shi, Peinan Yan, Jieji Ren, Guoying Gu, Jiang Zou
abstract: Due to their continuous electromechanical deformation, rate-dependent viscoelasticity, and complex mechanical vibration, dynamic modeling and high-speed tracking control of dielectric elastomer actuators (DEAs) remain elusive, significantly limiting their working bandwidth. In this work, we propose a Physics-Informed Token Prediction (PITP) that enables accurate modeling of DEA dynamics and high-speed feedforward tracking control. The PITP framework consists of two key components: a physics-informed encoder and a dynamic decoder. The physics-informed encoder is designed based on a simplified equivalent linear model and trained through the hierarchical optimization training method, which embeds the global dynamic characteristics into tokens, minimizing the need for extensive data and training. Then, the dynamic decoder is developed by using these tokens as state-dependent parameters, capable of describing complex dynamic responses through the autoregressive solution. Finally, by taking advantage of the model's reversibility, a direct inverse compensator is established to linearize the input-output relationship. Experimental results of several DEAs with different configurations and payloads demonstrate that, based on our PITP framework, the complex nonlinear dynamic responses of all DEAs can be precisely described and eliminated within their natural frequency, validating its generality and versatility. By leveraging fast modeling (<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$< $</tex-math></inline-formula>30 minutes) and high-speed feedforward tracking control, our PITP framework may accelerate DEAs' practical applications.

title: Confined THz Tamm Modes in Zero-Dimensional Cavities
authors: I. Abdourahamane, A. Wietzke, S. Messelot, S. Coeymans, C. Symonds, J. Tignon, S. Dhillon, B. Kuhlmey, J. Mangeney
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: We report on the confinement of THz Tamm modes in 0D Tamm cavities consisting of a finite-sized metallic disk deposited on a distributed Bragg reflector. Reflectivity spectra measurements reveal high quality factors of 490 and 310 for 0D Tamm cavities resonating at 308 GHz and 684 GHz, respectively. Both experimental results and theoretical analysis demonstrate the confinement of the Tamm modes in all three spatial dimensions. The modal dispersion relations of Tamm 0D cavities, measured using an angle-resolved spectroscopy experiment, exhibit discrete energy modes in contrast to the parabolic dispersion relation measured for a Tamm 2D cavity. Electromagnetic simulations show the lateral confinement of the Tamm mode beneath the metallic disk. These 0D Tamm resonators hold great potential for ultra-strong coupling to 0D quantum systems, such as artificial atoms or molecules.

title: Power Enhancement Strategies of PV System under Shading Conditions -A Multifaceted Macro Review
authors: Gutta. C. Prabhakar, Belwin. J. Bearearly
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Automation, Computing and Renewable Systems (ICACRS)
abstract: Partial shading (PS) is a prevailing situation raised due to the shadow casting of the static and dynamic obstacles on the photovoltaic (PV) system leading to the reduction in power generation. The reduction in output power depends on numerous factors such as characteristics of cell or module type, shading pattern, irradiance and temperature levels. This paper reviews and provides a macrolevel state of the art strategies to mitigate the effect of partial shading on the PV system and indeed option of power enhancement strategies at the module and array level. Here, the five methods, namely the PV cell technology, the maximum power point tracking (MPPT) method, the module level integrated converter, the equalization circuit and the array reconfiguration methods are covered. In this paper a new mitigating method based on PV cell technology is exclusively evaluated and compared with various methods. Besides updating the key aspects of technologies, this work serves as an informative resource for the researchers and budding learners in the thrust area of power enhancement under PS conditions.

title: The impact mechanism of perceived AI interaction style on citizen experience of innovative smart cities in China
authors: Hong Tao, Zhengang Zhang
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: China’s innovative smart cities face urgent challenges of low citizen experience and participation rates, necessitating a transition from government-led to market-driven development. While existing research predominantly examines macro-level development status and evaluation systems, this study addresses the micro-level gap by investigating how perceived AI interaction styles (task vs. social) influence citizen experience through a structural equation model (SEM) based on first-hand survey data from more than 300 citizens in smart Guangzhou. The results reveal that citizen adjustment fully mediates both interaction styles’ impact on citizen experience. Brand involvement amplifies these effects, with higher involvement strengthening the mediation pathways. Theoretically, this research integrates Sociotechnical Systems Theory and Brand Community Theory to propose a novel "Technology – Emotion - Community" framework, advancing scholarly understanding of human-AI synergy in urban governance. Practically, it guides policymakers to resolve citizen experience dilemmas by advocating differentiated AI strategies, thereby accelerating market-oriented smart city transitions through stakeholder collaboration.

title: Flexible conductive polymer metalenses for THz light engineering
authors: Simonas Driukas, Rusnė Ivaškevičiūtė-Povilauskienė, Vladislovas Čižas, Linas Labanauskas, Ernestas Nacius, Gintaras Valušis
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: One of the paths of innovation in the field of photonics and electronics is the strive to increase the integration possibilities for more compact and accessible platforms. For example, wearable biosensors which require compact design and often even flexibility have attracted much attention. In this study, we expand the research on wearable textile devices by exploring wearable and flexible photonics by the development of solution-processed metamaterial-based lenses.Resonant metalenses for 0.3 Terahertz (THz) frequency were designed, fabricated and characterized. Our results show that all the conductive polymer-based metalenses exhibit good focusing capabilities, achieving full width at half maximum (FWHM) of 0.61λ and focal spot intensities of up to 1.6 times higher than the incident field. Furthermore, focusing properties are preserved under limited mechanical bending.Our findings demonstrate the first ever study on solution processed conductive polymer metalenses in which effective focusing is realized. The proposed design and technological approaches aim to support future advancements in wearable biosensing and other THz optoelectronics.

title: CLASP: Contrastive Learning with Asymmetric Stochastic Patching for Anomaly Detection
authors: Zhenchang Xia, Ke Xu, Chengyi Qiu, Yuqi Zhou, Hanyuan Hang
publish: 2025 IEEE 31th International Conference on Parallel and Distributed Systems (ICPADS)
abstract: Reliable anomaly detection in multivariate time series is essential for distributed sensor networks, industrial IoT platforms, and cloud-edge infrastructures, where failures or attacks must be identified promptly to ensure system reliability and security. The task is challenging due to the scarcity and diversity of anomalies and the limited availability of labeled data in heterogeneous environments. To tackle these challenges, we propose CLASP (Contrastive Learning with Asymmetric Stochastic Patching), a framework that integrates clustering-guided patch mining, asymmetric augmentation, and stochastic patch exchange to provide strong contrastive supervision. This design enables the model to capture subtle and localized anomalies while preserving normal temporal dynamics. Experiments on five benchmark datasets-covering server logs, industrial control systems, and spacecraft telemetry-show that CLASP consistently outperforms competitive baselines, improving the average F1-score by 7.4 %. Well-suited for deployment in real-world distributed and ubiquitous computing environments, CLASP establishes a principled basis for robust anomaly detection, with future work targeting real-time edge deployments.

title: Non-contact temperature sensing through non-transparent containers by THz spectroscopy
authors: S. Tachikawa, M. Kinoshita, N. Ishiwata, Y. Shimizu
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: Non-contact temperature sensing techniques through opaque obstacles or inside non-transparent containers are in great need in various fields. In this study, we propose a spectroscopic technique using terahertz waves for measuring temperature inside containers made of non-transparent materials in the visible to near-infrared range. We performed terahertz spectroscopy on water vapor inside a polypropylene container and observed the decrease in the absorption intensities as the temperature increased. The obtained temperature dependence of the absorption intensities suggests the feasibility of a non-contact temperature sensing over non-transparent obstacles.

title: Hyperspectral Terahertz Spatial Light Modulator for Single-pixel Imaging
authors: Wenjing Ma, Zibo Lin, Yiwen Sun, Xudong Liu
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: Existing electronically controlled terahertz (THz) spatial light modulators (SLMs) rely on metamaterial resonant effects, limiting their operational bandwidth. This work presents a hyperspectral electronically controlled 10×10 THz SLM. Each pixel consists of a Schottky diode structure formed by metal microslits and an n-doped epitaxial GaAs layer, serving as real-time tunable, spectrally sensitive spatial masks for terahertz imaging with a single-pixel detector. We developed a single-pixel THz camera capable of spatial imaging without moving components.

title: Feature-Based Robust Multimodal Image Registration
authors: Huajin Sun, Jiang Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE 31th International Conference on Parallel and Distributed Systems (ICPADS)
abstract: Multimodal image registration seeks to establish spatial correspondences between images from different modalities. However, the generalization of existing methods to diverse multimodal scenarios remains limited due to significant modality gaps. To address this challenge, we propose CrossNet, a feature-based multimodal registration framework that integrates automated keypoint detection, cross-modal descriptor extraction, and correspondence consistency enforcement through constraints on intermediate feature maps. To further enhance robustness and minimize annotation requirements, we introduce a cross-supervision strategy that promotes consistent predictions, generates pseudo-aligned images, and leverages unlabeled image pairs during training. Extensive experiments across a variety of multimodal settings demonstrate that CrossNet significantly reduces the reliance on aligned training data while achieving state-of-the-art performance in both feature matching and image registration tasks.

title: GTree: A Trie-Based Alignment-Free Clustering Framework for Efficient DNA Data Storage and Enhanced Error Resilience
authors: Linxuan Han, Guanjin Qu, Zihui Yan, Huaming Wu
publish: 2025 IEEE 31th International Conference on Parallel and Distributed Systems (ICPADS)
abstract: With the rapid advancements in information technologies, global data volumes have increased exponentially. Deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA)-based data storage has gained significant attention due to its superior storage capacity and long-term preservation potential compared to traditional media. However, during this process, DNA sequences may be affected by errors such as deletions, insertions, and substitutions, resulting in altered copies of the original sequence. Furthermore, the sequences in the DNA pool lack inherent order, preventing direct access to specific fragments. In this paper, we propose GTree, a trie-based DNA clustering framework tailored for DNA data storage. GTree achieves both high accuracy and low runtime complexity. It introduces a lightweight pre-screening module that combines Q-gram feature extraction, MinHash signatures, and Locality Sensitive Hashing (LSH) indexing to efficiently reduce the comparison space. A majority-label voting mechanism is also integrated to enhance clustering robustness in the presence of sequencing errors. Finally, we validate the performance of GTree through clustering experiments on both real biological and simulated datasets, demonstrating its superior performance.

title: Design of a YOLO Model Integrating Multi-Scale Features for Remote Sensing Image Recognition
authors: Mu Weijie, Qin Peng, Cheng Dapeng, Jiang Haibo
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Automation, Electronics and Electrical Engineering (AUTEEE)
abstract: To address the problem of insufficient detection accuracy of traditional YOLO models due to the "dense small targets, large scale differences, and susceptibility to occlusion" in remote sensing images, this paper designs an innovative YOLO model integrating multi-scale features. First, a dynamic receptive field multi-scale feature extraction module is constructed, using three parallel branches with differentiated expansion rates and gating units to selectively capture features of targets at different scales. Second, an attention-driven adaptive feature fusion strategy is proposed, dynamically allocating cross-layer feature weights to enhance the utilization of details in small targets and semantic information in large targets. Finally, a small target weight factor and a hard sample mining coefficient are introduced on top of the CIoU loss to optimize the model's learning bias. Experiments are conducted using the NWPU VHR-10 and a self-made UAV remote sensing dataset as test sets, comparing YOLOv5s, YOLOv7-tiny, and YOLOv8s models. Results show that on the NWPU VHR-10 dataset, the proposed model achieves 92.3% mAP@0.5 (a 3.2% improvement over YOLOv8s) and 88.7% mAP-small (a 5.1% improvement); on the self-made dataset, mAP@0.5 reaches 90.5% (a 2.8% improvement), while maintaining an FPS of 28 frames/second (on par with YOLOv8s). This research demonstrates that the proposed model can effectively improve the accuracy of multi-scale target detection in remote sensing images, while also considering real-time performance, making it suitable for scenarios such as land monitoring and agricultural yield estimation.

title: Non-destructive Detection and Visualization of Clenbuterol in Pork Using High-Resolution Raman Imaging
authors: Tianzhen Yin, Yankun Peng, Yongyu Li
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Big Data, Artificial Intelligence and Internet of Things Engineering (ICBAIE)
abstract: Clenbuterol, as an illegal ${\beta}$-adrenergic agonist, is illicitly used in animal husbandry, leading to residues in meat products that pose a serious threat to public health. Although conventional detection methods (e.g., chromatography-mass spectrometry) offer high sensitivity, they suffer from inherent drawbacks such as complex sample preparation, long detection cycles, being destructive in nature, and the inability to provide spatial distribution information of contaminants. To overcome these limitations, this study proposed and validated a novel method based on high-resolution Raman imaging for the non-destructive, rapid detection and visualization of clenbuterol in pork. Through the systematic optimization of a custom-built Raman imaging system, including adjusting the working distance between the objective lens and the sample to 175 mm and setting the camera pixel binning value to 2, the signal acquisition efficiency and detection sensitivity were significantly enhanced. To counteract the strong fluorescence background from the pork matrix, the adaptive iteratively reweighted penalized least squares (airPLS) algorithm was employed for effective baseline correction. The core innovation of this study is the proposal of a “Pixel Ratio Method,” which establishes a precise quantitative model by identifying and quantifying pixels corresponding to the characteristic Raman peak of clenbuterol at $1600 \mathrm{~cm}^{-1}$. The results showed that the method exhibited an excellent linear relationship $\left(R^{2}=0.99\right)$ within the concentration range of $0.04 \%$ to $0.2 \%(\mathrm{w} / \mathrm{w})$, with a limit of detection (LOD) as low as $0.04 \%$ and a root mean square error of prediction (RMSEP) of only $0.0058 \%$. Crucially, this technique achieved the visualization of the spatial distribution of clenbuterol within pork tissue for the first time. Compared to traditional detection methods, this technique offers significant advantages of being non-destructive, rapid, and accurate, enabling the visualization of clenbuterol distribution in pork and providing a powerful new paradigm for food safety inspection.

title: Comparative Analysis of Algorithms for Detection and Classification of UAV in Video Surveillance
authors: Ivan Garvanov, Miroslav Tsintsarski, Magdalena Garvanova
abstract: This article presents a comparative analysis of the deep learning models MobileNetV2 and MobileNetV3, designed for mobile devices and convenient for use with stationary and mobile cameras for detection and classification of unmanned aerial vehicles (drones). The models are studied and compared under the same test scenarios. From the results obtained, conclusions and recommendations are made for the practical use of the models for detection and classification of drones in a real environment.

title: Physics-based Electrochemical Model of a Proton Exchange Membrane Water Electrolyzer
authors: Nicolas Vignal, Zhongliang Li, Benoit Latour, Daniel Hissel
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: This article presents the electrochemical aspect of a multiphysics model for a 1 kW proton exchange membrane (PEM) water electrolyzer. The electrochemical sub-model is based on established equations, incorporating corrections to the standard electrochemical formula to enhance generalization across different temperatures. The model parameters affecting electrochemical performance are identified to better represent real physical processes. Validation is conducted using experimental data obtained under various inlet temperature conditions. The optimized model accurately predicts electrochemical behavior in the temperature range of $\mathbf{4 0}^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ to $70^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$. These results demonstrate the model’s capability to reflect temperature-dependent electrochemical processes.

title: Analysis of Conventional PID, Fuzzy PD, and Fuzzy PID Controllers for Electric Vehicle Drive Systems Based on Simulink Simulation
authors: Feiyu Yao
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Automation, Electronics and Electrical Engineering (AUTEEE)
abstract: During the electric vehicle (EV) drive system, traditional Proportion-Integration (PI), Proportion-Differentiation (PD), and Proportion-Integration-Differentiation (PID) controllers are affected by the motor’s nonlinear characteristics in the performance and fail to keep optimum control effect. Different from it, the fuzzy controller adjusts the control parameters according to the current error and error changing rate at any time, which has more accuracy when it works on nonlinear, variable, and other time-varying systems. In this paper, on the basis of establishing the EV drive system model, the performances of 3 kinds of control algorithms, traditional PID, fuzzy PD, and fuzzy PID control strategies are studied, and from the simulation results, under torque disturbances and different input target conditions, fuzzy PD control and fuzzy PID controllers show a better performance compared to the conventional PID controller in responding time, overshoot suppression, and system stability under disturbances. All simulations are carried out in the MATLAB/Simulink environment.

title: A Unsupervised Wood Surface Defect Segmentation Method Based on Anomaly Reconstruction
authors: Yuhuan Ye, Zhezhuang Xu, Yuhang Zhu, Jin Ke, Yulong Zhang
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Big Data, Artificial Intelligence and Internet of Things Engineering (ICBAIE)
abstract: Wood surface defect detection is critical for quality control and production efficiency in the wood industry. While current deep learning-based methods have yielded promising results, their reliance on full supervision demands extensive and high-quality annotations, particularly for pixel-level segmentation tasks. To address this limitation, this study proposes a two-stage unsupervised method for wood defect segmentation. Firstly, a reconstructive network is designed to learn the feature distribution of normal patterns. By combining anomaly generation and mapping-reconstruction strategy, it can achieve anomaly simulation without labels. Additionally, a pixel correlation module is introduced to enhance global feature representation and improve the reconstruction fidelity. Then, a discriminative network is constructed to locate anomalous regions by analyzing the residuals between the reconstruction results and the anomalous input. Furthermore, an efficient feature fusion module is introduced to refine detailed information in the discriminative network. Experiments conducted on wood defect dataset demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method.

title: Assessing the Uneven Industrial Effects of Regional Electricity Market Integration Across the Yangtze River Delta Provinces
authors: Xiaozhe Yin, Huan Niu, Zhong Wang
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Machine Learning, Big Data and Business Intelligence (MLBDBI)
abstract: Electricity pricing exhibits substantial variation among the provinces within China's Yangtze River Delta (YRD) region. With the establishment of an integrated regional electricity market, price convergence is expected, which will impose uneven impacts on provincial industries. This study applies a simulation-based method to evaluate these impacts through the development of an electricity-output elasticity indicator. The results demonstrate that industrial sectors in Shanghai are less affected compared to those in Zhejiang, Jiangsu, and Anhui. Among these, Anhui experiences the greatest influence across most industries, while Zhejiang and Jiangsu occupy an intermediate position. The findings suggest that higher levels of economic development correspond to weaker sensitivity to electricity price changes. These results imply that policymakers should exercise caution in advancing regional electricity market integration and design differentiated policies to balance the interests of economically stronger and weaker provinces.

title: Smoothing Photovoltaic Power Output Fluctuation Using an Alpha-Beta Filter-Based Approach
authors: Wei-Chen Lin, Wei-Tzer Huang, Chun-Chiang Ma, Chao-Hsien Hsiao, Kai-Chao Yao
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: Photovoltaic (PV) power generation is inherently intermittent, as it depends on variable weather conditions, leading to output fluctuations that can compromise grid stability. To address this challenge, this study proposes a real-time PV output smoothing approach based on an Alpha-Beta filter algorithm. The method forecasts short-term power variations and dynamically regulates the charging and discharging of a Battery Energy Storage System (BESS), intervening only when significant deviations occur. This selective control reduces unnecessary cycling, improves State of Charge (SOC) management, and extends battery lifespan. Unlike conventional smoothing techniques, the proposed framework maintains the original PV generation profile while mitigating disruptive fluctuations. Implemented in Python and evaluated using OpenDSS simulations with real PV data from a high-penetration microgrid, the method achieved a 91.7% reduction in power variation and maintained voltage stability within regulatory limits. These results demonstrate the effectiveness and practicality of the Alpha-Beta filter-based strategy for stabilizing PV output and optimizing energy storage operation in distributed energy systems.

title: A Bibliometric review on the use of Artificial Intelligence for Image recognition applied at Risk Reduction
authors: Giuseppe Guido, Giulia Martino, Vittorio Astarita, Sina Shaffiee Haghshenas, Sami Shaffiee Haghshenas
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: With the advent of deep learning systems, the potential applications of machine learning and artificial intelligence have expanded to include image interpretation. Specifically, AI-driven image recognition has proven to be a valuable tool in emergency situations. When a disaster occurs, both rapid response times and accurate information are crucial. Image recognition technology helps quickly identify the type of disaster and determine an effective intervention strategy, thereby facilitating rescue efforts and minimizing damage. In this article, the authors analyze two scientific literature databases on the topic, using specific keywords and the VOSviewer software. While the scientific community largely agrees that image recognition technology is essential for providing accurate and rapid responses to various hazards, the authors argue that current technological advancements can be harnessed synergistically to address all disasters that threaten public safety.

title: Function Calling in Large Language Models: Industrial Practices, Challenges, and Future Directions
authors: Maolin Wang, Yingyi Zhang, Bowen Yu, Bingguang Hao, Cunyin Peng, Yicheng Chen, Wei Zhou, Jinjie Gu, Chenyi Zhuang, Ruocheng Guo, Wanyu Wang, Xiangyu Zhao
abstract: None

title: A Rotation-Translation Decoupled Solution for Visual-Inertial Initialization and Online Spatial-Temporal Calibration
authors: Bo Xu, Zewen Xu, Yijia He, Zhanpeng Ouyang, Hao Wei, Yihong Wu, Jiancheng Li, Hongdong Li
abstract: We propose a novel initialization and online spatial-temporal calibration method for visual-inertial odometry (VIO), which decouples rotation and translation estimation to achieve higher accuracy and better robustness. Existing initialization methods suffer from limited accuracy or robustness (e.g., in scenarios with small translational motion) and rarely integrate simultaneous spatial-temporal calibration during initialization, despite its considerable practical value. Our proposed method leverages rotation-translation decoupling constraints to enable simultaneous estimation of gyroscope bias, extrinsic rotation, and camera-IMU time offset-even under pure rotational motion. Moreover, we are the first to conduct observability analysis on rotational constraints in rotation-translation decoupling methods, experimentally identifying the unobservable state-space directions under three degenerate motions within our approach. We also perform extensive experiments to delineate practical parameter solution boundaries for our method, with both efforts substantially enhancing the overall practical applicability of decoupling-based methods. Extensive experiments on simulated and real-world datasets demonstrate that our method outperforms state-of-the-art approaches in accuracy and robustness while maintaining computational efficiency. Furthermore, experiments verify that it significantly improves convergence in VIO systems.

title: Retraction Notice: An Improved Method for Generating Biometric-Cryptographic System from Face Feature
authors: S. Aanjanadevi, V. Palanisamy, S. Aanjankumar
publish: 2019 3rd International Conference on Trends in Electronics and Informatics (ICOEI)
abstract: One of the most difficult tasks in networking is to provide security to data during transmission, the main issue using network is lack of security. Various techniques and methods had been introduced to satisfy the needs to enhance the firmness of the data while transmitting over internet. Due to several reasons and intruders the mechanism of providing security becomes a tedious task. At first conventional passwords are used to provide security to data while storing and transmitting but remembering the password quite confusing and difficult for the user to access the data. After that cryptography methodology is introduced to protect the data from the intruders by converting readable form of data into unreadable data by encryption process. Then the data is processed and received the receiver can access the original data by the reverse process of encryption called decryption. The processes of encoding have broken by intruders using various combinations of keys. In this proposed work strong encryption key can be generated by combining biometric and cryptography methods for enhancing firmness of data. Here biometric face image is pre-processed at initial stage then facial features are extracted to generate biometric-cryptographic key. After generating bio-crypto key data can be encrypted along with newly produced key with 0's or 1's bit combination and stored in the database. By generating bio-crypto key and using them for transmitting or storing the data the privacy and firmness of the data can be enhanced and by using own biometrics as key the process of hacking and interfere of intruders to access the data can be minimized.

title: Robust LMI based Model Predictive Control for discrete-time singular systems
authors: Andrey Yonchev
