abstract: This paper addresses the robust model predictive control (RMPC) for singular systems based on linear matrix inequalities (LMIs). The uncertain singular system is represented as a polytopic model, then a min-max approach is implemented to perform the RMPC design. In the proposed derivation procedure we theoretically replace the maximization of the considered cost function with a proper upper bound. The derived approach to perform RMPC in discrete-time case is valid under some conditions suitable for the singular systems. A theorem, involving LMIs and its proof is presented. Illustrative examples depicting the efficiency of the obtained approach are also included.

title: DeepUCS for knowledge extraction applied to sleep stages classification*
authors: Rahma Ferjani, Lilia Rejeb, Mohamed S Kander Tebourbi
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: For human mental and physical health, sleep is a fundamental restorative process. Sleep analysis is considered as a crucial task to identify the various abnormalities, given the risks that sleep disorders can present. The gold standard for human sleep analysis is sleep scoring. Sleep experts review the PSG recordings and visually identify the various sleep stages for each sleep epoch. Due to the massive volume of recordings acquired during a single sleep period, manual sleep scoring task is considered as a time-consuming and labor intensive task. In this paper we propose a new approach for an interpretable automatic sleep scoring model based on supervised deep learning method and learning classifier system. The effectiveness of our approach was investigated using real electroencephalography (EEG).

title: FedSAGA: Composite Federated Learning with Inertial Douglas-Rachford Splitting and Variance Reduction Method
authors: Jiao Xue, Chundong Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE 31th International Conference on Parallel and Distributed Systems (ICPADS)
abstract: Composite federated learning provides a comprehensive framework for addressing machine learning tasks that incorporate regularization terms. Nevertheless, numerous established methods within this framework face challenges stemming from data heterogeneity and the high variance induced by stochastic gradients mapping. These issues cause significant deviations in clients' local models, resulting in unstable and slow convergence of the global model and increased communication costs. To address this, we propose a novel algorithm named FedSAGA, designed to solve composite federated optimization problems that include a nonsmooth global regularization term. In FedSAGA, we construct a combination of the latest and historical local model updates without incurring additional communication overhead. This estimate serves as a control variate on the client side to reduce the variance introduced by stochastic gradient mapping and client sampling. To further accelerate convergence, we leverage the inertial extrapolation step locally at the clients. Theoretical analysis demonstrates that FedSAGA attains a sublinear convergence rate under general convex settings and a linear convergence rate under strongly convex settings. Numerical experiments based on both real and synthetic datasets effectively demonstrate the convergence of the proposed algorithm under partial client participation.

title: 3D Printed Subwavelength Optical Structures for Terahertz Beam Shaping
authors: Adrianna Nieradka, Mateusz Kaluza, Agnieszka Siemion
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: The presented research focuses on terahertz (THz) optical elements, characterized by a unique approach to manipulate the refractive index through the fill factor (FF) of manufactured element. The evaluated objects were manufactured using 3D printing fused deposition modeling (FDM) technology from highly transparent cyclic olefin copolymer (COC) material. In the paper, three different geometries of components with different FFs equal to 30%, 50%, and 80% are presented and analyzed.The investigation of the optical properties of the structures was conducted using terahertz time domain spectroscopy (THz TDS), within the wide frequency range from 0.1 to 2.0 THz. The results demonstrate the tendency of the absorption coefficient to decrease with an increase of FF, that is, to proceed towards its reference values. Moreover, the experimental results confirm the subwavelength properties of the proposed elements at low THz frequencies, enabling further extension of this unique approach for designing advanced THz optical elements.

title: A Review of Machine-Learning Approaches to Space-Weather Forecasting
authors: Dibyendu Ganguly, Arunya Paul, Shruti, Sasmita Pahadsingh, Bhoomika Sarkar
publish: 2025 5th IEEE International Conference on Applied Electromagnetics, Signal Processing, &amp; Communication (AESPC)
abstract: Space weather forecasting is vital to mitigate disruptions in satellite communications, power grids, and navigation systems. Conventional physics-based models struggle with realtime predictions due to the complexity of space weather events. This paper reviews advances in machine learning (ML) methods for space weather prediction, highlighting datasets, techniques, challenges, and future directions. We assess the performance of neural networks, deep learning, and hybrid models in forecasting solar storms, geomagnetic disturbances, and ionospheric changes. Studies show ML enhances predictions-such as solar flares and geomagnetic storms-through large-scale data analysis. Models like Random Forest and LSTM offer improved precision over traditional methods, with promising results in some cases. Key challenges include data quality and model interpretability, alongside efforts to integrate ML with physics-based models for better forecasting.

title: Determining Available Energy and Operating Voltage Range of a Supercapacitor Storage System for Inertia Support in Converter-Dominated Power Systems
authors: Karlo Kobeščak, Tomislav Baškarad, Igor Kuzle
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Clean and Green Energy Engineering (CGEE)
abstract: The shift from synchronous generators to converterbased sources is reducing system inertia, prompting concerns about frequency stability. In response, synthetic inertia is gaining attention, with supercapacitors emerging as promising technologies because of their specific advantages. However, the most used supercapacitor type, Electric Double-Layer Capacitors, have inherent limitations in voltage and current because of their nature, including internal resistance and capacitance that varies with voltage. Previous studies have typically relied on simplified supercapacitor models, often neglecting critical factors such as equivalent series resistance and voltage-dependent capacitance, resulting in inaccurate energy availability estimations and deviations in determining the appropriate operating voltage range. This paper provides an analytical comparison of how the operating, minimum, and maximum voltages required to deliver a specified amount of energy vary depending on the chosen equivalent circuit model of the supercapacitor.

title: Unveiling Spectral Attention Redundancy with Explainable AI
authors: Chen Ma, Oscar J. Pellicer-Valero, Kai-Hendrik Cohrs, Jiaqi Yao, Junjun Jiang, Huayi Li, Gustau Camps-Valls
publish: IEEE Geoscience and Remote Sensing Letters
abstract: Hyperspectral image (HSI) classification has advanced significantly through transformer-based models that leverage self-attention (SA) to capture global spectral dependencies. However, most existing HSI transformers implicitly assume that SA provides a faithful and discriminative modeling of spectral information, an assumption that has rarely been examined. We examine SA behavior in HSI classification using adversarial perturbations guided by explainable AI (XAI) techniques. By comparing transformer attention distributions with Integrated Gradients (IG) importance scores, we uncover discrepancies between attended bands and decision-driving features. Experiments show that SA often forms redundant clusters across neighboring spectral bands and that attention patterns evolve across layers, shifting from a localized to a broader focus. Such redundancy improves robustness to spectral corruptions but reduces feature specificity and leads to repeated processing of highly similar bands, increasing computational burden. Our findings question the everyday use of raw attention as an explanatory clue and guide the design of more reliable and interpretable attention mechanisms for HSI.

title: Insights on the Working Principles of A CNN for Forest Height Regression from Single-pass InSAR Data
authors: Daniel Carcereri, Luca Dell'Amore, Stefano Tebaldini, Paola Rizzoli
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: The increasing use of Artificial Intelligence (AI) models in Earth Observation (EO) applications, such as forest height estimation, has led to a growing need for explainable AI (XAI) methods. Despite their high accuracy, AI models are often criticized for their “black-box” nature, making it difficult to understand the inner decision-making process. In this study, we propose a multifaceted approach to XAI for a convolutional neural network (CNN)-based model that estimates forest height from TanDEM-X single-pass InSAR data. By combining domain knowledge, saliency maps, and feature importance analysis through exhaustive model permutations, we provide a comprehensive investigation of the network working principles. Our results suggests that the proposed model is implicitly capable of recognizing and compensating for the SAR acquisition geometry-related distortions. We find that the mean phase center height and its local variability represents the most informative predictor. We also find evidence that the interferometric coherence and the backscatter maps capture complementary but equally relevant views of the vegetation. This work contributes to advance the understanding of the model's inner workings, and targets the development of more transparent and trustworthy AI for EO applications, ultimately leading to improved accuracy and reliability in the estimation of forest parameters.

title: Multi-objective site selection stochastic optimization for overseas warehouse hubs considering sharing strategies
authors: Zhuo Sun, Dongxing Yang, Baoji Chen, Libao Sun
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Big Data, Artificial Intelligence and Internet of Things Engineering (ICBAIE)
abstract: With the rapid growth of cross-border e-commerce, the efficient deployment of overseas warehouses has become vital for enhancing global supply chain performance. This study develops a multi-objective hub location optimization model under a shared warehouse strategy, considering freight flow allocation, inter-warehouse transfers, and last-mile delivery. A stochastic optimization framework is solved using a modified Non-dominated Sorting Genetic Algorithm II (NSGA-II), achieving a trade-off between cost reduction and service improvement. Comparative results show that the shared strategy significantly enhances efficiency and cost-effectiveness over independent models, offering practical guidance for cross-border logistics network design under demand uncertainty.

title: UAV collision avoidance using multiple artificial potential functions: Practical implementation and experimental outdoor applications
authors: Oscar F. Archila, Alain Vande Wouwer, Johannes Schiffer
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: In unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) applications, fast-response collision avoidance is an essential requirement for a safe flight. This applies in particular to real-world settings with constrained hardware performance. With these challenges in mind, the authors have recently presented a collision avoidance strategy based on multiple artificial potential functions (MAPOFs). The strategy overcomes the typical drawbacks of the conventional, popular APOFs approach, such as chattering or deadlock. The main focus of the present paper is on the practical implementation and experimental demonstration of the proposed MAPOF strategy in two real-life outdoor scenarios using a commercial quadrotor and open-source software. The experiments show the effectiveness of the MAPOFs strategy in the presence of stationary obstacles as well as in the presence of another moving UAV. The experiments are complemented by additional simulation results to further illustrate and validate the proposed approach.

title: Exploring the potential of NDVI derivatives for monitoring in precision agriculture
authors: Asparuh Atanasov, Plamen Petrov, Radostina Yankova
abstract: This article is a study of the possibilities for obtaining key data from the first and second derivatives of the NDVI index from a winter wheat field. The dynamics of the index change was studied using images obtained from an Unmanned Aerial Vehicle (UAV) equipped with a multispectral camera. The results obtained were compared with meteorological data and the field condition of the wheat. It has been shown that the first derivative can diagnose deviations from the expected values. The second derivative emphasizes sharp changes and a more pronounced change in the curve in the presence of stress.

title: Photonic Terahertz Emitter with Improved Beam Quality Based on a High-Gain Silicon Lens Design
authors: Garrit Schwanke, Sebastian Lauck, Lauri Schwenson, Simon Nellen, Lars Liebermeister, Martin Schell, Robert B. Kohlhaas
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: The ultra-broadband operation capabilities of photonic terahertz systems impose stringent requirements on the design of the antenna and often used silicon lens. This work presents a directivity-optimized hyper-hemispherical silicon lens for photonic terahertz transmitters. A single main lobe is maintained from 100 GHz up to 600 GHz, and a peak directivity of 34 dBi is achieved. Compared to previously investigated lens designs, this marks a notable improvement of 7 dBi. The improved radiation characteristic of this lens facilitates the development of more compact systems with fewer additional mirrors or lenses and improves integration with other terahertz components.

title: Generative Adversarial Network for Cold Nuclear Fusion Data Set Generation
authors: Todor Malchev, Milena Lazarova, Yordan Paunov, Dimiter Alexandrov
abstract: Understanding and analyzing the process of cold nuclear fusion beyond human observation needs the use of artificial intelligence and machine learning. These technologies rely on vast and diverse datasets to extract patterns and improve predictive performance. In the cold nuclear fusion experiments, that are conducted at Lakehead University, the dataset from the experiments consists of around a few hundred thousand timesteps (seconds). However, expanding it is essential to enhance the accuracy and reliability of the analysis and predictions in further research of the subject. This paper introduces a novel methodology for generating high-quality simulation data based on existing experimental results using Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs), with a particular focus on the TimeGAN architecture. This approach enables the creation of synthetic time series data that enhances the training process, adding synthetic data to the overall data set.

title: Probability-Guaranteed Distributed Fusion Estimation With Event-Driven Censored Measurements: A Binary Encoding Scheme
authors: Jiayi Zhang, Guoliang Wei, Derui Ding, Han Chen
publish: IEEE Transactions on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics: Systems
abstract: This article investigates the probability-guaranteed distributed fusion estimation (DFE) issue for a class of nonlinear systems with censored measurements over sensor networks. In order to reduce the transmission load and minimize energy consumption, each sensing node sends its censored measurement to the estimator only when a predefined event-triggered media access condition is met. To enhance both the security and reliability of signal transmission, a binary encoding scheme is adopted, which encodes the transmitted information using a limited number of bits. The core objective of the addressed problem is to develop a novel distributed robust fusion estimator capable of maintaining effectiveness in the presence of censored measurements, nonlinear dynamics, and unknown-but-bounded noise, while confining the estimation error to ellipsoidal regions with a prespecified probability. To be specific, sufficient conditions for the existence of the desired fusion estimator, obtained through a weighted matrix fusion technique, are established using mathematical induction, linear matrix inequalities, and set theory. In addition, the estimator parameters and the fusion weights are determined through the solution of a series of optimization problems that are constrained by matrix inequalities. Finally, the efficacy of the DFE scheme developed in the article is confirmed by a ballistic object tracking example.

title: Mobile TantivyFormer U-Net: A Lightweight Network with Dynamic Tanh for UAV-Compatible Crack Segmentation
authors: Nan Jiang, Zhixiang Qian, Tongtong Zhou, Lihong Tong, Lingxiao Guan, Ziyi Li
publish: 2025 IEEE 31th International Conference on Parallel and Distributed Systems (ICPADS)
abstract: Accurate road crack segmentation is critical for ubiquitous intelligence applications in smart city infrastructure maintenance, particularly in UAV-based inspection systems. To address computational constraints on edge devices, we propose Mobile TantivyFormer U-Net: a lightweight network that integrates an Edge Localization Module (ELM) and Mobile TantivyFormer Blocks (MTFB). ELM combines deformable convolution with normalization-free Vision Transformers to enhance edge detection, while MTFB employs efficient additive attention with <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$O(n)$</tex> complexity to reduce parameters by 80 % versus standard Transformers. Our model enables device-edge-cloud orchestration by achieving real-time segmentation on UAVs with seamless cloud integration for large-scale analysis. Evaluations on three datasets show state-of-the-art accuracy (F1-Score: 85.2%) and efficiency (20.47 M parameters), showcasing its viability for ubiquitous intelligent infrastructure monitoring.

title: Design of Constant Current Control for Automotive LED Driver Using Dual-Side Current Sensing
authors: Jian-Yu Chen, San-Fu Wang, Xia-Zhen Yen, Hsiao-Hsing Chou
abstract: This work proposes an on-chip current sensing architecture for automotive LED drivers, achieving stable output current regulation (585.2-622 mA) across a 9–13 V input range. Implemented in TSMC 0.18 μm HV CMOS (T18HVG2) and operating at 1 MHz, the design eliminates off-chip sense resistors to reduce parasitics and simplify integration. The LED current remains within ±4% of the 600 mA target, meeting automotive lighting requirements with high robustness.

title: Compact Slot-Loaded UWB Microstrip Antenna with Finite Ground Plane
authors: B Anitha, Mannam Manikanta, Bappadittya Roy, Sambhudutta Nanda
publish: 2025 5th IEEE International Conference on Applied Electromagnetics, Signal Processing, &amp; Communication (AESPC)
abstract: This paper introduces a compact UWB microstrip antenna, aimed at future high-data-rate communication and sensing systems. The antenna has been designed, simulated and characterized. A rectangular radiating patch is constructed on an economical and readily accessible FR4 material with a dielectric constant of 4.4. The overall dimensions are $35 \times 30 \times 1.6 \mathrm{~mm}^{3}$, equivalent to $0.676 \lambda_{0} \times 0.58 \lambda_{0} \times 0.03 \lambda_{0}$, with $\lambda_{0}$ denoting the free-space wavelength at operating frequency 5.8 GHz. Simulation findings indicate that the suggested antenna design exhibits a consistent radiation pattern across its working frequency that ranges from 3.1 to 12.18 GHz, attaining the broad fractional bandwidth of 118%. This antenna is well-suited for research, military, and commercial applications. Its wide impedance bandwidth accommodates various systems, including the $5.2 / 5.8 \mathrm{GHz}$ WLAN bands, the 5.5 GHz WiMAX band, the Xband ($\mathbf{8 - 1 2 ~ G H z}$), and satellite communication services. The peak gain achieved is 4.5 dBi, with a maximum radiation efficiency of 70% and the detailed analysis of the radiation pattern and surface current distribution is also provided.

title: Cost-effective Single-laser-based Photomixing Architecture for Terahertz Intensity Modulation and Direct Detection
authors: Shenghong Ye, Ryota Kaide, Naoto Masutomi, Yiqing Wang, Yuya Mikami, Yuta Ueda, Kazutoshi Kato
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: We propose an improved cost-effective terahertz generation and modulation architecture based on a single wave-length tunable laser, which halves the required number of lasers for photomixing and thus reduces both cost and power consumption. Moreover, the catastrophic error propagation in the conventional single-laser terahertz generation architecture is eliminated. Error-free 100 Mbit/s on-off keying communication was demonstrated at 281 GHz.

title: Hybrid GA ANN Based Design and Optimization of a mmWave Antenna for Defense Communication Applications
authors: M. Jeyabharathi, R. Pandeeswari
publish: 2025 5th IEEE International Conference on Applied Electromagnetics, Signal Processing, &amp; Communication (AESPC)
abstract: This paper presents an AI-driven design framework for a compact millimeter-wave (mmWave) antenna targeting defense applications in the 13.5 GHz and $17.25-20 \mathrm{GHz}$ bands. A hybrid Genetic Algorithm-Artificial Neural Network (GAANN) approach is used to optimize antenna geometry and performance metrics including gain, bandwidth, and return loss. The ANN model is trained on simulation data from HFSS to predict performance metrics, allowing the GA to efficiently explore the design space without requiring exhaustive simulations. The hybrid approach achieves significant time reduction and improved design accuracy. The optimized antenna demonstrates high gain, directional stability, and robustness suitable for hostile environmental conditions. This framework represents a novel, rapid, and intelligent approach to mmWave antenna design for defense communication.

title: Dynamic Routing Optimisation for UAV Network Based on GA-HAPPO Algorithm
authors: Hefei Yin, Yuanyuan Wu, Zikai Feng, Mengxing Huang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Digital Society and Intelligent Systems (DSInS)
abstract: Unmanned Aerial Vehicle (UAV) networks hold significant applications in emergency communications, intelligent transport systems, and post-disaster rescue operations. However, constrained by factors such as dynamic topology, link instability, and limited energy resources, conventional routing methods often struggle to balance throughput, latency, and energy consumption. This paper proposes a Graph Attention-based Heterogeneous Multi-Agent Proximal Policy Optimization algorithm (GA-HAPPO). Building upon the HAPPO framework, this algorithm incorporates a Graph Attention Critic to model topological relationships between UAVs. It further enhances training stability in high-dimensional action spaces through factorised importance sampling and adaptive Kullback-Leibler divergence(KL) regularisation. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed algorithm outperforms baseline algorithm in convergence speed, system throughput and latency control.

title: Toward a multipactor-free cavity design for a very-high-frequency continuous-wave electron gun
authors: Yitong Duan, Lianmin Zheng, Yingchao Du
abstract: A very-high-frequency (VHF) photocathode electron gun serves as an electron source capable of generating high-repetition-rate, high-brightness electron bunches. It operates in continuous-wave mode with a 100% microwave duty cycle, a configuration where multipactor emerges as a critical operational challenge requiring meticulous mitigation. The exponential amplification of secondary electrons within the electron gun may cause power dissipation, cavity material degradation, and beam quality deterioration, ultimately compromising the performance and operational lifetime of the VHF gun. Analysis of electron trajectories inside the cavity reveals that the energy dispersion and angular distribution of emitted electrons significantly affect their subsequent motion. Although the multipactor behavior is non-resonant, multiple resonance modes can still be identified from the statistical distribution of particle flight times. This study examines the influence of radio-frequency (rf) cavity geometry on multipactor behavior, with the underlying mechanisms elucidated through statistical analysis of particle trajectories. The effect of the secondary electron yield of copper on multipactor is also discussed. Finally, an optimized rf cavity profile exhibiting very low multipactor intensity is presented, providing a promising approach to achieving stable VHF electron gun operation.

title: Real-Time, Low-Power Purkinje Cell Spike Sorting for Headstage Systems in Freely Moving Mice
authors: Kiran Fatima, Vincenzo Romano, Christos Strydis, Muhammad Ali Siddiqi
publish: 2025 IEEE Biomedical Circuits and Systems Conference (BioCAS)
abstract: Studying Purkinje cell activity is vital for understanding brain function and movement disorders. However, conventional wired headstage setups in mice restrict natural behavior, while transmitting full neural waveforms wirelessly is prohibitively power-intensive. This work presents a lightweight, real-time spike sorting system implemented on the EFM32PG28 microcontroller, capable of classifying complex spikes and simple spikes from Purkinje cells directly on the headstage. By extracting only relevant spike information, the system enables efficient wireless transmission or local storage. Leveraging knowledge distillation and Matrix Vector Processor (MVP) hardware acceleration, the spike sorter achieves an overall $\mathbf{F 1}$-score of 93.43% and completes detection and classification in 0.765 ms. With over 53 hours of continuous operation on a $50-\mathrm{mAh}$ battery, the proposed solution is well-suited for long-duration, untethered cerebellar experiments in freely moving mice.

authors: Chavva balannagari Manjunath Reddy, Uday kumar reddy, E. Brumancia, R.M. Gomathi, K. Indira
