title: SPD-DETR: An Eagle Eye for Insulator Fault Detection with Spatial-Channel Aggregation Attention
authors: Zhaoyang Chen, Tianxiong Chen, Yicong He
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Big Data, Artificial Intelligence and Internet of Things Engineering (ICBAIE)
abstract: In response to the challenges of complex image backgrounds, small target sizes, and low resolution in insulator fault detection, as well as the issues of high computational overhead of existing real-time detection models, we proposes an insulator fault detection model—SPD-DETR, based on SPDConv and attention mechanisms. First, the SPD-FasterNet backbone is constructed, where SPDConv replaces partial convolution to effectively preserve fine-grained spatial information of small targets during feature extraction, thereby reducing information loss at the source. Second, a Spatial-Channel Aggregation Attention (SCAA) is introduced to enhance multi-scale features from the backbone. By jointly optimizing key spatial locations and channel features in parallel, the method suppresses interference from complex backgrounds and improves the discriminative ability for defect features. Finally, the encoder is reconstructed using a HiLo attention that decouples high- and low-frequency information, enabling efficient capture of both global context and local details, while significantly reducing the computational overhead of the Transformer architecture. Experimental results show that compared with the baseline model, SPD-DETR reduces the parameters and computational complexity by 12.4% and 13.2% respectively, while increasing mAP@0.5 and mAP@0.5:0.95 by 3.76% and 5.35% respectively. This significantly improves the detection performance for small-sized insulator faults in low-resolution images. The model is highly suitable for deployment on edge devices such as Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) with limited computational resources.

title: Optimizing Household Water Distribution in Iligan City Using Genetic Algorithm: Addressing Adequacy and Equity Gaps
authors: Shehab D. Ibrahim, Cherry Lyn C. Sta. Romana, Larmie S. Feliscuzo
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Digital Transformation and Applications (ICDXA)
abstract: Iligan City in Northern Mindanao possesses abundant water resources, yet its distribution system suffers from inefficiencies, inequities, and high non-revenue water losses. Currently, only 30 of 44 barangays are connected to the Iligan City Waterworks System (ICWS), with many households either undersupplied or receiving excessive allocations. This study applies a Genetic Algorithm (GA) to optimize barangaypumping station assignments, introducing three key updates: a shift to household-level adequacy thresholds, integration of updated ICWS connection records, and adoption of stratified benchmarks set by the Philippine Institute for Development Studies-108, 58, and 48 liters per person per day for rich, middle, and poor households, respectively. A water supply analysis of the current system revealed pronounced imbalances, including severe undersupply in high-population barangays and extreme oversupply in select areas such as Abuno. Using GA, more than 800 iterations generated an optimized framework that redistributed supply more equitably, minimized oversupply, reduced undersupply, and diversified source dependency. The proposed system achieved near-normal discharge distributions, capped household deficits, and eliminated extreme outliers, demonstrating substantial improvements in adequacy, fairness, and resilience. These findings underscore the potential of optimization models to address water distribution challenges in Iligan City and comparable urban contexts across Southeast Asia.

title: Broadband and fast THz Time-Domain Spectrometer Based on Organic Crystal MNA
authors: S. Mansourzadeh, T. Vogel, A. Omar, M. F. Biggs, E. S.-H. Ho, C. Hoberg, D. J. Michaelis, M. Havenith, J. A. Johnson, C. J. Saraceno
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: We present a broadband and high-power THz-TDS utilizing the nonlinear organic crystal MNA as both emitter and detector for electro-optic sampling. The THz source in the TDS delivers 11 mW of average power at 100 kHz repetition rate, with a conversion efficiency of 0.13% and a broad, spectrally-dense spectrum spanning over 9 THz. We demonstrate capabilities of the system to extract THz properties of PTFE with high fidelity up to 8 THz, showcasing high dynamic range and bandwidth for linear spectroscopy applications.

title: FAI-CXL: An Efficient Hardware-Accelerated Fairness-Aware CXL Memory Pool Management with Fine-Grained Cacheline-Level Interleaving
authors: Jiaxi Li, Yixuan Liu, Yunfei Gu, Chentao Wu
publish: 2025 IEEE 31th International Conference on Parallel and Distributed Systems (ICPADS)
abstract: Compute Express Link (CXL) enables scalable memory disaggregation, allowing multiple hosts to share a global memory pool. However, existing CXL pooling designs require manual static configuration, underutilize link bandwidth, and suffer from performance unfairness among hosts with diverse memory intensities. This paper presents FAI-CXL, a hardwareaccelerated CXL memory pool unified management architecture that integrates fine-grained, weighted interleaving and adaptive fairness-aware scheduling into the CXL switch. The proposed interleaving mechanism operates at cacheline granularity, improving both link and device bandwidth utilization, while the scheduling policy dynamically adjusts priorities to mitigate unfairness under imbalanced workloads. We implement FAI-CXL in a cycle-accurate ChampSim + Ramulator simulation framework with realistic CXL protocol modeling. Across diverse workload sets, FAI-CXL achieves up to 21 % IPC improvement and 17 % throughput gain compared to conventional pooling approaches, while ensuring fair performance across heterogeneous hosts.

title: Grasshopper Optimization Algorithm based Sink Placement in Wireless Sensor Networks
authors: B. Pitchaimanickam, P. Muthuvel, R. Rajasekar
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Automation, Computing and Renewable Systems (ICACRS)
abstract: Wireless sensor network have shown promise in addressing issues in industrial and healthcare applications. Sensor nodes are distributed across the area to measure key environmental parameters. They then transmit the collected data to the base station for further processing and analysis. Efficient topology control plays a crucial role in optimizing resource utilization for data processing. Multi-Sink placement is a key strategy for minimizing energy consumption and extending network lifetime. Grasshopper Optimization Algorithm (GOA) is suggested for identifying the best sink placements by taking use of grasshoppers' swarming and foraging habits. Node energy and hop count are considered to evaluate the energy efficiency of the sensor network. The experimental findings clearly indicate that the proposed method performs better than both the Grey Wolf Optimizer (GWO) and the Ant Lion Optimizer (ALO). In particular, the new approach extends the overall network lifetime and achieves noticeable reductions in delay and energy usage. These improvements highlight the efficiency and reliability of the proposed solution when compared with existing optimization techniques.

title: Intelligent Multi Agent Systems Based Traffic Simulation for Adaptive Traffic Regulation Using Dynamic Message Signs
authors: Maram Mohamad, Rihab Abidi, Yasmine Amor, Nabil Sahli
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: Traffic congestion remains a critical challenge in urban mobility, necessitating adaptive and intelligent regulation strategies. This paper presents a novel, generic framework that integrates a Multi-Agent System (MAS) layer within a traffic simulator to optimize traffic flow through simulation-driven decision-making. The proposed system allows Dynamic Message Signs (DMS) to function as autonomous agents that assess congestion levels, exchange information, and collaboratively determine rerouting strategies. Unlike conventional approaches, our framework enables agents to negotiate multiple rerouting strategies offline, test them in simulation, and store the most effective ones in a learning module. When congestion occurs in real-world conditions, the agents perform a similarity check within their learning module; if a matching scenario is found, the best prevalidated strategy is immediately applied, eliminating the need for real-time simulations. Otherwise, new rerouting strategies are generated and tested offline for future optimization. The framework ensures that only reliable and effective strategies are deployed, leading to more adaptive and data-driven traffic regulation. Preliminary simulation results demonstrate significant reductions in total waiting time, highlighting the efficiency of integrating MAS-based learning into traffic management systems.

title: How Online Search Intensity Reshapes Cosmetic Imports — Evidence from Indonesia using an Augmented Gravity Model Analysis
authors: Angel Augustine Cheyla, Janice Ebelia Irfan, Dony Saputra
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Digital Transformation and Applications (ICDXA)
abstract: This study examines the determinants of Indonesia's cosmetic imports using an extended gravity model that incorporates traditional trade determinants (GDP, population size, exchange rate, geographical distance, and FTAs) alongside online search activity as a proxy for digitally driven consumer demand. Our analysis reveals that GDP, population size, FTAs, and online search intensity are crucial drivers of import volumes, explaining 83% of the variance; however, geographical distance is insignificant. The strong effect of search intensity validates the role of digital proximity in powering trade, counter to classic gravity expectations. The findings highlight how online activity bridges virtual demand signals and real-world trade outcomes. The study links digitalization to economic growth, offering exporters guidance on digital-first market strategies and providing policymakers with evidence to design trade policies suitable for an era of digital transformation.

title: Finding Time-Optimal Path Through a Forest of Circles by Graph Search
authors: Vadim Belotelov, Anna Daryina
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: Finding optimal path is required in many applications. However, there is no general method for doing it. There exist general numerical methods that optimize behavior of systems according to certain criteria, but these methods do not provide absolute optimum. In current article, a particular kinematic model of a wheeled mobile robot is concerned. For this model, it can be shown that the solution of the time-optimal problem of moving from one point to another through a forest of circular obstacles is one of the locally shortest paths between the two points, with addition of rotations around the starting and the finishing point. Therefore, an algorithm for automatic search of the optimal trajectory is proposed. It creates a graph of connections between the points on the circular obstacles and searches for the optimal trajectory on this graph using Dijkstra’s approach.

title: Industry 5.0 - the use of new business models and artificial intelligence in tourism in Bulgaria
authors: Neviana Krasteva
abstract: The report is dedicated to exploring possible business approaches in tourism in the context of AI and Industry 5.0, a new production model that focuses on human-machine collaboration. The main objective of the research is to clarify the general directions of change in business approaches and marketing in tourism in the age of AI and Industry 5.0. The primary research question is: "How does AI affect the customer experience in tourism and how can these technologies be applied to improve the tourism sector in Bulgaria?" Research methods include a desk study and content analysis as well as questions asked to ChatGPT. Currently, the tourism sector demonstrates the capacity to generate a wide range of diverse products. Conclusions will be drawn about the need to change strategies for tourism business and staff training through the knowledge of new technologies and their use. This necessitates the development of qualitatively new training programs in universities and specialized schools.

title: Design of an Electronic Circuit Bursting Neuron Model Based on the Concept of Ergodic Sequential Logic Neuromorphic Circuit
authors: Ryota Otawa, Hiroyuki Torikai
abstract: A novel electronic circuit bursting neuron model is designed based on the concept of ergodic sequential logic (ESL) neuromorphic circuit. It is shown that the ESL bursting neuron model can reproduce a typical bursting phenomenon of an ordinary differential equation neuron model known as the Hindmarsh-Rose (HR) neuron model. Possible applications of the ESL bursting neuron model such as in neural prosthetic device is also discussed.

title: A Color Quantum Polar Coordinate Image Representation Model based on YCrCb Space
authors: Dandan Ai, Zhanhong Wei, Jiahao Sun, Xiaolong Yang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Digital Society and Intelligent Systems (DSInS)
abstract: To address the limitations of existing models that predominantly represent data in Cartesian coordinate systems and RGB color representations, this paper proposes YCrCbQPI (A Quantum Polar Coordinate Color Image Representation Model Based on YCrCb Color Space, YCrCb-QPI). This model integrates luminance and chrominance separation properties of YCrCb with the geometric invariance of logarithmic polar coordinates. Through a differentiated quantum encoding strategy, more qubits are allocated to critical luminance information while less sensitive chrominance information is assigned simplified encoding. Corresponding quantum state preparation circuits are also designed. Theoretical analysis indicates that compared to traditional RGB polar coordinate models, this model achieves significant savings in color information encoding resources while maintaining comparable visual fidelity. Furthermore, the model inherently possesses the rotation and scaling invariance of polar coordinates, establishing a robust foundation for developing efficient quantum image processing algorithms.

title: Foundational Design and Transient Analysis of NAND Gate and Inverter in Cadence Virtuoso for CMOS Logic Circuits
authors: Jyotishko Chakrabotry, Bristi Hajra, Pradipta Dutta
publish: 2025 5th IEEE International Conference on Applied Electromagnetics, Signal Processing, &amp; Communication (AESPC)
abstract: This paper comprehensively analyzes the schematic design, physical layout, and transient analysis of elementary CMOS logic gates, such as the NAND and inverter, in the Cadence Virtuoso environment. Designs were implemented in the GPDK 90 nm technology node and verified on paper by intensive simulation and verification. The layouts were designed according to the standard CMOS rules, and the switching characteristics and transient analysis were done using Analog Design Environment Lite (ADE L). Functional correctness was verified via LVS checks and post layout simulations with PEX. Therefore, the comparative study focused on showing the inverter as the timing reference and the NAND gate as the most universal and efficient in design; especially when it comes to being of low power dissipation and high speed in VLSI digital applications. This paper is a reference source and a textbook guide for VLSI design beginners using EDA tools.

title: D-Band Reciprocal Passive Design and Analysis Based on Consecutive Single-Ended Two-Port Measurements
authors: Remco Schalk, Maarten Lont, Thiago Hanna Both, Luuk F. Tiemeijer, Daan Dekker, Mark van der Heijden, Marios Neofytou, Georgi Radulov, Vojkan Vidojkovic, Kostas Doris
publish: IEEE Transactions on Microwave Theory and Techniques
abstract: This work proposes and analyzes a methodology to characterize the scattering parameters of multiport passives up to 170 GHz by consecutive single-ended two-port measurements. The generalized methodology is based on duplicating the device under test with linear combinations of load and open terminations to create a system of equations that can be solved for full characterization. The methodology is applied to a D-band differential four-port quadrature hybrid (QH) coupler designed in 22-nm FDSOI technology. Measurement results are presented for even- and odd-mode and differential-mode over five samples. Moreover, a quantitative and qualitative study is presented to highlight the method’s sensitivity to variability in measurement, device under test, and terminations.

title: Error-Compensated Extended State Observer for Robust Disturbance Rejection of Nano-Stage With Time Delay Control
authors: Chen Yang, Jinhong Wei, Bo Jiang, Chaoqun Dang, Jiang Wu, Jie Zhao, Bingfeng Ju
abstract: Precision motion control systems are frequently challenged by exogenous disturbances and plant uncertainties, which compromise tracking accuracy and operational stability. To address these issues, the extended state observer (ESO) has been developed to estimate both system states and disturbances in real time. However, conventional ESOs rely on an integral-based mechanism, necessitating a high observer bandwidth to handle rapidly varying disturbances. This, in turn, increases noise sensitivity and reduces stability margins. In this article, we introduce a novel error compensation mechanism that dynamically minimizes the estimation errors inherent in traditional ESOs, thus eliminating the need for a high observer bandwidth. Furthermore, we propose a time delay controller, leveraging historical input–output data to mitigate residual disturbances and plant variations. Experimental results validate the efficacy of our approach: settling time is reduced from 49.81 (conventional ADRC) to 2.74 ms (the proposed method), while disturbance convergence time decreases from 49.94 to 2.41 ms. These results underscore its superiority in high-precision applications that require robustness against disturbances and uncertainties.

title: Improvement of RF Magnetic Field Strength and Tunable Frequency Range by Using HTS Modified Split-Type RF Coil for NMR
authors: T. Fujita, K. Sakuma, R. Tanaka, K. Toshima, N. Sekiya
abstract: A high-temperature superconductor (HTS) radio frequency (RF) coil that improved not only the RF magnetic strength but also the tunable resonant frequency range was developed for nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy. The HTS coil consisted of four individual half-wavelength resonators and was fabricated using a YBa<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sub>Cu<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sub>O<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">y</sub> thin film on sapphire substrates. The RF magnetic field strength of the fabricated HTS coil was 1.7 times higher than that of a previously developed HTS coil (HTS split-type coil), and the tunable resonant frequency range was 10 times wider. The measured quality factor (Q) of the proposed HTS coil at 11 K was 15 times higher than that of a commercial copper coil at 20 K. The SNR of 1H nuclei measured with the HTS coil was 1.5 times higher than that with the copper coil.

title: LLM on FPGA: Squeezing Language Models by Quantization and Multi-Query Attention and its Efficient Hardware Architecture
authors: Seoyoon Chae, Taewook Kang
abstract: We present an on-chip implementation of a compressed Transformer-based language model on a Xilinx Artix-7 FPGA. Our contributions include: (1) combining ultra-low-precision quantization (4 bits) and multi-query attention (MQA) to compress the KV cache by 8×, enabling sequence lengths up to 256 tokens; (2) a streaming hardware architecture in Verilog that implements pre-layernorm, attention, and feed-forward sublayers using block RAM (BRAM) and DSPs; and (3) post-synthesis results demonstrating real-time throughput (4.4 K tokens/s) with BRAM and DSP utilizations of 31.9% and 85%, respectively. The prototype supports generative inference entirely on-chip, paving the way for privacy-preserving, edge-scale LLMs. Code and scripts are available at https://github.com/chae-sy/squeezing_lm

title: Terahertz Second Harmonic Generation Based on Organic Crystals
authors: Hang Zhao, Lei Ge, Dayong Wang, Lu Rong, Yuejin Zhao
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: Achieving efficient and intense second harmonic generation (SHG) in the terahertz (THz) spectrum holds great potential for a wide range of technical applications. However, the current researches on THz harmonic emission primarily focus on inorganic materials, which often face challenges in achieving both efficient and broadband SHG. Here, the remarkable efficiency of organic materials in producing THz harmonics is studied and demonstrated, thereby opening up a new avenue for searching candidates for frequency-doubling devices in the THz band. By utilizing DAST, DSTMS, and OH1 crystals, we showcase their superior frequency conversion capabilities when pumped over a broadband THz range. This work presents a promising platform for efficient THz frequency conversion and generation across a wide range of frequencies.

title: Millisecond-Level Live Migration of Object-Detection Applications in Edge Environments
authors: Zhangyi He, Gaotao Shi, Shikang Yang, Zhijun Li, Wanyou Wang, Pingfu Chao
publish: 2025 IEEE 31th International Conference on Parallel and Distributed Systems (ICPADS)
abstract: Live migration is essential for service continuity of latency-sensitive applications in resource-constrained edge environments. However, current migration approaches for noncontainerized applications suffer from inefficiency, and existing HTTP-based state reporting methods incur substantial overhead while lacking replica pre-initialization capability, resulting in prolonged downtime. To address these limitations, we implement a prototype system that enables near-zero-downtime live migration of object-detection applications. By introducing lightweight, minimally intrusive state management interfaces, our system supports automated application pre-deployment and seamless state transfer. Experimental evaluations on a constrained 50 Mbps edge network demonstrate that object-detection applications experience an average downtime of 132.8 ms, while our solution maintains low resource consumption.

title: Quadrature Detection Systems for Contactless Probing of Active Semiconductor Devices
authors: Bryce Chung, Harrison Lees, Withawat Withayachumnankul
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: The sensitivity of terahertz waves to the presence and dynamics of free carriers within semiconductor materials is a well-established phenomenon. Previous studies have focused on using such effects to probe offline targets, such as silicon wafers, to assess dopant concentrations. We extend the concept of probing off-line wafers to on-line discrete components, demonstrating the applicability of terahertz waves for the covert inspection of devices. This abstract briefly demonstrates two different quadrature detection approaches used in our work on probing semiconductor devices.

title: Markov control of continuous time Markov processes with long run functionals by time discretization*
authors: Lukasz Stettner
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: In the paper we study continuous time controlled Markov processes using discrete time controlled Markov processes. We consider long run functionals: average reward per unit time or long run risk sensitive functional. We also investigate stability of continuous time functionals with respect to pointwise convergence of Markov controls.

title:
The Road to AI Companionship: Designing a Sentient AI Agent for Enhanced Driving Experience
                    <sup>*</sup>
authors: Mihai Duguleană, Răzvan Gabriel Boboc
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: Artificial intelligence (AI) integration in the automotive field primarily focuses on automation and driver assistance. However, the emergence of sentient AI agents offers new possibilities for enhancing user experience through interactive companionship. Recent trends indicate a growing interest in AI-driven conversational agents beyond traditional voice assistants, fostering real-time emotional intelligence and contextual understanding. This paper proposes an AI model designed to function as an in-vehicle AI companion, capable of emotional intelligence, real-time decision-making, and personalized engagement. Our approach leverages a large language model (LLM), combined with a rule-based framework, to create a robust AI companion that dynamically adapts to human behavior. The system is optimized to run on commercially available hardware, making it accessible for widespread adoption.The proposed AI agent can engage in meaningful conversations, provide weather updates, road conditions, current news, and location-based insights, such as nearby tourist attractions and landmarks. The methodology includes a mixed evaluation strategy based on a Technology Acceptance Model (TAM) with five variables encompassing simulated driving environments and real-world user testing. The findings suggest that incorporating sentient AI agents in vehicles significantly improves driver satisfaction, situational awareness, and emotional well-being, paving the way for future advancements in human-centric AI automotive applications. With a focus on real-time adaptability and naturalistic interactions, this research demonstrates the feasibility of AI companionship in modern vehicles, making transportation safer, more engaging, and more intuitive for drivers and passengers alike.

title: Terahertz Evaluation of Defense Components Using TDS scanners
authors: N. Pałka, M. Maciejewski, K. Kaminski, M. Piszczek, P. Zagrajek, E. Czerwińska
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: We present a terahertz time-domain spectroscopy (TDS) diagnostic station for testing defense and security components like ballistic armor, bulletproof vests, artillery cases and helmets. The station with four scanners enables non-destructive imaging and automatic defects detection. Tests on various samples confirmed its ability to quickly and reliably detect defects, demonstrating its effectiveness for 3D imaging.

title: Advancements in Multi-Beam Detection System for the LCT Telescope
authors: Chen Peng, Linjie Zhang, Lingchen Zuo, Boxun Wang, Duo Cao, Fangting Lin, Feng Liu, Wangzhou Shi
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: To improve the sky survey efficiency of the Leighton Chajnantor Telescope (LCT), a multi-beam detection system based on the superconducting mixing technology was explored. The status and experimental results of the system are presented.

title: Ferroelectric control of THz emission from active spintronic interfaces Via Inverse Rashba-Edelstein effects
authors: Filip Miljevic, Sylvain Massabeau, O. Paull, A. Pezo, Rodrigo Torrao Victor, Mudit Jain, Romain Lebrun, Frederic Leroy, M. Micica, S. Dhillon, M. Bibes, M. Jamet, Henri Jaffres, Jean-Marie George
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: Spintronic THz emission, based on optically induced spin-to-charge conversion (SCC) such as Inverse Spin-Hall Effect (ISHE) and Inverse Rashba-Edelstein Effect (IREE), recently emerged as a novel method for generation of electromagnetic waves in the THz bandwidth. In this talk, after having presented our THz-emission spectroscopy set-up and optical bench, we will present our main results dealing with THz emission from Rashba states of spintronics materials such as i) sputtered topological insulator BiSb, ii) GeTe ferroelectric material and iii) from 2d material stacking based PtSe<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>/MoSe<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> interfaces grown on the ferroelectric Lithium Niobate (LiNbO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf> or LNO) substrate. The latter system provides clear control of the magnitude of the THz emission vs. the direction of the ferroelectric polarization in z-cut LNO substrate with polarization normal to the 2D layers.

title: Bernstein modes in coherently excited multiple quantum wells
authors: D. Yavorskiy, F. Le Mardelé, I. Mohelsky, M. Orlita, Z. Adamus, T. Wojtowicz, J. Wróbel, K. Karpierz, J. Łusakowski
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: Terahertz Fourier magnetospectroscopy at 4.2 K was carried out in the transmission mode on a set of modulation-doped multiple CdTe/(CdMg)Te quantum wells (QWs). A metallic grid deposited on the surface of the samples allowed to excite magnetopasmons, the frequency of which was registered as a function of magnetic field up to 16 T. Analysis of the data led to the conclusion that observed magnetoplasmons resulted either from plasma excitation in one QW or coherently in all QWs in the sample. Both types of excitations showed a gap in the dispersion in the region where it crossed the frequency of the second harmonic of the cyclotron resonance, typically referred to as Bernstein modes. We described the observed dispersion relation using the theory of plasma excitation, which takes into account non-local interactions in the plasma.

title: Optimal Arrangement of Distributed Synchronous Condensers with Converted Thermal Units in Renewable Energy Stations
authors: Keming Wu, Zelong Chen, Likun Dai, Laichen Li
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Automation, Electronics and Electrical Engineering (AUTEEE)
abstract: As renewable energy continues to penetrate the power grid, the operational demand for synchronous generators has markedly decreased, resulting in many units being retired earlier than expected. However, the limited voltage support capability of renewable generation equipment brings challenges to the secure and stable operation of the power system. To mitigate these issues, this paper proposes an optimal configuration strategy for distributed synchronous condensers (DSCs) in renewable energy stations, considering the incorporation of thermal power units retrofitted into synchronous condensers to strengthen grid voltage support in a more economical manner. First, based on the multiple renewable energy stations short-circuit ratio (MRSCR) as an indicator of voltage support strength, the influence of DSC integration and varying operating modes of thermal power units on the MRSCR is examined. Then, a voltage support demand index is constructed for determining DSC siting, followed by an accurate calculation of DSC capacity requirements for sizing, along with the selection of appropriate economic evaluation indicators. On this basis, an optimal siting and sizing method for DSCs is developed. Finally, a high-renewable-penetration simulation model is established, and comparative analyses under different configuration schemes confirm the effectiveness and advantages of the proposed approach.

title: Dengue epidemic spread: modeling and optimal containment strategies
authors: Paolo Di Giamberardino, Daniela Iacoviello
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: One of the emergencies related to climate change concerns the spread of epidemics; even in areas not linked to a humid-tropical climate, Dengue, West Nile, Zika are spreading, to name the most common. Possible containment measures are linked to human behavior, such as the use of appropriate clothing, mosquito nets, repellents. Other measures concern actions to limit the reproduction of mosquitoes, for example avoiding stagnant water, and, in some cases, they are more invasive, such as acting with targeted disinfestations. The combined action of these strategies, taking into account the limitations related to their applicability and the protection of the ecosystem, is implemented in this work, within the framework of the optimal control theory. The proposed results underline the importance of prevention action and propose suggestions on how to implement the most invasive actions.

title: Cybersecurity and Intrusion Detection in Big Data’s Wireless Sensor Networks:A Survey
authors: Naima Samout, Thouraya Gouasmi, Nejah Nasri
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: Wireless Sensor Networks are becoming more and more crucial to the advancement of numerous technologies, particularly when combined with Big Data platforms. Although this connection has a lot of potential, there are challenging security challenges as well. Even though WSNs have been the subject of a lot of research, the security requirements for WSNs functioning in Big Data environments have not yet been thoroughly examined. It is also a crucial use of IoT, allowing sensors to exchange a variety of data. However, because of its inherent unreliability and natural surroundings, such a network is susceptible to numerous types of attacks, including insider attacks. Intrusion detection systems (IDSs) are commonly used in WSNs to protect against insider assaults by putting in place the right procedures and techniques. However, sensors may produce too much data in the big data era, which could reduce the efficiency of WSN computing. An overview of the security concerns and difficulties facing WSNs in the big data era is provided in this study. In order to improve the detection of insider threats and the overall security posture of WSNs, a literature review on cybersecurity IDS on WSN in the context of big data is finally suggested. It highlights advancements in IDS methodologies, including federated learning, machine learning, deep learning, and big data techniques.

title: CLF-SFC: Freshness-Aware Service Function Chain Orchestration Across End-Edge-Cloud
authors: Wenlin Cheng, Xingwei Wang, Bo Yi, Xijia Lu, Yong Zhao, Chuangchuang Zhang, Min Huang
publish: 2025 IEEE 31th International Conference on Parallel and Distributed Systems (ICPADS)
abstract: Latency-sensitive services across the end-edge-cloud continuum require not only low mean latency but explicit control of tail latency and data freshness. We propose Control-Loop Freshness-aware Service Function Chain orchestration (CLFSFC), a freshness-aware orchestration framework for Service Function Chains (SFCs) that jointly selects model variants and function placements. We define a Control-Loop Freshness (CLF) objective that combines 95th/99th-percentile (P95/P99) end-toend latency with an Age of Information (AoI) proxy. To make this objective operational under uncertainty, we allocate per-stage risk budgets via the union bound and convert mean/variance profiles into percentile constraints using Cantelli's inequality, yielding a two-stage greedy solver with interpretable quotas. We implement CLF-SFC with offline profiling of YOLOv5 n/s/m variants across end/edge/cloud devices, and evaluate it with profiling-driven measurements on COCO 2017 under synthesized network regimes. Across bandwidth and round-trip time settings, CLF-SFC reduces P95/P99 latency and Service Level Objective (SLO) violations relative to Edge-only, Cloud-only, and a riskagnostic heuristic; at high bandwidth it remains comparable to the Shortest-Latency-Path (SLP) baseline. The proposed CLF-SFC framework naturally fits embodied-AI pipelines where perception, fusion, and policy modules operate in a closed loop. By explicitly incorporating the Age-of-Information (AoI), our orchestration ties data freshness to control stability, complementing tail-latency minimization.

title: Research on Storage and Efficient Query Technologies for Massive Time Series Data
authors: Jing Zhang, Cheng Wan
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Automation, Electronics and Electrical Engineering (AUTEEE)
abstract: To address the limitations of traditional time series data storage and query technologies in terms of storage cost, query efficiency, and compression performance, we propose a Tiered Time Series Data Storage and Query (HTDSQ) algorithm. This algorithm constructs a "hot-warm-cold" three-tier storage architecture, dynamically allocating data based on access frequency, freshness, and type weight. It also designs a differentiated indexing mechanism (hot-tier hashing, warm-tier improved B+ tree, cold-tier compressed block indexing) and an adaptive compression strategy (numeric difference-Huffman coding, character-based dynamic dictionary encoding). Simulation experiments were conducted on industrial monitoring (520GB, 1 billion records) and financial transaction (410GB, 800 million records) datasets, comparing MySQL 8.0 and InfluxDB 2.0. Results show that after compression, HTDSQ reduces the storage capacity of industrial datasets to 120GB, a 57.1% reduction compared to InfluxDB 2.0 (280GB) and a 73.3% reduction compared to MySQL 8.0 (450GB). A single query takes 1.2ms, a 65.7% reduction compared to InfluxDB 2.0 (3.5ms) and an 86.4% reduction compared to MySQL 8.0 (8.8ms). The compression ratio for industrial numerical data is 1:8.5, significantly outperforming the competing solutions and effectively balancing time series data storage costs and query efficiency.

title: Gait-Based Soft Biometric Estimation Using Wearable Inertial Sensing: Comparative Evaluation and Demographic Fairness Analysis
authors: Shuo Li, Mohamed Elgendi, Carlo Menon, H. M. Rosa Chan, Edmund Y. Lam
publish: 2025 IEEE Biomedical Circuits and Systems Conference (BioCAS)
abstract: The ability to infer demographic patterns from passive inertial sensing raises important privacy considerations and has potential applications in user-aware systems. In this paper, we investigated whether natural walking patterns can provide indicative demographic insights. Building upon previous work in this field, we constructed an evaluation study to compare the performance of previous methods in IMU soft biometrics, random convolution models, and InceptionTime-based models to estimate subjects’ age and gender under a controlled and fair experimental setup on the OU-ISIR Gait Database. InceptionTime and H-InceptionTime obtained the best performance among all three tasks. The InceptionTime model achieved a mean absolute error of 6.60 years in age value regression, suggesting sufficient accuracy for coarse-grained demographicaware adaptation. It also yielded a correct classification rate of 88.88% in gender classification. H-InceptionTime achieved a correct classification rate of 59.46% in the challenging fourcategory age group classification (notably above the 25% chance level). The experimental results demonstrate the potential of using random convolution models like HYDRA, and advanced InceptionTime-based models, to effectively extract and identify subtle demographic signatures embedded in human movement patterns measured by inertial sensors.

title: Planar Design Metasurface Coupled Dual-port Same-Sense-Circularly-Polarized MIMO Antenna for X-band Applications
authors: Jyotiprakash Swain, Asutosh Mohanty, S.K. Behera, Wriddhi Bhowmik
publish: 2025 5th IEEE International Conference on Applied Electromagnetics, Signal Processing, &amp; Communication (AESPC)
abstract: A dual-port planar based metasurface coupled same-sense circularly polarized (CP) antenna has been proposed for X-band applications. To achieve consistent same-sense-CP asserted at dual-ports, a rhombic radiator enclosed by an array of meta-periodic unit cells are invoked with complimentary feeding low-loss $50 \Omega$ coaxial probes as source terminals. The metasurface diagonals are chamfered and a rectangular slot in rhombic radiator asserts $\mathbf{1 0}-\mathrm{dB}$ wideband impedance, 3-dB axial ratio response. Two CP antenna designs #Ant-1 and #Ant2 are proposed for discrete polarization with same-sense CP attributes, i.e., #Ant-1 triggers dominant right-hand-CP (RHCP) and #Ant-2 triggers dominant left-hand-CP (LHCP) radiated waves. The validation of antenna designs are extended further with fabricated prototype model of dimension $\mathbf{1. 3 3} \lambda_{0} \times \mathbf{0. 6 6} \lambda_{0} \times \mathbf{0. 0 5} \lambda_{0}$ ($\lambda_{0}=$ lowest operating wavelength at $\mathbf{1 0 ~ G H z}$) and the potential outcomes shows excellent performance merits. The operational frequency ranges from ($9.36-12.12$) GHz with 26% 10-dB IBW, from (10.5-12) GHz shows CP sensing with 3-dB ARBW of 13.3%, gain of 7.7 dBic and radiation efficiency of $\mathbf{9 7 \%}$. The port-isolations are $\gt \mathbf{2 4 d B}$, diversity parameters shows good correlation performance of $\mathbf{E C C}{\lt}0.01$, $\mathbf{D G}\gt9.98 \mathrm{~dB}$.

title: A Method for Synthesis of Complementary Quads of Binary Signals, Processed by Mismatched Filters
authors: Borislav Bedzhev, Deyan Atanasov
abstract: In the paper a new method for synthesis of complementary quads of binary signals, processed by mismatched filters with very small losses in the processing gain, is developed. The method could be applied for improving the resistance of the radar sensor networks and the remote control devices in hostile radio electronic environment.

title: THz metamaterial-based Monitoring and Authentication method for artworks
authors: Taeyeon Kim, Eui Young Rho, Minah Seo
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: In this research, we propose a method for monitoring and authenticating the artworks based on the terahertz (THz) metamaterials. By utilizing THz-time domain spectroscopy (THz-TDS), spectral fingerprints of oil paints samples in THz regime were analyzed for detection of the physicochemical property changes under various environmental factors. THz nano-slot structured metamaterials (MM) were fabricated to have resonance at specific frequency (1.47 THz) based on the extracted oil paint fingerprints. The oil paint samples were deposited onto the fabricated metasurface, then THz transmittance was measured. The measured THz transmittance spectra were fitted to the Lorentzian function to extract key parameters (A, x<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">c</inf>, w), which were digited and saved into QR codes as secure reference storage. Environmental stimuli such as heat, oxidation and UV exposure was induced to the samples, which would affect to the value of the key parameters. These changes in the parameters were visualized as ΔParameters (%) in 3D plot and its orthogonal projections to each plane, enabling accurate condition monitoring of the oil paints. Moreover, by comparing the reference parameters of the QR codes and extracted parameters from the transmittance of the current sample, our method provides unique perspective for nondestructive/labeling authentication method of the artworks.

title: The Impact of Artificial Intelligence on Quality in Smart Grid Requirements Engineering
authors: René A. Kuchenbuch, Dominik Vereno, Laura Niemann, Oliver Werth, Sebastian Lehnhoff, Jürgen Sauer
abstract: The growing complexity of the energy sector as a system of systems has led to structured approaches such as the IEC 62559 Use Case Methodology and the Smart Grid Architecture Model (SGAM) to tackle interoperability challenges as major fundament of the smart grid requirements engineering. Smart grid requirements engineering holds a unique role, as it must address the increasing diversity of actors, business models, and technologies, requiring particularly robust and adaptive methods to ensure coherence and interoperability across interconnected, independently managed systems. Artificial Intelligence (AI) is increasingly used in engineering, including requirements engineering, where it improves consistency, completeness, and traceability. This article hypothesizes that AI can similarly enhance the quality of smart grid requirements engineering and deepen system understanding. To investigate this hypothesis, we introduce and evaluate Smart Grid Assisting Artificial Intelligence in Requirements Engineering, a prototypical AI-assisted system designed to support users in creating, analyzing, and validating IEC 62559 Use Cases and SGAM Models. SGAAIRE operationalizes AI-based quality assurance by integrating reasoning and validation mechanisms tailored to the specific structures and semantics of these artifacts. Within a randomized controlled trial, conventional modeling approaches were compared with the AI-assisted method implemented in SGAAIRE. The results demonstrate that integrating AI into the quality assurance process can improve the quality of IEC 62559 Use Cases and SGAM Models, particularly among experienced users. AI can aid especially in the dimensions of correctness, consistency, and traceability – without reducing user awareness for additional, non-obvious errors.

title: Research on Loss Calculation Methods for Power Electronic Inverter
authors: Gao Xuesi, Lin Ziheng, Xu Zheyuan, Sui Xiaofei, Huang Yiqian
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Automation, Electronics and Electrical Engineering (AUTEEE)
abstract: The inverter based on fully controlled semiconductor devices is the core of power conversion in PWM rectifiers and the main source of converter losses. Therefore, accurately analyzing and evaluating inverter losses is crucial for optimizing product efficiency. Currently, methods such as simulation software and analytical calculations can obtain loss values of various inverter components, providing data support for preliminary design and component-level guidance for product optimization. However, factors like switching stress, harmonics, contact resistance, and deviations in component rated parameters are difficult to accurately quantify, which affects the precision of loss calculations. Meanwhile, testing methods such as calorimetry often only capture partial component loss data, making it difficult to achieve precise efficiency improvements. This paper takes a cascaded bipolar inverter as an example. First, the theoretical calculation methods for inverter losses are analyzed and explained. Then, a data acquisition model for steady-state operation of the inverter is constructed, and based on experimentally collected data, the calculation methods for losses of various inverter components are derived and decomposed to guide the efficiency optimization of the rectifier system. Subsequently, a steady-state operation model of the entire system is established to estimate inverter losses from a system-level perspective, and the results are compared with the aforementioned loss calculations. Finally, using measured parameters from an actual engineering case, the losses from theoretical calculations and the steady-state operation-based model are compared to analyze the accuracy of the calculations.

title: Dynamic Multi-Objective Task Offloading in Edge Computing via Proximal Policy Optimization with Hybrid Prioritized Experience Replay
authors: Xiaoli Lu, Gaizhi Guo
publish: 2025 IEEE 31th International Conference on Parallel and Distributed Systems (ICPADS)
abstract: With the rapid development of Internet of Things, Smart Manufacturing, and Telematics, edge devices are facing increasing computational demands and limited resources. Efficient multi-objective task offloading in dynamic network environments has become a key challenge in edge computing. This paper proposes a Proximal Policy Optimization algorithm based on Hybrid Prioritized Experience Replay (HyPER-PPO) for multi-objective optimization of task offloading decisions. The offloading process is modeled as a multi-objective Markov decision process (MOMDP), with a dynamic weight adjustment mechanism to adaptively balance delay and energy consumption. To address sample inefficiency in Proximal Policy Optimization, we introduce a hybrid prioritized replay mechanism based on Temporal Difference (TD) error and Generalized Advantage Estimation (GAE), enabling the reuse of high-value historical experiences. Additionally, an Importance Sampling (IS) weight is applied to correct bias caused by non-uniform sampling, improving update stability. Experimental results show that Multi-Objective HyPER-PPO significantly outperforms the UCB1, SPEA/R, and NSGA-III algorithms, achieving <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{7 3 \%}$</tex> lower task latency and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{5 6 \%}$</tex> lower energy consumption in complex MEC environments. The proposed approach offers a scalable and effective solution for intelligent task offloading in real-world edge computing systems.

title: Decentralized Control Strategy for Path-Following in Snake Robots
authors: Arpit Dwivedi, Hemanta Hazarika, Dwaipayan Mukherjee, Debasattam Pal
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: Path following and control research done so far for the modular snake robots is known to have the foundational assumption that friction acts exactly at the link’s center of mass. However, inspired by the biological snakes, we observe that friction acts as an uneven distribution over the snake’s body. The paper contributes towards a general modeling of the snake robot that incorporates an eccentric point where the friction force acts on each module. Moreover, we have proposed a decentralized path following control algorithm for our general model. The proposed algorithm exploits local link-level autonomy and helps the robot maneuver smoothly for any general path curve. We apply our algorithm to four different types of path curves and find promising results in the path following.

title: PAPR reduction of OFDM signals using partial transmit sequence: an optimal approach using sphere decoding
authors: A. Alavi, C. Tellambura, I. Fair
abstract: Partial transmit sequence (PTS) is a promising technique for peak-to-average-power ratio (PAPR) reduction in orthogonal frequency division multiplexing (OFDM) systems. Computation of optimal PTS weight factors via exhaustive search requires exponential complexity in the number of subblocks; consequently, many suboptimal strategies have been developed to date. In this letter, we introduce an efficient algorithm for computing the optimal PTS weights that has lower complexity than exhaustive search.

title: A Tri-Stage Cooperative Optimization Algorithm With Q-Learning Mechanism for the Multiobjective Distributed Flexible Job Shop Scheduling With Worker Factors
authors: Fuqing Zhao, Jiali Gao, Ling Wang, Hongyan Sang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics: Systems
abstract: The production process of aluminum profiles is a typical distributed flexible job shop environment. The scheduling problem in distributed systems with worker factors is a complex combinatorial optimization problem. In this article, the multiobjective distributed flexible job shop scheduling with worker factors (MO-DFJSPWF), including proficiency and the learning–forgetting effect, is studied to minimize makespan and total resource load (TRL). A mixed-integer linear programming (MILP) model is established according to the degree of proficiency and the rate of learning–forgetting effect of the workers. A tri-stage cooperative optimization algorithm (TSCOA) is designed for the MO-DFJSPWF. First, a knowledge-based initialization method considering worker proficiency, machine load, and job priority is proposed to generate the initial population of the problem. Second, a bi-population cooperative strategy with a dynamic adaptive search strategy (DASS) is developed to balance the convergence speed and candidate diversity of the algorithm. Eight perturbation operators in the second and third stages are introduced to explore and exploit the solution space of the TSCOA. Third, the perturbation operators are selected dynamically via the Q-learning mechanism by leveraging the historical performance data of local search operators. The effectiveness and efficiency of the TSCOA are tested on a benchmark test suite. The experimental results indicated that the performance of the TSCOA outperforms certain state-of-the-art algorithms in solving MO-DFJSPWF.

title: Poster: Boosting Inter-Procedural Vulnerability Detection via Retrieval-Augmented Generation
authors: Linru Ma, Hongquan Xu, Hongyu Kuang, Feng Yang, Boyu Deng
publish: 2025 IEEE 31th International Conference on Parallel and Distributed Systems (ICPADS)
abstract: Traditional LLM-based vulnerability detection methods face challenges like hallucinations and high false positive rates. In order to overcome these constraints, we propose an innovative RAG-based method for inter-procedural vulnerability detection named IPVRAG. The main innovation design of our IPVRAG is its multi-level feature extraction strategy: during knowledge base construction, it not only extracts functional semantics and vulnerability causes but also stores pruned Data Flow Graph structures and semantic identifier information. Evaluated on a widely-used dataset, IPVRAG outperformed many of LLM-based baselines. It achieved optimal overall performance in inter-procedural vulnerability detection, particularly demonstrating superior precision-recall balance that effectively reduced false negatives.

title: Fourier Transform Infrared Microspectroscopy on Glass Substrates in the Fingerprint Region Enabled by Deep Neural Network
authors: Xiangyu Zhao, Jingzhu Shao, Yudong Tian, Zhiqiang Gui, Ping Tang, Zhihong Wang, Chongzhao Wu
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: Dependency on specialized infrared (IR) substrates limits the effective and widespread clinical translation of Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) microspectroscopy as a pivotal pathological tool. Compared to 1 mm thick pathological glass substrates, IR transparent bases are costly and fragile, while IR reflective bases are opaque to visible light, calling for an effective way to test IR spectra on glass bases. Here, we propose a methodology to restore high-quality IR fingerprint absorbance from glass-based spectra spanning the wavenumber from 1800 cm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">-1</sup> to 1000 cm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">-1</sup> by training a deep neural network, termed glass substrate spectral restoration neural network (GLASSR-Net). The GLASSR-Net is demonstrated to successfully restore the sample absorbance and accurately reconstruct the biochemical distribution in both the spatial and spectral domains, which presents a novel framework for data collection, spectral restoration, and integration of traditional methodology in glass-based IR microspectroscopy.

title: Unbalanced Fault Ride-Through in Grid-Forming Modular Multilevel Converters
authors: Ye Zhu, Shan Jiang, Georgios Konstantinou
publish: IEEE Journal of Emerging and Selected Topics in Power Electronics
abstract: Unbalanced grid conditions generate negative-sequence (NS) components in power systems and lead to oscillating output power from converters, posing technical challenges to the fault ride-through (FRT) capabilities of grid-forming (GFM) converters. The current limiter in the GFM converter avoids overcurrent issues during contingencies but it compromises system synchronization stability under grid voltage sags if the power synchronization loop (PSL) is used. This paper proposes a GFM control scheme based on the current synchronization loop (CSL) as a generalized solution for enhancing system synchronization stability under both balanced and unbalanced grid voltage sags. Theoretical analysis informs the selection of power control coefficients to coordinate unbalanced FRT objectives, including oscillating active power elimination and negative-sequence voltage suppression. An adaptive unbalanced limiter for GFM modular multilevel converters (MMCs) is further proposed based on the characteristics of the internal arm current, making full use of the power semiconductor current ratings and improving fault current contribution. The combination of the adaptive current limiter with the CSL-based GFM control allows GFM MMCs to provide additional reactive power to support positive-sequence voltage and suppress NS voltage at the PCC, enhancing their unbalanced FRT capabilities. All these grid supporting functionalities are quantified and validated with hardware experimental results from a laboratory-scale, grid-connected GFM MMC system.

title: Electronically Tunable Half-Mode Substrate-Integrated Waveguide Coupler
authors: Laeeq Riaz, Haider Ali, Bilal Tariq Malik, Adnan Iftikhar, Muhammad Farhan Shafique, Jamal Nasir, Slawomir Koziel
abstract: This paper presents the design and implementation of a compact and highly efficient –10 dB directional coupler based on a half-mode substrate integrated waveguide cavity resonator configuration. The proposed structure is based on stub-loaded cavity resonators that are responsible for coupling the desired energy to the auxiliary port. A four-resonator arrangement is used to realize the desired coupling level of –10 dB while maintaining compact dimensions. Experimental validation demonstrates a reflection coefficient better than –15 dB, insertion loss below 1.56 dB, and isolation exceeding 15 dB across the operational bandwidth 4.341-5.26 GHz (≈919 MHz bandwidth). Furthermore, a 90-degree phase difference between the through and coupled ports is maintained. The coupler also exhibits tunable coupling characteristics at the coupled port, with experimentally verified coupling levels ranging from 5 dB to 10 dB, highlighting its reconfigurability for adaptive microwave applications.

title: Lamb-dip Spectroscopy in Rotational Levels of Acetonitrile Molecules with UTC-PD THz Emitter
authors: Kohei. Eguchi, Koichiro. Tanaka
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: We have performed Lamb-dip spectroscopy in the rotational transition of gas-phase acetonitrile molecules in the sub-THz region. We observed Lamb-dips at much lower excitation powers than previously reported. The linewidth in the zero-pressure limit was 10 kHz, which was estimated from the intensity and pressure dependence. This corresponds to the transit-time broadening.

title: Elastic Heterogeneity and Infrared Boson Peak in Hydrogen-Bonded Glycerol Glass
authors: Soo Han Oh, Dan Kyotani, Suguru Kitani, Yasuhiro Fujii, Shinji Kohara, Tatsuya Mori
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: The boson peak (BP) is an anomalous excess in the vibrational density of states in the terahertz (THz) region of glasses, playing a key role in their low-energy excitations. Understanding BP is essential not only for elucidating the nanoscale mechanical properties of glasses but also for controlling their THz optical properties. In this study, we quantitatively analyzed BP in glycerol, a representative hydrogen-bonded glass, using the heterogeneous elasticity theory (HET). By solving the coherent potential approximation (CPA) equation for the shear modulus, we extracted both the spatial correlation length of elastic heterogeneity and the magnitude of elastic fluctuations, which govern the BP frequency and intensity. Our results demonstrate that the nanoscale elasticity of glycerol significantly affects its BP characteristics, which in turn influence its THz optical response. This study highlights the potential of BP analysis as a framework for tailoring the THz optical properties of glasses, opening new possibilities for the design of functional disordered materials.

title: A Self-Training and Semi-Supervised-Based Microservice Performance Prediction Method for Cloud-Native Microservices
authors: Ruijie Cao, Jia Hao, Hongyan Xia
publish: 2025 IEEE 31th International Conference on Parallel and Distributed Systems (ICPADS)
abstract: Cloud-native microservices, with a loosely-coupled architecture, enable elastic deployment, scalability, and streamlined development cycles while reducing software updating complexity. However, due to scarce labeled performance data and intricate node interactions, ensuring quality of service (QoS) and optimizing resource allocation remain challenging. To address these limitations, we propose a self-training and semi-supervised learning-based microservice performance prediction method (SMPP). Specifically, SMPP collects limited microservices labeled resource-performance data, and then constructs a self-training and semi-supervised microservice performance prediction model, which predicts the performance of microservice nodes under dynamic resource constraints. To validate the effectiveness of our proposed method, we deploy SMPP on Docker Engine and DeathStarBench, and the experimental results demonstrate that SMPP outperforms conventional methods in predicting critical resource metrics, confirming its efficacy for microservice performance prediction.
