title: KMPE Loss Function-Based Clustering Multi-View Point Cloud Registration Algorithm
authors: Shengmei Chen, Jingyi Han, Lu Ren, Tianzhang Xing, Lin Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE 31th International Conference on Parallel and Distributed Systems (ICPADS)
abstract: Multi-view point cloud registration remains a significant challenge in 3D computer vision due to the sensitivity to outliers. In this paper, we propose a clustering multi-view point cloud registration algorithm based on kernel mean p-power error (KMPE) loss function. Firstly, the 3D point clouds are clustered by using the K-means algorithm, where the centroids of the clusters are regarded as the model point cloud for multi-view point cloud registration. Secondly, the model point cloud is used to estimate the rigid transformation of each point cloud sequentially. Considering that the KMPE loss function can efficiently suppress outliers, a robust point cloud rigid registration optimization model based on the KMPE loss function is established. The Levenberg-Marquardt (LM) algorithm is adopted to optimize the optimization model to obtain the optimal rigid transformation between each point cloud and the model point cloud. Finally, the clustering and KMPE-based rigid transformation estimation are iteratively and alternatively applied to all point clouds to realize multi-view point cloud registration. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed algorithm can effectively suppress the influence of outliers on the multi-view point cloud registration of, and can achieve high accuracy of multi-view point cloud registration.

title: Research on Transformer Operation Status Monitoring and Fault Warning Technology Based on Big Data Analysis
authors: Ruojia Gang, Jiguang Xue, Chang Liu, Keyi Liu, Hao Zhou
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Automation, Electronics and Electrical Engineering (AUTEEE)
abstract: This paper proposes a LSTM-Random Forest fusion algorithm based on an improved attention mechanism for transformer fault warning. This algorithm combines the LSTM's ability to capture temporal dependencies with the strong classification performance of the random forest. By dynamically adjusting feature weights through an improved attention mechanism, it addresses the irrational feature weight distribution problem found in traditional methods. Experiments used operational data from 100 transformers in a 220kV substation cluster of a provincial power grid company in China (January to December 2023, 16 parameter categories, 1.2TB), to compare the performance of traditional LSTM, random forest, and the proposed algorithm. Results show that the proposed algorithm achieves an accuracy of 98.5%, an improvement of 6.2% and 5.0% over traditional LSTM and random forest, respectively. It also achieves a warning lead time of 4.5 hours and a fault loss avoidance rate of 91.2%, both significantly outperforming the competing algorithms. The introduction of the improved attention mechanism improves the algorithm's accuracy by 3.2% and precision by 2.8%, validating its effectiveness. This algorithm achieves an early warning accuracy exceeding 97% for four types of faults, including insulation aging and core saturation, meeting the actual needs of power systems.

title: On the Stabilization of Unstable Internal Dynamics: Model Predictive Control of Feedback Linearized Vehicle Kinematics
authors: Bernd Juris, Pu Li
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: In this paper, we propose an approach to stabilize unstable internal dynamics occurring from the feedback linearization of a kinematic vehicle model. Since the input affine model formulated has no full relative degree, a diffeomorphic transformation is performed to reduce the internal dynamics to an integration of the steering speed of the vehicle. We then introduce a Lyapunov candidate to ensure asymptotic stability. Incorporating this Lyapunov function, the resulting input-output linearized system is stabilized with a model predictive control (MPC) scheme. The new internal dynamics is posed as equality constraints in the feedback linearized MPC framework. Numerical results demonstrate that the proposed approach provides a satisfactory control performance and takes a significant lower computation time in comparison to a nonlinear MPC based on the original model.

title: Comparative Evaluation of Machine Learning Models for Credit Scoring in FinTech Applications
authors: Sayyed Khawar Abbas
abstract: Proper credit scoring is also crucial for controlling financial risks and targeting customers in the financial technology (FinTech) industry. Although conventional statistical modeling has always been the modeling choice, its successor, modern machine learning (ML) algorithms, demonstrates more outstanding predictive power. However, these models often involve a trade-off between predictive accuracy and interpretability. This study contrasts the results of three well-known ML models: Logistic Regression, Random Forest, and XGBoost. The tools were applied to a real-life dataset of a financial institution, namely, personal loan data. The evaluation metrics used were accuracy, precision, recall, F1-score, and Area Under the Curve (AUC), receiver operating characteristic. According to the results, XGBoost achieves the highest overall performance, with an impressive accuracy of 98.5% and a recall score of 96.9%. Close behind was Random Forest with its competitive performance. Logistic Regression provided better interpretability, but it was not as accurate as recall. This weak point suggests that more people who could actually be creditworthy will be discounted as applicants. These insights enable practitioners to make informed decisions about the most suitable ML methods to adopt in credit scoring tasks, particularly where accuracy and sensitivity are key considerations. In addition, the current analysis will establish a performance reference that will be useful when attempting to enhance transparency and fairness in future credit decision processes driven by AI.

title: Computational Framework for Multi-UAV Smoke-Munition Scheduling: Chaos-Mapped, Gaussian-Mutated PSO for Trajectory–Timing Optimization
authors: Zhixiao Li, Sichen Sun, Jintong Zhu, Jie Li
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Automation, Electronics and Electrical Engineering (AUTEEE)
abstract: This paper addresses simulation-based decision optimization for coordinating UAV-deployed smoke munitions to mask a protected target from an incoming missile. A three-dimensional kinematic model defines a line-of-sight masking metric under motion, timing, and spacing constraints, and a computational framework centered on particle swarm optimization is developed. The framework progressively enriches PSO with genetic mutation and adaptive learning (for multi-munition scheduling) and with chaos-mapped inertia, Gaussian mutation, and hash-table memoization (for multi-UAV coordination), while a union-overlap procedure aggregates discontinuous masking intervals. Across staged scenarios, the approach attains masking durations of 1.4 s (fixed-parameter baseline), 4.80 s (single munition optimization), 7.40 s (three munitions), and 13.20 s (three UAVs), with stable convergence and efficient runtimes under strict feasibility checks. The result is a practical and robust trajectory–timing optimizer that generalizes to countermeasure scheduling problems requiring fast, constraint-aware search in high-dimensional spaces.

title: HiPOD: Hierarchical Pruning for Low-Distinction Multi-Scale Object Detection on Edge Devices
authors: Jieyu Zhou, Feng Lyu, Mingliu Liu, Hao Wu, Xueying Li, Fan Wu, Yaoxue Zhang
publish: 2025 IEEE 31th International Conference on Parallel and Distributed Systems (ICPADS)
abstract: The deployment of high-accuracy low-distinction and multi-scale object detection models on resource-constrained edge devices is essential for ubiquitous intelligent applications, from autonomous obstacle avoidance to anomaly object recognition. However, these models' computational burden, energy consumption, and memory footprint pose significant challenges for distributed and pervasive systems. In this paper, we propose HiPOD, a hierarchical pruning framework designed to prune low-distinction and multi-scale object detection models by jointly learning layer-wise and path-wise pruning strategies. HiPOD balances the accuracy-efficiency trade-off through two novel components: Layer-Adaptive Ratio Learning, named AdaLR, which leverages network structural characteristics and a reinforcement learning-based action-feedback mechanism to adaptively generate balanced layer-wise pruning ratios; and Genetic Path Optimization, named GenPath, which employs crossover and mutation operations to optimize inter-layer kernel pruning paths, preserving critical semantic and spatial information. Extensive experiments on three benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of HiPOD, with only a 3 % drop in mAP50 and a 2 % drop in mAP50:95 compared to the full models. The ablation studies and impact analysis further validate the effectiveness of each module and highlight the robustness of our framework. Furthermore, evaluations on an edge device demonstrate the practicality of the proposed solution for powerline inspection.

title: Ultrafast Terahertz Responses of TMDC Thin Films monitored by Optical Pump Terahertz Probe Spectroscopy
authors: Aytekin Y. Samet, Jamet Matthieu, Altan Hakan, Esenturk Okan
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: Few-layer Transition Metal Dichalchogenide (TMDC) heterostructures coated on mica by CVD technique were analysed for their dynamic properties by Optical Pump Terahertz Probe spectroscopy. The observed fast dynamics imply that the samples suit well for THz device applications and high-frequency requiring optoelectronic structures.

title: A Hybrid Deep Learning Framework for Brain Tumor Detection Fusing CycleGAN-based Augmentation with U-Net and DenseNet
authors: K. Elavarasi, C. Indumathy, S. Kanaga Vaarshini
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Automation, Computing and Renewable Systems (ICACRS)
abstract: The manual interpretation of magnetic resonance imaging to identify the presence of cerebral tumors is still a time-consuming and objective task, which in most cases leads to diagnostic delay. To overcome this shortcoming, the current study is initiating a hybrid deep-learning model, which advances in unity with its blended state-of-the-art models, thus making unassisted and precision diagnosis of cerebral tumors. The framework suggested is designed with the help of a three-stage pipeline. A Cycle-Consistent Generative Adversarial Network (CycleGAN) is used first to implement data augmentation and modality synthesis effectively by increasing the limited training corpus with the created realistic synthetic magnetic resonance images. This is followed by an application of a U-Net architecture, which performs high-accuracy pixel-wise segmentation and, therefore, localizes the tumor area and describes a region of interest that entraps non-lethal background data. Finally, the obtained region of interest is classified in a set of DenseNet-121 and VGG16 convolutional neural networks. Their predictions amplitude is then combined to present the final diagnostic result using an ensemble-learning module with more weight given to DenseNet-121 due to its excellent success in terms of feature-extraction capabilities. It is expected that the system will reach a 98% classification accuracy with a high accuracy and recall rate, which highlights the potential of the system as a powerful decision support system that can be utilized to speed up diagnosis and improve patient outcomes in clinical care.

title: Optimization of Wireless Charging Technology for Electric Vehicles
authors: Zhongyu Shu
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Automation, Electronics and Electrical Engineering (AUTEEE)
abstract: For the convenience of the trip, it is important to optimize wireless charging technology for electric vehicles. Though now the wireless charging technology for electric vehicles has been developed, it is still not widespread. This paper researches how to deal with the problem of reduced wireless charging efficiency caused by the appearance of excessive vertical distance between the coil on the road and the coil in the vehicle, and the appearance of the lateral distance between the coils. The paper adopts the approaches of utilizing mechanical devices to reduce the position of the coils to lower the vertical distance between the coils and covering the roads with coils to lower the lateral distance between the coils, conducts simulation experiments, draws the conclusion that the approaches can increase the efficiency of energy transmission between the coils in electric vehicles with wireless charging capabilities and the coils on the roads, and finally increase the wireless charging efficiency. The approach of installing wireless charging coils inside the wheels may become one of the ways to optimize the wireless charging technology for electric vehicles.

title: Terahertz rectification up to 2.5 THz by using an Asymmetric Dual-Grating Gate GFETs via ratchet effect
authors: E. Abidi, V. Clericó, J. Calvo-Gallego, T. Taniguchi, K. Watanabe, T. Otsuji, J.E. Velázquez Pérez, Y.M. Meziani
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: Asymmetric dual grating gates graphene field effect transistor (FET) was fabricated and characterized at two tones terahertz frequency 0.15 & 0.3 THz at 10K. The channel of the device was a monolayer graphene placed between two sheets of hexagonal boron nitride h-BN. Enhancement of the measured photocurrent was observed at a bias of different signs between the top and the back gates. This behavior was associated with the ratchet effect that is induced by both biasing and THz radiation. This opens the way for the development of new highly efficient detectors of terahertz radiation for different applications.

title: Synthesis of Passively Loaded Reflectarrays for Perfect Anomalous Deflection
authors: Sravan K. R. Vuyyuru, Risto Valkonen, Viktar S. Asadchy, Do-Hoon Kwon, Sergei A. Tretyakov
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: Achieving wide-angle beam steering without parasitic scattering is essential for large-scale passive anomalous reflectarrays in RIS applications. This talk presents a novel design methodology for planar antenna arrays using reactive loads to enable efficient, tunable anomalous reflection. Unlike conventional reflectarrays, the technique allows efficient extreme-angle beam steering while minimizing undesired scattering by accurately optimizing sub-wavelength current distributions. Each meta-atom, equipped with a tunable bulk component (e.g., capacitor), is treated as a linear multi-port network, allowing algebraic load optimization. The results pave the way for scalable, reconfigurable reflectarrays for next-generation wireless architectures.

title: On the Issue of an Anomaly Detection Algorithm for Identifying Potentially Generated Entangled Photons
authors: Serhii Aleksieienko, Dmytro Babets, Kamil Wereszczyński, Krzysztof A. Cyran
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: Detecting entangled photons is critical for quantum technologies but challenging due to weak signals, noise, and rarity. This study proposes a fast, unsupervised anomaly detection algorithm using a multivariate Gaussian distribution to identify potential entangled photon events. Applied to data from spontaneous parametric down-conversion (SPDC) and silicon photomultiplier (SiMP) detectors, it successfully detected rare correlated events, offering a simple, efficient tool for quantum optics.

title: A Survey on Multimodal Data Fusion for Autonomous Collaborative Robots: Advances and real world challenges
authors: Khalil Zarrouk, Lamia Rzouga Haddada, Sami Gazzah
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: Collaborative robots (cobots) are revolutionizing industries, warfare, and smart cities. Multimodal data fusion (MMDF) enables a smart system to predict or decide based on the basis of multiple sensor input modalities. This survey comprehensively reviews MMDF techniques and their use cases for various cobots architectures and general approaches for multi-robot cooperation. By addressing future directions and challenges such as real-time processing and robustness in dynamic environments and identifying open research questions, this survey aims to guide future developments in the field, fostering innovation in robot collaboration.

title: A Comparative Analysis on the Differences Between Client-Side Databases and Server-Side Databases
authors: Shayantan Bose, Sathvik S Rao, Ansh Ezhava, J. Shajeena
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Automation, Computing and Renewable Systems (ICACRS)
abstract: Databases play an important role in creating any contemporary software or web-based application. Historically databases are of various kinds, such as relational, non-relational, and cloud databases. With the HTML5 standardization, local or session-based storage databases have become more popular that are directly included in web browsers. While client-side storage has its advantages like offline usage and server computation offloading, it also has its own drawbacks, such as the need for local space dependency. Historic server-side databases still enjoy scalability advantages.Within this review paper, we examine the performance of client-side local storage databases (IndexedDB and LocalStorage) in Google Chrome 134. We also compare it with server-side databases, such as PostgreSQL, MySQL, and the non-relational database MongoDB. Our test cases consist of the most prevalent create, read, update, and delete (CRUD) operations. Recognizing these differences in performance is important, since optimizing where data is located will yield a better-performing application with seamless user interaction. This comparison hopes to assist developers in choosing the correct database, since the selection ultimately lies with the size and needs of the application.

title: Spatially patterned photoexcitation for enhanced THz emission from photoconductive antennas
authors: Rayko I. Stantchev, Simon A. R. Horsley, Samuel M. Hornett, Peter Hobson, Euan Hendry
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: Terahertz (THz) time domain spectrometers have been used in security, bio-medical imaging and non-invasive inspections of both car paint and historical paintings. Signal to noise ratios and therefore speed of acquisition is currently limited by the low output power of the photoconductive anntenna's used to generate the single cycle THz pulse. Here, by using a digital micromirror device to spatially pattern the photoexcitation profile of a photoconductive antenna into periodic stripes, we show enhanced THz generation when compared to a homogeneous excitation profile.

title: GOOSE-Optimized Neural Network for Day-Ahead PV Power Forecasting
authors: Yushu Du, Zhenhua Zhu, Xuanwei Zhang, Jianyong Tuo
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Big Data, Artificial Intelligence and Internet of Things Engineering (ICBAIE)
abstract: Accurate day-ahead forecasting of photovoltaic (PV) power output is critical for ensuring the stability and economic operation of modern power grids. This paper proposes a multi-stage, hybrid forecasting framework designed to enhance prediction accuracy through a systematic integration of physical modeling and advanced machine learning techniques. Firstly, a theoretical power output model based on solar geometry and system parameters was established as an analytical baseline. This model revealed that the actual output is approximately 72% of the theoretical maximum, with distinct and predictable seasonal variations. Secondly, a backpropagation (BP) neural network optimized by the novel GOOSE Algorithm (GOOSE-BP) was developed for time-series prediction. It achieved a goodness-of-fit R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> of 0.91223 and significantly outperformed the traditional BP model by maintaining prediction errors in a tight band around zero. Thirdly, the model’s predictive power was augmented by incorporating numerical weather prediction (NWP) variables, which were systematically selected based on a Random Forest feature importance analysis. This enhancement elevated the model’s R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> to 0.95445. A scenario classification model further demonstrated robust performance under distinct weather conditions (sunny, cloudy, and overcast). Finally, a spatial downscaling feature construction model was implemented to refine the resolution of meteorological inputs, which, when coupled with a multi-model ensemble (GOOSE-BP, XGBoost, Random Forest), further reduced prediction errors. The optimized GOOSE-BP model achieved a final Root Mean Square Error (RMSE) of 0.0498 and an R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> of 0.9716. The results confirm that this multi-stage, integrated approach provides a highly accurate and reliable solution for PV power forecasting.

title: Sentimental Analysis and Forecasting using Machine Learning Algorithms
authors: Deepshikha Saxena, Jyoti Sharma, Gaurav Kumar Soni, Yogesh Rao, Shailendra Sharma, Shivank Lavania
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Automation, Computing and Renewable Systems (ICACRS)
abstract: Sentiment analysis can be used to gain insight about the views of customers to make business decisions better as well as look into upcoming trends. In this study, the analysis of Amazon product reviews through the use of machine learning algorithms is used to determine the sentiment of customers and also to identify the trend in future. The pre-processing methods, such as text cleaning, tokenizing, and lemmatizing are used in such study and in this work used oversampling and under sampling to balance the classes. Sentiment forecasting, deals with missing values and resampling time-series data and normalizing sentiment scores. The TF-IDF is part of the feature extraction in classification and more time-series features enhance the forecast. It splits the data into the ratio of 80-20 split in order to evaluate the same. The sentiment classification in this study has employed Support Vector Machine (SVM), Naive Bayes (NB), and Logistic Regression (LR) with their accuracies being 89 percent 87 percent and 88 percent respectively and SVM gave the best accuracy. Sentiment forecasting is carried out with the help of an LSTM model, which proves to be excellent in the capture of how things evolve with time. A real-time sentiment analysis interactive application is developed and users can classify reviews and even evaluate how models perform. This research pinpoints the positivity of machine learning in sentiment analysis use and how it is applied in the real world.

title: NIST Post-Quantum Cryptography Standards: A Comprehensive Review of Theoretical Foundations and Implementations
authors: Quang Dang Truong, Hien Nguyen, Tuy Tan Nguyen, Hanho Lee
abstract: The transition to post-quantum cryptography (PQC) marks a pivotal shift in ensuring digital security, prompted by the potential of quantum computers to compromise classical systems such as Rivest-Shamir-Adlema and elliptic-curve cryptography. In response, NIST has standardized three foundational PQC algorithms: Module-lattice-based Key-encapsulation Mechanism for key establishment; Module-lattice-based Digital Signature, and Stateless Hash-based Digital Signature algorithms for digital signatures. Meanwhile, FALCON and Hamming Quasi-cyclic (HQC) schemes, both selected as finalists, are expected to join the standards soon. This paper presents a comprehensive survey of these NIST-selected PQC standards, with a dual focus on software implementations and hardware architecture designs. We analyze their mathematical frameworks, distinctive features, and optimization strategies related to performance, security, and resource efficiency. The software review examines algorithmic complexity, memory usage, and programming considerations, while the hardware review discusses FPGA and ASIC implementations, emphasizing modular arithmetic, polynomial operations, and resource efficiency challenges. A comparative analysis highlights the strengths and trade-offs of each algorithm, offering insights into their applicability across various platforms-from resource-constrained internet of things devices to high-performance computing environments. This study provides a foundational understanding of NIST’s selected PQC standards and their practical deployment in securing the post-quantum era.

title: Fully On-Chip Isolated Gate Driver IC for Efficient Power Control
authors: L S S Pavan Kumar Chodisetti, Yun-Che Chang, Mitch Ming-Chi Chou, Chua-Chin Wang
abstract: A high-efficiency and high-isolation power device driver system is disclosed in this investigation featuring an on-chip coil coupler to carry out high-speed digital signal trans-mission from the primary side to the secondary side, such that power MOSFETs in robotic systems, e.g., GaN and SiC devices, will be driven reliably and effectively. The proposed design is realized using a typical HV CMOS process and verified by on-silicon measurement to demonstrate 148 mW at 1 MHz data rate and 5 V power supply voltage.

title: Low-Power TinyML CNN Accelerator using Integrated Clock Gating for Edge Devices
authors: Shashi Kant Dargar, Akash, Antony Fedrick, Avinash Kumar
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Automation, Computing and Renewable Systems (ICACRS)
abstract: In this work, a compact low-power convolutional neural network (CNN) hardware accelerator is developed for TinyML-based edge AI systems. The design applies integrated clock gating (ICG) using Synopsys EDA tools, where gating decisions are guided by real switching activity captured in SAIF files. This approach effectively reduces dynamic power without affecting timing or area efficiency. The Verilog RTL architecture includes modules such as a line buffer, adaptive multiplier supporting exact and approximate modes, ReLU, pooling, and automated clock control. When synthesized with a 45 nm standard-cell library, the proposed accelerator achieved 38.2% lower dynamic power and an improved timing slack of 3.41 ns. Functional correctness was verified through simulation and waveform inspection, confirming the design’s reliability. The overall methodology is reproducible and suitable for energy-constrained IoT and always-on microcontroller platforms.

title: Separation Approach to Adaptive Control for Robot Manipulators Without Joint-Space and Task-Space Velocity Measurements
authors: Bo Zhang, Changchun Hua, Jiafeng Zhou, Jian Zhang, Yu Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics: Systems
abstract: This article investigates the task-space adaptive control problem of robot manipulators under both uncertain dynamics and kinematics. The proposed algorithm employs dual observers for the dynamic and kinematic loops to estimate joint-space and task-space velocity signals, thereby eliminating numerical differentiation, mitigating sensor-noise effects, and avoiding reliance on high-precision velocity sensors, which collectively improve control accuracy. Moreover, the controller achieves the desired separation between the dynamic and kinematic loops even in the presence of time-varying control coefficients. This separation simplifies controller synthesis and stability analysis and reduces conservatism in controller-gain selection caused by loop coupling. Finally, the asymptotic convergence of the task-space tracking error is established via the Lyapunov stability theory. The effectiveness of the proposed scheme is demonstrated through comparative simulations and experiments.

title: MERBench: A Unified Evaluation Benchmark for Multimodal Emotion Recognition_supp1-3653457.pdf
authors: Zheng Lian
abstract: Multimodal emotion recognition plays a vital role in enhancing user experience in human-computer interaction. Over the past few decades, researchers have developed a range of algorithms and made remarkable progress. While each approach demonstrates certain advantages, inconsistent choices in feature extraction methods, evaluation protocols, and experimental settings have hindered fair comparisons among them. These inconsistencies significantly impede the advancement of the field. To address this issue, we introduce MERBench, a unified evaluation benchmark for multimodal emotion recognition. Our goal is to assess the contributions of several key techniques commonly used in prior studies, such as feature selection, multimodal fusion, robustness analysis, fine-tuning, and pre-training. We believe this work offers clear and comprehensive guidance for future research. Based on the evaluation results of MERBench, we further point out some promising research directions. In addition, we present a new emotion dataset, MER2023, specifically designed for the Chinese language environment. This dataset serves as a benchmark for research in multi-label learning, noise robustness, and semi-supervised learning. and encourage researchers to evaluate their algorithms under the same experimental setup as MERBench for fair comparisons.

title: Fast 64-Bit Integer Multipliers for FPGAs
authors: Takumi Hikino, Wakana Ohashi, Hiroyuki Tomiyama
abstract: Multipliers play a crucial role in various computing applications, including image processing and artificial intelligence. This paper proposes an improved 64-bit multiplier for FPGA (Field Programmable Gate Array) by leveraging the Xilinx Multiplier IP. The proposed multipliers use DSPs to generate partial products, and CSA (carry-save adder) and CPA (carry-propagation adder) implement carry-up addition. In our experiments, we evaluated the delay and power consumption of the proposed multipliers using Vivado. The experimental results show that the proposed multipliers reduces the delay by 27.8% to 28.8%.

title: Electrical manipulation of terahertz spin waves by spin orbit torque in antiferromagnets
authors: T. H. Kim, Jung-Il Kim, Geun-Ju Kim, Kwang-Ho Jang, Sang-Hoon Kim, Jeong-Hun Lee, Insoo S. Kim
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: We explore the electrical manipulation of terahertz spin waves in antiferromagnetic orthoferrite featuring biaxial anisotropies and Dzyaloshinskii-Moriya interactions. In such orthoferrites, canted antiferromagnetism results in a split spin wave dispersion with separate high-frequency and low-frequency bands. Employing a heterostructure made of platinum, a ferromagnet, and a canted antiferromagnet, we demonstrate anisotropic control over these spin-wave bands through spin currents with three-dimensional spin polarizations, covering both resonant and propagating modes. By developing a coupled pendulum model, we establish that the efficiency of frequency modulation is inversely related to the effective potential energy determined by the anisotropy and DM interaction energies. Additionally, by utilizing the confined geometry of our system, we investigate the potential for controlling spin waves across a broad spectral range from tens of gigahertz to sub-terahertz frequencies. Our findings highlight the potential for creating a terahertz wave source with electrical tunability, which could significantly enhance ultrafast, broadband, and wireless communication technologies.

title: A Novel UAV Fault Detection Method using Data-based Dissipativity
authors: Wangyan Li, Yanling Yang, Chang Lu, Jie Bao
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Big Data, Artificial Intelligence and Internet of Things Engineering (ICBAIE)
abstract: In this work, a novel data-based fault detection scheme for quadrotor unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) is formulated using data-based dissipativity theory. The basic idea is mapping the nonlinear dynamics into a higher-dimensional space, wherein the evolution approximates linearity. Dissipativity properties are shaped from available input/output trajectories in a data-based manner, to be fault-sensitive (i.e., no longer efficient during fault occurrences). The dissipative properties are determined offline through the solution of an optimization problem, then applied online to design a monitoring algorithm that only involves verifying the inequalities of the input/output trajectories. Finally, an UAV example is presented to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed approach.

title: Insulator Defect Detection Algorithm Based on Lightweight HGNet-YOLO
authors: Jie Wang, Yanan Yang
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Automation, Electronics and Electrical Engineering (AUTEEE)
abstract: To guarantee the safe operation of electricity grids, insulators on transmission lines must be inspected on a regular basis. The following issues are now the principal obstacles to insulator defect detection: complex detection background, small target size leading to high false negative rates, and existing algorithms struggling to balance precision of identification and performance in real time. In this work, a lightweight insulator defect detection method based on the improved YOLOv11 is presented: HGNet-YOLO. Firstly, the lightweight feature extraction backbone network is an improved SC-HGNetV2. The convolutional modules in the neck network are replaced with lightweight average pooling downsampling ADown modules in order to reduce the amount of parameters in the model. Secondly, to improve the model's capacity to extract features from complicated backdrops, a hybrid multi-scale depth-enhanced fast pyramid module called HMDSPPF-SE is built. The issue of small target feature loss is then successfully resolved by integrating the MSDA attention method into the tiny target detection layer. The Shape-IoU loss function is ultimately presented with the intention of resolving the issues of CIoU's poor adaptability to complex backdrops and sensitivity to minute target position changes. Experimental findings on the built insulator dataset FBDID show that this strategy improves the mAP(0.5) by 3 percentage points, reduces the parameter count by 21.0%, and enhances the accuracy and recall rates by 2.2% and 2.8%, respectively, compared to the original model. Compared to other widely used object detection models, this model strikes a better balance between detection accuracy and lightweight, satisfying the deployment requirements of edge computing devices.

title: Integrated Energy Load Forecasting Method Based on CDA-SynFusion and CPO-VMD
authors: Fanqi Meng, Jing Cui, Jingdong Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE 31th International Conference on Parallel and Distributed Systems (ICPADS)
abstract: To enhance multi-load prediction accuracy in integrated energy systems, this paper proposes a load prediction method based on CDA-SynFusion and CPO-VMD, aiming to innovate from three levels: anomaly point identification, feature mining and modal decoupling. First, a CDA-SynFusion (Cross-Domain Adaptive Synergistic Feature Fusion) preprocessing framework is constructed, where a multivariate synergistic anomaly detection algorithm combines temporal fluctuation patterns, load synchrony constraints, and holiday effects to accurately identify and correct outliers, ensuring high-quality input data. Second, a cross-domain temporal feature screening and fusion mechanism is developed to dynamically quantify the correlation between load and meteorological domains, enabling the construction of a feature matrix with strong representational capability. Finally, the CPO (Crested Porcupine Optimizer) is introduced to adaptively optimize key VMD parameters, eliminating empirical dependency and achieving precise decoupling of cross-domain multi-frequency components. Experimental results verify that the proposed CDA-SynFusion-CPO-VMD framework significantly improves prediction accuracy across electrical, cooling, and heating loads, demonstrating its effectiveness in data preprocessing and modal decomposition, as well as its strong applicability to integrated energy system forecasting.

title: A Game-theoretic Approach to Cooperative Robust Nonlinear Model Predictive Control for a Network of Unmanned Ground Vehicles
authors: Giovanni Marinello, Lorenzo Zino, Carlo Novara, Michele Pagone
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: We propose a Pontryagin-based cooperative Robust Nonlinear Model Predictive Control (RNMPC) approach for the formation control of a network of Unmanned Ground Vehicles (UGVs). In the proposed scenario the UGV dynamics incorporates exogenous disturbances to capture real-world uncertainties, making the control problem nontrivial. The RNMPC foresees the solution of a min-max optimal control problem, where the goal is to optimize the control input to be delivered to the single UGV in the worst-case scenario. To this end, the Pontryagin-based min-max problem can be viewed as a zero-sum differential game, where the two players are the control input and the uncertainty whose solution is the Nash equilibrium. Additionally, collision avoidance for UGV is enforced through the implementation of artificial potential fields. The effectiveness and robustness of the proposed control technique have been assessed by means of numerical simulations.

title: A Multi-Modal DRL Framework for Fair and Efficient Multi-UAV Communication Coverage
authors: Cheng Cui, Xiaoyu Wang, Ning Chen
publish: 2025 IEEE 31th International Conference on Parallel and Distributed Systems (ICPADS)
abstract: Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) are critical for wireless communication in dynamic, infrastructure-less environments. However, optimizing trajectories to maximize coverage while ensuring fairness and minimizing energy consumption remains challenging. Relying on a single modality is a key limitation, as graph-only methods miss crucial spatial context while image-only methods ignore the underlying network structure. We propose Multi-Modal Dynamic Edge-featured Graph Attention Network (MM-DEGAT), a novel deep reinforcement learning framework that integrates image-based spatial distributions and graph-structured topological relations. Our approach includes: (1) a dynamic edge-featured mechanism for modeling relationships within the network, (2) bi-directional cross-attention for deep image-graph integration, and (3) adaptive gated fusion for dynamic multi-modal weighting. Experiments demonstrate improved communication efficiency and fairness, validating MMDEGAT's effectiveness for UAV coverage applications.

title: Role-Playing LLM-Based Multi-Agent Support Framework for Detecting and Addressing Family Communication Bias
authors: Rushia Harada, Yuken Kimura, Keito Inoshita
publish: 2025 IEEE Cyber Science and Technology Congress (CyberSciTech)
abstract: Well-being in family settings involves subtle psychological dynamics that conventional metrics often , overlook. In particular, unconscious parental expectations termed ideal parent bias, can suppress children’s emotional expression and autonomy. This suppression, referred to as suppressed emotion, often stems from well-meaning but value-driven communication, which is hard to detect or address from outside the family context. Focusing on these latent dynamics, this study explores Large Language Model (LLM)-based support for psychologically safe family communication. We constructed a Japanese parent–child dialogue corpus of 30 scenarios, each annotated with metadata on ideal parent bias and suppressed emotion. Based on this corpus, we developed a role-playing LLM-based multi-agent dialogue support framework that analyzes dialogue and generates feedback. Specialized agents detect suppressed emotion, describe implicit ideal parent bias in parental speech, and infer contextual attributes such as the child’s age and background. A meta-agent compiles these outputs into a structured report, which is then passed to five selected expert agents. These agents collaboratively generate empathetic and actionable feedback through a structured four-step discussion process. Experiments show that the system can detect categories of suppressed emotion with reasonable discrimination, and produce feedback rated highly in empathy and practicality. Moreover, simulated follow-up dialogues incorporating this feedback exhibited signs of improved emotional expression and mutual understanding, suggesting the framework’s potential to support positive transformation in family interactions.

title: Nonlinear Adaptive Differentiator Estimator For Ideal Signals
authors: Karim Khayati
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: In this article, new nonlinear differentiator estimators for noise-free signals, with gains adaptively adjusted, are proposed. The algorithms allow finite time convergence of the differentiator estimation, and circumvent the unknown bounds of the second derivative of the original signal. Simulation results are led using different signal shapes to validate the efficiency of the proposed techniques, and to compare their performances to existing estimators depicted from literature.

title: Towards Goal-Oriented Semantic Orchestration for Resource-Aware Robotic Function Offloading
authors: Alejandro Calvillo-Fernandez, Milan Groshev, Carlos J. Bernardos
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: Edge computing is increasingly seen as the perfect enabler for distributed robotic applications requiring low latency and high adaptability. However, current approaches offload computational tasks exclusively to edge nodes, overlooking scenarios where onboard processing can meet performance tar-gets. Therefore, we propose a framework that unifies offloading decision and resource orchestration into a single algorithm that compares different allocation strategies under accuracy, latency, and energy goals. Results show that this approach admits more functions while maintaining strict performance targets, offering substantial gains in overall system utility.

title: Research on Energy Storage Configuration and Scheduling Strategy of Distribution Network Based on Two-Layer Optimization
authors: Qiang Luo, Zhuohui Huang, Weiqiang Liang, Shuying Zhang, Sizheng He, Fengneng Li
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Automation, Electronics and Electrical Engineering (AUTEEE)
abstract: To address the problems of increased network loss and enhanced operational vulnerability in distribution networks under high-penetration distributed photovoltaics (PV) integration, a two-layer optimization model of "upper-layer energy storage capacity configuration and lower-layer charging/discharging scheduling" is proposed. The upper layer takes minimizing the rated capacity of energy storage as the goal, derives the capacity calculation formula, and determines the optimal installation location and capacity. The lower layer aims to minimize the active network loss and operational vulnerability of the distribution network, constructs a vulnerability assessment index integrating voltage deviation and branch thermal stability, and optimizes the 24-hour charging/discharging power of energy storage. Global constraints include power balance, power flow constraints, PV output characteristics, and energy storage charging/discharging limitations. The upper layer adopts the improved Beetle Antennae Search (IBAS) algorithm, which enhances optimization accuracy and convergence speed through adaptive step size and local search enhancement. The lower layer uses the adaptive Genetic Algorithm (AGA), which solves the problems of local optimality and slow convergence of traditional algorithms with adaptive crossover and mutation probabilities. Simulation verification on the IEEE 33-bus system shows that this two-layer optimization strategy can minimize the cost of energy storage configuration while significantly reducing the distribution network loss, improving voltage quality, and lowering the thermal stability risk. It provides theoretical support for the energy storage planning and operation of distribution networks.

title: Robust Super Twisting Based Sliding Mode Control for a 2-DOF Nonlinear Helicopter Model
authors: Jasmin Velagic, Salko Vladavic
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: This paper presents a robust control strategy, namely Sliding Mode Control (SMC), to control a two-degree-of-freedom (2DOF) helicopter model. This model is an inherently unstable, nonlinear, and multivariable system with coupling effects between two axes. Due to the mentioned characteristics, helicopter control remains a challenging problem, especially in the presence of external disturbances, parameter perturbation and model uncertainties. In order to overcome some of these difficulties, we developed a second order sliding mode controller based on the super-twisting algorithm (STSMC). It represents a modification of the standard SMC with the aim of improving its control capabilities. The effectiveness and robustness of the used STSMC were verified through simulations and experiments. The results obtained were compared with the same achieved by a previously developed PID and adaptive controllers. The STSMC significantly outperforms the PID controller and additionally improves the efficiency of the used adaptive controller in terms of stability of the system, tracking error, and overall control performance in the presence of system uncertainties and coupling effects between two axes, the azimuth and elevation.

title: Deployment and Verification of an automated backup solution for Zscaler Private Access (ZPA)
authors: Tsvetomir Bogdanov, Nayden Chivarov
abstract: This article presents the deployment and verification of an automated configuration-backup solution for Zscaler Private Access (ZPA). For the past four years, ZPA provided no client-accessible backup capability in its admin UI, creating operational and compliance risks; a later backup feature (introduced in April 2025) remains incompatible with SSL Inspection and AppProtection and can incur restoration delays of up to three days. We designed and deployed a vendor-agnostic backup framework using a Kubernetes cluster for scalability and AWX (open-source Ansible Tower) on an Ubuntu 22.04 LTS VM. The solution aligns operations with ISO/IEC 27001 and the NIST Cybersecurity Framework, enables rapid disaster recovery, and supports ancillary analyses (e.g., AutoDiscovery usage and tenant duplication). The contribution is a practically validated backup architecture that integrates zero-trust principles in ZPA environments via open-source automation, demonstrating reliable scheduling, retention, and audit-grade reporting. Contextual background on zero trust follows NIST SP 800-207 and 800-207A [8], [9].

title: i-DGCN: A Spectral Convolutional Network For Directed Graphs Using An Intensity Laplacian
authors: Theodor-Adrian Badea, Bogdan Dumitrescu
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: The development of graph neural networks has been driven by the widespread area of applications where graphs are naturally fit and by the advances in making solutions scalable. When it comes to spectral graph convolutional networks (GCNs), directed graphs suffer from the asymmetric nature of their Laplacian matrices. For such graphs, there is no natural extension of the spectral graph theory well-established for their undirected analogues with inherent symmetric matrices. In this paper, we propose i-DGCN: a spectral GCN approach addressing directed graphs by means of a novel symmetric Laplacian matrix constructed using a quantification of the interaction between the nodes. In order to assess i-DGCN, we undertake two tasks: anomaly detection for graph-structured data (unsupervised) and graph link existence prediction (supervised). Then, we compare the results with other Laplacian alternatives for directed graphs.

title: A Two-Step Online Diagnosis Strategy for Open-Phase Fault in Doubly Salient Electromagnetic Motor Drives
authors: Wenjing Fang, Bo Zhou, Yijun Zhang, Qingyun Chang, Yujie Yin, Jiadan Wei
abstract: Open-phase fault is a common fault in motor drives and occurs as the phase winding is disconnected or one leg of the converter bridge fails, which may generate significant torque ripple and reduce the output torque of the motor. To enhance the reliability of the system, this article proposes a two-step online diagnosis strategy for open-phase faults in doubly salient electromagnetic motor (DSEM) drives. In the first step, the occurrence of open-phase fault is detected based on the variation of active phase currents under normal and fault conditions. In the second step, the differentiation of two fault types (phase-winding open-circuit faults and two-switch open-circuit faults in the same bridge leg) as well as the localization of the fault phase winding can be realized by analyzing the variation of the zero-sequence voltage component (ZSVC) in the fault sector. And combined with the two-phase energization characteristic of the DSEM, the fault bridge leg can be localized based on the changes of the working phase currents within the fault sector and its subsequent sector. Finally, the effectiveness of the proposed method is experimentally verified on a 12/8-pole DSEM system.

title: Numerical Modelling of Bismuth-doped Fiber Amplifiers for Wideband Optical Communications
authors: Michelangelo Federico, Federica Poli
abstract: We present an improved matrix-based rate-equation model for simulating the behavior of Bismuth-doped fiber amplifiers (BDFAs) across ultra-wide wavelength ranges. The model accounts for multiple Bismuth active centers (BACs), treated as independent dopants with distinct spectroscopic properties, and incorporates an automatic optimization routine that iteratively refines uncertain input parameters by fitting simulations to experimental data. This approach allows accurate modeling of BAC dynamics while compensating for incomplete or uncertain input data on the characteristics of the different active centers. The model is validated through comparison with experimental results for BDFAs based on phosphosilicate and germanosilicate fibers operating in the O-, O+E-, and E-bands, showing excellent agreement for both gain and noise figure spectra under different pumping conditions. The proposed framework significantly improves the predictive accuracy of BDFA simulations and provides a practical tool for the design and optimization of next-generation wideband optical fiber amplifiers.

title: Achieving high repetition-rate operation of a spintronic terahertz emitter
authors: T. Gething, T. Thomson, P. W. Nutter, D. M. Graham
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: We study the thermal processes limiting high-repetition-rate operation of a spintronic terahertz emitter (STE) by utilizing the rapid data acquisition capabilities of an asynchronous optical sampling-based terahertz time-domain spectrometer. We identify a simple, inexpensive thermal management approach for preserving the emission amplitude when the STE is driven with a repetition rate of 1 GHz.

title: Enhanced Early Detection of Autism Spectrum Disorder Through LightGBM and Advanced Feature Optimization
authors: Suresh Chanamala, S. Anu H. Nair, K. P. Sanal Kumar
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Automation, Computing and Renewable Systems (ICACRS)
abstract: Autism spectrum disorder (ASD) refers to a complicated neurodevelopmental disorder that influences social interaction, verbal communication, and adaptability of behaviour. This is important because early diagnosis can greatly enhance the long-term. Nonetheless, conventional machine learning methods and traditional approaches to diagnosis are prone to redundancy of attributes, high dimensionality, reduced generalization, and lower diagnostic accuracy. To overcome the difficulties, the current research proposes an ASD detector in the form of Light GBM. As the primary dataset, the ASD Children Traits Dataset, which comprises Behavioral indicators and demographic information, is utilized. During the preprocessing phase, numerical variables are normalized to stabilize and accelerate convergence. The extraction of features is used to realize the underlying Behavioral patterns. Further, the feature selection procedure is applied to extract the most informative features (Sequential Feature Selection (SFS). This helps to reduce redundancy of features and to increase their interpretability. Lastly, LightGBM was used as a classifier option, including Exclusive Feature Bundling (EFB) and Gradient-based One-Side Sampling (GOSS) to easily work with structured data. The experimental assessment showed good performance with an accuracy of 0.99 %, precision of 1.0 %, recall of 0.99%, F1-score of 0.99 %, and ROC-AUC of 1.0%. These findings substantiate that LightGBM has better predictive performance and can be regarded as an advanced and highly reliable predictive instrument to detect ASD in its initial stages.

title: Simulation of Amplitude Modulated Resonant Tunneling Diode Oscillator
authors: G. Josefsson, C. Johansson, V. Fredriksson, A. Jartun, P. Blomberg, J. Vukusic, J. Stake
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: Resonant tunneling diode (RTD)-based oscillators have shown promising results in terms of dc-to-rf efficiency and are currently regarded as a viable candidate in enabling terahertz wireless communication. Using a simplified oscillator circuit topology together with a cubic RTD-model we derived the Van der Pol oscillator equation, whose transient response was simulated. The RTD-based oscillator shows clear eye patterns at 50 Gbit/s. However, there appears to be an inherent limitation in the system rise time, restricting the use of amplitude modulation at higher bit rates.

title: Impact of Electrode Geometry on THz Photoconductive Antenna Performance
authors: Florian Bek, Jakob Schmidt, Sascha Preu
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: This work focuses on the experimental performance analysis of different electrode finger structures in THz photoconductive antennas for continuous wave operation. Three different electrode structures containing 1 µm-wide fingers are investigated, and the THz signal is measured in a homodyne setup. While there is little difference at low frequencies, the responsivity of two finger electrode structures is increased for frequencies from 500 GHz to 1900 GHz as compared to the four interdigitated finger electrodes. The results help to select the superior electrode structure for a specific design frequency range to enhance bandwidth and photocurrent in THz photoconductive antennas.

title: Additive Residual Personalization for Federated News Recommendation
authors: Jichang Yao, Kedong Yan, Chanying Huang, Dan Yin
publish: 2025 IEEE 31th International Conference on Parallel and Distributed Systems (ICPADS)
abstract: In federated news recommendation, representing each news with a single embedding entangles shared semantics with user-specific preference shifts, which weakens personalization under non-IID users and strains communication when catalogs are large. To address this problem, we introduce FedDEN, a Dual News-Embedding framework that cleanly disentangles the two roles of item representation: a server-maintained global embedding captures cross-user semantics, while a lightweight client residual captures user-dependent deviations only where needed. Based on this core and tailored to the peculiarities of news recommendation, we attach two targeted mechanisms: (i) a minimal cold-start bias that substitutes residuals when histories are scarce, enabling immediate participation without extra rounds; and (ii) an alignment-and-sparsity regularization that keeps residuals complementary to the global table while promoting a compact, communicable global news embedding via proximal updates. Experiments on three real world datasets show consistent gains over strong centralized and federated baselines on metrics, together with robust behavior under cold-start settings, and favorable per-round communication. By solving the conflation of shared semantics and user-specific shifts at its source, FedDEN achieves strong personalization with practical efficiency. Specifically, it outperforms centralized baseline NRMS by 13.61 % and FedRec by 15.59 %.

title: SwiftReTaKe: Quick and Accurate Redundancy Reduction for Cloud-Edge Collaborative Video-Language Understanding
authors: Xinqi Jin, Fan Dang, Kebin Liu, Jiangchuan Liu, Jingao Xu
publish: 2025 IEEE 31th International Conference on Parallel and Distributed Systems (ICPADS)
abstract: Vision Language Models (VLMs) can enhance Internet of Things (IoT) applications by efficiently extracting valuable information from excessively long videos captured by IoT cameras. Due to the large volume of video data and the high computation overhead of VLMs, a practical deployment strategy is to transmit the video to the cloud only on demand and also deploy the VLMs on the cloud for video analytics. Yet, the interaction experience between humans and VLMs is degraded by the high latency in such cloud-edge collaboration applications. The latency is caused by both the video transmission process and the heavy VLM inference process. We propose SwiftReTaKe, a two-round transmission framework coupled with a low-latency pre-pruning strategy to reduce both network and inference latency. By first sending keyframes for relevance estimation and then adaptively transmitting informative frames, SwiftReTaKe minimizes data transfer and LLM computation. Compared to the state-of-the-art (SOTA) long video processing method, SwiftReTaKe reduces the latency by 6 times with only 3.33% accuracy drop.

title: Enhanced Efficiency of 10 µm Mid-infrared Quantum Cascade Lasers
authors: Hiroaki Yasuda, Yusuke Awane, Tomoji Terakado, Itsuki Matsumura, Kota Taniguchi, Makoto Matsuhama
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: We have enhanced the performance of a 10 µm band MIR-QCL for application in ammonia gas analyzers. By optimizing the number of wells in the injection region, we achieved higher optical output in the 10-well structure and lower power consumption in the 8-well structure compared to the conventional 12-well structure. Furthermore, we have clarified the scattering process that significantly reduces gain.

title: Aurora: Adaptive Audio-Video Multi-Scale Attention Fusion for Deepfake Detection
authors: Jie Xu, Shan Chang, Hongzi Zhu
publish: 2025 IEEE 31th International Conference on Parallel and Distributed Systems (ICPADS)
abstract: With the rapid advancement of generative forgery technologies, the detection of multi-modal deepfake audio-video content has become an urgent demand in cyber security and forensic analysis. However, detecting audio-video deepfakes remains challenging: forgery traces are often subtle, dispersed, and highly resolution-dependent; existing multimodal methods rely on simple concatenation or shallow interactions, leading to insufficient exploitation of cross-modal consistency. To address these issues, we propose a Cross-level Multi-modal Fusion (CLMF) framework that progressively integrates audio cues into visual representations through cross-level attention, adaptively enhancing complementary information while suppressing redundancy. In addition, we design an Adaptive Audio Feature Enhancement module (AAFE) to highlight subtle frequencydomain artifacts often masked by noise, and a Multi-scale Visual Feature Enhancement module (MVFE) to capture both local texture inconsistencies and global structural distortions. These components jointly achieve robust and consistent cross-modal alignment of forgery traces, leading to significant improvements in deepfake detection performance. On the FakeAVCeleb benchmark, AURORA achieves an accuracy (ACC) of 94.32% and an area under the curve (AUC) of 93.66%, demonstrating superior performance.

title: MixLoc: Universal Magnetic Indoor Localization via Mixed-Frequency Data Representation Learning
authors: Qinghu Wang, Jie Jia, Jian Chen, Yansha Deng, Xingwei Wang, Abdol Hamid Aghvami
publish: 2025 IEEE 31th International Conference on Parallel and Distributed Systems (ICPADS)
abstract: Using ambient magnetic for indoor localization has been a research focus in recent years. However, intricate magnetic feature patterns in complicated indoor ambiance, with particular emphasis on the multi-scale dynamics arising from diverse user motion states, further hinder localization accuracy and universality. To address these challenges, this paper originally proposes a novel mixed-frequency magnetic data representation learning-based framework (MixLoc) for accurate and universal localization. Our core idea is to systematically model the multi-scale dynamics-affected pedestrian indoor localization as a location-semantic learning problem based on mixed-frequency magnetic data. First, we propose a data augmentation method to automatically construct a mixed-frequency magnetic dataset. Then, we propose a novel encoder to learn temporal and spatial representations from these data and extract subtle differences among multi-scale sequences. Finally, a novel localization model is proposed to accurately infer locations by capturing significant global and local features from both temporal and spatial representations. The evaluation results based on comprehensive experiments show that the accuracy of MixLoc increases about 42% compared to other state-of-the-art approaches.

title: Terahertz Time Domain and Laser Feedback Interferometry Study of Sulfur Inclusion in Marble
authors: Puspita Chanda, Karl Bertling, Uzair Aalam, Mayuri Kashyap, Jari Torniainen, Xiao Guo, Tim Gillespie, Dragan Indjin, Lianhe Li, Edmund H. Linfield, A. Giles Davies, Paul Dean, Aparajita Bandyopadhyay, Amartya Sengupta, Aleksandar. D. Rakić
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: The accelerated deterioration of marble monuments and structures in recent times, due to acid (mainly sulfuric acid) deposition presents substantial challenges for heritage conservationists. This work investigates the effectiveness of utilizing Terahertz Time-Domain Spectroscopy and Imaging (TDSI) in addition to Laser Feedback Interferometry (LFI) in reflection mode to assess sulfur-induced deterioration in marble specimens.

title: User-Aware Critical Thread Identification and Proactive CPU Governing on Mobile Devices
authors: Jiahao Qiu, Yuezhi Che, Dazhao Cheng
publish: 2025 IEEE 31th International Conference on Parallel and Distributed Systems (ICPADS)
abstract: Modern mobile devices now support increasingly complex, interactive applications that demand both low-latency frame rendering and energy efficiency. However, current Android CPU governors and schedulers react only to coarse CPU-utilization and ignore dynamic inter-thread dependencies and the computation demand of frame rendering, therefore, often fail to provide timely CPU resources, leading to missed frame deadlines or unnecessary energy consumption. To bridge this semantic gap, we propose Argus, a lightweight, kernel-integrated framework that dynamically identifies UI-critical threads based on real-time inter-thread interactions, and boosts their priority to ensure responsive user experiences. Furthermore, it incorporates a frame-aware CPU governor that adjusts frequency decisions based on frame deadlines and critical thread load. Comprehensive evaluations on popular mobile applications demonstrate that Argus can reduce the number of frame drops by up to 76.2 % and improve energy efficiency by up to 17.2 % compared to existing CPU governors, with negligible runtime overhead.

title: A Neural Network-Based Prescribed-Time Controller Formulation with Update Modularity for a Class of Nonlinear Systems
authors: Huseyin Deniz Ozturk, Enver Tatlicioglu, Erkan Zergeroglu
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: This work concentrates on a neural network-based, prescribed time controller formulation for a class of nonlinear systems having parametric uncertainty. The aim of the controller is to ensure that the tracking error converges to the origin within a user-defined prescribed time despite the presence of bounded disturbances and parametric uncertainties with controller/update law modularity. The stability of closed–loop error system has been ensured via Lyapunov-based arguments. Numerical simulations are conducted to illustrate the feasibility of the proposed method.

title: Standard and High-Voltage MOS Class-E Power Amplifier Design
authors: Roberto Cancelli, Gianfranco Avitabile
abstract: Integrating Class-E Power Amplifiers (PAs) on a single die presents significant challenges due to transistor breakdown limitations. Additionally, the cascode configuration introduces additional loss mechanisms, while the lower quality factor of integrated inductors leads to increased unwanted power dissipation in the output network. This work proposes a Class-E PA design optimized to minimize power losses and improve efficiency. The PA operates in the 2.4 GHz ISM band and incorporates a combination of high-voltage and standard NMOS transistors. The inductors are integrated on-chip and optimized to reduce parasitic resistance. Simulation results demonstrate a Power Added Efficiency of 50.46%, with an output power of 20.12 dBm.

title: Model Checking PLC Programs: Enhancing Formalization for Scalability
authors: Jessica Ravakambinintsoa, Emil Dumitrescu, Eric Zamaï, Denis Chalon
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: Formal verification of PLC programs requires transforming control logic into a mathematical model. Since PLC languages lack a formal semantics, multiple transformation methods exist, based on various code interpretations. This work introduces a novel approach leveraging Single Static Assignments (SSA) to ensure a faithful PLC code transformation while enhancing model checking scalability. By systematically tracking variable assignments, the method accurately captures execution dependencies and preserves control logic. Experimental results demonstrate promising improvements in verification efficiency.

authors: N/A
