title: Cooling as You Wish: Component-Level Cooling for Heterogeneous Edge Datacenters
authors: Fangming Liu, Qiangyu Pei, Shutong Chen, Yongjie Yuan, Qixia Zhang, Xinhui Zhu, Ziyang Jia, Fei Xu, Dong Zhang, Bingheng Yan
abstract: As computing shifts toward the edge, edge datacenters are becoming essential for supporting diverse real-time applications. Unlike traditional cloud datacenters, edge datacenters face unique cooling challenges due to their requirements for proximity to end users, high density, and hardware heterogeneity. While warm water cooling is a promising technique for this infrastructure, current one-size-fits-all cooling strategies significantly compromise efficiency due to severe inter- and intra-component hotspots. In this work, we present CoolEdge+, a cost-effective component–level water cooling system for enhancing the cooling efficiency of edge datacenters. Specifically, CoolEdge+ dynamically adjusts the inlet water temperature for each component through a carefully designed water circulation architecture to mitigate inter-component hotspots. To address intra-component hotspots, it employs vapor chamber–based cold plates that rapidly dissipate heat without manual intervention or additional energy consumption. We further design a fine-grained cooling control framework that leverages a well-managed power capping approach to decide on customized inlet water temperatures and hardware power limits. Based on a hardware prototype and a real-world trace from Alibaba PAI, evaluation results show that CoolEdge+ reduces cooling energy consumption by up to 27.19% compared to existing coarse-grained systems, while maintaining performance guarantees. Compared to the state-of-the-art CoolEdge, CoolEdge+ saves 35.24% more cooling costs with comparable energy consumption and no latency violations.

title: Design and Analysis of a Corner-Cut Patch Antenna for Multiband Applications
authors: Aditya Panigrahi, Sampriti Ghosh, Aarush Nigam, Alisha Dash, Shithan Ghosh, Arunya Paul, Sasmita Pahadsingh
publish: 2025 5th IEEE International Conference on Applied Electromagnetics, Signal Processing, &amp; Communication (AESPC)
abstract: A corner-cut microstrip patch antenna with a fractal tree design is designed for multiband wireless purposes. By the addition of some corner truncations and design alterations, the antenna generates different resonant frequencies while keeping the size small and the design uncomplicated. The fractal design allows for a larger electrical length in a smaller area, allowing for enhanced bandwidth and multi-band applications. Simulations show low return loss, matched impedance and high gain along with other characteristics across the bands. The planar design and multi-band properties allow for the antenna to be appropriate for WLAN, WiFi, and 5G applications.

title: HERMES: An XGBoost Approach to Detecting Low-Quality Radio Transmissions on Martian Missions
authors: Sai Tummala, Mittansh Bhatia, Robert Chun
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Big Data, Artificial Intelligence and Internet of Things Engineering (ICBAIE)
abstract: Reliable communication between Mars surface assets and Earth is essential for mission success, yet space weather events frequently degrade radio transmission quality. Solar energetic particle events, coronal mass ejections, and electromagnetic disturbances create ionospheric perturbations that attenuate UHF signals and introduce phase distortions. We present HERMES (Heliospheric Event-Responsive Messaging and Estimation System), a machine learning framework that predicts communication link degradation by analyzing rover telemetry data combined with real-time solar particle flux measurements. Using XGBoost classification on historical data from NASA’s Mars Exploration Rovers and ACE spacecraft measurements, HERMES achieves 87.5% accuracy in identifying periods of poor transmission quality. This autonomous assessment capability reduces dependence on ground-based monitoring and enables proactive communication scheduling for future Mars missions.

title: A Lightweight Classifier for Prostate Cancer Detection
authors: Tzu-Hao Li, Ethan Murphy, Allaire Doussan, Ryan Halter, Kofi Odame
publish: 2025 IEEE Biomedical Circuits and Systems Conference (BioCAS)
abstract: Bioimpedance analysis is a promising technology for real-time surgical margin assessment (SMA) during prostate cancer surgery, but its clinical adoption is hindered by bulky analog front-end (AFE) hardware. This paper introduces a hardware-efficient algorithm for SMA that relaxes the AFE requirements, allowing for significant miniaturization. The algorithm was evaluated on bioimpedance measurements of ex vivo prostate tissue, where it achieved an AUROC of 0.84 in detecting cancerous regions of 2.33 mm or larger. The proposed AFE and algorithm would occupy an estimated chip area of $4 \mathrm{~mm}^{2}$, which is small enough for integration into an SMA probe head. This offers a path to a real-time, intraoperative solution for surgical margin assessment during radical prostatectomy.

title: Development of a Digital Twin for an Electric Vehicle Emulator Modeling, Control, and Experimental Validation
authors: Lamine Chalal, Ahmed Rachid
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: This paper presents the development and validation of a digital twin for a scaled-down electric vehicle (EV) emulator, designed to replicate longitudinal vehicle dynamics under diverse operating conditions. The emulator integrates a separately excited DC motor (SEDCM), a four-quadrant DC-DC converter, a battery emulator, and a mechanical load emulator. The system models tractive effort, aerodynamic drag, and gradient resistance using Newton’s second law. In contrast to conventional graphical modeling tools (e.g., block diagrams and bond graphs), the adopted Energetic Macroscopic Representation (EMR) framework offers clear advantages by explicitly representing energy interactions and facilitating the systematic derivation of control structures. A control strategy developed within this framework governs energy flow across the powertrain, enabling accurate speed control via armature voltage regulation. Experimental tests conducted on a Lucas-Nülle test bench show strong correlation with simulation results. The study also introduces a methodology to compute the maximum admissible vehicle mass—determined to be 13.5 kg for a 180 W motor operating at 1900 rpm—based on acceleration and slope constraints. Furthermore, a switching algorithm for the bidirectional converter ensures reliable four-quadrant operation. Overall, the proposed framework provides a scalable and effective approach for EV emulation, control design, and energy management validation.

title: A Lightweight CNN Framework with Proportional Class-Balanced Sampling and SpecAugment for Multi-Class Respiratory Sound Classification
authors: Sing-An Chiu, Chia-Yu Yeh, Wai-Chi Fang
publish: 2025 IEEE Biomedical Circuits and Systems Conference (BioCAS)
abstract: Respiratory sound classification is critical for telemedicine, yet it faces significant challenges, including severe class imbalance, limited expert-annotated data, and the high computational cost of existing large models. To address these issues, we present a lightweight CNN framework that integrates proportional class-balanced sampling to mitigate class bias, SpecAugment to enhance feature diversity and generalization, and an EfficientNet-B0 backbone with a classifier trained using focal loss. Our framework also employs audio concatenation to standardize input duration. Evaluated on the BioCAS Grand Challenge’23 testing set, our method achieved a top score of 0.7002, outperforming all existing methods. The results demonstrate that the proposed approach achieves balanced performance with high efficiency, making it practical for resource-limited healthcare environments.

title: Retraction Notice: Region Merging Based Segmentation Approach for Color Image Using Maximal Similarity Index
authors: Anuradha Sharma, Vijay Kumar Sharma, Devesh Kumar Srivastava
publish: 2018 2nd International Conference on Trends in Electronics and Informatics (ICOEI)
abstract: Color image segmentation and color preservation a major requirement of various applications equipped in the image processing. In this article we have focused our research on the color image segmentation using region merging approach. The segmentation process comprises of two stages, (a) Retrieving the foreground and background mask using mean shift algorithm and (b) Region Merging on behalf of histogram defined maximal similarity index using Bhattacharya coefficient. The simulation outcome proves the significance of the proposed approach for solving the issue of color preservation

title: Location History-based Improvement of Message Delivery in Delay-Tolerant Networks
authors: Kazuma Matsubara, Naohiro Hayashibara
publish: 2025 IEEE Cyber Science and Technology Congress (CyberSciTech)
abstract: The message routing protocol is essential for the efficient delivery of messages in Delay/Disruption-tolerant networks (DTNs). Messages dispatched by a mobile node are transmitted in a Store-Carry-Forward fashion between mobile nodes in Delay Tolerant Networks (DTNs). Current protocols comprise the behavior of mobile nodes, connection data, and movement models to enhance their mechanisms for message exchange during encounters. PRoPHET is one of the protocols attracting attention. It computes the likelihood of encountering other nodes and the message’s destination to regulate message forwarding. When the probability of an encounter diverges from the actual encounter, it cannot transmit messages effectively. We propose LH-PRoPHET, an enhancement of PRoPHET, that not only utilizes the encounter frequency for controlling message forwarding, but also takes into account the trajectory prediction based on the position history of encountered nodes. This approach seeks to maximize node coverage by transferring messages to nodes moving in divergent directions, hence enhancing the delivery ratio without increasing resource expenditure. Our simulation findings indicate that LH-PRoPHET markedly enhances the delivery ratio and latency while concurrently decreasing resource consumption.

title: A Balanced Multiplier Design Using Novel Parallel Adder for Optimized Performance and Energy
authors: Kaeun Lim, Youngmin Kim
abstract: This paper evaluates 64-bit adders—Ripple Carry Adder (RCA), Kogge-Stone Adder (KSA), Ladner-Fischer Adder (LFA), and the proposed Energy-efficient Parallel Computational Adder (EPCA). EPCA significantly reduces delay compared to RCA while using less power and area than KSA. Applied to 32-bit multipliers, EPCA achieves the lowest Figure of Merit (FoM), effectively balancing delay, power, and area. Its optimized design minimizes unnecessary propagation and generation, making it ideal for energy-efficient, high-performance digital systems.

title: Digital Invigilation Duty Roster Management using MERN Stack
authors: Sheetal Janthakal, Anita Patil, Harish Naik, Chaturdev, Amit Kumar, Nitish Ranjan Jumnalmath
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Automation, Computing and Renewable Systems (ICACRS)
abstract: An important part of educational system is the conduction of examination. Most of the institutions plan and arrange the examination process like examination schedule, faculty details, availability of rooms, etc. manually which results in excessive wastage of time and manpower. A digital solution is needed to streamline the process, improve transparency, and reduce administrative workload. Hence, this system adopts greedy algorithm that develops an invigilation application using the MERN (MongoDB, Express.js, React, Node.js) stack. It automates several tasks, including assignment and monitoring of invigilation duties to the faculties. The system offers a streamlined workflow for administrators and faculty through a role-based access mechanism. Administrators perform key tasks such as user registration, login, and duty assignment, while faculty can securely access their individual invigilation schedules. Security is enhanced through Secure JWT (JSON Web Token) based authentication which ensures that only the authorized users will be able to access the protected resources. All communication between frontend and backend is handled via Representational State Transfer Application Programming Interfaces (RESTful APIs), ensuring seamless data flow and real-time updates. This system replaces traditional manual processes with a centralized digital platform that reduces human errors, improves scheduling accuracy, and saves significant administrative effort. Overall, it enhances operational efficiency, accountability, and transparency in academic exam management.

title: Comparative Study of Edge Deployment of LLM on Arm and RISC-V SBC Clusters
authors: Tay-Jyi Lin, Bo-Chen Liao, Chih-Yen Liao, Kai-Siang Shih, Chingwei Yeh, Peng-Sheng Chen, Shih-Chieh Chang, Tien-Fu Chen, Jinn-Shyan Wang
abstract: Connecting multiple low-cost single-board computers (SBCs) through network to form a computing cluster is a feasible solution for deploying large language models (LLM) at the edge. This work compares the deployment of Llama3 8B on computing clusters composed of leading-edge Arm and RISC-V SBCs. The performance numbers (as tokens/sec) are given and analyzed in correspondence to the hardware architecture & software design implementations.

title: Quasi-Smith-Purcell Radiation from a Hole Pulse
authors: Li-Hung Yu, Yen-Chieh Huang
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: Smith-Purcell Radiation is generated when free electrons propagate above the surface of a periodic structure. We verified numerically that a positively charged surface-plasmon-polariton pulse or a hole pulse propagating atop a metal grating can surprisingly generate radiation similar to the Smith-Purcell radiation generated by a positron pulse moving at the same speed. Although this novel radiation-generation phenomenon is numerically discovered in the microwave spectrum, the mechanism of this novel technique applies to radiation generation at higher frequencies.

title: Bridging the Gap Between Simulations and Reality: A CycleGAN-Based Approach for Drone Landing Systems
authors: Diyar Altinses, David Orlando Salazar Torres, Andreas Schwung
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: Drone delivery systems are increasingly gaining importance in modern logistics due to their efficiency and potential to revolutionize the supply chain. However, among the various stages of drone operations, the landing phase stands out as the most critical, as it requires precise navigation and control to ensure the safe and successful delivery of goods. Therefore, testing simulations are required to accurately replicate the complex dynamics of real-world environments. In this paper, we propose a CycleGAN-based framework for bidirectional domain translation between simulated and real-world data, with a focus on GPS features. The proposed architecture facilitates seamless transfer learning by enabling simulation-trained controllers to operate effectively in real-world environments and vice versa. Additionally, we integrate the translated data into a downstream control framework for autonomous landing tasks, validating the practicality of the approach.

title: Real-Time Parameter Estimation in SS Compensated Wireless Power Transfer Systems Considering Nonlinearity of the Diode Rectifier_supp2-3653046.mp4
authors: Jiayang Wu
abstract: A real-time parameter estimation method is proposed for series-series (SS) compensated wireless power transfer (WPT) systems in this paper. Unlike conventional approaches that model the input impedance as purely resistive, a more accurate inductive model is established with the consideration of the nonlinearity of diode rectifiers. Based on the derived model, the key system parameters can be accurately estimated in real time, by simply sampling the primary compensation capacitor voltage and the input voltage. This method eliminates the need for bilateral communication and causes zero interference on normal system operation as no prior or special actions are required. The estimation procedures are presented in detail and verified on a prototype. Experimental results demonstrate the feasibility of the proposed method, which achieves a high-accuracy estimation of the coupling coefficients and output voltage in 131 μs.

title:
Physics-Informed Fusion of Vision and Sensor Data for CO
                    <sub>2</sub>
                    Prediction
authors: Shouqi Wang, Lijuan Lan, Qiwu Luo, Yang Yang, Cong Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE 31th International Conference on Parallel and Distributed Systems (ICPADS)
abstract: Accurate real-time prediction of indoor Carbon dioxide concentration (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{CO}_{2}$</tex>) is crucial to optimizing ventilation, ensuring the well-being of the occupants, and improving energy efficiency. Traditional methods typically predict <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{CO}_{2}$</tex> concentration with unimodal time series. The recent advance from multi-modal learning provides a new dimension of fusing visual and timeseries sensor data. Although multimodality offers a more holistic view of the environment, it introduces potential conflicts from physical dynamics that conventional fusion methods could simply overlook. This paper identifies and addresses two such challenges: (1) Multimodal Temporal Conflict, which arises when static visual cues correspond to dynamic <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{CO}_{2}$</tex> changes; (2) Cross-Modal Causal Lag, which stems from the physical inertia of air volume that delays the sensor's response to occupancy changes. To address these challenges, we propose a novel physics-informed fusion framework to mitigate inconsistencies during transient physical states and model the time-varying delay between visual events and their corresponding <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{CO}_{2}$</tex> responses. We validate our framework on a month-long, real-world multimodal dataset collected from an office environment. Extensive experiments demonstrate that our proposed methods significantly outperform both unimodal timeseries models and conventional fusion techniques, highlighting the critical importance of embedding physical priors into fusion models for robust and accurate environmental sensing.

title: Thickness Measurement of Bilayer Tablets Using Terahertz Time-Domain Spectroscopy
authors: Snehal Haldankar, Vibhavari Parkar, Fathimath Faseela, Shriganesh Prabhu
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: Terahertz Time-Domain Spectroscopy (THz-TDS) was employed to measure the thickness of a bilayer pharmaceutical tablet. THz-TDS enabled the extraction of optical parameters such as refractive index, which was then used to calculate the tablet's total thickness as well as the thicknesses of individual layers. Unlike vernier callipers, this technique's nondestructive nature allowed for precise measurements with an error margin of only 0.3% to 0.6%. This study demonstrates that THz-TDS is a reliable tool for determining multilayer tablet thickness.

title: Reinforcement Learning for Enhanced Path Tracking in Autonomous Vehicles: A Formula SAE Skid-Test Validation
authors: Danilo Menegatti, Francesco Luzi, Francesco Pappalardo, Antonio Pietrabissa, Alessandro Giuseppi
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: Accurate path tracking is one of the main challenges autonomous vehicles have to deal with. It is known that, when dealing with real hardware systems, the presence of parametric uncertainty and unmodelled aspects of the system dynamics affects all model-based control approaches, hindering their nominal performance guarantees. To compensate for this issue, data-driven schemes have drawn significant attention from the scientific community thanks to their inherent ability to learn from experience, thus automatically compensate for system uncertainties and time-varying behaviours. This work aims to develop a reinforcement learning-based longitudinal and lateral dynamics control introducing mismatch and motion penalization metrics, validating the resulting controller in a simulated Formula SAE skid-test scenario employing the Sapienza Fast Charge Formula SAE Electric Racing Team dynamical model.

title: Latency Analysis of DAG-Driven Blockchain System for IoV Through the Lens of IOTA
authors: Xuefeng Piao, Jiasi Li, Hao Ding, Haobo Wang, Huihui Song, Seong-Je Cho, Zhenzhou Ji
publish: 2025 IEEE 31th International Conference on Parallel and Distributed Systems (ICPADS)
abstract: The Internet of Vehicles (IoV) has emerged as a key enabler of Intelligent Transportation Systems (ITS), IoV faces significant challenges in scalability and security. The growing volume of real-time vehicular data strains network resources, and traditional centralized architectures introduce single points of failure that compromise reliability and data integrity. This paper investigates the integration of IOTA-a Directed Acyclic Graph (DAG) based distributed ledger designed for feeless and scalable transactions-into the IoV system. In the proposed architecture, vehicles operate as lightweight nodes and roadside units function as full nodes, yielding a resource-efficient architecture for secure, tamper-resistant data interaction across vehicular networks. We formally model the latency of transaction propagation and consensus confirmation phases to gain insight into its performance characteristics under high concurrency. We conducted extensive simulations under diverse traffic conditions on a private IOTAenabled vehicular network. Experimental results demonstrate that the IOTA-based IoV system achieves low latency on the order of a few milliseconds and high throughput of hundreds of transactions per second even as vehicle density increases. The system exhibits strong scalability and operational stability, indicating considerable potential for deployment in real-world ITS environments.

title: RIS-Assisted Exploitation of Side Lobes for Coverage Extension in THz-Indoor Scenarios
authors: Christoph Herold, Bo Kum Jung, Thomas Kürner
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: Point-to-point links at THz-frequencies rely on high-gain antennas to overcome their challenging propagation conditions. Even with a narrow half-power-beam-width, side lobes of these antennas still exist. This simulation-based study investigates the possibility to redirect the power of side lobes by using reflective intelligent surfaces to provide coverage for additional users besides the original target. Ray-tracing simulations show that additional coverage outside of the main lobe can be achieved in a meeting room scenario. On average, an improvement of 19.28dB in received power was reached.

title: Small Object Detection from a UAV Perspective Based on an Improved YOLOv11 Approach
authors: Chuan Liu, Mengxing Huang, Zikai Feng
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Digital Society and Intelligent Systems (DSInS)
abstract: With the rapid development of the low-altitude economy, target detection from a drone's perspective is increasingly significant in its impact on human life. However, the minute dimensions, dense distribution, and lack of distinct features of the targets pose more stringent challenges to detection performance. This paper proposes an improved method based on YOLOv11, enhancing the model's representation capabilities for minute objects and edge features through the introduction of an efficient feature reorganisation and multi-scale fusion strategy. Experimental results based on the VisDrone2019 dataset demonstrate that this method achieves improvements of 5.2 % and 3.7 % over YOLOv11n in mAP50 and mAP50-95 respectively, significantly enhancing detection accuracy for small objects in drone aerial imagery. The research findings provide novel insights and technical support for efficient, reliable small object detection in low-altitude economic applications.

title: A 128-Channel Neural Recording SoC with Hybrid Spike and LFP Monitoring for High-Density Brain-Machine Interfaces
authors: Haoyang Su, Zhengyu Hu, Shuntian Cheng, Xiaofang Zhang, Wanglian Zhao, Xi Tian, Wenwei Yang, Xiangming Sun, Liuyang Sun
publish: 2025 IEEE Biomedical Circuits and Systems Conference (BioCAS)
abstract: High spatiotemporal resolution invasive neural signal acquisition provides significant benefits for neuroscience research and neurorehabilitation. However, full-rate acquisition of action potential (AP, also known as spike) results in substantial data bandwidth waste due to their inherent sparsity, which is unfavorable for low-power and miniaturized designs. This work presents a 128-channel system-on-chip (SoC) supporting both Full Bandwidth Recording (FBR) mode and Hybrid Recording (HR) mode. In FBR mode, the SoC performs neural recording at $20 \mathrm{kS} / \mathrm{s}$ sampling rate with $2.26 \mu \mathrm{~V}_{\text {rms }}$ inputreferred noise (IRN) over a $\mathbf{1 - 1 0} \mathbf{~ k H z}$ frequency range. In HR mode, the SoC directly digitizes spikes while recording local field potentials (LFPs) at $1 \mathrm{kS} / \mathrm{s}$, reducing power consumption by 84% and data bandwidth by 94.7%. The SoC integrates impedance measurement, power management, clock generation, and digital control, enabling a high-density and compact design. Designed in SMIC 130 nm technology, the SoC consumes 11.8 mW in FB mode and 1.8 mW in SPD mode, with a die size of $\mathbf{4. 4 5 ~ m m} \boldsymbol{\times} \mathbf{4. 4 5 ~ m m}$.

title: Prevention of Malaria and Dengue Fever with Deep Analysis using ML Techniques
authors: Koushik P, L V Adithya, Manisha B, G. Muthupandi, S. Pavithra
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Automation, Computing and Renewable Systems (ICACRS)
abstract: Malaria and dengue fever remain remarkable public health threats in subtropical and tropical regions across the globe. Both the Malaria and dengue fever are Mosquito-borne diseases. Many methods of inspection and control methods frequently fail due to resource restriction and late reaction times. For controlling this disease, the Machine Learning (ML) technologies offers an innovative approach to disease control and public health measures. Representing for purpose of designing, implementation, and development of an ML-based smart surveillance system aimed at surveillance, prevention, and control strategies for these vector-borne diseases like malaria and dengue. The system consists of a network of machine learning algorithm such as K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN) and, Artificial Neural Networks (ANN are implemented to collect real-time data on track environmental conditions, mosquito population dynamics, and health indicators. By analyzing this data, the system can predict the possibility of a disease spreading, identify precarious areas, and to accelerate responses, thereby improving vector control, strengthening disease prevention, minimizing the spread of diseases, and optimizing disease management.

title: Stimulation of Tumor Growth and Angiogenesis with Energy-Dependent Photobiomodulation
authors: Jihye Jo, Myungji Kang, Hyun Wook Kang
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Quantum Electronics
abstract: Photobiomodulation (PBM) has emerged as a supportive treatment for managing side effects of cancer radiation therapy. However, its safety and potential tumor-stimulating effects under specific irradiation conditions remain unclear. This study aims to evaluate the energy-dependent effects of 808 nm PBM on cellular proliferation, tumor growth, and angiogenesis in vitro and in vivo. B16F10 melanoma cells and tumor-bearing mice were irradiated with 808 nm laser at various energy densities of 0, 5, 10, and 50 J/cm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>. In vitro tests revealed that 808 nm PBM significantly increased cell viability to 108% and 108% at 5 and 10 J/cm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>, respectively, compared to the control group. In vivo tests demonstrated that 808 nm PBM at 5 J/cm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> induced the greatest tumor growth, with a 100-fold increase in relative tumor volume 10 days after the laser irradiation. Histological and western blot analyses confirmed significantly upregulated expression of VEGF and HIF-1α, markers of angiogenesis, and ERK1/2, a key mediator of cell proliferation, in tumors exposed to 5 J/cm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>. These findings suggest that 808 nm PBM at a low energy density can stimulate melanoma tumor progression by promoting angiogenesis and cellular proliferation, highlighting the significance of optimizing the energy density and the necessity for establishing safety guidelines for oncologic PBM applications.

title: Accelerated Charging System for E-Bikes using Interleaved Sepic Converter
authors: Mani Sankar S, Ramprabu J, Kandasamy V
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Automation, Computing and Renewable Systems (ICACRS)
abstract: The rapid adoption of electric two-wheelers in urban areas and semi-urban settings has generated an excellent chance to get a rapid, reliable, and secure charging deployment. The Lithium-ion batteries are very desirable because of their better energy density and long cycle life. Single-phase and non-interleaved converters, which are conventional and linked to fixed CC-CV algorithms have poor energy management, large current ripple, slow charging, and high battery loss rates. In this paper, the interleaved Sepic converter is suggested to be used with an Model Predictive Control (MPC) and a 48 V, 10 Ah Li-ion pack. The converter has an interleaved structure that decreases current ripple, thermal stress and the adaptive algorithm self-adjusts current and voltage set points using real-time state-of-charge (SOC) and temperature feedbacks. The use of MATLAB/Simulink to simulate the proposed charger indicates that the charger would take 23 minutes to charge 50 percent SOC, 37 minutes to charge 80 percent SOC and 56 minutes to charge fully, a 11 percent improvement over the results of CC-CV systems. The findings show that converter topology and algorithm co-design results in fast, safe, and efficient charging that makes them appropriate to the futuristic urban EV charging system.

title: Spatial and Temporal Reservoir Computing with Biologically Modeled Neurons
authors: Duna Wattad, Valariia Kravchik, Rishona Daniels, Ramez Daniel, Shahar Kvatinsky
publish: 2025 IEEE Biomedical Circuits and Systems Conference (BioCAS)
abstract: As artificial intelligence (AI) systems grow in complexity, traditional computing architectures struggle to match the brain’s energy efficiency, adaptability, and parallelism. Neuromorphic computing offers a promising alternative by leveraging biologically inspired neural models-such as Leaky Integrate-and-Fire (LIF) that emulate the key dynamics of neural computation. In this paper, we introduce a modeling approach grounded in biological data recorded from live neurons using multi-electrode arrays (MEA). We evaluate LIF and conductancebased LIF models using the MEA data to capture biologically realistic dynamics for machine learning applications. To asses performance, we developed and compared a conductance-based temporal LIF reservoir with a biologically inspired recurrent neural network (RNN) tailored for spatiotemporal classification. Using the same $5 \times 3$ spatial input layout, the conductive LIF reservoir introduced a more dynamic architecture. With 100 neurons, it achieved 61% accuracy and a loss of approximately 0.23. Scaling the reservoir up to 1000 neurons reduced the loss to 0.15 and increased accuracy to 80%, demonstrating an enhanced ability to capture fine-grained temporal features. To benchmark performance, we employed a memristor-based hardware reservoir, which achieved up to 93% accuracy in multiclass and 95% in binary MNIST digit classification. These results demonstrate the promise of biologically inspired, hybrid neuromorphic systems for developing energyefficient and adaptive AI applications.

title: Benchmarking Model-Free Reinforcement Learning Algorithms for Robotic Manipulation
authors: Ngoc Quoc Huy Hoang, Yasaman Mohammadidargah, Dmitrii Dobriborsci
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: Reinforcement Learning (RL) is increasingly transitioning from controlled simulation environments to real-world robotic applications. However, this shift presents a major challenge: designing effective reward functions and training procedures tailored to specific robotic tasks remains time-consuming and largely empirical. In this work-in-progress study, we investigate the impact of reward shaping and algorithm selection on robotic manipulation, focusing on two foundational skills: reaching and pushing. We benchmark five RL algorithms PPO, SAC, SAC-HER, DDPG, and DDPG-HER using a UR10 robotic arm in the PyBullet simulator. We compare sparse and dense reward formulations and analyze their influence on training dynamics and preliminary success rates. Our results demonstrate the effectiveness of hindsight-based approaches in sparse-reward scenarios and highlight the importance of proper reward design. Ongoing work includes extending the benchmark to more complex tasks such as sliding and pick-and-move, exploring hierarchical learning methods, and validating sim-toreal transfer on a physical UR10 platform.

title: Hall Sensor Signal Conditioning and Time Synchronization Using dSPACE DS-1103 for PMBLDC Motor Drive
authors: Subhendu Bikash Santra, Makireddi Ramana, Subrata Banerjee
publish: 2025 5th IEEE International Conference on Applied Electromagnetics, Signal Processing, &amp; Communication (AESPC)
abstract: Hall Sensors are the integral parts of permanent magnet brushless DC motor (PMBLDC) drive for applications like commercial 3-wheeler electric vehicle (EV) and compressors. Hall sensor signal conditioning and proper time synchronization are important for inverter operation and even for speed calculation for sensored drive operation. The closed loop operation of PMBLDC motor for different frequencies for transient and steady state required correct time and phase sequence coming from hall sensors data. Further the study can be extended for single hall sensor-based position detection estimation for the drive operation. In this work, time synchronization and hall sensor data synchronization for 850 W PMBLDC Motor drive using dSPACE DS-1103 are discussed.

title: Novel PI-type Direct Power Control Applied on Grid-tied VSIs
authors: Panos C. Papageorgiou, Antonio T. Alexandridis
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: Grid-tied voltage source inverters (VSIs) play the role of a controlled power interface between different power production units and the ac grid. Instead of the usual cascade control scheme of a VSI with current proportional-integral (PI) inner-loops and voltage or even power PI outer-loops, a direct power control (DPC) scheme is considered. DPC is implemented through one stage PI-type controllers that directly regulate the active and reactive power flow. The process does not require a synchronization mechanism, known as phaselocked loop (PLL) but clearly introduces a zero open-loop pole. In the paper, the proposed control scheme realizes PItype direct active and reactive power regulators, stabilized on the left of the imaginary axis by introducing suitable damping terms. Since this has a clear impact in steady-state error, an appropriate mechanism is proposed which allows the damping term action exclusively during the transient period. Another design innovation introduced by the proposed controller is its robustness against ac voltage variations and system parameters since it does not include the conventionally used decoupling terms. The full nonlinear plant and control scheme is extensively analyzed for its stability and convergence characteristics by applying a rigorous Lyapunov based methodology. Further evaluation of the proposed approach is finally provided by suitable simulations.

title: Dual-Level Facilitated Multi-View Contrastive Graph Clustering
authors: Guangyu Zhang, Zi-Ying Li, Hai-Yan Wang, Dong Huang, Changdong Wang, Yang Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE 31th International Conference on Parallel and Distributed Systems (ICPADS)
abstract: Multi-view attributed graph clustering (MAGC) has recently experienced impressive attention in the graph exploration literature. Although several excellent achievements have been made, previous MVAGC approaches merely consider the homogeneous information across different views, easily resulting in the compromised results when faced with the heterogeneous graph scenarios. Further, many of them rely on the static neighborhood connection from original attributed graphs, which ignores the dynamical structural relationship for enhancing cross-view contrastive learning. To deal with these drawbacks, this paper derives a Dual-level Facilitated Multi-view Contrastive Graph Clustering (DF-MCGC) approach. Specifically, we design a hybrid graph filter by considering the homogeneity hidden in individual view. Further, the view-consistent topology invariant matrix is derived to exploit the topological relationship among different embedded representations. This design progressively helps to construct the cluster-wise sample pairs for cross-view contrastive learning. Especially, the overall network is incorporated with a dual-level self-supervised paradigm, among which the self-supervised signals can be efficiently facilitated in a mutually enhanced manner. Experiments on heterogeneous benchmarks have confirmed the advantages of our DF-MCGC approach in comparison with the advanced competitors.

title: Characterization of 3.4-4.7 THz Schottky Diode Mixers
authors: Theodore Reck, Nick Rothbart, Divya Jayasankar, Jeffrey Hesler, Jan Stake, Heinz-Wilhelm Hüebers
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: The performance of Schottky-diode mixers operating above 3THz are explored. First, two mixers are characterized at 3.5 THz and 4.7 THz. Fundamental mixer measurements at 3.5THz achieve an uncorrected receiver temperature of 50,000 K. The responsivities drop from 25 V/W at 3.5 THz to less than 5 V/W at 4.7 THz. To understand this dramatic roll-off across the WM57 waveguide band, a simulation model is developed that applies the Drude model for the conductivity of the epitaxial layers of the diode. Incorporating these parameters directly into the finite element simulation of the diode agrees better with these measured results than the classical lumped element model.

title: Quasi-Optical Systems: From Modelling to Applications
authors: N. Llombart
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: THz waves are sandwiched between micro and optical waves with frequencies in the order from 300 GHz up to 10 THz. In this part of the spectrum, technological development remains less advanced compared to optics and microwaves. Electronic devices exhibit cut-off frequencies in the lower THz range, while the energy of THz waves at these frequencies is relatively low, resulting in limited available power and sensitivity. This raises the question of why exploration of this spectral region is worthwhile. Historically, and still predominantly, the primary application has been the development of receivers for astronomical observations in the THz band. The inherent limitations in power and sensitivity characteristic of this spectral region have been mitigated through radiation coupling mechanisms utilizing quasi-optical systems.

title: Architecture Design of Large Model Systems in Vertical Fields for Multimodal Fusion
authors: Jingchu Zhang, Chaojie Wang, Hao Yang
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Automation, Electronics and Electrical Engineering (AUTEEE)
abstract: The application of multimodal artificial intelligence in vertical fields is confronted with three core challenges: modal heterogeneity, scarcity of domain data, and limitations of computing resources. To this end, this paper proposes a novel multimodal fusion system architecture for vertical fields. This system takes the Transformer encoder as the core fusion engine and achieves deep-grained cross-modal interaction through its inherent self-attention mechanism, effectively integrating visual and text information. Meanwhile, the system innovatively adopts low-rank adaptation (LoRA) technology for efficient domain fine-tuning of parameters, aiming to achieve high-performance domain adaptation with an extremely low number of training parameters. To verify the effectiveness of the system, we designed comparison and ablation experiments on multiple typical vertical tasks such as medical image report generation, industrial defect detection, financial risk control, and autonomous driving scenarios. The experimental results show that this system not only significantly outperforms the single-modal baseline in multimodal fusion performance, but also demonstrates significant advantages in computational efficiency, model robustness, and few-shot learning ability.

title: Design and Development of an Ambient Air Cold Atmospheric Plasma System for Antimicrobial Resistance Control
authors: T. Sowmya Shree, J. Rajalakshmi, M. Andrush Shiyam, K.M. Hemaprabha, K.S. Janane, V.S. Kishore
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Automation, Computing and Renewable Systems (ICACRS)
abstract: The increased incidence of antibiotic-resistant infections is a major challenge of modern wound care. To solve this problem, a Cold Atmospheric Plasma (CAP) system operating with ambient air has been introduced as a non-antibiotic antimicrobial therapy and a woundhealing promoter. The system is based on a plasma jet reactor powered by a low-frequency RF source, which is able to produce a stable, non-thermal plasma plume at room temperature from filtered ambient air instead of medical-grade gases. Such a system generates reactive oxygen and nitrogen species (RONS) like ozone (O₃), nitric oxide (NO) and hydroxyl radicals (·OH) that have a strong antimicrobial and healing effect. A specially designed microjet applicator facilitates the targeted plasma delivery and temperature control is carried out in real-time to ensure the patient's safety. In vitro, the device inactivates a >99.9% load of pathogens and multi-drug resistant bacteria such as MRSA and E. coli within 120 seconds of the area exposed to plasma. Besides disinfection, CAP therapy also promoted fibroblast proliferation and cell migration, thus, the wound closure process was faster. The instrument is small, mobile and simple to use, making it a non-invasive, chemical-free solution that is suitable both at home and in a clinic. So, this ambient air CAP system is an effective, safe and inexpensive way to achieve infection control and wound healing.

title: A 550 nA Quiescent Current Capacitor-Free Time-Domain LDO Powered by Photovoltaic Energy Harvester for ULV Wearable Sensor Nodes
authors: Siyuan Xu, Huan Hu
publish: 2025 IEEE Biomedical Circuits and Systems Conference (BioCAS)
abstract: This paper proposes a capacitor-free, time-domain low-dropout regulator (LDO) directly powered by photovoltaic energy harvester, operating down to 0.3 V for ultra-low-voltage (ULV) sensor nodes. Conventional LDOs employing operational amplifier as error amplifier (EA) are unsuitable for ULV operation. In this work, a VCO-integrator is adopted as the EA to enable a digitally intensive architecture. A transient enhancement module (TEM) is incorporated to improve load transient response. Implemented in 65 nm CMOS process, the proposed LDO operates with $\mathbf{0. 3 - 0. 7 V}$ input voltage, consumes quiescent current of only 550 nA with compact area of $0.043 \mathrm{~mm}^{2}$. It achieves line and load regulation of $0.079 \mathrm{mV} / \mathrm{V}$ and $0.012 \mathrm{mV} / \mathrm{mA}$, respectively. In addition, the LDO demonstrates a 94 mV undershoot and 108 mV overshoot under a 1 mA load step, achieving a figure-of-merit (FoM) of 4.7ps.

title: DPA-TA2C: Dynamic Priority-Aware Workflow Scheduling Method with Transformer and A2C in Cloud Data Center
authors: Fashun Jian, Guowei Shen, Xiaodan Lv, Chun Guo, Yunhe Cui
publish: 2025 IEEE 31th International Conference on Parallel and Distributed Systems (ICPADS)
abstract: Workflow scheduling in cloud data centers faces challenges such as task dependencies, resource heterogeneity, and dynamic workloads. Heuristic and meta-heuristic algorithms lack environment awareness and fail to meet real-time scheduling requirements. Existing deep reinforcement learning algorithms exhibit specific environment-aware capabilities; however, their feature modeling capabilities are insufficient, making it challenging to effectively model the nonlinear relationships between tasks and resources. To address these issues, we design a dynamic priority-aware mechanism that computes task priority factors in real time to adjust scheduling strategies adaptively. In low-load scenarios, dependency release is accelerated based on the priority rule of the successor node quantity to improve resource utilization; in high-load scenarios, bottleneck subtasks are prioritized based on the priority rule of the weighted critical path to shorten overall task completion times. We propose a Dynamic Priority-Aware Transformer-based Advantage ActorCritic (DPA-TA2C) scheduling method. The proposed method models the task topology, resource states, and priority factors as a sequence of features via a Transformer encoder. It collaboratively optimizes scheduling decisions using the policy and value functions of the A2C network to achieve end-to-end scheduling. Experimental results show that DPA-TA2C improves resource utilization by 49.5 % on average in low-load scenarios and reduces makespan by 51.6 % in high-load scenarios, demonstrating the efficiency and robustness of the proposed method for scheduling in complex cloud environments.

title: InAs metalens emitter for efficient THz beam generation and wavefront shaping
authors: Igal Brener, Hyunseung Jung, Sadhvikas J. Addamane, Ting Shan Luk, C. Thomas Harris, Ganapathi Subramania, Oleg Mitrofanov
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: Terahertz (THz) waves with controlled spatial structure can enable a broad range of applications from beam focusing to the formation of localized THz magnetic fields and THz vortex beams. Nonlinear optical metasurfaces can facilitate many of those applications by offering a novel approach where the spatial structure is imprinted at the THz pulse generation stage. In this presentation we demonstrate a nonlinear metasurface comprising a full-size (6 mm x 9 mm) binary-phase Fresnel lens design, which efficiently generates and focuses THz pulses when photoexcited by femtosecond optical pulses. The metalens is made of InAs nanoscale resonators and it combines two essential functionalities, THz pulse generation and wavefront engineering, in an ultrathin (130nm) flat device.

title: Digital disruptor of communication and navigation systems using phase manipulation
authors: Nikolay L. Gueorguiev, Atanas Nachev, Konstantin N. Nesterov, Ognyan D. Todorov, Yavor Boychev
abstract: The material presents a block diagram of a digital disruptor for communication and navigation systems using phase manipulation. The creation of interference through the use of random phase modulation of signals is the subject of numerous studies, each applicable for solving a specific set of tasks. The development and widespread use of radio control systems and satellite navigation for aircraft, which utilize phase-modulated signals, determine the relevance of assessing various possibilities for creating a digital jammer with phase manipulation designed for these systems The object of the study is creation of a possible sample of disruptor with phase manipulation that can be quickly reconfigured to operate in different frequency ranges and with different modulation periods of the generated disturbances. The main results from laboratory and field tests with laboratory samples and a prototype of a multi-channel digital disruptor are presented. Based on this, it is demonstrated that the creation of single-channel and multi-channel disruptors with digitally synthesized signals, which utilize phase manipulation, is possible, along with the capability for rapid reconfiguration across a wide frequency and phase range.

title: Data-driven Crack Detection in the Realm of Structural Health Monitoring: An Overview*
authors: Hassan Dabaja, Hassan Noura, Mustapha Ouladsine
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: The advancements of sensor technologies, improvements in computational power, and massive amounts of data from the increasing number of sensors deployed on structures have augmented the need for data-driven techniques in structural health monitoring (SHM), particularly for fatigue crack detection. Data-driven methods and tools are increasingly used in analyzing structures to ensure the absence of any fatigue crack in various engineering fields including civil, mechanical, aerospace, and maritime engineering. This overview aims to present the most recent research that utilizes data-driven methods for fatigue crack detection in engineering structures that fall within the realms of signal processing (SP) and machine learning (ML). It focuses on studies utilizing Deep Learning (DL) for crack detection, highlighting the importance of Transfer Learning (TL).

title: Twiddle-Factor Generation Using Reused Butterfly Array for Fully Homomorphic Encryption
authors: Muhammad Ogin Hasanuddin, Hanho Lee
abstract: The Number Theoretic Transform (NTT) and its inverse (INTT) are essential operations in Fully Homomorphic Encryption (FHE), converting expensive polynomial convolution into element-wise multiplication in <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathcal{O}(n)$</tex> time while each transform itself costs <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathcal{O}(n\log n)$</tex>. However, these transformations require storing <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathcal{O}(n)$</tex> twiddle factors (TF). As the polynomial degree increases, storing these TFs imposes significant memory overhead, limiting available resources for ciphertexts and intermediate data in hardware accelerators. Prior work has used a separate TF generation datapath, leading to higher additional resource overhead. To address this, we propose an on-the-fly TF generation method using a reused butterfly array, which eliminates the need for dedicated TF logic. The design reduces memory usage from ~12.09 MB to only ~0.38 MB, a 96.9% reduction, with zero DSP overhead. Compared to prior designs, it achieves up to 9.6 × better resource efficiency in terms of equivalent normalized slices (ENS), enabling more area- and memory-efficient FHE hardware accelerators.

title: Hybrid Soft-Rigid Elbow Exosuit: Theory, Mechatronic Design, and Experimental Assessment
authors: Ali KhalilianMotamed Bonab, Cristian Camardella, Antonio Frisoli, Domenico Chiaradia
abstract: Hybrid wearable robotics, combining soft and rigid elements, offer a promising solution for upper limb assistance by balancing comfort and functionality. This study evaluates a hybrid soft-rigid elbow exosuit designed for elbow movement support in dynamic and endurance tasks, focusing on biomechanical impact, user perception, and ergonomics. A theoretical model guided the design, optimizing device dynamics and assistive force delivery. A generic interaction controller, combined with fixed system parameters, provided effective assistance across participants without the need for subject-specific tuning, simplifying deployment in practical settings. During dynamic tasks, the exosuit significantly reduced biceps muscle activity compared to the unassisted condition, with an average reduction of 28.40%. In endurance tasks, it reduced infraspinatus activity by an average of 44.55% and mitigated increased muscle activation during load-carrying. Subjective assessments indicated lower perceived physical demand, while the System Usability Scale confirmed high usability and acceptance. These findings highlight the exosuit's ability to reduce physical effort and improve muscle coordination while maintaining comfort. The robust mechatronic design enabled effective assistance through a generic controller, emphasizing the importance of hardware reliability.

title: EEG based Emotion Detection Using CNN on the PYNQ Z2 Platform
authors: B.S.S. Tejesh, Ravisankar Dakupati, Syed Ali Hussain, Manas Ranjan Tripathy
publish: 2025 5th IEEE International Conference on Applied Electromagnetics, Signal Processing, &amp; Communication (AESPC)
abstract: This paper outlines a system for emotion recognition based on EEG utilizing Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) implemented on the PYNQ-Z2 FPGA board for instantaneous emotion classification. EEG signals undergo pre-processing through bandpass filtering $(0.5-30 \mathrm{~Hz})$ to eliminate noise and Z -score normalization to maintain data consistency. The CNN model differentiates emotions into three groups: positive, negative, and neutral. The system is trained on a labelled EEG dataset and is equipped on the PYNQ-Z2 board with an efficient and low-latency emotion recognition. The overall accuracy of the proposed system is 98%, while the accuracies for individual emotions are 99% for negative, 100% for neutral, and 95% for positive. These findings show the efficiency of CNNs in EEG-based emotion recognition and confirm that FPGA-based deployment is feasible for real-time, power-constrained applications in affective computing.

title: Experimental validation of zonotopic Tube-MPC applied to a Hexacopter
authors: Delansnay Gilles, Laurent Dewasme, Alain Vande Wouwer
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: In this paper, we present a real-time control strategy for a unmanned aerial vehicle operating under external disturbances, utilizing a Tube-based Model Predictive Control (Tube-MPC) framework integrated with a zonotopic representation. The approach ensures robust control by enforcing a bounded deviation between the real system trajectory and the nominal trajectory. The UAV’s control problem is formulated as a linear MPC for nominal control, and a state feedback controller for disturbance rejection, using zonotopes to compute robust invariant sets. The proposed method is tested on a UAV equipped with a Pixhawk 4 flight controller and Raspberry Pi 5, where the system’s robustness is validated in outdoor experiments under disturbances. The results demonstrate both the system’s performance and safety under real-world conditions.

title: The Application of TDLAS Technology in the Detection of Multi-Component Gases in Coal Mines Current Situation and Prospect: A review
authors: Xinhu Xu, Tongqiang Xia, Feiqiang Guo, Zhongke Yi
abstract: Tunable Diode Laser Absorption Spectroscopy (TDLAS) technology, as a highly selective, interference-resistant, and rapid-response (<1 s) optical gas detection method, demonstrates significant advantages in real-time monitoring of multi-component toxic and hazardous gases (such as CH₄, CO, H₂S, etc.) in coal mines. It is progressively replacing traditional electrochemical sensors and gas chromatography techniques. This paper systematically reviews the key technical pathways, current engineering applications, and future challenges of TDLAS in complex coal mine environments. It highlights the performance differences between Direct Absorption Spectroscopy (DAS) and Modulation Spectroscopy (MS), emphasizing the mainstream role of the WMS-2f/1f normalization method in enhancing trace gas detection sensitivity and anti-interference capabilities. For multi-component detection, the paper thoroughly examines the advantages and disadvantages of time-division multiplexing (TDM) Technology, frequency-division multi-plexing (FDM) Technology, and their hybrid strategy (F-TDM). It also explores the potential of overlapping spectral line separation strategies based on single lasers and machine learning algorithms for achieving low-cost, compact multi-component sensing. Although TDLAS has achieved preliminary applications in duct monitoring and in-situ detection, challenges persist, including nonlinear responses to high-concentration gases, laser costs, system complexity, and adaptability to extreme environments (high humidity, high dust, strong vibration). Future research should focus on developing high-concentration correction algorithms, low-cost laser sources, enhanced environmental robustness, and multi-technology integration to advance the comprehensive application of TDLAS in intelligent gas safety monitoring systems for mining environments.

title: Experiment Verification of a Novel Adaptive Robust Altitude Controller for UAVs Subject to Weight Disturbances*
authors: Abdulkadir Sehmus Ozgun, Zeki Gul, Serap Demirkol Ozgun, Enver Tatlicioglu
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: This study focuses on the challenges in controlling altitude changes in agricultural UAVs due to dynamic weight changes as a result of spraying. An innovative controller framework is developed to adapt quickly to weight changes, maintaining precise altitude control. The framework uses correction functions based on weight changes and height error, validated through experimental tests on quadcopters and hexacopters. The results demonstrate high performance in mitigating disturbances such as weight changes, wind, gusts, and thus enhance the reliability and effectiveness of UAVs in agriculture, promoting their broader adoption.

title: Deep Learning Assisted Adaptive Coding and Modulation Technology in High-Throughput Satellite Communication
authors: Jingyang Zhang, Siyi You, Yifeng He
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Automation, Electronics and Electrical Engineering (AUTEEE)
abstract: Due to the ever-changing channel conditions (rain attenuation, Doppler effect, and long delay) in High-Throughput Satellite Communication (HTS), classical Adaptive Coding and Modulation (ACM) technology cannot respond to channel conditions in real-time, resulting in an unreliable system throughput and an increased bit error rate. This paper utilizes a deep prediction model based on GRU (Gated Recurrent Unit) and MHSA (Multi-Head Self-Attention). First, the model is given the historical CSI (Channel State Information) sequence, which evaluates real-time Signal to Noise Ratio (SNR) and bit error rate information. Second, the GRU layer looks to model the long-term time dependence of capturing the long delays and sudden fading of the satellite channel. In addition, MHSA dynamically calculates weight coefficients for each historical time step to be more sensitive to rain attenuation and the Doppler effect. Third, the fully-connected output layer generates an accurate probability distribution of future channel state, including SNR confidence intervals and error rate thresholds. Finally, this distribution drives the ACM module to optimize the modulation order and encoding rate in real-time. The experimental results indicate that the root mean square error of the SNR prediction in the rain attenuation and Doppler composite scene is 6.87 decibels with an error rate of 0.1432, which demonstrates the feasibility and novelty of this method in optimizing communication performance in dynamic channel conditions.

title: Research on Machine Learning-Based Early Warning Models for New Energy Electric Vehicle Failures
authors: Wei Guangyuan, Xu Yanyan, Xia Fuzhi, Qin Jingjing, Guo Haibing
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Automation, Electronics and Electrical Engineering (AUTEEE)
abstract: With the rapid increase in the number of new energy electric vehicles, the risk of failure in their core components has become a critical issue affecting driving safety and user experience. Traditional fault diagnosis relies on post-event detection, making it difficult to meet real-time warning requirements. This paper proposes a fault early warning model for new energy vehicles based on a hybrid XGBoost-LSTM machine learning algorithm. By collecting vehicle operational data from multiple sensor sources, followed by data preprocessing and feature engineering, the model captures nonlinear characteristics while modeling temporal dependencies. Experiments conducted using NASA battery failure datasets and real-vehicle triple-electric system data demonstrate superiority over standalone SVM, Random Forest, and LSTM models in terms of fault prediction accuracy, recall, and F1-score. The proposed hybrid model achieves fault warnings 5–10 minutes earlier than single models, providing technical support for proactive safety protection in new energy vehicles.

title: Non-Invasive Cholesterol Detection Leveraging FTIR Spectroscopy
authors: Ravisankar Dakupati, B.S.S. Tejesh, Syed Ali Hussain, Pradyut Kumar Sanki, M. Ramakrishnan
publish: 2025 5th IEEE International Conference on Applied Electromagnetics, Signal Processing, &amp; Communication (AESPC)
abstract: Cholesterol is essential for cell structure, hormone production, and metabolism, but high levels raise the risk of cardiovascular diseases. Traditional detection methods like enzymatic assays and chromatography are invasive and not ideal for frequent use. This study explores Fourier Transform Infrared (FTIR) Spectroscopy as a non-invasive alternative. FTIR detects molecular vibrations, with key peaks at $1000 \mathrm{~cm}^{-1}$ ($\mathrm{C}-\mathrm{H}$ bending) and $3000 \mathrm{~cm}^{-1}$ ($\mathrm{O}-\mathrm{H}$ stretching) that indicate cholesterol presence. Tests on synthetic samples showed 90$\mathbf{9 5 \%}$ accuracy. Compared to standard methods, FTIR is faster, cheaper, portable, and reagent-free. The findings support the development of wearable FTIR devices for continuous cholesterol monitoring, with future enhancements possible via machine learning. Keywords: FTIR Spectroscopy, Cholesterol Detection, Non-Invasive Testing, Spectral Analysis, Biomedical Applications.

title: Toward Prediction-Driven Time-Adaptive Seizure Management Using a WC-NMM Network
authors: Samira Nabavi, Hossein Kassiri
publish: 2025 IEEE Biomedical Circuits and Systems Conference (BioCAS)
abstract: This paper presents a biologically plausible framework for modeling and controlling seizure dynamics using a small-world scale-free network of Wilson-Cowan neural mass models (NMMs). Our approach captures both normal and pathological cortical states by coupling 80 excitatory-inhibitory populations via long-range connectivity based on a down-sampled cortical connectome. By incorporating realistic EEG recon-struction-where each electrode collects a distance-weighted summation of local population activities-we generate multichannel iEEG signals that closely mimic both interictal and ictal patterns. To evaluate closed-loop stimulation strategies, we introduce a cost function comparing the stimulated signal’s spectral content against a normal baseline, thus quantifying seizure suppression effectiveness. Parameter sweeps of bipolar stimulation pulses reveal optimal amplitude-frequency ranges for terminating seizure-like events, demonstrating the potential for personalized, model-driven neurostimulation.

title: A Novel Jamming Modulation Scheme Using Jamming Elimination and Amplificationfor Reliable Communications
authors: Yusi Zhang, Yuxin Shi, Zhenyao He, Ke Shi, Ying Liu, Chen Han
abstract: Recently, an active anti-jamming (AAJ) scheme called jamming modulation (JM) scheme has been proposed, which shows better bit error rate (BER) performance under jamming attack by controlling the on-off state of the programmable gain amplifier (PGA). For the purpose of further improving the BER performance under high jamming-to-noise ratio (JNR) cases, this paper proposesa novel JM scheme using jamming elimination and amplification (JM-JEA). Specifically, the JM-JEAuses the PGA to generate the two states: jamming elimination and jamming amplification for transmitting information bits, which enables the reliable detection at the receiver. Moreover, we derive the expression for the BER performance and provide the optimal threshold for decoding the information bits for the JM-JEA.Our analysis shows that the JM-JEA overcomes the BER floor of the traditional AAJ scheme at large JNR, and achieves the significant improvement on the BER performance.

title: A New Approach to Hybrid Delay Test Using Shared Observe Points
authors: Jaehyun Kim, Sangjun Lee, Laesang Jung, Hanseong Cho, Sungho Kang
abstract: As semiconductor technologies scale down, timing-related defects have become a major reliability issue. Traditional stuck-at fault models fail to detect subtle timing violations, making delay testing essential for identifying transition delay faults (TDFs). This paper presents a hybrid test method combining Launch-on-Capture (LOC) and Launch-on-Shift (LOS) to improve coverage. To address fault blocking, test points (TPs) are inserted at critical nodes. Unlike conventional approaches that require dedicated flip-flops for each OP, the proposed method reuses existing flip-flops through shared observe point insertion, reducing hardware overhead. This enables high fault coverage with fewer test patterns and minimal hardware overhead.

title: Retraction Notice: Breast Cancer Prediction via Machine Learning
authors: Mamatha Sai Yarabarla, Lakshmi Kavya Ravi, A. Sivasangari
publish: 2019 3rd International Conference on Trends in Electronics and Informatics (ICOEI)
abstract: Breast cancer is one of the most common and leading causes of cancer among women. Currently, it has become the common health issue, and its incidence has increased recently. Prior identification is the best way to manage breast cancer results. Computer-aided detection or diagnosis (CAD) systems plays a major role in prior identification of breast cancer and can be used for reduction of death rate among women. The main intention of this paper is to make use of the recent advances in the development of CAD systems and related techniques. The mainstay of the project is to predict whether the person is having breast cancer or not. Machine learning is nothing but training the machines to learn and perform by itself without any explicit program or instruction. So here, predicting whether a person is suffering with breast cancer or not is done with the help of the trained data.

title: Neuromorphic Classification of Geophone Signals with Legendre Memory Units
authors: Avi Hazan, Shlomo Greenberg, Elishai Ezra Tsur
publish: 2025 IEEE Biomedical Circuits and Systems Conference (BioCAS)
abstract: Geophones are acoustic detectors that respond to seismic waves, which generate ground vibrations. In this work, we utilized a neuromorphic (brain-inspired) Legendre Memory Units (LMUs)-driven neural model for low-power, real-time classification of Geophone data, discriminating vibrations, which were generated by human footsteps, a moving vehicle, and ambient noise. We show that our neuromorphic hardware-compatible neural design produces comparable results with state-of-the-art long-short-term memory (LSTM) models, achieving high test accuracy (LMU: 93.88%, LSTM: 95.15%). Our work highlights the potential of LMUs-driven inference models for classifying analog data in energy-constrained environments.

title: An Inclusive AI-Powered Smart ATM Interface using OpenCV for Deaf, Mute, and Visually Impaired Individual
authors: Trisha S, Dhivyadharshini.S, P. Baraneedharan
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Automation, Computing and Renewable Systems (ICACRS)
abstract: The work addresses the issue of inaccessibility with conventional ATMs, which cannot cater to the requirements of people with hearing, speech, and visual impairments, thereby limiting their autonomy regarding financial transactions. This work proposes a Smart ATM system that integrates assistive technologies into an inclusive and userfriendly banking interface. The aim is to allow differently-abled users to perform secure and private transactions with a minimum level of assistance. An Arduino Mega microcontroller acts as the controlling unit, while OpenCV-based face recognition provides personalized authentication. A servo motor-driven tactile Braille keypad allows for independent input, while a DF Player module gives real-time audio guidance and feedback. An LCD display provides visual feedback during transactions. The system is an example of a novel embedded platform where multi-modal interaction-a combination of tactile, audio, and visual interfaces-has been integrated, ensuring access, independence, and enhanced usability that guarantees financial inclusion for all users.

title: AODMS: Adaptive Online Edge-Cloud Collaborative Inference with Dynamic Model Switching and Resource Allocation
authors: Lulu Zuo, Qingfang Zheng, Zheming Yang, Wen Ji
publish: 2025 IEEE 31th International Conference on Parallel and Distributed Systems (ICPADS)
abstract: Cloud inference consumes massive amounts of resources and carbon emissions, which has prompted edge-cloud inference to become a new paradigm. However, constrained by limited edge resources, existing approaches predominantly adopt periodic model switching strategies, overlooking the heterogeneity of application requirements and the highly dynamic nature of task demands in large-scale edge-cloud environments. To address these challenges, this paper proposes an Adaptive Online Dynamic Model Switching (AODMS) framework, which jointly optimizes real-time model switching, cross-layer resource allocation, and edge-cloud collaborative inference to minimize long-term system cost, including task execution time and carbon emissions. First, an average saving cost evaluation mechanism is developed to determine optimal model switching points, coupled with a matrix-constrained pairwise search strategy for efficient exploration of feasible edge model loading. And then a distributed iterative optimization scheme is proposed for joint resource allocation and edge-cloud task scheduling. Extensive experimental evaluations demonstrate that AODMS can significantly reduce model switching frequency, average inference time, and Carbon Footprint (CF), offering a scalable and adaptive solution for the sustainable edge-cloud system.

title: Multi-Agent Collaborative Reasoning via Cloud-Edge Framework
authors: Jiandian Zeng, Junjie Liao, Shaochen Sun, Guangxue Zhang, Changfu Xu, Huaijin Liu, Yang Li
abstract: Large Language Model (LLM)-based agents have significantly advanced the reasoning and problem-solving capabilities of intelligent systems. As tasks grow more complex, there is an increasing need to shift from single-agent framework to Multi-Agent Systems (MAS) for enhanced collaborative performance. Achieving better performance typically requires deploying large-scale LLMs, however, it poses significant challenges on resource-constrained edge devices. In addition, most MAS adopt a fully connected communication topology and require multiple rounds of interaction, resulting in considerable communication redundancy and increased computational overhead. To address the issues, in this paper, we propose a Directed Acyclic Graph-based Multi-Agent System (DAG-MAS) via cloud-edge framework for collaborative reasoning. Specifically, considering the limited resources on the edge, we utilize a 72B-LLM in the cloud finetunes a lightweight Small Language Model (SLM) for edge deployment. To generate a one round interaction graph, the SLM is further employed to analyze task requirements and determine optimal communication topology, minimizing overhead while enabling effective information exchange. Extensive experiments and analyses on four reasoning datasets demonstrate the superiority of our approach compared to several benchmark methods, validating the effectiveness in achieving higher reasoning performance with lower communication costs.

title: PQGNet: Perceptual Query Guided Network for Infrared Small Target Detection
authors: Pingping Liu, Aohua Li, Yubing Lu, Tongshun Zhang, Ming Yang, Qiuzhan Zhou
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Infrared small target detection (IRSTD) holds critical importance for military security applications. Although U-shaped architectures have improved baseline performance, existing methods still suffer from two key limitations: 1) Insufficient spatial perception for tiny targets leads to target location loss.; 2) Edge degradation and semantic ambiguity in deep feature reconstruction. To address these challenges, we propose PQGNet with the following contributions: To enhance capability of spatial perception and improve feature fusion guidance, we introduce the Perceptual Query Supervision Mechanism (PQSM), which utilizes perceptual loss to constrain spatial feature learning of each encoder layer. The Perceptual Feature Construction Module (PFCM) constructs enhanced perceptual features to preserve target localization information, while the Perceptual Query Guidance Module (PQGM) adopts cross-attention to guide global and regional feature queries through skip connections, optimizing target feature extraction.  To mitigate reconstruction degradation and semantic ambiguity, distinct from existing wavelet-based approaches that simply substitute pooling layers, we design a Max pooling-Wavelet Hybrid Layer (MWHL) and High-frequency Enhancement Wavelet Layer (HEWL) that exploit discrete wavelet transform properties to enhance deep semantic representations using shallow high-frequency details. Comprehensive experiments on NUDT-SIRST, NUAA-SIRST, and IRSTD-1K datasets demonstrate that PQGNet significantly surpasses state-of-the-art methods in detection performance, while maintaining a competitive balance between computational complexity and accuracy. Our code will be made public at https://github.com/PepperCS/PQGNet.
