title: Hybrid Orchestration of AI Services and Microservices in Cloud-Edge Collaboration
authors: Kai Peng, Xudong Liu, Di Han, Yi Hu, Menglan Hu, Chao Cai, Zehui Xiong
abstract: The rapid development of AI accelerates the implementation and delivery of AI applications in diverse fields. In cloud-edge collaboration, delivering a complete AI application relies on the robust coordination between AI-supporting microservices and AI services. However, most existing studies only coarsely considered monolithic AI service orchestration while neglecting microservice orchestration. Such coarse-grained orchestration severely impacts application performance. To enable diverse high-performance AI applications, fine-grained hybrid orchestration of AI services and microservices (HOAIM) is highly desirable, yet presents formidable challenges. Due to heterogeneous services, call dependencies, and service multiplexing, fine-grained hybrid orchestration modeling is highly non-trivial. Moreover, the tight coupling between deployment and routing results in a complex joint optimization problem. To address this, we first propose a heterogeneous service orchestration network that supports orchestration optimization and automated management. Then, based on queuing networks and multi-instance models, we conduct an accurate analysis of delay and load. Furthermore, to achieve efficient hybrid orchestration, we propose preference-driven resource allocation and instance computation algorithms, along with reinforcement learning with action masking and reward shaping. Finally, extensive trace-driven simulations demonstrate that our algorithms optimize average response delay by up to 41.83%, and achieve significant advantages in load balancing, response success rate, and resource efficiency.

title: Reinforcement Learning based Adaptive PID Controller for Non-minimum Phase Unstable Systems with delay
authors: Sourabh Yadav, Ketan P. Detroja
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: Control of unstable systems is a pretty challenging task, since even a slight mismatch in controller gains can cause the system to go out of bounds. The control task becomes even more difficult if an unstable system has a zero in the right half-plane (RHP) of the complex s-plane. In this paper, a reinforcement learning (RL) based controller tuning method for non-minimum phase unstable systems is proposed. An adaptive PID controller is designed using RL and a modified Smith predictor structure is used to accommodate any delay in the system. The Deep Deterministic Policy Gradient (DDPG) algorithm has been employed along with a long short term memory (LSTM) layer in the actor as well as the critic network to design an RL-based adaptive PID controller. The proposed framework with the modified Smith predictor and RL based PID controller provide improved control performance. The performance has been evaluated against a state-of-the-art PID controller based on Integral Absolute Error (IAE) and Integral Square Error (ISE). Various case studies highlight the applicability of the proposed framework to a wide range of unstable and non-minimum phase systems.

title: Tensile Testing at Elevated Temperatures of Test Specimens Made of Polymer Materials Obtained by Fused Deposition Modeling
authors: Miglena Paneva, Peter Panev, Veselin Tsonev
abstract: Plastic products are increasingly used both in our daily lives and in industry. There are many methods for their manufacture, but the most widespread nowadays is three-dimensional printing using Fused Deposition modeling. Using the mentioned technology, test specimens for testing tensile strength have been made from different groups of polymer materials, which will be tested at elevated temperatures using a test stand. The analyses performed will verify the temperature to which each of the materials can withstand. A thermocouple and an infrared thermal camera were used to control the temperatures during testing. The testing temperatures were selected depending on the characteristics of the materials. Strength-strain curves were constructed for each material.

title: Hardware Emulation of Membrane Potential Using a 1T1C FeFET–Capacitor Structure for Neuromorphic Applications
authors: Kazuki Sawai, Riku Horio, Rodrigo Vieira Witt, Tokiyoshi Matsuda, Hidenori Kawanishi, Takaaki Miyasako, Sanggyu Koh, Tadasu Hosokura, Reon Oshio, Takumi Kuwahara, Yasuhiko Nakashima, Mutsumi Kimura
abstract: With the increasing demand for high-density implementation and low-power operation of artificial intelligence (AI), inherent limitations of the conventional von Neumann architecture have been recognized, highlighting the development of energy-efficient synaptic devices as a critical issue in neuromorphic systems. In this study, a novel synaptic architecture was proposed based on a 1T1C structure, in which a ferroelectric field-effect transistor (FeFET) is connected in series with a capacitor, to realize analog responses similar to the membrane potential of biological neurons through circuit-level integration based on the 1T1C synaptic behavior. The transfer characteristics of the FeFET were experimentally measured and modeled, and circuit simulations emulating neural network structures reproduced dynamic membrane potential ( ${V} _{\text {mem}}\text {)}$ variations using 196 cells (input-to-hidden layer) and 80 cells (hidden-to-output layer). Through evolutionary symbolic regression, a mathematical model expressing ${\Delta }$ V mem as a function of ${\Sigma } {G}$ and the preceding ${V} _{\text {mem}}$ was derived, and its implementation in a spiking neural network (SNN) achieved 95.5% recognition accuracy for MNIST image classification. The energy consumption of the synaptic circuit was further estimated to be 239 nJ/inference, and scaling the device dimensions down to the 100-nm regime suggested a reduction to 3.74 pJ/inference. These findings demonstrate the extremely high potential of the proposed approach for ultralow-power operation, indicating that the FeFET–capacitor 1T1C structure constitutes a promising synaptic device architecture for high-density neuromorphic systems and edge AI applications.

title: EV Battery Thermal Management System Using Nanofluids and Integrating Hybrid Cooling
authors: Kalpana Kumari, Rakesh Mohanty, Srija Adhikari, Swadhin Sarangi, Nirmal Kumar Rout
publish: 2025 5th IEEE International Conference on Applied Electromagnetics, Signal Processing, &amp; Communication (AESPC)
abstract: Electric vehicles (EVs) use lithium-ion batteries that function best within the range of $15^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ to $35^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$; deviations cause decreased performance, faster degradation, or thermal runaway. Traditional battery thermal management systems (BTMS), often air or ethylene glycol-based liquid-cooled, usually are not able to provide uniform and effective temperature control under rapid charging or high load conditions. This work introduces the design, simulation, and analysis of a modern BTMS based on nanofluid coolants to improve heat transfer and system efficiency. Nanofluids, which consist of nanoparticles dispersed in the base fluid, have greater thermal conductivity, higher heat absorption capability, and reduced viscosity relative to conventional coolants. A MATLAB/Simulink model was constructed by manually specifying nanofluid thermophysical properties, simulating realistic driving conditions. Tests indicate better temperature regulation throughout battery, motor, charger, inverter, and DC-DC converter components, with temperature decreases of as much as 5.26 % over ethylene glycol. Components were kept within their optimal ranges of operating temperatures, improving safety and efficiency. Cost calculations reveal that even though higher-cost coolants are used, better efficiency makes nano-fluid utilization worth it. The suggested system reveals an efficient solution for future-generation EV BTMS in terms of improved thermal performance, modeling fidelity, and integration capabilities.

title: Thermoelectric Energy Harvesting for Tire Pressure Monitoring System
authors: Vasantharaj A, Dharani G, Sanjay Joshua B, Muthu Siva R
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Automation, Computing and Renewable Systems (ICACRS)
abstract: This study analysis the possibility of powering a Tire Pressure Monitoring System (TPMS) in automobiles using a energy harvesting method. The idea of this work is to place a thermoelectric generator (TEG) between the tire and the rim, where a temperature difference consistently develops during driving can be turned into a power. The study is carried out in two parts. First, a thermal analysis of the tire is performed in ANSYS to understand how the temperature builds up at different vehicle speeds. The temperature values from this simulation are then used as inputs for a second model, where a TEG's one side is exposed to the hot-side and and another to the less-side conditions. By doing this, the electrical output of the TEG can be estimated. The findings show that higher speeds of the vehicle lead to a more noticeable temperature gradient inside the tire, which improves the potential for energy harvesting. The generated power is then evaluated considering the TEG’s material properties, size, and electrical loading. This study looks at whether a small, self-powered tire pressure monitoring system (TPMS) could run using the heat produced naturally by a spinning wheel.

title: Cached Model-as-a-Resource: Provisioning Large Language Model Agents for Edge Intelligence in Space-air-ground Integrated Networks
authors: Minrui Xu, Dusit Niyato, Hongliang Zhang, Jiawen Kang, Zehui Xiong, Shiwen Mao, Zhu Han
abstract: Edge intelligence in space-air-ground integrated networks (SAGINs) can enable worldwide network coverage beyond geographical limitations for users to access ubiquitous and low-latency intelligence services. Facing global coverage and complex environments in SAGINs, edge intelligence can provision large language models (LLMs) agents for users via edge servers at ground base stations (BSs) or cloud data centers relayed by satellites. As LLMs with billions of parameters are pretrained on vast datasets, LLM agents have few-shot learning capabilities, e.g., chain-of-thought (CoT) prompting for complex tasks, which raises a new trade-off between resource consumption and performance in SAGINs. In this paper, we propose a joint caching and inference framework for edge intelligence to provision sustainable and ubiquitous LLM agents in SAGINs. We introduce “cached model-as-a-resource” for offering LLMs with limited context windows and propose a novel optimization framework, i.e., joint model caching and inference, to utilize cached model resources for provisioning LLM agent services along with communication, computing, and storage resources.We design “age of thought” (AoT) considering the CoT prompting of LLMs, and propose a least AoT cached model replacement algorithm for optimizing the provisioning cost. We propose a deep Q-network-based modified second-bid (DQMSB) auction to incentivize satellite/ground network operators in real-time, which can enhance allocation efficiency by 23% while guaranteeing strategy-proofness and being free from adverse selection.

title: From Measurement to Monitoring: Evaluating Privacy Risks in Carbon Footprint Tools
authors: Yehia Ibrahim Alzoubi, Ahmet E. Topcu, Ersin Elbasi
abstract: The increasing urgency of climate change mitigation has accelerated the adoption of tools to measure and monitor greenhouse gas emissions at individual, organizational, and infrastructural levels. While these tools enhance the accuracy and accountability of emissions measurement, they also raise privacy concerns due to the sensitive data they collect, the granularity of monitoring, and the potential for secondary use. Despite their growing adoption, no prior study has systematically evaluated the privacy implications of carbon footprint tools across categories or examined how data practices differ between consumer calculators, enterprise systems, and emerging Internet of Things (IoT), Artificial Intelligence (AI), and blockchain solutions. This study addresses this gap by conducting a structured, cross-category privacy evaluation of carbon footprint tools, reviewing 46 tools from academic and industry sources. A novel five-dimensional privacy risk framework, encompassing data type, granularity, storage, processing, secondary use, and user agency, is developed and applied across five tool categories: individual calculators, corporate platforms, infrastructure tools, IoT/AI/blockchain systems, and research tools. The findings reveal pronounced privacy–accuracy trade-offs: tools offering higher measurement precision often require more intrusive data collection. The study also identifies category-specific least- and highest-risk tools, showing that simple household calculators present low risk. In contrast, enterprise platforms and IoT/blockchain systems exhibit the highest exposure due to sensitive operational, financial, and real-time data flows. The study is limited by its reliance on literature and public documentation, suggesting the need for empirical field studies and technical audits. Future research should expand on these findings by investigating user perceptions, legal frameworks, and privacy-preserving design strategies for sustainable digital tools.

title: Accelerating Spell Checking with Parallel Processing Techniques
authors: Nikola Petrushevski, Vladimir Zdraveski
abstract: Spell checking plays a vital role in ensuring the quality of written content across a wide range of applications. However, traditional sequential spell-checking methods become inefficient when handling large-scale text data. This paper explores a parallelized approach to spell checking, designed to leverage modern multi-core processors for improved scalability. By distributing the workload across multiple worker processes and incorporating both phonetic and edit-distance techniques, the system efficiently identifies and corrects spelling errors. Experimental results demonstrate that the parallel architecture significantly improves processing time while maintaining the accuracy of correction suggestions, making it well-suited for high-volume or real-time applications.

title: SLAG: A Sensitive Layer Activation-Guided Jailbreak Attack on Vision-Language Models
authors: Jingjing He, Yujie Wang, Yisheng Li, Zhichao Lian
publish: 2025 IEEE 31th International Conference on Parallel and Distributed Systems (ICPADS)
abstract: We present SLAG, a Sensitive Layer ActivationGuided jailbreak attack for Large Vision-Language Models (LVLMs). SLAG identifies safety-sensitive layers whose activations differ between harmful and benign inputs, and perturbs images using a dual-objective loss to enhance harmful generation while suppressing refusals. On MiniGPT-4, SLAG achieves a 95.0% Attack Success Rate with only 2000 steps, outperforming existing image-only attacks and approaching multimodal methods. Layer analysis shows that a few mid-to-late layers suffice, revealing multiple activation pathways linked to safety failures.

title: Terahertz Chiral Phonon-Polaritons Probed via the Faraday Effect
authors: Megan F. Biggs, Sin-Hang Enoch Ho, Aldair Alejandro, Matthew J. Lutz, Clayton D. Moss, Jeremy A. Johnson
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: We create a circularly polarized THz pump pulse by combining a pair of orthogonal THz pulses with appropriate relative delay. This circular drive launches a chiral phonon-polariton and we probe the time-reversal symmetry breaking response with the ultrafast Faraday effect.

authors: Dingding Li, Zihan Wei, Ping Zhang, Yangyang Lv, Huabing Wang, Peiheng Wu
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: Bi<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>Sr<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>CaCu<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>O<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">8</inf>+δ (BSCCO) single crystal, due to its naturally formed Josephson junction array structure, has become an ideal material system for the fabrication of terahertz (THz) radiation sources. In this work, we studied the mechanism of regulating the radiation frequency of the THz source by introducing hole perturbations into the intrinsic THz junction array, laying an important theoretical foundation for the development of frequency-tunable BSCCO terahertz radiation sources.

title: A domain adaptation approach in fault detection and isolation of ultrasound sea altimeters
authors: Vito Antonio Nardi, Federico Casella, Mariacarla Lugarà, Valerio Scordamaglia, Claudio De Capua, Pasquale Filianoti
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: This work proposes an approach for the fault detection (FD) of a single out-of-water ultrasound range meter for the measurement of sea height. Although they provide high-frequency and accurate measurements, such sensors are prone to faults, and the presence of foam on the water surface can hinder their measurement capabilities. In contrast, underwater pressure sensors provide more reliable but less accurate measurements of wave characteristics. Furthermore, wave attenuation below the sea surface affects the accuracy of pressure sensors-based measurements of wave motion. This work introduces a procedure for performing transfer learning, aimed at leveraging knowledge acquired from pressure sensor data to train a neural network that provides fault detection capabilities in ultrasonic measurement of sea level. The proposed transfer learning procedure takes advantage of linear wave theory, a description of the motion of small amplitude sea waves, to perform domain adaptation. The effectiveness of the proposed approach is discussed through simulations on a real-world dataset in which three common types of faults are injected.

title: Effect of Meta Surface at different distances on an optimized inset feed patch antenna for 3.6 GHz Application
authors: Ribhu Abhusan Panda, Prabhat Kumar Patnaik, Rokkam Sandhya Rani, Bali Sudhir, Subhrat Kumar Samal
publish: 2025 5th IEEE International Conference on Applied Electromagnetics, Signal Processing, &amp; Communication (AESPC)
abstract: A conventional rectangular patch has been designed with line feed in this article. Optimization of the feed width has been done to determine the best width for impedance matching. A Meta surface has been implemented below the ground plane to enhance the antenna performance. Distance of the Meta surface has been varied in accordance to the wavelength and the variation in S-Parameter has been observed. It has been observed that at an optimized feed width 3 mm leads provides a return loss of -21 dB at 3.54 GHz frequency. Implementation of Meta surface at different positions leads to different resonant frequency and the appropriate position has been determined. With an antenna gain of 8.78 dB the optimal distance of meta surface from ground has been found out to be $\boldsymbol{\lambda} \boldsymbol{/} \mathbf{2}$. The directivity and return loss have been determined from HFSS simulation is 9.56 dB and -28.05 dB respectively.

title: Research on Microwave Thermal Effects of GaAs Using a Terahertz Open Resonator
authors: Jin Cheng, Yunpeng Zhang, Xiangbao Zhu, Yong Gao, En Li
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: In this paper, a complex permittivity measurement system using a terahertz open resonator with microwave field loading is proposed for the research on microwave thermal effects. Based on this system, experiments were carried out on GaAs materials under different power applications. The system reflects the thermal effect of GaAs material under different microwave electric field by observing the change of resonance parameters of the terahertz open resonator. Moreover, the thermal effect of GaAs materials under microwave power is quantified by the amount of change in resonance parameters. The terahertz quasi-optical cavity adopts a multi-channel coupling technique, which uses two cavities to operate in 0.11~0.5 terahertz (THz) range. Furthermore, an open-structure re-entrant coaxial cavity working in X band is used to provide a microwave strong electric field environment.

title: Behavioral Effects of AI-generated Synthetic Vocalizations in Free-Moving Marmosets
authors: Emma Woolgar, Yegang Du, Steven Errington, Benjamin Slater, Toshimi Ogawa, Yukiko Kikuchi
publish: 2025 IEEE Cyber Science and Technology Congress (CyberSciTech)
abstract: AI-based voice synthesis technologies are central to improving human-computer interaction (HCI). Socially assistive robots, which incorporate such voice technology, are emerging as promising tools for enhancing the quality of care for individuals with cognitive decline. However, the development of emotionally expressive artificial voices, particularly for older adults, remains limited. A key challenge is the lack of understanding of how auditory and emotional cues in artificial voices influence perception and behavior in cognitively impaired populations. To address this, it is important to study how deep learning models used for voice synthesis affect behavior in animal models that can translate to human clinical conditions.In this study, we used a Variational Autoencoder (VAE) to generate synthetic vocalizations and compared the behavior of three freely moving marmosets in response to AI-generated and natural vocalizations. We observed a significant main effect of condition on two behaviors (stationary and leg stand - contact), suggesting that vocalization type influenced behavioral responses. However, post hoc pairwise comparisons did not show statistically significant differences between specific conditions, possibly due to limited power or individual variability, suggesting that AI-generated vocalizations were not perceived as equivalent to natural ones. These findings highlight the need for more diverse training datasets to develop VAE models for this species. Despite current limitations, marmosets remain a promising model for advancing synthetic voice technologies to enhance communication and cognitive outcomes in humans.

title: Density characterisation of solid-state electrolytes using terahertz time-domain spectroscopy
authors: S. Kiritharan, R. Degl’Innocenti, P. Bawuah, S. Engelbrecht, B. Fischer, X. Hua, R. Dawson, H. Lin
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: Terahertz time-domain spectroscopy (THz-TDS) has previously been used to characterize porosities inside pharmaceutical dosage forms. With an increasing demand for clean energy, we examine the broad applicability of this emerging technique for characterizing densities of solid-state electrolytes (SSEs). In particular, relative densities of NaSICON (Sodium SuperIonic CONductor) pellets prepared at a range of sintering temperatures were quantified and compared against complementary hydrostatic weighing and mercury porosimetry, where results were in close agreement. This therefore shows the THz-TDS as a promising tool for electrolyte characterization.

title: Generation and applications of strong terahertz bursts driven by high-intensity laser pulses
authors: Yutong Li
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: Recently Terahertz (THz) radiation from laser-produced plasmas has attracted much interest since plasmas can work at arbitrarily high laser intensity. We systematically investigate the generation of strong THz radiation from solid targets irradiated by ultraintense laser pulses with relativistic intensities exceeding 10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">18</sup>W/cm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>.The experiments were performed with femtosecond and picosecond laser facilities respectively. The numerous energetic MeV fast electrons produced by the high-intensity laser pulses serve as the primary source of the THz radiation. When the forward fast electrons reach the target rear surface, THz radiation is induced via the mechanism of transition radiation. To enhance the THz radiation, a variety of techniques have been employed. These include increasing laser absorption through the use of a preplasma, fabricating nanostructures on the front surface of the target, optimizing the target thickness, applying a CH coating, and employing an additional laser pulse to ablate the target rear. The optimized energy of the terahertz pulses can reach the millijoule to hundreds of millijoules range, depending on the specific parameters of the driving laser pulses. Additionally, we have conducted preliminary studies exploring the nonlinear interaction between the strong terahertz pulses and condensed matters, such as the excitation of biological protein dynamics, water dynamics, and phonons.

title: Energy-Efficient DSP Design Using Adiabatic Logic: From Barrel Shifter Circuits to FIR Filters
authors: Shwetha Shetty, Mrunalini Gavfale, Reshma Patil, T.P. Vinutha
publish: 2025 5th IEEE International Conference on Applied Electromagnetics, Signal Processing, &amp; Communication (AESPC)
abstract: Low-power design is a critical requirement for digital signal processing (DSP) hardware in portable and embedded platforms. Traditional — Complementary Metal-Oxide-Semiconductor (CMOS) circuits, although fast and reliable, waste significant energy through capacitive charging and discharging. Adiabatic logic reduces this overhead by recycling charge during switching events. In this work, a barrel shifter is implemented in four logic families: CMOS, Two-Phase Adiabatic Static CMOS Logic (2PASCL), Efficient Charge Recovery Logic (ECRL), and Pass-Transistor Adiabatic Logic (PAL)—using a 45 $\mathbf{n m}$ Cadence flow. The measured power results from these implementations are analyzed in the context of a finite impulse response (FIR) filter modeled in Python to assess the potential system-level impact on DSP workloads. The study shows that PAL achieves the most favorable balance between power efficiency and signal integrity, making it well suited for energy-constrained DSP applications.

title: Encrypted Function-Based Fragment Management for Verifiable Privacy-Preserving Image Storage in Cloud Environments
authors: Zhixuan Wang, Ruixiong Huang
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Big Data, Artificial Intelligence and Internet of Things Engineering (ICBAIE)
abstract: With the rapid growth of image sharing on social networks and cloud platforms, ensuring the security, reliability, and availability of cloud-stored image data has become a pressing challenge, often leading to privacy leakage. Recent segmentationbased privacy protection methods show promise but largely overlook the structured management and secure indexing of image fragments once stored in the cloud. To address these limitations, this paper proposes an encrypted function-based image fragment management scheme. The method uses cryptographic function mapping to build a computable index management mechanism that generates a main identifier (MID) and multiple subidentifiers (SIDs) across distributed cloud servers, securely linking sensitive and nonsensitive fragments. Moreover, to guarantee fragment authenticity and integrity during reconstruction, an HMAC-based key derivation function (HKDF) is employed to generate unique verification keys for each fragment, ensuring accurate and verifiable image reassembly.

title: Design and Implementation of Multiattention Convolution Neural Network Architecture to Drones towards Detection and Control of Wheat Disease and Pest
authors: Vishwetha, K. Tharageswari
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Automation, Computing and Renewable Systems (ICACRS)
abstract: Automated Crop disease detection and control becomes significant research in agriculture domain as viral, fungal and bacterial types impacts the yield potential of the crop also it generates economic damage to the farmers. Nowadays Humanoid Robots considered as drones has deployed in agriculture field to monitor and interact with crop regions to perform human related tasks. Drones were trained using artificial intelligence and machine learning architecture to perform specialized complex tasks such as crop disease prediction and disease controlling through employment of the specified pesticides and fertilizers. Despite of multiple advantages of machine learning and deep learning model towards predicting crop diseases on monitoring and controlling by applying pesticides and fertilizer faces several challenges in predicting disease due to diversity of the crop diseases with respect to lightening, climatic condition and soil conditions in the agriculture field. In this paper, a new deep learning architecture entitled as multiattention convolution neural network is designed and it is used to train drone which is deployed to predict and control wheat crop diseases against different conditions accurately. Multiattention convolution neural network uses attention mechanism to process the monitored wheat crop images with attention coefficients. Initially Image preprocessing techniques is applied to eliminate the noise and to perform image augmentation. Preprocessed image is processed in the convolution layer to extract disease specific features related to climate and soil. Attention coefficient of attention mechanism is incorporated in the polling layer of the model to determine the anthracnose and other fungal diseases in the crops and obtains saliency map. Finally fully connected layer of the model incorporating the softmax function classifies the saliency map into crop diseases with respect to severity classes and predict the appropriate fertilizer and pesticide to manage specified severity of the crop diseases as control mechanism. Experimental analysis of the model is performed using training data of the Global Wheat Head Detection (GWHD) dataset in python environment. Performance analysis is performed using test data of the GWHD dataset. On evaluation, it is identified that model predict and controls wheat crop disease with 98.8% accuracy while compared to conventional deep learning architectures.

title: Additively Manufactured Alumina Substrates with Tailored Permittivity for mm-Wave Antennas
authors: Masoud Sakaki, Ehsan Farokhipour, Zhenming Tian, Kai Daniel Jenkel, Lars Leander Schaberg, Fabian Langer, Lorena-Doreen Woissa, Andreas Rennings, Daniel Erni, Niels Benson
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: A method for additive manufacturing of ceramic substrates with desired dimensions is proposed in which permittivity is tailored by varying the sintering temperature. Samples are used as dielectric substrates for a mm-wave bow-tie antenna. A wide tuning range, from 83 GHz to 93 GHz, in the operating frequency of the antenna can be achieved by simultaneously adjusting the substrate thickness and the permittivity, without changing the antenna structure itself.

title: Manual Segmentation of Human Lumbar Vertebrae from MRI: Challenges, Methods, and Applications
authors: Neethu Rose Thomas, Parkavi K
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Automation, Computing and Renewable Systems (ICACRS)
abstract: Accurate segmentation of human vertebrae from magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) plays a vital role in spinal disorder diagnosis, surgical planning, and enabling quantitative morphometric analysis. While automated methods have advanced considerably, their performance largely depends on the availability of high-quality ground truth data. Manual segmentation serves as the gold standard for generating reference datasets, offering precise boundary delineation of vertebral bodies and intervertebral discs. In this study, we focus on the creation of a ground truth dataset through detailed manual annotation of adult lumbar vertebrae (L1–L5) and intervertebral discs (T12/L1–L5/S1) using T2-weighted MRI scans. Segmentation was carried out in sagittal planes using the 3D Slicer platform, with cross-validation across axial, and coronal planes to ensure accuracy. A total of 48 cases were annotated, with an average of 3 hours per case. Intra-observer evaluation yielded a high Dice Similarity Coefficient (DSC ≈ 0.95), confirming excellent reproducibility of the manual protocol. The resultant dataset offers a clearly defined and validated ground truth, crucial for training and evaluating automated deep learning models for vertebral segmentation. The objective of this study is to document the process and challenges of manual annotation of lumbar vertebrae, emphasizing its critical role in generating high-quality ground truth data, which will serve as the foundation for developing an automated and clinically deployable spine segmentation framework.

title: ADOS: A Real-Time Edge Anomaly Filtering Framework for Reliable LoRa-based Smart Agriculture
authors: Anusha Chidimilla, Sathish Jelli, Kumar Dorthi, Ravi Kanth Kotha, Priyanka P, Sowjanya Reddy Y
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Automation, Computing and Renewable Systems (ICACRS)
abstract: Precision agriculture relies heavily on the integrity of real-time sensor data collected from diverse environmental parameters. However, traditional cloud-based anomaly filtering approaches often suffer from latency, inefficiency, and poor scalability. To address these limitations, this paper presents a framework based on Anomaly Detection and Outlier Screening (ADOS), which is deployed at the LoRaWAN gateway level. ADOS is combined threshold-based filtering model and statistical techniques such as Z-score and Interquartile Range (IQR), to detect both physical and contextual anomalies in sensor data. The framework was practically implemented in a smart greenhouse over a 7-day deployment. A total of 1000 sensor readings were processed, with 28 anomalies detected using rule-based validation and 16 anomalies identified using Z-score analysis. The system achieved a false positive rate of only 2%, real-time responsiveness with 100–120 ms latency, and 25% bandwidth savings compared to traditional systems. Integration with MQTT, ThingSpeak, and Blynk provided seamless visualization and mobile alerts, supporting timely and informed decision-making for precision irrigation and crop monitoring.

title: Learning-based Approach for Early Detection of Hardware Trojans in Open-Source Hardware
authors: Polepalli Bhargavi, Nukamreddy Sai Samhita, G Mahesh, Hirekurubara Narayana, Kothapu Ajay Kumar
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Automation, Computing and Renewable Systems (ICACRS)
abstract: The growing popularity of open-source hardware has unfortunately made it easier for untrustworthy actors to slip hardware Trojans into designs. While we have got some decent detection methods already, they often stumble when dealing with complex stuff like RISC-V processors and cryptographic accelerators. Introducing a new framework with mixed semantic code analysis and some intelligent embedding tricks. Instead of simply depending on text-frequency methods such as TF-IDF or Bag-of-Words, we analyze the structure in depth of Verilog code and using lightweight contextual embeddings to really get a feel for both the text and how the hardware's supposed to work. We even built a dataset of 3,900 examples, pulling from standard and injecting Trojans with the help of some refined LLM-guided mutation techniques. After pitting different classifiers and transformer models against each other, we found that our hybrid embedding approach, powered by Gradient Boosting, nailed a 98% accuracy rate. Plus, with some optimized LLM prompts, we reached recall at 99% which is too high, it reduces the number undetected Trojans attacks. This new method is all about being scalable, easy to understand, and rock-solid when it comes to keeping open-source hardware secure.

title: Consistency-Aware Spot-Guided Transformer for Accurate and Versatile Point Cloud Registration
authors: Renlang Huang, Li Chai, Yufan Tang, Zhoujian Li, Jiming Chen, Liang Li
publish: IEEE Transactions on Pattern Analysis and Machine Intelligence
abstract: Deep learning-based feature matching has showcased great superiority for point cloud registration. While coarse-to-fine matching architectures are prevalent, they typically perform sparse and geometrically inconsistent coarse matching. This forces the subsequent fine matching to rely on computationally expensive optimal transport and hypothesis-and-selection procedures to resolve inconsistencies, leading to inefficiency and poor scalability for large-scale real-time applications. In this paper, we design a consistency-aware spot-guided Transformer (CAST) to enhance the coarse matching by explicitly utilizing geometric consistency via two key sparse attention mechanisms. First, our consistency-aware self-attention selectively computes intra-point-cloud attention to a sparse subset of points with globally consistent correspondences, enabling other points to derive discriminative features through their relationships with these anchors while propagating global consistency for robust correspondence reasoning. Second, our spot-guided cross-attention restricts cross-point-cloud attention to dynamically defined “spots”—the union of correspondence neighborhoods of a query's neighbors in the other point cloud, which are most likely to cover the true correspondence of the query ensured by local consistency, eliminating interference from similar but irrelevant regions. Furthermore, we design a lightweight local attention-based fine matching module to precisely predict dense correspondences and estimate the transformation. Extensive experiments on both outdoor LiDAR datasets and indoor RGB-D camera datasets demonstrate that our method achieves state-of-the-art accuracy, efficiency, and robustness. Besides, our method showcases superior generalization ability on our newly constructed challenging relocalization and loop closing benchmarks in unseen domains. Our code and models are available at https://github.com/RenlangHuang/CASTv2.

title: A Ring-Oscillator-Based Digital Harmonic-Mixing Fractional- N PLL
authors: Hongyu Lu, Nader Fathy, Patrick P. Mercier
abstract: This paper presents a low-jitter digital harmonic-mixing fractional-N phase-locked loop (PLL) using a ring oscillator (RO). To extend the loop bandwidth, a mixer with unity gain in the phase domain is adopted, which helps suppress phase noise of the phase detector (PD) and delta-sigma modulator (DSM). Furthermore, to reduce mixing harmonics that would otherwise dominate the in-band jitter, the sinusoidal reference is buffered by a linear source follower, in contrast to the inverters used in other LC-oscillator-based harmonic-mixing PLLs. Implemented in 65 nm CMOS, the proposed PLL achieves 603.8 fs root-mean-square (RMS) jitter with a 100 MHz integration bandwidth. It occupies 0.12 mm2 of silicon area and consumes 12.72 mW of power.

title: Research on dynamic carbon emission prediction method of low-carbon park integrated energy system based on artificial intelligence algorith
authors: Hao Chen, Biao Qiao, Hua Zheng, Shukui Liang, Te Hu, Haijian Chen
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Big Data, Artificial Intelligence and Internet of Things Engineering (ICBAIE)
abstract: With the escalating challenges of global climate change, low-carbon park development has become a crucial pathway for sustainable growth. As the core component of low-carbon parks, integrated energy systems require dynamic carbon emission forecasting to optimize energy structures and reduce emissions. This study proposes an AI-driven method for real-time dynamic prediction of multi-load systems in low-carbon parks. By establishing precise predictive models, the approach enables accurate carbon emission tracking, providing scientific support for park planning, operations, and management. The methodology integrates annual hourly simulation models with dynamic carbon accounting techniques, incorporating an enhanced GRU network model optimized through particle swarm optimization algorithms. These innovations significantly improve both prediction accuracy and computational efficiency.

title: Multiobjective Joint Optimization for Trajectory and Controller Parameters to Enhance Hydraulic Legged Robot Jumping Performance
authors: Junhui Zhang, Jinyuan Liu, Lei Zhou, Lizhou Fang, Kun Zhang, Huaizhi Zong, Bing Xu
abstract: Vertical jumping performance of the limb leg unit (LLU) significantly impacts the movement of legged robots. In this article, a multiobjective joint optimization method for the trajectory generator and controller coupling parameters is proposed. This method constructs a quasi-realistic simulation model with physical feasibility constraints, ensuring an accurate representation of the physical prototype performance. Subsequently, the design variables and objectives are defined considering the inherent coupling relationships and complex evaluation metrics of the LLU. By leveraging data from the proposed model, the empirical objective functions are formulated in the form of a response surface model and used to analyze the influence of variables on different objectives. An improved genetic algorithm with weight selection is proposed to prioritize maximizing the jump height while satisfying the optimization objectives. Finally, the accuracy of the quasi-realistic model is validated by experiments and the results demonstrate an increase of 11.95% in jump height and a decrease of 6.60% in force ratio compared with the conventional method. The joint optimization method can serve as a valuable reference for parameter selection in other multivariable, multiobjective, and multiconstraint problems.

title: Design of Multi-Objective Scheduling Optimization Methods for RGV in Flexible Manufacturing Systems
authors: Jiaxin Lin, Bo Li, Minmin Liu, Chao Gao, Zhoujie Zhao
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Digital Society and Intelligent Systems (DSInS)
abstract: In flexible manufacturing systems (FMS), the scheduling efficiency of rail guided vehicle (RGV) directly impacts the operational efficiency and energy consumption of the entire production system. Addressing the challenge that traditional scheduling methods struggle to simultaneously minimize task completion time and optimize energy consumption, this paper constructs a mathematical model for multi-objective static scheduling. It proposes an Improved Dung Beetle Optimizer with Simulated Annealing (IDBO-SA) to solve this problem. Building upon the original Dung Beetle Algorithm, this approach incorporates a rolling path selection strategy guided by task urgency, a multi-operator local perturbation and diversity enhancement mechanism under dance behavior, and a simulated annealing acceptance policy based on the Metropolis criterion to enhance local search capability and convergence stability. Comparative experiments across multiple instances validate the algorithm's superior convergence performance.

title: MIMO Capacity Analysis and Channel Estimation for Electromagnetic Information Theory
authors: Jieao Zhu, Vincent Y. F. Tan, Linglong Dai
publish: IEEE Journal on Selected Areas in Communications
abstract: Electromagnetic information theory (EIT) is an interdisciplinary subject that serves to integrate deterministic electromagnetic theory with stochastic Shannon's information theory. Existing EIT analysis operates in the continuous space domain, which is not aligned with the practical algorithms working in the discrete space domain. This mismatch leads to a significant difficulty in application of EIT methodologies to practical discrete space systems, which is called as the discrete-continuous gap in this paper. To bridge this gap, we establish the discrete-continuous correspondence with a prolate spheroidal wave function (PSWF)-based ergodic capacity analysis framework. Specifically, we state and prove some discrete-continuous correspondence lemmas to establish a firm theoretical connection between discrete information-theoretic quantities to their continuous counterparts. With these lemmas, we apply the PSWF ergodic capacity bound to advanced MIMO architectures such as continuous-aperture MIMO (CAP-MIMO) and extremely large-scale MIMO (XL-MIMO). From this PSWF capacity bound, we discover the capacity saturation phenomenon both theoretically and empirically. Although the growth of MIMO performance is fundamentally limited in this EIT-based analysis framework, we reveal new opportunities in MIMO channel estimation by exploiting the EIT knowledge about the channel. Inspired by the PSWF capacity bound, we utilize continuous PSWFs to improve the pilot design of discrete MIMO channel estimators, which is called as the PSWF channel estimator (PSWF-CE). Simulation results demonstrate improved performance of the proposed PSWF-CE, compared to traditional minimum mean squared error (MMSE) and compressed sensing-based estimators.

title: Intelligent Approval Model Based on Heterogeneous Enhanced Integration and Deep Neural Network Fusion
authors: Jinsong Li, Wenling Che, Xiaoyue Liu, Guotai Zhu, Jinlei Liu, Wei Zhou, Dong Sun, Yong Wan, Bo Gao
publish: 2025 IEEE Cyber Science and Technology Congress (CyberSciTech)
abstract: Against the backdrop of the intelligent wave sweeping through all industries, constructing high-performance and generalized intelligent approval models has become a key challenge. Take the offshore oil operation field as an example. Currently, this field is faced with three major approval problems: cumbersome processes, incomplete documentation, and slow information exchange. To address these issues, this paper proposes a novel heterogeneous integration framework, HEI-DNN (Heterogeneous Ensemble Integration with Deep Neural Network). This framework innovatively integrates the ensemble capabilities of multiple tree-based paradigms and utilizes deep neural networks for feature fusion and nonlinear optimization, making it widely applicable to approval scenarios in various fields. Due to the lack of approval data in the oil industry, this paper conducts experiments using three real-world financial approval datasets instead. The results show that, compared with traditional machine learning and ensemble methods, HEI-DNN demonstrates more competitive performance in key indicators such as accuracy. These experiments indirectly verify the potential of this method for applications in other fields, laying a theoretical and methodological foundation for future application explorations in the oil industry and beyond.

title: A 150-GHz Upconversion Mixer of 17.9-dB High Conversion Gain
authors: Fu-Qun Huang, Yu-Shun Chen, Chien-Nan Kuo
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: This work presents a 150 GHz upconversion mixer designed in 40-nm CMOS technology. The transconductor applies resistive-feedback inverters for high conversion gain. The capacitive neutralization technique is employed to enhance the driving capability of the RF and LO buffer amplifiers. The core die size is only 0.159 mm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>. The measured data show a high conversion gain of 17.9 dB, output power of 4.3 dBm at 1-dB gain compression point, and saturated output power of 8.3 dBm, under dc power consumption of 63 mW.

title: Design of a Wideband Low-fluctuation 340 GHz TWT Slow-wave Circuit
authors: Yuan Feng, Lin Zhang, Pan Pan, Jinjun Feng, Yubin Gong
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: This paper presents a wideband low-fluctuation 340 GHz traveling-wave tube (TWT) slow-wave circuit design. The proposed integrated with a partial phase velocity jumping to minimize power and gain fluctuations. The simulation results show that within the operational frequency band of 330 ~ 355 GHz, the saturated output power, saturated gain and small signal gain exceed 5.8 W, 29.6 dB and 33 dB, respectively. The corresponding in-band fluctuations of saturated power, saturated gain and small signal gain are 0.5 dB, 4.4 dB and 4 dB, respectively.

title: Color contour polygon recognition based on FPGA
authors: Zhihao Liu, Yaxin Wang, Panyu Chen, Fangjuan Wang, Guidi Li
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Automation, Electronics and Electrical Engineering (AUTEEE)
abstract: In this paper, a real-time color contour polygon recognition system based on FPGA is designed. The system collects images through the camera, performs YCbCr color space threshold segmentation, morphological filtering and improved eight-direction Sobel edge detection in FPGA, and finally realizes the positioning and classification of multiple polygon targets. Experiments show that the recognition accuracy of the system reaches 90%, and the improved edge detection algorithm reduces the resource consumption by 13% compared with the traditional algorithm, which provides an efficient hardware solution for industrial vision applications.

title: YOLOv8-SL: An Enhanced Student Behavior Detection Model with Swin Transformer and LDConv
authors: Gan Huang, Yan Mei Jiao, Bo Wu, Ryohei Sasaki
publish: 2025 IEEE Cyber Science and Technology Congress (CyberSciTech)
abstract: In recent years, deep learning-based computer vision technology has developed rapidly. The use of computer vision for abnormal behavior detection has become a research focus and has been widely applied in various fields. Using computer vision to recognize student behaviors in the classroom can reduce the teacher’s workload in monitoring students during lectures. At the same time, students’ classroom performance is closely related to their exam results and can also reflect the teaching condition of the instructor. However, existing student behavior detection systems do not yet achieve high enough accuracy in behavior recognition, which cannot meet the current demand for precise detection of classroom behaviors. To solve this problem, this paper proposes an improved model, YOLOv8-SL, based on the YOLOv8 algorithm to recognize and detect student behaviors in the classroom. Here, "SL" stands for Swin Transformer and LDConv (Linear Deformable Convolution), which represent the two major improvements incorporated into the baseline model. First, the input images are preprocessed and then fed into the model. In the backbone, the Swin Transformer is introduced to enhance global feature modeling and capture long-range dependencies, while preserving local detail extraction. Meanwhile, LDConv is used to improve the network’s adaptability to different student postures. In addition, a small-object detection head is added to enhance the model’s ability to detect small targets. Finally, a multi-scale feature fusion module is used for classification and regression. Through experiments, the improved model shows better detection performance than the original YOLOv8 on the public dataset SCB-Dataset3. Compared with the original YOLOv8, the proposed model achieved an improvement of 6.8% in mAP@0.5 and 6.6% in mAP@0.5:0.95.

title: Cognitive Decline Trajectories in Dementia Patients Using Monte Carlo Simulation and Parallel Computing
authors: Lavigne Kaye S. Sistona, Orven E. Llantos
publish: 2025 IEEE Cyber Science and Technology Congress (CyberSciTech)
abstract: Among the elderly, Dementia is a crawling illness that is difficult to avoid and it remains a progressive fog gradually blurring cognitive function and memory. As defined by the World Health Organization (WHO), it is a term for several diseases that affects an individuals memory, thinking, and the ability to perform daily activity, this illness leads to significant physical, psychological and social impacts. With no known cure as of the present, the cognitive decline in dementia is irreversible once it starts. However, certain interventions may help in slowing its progression. This study fills a gap in the limited research on methods that shows dementia trajectories in individuals. Current models do not account well for how genetics, lifestyle, and health factors shape each person’s decline. Since the cognitive scores vary based on the multiple factors, the goal of this paper is to show the trajectory of cognitive decline in the dementia patients over time. By integrating Monte Carlo simulation with parallel computing, this study models the probabilistic trajectories of fluctuations in cognitive score under various outcomes with or without interventions. The paper also aligns with the Sustainable Development Goal (SDG) 3 which scopes the good health and well being.

title: Fault Detection in FBG Flexible Sensing Networks Driven by Graph Neural Networks (GNN)
authors: Tingting Zhan, Haoyu Wang, Jinwei Li
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Automation, Electronics and Electrical Engineering (AUTEEE)
abstract: The development of modern industrial intelligence has driven the widespread application of fiber Bragg grating (FBG) flexible sensing networks in fields such as equipment health monitoring and structural safety assessment. However, their complex topology and multi-dimensional monitoring data make it difficult for traditional fault detection methods to effectively mine topological correlations in the data, resulting in limited detection accuracy and robustness. Graph neural networks (GNNs), however, excel at processing graph-structured data and demonstrate excellent feature learning capabilities in fault diagnosis, offering potential for addressing this issue. This study aims to construct a GNN-driven framework for efficient and accurate fault detection in FBG flexible sensing networks, overcoming the application bottlenecks of traditional methods. Methodologically, FBG sensor nodes are first mapped to graph nodes, and the graph structure is constructed by combining the sensor physical connections and signal correlations. After preprocessing the FBG spectral signals with denoising and normalization, a GNN is used to extract node local-global features layer by layer and perform fault classification. A 12-node FBG experimental system is used to simulate typical faults such as sensor failure, signal drift, and noise interference, and the detection performance of traditional threshold methods and support vector machine (SVM) methods is compared. Experimental results show that the proposed GNN method achieves a fault detection rate of 96.2%, a false alarm rate as low as 2.1%, and an F1 score of 0.942, significantly outperforming traditional threshold methods and SVMs. Its average detection time of 45.2ms meets real-time monitoring requirements while also offering excellent fault tolerance. This research provides a new technical path for reliability assurance and intelligent maintenance of FBG flexible sensor networks and offers a valuable solution for fault detection in sensor networks with complex topologies.

title: Strain-based Shape and 3D Force Estimation for Rod-driven Continuum Robots with Stretch Sensors
authors: Peiyi Wang, Daniel Feliu-Talegon, Yuchen Sun, Zhexin Xie, Wenci Xin, Muhammad Sunny Nazeer, Cosimo Della Santina, Cecilia Laschi, Federico Renda
abstract: Soft robots' ability to safely navigate complex environments motivates the development of algorithms for accurate environmental interaction assessment, enabling greater autonomy. Specifically, strain-based shape and force estimation of continuum robots with embedded soft sensors poses an open challenge mainly owing to continuous softness, anisotropic deformation, and non-linear properties. Mathematical description of deformable soft bodies and accurate estimation of external forces are crucial for achieving controllable and intelligent behaviors of these robots. In this paper, a kinetostatic strain-based modeling for rod-driven soft robots (RDSR) with embedded stretch sensors is proposed, which incorporates local strains, actuation variables, and external interactions. The strain model enables full shape estimation of the robot and prediction of strain variations in soft bodies. Building on this, we develop a force estimator based on predicted and measured sensor and actuator lengths to evaluate 3D external forces, accounting for both orthogonal and tangential components relative to the backbone. Moreover, we introduce a methodology using a novel ellipsoid representation to handle tangential forces that may become insensitive in certain singular configurations. This estimator allows us to either disregard such forces when they do not influence deformation or estimate them when they become observable. Our simulations and experiments demonstrate how this approach can be used to analyze the robot's configuration and successfully estimate external forces. Finally, it is demonstrated that when the continuum arm follows trajectories with higher strain sensitivity, tangential force estimation is significantly improved.

title: WPM-GAN: Watermark-Preserving Module for GAN-Based Robust Industrial Image Watermarking
authors: Xiangyu Wang, Yingchao Yang, Ruilin Wang, Lingchen Gu, Wenbo Wan
publish: 2025 IEEE 31th International Conference on Parallel and Distributed Systems (ICPADS)
abstract: In this paper, a robust watermarking framework is proposed for ensuring copyright and authenticity of industrial imagery. Leveraging Squeeze-and-Excitation (SE) blockbased encoder-decoder network, our method embeds and extracts watermarks in a more efficient and imperceptible manner, and our method introduces a novel Watermark-Preserving Module (WPM) at the receiving end, which maximizes the preservation of watermark features in noise-corrupted images to assist the decoder in watermark extraction. And we adopt a dualstage training strategy to capture and learn specific watermark features, along with a decoder-based watermark-preserving loss to further enhance robustness. Experimental results demonstrate that WPM-GAN achieves superior visual quality while effectively resisting various attacks.

title: E2-BKI: Evidential Ellipsoidal Bayesian Kernel Inference for Uncertainty-Aware Gaussian Semantic Mapping
authors: Junyoung Kim, Minsik Jeon, Jihong Min, Kiho Kwak, Junwon Seo
abstract: Semantic mapping aims to construct a 3D semantic representation of the environment, providing essential knowledge for robots operating in complex outdoor settings. While Bayesian Kernel Inference (BKI) addresses discontinuities of map inference from sparse sensor data, existing semantic mapping methods suffer from various sources of uncertainties in challenging outdoor environments. To address these issues, we propose an uncertainty-aware semantic mapping framework that handles multiple sources of uncertainties, which significantly degrade mapping performance. Our method estimates uncertainties in semantic predictions using Evidential Deep Learning and incorporates them into BKI for robust semantic inference. It further aggregates noisy observations into coherent Gaussian representations to mitigate the impact of unreliable points, while employing geometry-aligned kernels that adapt to complex scene structures. These Gaussian primitives effectively fuse local geometric and semantic information, enabling robust, uncertainty-aware mapping in complex outdoor scenarios. Comprehensive evaluation across diverse off-road and urban outdoor environments demonstrates consistent improvements in mapping quality, uncertainty calibration, representational flexibility, and robustness, while maintaining real-time efficiency.

title: A Self-Supervised Heterogeneous Graph Learning Framework for Customer Value Prediction
authors: Junjie Lin, Kaiwen Xia, Xinrui Zhang, Li Lin, Shuai Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE 31th International Conference on Parallel and Distributed Systems (ICPADS)
abstract: The rapid development of e-commerce systems has led to the accumulation of substantial customer data. Effectively utilizing this data for marketing and customer management is crucial for enterprises. Customer value prediction, a key task, aims to predict the revenue value of customers for the platform. Although various customer value prediction models have been proposed in existing studies, challenges remain in dealing with the complexity of heterogeneous interaction data and quantifying customer value. This is particularly because the process of data collection and obtaining customer value labels heavily relies on extensive manual annotation. To address these challenges, we propose SPHGraph, a self-supervised pre-training framework tailored for heterogeneous graphs, driven by pseudo labels automatically extracted from the data. SPHGraph integrates three core components: a pseudo label initialization module to provide structure-aware supervision, a representation learning module to capture semantic and structural information from heterogeneous interactions, and a label refinement module that iteratively improves learning signals through attention-guided propagation. This design allows the model to learn robust and transferable representations under label-scarce conditions. Extensive experiments across three real-world datasets consistently demonstrate the superior performance of SPHGraph compared to state-of-the-art baselines.

title: Research on improved single-neuron adaptive PID control algorithm in plasma discharge system
authors: Li Hao, Lei Fan, Zhou Hui, Liu Zhiwei
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: The large-area closed-loop RF discharge plasma system features multiple variables, significant lag, non-linearity, and strong coupling among its control loops. Based on the Hebb algorithm, fuzzy control rules have been incorporated, proposing an improved single-neuron adaptive control strategy. By constructing models and simulations of the aforementioned algorithms in Simulink, real-time control of the discharge chamber is maintained in the presence of external disturbances, theoretically providing support for plasma discharge chambers.

title: FCSA: A Multi-Domain Enhancement Method for Improving Adversarial Transferability
authors: Shengyu Xiong, Anjie Peng, Hui Zeng, Qiang Wan, Shujian Liao, Fudie Ai, Yong Peng, Wanli Dong
publish: 2025 IEEE 31th International Conference on Parallel and Distributed Systems (ICPADS)
abstract: Transfer-based adversarial attacks craft perturbations on a surrogate and transfer them to black-box models, yet most prior methods diversify perturbations in only one domain, spatial or frequency, which limits overall transferability. We introduce Frequency-Channel-Structure Augmentation, FCSA, a multi-domain attack that jointly enriches perturbations in the frequency, color-channel, and spatial-structure spaces. FCSA couples lightweight frequency masking with Channel Fusion, a stochastic linear mixing across RGB channels, and MultiPattern Structured Perturbation that injects multi-orientation and multi-scale texture fields. The branch gradients are fused with data-dependent nonnegative weights normalized to sum to one, yielding a single update direction and reducing inter-branch conflict. By expanding surrogate diversity across complementary domains, FCSA produces adversarial examples with stronger black-box transfer. Extensive experiments demonstrate that our method achieves strong transferability on both standard and defended models. The method can be combined with a wide range of existing techniques to further improve the transferability of adversarial examples. Our code is available at https://github.com/zhangyuguai/FCSA-Attack.

title: Classifying Host-Side RDMA Pingmesh Results to Efficiently Identify Transport Faults in Data Centers
authors: Songhao Ding, Boyang Zhou, Yuhua Zheng
publish: 2025 IEEE 31th International Conference on Parallel and Distributed Systems (ICPADS)
abstract: To diagnose the transport-layer fault in RDMA for ensuring the reliability of data center networks (DCN), the existing RDMA pingmesh (R-Pingmesh) technology often requires manual analysis to identify the root causes of faults. However, the fault identification faces challenges in few-shot training for rare faults and prominent fault-normal data imbalance. To address the challenges, this paper proposes an LSTMbased fault classifier: The model pre-training phase captures general fault patterns to alleviate the difficulty of few-shot training for rare faults. To deploy the model in the target DCN, it uses supervised fine-tuning (SFT) with the data obtained from the network to adapt to the different network topological characteristics. Through such training, this classifier enables finegrained RDMA transport-layer fault diagnosis across multiple network topologies, achieving accurate classification of various fault types and fine-grained localization from “abnormal paths” to “fault segments”. This collaborative design of pre-training and topology adaptation achieves key challenges of few-shot learning under data distribution imbalance for accurate distinction and localization of RDMA transport-layer faults. Our experiments show that this method performs excellently on datasets from different typical DCN, providing an effective technical solution for the automated diagnosis of RDMA transport-layer faults.

title: AS-Mamba: Multimodal Semantic Segmentation via Mamba with Asymmetric Cross and Spatial Perception
authors: Guohao Shen, Hongzhao Li, Hao Yang, Xianglong Shen, Jingya Dong, Shupan Li
publish: 2025 IEEE 31th International Conference on Parallel and Distributed Systems (ICPADS)
abstract: Multimodal semantic segmentation integrates information from multiple data sources to perform pixel-wise semantic classification of images. By fusing complementary information from modalities such as thermal infrared and depth with traditional RGB, robust and reliable predictions can be achieved. However, existing methods still face challenges such as insufficient utilization of cross-modal information, limitations imposed by local receptive fields, and cross-category semantic confusion. To address these issues, this paper proposes the AS-Mamba framework, which introduces a Mamba structure with linear complexity into the field of image segmentation. Firstly, an Asymmetric Cross Mamba module is constructed to dynamically integrate complementary information from RGB and X modalities through an attention weight allocation strategy and enhanced cross-modal semantic alignment, enabling crossmodal dynamic interaction and global feature fusion. Secondly, a Spatial Perception Mamba module is designed to enhance fine-grained feature representation through a spatial-channel attention mechanism. Experiments on RGB-Thermal and RGBDepth tasks demonstrate the superiority of AS-Mamba.

title: Optimal Energy Management of a Fast Charging Service Station with Physics-Informed Neural Networks
authors: Francesco Liberati, Emanuele De Santis, Mohab M. H. Atanasious, Alessandro Di Giorgio
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: In this paper, we investigate the use of Physics-Informed Neural Networks (PINNs) for the solution of an optimal control problem related with the optimal control of a stationary electric storage system (ESS) installed in a service station for plug-in electric vehicles (PEVs). The ESS is used to balance the PEVs charging power, in order to mitigate the impact on the grid, and keep low the power flow at the point of connection with the grid. The proposed PINN is trained in order to learn the optimality conditions of the optimal control problem so that, after training, it can provide the solution with no significant computation effort. This one represents a promising alternative to the analytical computation of the optimal control (which is possible only in very simple settings), and to the solution of the optimal control problem with numerical methods, which requires significant time in the more complex and realistic settings. Numerical simulations are presented to evaluate the effectiveness of the trained PINN in solving the optimal control problem.

title: Single and Poly-crystalline diamond TLS losses study via superconducting LC micro-resonators
authors: Francesco Mazzocchi, Martin Neidig, Sebastian Kempf, Dirk Strauß, Theo Scherer, Hideaki Yamada
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: Research on diamond has grown rapidly due to its exceptional properties, making it crucial in fields such as quantum technologies and high-power applications like Electron Cyclotron Resonance Heating (ECRH) in nuclear fusion. Accurate measurement of the dielectric loss (tanδ) in diamond is essential, especially for developing ultra-low-loss single-crystal diamond windows for fusion applications. Conventional Fabry-Perot resonators have limited resolution, while superconducting thin-film micro-strip resonators, with Q factors exceeding 10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">6</sup>, offer improved sensitivity. We report on loss measurements on single- and polycrystalline diamond samples grown using PECVD, cloning, and HPHT techniques. The results are analyzed using the Two-Level System (TLS) model to assess dielectric losses and material characteristics.

title: 1.2-Gbit/s Data-Rate Free-Space Optical Communications with Terahertz Laser
authors: Jayaprasath Elumalai, Mohammed Salih, Martyn Fice, Adam Brown, Lianhe Li, Edmund H. Linfield, Alexander Valavanis, Alwyn J. Seeds, A. Giles Davies, Joshua R. Freeman
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: Terahertz quantum cascade lasers offer promising capabilities for free-space optical communication, bridging the gap between microwave electronics and optical fiber technologies. We report the first experimental demonstration of free-space optical communication at terahertz frequencies, utilizing a quantum cascade laser transmitter and a room temperature Schottky barrier diode receiver at 1.2 Gbit/s data rate. We achieve reliable data transmission over a 0.5m free-space distance, with bit error rates dropping below the hard-decision forward error correction threshold (3.8×10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">−3</sup>) as the received optical power increases. This gigabit-scale communication link highlights the potential of THz photonic devices for high-speed, short-range wireless communications in 6G and beyond.

title: Remote sensing-driven analysis of hourly urban heat storage and its effects on air temperature in China_supp1-3653410.docx
authors: Nana Li
abstract: Urban heat storage (Q<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">s</sub>) is a critical contributor to the urban heat island (UHI) effect, yet its spatiotemporal patterns and quantitative contribution remain poorly understood. Urban surface thermal properties directly influence Q<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">s</sub>, but accurately quantifying these properties at a regional scale remains a challenge. This study retrieves urban thermal inertia (TI) and hourly Qs based on heat conduction theory, using 24-hour cycles of Himawari-8 land surface temperature (LST), in three urban agglomerations of China. The quantitative impact of Q<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">s</sub> on near-surface air temperature (T<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">a</sub>) is also investigated at both city and local climate zones (LCZs) scales. With validation of Q<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">s</sub> against flux tower data, the correlation coefficient can be up to 0.92 and RMSE is 39 W/m<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>. Results show that there is a significantly stronger correlation of Q<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">s</sub> with T<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">a</sub> during nighttime (R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>>0.95) than daytime, confirming its dominant control in nocturnal UHI. To be specific, across local climate zones (LCZ), high-rise and open-built areas exhibited greater nocturnal Q<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">s</sub> (and correspondingly higher T<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">a</sub>) compared to compact mid-low-rise neighborhoods. Notably, water bodies remain higher Q<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">s</sub> (higher T<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">a</sub>) than vegetated surfaces. Entropy-based thermodynamic assessment suggests high-rise buildings exhibit higher but faster UHI change than low-rise. For future urban planning, we recommend prioritizing the heat mitigation of high-rise buildings and strategically planning blue space to balance its daytime cooling against nocturnal warming effects.

title: Comparative Performance Analysis of Deep Learning and Traditional Algorithms for Facial Recognition and Image Classification
authors: Ajay Jangir, Anushka Agrawal, Chanchal Sharma, Gaurav Kumar Soni, Reema Ajmera, Anantika Johari
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Automation, Computing and Renewable Systems (ICACRS)
abstract: Facial and object recognition are mostly applied in our life. That’s why this field has become important to both academicians and practitioners. Face recognition systems are complex systems by following features of face to recognize. Let’s see a performance analysis of four algorithms ResNet, Haar Cascade, RNN and CNN which is used for facial recognition and image classification. These algorithms are used to evaluate their accuracy and performance in identifying human faces under varying conditions of lighting, pose and expressions. Out of the tested models, the ResNet achieved the highest accuracy of 96.8%, this indicates that ResNet have the superior feature extraction and generalization capabilities. the accuracy of CNN model is 94.3%, while RNN and Haar Cascade achieved 91.2 % and 87.5% respectively.

title: Fabry-Pérot Open Resonator in Measurements of Complex Permittivity of Thin Dielectric Samples in the 500-600 GHz Range
authors: P. Kopyt, J. Cuper, B. Salski, P. Zagrajek
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: A novel FPOR excited with a free-space beam has been designed and manufactured. The set-up has been then employed to measure in the frequency range of 500-600 GHz the complex permittivity of a 100-micrometer-thick sample of COP (exemplary low-loss dielectric that often comes in form of a thin sheet). The results have been compared with data obtained using a time-domain spectrometer (THz-TDS) supported by the state-of-the-art processing software. The comparison suggest that FPOR-based approach can offer a similar spectral resolution to THz-TDS, while significantly reducing the measurement uncertainty, especially in case of the dielectric loss data.

title: Boosting Zero-Shot Learning using A Combination of EfficientNet and Deep Visual-Semantic Embeddings
authors: Shreyas Changder, Dakshina Ranjan Kisku
publish: 2025 5th IEEE International Conference on Applied Electromagnetics, Signal Processing, &amp; Communication (AESPC)
abstract: This paper reports an enhanced approach to ZeroShot Learning (ZSL) by optimizing the Deep Visual- Semantic Embedding (DeViSE) model with an efficient visual backbone. ZSL enables image classification for unseen categories by mapping visual features and semantic information into a shared embedding space. The proposed work has replaced the conventional ResNet backbone in the DeViSE model with EfficientNetB0, which employs compound scaling and mobile inverted bottleneck convolutions to achieve a superior balance of accuracy and efficiency. As part of the integrated framework, the pre-trained 300 -dimensional GloVe embeddings is utilized to define the semantic space, enabling knowledge transfer between seen and unseen classes. The proposed model is evaluated on two benchmark datasets: Animals with Attributes 2 (AWA2) and Caltech-UCSD Birds- 200-2011 (CUB). Through selective finetuning, data augmentation, and hinge-based ranking loss, the proposed model achieves Top-1 accuracies of 65.5% on AWA2 and 59.7% on CUB-substantially outperforming traditional embedding-based methods. This represents an improvement of approximately 6.0 percentage points (p.p.) on AWA2 and 4.0 p.p. on CUB compared to traditional embedding-based methods using ResNet or VGG backbones. Additionally, the analysis reveals strong performance in coarse-grained classification and competitive results in fine-grained task.

title: Research on Replenishment Strategy Based on Time Series Machine Learning Prediction and Big Data Analysis
authors: Enqi He
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Machine Learning, Big Data and Business Intelligence (MLBDBI)
abstract: This article is based on big data of vegetable sales, using time series machine learning algorithms and optimized mathematical models to study the optimal supply strategy. Firstly, based on big data analysis and the time series prediction machine learning algorithm, the wholesale price and sales volume of each vegetable from August 20 to September 20, 2024 were used to predict the wholesale price and sales volume of each vegetable on September 21. Then, constrained by multiple real-world conditions and with the replenishment quantity and pricing as decision variables, a 0-1 optimization model was established to solve for the purchase quantity and pricing strategy of each product when the supermarket's revenue was maximized on September 21st, ensuring the quality of fresh supermarket vegetables and achieving the maximization of fresh supermarket revenue.

title: Neural Network Model Design and Mapping Optimization for Integrated Memory and Computing Architectures
authors: Jianmin Liu, Qian Sun
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Automation, Electronics and Electrical Engineering (AUTEEE)
