abstract: While integrated memory and computing (IMC) architectures can overcome the storage-computing bottlenecks of traditional architectures, existing mapping algorithms suffer from fixed block partitioning, neglect of load balancing, and difficulty balancing energy efficiency and accuracy. To address this issue, this paper designs a "computing power-matched" neural network model and a dynamic block sparse mapping (DBSM) algorithm. This model adapts to IMC characteristics through lightweight network layers, dynamic precision switching, and mixed-bit width quantization. The DBSM algorithm integrates dynamic block partitioning, sparse-aware mapping, and load balancing to achieve deep parameter adaptation to the architecture. An IMC simulation platform built on an FPGA was tested on ResNet-50 and YOLOv5s models, and on the ImageNet-1K and COCO 2017 datasets. The results showed that DBSM reduced inference latency by 17.9%-40.0% compared to traditional layer-by-layer mapping (LM), static block mapping (SBM), and sparse priority mapping (SPM), while increasing throughput by 15.7%-67.9%. Its energy efficiency reached 38.5 GOPS/W (ResNet-50) and 29.8 GOPS/W (YOLOv5s). Its Top-1 accuracy (76.2%) and mean average prediction accuracy (mAP) (56.8%) were less than 0.2% lower than those of the competing algorithms, achieving both performance and energy efficiency improvements while maintaining accuracy.

title: Data–Driven Image Resolution and Uplink Power Control for Mobile Augmented Reality Applications
authors: Andrea Wrona, Danilo Menegatti, Emanuele De Santis, Andrea Tortorelli
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: In the context of Mobile Augmented Reality, satisfying the challenging users’ requirements about Quality of Service and Quality of Experience is not an easy task due to the limited computing capabilities of mobile devices, and the rapid, free movement of users within the environment. To deal with these issues, graphical computations are typically offloaded from mobile devices to edge servers. While traditional offloading strategies rely on static optimization or heuristics, this work proposes a multi–input data–driven dynamic control of uplink power and image compression rate, introducing a Policy Broadcasting Deep Reinforcement Learning approach, based on the Deep Deterministic Policy Gradient algorithm. The proposed solution is aimed at matching the challenging Quality of Service constraints, in terms of maximum round–trip latency and minimum resolution accuracy, while minimizing the energy consumption. Simulations show the effectiveness and scalability of the proposed approach for real–time applications.

title: A Framework for Designing Serious Games with Extended Reality to Enhance Learning
authors: Besma Ben Amara, Hédia Mhiri Sellami, Lamjed Ben Said
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: This paper introduces a comprehensive framework for designing Serious Games (SG) that integrate eXtended Reality (XR)-including virtual, mixed, and augmented reality systems, to create immersive and interactive learning experiences. Key features include a model to define game mechanics and learning content, a specification approach to ensure effective XR integration, alignment with educational goals, and iterative evaluation by designers, educators, and students to ensure continuous improvement. Our design approach empowers educators to define the purpose, mechanics, and XR features of the game while keeping them closely aligned with the pedagogical objectives. The proposed framework provides a step-by-step guide for participants in SG with XR (XR-SG) design, covering all stages from preparation to testing. This work contributes to the workshop’s mission by advancing the use of XR applications in education and fostering multidisciplinary collaboration for the creation of impactful, immersive learning solutions.

title: Graph Embedding with First-Order Connectivity for Enhanced Heterogeneous Arithmetic Resource Scheduling Model
authors: Zisu Yuan, Xiaochao Li, Qianmu Li
publish: 2025 IEEE Cyber Science and Technology Congress (CyberSciTech)
abstract: The research on heterogeneous arithmetic scheduling faces two primary challenges: the fragmentation of behavioral and attribute semantics within knowledge graphs, and the absence of a systematic evaluation framework for graph embedding algorithms and the fitness of these algorithms for scheduling tasks. Current models demonstrate inadequacies in effectively integrating temporal information, and end-to-end architectures struggle to align knowledge representation with scheduling objectives. This study introduces the EHCRSM model, designed to enhance heterogeneous arithmetic resource scheduling through first-order connected graph embedding. The model seeks to unify heterogeneous semantics via a dual-stream architecture that incorporates knowledge and attention mechanisms, assess the influence of six distinct graph embedding algorithms, and facilitate personalized resource allocation by integrating the HC3 concept. Our findings indicate that while TransD embedding yields optimal results on the MovieLens dataset, DistMult scheduling demonstrates superior performance, suggesting a non-positive correlation between the two. The EHCRSM model approaches state-of-the-art performance on the MovieLens dataset and enhances personalized responses through adaptive positional encoding. This model establishes a novel paradigm for multi-semantic collaboration, and the fusion mechanism inherent in its architecture, along with the HC3 concept, is applicable across various domains, including intelligent computing and cloud computing.

title: Retrieval Augmented Generation-Enhanced Distributed LLM Agents for Generalizable Traffic Signal Control with Emergency Vehicles
authors: Xinhang Li, Qing Guo, Junyu Chen, Zheng Guo, Shengzhe Xu, Lei Li, Lin Zhang
publish: 2025 IEEE 31th International Conference on Parallel and Distributed Systems (ICPADS)
abstract: With increasing urban traffic complexity, Traffic Signal Control (TSC) is essential for optimizing traffic flow and improving road safety. Large Language Models (LLMs) emerge as promising approaches for TSC. However, they are prone to hallucinations in emergencies, leading to unreliable decisions that may cause substantial delays for emergency vehicles. Moreover, diverse intersection types present substantial challenges for traffic state encoding and cross-intersection training, limiting generalization across heterogeneous intersections. Therefore, this paper proposes Retrieval Augmented Generation (RAG)-enhanced distributed LLM agents with Emergency response for Generalizable TSC (REG-TSC). Firstly, this paper presents an emergencyaware reasoning framework, which dynamically adjusts reasoning depth based on the emergency scenario and is equipped with a novel Reviewer-based Emergency RAG (RERAG) to distill specific knowledge and guidance from historical cases, enhancing the reliability and rationality of agents' emergency decisions. Secondly, this paper designs a type-agnostic traffic representation and proposes a Reward-guided Reinforced Refinement (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{R}^{3}$</tex>) for heterogeneous intersections. <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{R}^{3}$</tex> adaptively samples training experience from diverse intersections with environment feedbackbased priority and fine-tunes LLM agents with a designed reward-weighted likelihood loss, guiding REG-TSC toward highreward policies across heterogeneous intersections. On three realworld road networks with 17 to 177 heterogeneous intersections, extensive experiments show that REG-TSC reduces travel time by 42.00%, queue length by 62.31%, and emergency vehicle waiting time by 83.16%, outperforming other state-of-the-art methods.

title: XAI-based Customer Behavior Analysis for Network Intrusion Detection in Edge Intelligence
authors: Xiaotong Wu, Chenxi Liu, Wenmin Lin
publish: 2025 IEEE Cyber Science and Technology Congress (CyberSciTech)
abstract: When the fifth-generation network is being widely deployed, sixth-generation (6G) network has attracted attention from practitioners in academia and industry. Most of researchers argue that cloud computing and artificial intelligence are the essential components in 6G and offer the better network automation and stronger communication security. In this paper, we propose a federated learning-empowered 6G network architecture and utilize its intelligence to propose an XAI-based pre-trained data interpretation model for network intrusion detection. At first, we design an architecture of 6G network that utilizes the computation capability of edge cloud and the intelligence of federated learning to enhance communication efficiency and data privacy of the future network paradigm. Then, we propose an efficient data interpretation model based on XAI that evaluates the importance level of datasets from data clients relative to the global model for network intrusion detection in 6G network. We apply the explanation result of the importance level of data clients and adjust the procedure of federated learning to further improve the prediction accuracy and the convergence speed of the global model for network intrusion detection. The results of extensive experiments show that the proposed pre-trained data interpretation model indeed improves the performance of network intrusion detection.

title: Research on 0.14 THz Dual-cavity Gap-coupled Structure Extended Interaction Oscillator
authors: Ruizhe Ren, Biao Xu, Lin Xu, Zongjun Shi, Xiaoxing Chen, Zhenhua Wu
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: This study proposes a novel dual-cavity gap-coupled Extended Interaction Oscillator (EIO) that achieves power synthesis through coupled electron beams. Simulation results demonstrate that under 12.6 kV operating voltage, 200 A/cm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> current density, and 0.5 T longitudinal magnetic field, the device delivers 653.72 W output power at 0.142 THz, showing significant enhancement compared to single-cavity structures. This design provides a new approach for developing high-power terahertz radiation sources.

title: Hybrid Feature-Driven Machine Learning Model for Cervical Cancer Risk Assessment using Clinical and Behavioural Factor
authors: S. Saradha, Bhavana Jamalpur, Bediga Sharan, Navjot Kaur, Harmeet Singh, B. Jegajothi
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Automation, Computing and Renewable Systems (ICACRS)
abstract: Cervical cancer is one of the major causes of mortality in the world among women especially in those countries in which early screening and diagnostic methods are not readily available. This paper suggests a hybrid machine learning architecture, called XGB-AEStackNet, to perform low-error and explainable cervical cancer risk estimation via assessments of clinical history and behavioral characteristics. This model also adds a dual-domain autoencoder to encode the clinical and the behaviors features into domains separately into latent representations and later recombined and re-weighted by a SHAP (SHapley Additive Explanations) into ranks in order to give more weight to informative attributes. The stacked ensemble is made of XGBoost, LightGBM, and meta-learner logistic regression to classify these transformed features. The model was tested using the UCI Cervical Cancer (Risk Factors) Dataset that contained 36 attributes across 858 patient records. With a test accuracy of 92.2 percent, F1-score of 91.4 percent and an AUC score of 94.8 percent, the proposed model showed an improved performance in comparison to baseline models such as CNN, Random Forest and SVM. Moreover, the model recorded a shorter time of inference per sample (1.6 ms) and scores higher in explainability (0.93) in both cases thus showing its translational potential to real-world application in addition to ease of interpretation. SHAP analysis indicated principal characteristics that model decisions were based on to include age, HPV diagnosis, and history of smoking. The study presents a clinically useful, interpretable AI system of cervical cancer screening in its initial stages. Use of feature extraction, interpretability, and decision by ensemble classification area allows both accuracy and clarity, which qualifies the system to be used in public health interventions and telemedicine programs.

title: Robust Container Scheduling Based on Resource Prediction and User Request Characteristics
authors: Mingdong He, Zhaoyi Yang, Lei Xu, Hao Wei, Bo Li, Xiaobo Huang, Hongyu Liao, Liquan Luo
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Automation, Electronics and Electrical Engineering (AUTEEE)
abstract: Nowadays, enterprises demand to deploy rapidly increasing information and/or computation systems with high complexity and diversity, making traditional monolithic architectures hard to apply. Microservice architecture, with its modularity and loose coupling, has emerged as a viable solution. However, the intricate interactions between microservices expose the limitations of existing resource scheduling strategies. This paper proposes a novel resource scheduling approach for microservice container clusters based on resource prediction and user request characteristics. We first build a Kubernetes (K8s)-based Power grid service system and collect datasets through simulation. A Graph Neural Network (GNN)-based time series prediction model, G-TimesNet, is then designed to improve resource prediction accuracy. Then, an intelligent scaling and load balancing strategy is introduced, leveraging both the prediction model and user request features. Experimental results show that our approach can increase the request success rate to more than 95%, reduce response time by about 80%, and significantly outperform traditional algorithms in prediction accuracy.

title: Automated Robotic Arm System for Handling Plastic Connectors Utilizing Deep Learning and Advanced Lighting Control*
authors: Y.-C. Chen, S.-H. Chen
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: The manufacturing and assembly of small-batch electronic connectors involve significant labor, but industries are currently facing severe shortages. This study presents an automated grasping system utilizing a six-axis robotic arm that handles plastic components. It integrates vision technology, light source control, and deep learning. The system operates on Linux Ubuntu 18.04 and utilizes the Robot Operating System (ROS) to manage robotic operations.Using a distributed ROS framework, the system integrates the robotic arm, industrial camera, adaptive gripper, and machine vision based on deep learning. It accurately recognizes plastic components' front and reverse faces and their orientation and position, achieving a grasping and alignment success rate of 94%. This solution enhances automation in small-batch production, effectively addressing labor shortages.

title: Aware Foreign Language Assessment with Integrated Speech-to-Speech Translation and Multimodal Learning Analytics
authors: George Pashev, Silvia Gaftandhieva
abstract: This paper presents a novel formal model for intelligent foreign language assessment, which integrates Bloom's Taxonomy cognitive levels with advanced speech-to-speech translation and multimodal learning analytics. The mathematical framework enables automated generation of pedagogically sound units across different cognitive complexity levels, incorporating real-time speech recognition, semantic understanding, and adaptive feedback. The system, leveraging transformer-based architectures and neural text-to-speech synthesis within a unified assessment framework, supports over 60 languages and integrates spoken and written assessment. This research contributes to educational technology, computational linguistics, and cognitive science by offering a theoretical and practical foundation for nextgeneration language learning systems.

title: Cross-Platform Integration of Ontologies and Information Extraction for Plant Genetic Resources for the Bulgarian National GeneBank
authors: Pencho Malinov, Sebiha Madanska, Emil Doychev, Laska Kostadinova-Tsankova, Ivan Stoyanov, Katharina Wassilew
abstract: This paper presents a cross-platform approach that integrates various ontologies and methods for information extraction. The case study used for the experimentation phase focuses on an ontology for Plant Genetic Resources for Bulgarian National GeneBank in Sadovo. The ontology contains structured knowledge about plants, including genus, orders and others. The system also incorporates a database, with the key feature that the information extraction is performed from both ontological and database sources, improving the precision of the search and retrieval – an advancement of significant value for research and scientific studies.

title: A weighted approach for Bearing-Only Tracking of underwater acoustic sources with unbalanced measurements
authors: Tony Punnoose Valayil, Paolo Di Lillo, Gianluca Antonelli
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: This paper addresses the Bearing-Only Tracking problem of an underwater acoustic source using multiple Autonomous Underwater Vehicles. The vehicles, equipped with Passive Acoustic Monitoring sensors, must communicate to exchange their local target Direction of Arrival estimates through acoustic communication systems, which are typically characterized by low bandwidth and high latencies. The different availability of local measurements compared to those coming from the other vehicles in the team can create situations where one vehicle is forced to generate an estimate based on measurements that are heavily unbalanced toward one source. This negatively impacts the numerical balance of the regressor matrix used for the estimation, potentially leading to biased results. This paper proposes a weighting method to mitigate this effect, validating it through numerical simulations.

title: Multi-Layer Feature Fusion with Long–Short-Term Cascaded Matching for Multi-Object Tracking
authors: Ruixiang Zhu, Peng Luo, Xin He, Ming Fu, Renbin Liu
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Big Data, Artificial Intelligence and Internet of Things Engineering (ICBAIE)
abstract: Multi-object tracking remains challenging due to inherent conflicts between detection and ReID tasks in joint learning frameworks. Existing methods frequently employ over-simplified ReID module designs that compete with detection modules for shared backbone features, consequently degrading the performance of both tasks. Furthermore, re-association of targets after long-term disappearance remains a bottleneck. To resolve these issues, we propose a multi-layer fusion framework that strategically integrates and transforms hierarchical backbone features, simultaneously enhancing ReID accuracy while mitigating feature conflicts with detection demands. Additionally, a Long-Short-Term Cascaded Matching algorithm reliably associates long-disappeared targets. Comprehensive evaluations on VisDrone-2019MOT and UAVDT datasets substantiate the superior performance of our approach.

title: Street Detection Gaussians: An Approach for Efficient Real-Time 3D Scene Reconstruction
authors: Yu Du, Ho-Pun Lam, Ka Lok Man, Xinyue Zhang, Jeremy S. Smith
abstract: In this work, we present Street Detection Gaussians (SDGs), a unified framework for real-time 3D reconstruction and dynamic object detection in urban environments. Our method combines 3D Gaussian splatting with a streamlined detection pipeline to address the limitations of existing NeRF based and point cloud approaches in handling large-scale dynamic scenes. By integrating tracked poses for dynamic objects and leveraging depth-aware segmentation via Grounded-SAM, our model achieves 135 FPS rendering speeds on the Waymo dataset while maintaining photorealistic reconstruction quality (PSNR: 34.92 dB, SSIM: 0.940). Experimental results demonstrate state-of-the-art performance in both static scene rendering and dynamic traffic element detection, outperforming 3DGS by 25% in mAP for object localization. This work bridges the gap between high-fidelity reconstruction and real-time urban monitoring applications.

title: FVM-UNet: FFT-enhanced VM-UNet for Medical Image Segmentation
authors: Hanlin Wu, Qun Jin
publish: 2025 IEEE Cyber Science and Technology Congress (CyberSciTech)
abstract: Within medical imaging’s segmentation domain, VM-UNet with state space models (SSMs) has shown promising results because of its linear computational complexity and efficient sequence modeling capabilities. However, its ability in capturing comprehensive image features, especially in boundary delineation and fine-grained details, remains limited. While recent studies have explored various architectural enhancements, the potential of frequency domain analysis in complementing state space models has remained largely unexplored. In this paper, we propose FVM-UNet, a framework that integrates the Fast Fourier Transform (FFT) with VM-UNet to enhance medical image segmentation. Our approach maintains the computational efficiency of state space models while incorporating frequency domain features to improve feature representation and boundary detection. With carefully designed FFT modules and feature fusion mechanisms, FVM-UNet effectively combines spatial and frequency domain information to achieve superior segmentation accuracy. Extensive evaluation performed on the ISIC2017 and ISIC2018 datasets reveal that FVM-UNet consistently outperforms existing methods, achieving mIoU improvements of approximately 0.58% on ISIC2017 and 0.13% on ISIC2018 over VM-UNet. Ablation studies further validate the effectiveness of our frequency domain integration. Our work establishes a new direction for integrating the Fast Fourier Transform in state space model-based medical image segmentation.

title: Dynamic pricing to control stochastic retail demand: Near-Optimal Weight Functions for Large Lots of Perishable Product Considering Leftovers*
authors: Yu Cao, Anna V. Kitaeva
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: This research investigates an inventory system employing a fixed-order quantity policy for managing a perishable product with deterministic shelf life over a finite planning horizon, assuming no replenishment during the sales period. The demand follows a non-homogeneous compound Poisson distribution, where the intensity exhibits dual dependence on both current inventory availability and an unspecified temporal weight function while controlled by retail price. Through the application of diffusion approximation of the inventory level and incorporating intensity-price dependence, we derive a practical approximation for the optimal weight function that remains computationally efficient even for substantial lot sizes. The case of leftovers’ salvage has been considered. For two types of near-optimal weight functions the expected revenues are obtained, and numerical examples of their maximization with respect to an unknown constant are presented.

The channel auto relationship shape and uproar difference is gotten by way of using the clatter smothered channel force response. In this paper a useful and further created channel appraisal methodology is introduced the use of the MMSE channel evaluation technique.

title: Investigation of THz quasi-BIC based metasurface by selectively breaking symmetry
authors: Samuel John, Bhairov Kumar Bhowmik, KM Rohith, Shriganesh Prabhu, Gagan Kumar
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: We designed a ring-shaped metamolecule system where we selectively break the symmetry of half of the resonators in the metamolecule through radial perturbation. The farfield and nearfield response of these metasurfaces were studied experimentally.

title: Predicting User Satisfaction from Swiggy Reviews: A Machine Learning Approach
authors: Syed.Akbar, N.Divya Sri, Sajida Sultana. Sk
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Automation, Computing and Renewable Systems (ICACRS)
abstract: The sector of food service in India has undergone a rapid transformation with the advent of online food delivery services, e.g., Swiggy and Zomato, where the consumer's choice is very much influenced by reviews, sentiments, influencers, and digital interactions. Prior research has identified various factors affecting platform performance post-pandemic, such as demand-supply dynamics, user satisfaction, pricing transparency, online payments, and changing views of "local food."This study extends these insights and performs a case analysis based on a vast Swiggy dataset comprising restaurant data, cuisines, ratings, pricing and city-wise distributions employing various machine learning algorithms like Random Forest, Decision Tree, Gradient Boosting, Linear Regression, and SVR. The findings indicate that ratings are mainly determined by cuisine diversity and city location, while moderate R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> values imply that other factors, such as taste authenticity, service quality, and ambience, also play a role in the rating process. PCA detects independent major components, and permutation-based feature importance reaffirms that city and cuisine are the most influential predictors. The paper presents a solid case that customer behaviour, culture, restaurant diversity, and the company's recommendation system work together to form a significant part of Swiggy's digital ecosystem, delivering crucial insights for the purveyors, techies, and marketers to tune their approaches, increase the customer satisfaction level, and further develop accurate predictive models for the food delivery sector.

title: Advanced Micro/Nano Biodegradable Materials for the Design and Modeling of Bio-Medical Applications
authors: A R Kalaiarasi, M Prabakaran
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Automation, Computing and Renewable Systems (ICACRS)
abstract: Micro/Nanomaterials are increasingly used in the biomedical field for advanced applications. In this work, microneedles made from biodegradable materials are designed and simulated for drug delivery systems. Different materials and dimensions are analyzed through stress and laminar flow studies to evaluate their performance. Biodegradable materials are chosen since they are safer for the environment and suitable for biomedical use. Stress analysis is carried out to study the effect of needle insertion on the skin, while flow analysis helps in understanding the velocity and pressure distribution of the drug. Additionally, micro/nano pumps are designed and simulated to handle small fluid volumes, ensuring controlled drug delivery. The pump uses piezoelectric actuation, and its performance is tested with variations in inlet, outlet, and channel sizes.

title: Physics-Informed Adaptive Conformal Prediction for Wind Power under Dynamic Weather Regimes
authors: Poonam Dhaka, Mini Sreejeth, M. M Tripathi
abstract: Accurate wind-power forecasting is essential for grid stability and the reliable integration of renewable energy sources. However, dynamic weather regimes and turbine nonlinearities introduce uncertainties that challenge conventional interval prediction techniques. Traditional conformal prediction methods, despite distribution-free, typically presume data exchangeability and disregard temporal dependencies, heteroscedasticity, and physical constraints on normalized power output. To address these limitations, a Physics-Informed Adaptive Conformal Pre diction (PI-ACP) framework is developed for uncertainty-aware wind-power forecasting. The method introduces a regime-aware, temporally weighted nonconformity scoring mechanism that emphasizes recent residuals and adapts prediction intervals to evolving meteorological conditions, particularly during wind ramp events. Physical feasibility is ensured through physics aware interval constraints that restrict predicted power within the normalized range [0, 1]. Moreover, the framework is extended to multi-step forecasting by employing a multivariate conformity score that enables joint uncertainty calibration across several future horizons. Comprehensive evaluations on two utility-scale wind-farm datasets demonstrate that PI-ACP produces sharper and more reliable prediction intervals than existing state-of-the art baselines while maintaining linear-time computational efficiency. The proposed PI-ACP framework improves probabilistic forecasting performance by up to 44% compared with existing state-of-the-art methods, offering sharper and more reliable prediction intervals for diverse wind regimes. The proposed approach provides physics-consistent and adaptively calibrated uncertainty quantification suitable for real-time operational planning in power systems with high wind-energy penetration.

title: A Constructive Framework for Nondeterministic Automata via Time-Shared, Depth-Unrolled Feedforward Networks
authors: Sahil Rajesh Dhayalkar
abstract: We present a formal and constructive simulation framework for nondeterministic finite automata (NFAs) using time-shared, depth-unrolled feedforward networks (TS-FFNs), i.e., acyclic unrolled computations with shared parameters that are functionally equivalent to unrolled recurrent or state-space models. Unlike prior approaches that rely on explicit recurrent architectures or post hoc extraction methods, our formulation symbolically encodes automaton states as binary vectors, transitions as sparse matrix transformations, and nondeterministic branching—including ε-closures—as compositions of shared thresholded updates. We prove that every regular language can be recognized exactly by such a shared-parameter unrolled feedforward network, with parameter count independent of input length. Our construction yields a constructive equivalence between NFAs and neural networks and demonstrates empirical learnability: these networks can be trained via gradient descent on supervised acceptance data to recover the target automaton behavior. This learnability, formalized in Proposition V.1, is the crux of this work. Extensive experiments validate the theoretical results, achieving perfect or near-perfect agreement on acceptance, state propagation, and closure dynamics. This work clarifies the correspondence between automata theory and modern neural architectures, showing that unrolled feedforward networks can perform precise, interpretable, and trainable symbolic computation.

title: An Energetic Analysis of a Sufficient Synchronization Criterion Applied to FitzHugh-Nagumo Oscillator Networks
authors: Jonas Röhrig, Robin Lautenbacher, Karlheinz Ochs, Ralf Köhl
publish: 2025 IEEE Biomedical Circuits and Systems Conference (BioCAS)
abstract: Oscillator networks play an important role as abstractions of biological neural networks. As such, electrical implementations of oscillator networks are promising candidates for future computing hardware. The FitzHugh-Nagumo oscillator (FNO) is an example for a bio-inspired oscillator used for implementing electrical neural networks. For the design of oscillator networks for neuromorphic computing, understanding synchronization dynamics is important. Interpretable synchronization criteria contribute to that as they enable the synthesis of e.g. effective coupling circuits and topologies. In this work, we deal with a sufficient synchronization criterion that is applicable to FNOs but framed in the language of control theory. This entails that it is disconnected from physical quantities which complicates interpretation and application. We address this issue by retracing the criterion purely in the electrical domain for the special case of networks of FNOs. This restatement shows that synchronization is guaranteed if the coupling circuit dissipates more incremental power than the locally active nonlinearities of the oscillators inject. We present emulation results of an exemplary setup to illustrate this. The insights gained through this work are an important precursor to formulating a general synchronization criterion for oscillator networks in the electrical domain.

title: A Pneumatic Origami-Inspired Continuum Robot with Active Crease Control for Multimodal Deformation
authors: Yi Yu, Dongqi Wang, Peng Chen, Yuwang Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Automation, Electronics and Electrical Engineering (AUTEEE)
abstract: Continuum robots have shown great potential in unstructured environments due to their inherent compliance and safety. Pneumatic actuation is particularly suitable for such applications, offering high power density and robustness. However, achieving controllable multimodal deformation with adequate load capacity remains challenging, especially for origami-inspired robots whose motion is often passively coupled across all creases. To address this, this paper presents a pneumatically driven continuum robot based on the Yoshimura origami pattern, incorporating active crease control as its core innovation. By strategically arranging rigid and compliant materials and co-optimizing crease parameters, we enable independent and localized actuation of selected folds, transforming origami deformation from globally passive to actively controllable. The fabricated prototype achieves a maximum length of 1.1 m with an extension ratio of 2.6:1, and demonstrates both continuous and segmental deformation for adaptive wrapping around complex objects. Moreover, it exhibits significant load capacity—5 kg horizontally and 20 kg vertically—substantially advancing the practical utility of origami-based continuum robots in real-world tasks.

title: Random-Number Generation Using Chaos in RF-Irradiated Stacked Intrinsic Josephson Junction
authors: Dai Oikawa, Hirokazu Komatsu, Keita Tsuzuki, Hiroya Andoh
abstract: The configuration of a robust, high-security system has become increasingly important because, as computer processing speeds continue to improve, the vulnerabilities of cryptographic systems that rely on conventional pseudo-random-numbers have raised concerns regarding potential leaks of confidential information. To establish such a secure system, high-quality and high-speed random numbers are essential. Here, high-quality random-numbers are defined as statistically unbiased, non-reproducible, and unpredictable values. One approach to generating such numbers is to exploit physical random phenomena, such as chaos. In particular, chaos in Josephson junctions (JJs) under radio-frequency (RF) irradiation has been identified as a suitable mechanism for random-number generation. In this study, we considered RF-biased intrinsic Josephson junctions (IJJs) in a mesa-type Bi <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$_{2}$</tex-math></inline-formula> Sr<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$_{2}$</tex-math></inline-formula>CaCu <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$_{2}$</tex-math></inline-formula> O<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$_{8+\delta }$</tex-math></inline-formula> single crystal. Since the interactions among stacked IJJs must be considered, it is insufficient to evaluate their properties using the conventional resistively and capacitively shunted junction (RCSJ) circuit model. Instead, we numerically investigated the chaotic voltage of an IJJ stack irradiated with higher frequencies than those typically used in conventional RF systems, employing the capacitively coupled JJ model with diffusion current, which incorporates interlayer interactions. Based on the time-series output voltage of the IJJ, we then generated random-numbers and evaluated their quality using statistical tests.

title: Compact Self-Packaged Dual-Band Bandpass Filters Based on FSIW With Embedded CRLHR and MLR
authors: Yuexiao Hao, Ke Gong, Hang Qian, Chunfeng Fan, Xuehui Hu, Xicheng Zhu, Qing Liu
publish: IEEE Microwave and Wireless Technology Letters
abstract: This letter proposes and analyzes two novel self-packaged hybrid-structure folded substrate integrated waveguide (FSIW) bandpass filters (BPFs). For the first time, the meander-line resonator (MLR) and composite right-/left-handed resonator (CRLHR) are embedded in the middle layer to avoid the reduction in unloaded quality factors (QU) caused by surface etching slot lines. Meanwhile, the embedded MLR and CRLHR not only achieved excellent shielding performance, but also could contribute a pole to each passband, respectively. Additionally, both TE<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">0.5,0,1</sub> and TE<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1,0,1</sub> modes of the inline right and left FSIW cavity (FSIWC) contribute two poles for each passband, respectively. Two compact dual-band BPFs with five poles and six poles, featuring controllable passband frequency ratios, have been fabricated and measured.

title: AACoT: Chain-of-Thought Fine-Tuning via Associative Memory and Adaptive Error Correction
authors: Ruiyue Wang, Lingyun Song, Xinbiao Gan, Yudai Pan, Xuequn Shang
publish: 2025 IEEE 31th International Conference on Parallel and Distributed Systems (ICPADS)
abstract: Traditional Chain-of-Thought (CoT) approaches in large language models (LLMs) often miss long-range semantic dependencies. As a result, early reasoning errors may cause subsequent cascading failures. To address these issues, we introduce AACoT, a fine-tuning framework that integrates associative memory and adaptive error correction within the CoT reasoning process. The AACoT memory functions in a dualmode capacity that differentiates entity-level knowledge from relation-level knowledge, facilitating dynamic knowledge interaction and efficient retrieval for reasoning. The adaptive error correction mechanism monitors the reasoning process, backtracks upon error detection, and regenerates the corrected reasoning paths. To improve robustness, a prompt refinement module adjusts short-term memory by collecting frequent error patterns to direct future reasoning, and a memory warm-up strategy loads crucial knowledge in advance of inference to minimize dependency on additional training. In the inference process, AACoT produces several reasoning paths and employs weighted voting to determine the final result. Results from experiments conducted on mathematical reasoning benchmarks reveal significant improvements in accuracy, validating that AACoT provides a clear and effective method for enhancing complex reasoning in foundational LLMs.

title: RainfalLTE: A Zero-Effect Rainfall Sensing System Utilizing Existing LTE Infrastructure
authors: Pengfei Shi, Fei Shang, Haohua Du
publish: 2025 IEEE 31th International Conference on Parallel and Distributed Systems (ICPADS)
abstract: Environmental sensing is an important research topic in the integrated sensing and communication (ISAC) system. Current works often focus on static environments, such as buildings and terrains. However, dynamic factors like rainfall can cause serious interference to wireless signals. In this paper, we propose a system called RainfalLTE that utilizes the downlink signal of LTE base stations for device-independent rain sensing. In particular, it is fully compatible with current communication modes and does not require any additional hardware. We evaluate it with LTE data and rainfall information provided by a weather radar in Badaling Town, Beijing The results show that for 10 classes of rainfall, RainfalLTE achieves over 97 % identification accuracy. Our case study shows that the assistance of rainfall information can bring more than 40 % energy saving, which provides new opportunities for the design and optimization of ISAC systems.

title: Simulation Environment for Studying EnOcean Communication Processes
authors: Georgi Genev, Aydan Haka
abstract: The growth of the Internet of Things (IoT) technology continues at a rapid pace, with increasing attention being paid to technologies that are energy efficient. One of the technologies with high energy efficiency and application in the fields of IoT is EnOcean. EnOcean technology is becoming increasingly used, and this naturally directs attention to its operation and research into its specifics. Simulation products are very often used to study such technologies, due to their easy applicability and the advantage of not purchasing physical equipment. Existing simulators of EnOcean technology are limited in number and have specific capabilities. This paper proposes a new simulation product (GEnOSim), which provides the opportunity to simulate various aspects of the functionalities of EnOcean technology. The object of research in this paper is the communication processes under the ERP1 and Smart Acknowledge protocols, with the aim of validating the operation of the simulator. The experiments performed show that the proposed GEnOSim simulator represents the processes under consideration and the structure and content of the exchanged messages in accordance with the definitions of the EnOcean standard.

title: Active Safety Path Tracking Method for Autonomous Vehicles under Cyber Attacks
authors: Jiaxi Gao, Jintian Zhang, Wenxi Bai, Shuai Li
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Automation, Electronics and Electrical Engineering (AUTEEE)
abstract: Aiming at the problem that autonomous vehicles in network environments are vulnerable to Denial-of-Service (DoS) attacks, this paper proposes a path tracking control strategy with resilient anti-disturbance capability to enhance the driving stability and control reliability of vehicles under attack scenarios. Firstly, the Euler discretization method is adopted to establish a discrete-time vehicle-road system model. Key state variables such as lateral error and heading error are incorporated into the system state space, laying a foundation for subsequent control design. Secondly, considering the characteristics of DoS attacks (i.e., randomly triggered and energy-constrained), a Bernoulli random variable is used to model the activation behavior of such attacks, thereby accurately characterizing the intermittent interference caused by attacks on sensor-controller communication links. To ensure the robustness of the system under attacks and disturbances, an appropriate Lyapunov function is selected. Through stability analysis, the sufficient conditions satisfying performance index are derived, which guarantee the asymptotic stability and disturbance rejection capability of the closed-loop system, and realize the effective convergence of trajectory tracking errors. Finally, a co-simulation platform integrating Carsim and Simulink is established, which verifies the effectiveness and engineering applicability of the proposed method.

title: Adaptive Pruning Method of Digital PreDistortion Models Based on DLA Algorithm for LTE/5G Applications
authors: Zixiao Yang, Smail Bachir, Claude Duvanaud, Jean-Marc Ouvrard, Thomas Gambier
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: This paper proposes an adaptive pruning method for digital predistortion using a direct learning architecture. To linearize RF power amplifiers, the Generalized Memory Polynomial model is widely used as an inverse dynamical function. However, due to its large number of required terms, many studies focus on reducing implementation complexity. This work mainly uses the doubly orthogonal matching pursuit approach to select active terms while incorporating the Levenberg-Marquardt algorithm to enhance linearization performance. The proposed method achieves a linearity performance nearly equivalent to that of the full model, while significantly reducing the search time for the optimal structure. It’s applied to the linearization of an Open Radio Station for LTE/5G applications, including an asymmetrical two-stage 10W Doherty power amplifier implemented in GaN technology. Comparisons with other state-of-the-art approaches, such as the Gradient method and the Least-Squares algorithm, demonstrate that the proposed method achieves better linearization performance in terms of spectral regrowths reduction and lower computational complexity.

title: Conducting Gel-Assisted Triboelectric Sensor Array for Self-Powered Wireless Pressure Distribution and Emergency Alert System_supp4-3651863.docx
authors: Dr. Ranbir Singh
abstract: Triboelectric nanogenerators (TENG) is a promising and sustainable solution for converting mechanical energy into electrical energy, as well as utilize for energy harvesting and sensing applications. However, TENG devices inherently suffers from limited electrical conductivity, which limits output current from dielectric triboelectric layers despite their high voltage generation. To address these challenges, this work presents the development of high-performance polyvinyl alcohol/silver nitrate (PVA/AgNO<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sub>) conducting gels, engineered to be flexible, stretchable, and employed as an electropositive intermediate dielectric layer embedded within the TENG architecture to facilitate efficient charge generation and transfer. Synthesized PVA/AgNO<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sub> conducting gel exhibits improved electrical conductivity, tensile strength, and compressive strength of 32.8 S/m, 0.5 MPa, and 0.6 MPa, respectively. Further, conducting gel was employed to fabricate a triboelectric nanogenerator (CG-TENG), delivering an output voltage of 27.6 V and a current density response up to 0.4 μA/cm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>, which is a threefold increment compared to reference conducting gel free-TENG. The CG-TENG efficiently produces a maximum power density of 0.16 mW/cm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> across a 1 kΩ load resistor. Additionally, a 2 × 2 self-powered pressure sensor array prototype was fabricated using CG-TENG to demonstrate spatially resolved pressure sensing, where each pixel generated distinct electrical signals under mechanical stimulation. The prototypes successfully demonstrate emergency alert messages on OLED, wirelessly visualize pressure sensing and distribution on the graphical user interface (GUI).

title: Democratizing IVDR Technology: Low-Cost Real-Time Driver Feedback Using Consumer Hardware
authors: David Trajkoski, Aleksandar Karadimce, Dijana Capeska Bogatinoska
abstract: In-Vehicle Data Recorders (IVDRs) have emerged as promising tools for improving road safety and driving efficiency by providing continuous monitoring and feedback to drivers. Despite their proven effectiveness in commercial applications, IVDR adoption remains limited due to high costs and accessibility issues, with most systems designed for commercial fleets rather than individual consumers. This paper presents a comprehensive study on the impact of IVDR feedback mechanisms on driver performance, integrating both literature review and practical experiments involving smartphone sensors and On-Board Diagnostics (OBD) data. The research combines findings from existing studies with newly collected datasets to analyze driving behavior across various conditions. We examine the influence of real-time feedback on key metrics such as harsh acceleration, braking frequency, speed variation, and fuel consumption through a dual-approach methodology. Our experiments achieved 89.2% classification accuracy using consumer-grade smartphone sensors and successfully extracted critical vehicle parameters from OBD-II ports across different vehicle generations, demonstrating broad compatibility with existing vehicle infrastructure. We developed four real-time feedback algorithms to provide immediate driver guidance, addressing safety, efficiency, and vehicle maintenance. The findings reveal the effectiveness of IVDRs in promoting safer driving habits and highlight opportunities for technological enhancements. Additionally, the research proposes innovative solutions to enhance the accessibility and affordability of IVDR technology, thereby democratizing safer driving practices. By offering actionable recommendations for integrating IVDR technology into vehicles, this research aims to contribute to broader-scale improvements in road safety and efficiency.

title: Germanium-on-Glass Photoconductive Antennas for Terahertz Detection
authors: Dhanashree Chemate, Abhishek Singh, Utkarsh Pandey, Ruturaj Puranik, Siddhartha P. Duttagupta, Shriganesh S. Prabhu
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: We investigate a Germanium (Ge) based Photoconductive Antenna (PCA) as a Terahertz (THz) detector. The bowtie antenna comprises Sputtered-Ge film and Gold-Germanium (AuGe) electrodes. Time-resolved measurements reveal a carrier lifetime of around ~ 650 fs in the Ge films. The PCA demonstrates a detection bandwidth of up to 1.5 THz with a signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) of 27 dB. This simple approach paves a path for compact, scalable, and cost-effective THz detectors using Ge film on glass.

title: LatentZoom: Seamless Scaling in Generative Latent Space for Visual Exploration of Local Performance in Deep Neural Networks
authors: Xinying Ma, Jie Li
publish: IEEE Transactions on Visualization and Computer Graphics
abstract: Deep Neural Network (DNN) evaluation is a classic topic in machine learning. Unlike existing methods that assess a DNN's general performance on pre-collected real-world data, we propose an approach to exploring a DNN's local performance on generated data. The core idea is to train a generative model (GM) on real-world data and visualize the DNN's performance over the GM's latent space (GLS). The GLS contains all generated samples (GSs) of the GM, capturing combinations of features and their variations present in the GM's training set, thereby enhancing the comprehensiveness of testing. Moreover, the plane organizes all GSs into a continuous space with regular variations in features, enabling users to conduct cross-scale exploration to understand the DNN's behavior across different levels of feature granularity. Our research focuses on two challenges in achieving and applying the idea. First, the GLS is unvisualizable due to its high dimensionality and unboundedness. We thus project the GLS onto a plane and visualize the DNN's performance on this plane. The plane serves as a surrogate for the GLS, providing rich visual cues for locating regions containing GSs involving performance-relevant patterns. Second, the plane alone is insufficient for performance exploration. To overcome this, we develop a system based on it. The system comprises two main views that integrate interactions, such as panning and zooming, to enable users to observe any plane region and assess the DNN's performance on the corresponding GSs. We also develop three auxiliary views to facilitate pattern exploration and to diagnose factors that lead to specific performance patterns. Experimental results demonstrate the usability and effectiveness of our approach.

title: A Blockchain-based Smart Contract Framework for Decentralized Peer-To-Peer Lending
authors: Ragavarthini. V, Maddukuri Naga Tanuja, Maddukuri Lakshmi Vanaja, Kucharlapati Gowtham Varma, Maruboina Avinash
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Automation, Computing and Renewable Systems (ICACRS)
abstract: Traditional financial lending systems face ongoing issues. These include too much involvement from middlemen, limited financial inclusion, a lack of transparency, and centralized decision-making. Such problems push unbanked and underbanked populations to the margins. This paper presents a blockchain-based decentralized peer-to-peer (P2P) credit system built on the Ethereum network. It uses smart contracts and Decentralized Autonomous Organization (DAO) frameworks that are transparent, secure, and accessible worldwide. Traditional financial institutions still rely heavily on centralized models. These models involve many intermediaries, slow processes, and high operational costs. As a result, many people have restricted access to financial services. According to the World Bank's Global Findex Database, around 1.7 billion adults are unbanked and shut out from essential financial systems. This exclusion often stems from strict eligibility requirements, lack of credit history, and absence of collateral. It not only hampers individual financial growth but also limits broader economic inclusion in developing nations. The proposed model eliminates the need for centralized institutions. It speeds up transactions, increases transparency, and allows for borderless digital lending. The system architecture uses Solidity for smart contract development, Web3.js for blockchain interaction, and a React-based user interface to create a robust full-stack decentralized application (DApp). The framework features automated asset collateralization, AI-driven interest rate modeling, trust-score-based borrower assessment, and community governance mechanisms. Performance comparisons show marked improvements in transaction speed, efficiency, and financial access compared to traditional lending models. The prototype achieves a 65% reduction in infrastructure costs and an 80% faster loan settlement time across different regions.

title: Computationally Efficient MPC With Embedded Adaptive Battery Balancing for CHB Inverters
authors: Filippo Gemma, Giulia Tresca, Jacopo Riccio, Behrouz Mohammadzadeh, Andrea Volpini, Pericle Zanchetta
abstract: This paper proposes a Tree-Based Finite-Control-Set Model Predictive Control (TBFCS-MPC) strategy for a Cascaded H-Bridge (CHB) inverter, integrated with an adaptive online Look-Up Table (LUT) for real-time battery voltage balancing. The proposed TBFCS-MPC reduces computational complexity by limiting the number of evaluated voltage vectors to a maximum of 22, compared to 127 in conventional FCS-MPC approaches. This reduction enables real-time execution on embedded hardware, achieving a cost function evaluation time of only <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\bf {4.2\ \mu s}$</tex-math></inline-formula>, compared to <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\bf {24.1\ \mu s}$</tex-math></inline-formula> with state-of-the-art solutions. The LUT dynamically selects switching states based on instantaneous battery voltages, ensuring active balancing. Experimental results validate the method's fast current reference tracking, effective balancing, and significantly reduced computational burden, making it a practical solution for high-performance, battery-fed multilevel inverter applications.

title: N-Queens using Genetic Algorithm: A Comparative Study
authors: Mehul Dinesh Jain, Ahmed Hassan, Muhammad Saqib, Syed Arslan Abbas Rizvi, Somesh Onkar Rewadkar, Rand Kouatly
abstract: This paper aims to shed light on the use of genetic algorithm to solve for the N Queens problem on values of N that are too large to compute using the simple backtracking method. The N Queens problem is where Queens are to be placed on a N*N matrix that represents a chessboard such that no two queens are able to be in contact with each other. The textbook solution for the problem is to use backtracking, a problem-solving algorithmic technique that involves finding a solution incrementally and reverting to the previous state when one route is blocked. This approach can become computationally infeasible when the value of N is too large. By implementing the solution using a genetic algorithm we see a sharp drop in the complexity and the time taken for higher values of N. We compare and contrast the approach with the backtracking method and conclude the superior efficiency of genetic algorithm for this particular problem.

title: Adaptive Data Processing Framework for Enhanced Predictive Maintenance in Industrial IoT Ecosystems
authors: Kalthoum Zaouali, Nawel Bayar, Narimen Aloui, Mohamed L. Ammari, Ridha Bouallegue
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: Predictive Maintenance (PdM) in industrial systems has evolved from reactive, time-based approaches to AI-driven strategies leveraging sensor and big data for failure prediction. However, existing architectures often rigidly separate streaming and batch processing, leading to inefficiencies in resource utilization and delayed responses. This paper proposes a novel Adaptive Data Processing Framework (ADPF) that dynamically switches between streaming and micro-batching modes based on real-time contextual factors such as data criticality, network latency, and computational load. By integrating a reinforcement learning (RL)-based decision algorithm, ADPF optimizes the trade-off between latency, cost, and prediction accuracy. Implemented within an Industrial IoT (IIoT) and Big Data ecosystem, the framework improves maintenance scheduling, reduces operational costs by 30%, and ensures timely interventions. The experimental results demonstrate a 25% improvement in the accuracy of failure prediction and a 40% reduction in maximum CPU load compared to static architectures.

title: New Approach for the Identification of a Class of Time-Varying Parameters Dynamic Systems
authors: Francis A. Okou, Lauhic Jm Ndong Mezui, Donatien Nganga-Kouya, Rachid Beguenane
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: This paper presents a novel method for the identification of a class of dynamic systems with time-varying parameters. The targeted class includes uncertain systems with a one-to-one correspondence between state equations and unknown parameters. The approach leverages the swapping lemma and a series of filters to reformulate the parameter identification problem as a state observer design problem. Unknown parameters are determined by solving nonlinear equations using the continuous-time Newton’s method. For clarity, the proposed technique is demonstrated through two illustrative examples. Simulation results indicate that the estimated parameters converge to their true values almost instantaneously, with a tracking error that can be reduced to an arbitrarily small level.

title: Night-to-Day Translation for Nighttime Surveillance
authors: Jingzhu Li, Guanzhou Lan, Bin Zhao, Jianbin Jiao
publish: 2025 IEEE 31th International Conference on Parallel and Distributed Systems (ICPADS)
abstract: Nighttime surveillance suffers from degradation due to poor illumination and arduous human annotations. It is challengable and remains a security risk at night. Existing methods rely on multi-spectral images to perceive objects in the dark, which are troubled by color absence. We argue that the ultimate solution for nighttime surveillance is night-to-day translation, or Night2Day, which aims to translate a surveillance scene from nighttime to the daytime while maintaining semantic consistency. To achieve this, this paper presents a Disentangled Contrastive (DiCo) learning method. Specifically, to address the poor and complex illumination in the nighttime scenes, we propose a learnable physical prior, i.e., the color invariant, which provides a stable perception of a highly dynamic night environment and can be incorporated into the learning pipeline of neural networks. Targeting the surveillance scenes, we develop a disentangled representation, which is an auxiliary pretext task that separates surveillance scenes into the foreground and background with contrastive learning. Such a strategy can extract the semantics without supervision and boost our model to achieve instanceaware translation. Finally, we incorporate all the modules above into generative adversarial networks and achieve high-fidelity translation. This paper also contributes a new surveillance dataset called NightSuR. It includes six scenes to support the study on nighttime surveillance. This dataset collects nighttime images with different properties of nighttime environments, such as flare and extreme darkness. Extensive experiments demonstrate that our method outperforms existing works significantly.

title: A Pose-Free Approach for 4D Gaussian Splatting to Reconstruct Dynamic Scenes
authors: Huosen Ou, Yiding Ji
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: This work develops PF-4DGS, an novel framework for 4D Gaussian splatting that addresses the challenges associated with the reliance on accurate prior knowledge of camera poses in dynamic scene modeling. Our approach employs a pose-free optimization strategy that simultaneously estimates camera parameters and reconstructs the scene within a unified framework. We introduce a stable initialization technique and an efficient joint optimization loop that simultaneously improves scene reconstruction and camera tracking. Comprehensive evaluations on real-world datasets demonstrate that PF-4DGS achieves accuracy comparable to leading methods, even without prior camera pose information. This advancement marks a huge breakthrough in Gaussian splatting and promotes the application of this technique in dynamic environments.

title: VRPTD: Verifiable and Robust Privacy-Preserving Truth Discovery for IoT Crowdsensing
authors: Shuang Chen, You Li, Pengfei Zhang, Zhao Li, Ji Zhang, Yining Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE 31th International Conference on Parallel and Distributed Systems (ICPADS)
abstract: The rapid development of Internet of Things (IoT) devices has greatly boosted large-scale crowdsensing, where truth discovery (TD) technique is a feasible solution to extract more reliable data from heterogeneous measurements or noisy environment. However, most existing approaches send raw readings to a centralized server, implicitly fully trusting the server and fog nodes. In practice, these nodes are geographically dispersed, outsourced, and operated by different parties, making such blanket trust untenable. To address these threats, a verifiable, robust, and privacy-preserving truth discovery (VRPTD) framework is proposed. Specifically, VRPTD shields individual reports through a lightweight dual-layer mechanism that combines unbiased expected mask correction with modular arithmetic encryption. Data requesters can publicly audit the result via linear homomorphic hash proof. VRPTD redesigns the weight update step using a Gaussian radial basis function distance, which yields more accurate processing of multidimensional measurements. Security analysis indicates that VRPTD satisfies verifiability under a well-defined threat model. Extensive experiments on real-world IoT datasets demonstrate that VRPTD boosts baseline TD accuracy, halves convergence rounds and reduces communication and computation overhead, all while providing strong privacy and resilience against active attacks.

title: AranVoting: Ensuring Anonymity and Fairness in Blockchain-Based Ranked-Choice Voting
authors: Yu Xia, Meiqi Li, Qiantong Jiang, Wentuo Sun, Yingjie Xue, Kaiping Xue
publish: 2025 IEEE 31th International Conference on Parallel and Distributed Systems (ICPADS)
abstract: Electronic voting is crucial for contemporary democratic processes. However, conventional systems often struggle with a single point of failure and insufficient support for intricate voting semantics, especially in ranked-choice elections requiring distinct ranking constraints. Although blockchain technology enhances fault tolerance and auditability, existing blockchainbased solutions primarily focus on simpler voting schemes, encountering difficulties in effectively verifying privacy-preserving ranked ballots. To address this gap, we propose AranVoting, an innovative blockchain-based ranked-choice voting scheme designed to ensure anonymity and fairness through homomorphic encryption. AranVoting employs a structured matrix ballot format alongside zero-knowledge proof to ensure the correctness of the ballot format. Furthermore, we introduce a smart contractdriven counting mechanism that facilitates the availability and transparency of ballot tallying through gradient incentive and committee election algorithms. Our security and performance evaluations demonstrate that AranVoting provides secure rankedchoice voting, effectively guaranteeing essential security properties such as anonymity, correctness, and verifiability while maintaining practicality and reasonable computational overhead throughout the voting process.

title: Exploiting hot-electron photoconductivity in graphene for terahertz photomixer detection
authors: Mark D. Thomson, Florian Ludwig, Jakob Holstein, Rohit Kapoor, Reiam al-Mudhafar, Shihab Al-Daffaie, Hartmut G. Roskos
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: The ultrafast periodic heating and cooling of electrons in graphene, driven by a two-color optical beat signal, provides an alternative mechanism to realize terahertz (THz) photomixers, owing to the large bolometric photoconductivity. This allows operation over a broad range of optical wavelengths without the need for specialized epitaxial sample growth used in conventional semiconductor (SC) devices based on interband photoconductivity. We have recently demonstrated coherent, continuous-wave THz detection up to 0.7 THz in multi-layer graphene devices with telecom-wavelength optical lasers. In the case of detection, the bias-free operation allows operation without any dark current. Here we further investigate the physical origin of the effect and experimental performance using simulations of the hot-electron dynamics, and discuss potential routes to reach the sensitivity of state-of-the-art SC photomixers.

title: Toward Mechanically Intelligent Reconfiguration via Origami Bifurcations_supp1-3647559.pdf
authors: Chenying Liu
abstract: Reconfigurability allows robots to create new morphologies to better match their environment or task. This ability is often viewed as a form of robotic intelligence. The process of reconfiguration is typically achieved either by mechatronic modules that disassemble and reassemble themselves, or by malleable bodies, such as soft materials and linkage-like mechanisms with multiple degrees of freedom (DoFs). Despite these advances, the former approach can compromise robustness due to reconnections, while the latter often reduces controllability as the system’s DoFs proliferate. To address these limitations, we introduce a novel reconfigurable robot based on thick-panel rigid origami and exploit kinematic bifurcations, branch points in the configuration space, to realize multiple configurations without module reconnections and without increasing overall DoF. In our framing, the bifurcation mechanism constitutes the element of mechanical intelligence that enables the intelligent behavior of reconfiguration. As a proof of concept, we built a chain of interlinked rigid origami units that morphs among coil, wave-like, and triangular shapes, mimicking the morphology of a millipede. We also observe additional configurations due to compliant joint behavior relative to the ideal model. Furthermore, the robot’s dynamic performance and locomotion modes are explored. The work represents a further step toward real-world deployment of mechanically intelligent robots, illustrating the enabling role of bifurcation-guided reconfiguration.

title: Evaluation of the Kerr Effect and Electron Transport Properties of InSb using Magneto-Optical Terahertz Time-Domain Ellipsometry
authors: Zixi Zhao, Verdad C. Agulto, Atsuki Kamio, Kosaku Kato, Thanh Nhat Khoa Phan, Toshiyuki Iwamoto, Toshihiko Shimizu, Nobuhiko Sarukura, Makoto Nakajima
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: In order to demonstrate the application of magneto-optical terahertz time-domain ellipsometry (MO-THz-TDE) in the characterization of semiconductors, doped and undoped InSb wafers were evaluated with a magnetic field of B = 0.4 T. The dielectric tensors of both InSb samples were obtained, and the influence of plasma resonance on the Kerr effect was observed. Furthermore, electron transport properties such as effective mass and carrier density were derived using the Drude model without any assumptions.

title: A hybrid architecture multistatic track initiation method based on spatio-temporal feature fusion network
authors: Wang Dewu, Wang Xinghao, Li Luyu, Zhang Ruiyang, Yu Jiushen, Zong Hua, Li Yang
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: This paper proposes an intelligent track initiation method based on spatio-temporal feature fusion network for multistatic radar systems, addressing the challenge of multi-target track initiation in complex electromagnetic environments. The technique leverages a combination of a Spatio-Temporal Feature-driven Threshold Network (STFTN) and a Spatio-Temporal Graph Convolutional Network (STGCN) within a hybrid architecture, combining the computational efficiency of distributed processing with the information richness of centralized processing. Initially, a coarse screening is performed locally at the sub-processor using the speed limit method. Subsequently, relevant data is sent to a central processor where the STFTN dynamically generates intelligent thresholds to optimize the correlation range for candidate tracks. Finally, motion features of candidate tracks are extracted and fed into the STGCN in the central processor for secondary intelligent judgment, effectively distinguishing true tracks from false alarms. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed algorithm achieves higher track initiation rates and fewer false tracks compared with traditional methods.

title: Inspection for Grout Voids in an External Bridge Tendon Using a D-Band THz A-Scanner
authors: Dae-Su Yee, Ji Sang Yahng, Seung Hyun Cho
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: In bridge tendons, voids in the grout can expose the steel strands to corrosive ions and moisture, accelerating the corrosion of the steel strands. For non-destructive inspection of bridge tendons, we have developed a D-band terahertz A-scanner based on the electronic frequency-modulated continuous-wave method. It is presented that the terahertz A-scanner can be used to detect the presence of grout voids beneath the protective duct of an external bridge tendon.

title: Finite-Time Stability and State-Feedback Stabilization of Output-Constrained Stochastic Nonlinear Systems
authors: Huifang Min, Shengyuan Xu, Guozeng Cui, Shang Shi
publish: IEEE Transactions on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics: Systems
abstract: Traditional Lyapunov stability theory cannot directly apply to constrained stochastic nonlinear systems when using barrier Lyapunov functions due to their inherent lack of radial unboundedness. This article presents a novel approach to establishing finite-time stability for such systems by employing Lyapunov functions. The proposed stability analysis relies on a time-varying gain function that remains uniformly bounded. This approach ensures that the system achieves finite-time stability with an arbitrarily prescribed upper bound on the settling time, thereby effectively avoiding the unbounded controller gain problem. The resulting stability is further extended to the finite-time state-feedback control for strict-feedback stochastic nonlinear systems with output constraints. Simulation studies validate the effectiveness of the proposed control scheme.

authors: N/A
