title: THz Photonics: A Journey from Scientific Curiosity to Transformative Technology
authors: X.-C. Zhang
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: The field of THz photonics emerged through foundational contributions in ultrafast laser technology, optical rectification, photoconductive switches, and electro-optic sampling. Early pioneers, including David Auston, Y.R. Shen, Daniel Grischkowsky, and Federico Capasso, laid the groundwork for transformative advancements in THz wave generation, detection, and applications. This paper comments the historical evolution of THz photonics, highlighting key scientific milestones and their impact on modern imaging, sensing, and communication systems. Personal reflections from the author’s career and a tribute to Dr. Hua Zhong, a notable contributor, underscore the human and scientific legacy of this field.

title: Exploring the Hydrogen Bonding in Organic Crystals using THz Spectroscopy
authors: Gnana Maheswar Kothapalli, Snehal Haldankar, Samuel John, Shriganesh Prabhu, Kalaivanan Nagarajan
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: Terahertz Time-Domain Spectroscopy (THz-TDS) has been employed to characterize the low-energy vibrational modes, including those arising from inter- and intramolecular interactions such as hydrogen bonding in organic materials. Temperature-dependent THz-TDS offers a molecular-level understanding of weak interactions, dictating physical parameters such as melting point and phase transition. Similar studies have been performed in the mid-IR region, which offers vibrational features of bonds in the molecule during the phase transition. Combining these techniques could correlate weak interactions and chemical bonds to the physical understanding of materials. This report studies the THz-TDS and mid-IR spectral features of 2-nitroaniline, well-known for its intramolecular hydrogen bonding and associated properties.

title: FRQI Pairs method for image classification using Quantum Recurrent Neural Network
authors: Rafał Potempa, Michał Kordasz, Sundas Naqeeb Khan, Krzysztof Werner, Kamil Wereszczyński, Krzysztof Simiński, Krzysztof A. Cyran
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: This study presents the Flexible Representation for Quantum Images (FRQI) Pairs method, a novel approach that leverages Quantum Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN) for image classification. The proposed method achieves an accuracy of 74.60% on the full Modified National Institute of Standards and Technology (MNIST) handwritten digit data set, demonstrating its effectiveness in handling quantum encoded data for classification tasks.By reducing the size of the QRNN by the exponential factor, the FRQI Pairs method highlights the potential of integrating quantum computing principles with neural network architectures, offering a promising direction for advancing quantum machine learning.The research evaluates the FRQI Pairs method against existing quantum and classical models, demonstrating its competitive performance against other state-of-the-art approaches and showing potential for future advancements in the field. This research opens avenues for further exploration of quantum preprocessing and hybrid model architectures, marking a step forward in the application of quantum machine learning.

title: FedSDT: A Federated Distillation Optimization Method for Heterogeneous Non-IID Data Through Dual-Teacher Distillation and Bidirectional Knowledge Filtering
authors: Zhenqi Zhang, Hua Sun, Haiyang Fan, Linlin Zhang
publish: 2025 IEEE 31th International Conference on Parallel and Distributed Systems (ICPADS)
abstract: Federated Learning (FL), as a distributed machine learning paradigm, enables collaborative training of a central model across local nodes without sharing private data. However, it faces challenges such as high risks of white-box privacy attacks, large communication overhead, and difficulty in adapting to heterogeneous models. Federated Distillation (FD), which transfers knowledge among clients instead of exchanging parameters, has emerged as an alternative paradigm to address these challenges. Yet, under heterogeneous models and Non-IID data settings, FD suffers from global performance degradation due to knowledge bias, class imbalance, and model heterogeneity. To tackle this degradation issue, this paper proposes FedSDT, an enhanced federated distillation method for heterogeneous NonIID scenarios. Specifically, a dual-teacher distillation mechanism is introduced to alleviate the imbalance between global and local knowledge transfer and to mitigate the problem of “local forgetting”. A bidirectional knowledge filtering strategy is employed to select reliable samples and mine rare classes, preventing local models from losing knowledge of underrepresented categories. Furthermore, a class-aware balancing mechanism is designed to identify potential rare classes and dynamically weight the loss, thereby strengthening the model's focus on minority classes. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method not only ensures communication efficiency but also significantly improves model performance. It consistently outperforms baseline methods and effectively enhances the generalization capability of the FD framework.

title: Robust Distributed Fractional-Order Dynamic Output Feedback for Limited-Time Consensus Control in Multi-Agent Systems
authors: Mohammad Fiuzy, Stefan Rass
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: This paper presents a new approach to tackling one of the intricate challenges of consensus control in distributed systems, specifically targeting the stabilization of fractional-order outputs in linear fractional-order multi-agent systems. We introduce an innovative distributed feedback control strategy that leverages dynamic output feedback to stabilize the closed-loop system. By refining the H<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> robust control method, the controller and observer gains are precisely determined through an eigenvalue-based optimization process. The effectiveness and robustness of the proposed methodology are validated through simulations, with graphical results illustrating enhanced system performance and stability.

title: Enhanced THz self-mixing detection in TeraFETs via asymmetric interdigitated grating gates coupled to SRR metasurface arrays
authors: Yihao Li, Shengji Wang, Zhengyang You, Xiaojiao Deng, Xinhua Li
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: The efficiency of on-chip couplers plays a crucial role in field-effect transistor-based terahertz detectors (TeraFETs), directly influencing both the intensity and spatial distribution of the mixing factor. However, previous research has primarily focused on simple rectangular gate structures, limiting further improvements in the antenna factor beneath the gate region. In this work, we overcome this limitation by proposing an asymmetric interdigitated grating gate structure integrated with a split-ring resonator (SRR) metasurface. Using full-wave simulations, we precisely extract the self-mixing electric field and quantify the antenna factor beneath the gate. Compared to conventional SRR-coupled TeraFET detectors, our design achieves a 29.5-fold enhancement in the antenna factor.

title: Analyzing the Short Term Impact of News Sentiment on Indonesian Stock Prices Using Deep Learning Models
authors: Aurelius Alvin Wijaya, Bakti Amirul Jabar, Glenn Madison Sutarman, Andreas Wijaya
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Digital Transformation and Applications (ICDXA)
abstract: The influence of financial news sentiment on stock market volatility is a critical area of financial research, yet it's predictive power in emerging markets like Indonesia remains underexplored. This paper investigates the short term impact of news sentiment on Indonesian stock prices by developing and evaluating deep learning models. Utilizing a dataset of around 2000 news articles from IDXChannel and corresponding stock data, we engineer a feature set that combines textual sentiment and crucial contexes market variables, including momentum, volume anomalies, and market trends. We employ two transformer models, FinBERT and IndoELECTRA, alongside a stacking ensemble model, to predict binary stock price direct (UP/DOWN) over a 1 hour horizon following a news release. Our results demonstrate that, all models failed to establish a reliable signal. Performance metrics MCC and Brier score, indicate that the model's predictions were no better than random change. The findings suggest that for the Indonesian stock market, impact from news sentiment is either priced in with extreme efficiency, making it undetectable in a short term window, or the signal is too weak to be distinguished from market noise with current situation.

title: A Study on Face and Gesture Recognition using Raspberry Pi
authors: Qi Xiang Choo, Hui Ying Chan, Yiqi Tew
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Digital Transformation and Applications (ICDXA)
abstract: Two real-time and low-cost machine learning systems, one for face detection and recognition and another for gesture recognition, were developed on a Raspberry Pi to overcome embedded device limitations and create effective edge AI solutions. The face recognition system used a multilevel optimisation strategy, primarily involving external model training (OpenCV, Dlib) and real-time inference on the Pi, achieving accurate results suitable for smart home environments, although continuous on-device reinforcement learning proved unfeasible due to hardware constraints. The gesture recognition system, designed for natural humancomputer interaction, supported six static gestures. Four deep learning models, including externally trained (VGG16, MediaPipe) and on-device trained (MobileNet with TensorFlow Lite) options, were evaluated. The model trained on-device using MediaPipe for hand landmark extraction and MobileNet/TensorFlow Lite provided the best balance of speed and efficiency. Ultimately, both projects successfully demonstrated the feasibility of deploying accurate and efficient machine learning applications on low-cost embedded platforms, offering a practical contribution to edge AI.

title: A Blockchain-Based Traceable Aggregate Signcryption Scheme for VANETs
authors: Yingfu Xu, Feng Zhao, Meng Zhao, Zhaoyu Su, Chunhai Li, Yujue Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE 31th International Conference on Parallel and Distributed Systems (ICPADS)
abstract: In Vehicular Ad-hoc Networks (VANETs), vehicles exchange information in real-time by collaborating with Roadside Units (RSUs) and On-Board Units (OBUs) to enhance traffic efficiency and safety. Therefore, guaranteeing the integrity and confidentiality of messages, as well as the authenticity of the sender's identity, is crucial for establishing reliable communication. To address the aforementioned issues, this paper proposes an improved unforgeable aggregate signcryption scheme for VANETs, where a receiver can efficiently verify the legitimacy of multiple message sources simultaneously. The scheme enhances the security and privacy of VANETs by deploying a mapping between anonymous identities and public keys on a blockchain. Security analysis demonstrated that, under the hardness assumptions of the Elliptic Curve Discrete Logarithm Problem (ECDLP) and the Computational Diffie-Hellman Problem (CDHP), this scheme can achieve ciphertext unforgeability and confidentiality. Compared to existing related schemes, our proposed solution significantly reduces computational costs in both the signcryption and unsigncryption (especially in batch processing) phases.

title: Broad-band & Large-scale Near-field Analysis of Terahertz Structures of High Complexity – Measurement vs. Simulation
authors: M. Nagel, A. Michalski, S. Sawallich, T. Flisgen
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: This work addresses the challenges of analyzing highly complex terahertz (THz) devices. We directly compare experimental measurements with full-wave numerical simulations of a large, complex co-planar stripline structure, analyzing its time- and frequency-domain near-field behavior. The analysis reveals localized oscillations and propagating field modes, allowing for quantitative comparison between experimental and simulated data. By evaluating the computational effort required for comprehensive simulations, the work highlights the importance of a synergistic approach combining rigorous experimental characterization with sophisticated computational modeling to advance the rapidly evolving field of THz technology.

title: Research on Adaptive Adjustment Technology for Distribution Network Element Partitioning at Multiple Time Scales
authors: Lu Yangdong, Xiao Li, He Yiying, Li Jin, Lv Xiang, Zeng Hao
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Automation, Electronics and Electrical Engineering (AUTEEE)
abstract: To address the low accuracy and poor adaptability of distribution network element partitioning at multiple time scales, this paper constructs a multi-time scale element partitioning model and proposes an adaptive adjustment algorithm based on multi-scale dynamic clustering. First, the electrical, topological, and load characteristics of distribution network elements are analyzed, and the network elements are divided into short-term (0-15 minutes), intraday (15 minutes to 24 hours), and long-term (⩾24 hours) scales, and corresponding objective functions and constraints are established. Next, a "time-feature" dual-driven algorithm framework is designed to improve performance through data preprocessing, optimized cluster center initialization, and a dynamic adjustment mechanism. Experiments are conducted using Intel Xeon Gold 6348 hardware and Ubuntu 20.04 using measured data from a 10kV distribution network in an eastern city (containing 356 elements) and virtual data of 1000 elements augmented by a Generative Adversarial Network (GAN). The algorithm is compared with K-means and hierarchical clustering. Results show that the proposed algorithm achieves an average segmentation accuracy of 95.4% across all scenarios, improving by 7.7 and 5.6 percentage points compared to K-means (87.7%) and hierarchical clustering (89.8%), respectively. Processing 1,000 network elements takes 2.37 seconds, 18.3% and 32.6% less than K-means (2.90s) and hierarchical clustering (3.52s), respectively. The average adaptability index for scale switching is 0.92, significantly higher than that of the comparison algorithms. This algorithm can support distribution network fault handling, dispatch optimization, and long-term planning.

title: High-Voltage Tens Nanosecond Pulse System for Immune Activation in Pancreatic Cancer Treatment: From Design to In Vitro Evaluation
authors: Wen Dang, Yasir Alfadhl, Fatima S. A. Alzaabi, Xiaodong Chen
publish: 2025 IEEE Biomedical Circuits and Systems Conference (BioCAS)
abstract: In this work, a high-voltage nanosecond pulse generator is developed to deliver reconfigurable pulses for biomedical applications. This system adopts a capacitor-based energy storage architecture, where the capacitor is charged to a desired voltage level and rapidly discharged through solid-state switches to produce nanosecond-scale pulses. A Field-Programmable Gate Array (FPGA) is employed as the digital control core, enabling precise and programmable modulation of pulse parameters. All of these contribute to three key features: adjustable pulse width ($80-400 \mathrm{~ns}$), high output voltage (up to 2.4 kV), and tunable repetition frequency $(1-1000 \mathrm{~Hz})$. To enhance safety and portability, all functional modules are integrated into a customdesigned plastic enclosure, experimentally validated through electrical measurements. To investigate the biological effect of the generated pulses, cell survival of murine pancreatic cancer (PanC02) was assessed via CCK-8 assay at five post-treatment time points: $0 \mathrm{~h}, 6 \mathrm{~h}, 24 \mathrm{~h}, 48 \mathrm{~h}$, and 72 h. The results reveal an inverse correlation between pulse width and cell survival, indicating that nanosecond pulsed electric fields (nsPEFs) could serve as an effective and controllable treatment for targeted cancer cells. This approach shows strong potential to advance next-generation non-thermal immunotherapeutic strategies for cancer treatment.

title: Power-Conserving Propagation Graph Modeling for Diffuse Scattering Analysis via Rigorous Power Integration
authors: Yongwan Kim, Hooyoung Kim, Junpyo Jo, Semin Lee, Jungsuek Oh
publish: IEEE Transactions on Antennas and Propagation
abstract: Propagation graph (PG) models offer an efficient framework for simulating multi-link wireless channels through closed-form matrix operations. However, conventional Lambertian scattering-based PG models typically assume uniform power distribution over scattering area, which can violate the power conservation law in scenarios with large tile sizes or strong scattering, leading to spectral radii exceeding unity and invalid matrix inversion. To overcome this limitation, this study developed a physically consistent PG framework that guarantees power conservation regardless of tile size or scattering coefficient. By deriving a closed-form integration expression based on the Lambertian scattering pattern through a coordinate transformation fixed to the receiving tile, the proposed model performs rigorous power integration on each tile. This formulation enables accurate evaluation of power exchange between arbitrarily oriented tiles while introducing only approximately 0.2% additional computational overhead. Simulation results confirm that the proposed model consistently maintains spectral radii below one under various conditions, ensuring both mathematical convergence and physical power conservation, whereas the conventional model violates the power conservation law in most large-scale scenarios. This improvement enhances the reliability and scalability of PG-based multi-link wireless channel modeling in large-scale environments, without sacrificing computational efficiency.

title: High Performance Sobel Edge Detection using Hybrid Approximate Multiplier
authors: P.Durggashre, K.S.Neelu Kumari, R. Kavya, R.Jayaragavi, A.Kiruthika
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Automation, Computing and Renewable Systems (ICACRS)
abstract: Sobel edge detection is an important image processing tool used in many applications such as vision, medical, navigation and surveillance systems using 3×3 convolution kernels to extract structural features. Convolutional operations are typically achieved using precision multipliers, but they face constraints in terms of power, area and delay, which constrain scalability of design that are limited in resources. This presents the case for introducing a Verilog Sobel design based around high-performance streaming architecture where line buffers process the pixel stream and convolution modules are computing gradients in real time. Subsequently, performance of the traditional precision segmented multipliers is compared with a hybrid approximate method. In this hybrid method, the more significant bits are illustrated as computed exactly for the precision required based on potential errors, and the less significant bits are computed approximately to save logic, power and delay. This balance is essential to manage efficient operation while maintaining errors within acceptable tolerances offers an edge detection task. This architecture was configured to provide scalability, energy savings and design flexibility. Overall, it is very amenable to practical application in the IoT, robotics and other real-time, low-power, embedded platforms.

title: AeGANet: Adversarially-Enhanced Deep Learning Approach for GNSS Interference Discrimination
authors: Zhuo-Jian Cao, Jiang Liu, Wei Jiang, Fabio Dovis, Bai-Gen Cai
publish: IEEE Transactions on Aerospace and Electronic Systems
abstract: Technological advancements in Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS) have greatly brought substantial benefits to positioning services. However, given the inherent vulnerability of GNSS signals to radio-frequency interference (RFI), addressing safety concerns of GNSS-based positioning should be a necessary focus. To support the accurate and effective interference mitigation strategies, this research focuses on the interference nature discrimination, including both interference type and interference power level. Inspired by the profound capabilities of deep learning in image recognition, an improved adversarially-enhanced solution based on Generative Adversarial Network (AeGANet) is proposed, utilizing spectrogram of signals as feeding features. We focus on the pre-correction stage of the receiver, analyzing Intermediate Frequency (IF) signals using Short-Time Fourier Transform (STFT), and feeding the 3-channel spectrogram with power heat mapping into the model. Key innovations of the adversarial model include the label encoding of the generator, the dual-part discriminator design, the detached-objective training approach, as well as the loss function design. These improvements enable the adversarial model to generate and extend the interference dataset, enhancing discriminator training and boosting interference discrimination performance. Evaluated based on a GNSS positioning scenario and an interference test platform with seven signal types across varying interference power levels, the proposed solution demonstrates superior accuracy and performance, laying a solid foundation for the future implementation of effective interference mitigation techniques.

title: Farfield and Coupling Analysis of an Ultra Broadband THz Device
authors: Sagnik Banerjee, Kewei Wang, Ali Reda, Théo Hannotte, Jean-François Lapin, Flavie Braud, Romain Peretti
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: This paper analyzes the farfield radiation pattern of a broadband light concentrating device aimed at enhancing light-matter interactions at THz frequency where a 1mm long waveguide opens into an exponentially tapered antenna. We investigate the tradeoff with respect to the radiation pattern on the two orthogonal principal planes under two circumstances- lower opening angle with higher opening aperture diameter and, higher opening angle with lower opening aperture from 1.4THz to 4.25THz frequency. Our broader objective is to improve the coupling of the mode to the exiting farfield.

title: Color Vision Test: U-Net Powered Web Application for Color Vision Deficiency Assessment
authors: Bheemaneni Gnapika Chowdary, M.Mythily
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Automation, Computing and Renewable Systems (ICACRS)
abstract: Color vision deficiency (CVD), more commonly known as color blindness, is a common visual impairment that affects the discrimination of specific colors, affecting daily life, schooling, and occupations such as driving or graphic design. This paper introduces ColorVisionTest, a web-based system using deep learning to evaluate CVD in an easy-to-access and interactive manner. The system utilizes a U-Net model that has been trained on a special synthetic dataset of colored images with varying shapes and colors to accurately perform pixel-level color segmentation. Users engage with the application by selecting particular colors within images, and in accordance with their performance, the system diagnoses particular types of CVD, including red-green deficiencies (protanopia and deuteranopia) or blue-yellow deficiencies (tritanopia). The dataset generation pipeline generates diverse images consisting of red, green, blue, and yellow objects, along with multi-channel masks for supervised learning. Experimental findings indicate the U-Net model performs robust color separation, reaching a mean Intersection over Union (IoU) around 0.95 (following traditional benchmarks for synthetic datasets; actual performance can differ). Developed with Flask, the web application returns real-time feedback, diagnostic results, and accuracy rates, promising a scalable solution for large-scale CVD screening. This piece of work adds to digital health, learning, and inclusive tech by offering a cheap substitute to traditional clinical testing.

title: Signatures of Ultrafast Structural Dynamics and Phase Segregation in Photoexcited SnSe
authors: Benjamin J. Dringoli, Zhongzhen Luo, Mercouri Kanatzidis, Mark Sutton, David G. Cooke
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: In this work we use time-resolved multi-terahertz (THz) spectroscopy to observe phonon linewidth and optical conductivity dynamics in the thermoelectric tin selenide (SnSe). At early pump delays (< 0.5 ps), a broadened phonon response is observed near the strongly coupled TO phonon near 3.8 THz in the Peierl’s-distorted Pnma phase. At longer pump delays and scaling with excitation fluence, this phonon narrows, opposite to the typical temperature-induced broadening with additional deposited pump energy and consistent with a restoration of phonon degeneracy expected for a transition towards the more symmetric Immm phase. Additionally, above and below all phonon frequencies, dynamics in the optical conductivity align with our previous work suggesting nucleated domains of metallic surface states, in agreement with recent time-resolved ARPES results.

title: An Intelligent TCM Diagnosis System with Localized LLMs and Modular Multimodal Reasoning Enhanced by RAG
authors: Runhe Huang, Adili Abudukeranmu, Chunyu Tu, Zhiyong Yu, Zeyang Cui, Bowen Du
publish: 2025 IEEE Cyber Science and Technology Congress (CyberSciTech)
abstract: Traditional Chinese Medicine (TCM) diagnosis relies on multimodal data including tongue images, voice signals, pulse waveforms, and symptom descriptions obtained through inspection, auscultation, inquiry, and palpation. Recent advances in large language models (LLMs) and multimodal integration offer new opportunities for intelligent TCM diagnostics. However, current approaches suffer from unstructured modality handling, inefficient cross-modal fusion, and limited interpretability, hindering clinical adoption. This paper proposes a locally deployed LLM-based TCM diagnostic system with structured multimodal perception. Four AI agents—Observation, Listening, Inquiry, and Palpation—are coordinated via Modular Component Processing (MCP) and multimodal Retrieval-Augmented Generation (mRAG) for structured feature extraction and semantic fusion. A central reasoning module generates diagnostic results and personalized health advice using structured prompts and patient history. A certainty assessment mechanism further enhances interpretability and reliability. Experiments demonstrate strong generalizability and scalability, validating the system’s potential for intelligent multimodal TCM diagnosis.

title: Contact Resistance Determination of AlGaAs/GaAs TeraFET THz Detectors via Terahertz Responsivity Measurements
authors: Rahul Yadav, Fahd Rushd Faridi, Florian Bek, Hong Lu, Andreas Penirschke, Sascha Preu
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: We demonstrate a method for extracting the contact resistance of AlGaAs/GaAs TeraFET THz detector technology from low-frequency THz measurements (0.1 to 0.5 THz) in a non-resonant operation regime. Six THz detectors with different channel length and width ratios are investigated. The contact resistance per width can be extracted from the relation between current responsivity and the DC source-drain resistance, which allows for calculating the contact resistances for any device made from the same material.

title:

                    KDH: Fine-Grained Feature Fusion Knowledge Distillation Hashing for Cross-Modal Retrieval
authors: Liangliang Su, Yubin Liu, Li Gao, Xiao Wei, Yalong Yang
publish: 2025 IEEE 31th International Conference on Parallel and Distributed Systems (ICPADS)
abstract: In recent years, deep cross-modal hashing retrieval methods have attracted extensive attention due to their strong ability to learn efficient binary encodings. However, they still face two main challenges: 1) insufficient fusion of cross-modal information, leading to low semantic quality of the generated hash codes. 2) limited scalability for deployment in lightweight frameworks. To address these issues, this paper proposes a novel cross-modal hashing method based on knowledge distillation, termed Fine-Grained Feature Fusion Knowledge Distillation Hashing (F<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sup>KDH). Specifically, the teacher model incorporates the AFM that thoroughly fuses heterogeneous information, effectively capturing salient semantic cues in cross-modal data to enhance the weighting of important regions. Moreover, we employ a cross-modal knowledge distillation strategy to transfer the rich semantic knowledge captured by the teacher to a deliberately lightweight student model, enabling it to learn compact yet expressive hash representations while greatly reducing computational complexity. Experimental results on multiple benchmark datasets demonstrate that, compared to existing cross-modal hashing methods, our approach achieves significant model compression without sacrificing retrieval accuracy.

title: A Hybrid Optimization Approach for a Continuous and Efficient Pump Operation Scheduling in Water Supply Systems
authors: Marlene Brás, Ana Moura, António Andrade-Campos
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: Solving the pump scheduling problem in Water Supply Systems (WSS) is essential for reducing energy costs and ensuring operational efficiency. This study applies the Smart Dynamic Local Search (Smart-DLS), a hybrid optimization framework, as a decision support tool to reduce the costs of five days of continuous pumping operation in a real WSS. Smart-DLS integrates deterministic local search with an intelligent shaking process, enhancing solution robustness and scalability while efficiently exploring the solution space. The results demonstrate that Smart-DLS achieved an approximately 19% cost reduction while ensuring tank-level compliance and offering flexible solutions that balance cost efficiency and pump wear reduction. These outcomes demonstrate the Smart-DLS as an effective decision support tool for real-time WSS optimization.

title: Machine Learning and RBF Interpolation on Nanofluid Flow in a Rounded Corner Cavity
authors: Merve Gurbuz-Caldag, Bengisen Pekmen
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: In this study, three machine learning techniques and RBF interpolation are compared on a heat transfer and fluid flow problem in a cavity having rounded corner through the left bottom corner. The two dimensional, time dependent dimensionless governing equations of the problem are numerically solved by the radial basis function (RBF) method for space derivatives and by the backward Euler method for time derivatives. The differentially heated cavity has straight hot left wall and cold right wall, the top wall is the adiabatic wall and the bottom wall involving the rounded corner is the insulated wall. The numerical results show that the presence of the rounded corner causes convective heat transfer to increase. A dataset involving inputs as Rayleigh number and the radius of the circular corner and output as the average Nusselt number along the hot left wall is collected from the numerical results. The machine learning techniques, neural networks, gaussian process regression and ensemble learning as well as RBF interpolation are deployed for modeling. Each modeling results in small mean squared error metric results, but the best modeling is found by RBF interpolation.

title: Towards Communication-Efficient Heterogeneous Collaborative Perception via Semantic Disentanglement
authors: Shijie Feng, Tiange Fu, Hongru Zhao, Guiyang Luo, Quan Yuan, Jinglin Li
publish: 2025 IEEE 31th International Conference on Parallel and Distributed Systems (ICPADS)
abstract: Heterogeneous collaborative perception enables interconnected agents to share and fuse intermediate features extracted from multimodal sensor data, thereby enhancing robustness and reducing perception blind spots. However, shared high-dimensional features often contain redundant and modality-specific information, leading to semantic inconsistencies and excessive communication overhead. To address these challenges, we propose an efficient communication framework for heterogeneous collaborative perception. This framework integrates a shared-private feature decoupling module that disentangles cross-modal features into shared and private components, sharing only shared feature to improve communication efficiency. Additionally, we design a spatial redundancy elimination module to remove background information from transmitted features, further reducing bandwidth consumption. Collectively, these modules enable compact and communication-efficient perception capabilities across heterogeneous modalities, models, and tasks. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed framework significantly reduces communication overhead in complex heterogeneous scenarios while maintaining perception accuracy.

title: A Hybrid Machine Learning Framework for Water Quality Index Prediction Using Feature-Based Neural Network Initialization
authors: Ali Al Bataineh, Bandi Vamsi, Scott Alan Smith
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: Accurate prediction of the Water Quality Index (WQI) is essential for protecting public health and managing freshwater resources. Existing models often rely on arbitrary weight initialization and make limited use of ensemble learning, which results in unstable performance and reduced interpretability. This study introduces a hybrid machine learning framework that combines feature-informed neural network initialization with gradient boosting (XGBoost) to address these limitations. Neural network weights are initialized using feature significance scores derived from SHapley Additive exPlanations (SHAP) and predictions are iteratively refined using XGBoost. The model was trained and evaluated using the public Quality of Freshwater dataset and compared against several baselines, including Random Forest, Support Vector Regression (SVR), a conventional Artificial Neural Network (ANN) with Xavier initialization and an XGBoost-only model. Our framework achieved an accuracy of 86.9%, an F1-score of 0.849 and a Receiver Operating Characteristic–Area Under the Curve (ROC-AUC) of 0.894, outperforming all comparative methods. Ablation experiments showed that both the SHAP-based initialization and the boosting component each improved performance over simpler baselines.

title: Blockchain-Secured Multi-Agent Digital Twin Framework for Distributed Manufacturing With Fuzzy PID Control
authors: Shuo Kang
abstract: Industry 4.0’s quick development and the introduction of 6G connectivity technologies have increased the need for intelligent, adaptable, and safe control systems in remote industrial settings. This research explores a Blockchain-Secured Multi- Agent Digital Twin and Deep Net Framework (BSMDTDF) to enhance real-time collaboration, system reliability, and operational efficiency across decentralized manufacturing networks. The framework utilizes IoT-driven smart manufacturing datasets with preprocessing for noise reduction and normalization. To create dynamic virtual recreations of physical assets and facilitate real-time monitoring, predictive maintenance, and performance enhancement, the framework makes use of Digital Twin (DT) technology. A Multi-Agent System (MAS) architecture supports decentralized decision-making, allowing autonomous agents to coordinate manufacturing resources and adapt to fluctuating production demands. To ensure data integrity and trust in distributed environments, a Blockchain layer with smart contracts secures inter-agent communication and transaction records. The integration of 6G networks provides ultra-low latency, massive device connectivity, and high-speed data transmission, significantly improving responsiveness and synchronization among distributed agents. Furthermore, Fuzzy PID control enhances process adaptability by dynamically tuning parameters under uncertain and nonlinear operating conditions. To further improve predictive accuracy and control optimization, a Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) deep learning model is incorporated to learn temporal dependencies and forecast control behavior for enhanced stability and precision. Experimental simulations demonstrate f1-score (98.41%), accuracy (98.56%), recall (98.23%), and precision (99.53%) compared to conventional methods. The BSMDTDF framework establishes sustainable manufacturing through the convergence of blockchain security, DT intelligence, 6G connectivity, multi-agent coordination, fuzzy adaptive control, and DL framework.

title: Retraction Notice: Convolutional Neural Network based Driver Fatigue Recognition by Utilizing the Facial Features
authors: S Suseela, A Karunya Abinisha, S Harini, K Pradhiksha
publish: 2022 6th International Conference on Trends in Electronics and Informatics (ICOEI)
abstract: Drowsiness and sleepiness impair a purpose pressure's capacity to alter his or her car, further to their everyday reflexes, identification, and interest. Drivers with lower levels of vigilance are seen riding at night or overdriving, beginning accidents and posing a severe hazard to human beings and life-style. As a end result, it's far essential to encompass a riding pressure useful resource gadget that can come upon drowsiness and fatigue in drivers in this current fashion within the car business corporation. This research gives a nonintrusive prototype computer imaginative and prescient device for tracking a driving force's alertness in real time. Eye tracking is a critical era for destiny driving force assistance structures while you bear in mind that human eyes deliver a plethora of information about the purpose force's situation, which include gaze, hobby degree, and weariness diploma. One difficulty that many eye monitoring systems proposed thus far have is their sensitivity to modifications in lights assets. This has the effect of severely restricting their options for automobile bundles. In the sector of laptop imaginative and prescient, real-time detection and monitoring of interest is a hot topic. In terms of facial alignment, hobby localization and tracking can be helpful. This studies demonstrates a method for actual-time eye detection and monitoring that works in numerous lighting fixtures conditions. It is primarily based totally on the improvement of a hardware device for actual-time acquisition of a motive force's images, the usage of a digital digicam, and the advent of a software software for eye tracking which can prevent accidents

title: Adaptive Multimodal Deep Learning for Emotion Recognition via Facial Micro-Expressions and Physiological Signals
authors: Mushika Shylaja, M Sheshikala
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Automation, Computing and Renewable Systems (ICACRS)
abstract: This paper examines the challenge of recognizing emotions by combining fleeting facial micro-expressions with slower physiological responses, acknowledging that each modality alone often provides an incomplete picture of human affect. To address this, the study adopts an adaptive deep-learning framework designed to align sub-second facial events with incremental physiological signals, adjust its fusion strategy according to real-time reliability and generalize across subjects and datasets. The methodology integrates high-frame-rate micro-expression sequences captured at 200 frames per second with synchronized physiological windows, processed through separate encoders and merged through a gating mechanism that learns how much emphasis each modality deserves at different moments. Using this framework, the fused model achieved an accuracy of 85.2 percent and an F1 score of 0.84, outperforming facial only and physiology only models and maintaining 80.3 percent accuracy even when one modality was intentionally removed during inference. Cross dataset tests further confirmed strong generalization, with the fused model reaching 78.6 percent accuracy on unseen data while preserving stable temporal alignment and improved calibration behavior. The paper concludes that the proposed approach offers a more resilient and trustworthy solution for emotion recognition, especially in settings where signals fluctuate or user conditions vary widely.

title: Transport optimization of an anaerobic digestion co-product in a closed-loop supply chain
authors: Mathieu Faure, Tasseda Boukherroub, Jean-François Audy, Pierre-Olivier Lemire
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: This research explores the opportunities and challenges of integrated logistics, covering both the inbound (supply) and outbound (distribution) transportation to/from an anaerobic digestion plant involving several types of suppliers and customers in a region of Quebec (Canada). All participants supply organic residues (in liquid or solid form), and some are also customers who require to receive and use the co-product. The residues are transported to the plant by two types of truck (tanker and solid bulk) of different capacities, where they are transformed by anaerobic digestion. The resulting co-product, a digestate used as an organic fertilizer, must then be efficiently distributed to the customers. The main objective of this project is to size a fleet of trucks adapted to the needs and capacity of the plant under study and minimize transportation costs. After defining and modeling the problem by using mathematical optimization, several scenarios reflecting different transportation strategies (backhauling and heterogeneous truck fleet configuration) have been tested. This article presents and compares the results of the different scenarios, highlighting the economic benefits and suggesting future research avenues. The preliminary results show that substantial transportation cost savings can be obtained by using backhauling and a heterogeneous fleet, reaching up to 17% when both are combined while decreasing the traveled distance by up to 42%.

title: Miniaturized Foldable Electrodes with Direct CMOS Integration for Implantable Applications
authors: Junyan Qian, Melania Coronese, Andrea Pafundo, Ali Meimandi, Gian Luca Barbruni, Marco Carminati, Sandro Carrara
publish: 2025 IEEE Biomedical Circuits and Systems Conference (BioCAS)
abstract: This study demonstrates the feasibility of directly integrating foldable microelectrodes (starting from $250 \mu \mathrm{~m}$ width and $1600 \mu \mathrm{~m}$ length) with CMOS front-end for implantable biomedical applications. Mechanical robustness was evaluated through Finite Element Method (FEM) simulations and validated by implantation into an agarose phantom, showing no structural failure. Electrical performance was assessed using Electrochemical Impedance Spectroscopy (EIS) measurement, with results in agreement with values reported in the literature, confirming the integrity of the microfabrication process. Additionally, an electrochemical sensing front-end was also designed, consisting of a full-custom digital potentiostat to illustrate functional capability. This study presents a complete and reproducible microfabrication workflow, providing a promising foundation for future development of highly integrated, minimally invasive bioelectronic interfaces.

title: GRU-Based Sequence Detection for Faster-than-Nyquist Signaling
authors: O. Tokluoglu, A. Cicek, E. Cavus, E. Bedeer, H. Yanikomeroglu
publish: IEEE Open Journal of Vehicular Technology
abstract: This paper presents a deep learning-based detector for faster-than-Nyquist (FTN) signaling that leverages a Gated Recurrent Unit (GRU) architecture optimized using the Nesterov-accelerated Adaptive Moment Estimation (NADAM) algorithm. Compared with Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks commonly employed in similar detection tasks, GRUs offer improved computational efficiency, while NADAM contributes to stable and effective convergence in non-convex optimization settings. Rather than relying on generic neural models, the proposed design explicitly aligns the GRU input structure with the one-sided inter-symbol interference (ISI) span of FTN signaling, enabling the network to learn interference patterns efficiently without incurring unnecessary complexity. This structured integration results in reduced computational burden and enhanced convergence behavior. Simulation results demonstrate that the NADAM-optimized GRU achieves bit error rate (BER) performance close to the optimal BCJR algorithm for <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\tau \geq 0.7$</tex-math></inline-formula>, while offering superior computational efficiency compared with conventional deep learning-based detectors. A detailed complexity comparison with the M-BCJR algorithm shows that the proposed approach reduces hardware resource usage—measured in Look-Up Tables (LUTs)– -by up to 76% while maintaining comparable BER performance in the same <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\tau$</tex-math></inline-formula> regime. Additional evaluations further highlight its robustness, demonstrating reliable performance in quasi-static multipath Rayleigh fading channels and strong compatibility with LDPC-coded FTN transmission. These results collectively underscore the practicality and efficiency of the proposed GRU-based FTN detector.

title: Comparison of Classification Algorithms for Notebook Fault Prediction System Using Machine Learning
authors: Ralitza Raynova
abstract: This paper presents a comparative analysis of five machine learning classification algorithms that were applied to predict notebook hardware and software faults, using structured system logs and symptom descriptions. A Python-based microservice was developed to automate the construction of the dataset, including text normalisation and TF-IDF vectorisation. The models that were evaluated were Random Forest, XGBoost, Logistic Regression, Support Vector Classifier (SVC) and LinearSVC. The experimental results show that LinearSVC achieved the highest performance, with macro-averaged accuracy, precision, recall and F1-score of around 98.15%. These results highlight the effectiveness of integrating text-based features and lightweight classifiers for the automated prediction of faults in computing systems.

title: A Hierarchical Attention Network with PCA-Driven Feature Selection for Enhanced Credit Card Fraud Detection
authors: R. Vaishnavi, Anish John M, Mohamed Farhan B, Manju Sri S, Sona Anna Mathew, Surya K S
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Automation, Computing and Renewable Systems (ICACRS)
abstract: Credit card fraud detection is difficult due to significant class disparity and the evolving tactics employed by fraudsters. This paper presents a Hierarchical Attention based GRU–Transformer (HA-GRU-T) model that combines Gated Recurrent Units for short-term dependency modeling with Transformer based self-attention for long-range contextual learning. The model employs a hierarchical attention mechanism to provide interpretability at both local and global temporal scales. Four feature selection methodologies Pearson Correlation, Information Gain (IG), Random Forest Importance (RFI), and Principal Component Analysis (PCA) were carefully assessed alongside advanced deep learning (DL) baselines, including Deep Reinforcement Learning (DRL), Gated Recurrent Unit (GRU), Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM), and Transformer models. Experimental findings on the Credit Card Fraud Detection benchmark dataset demonstrate that PCA consistently provides the most efficient feature representation. The HA-GRU-T model, integrated with PCA, attained an accuracy of 99.0%, precision of 98.6%, recall of 97.8%, and an F1-score of 98.2%, surpassing all baseline models. These findings illustrate that integrating sophisticated dimensionality reduction with hybrid hierarchical attention structures establishes a strong framework for practical fraud detection.

title: Acquisition of kinematic and sEMG data from young and older adults using an upper limb exoskeleton
authors: Hellen Rivero-Pineda, Estefania Suarez-Perez, Manuela Gomez-Correa, Javier M. Antelis, Luis G. Hernández-Rojas, Mariana Ballesteros, David Cruz-Ortiz
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: This work describes the acquisition of kinematic and surface electromyography (sEMG) data from young and older adults during the execution of wrist movements using an upper limb rehabilitation robot (ULRR), along with a wristband equipped with inertial measurement units (IMUs) and sEMG sensors. These devices enable the observation of electrical muscle activation in the forearm during movement execution, providing valuable insights into the neuromuscular dynamics involved in motor control and movement mechanics. The description covers the robot configuration, sensor array, graphical user interfaces (GUIs) for visualizing robot data and biosignals, the experimental protocol, the database structure, and the signal processing and evaluation procedures. For the experimental protocol, 20 participants, 10 young and 10 older adults, were recruited. The test consisted of four basic wrist movements: radial deviation, ulnar deviation, flexion, and extension, which were performed in random order under the guidance of the ULRR GUI. The sEMG analysis indicated that older adults tend to overuse specific muscles and exhibit a higher percentage of compensatory movements $(38.5 \%)$ than younger participants $(24.25 \%)$. The study’s findings enable the identification of age-related differences in muscle activation and compensation, aiding the design of personalized rehabilitation programs and improved devices to enhance motor function in older adults.

title: Power Supply Units in Bee Behaviour Monitoring Systems
authors: Ivaylo Penev, Dimitar Avramov
abstract: Power supply units are an integral part of bee behaviour monitoring systems. These power supply units typically consist of a solar panel, batteries or accumulators, and a charge controller. The paper proposes three solutions, implemented by the authors. The advantages and disadvantages of each solution are discussed. The proposed solutions are applicable in real-world operational environments.

title: A 1200 V AGD with Voltage Regulator and Deadtime Control using 0.5-um GaN Process
authors: Tzung-Je Lee, Jyu-Heng Chen, Zi-Yi Wang
abstract: This paper proposes an active gate driver (AGD) capable of controlling 1200 V silicon carbide (SiC) power transistors. To prevent overshoot voltage generated during switching from affecting the AGD, a voltage regulator with low line regulation and low load regulation is proposed and utilized. Additionally, to avoid simultaneous conduction of high-side and low-side power transistors, which can lead to significant power loss and potential damage to the gate driver chip, a Dead-time control circuit is included. The proposed design is implemented with TSMC 0.5-um GaN process. The output power is up to 1200 W and the output slew rate is 86.3 V/ns.

title: Model-based Predictive control of a concentrated solar plant for heat production
authors: Eliott Girard, Stéphane Thil, Julien Eynard, Stéphane Grieu
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: Industrial heat processes are one of the most energy-intensive and polluting activities in the industry. Concentrated solar energy could be used to supply thermal energy to industrial processes, however, the intermittency of this energy source makes it difficult to satisfy a specific energy demand. Adaptation to this high variability can be achieved by using real-time control of solar plants in combination with energy storage systems. To address this issue, this paper presents a real-time control strategy of a parabolic trough solar plant used to produce industrial heat. The control strategy uses a Model-based Predictive Control (MPC) method based on an optimization algorithm, with the objective of satisfying a heat demand by modifying the mass flow rate of the heat transfer fluid in the storage system, which is a thermocline tank. In order to determine the behaviour of the solar plant, the optimization algorithm requires forecasts of solar irradiance, however, it is well-known that short-term forecasts of this quantity are difficult to obtain due to atmospheric disturbances. Therefore, the influence of forecast errors has been assessed to ensure the robustness of the control strategy using available forecast models: a smart persistence of incident solar energy and a model relying on the analysis of ground-based sky images. The integration of these predictions has also been studied to reduce the performance loss due to forecast errors by adapting the forecast horizon and integrating measured data.

title: An Efficient Electromagnetic Scattering Analysis Method for Multiple Objects based on Characteristic Modes and MLFMA
authors: Zhaoyuan Wang, Jihong Gu, Jiamin Shi, Chao-Fu Wang, Dazhi Ding
publish: IEEE Transactions on Antennas and Propagation
abstract: An efficient method, characteristic mode-multilevel fast multipole algorithm-clustering (CM-MLFMA-Clustering) method, is proposed for analyzing electromagnetic scattering in multi-object systems. This approach integrates theory of characteristic modes (TCM) with the fast multipole method (FMM) to accelerate the computation of total scattering contributions, including individual object scattering and mutual coupling effects. To accurately account for mutual coupling effects induced by scattering fields between objects, we introduce a novel coupling modal weighting coefficient (CMWC), extending the conventional modal weighting coefficient (MWC). The total scattering fields are obtained through a linear superposition of dominant modes weighted by both MWC and CMWC. Additionally, a dual-scheme FMM is proposed to enhance computational efficiency. The first scheme employs MLFMA for pairwise electromagnetic coupling calculations, while the second scheme utilizes a K-means clustering algorithm to efficiently manage large multi-object systems. Numerical results confirm the method’s accuracy, demonstrating a significant reduction in memory requirements and computational complexity, achieving approximately O(N) scaling observed in numerical simulations.

title: A Unipolar IGZO TFT-based 9.23 μW Operational Amplifier Achieving 73.7 dB Loop Gain and 554.6 kHz Bandwidth
authors: Zhenhan Wang, Kwantae Kim
publish: 2025 IEEE Biomedical Circuits and Systems Conference (BioCAS)
abstract: This work presents a 73.7 dB gain and 554.6 kHz gain bandwidth (GBW) operational amplifier (OpAmp) based on a cross-coupling equalization (XE) technique implemented using 600 nm indium gallium zinc oxide (IGZO) thin-film transistor (TFT) on a flexible substrate. Designing high-performance analog circuits with IGZO TFT poses several challenges, primarily due to the low gain caused by the unipolar (N-type only) nature of transistors. To address these limitations, this work proposes a XE technique that enhances DC loop gain, GBW, and DC input range, ensuring robust closed-loop operation. The proposed XE OpAmp achieves a 42.5 dB increase in DC loop gain at an input DC level of 1 V while maintaining a phase margin of 67°. Additionally, the input voltage range is extended by $\mathbf{2. 5} \times$, from $\mathbf{0. 9 7 ~ V}-\mathbf{1. 5 9 ~ V}$ to $\mathbf{0. 6 8 ~ V}-\mathbf{2. 2 4 ~ V}$. It achieves a low power consumption of $9.23 \mu \mathrm{~W}$ across a capacitive load range from 0.6 pF to 113 pF, with an average slew rate decreasing from $793.6 \mathrm{~V} / \mathrm{ms}$ to $13.6 \mathrm{~V} / \mathrm{ms}$ as the load increases.

title: Control of an HVDC transmission system with virtual synchronous machines providing inertia
authors: Florian Reißner, George Weiss
abstract: This paper proposes a virtual synchronous machine (VSM)-based control scheme of a high voltage direct current (HVDC) system to provide inertial frequency support without a dedicated energy reservoir, based on the energy stored in the submodule capacitors of the modular multilevel converters (MMCs) and the HVDC line itself. In order to achieve this, we introduce a direct current (DC)-voltage control scheme consisting of a slow and a very fast controller that allow the cell voltages and the DC-voltages to drop or rise by up to 10% in order to provide an energy reserve for inertia emulation, while protecting the system from over- and undervoltages. We investigate this control in a setup similar to the German Suedlink project, with 4 MMC converters in a rigid bipolar (RBP) configuration with a <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\pm 525$</tex-math></inline-formula>kV DC-line. Simulations show the performance of the system to provide inertia when the frequency in the power grid drops. The protection scheme is activated only when the DCvoltage drops below (or rises above) predefined thresholds, and is able to prevent the DC-voltage from leaving the allowed range. The control scheme is validated in simulations and compared to a more standard control scheme, where a fast DC-voltage controller is employed at one terminal.

title:
Mapping the Temperature Dependent Surface States of Bi
                    <sub>2</sub>
                    Te
                    <sub>3</sub>
                    Topological Insulator Flakes by Ultra-cryogenic Terahertz Near-Field Nanoscopy
authors: Xinyun Liu, Piet Schoenherr, Keir Murphy, Thorsten Hesjedal, Jessica Boland
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: Topological insulators (TIs) have drawn considerable attention for next generation high sensitivity, high efficiency devices thanks to their unique metallic surface conductivity via their topologically-protected surface states (TSSs). In this study, we utilized near-field nanoimaging and nanoscale spectroscopy in the Terahertz (THz) frequency range to explore the optical response of the surface layer from Bi2Te3 TI flakes. In all cases, we observe a higher near-field optical response from the TI flakes compared to a Si substrate. This contrast increases for more surface sensitive probing, which indicates the presence of a conductive surface state. In addition, we have performed temperature dependent THz nanoscopy and demonstrate a significantly enhanced near-field contrast for the TI flake at a sample temperature of 8.9 K compared to the Si substrate. This temperature-dependent behavior provides vital insight into the underlying mechanisms behind the observed conductive surface state in TI materials.

title: Green Data Centers: Trends, Technologies, and Strategies for Sustainable Digital Infrastructure
authors: Anita M, Kuppulakshmi. G, Dhivya Bharathi R, R. Kennady, D. Lekha, T. Veeramani
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Automation, Computing and Renewable Systems (ICACRS)
abstract: As use of data continues to increase and the use of digital services, the issue of the footprint of data centres has become a very sensitive issue. It was also observed that data centres contribute immensely to energy consumption and carbon footprint around the world, creating the demand for green solutions. This survey paper focuses on the present trends, the technologies, and the strategies that have been adopted to increase efficiency and reduce the environmental impact of data centres. Areas of interest encompass hardware design for efficiency, renewable power systems, cooling technologies, virtualization and the part played by green accreditation programs like Energy Star and LEED. This paper also looks at the barriers to green practices in data centres which include high initial costs, retrofitting old structures and the unreliability of renewable energy. But at the same time, it outlines possibilities for work in a new environment with the help of new technologies, such as AI, quantum computing, edge computing, etc. In addition, partnership with industries and government policies are fostering the practice of sustainability. As data centres develop, they will become critical in the drive toward creating a more sustainable global information economy.

title: Network Traffic Anomaly Detection Based on a Composite Diffusion Model and Expected Perturbation Score
authors: Sirui Yao, Peng Gao, Qingyang Tong, Mingyu Li
publish: 2025 IEEE Cyber Science and Technology Congress (CyberSciTech)
abstract: Anomalous traffic detection in network security faces challenges of complex and variable malicious behavior patterns and low detection accuracy. Existing methods based on static representation learning have limited expressive capabilities in modeling complex traffic semantic relationships, making it difficult to effectively identify hidden advanced threat behaviors. To address this issue, this paper proposes a score- guided diffusion graph contrastive learning framework for network traffic anomaly detection. The framework models network traffic as graph structures, learns traffic representation features through Deep Graph Infomax (DGI), and introduces diffusion models to perform controllable noise perturbations on normal traffic, thereby enhancing the model's ability to characterize normal distributions.The main contribution of this paper is the proposal of Expected Perturbation Score (EPS) as a quantitative indicator of anomaly degree. By training a score network to predict gradient information during the diffusion process, the method calculates expected response values under different perturbation intensities to identify anomalous patterns. Higher EPS values indicate that the traffic sample deviates more significantly from the normal distribution, suggesting a higher probability of anomaly.Experimental results on the CTU-13 dataset demonstrate that the proposed method achieves excellent performance in detecting complex threats such as botnets and malware communications, with improvements of 5%~6% in accuracy and recall compared to existing methods, validating the effectiveness and robustness of the approach in network anomaly detection scenarios.

title: Integrating TinkerCad in the Flipped Classroom Method*
authors: J. Udvaros, I. Pšenáková
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: The rapid development of digital technologies opens up new opportunities for the renewal of educational methodologies. The aim of our study is to investigate the applicability of TinkerCad, a web-based 3D modeling and circuit simulation tool, as an educational technology within the framework of the flipped classroom method. The research was conducted using qualitative and quantitative methods, including the analysis of student feedback, observations, and comparison of learning outcomes in traditional and flipped classroom environments.The results show that TinkerCad effectively supports active learning, encourages the development of problem-solving skills, and increases student motivation. Combined with the flipped classroom method, it provides students with the opportunity to master prior knowledge at their own pace, while practical application and joint problem solving come to the fore during classroom work. The study presents in detail the pedagogical potential of TinkerCad and makes suggestions for its effective integration into educational environments.

title: Optical Phase Stabilization for Photomixing-Based Terahertz Generation Using Interferometric Feedback
authors: Amalina Athira Ibrahim, Isao Morohashi, Kazutoshi Kato, Norihiko Sekine
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: An interferometric optical phase stabilization system is proposed and demonstrated for application in photomixing-based terahertz (THz) generation. The system suppresses phase fluctuations between dual optical paths by utilizing a backward-propagating pilot lightwave in a Mach-Zehnder interferometer (MZI) configuration. A feedback-controlled piezoelectric fiber stretcher, driven by a proportional–integral–derivative (PID) controller, actively corrects phase drift in real time. Time- and frequency-domain analyses confirm that low-frequency noise, specifically a 0.22 Hz drift component, is reduced by over 97% (∼32dB suppression). The stabilization scheme is compact, low-complexity, and directly applicable to photomixing-based THz sources, ensuring improved spectral purity and power stability.

title: Polarization-dependent THz conductivity of sodium mesitylene sulphonate (SMS) single crystal
authors: Yamuna Murtunge, Ajinkya Punjal, S.B. Kulkarni, S.S. Prabhu
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: This study investigates the polarization-dependent complex optical conductivity of sodium mesitylene sulphonate crystal. The optical conductivity was extracted across the 0.2-2.5 THz for full rotation from 0°-360°. We observed two distinct phonon modes at two different frequencies at 0.94THz and 1.93 THz, whose oscillator strength gradually increased as the polarization angle increased. Reaching maximum, coupling approximately at 50° followed by decreasing till 140°, after which the strength of the oscillator is increased again as this crystal has a C2 space group.

title: Research on Intelligent Substation Operational Status Monitoring and Evaluation Based on Digital Twins
authors: Dong Jie, Xu Yaoting, Zhu Xiaoxiao, Zhu Chenxin
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Automation, Electronics and Electrical Engineering (AUTEEE)
abstract: As smart grids undergo profound evolution towards digitalisation and intelligentisation, the real-time and accurate monitoring and assessment of operational status at smart substations—the core hubs of the grid—become pivotal to ensuring grid security and stability. Traditional monitoring methods suffer from data silos, disconnect between physical and virtual domains, and delayed evaluation, rendering them inadequate for complex operational scenarios. This paper proposes a digital twin-based monitoring and evaluation scheme for smart substation operational status. Firstly, a four-layer architecture system is established, encompassing the physical entity layer, data interaction layer, virtual twin layer, and service application layer, achieving precise mapping across multiple physical domains and dimensions within the substation. Secondly, a multi-source data fusion monitoring mechanism is designed, leveraging edge computing and cloud-based collaborative processing of heterogeneous data—including electrical, mechanical, and environmental—to enhance monitoring timeliness. Finally, a three-tier assessment model— comprising an indicator system, weight allocation, and comprehensive evaluation—is established. Integrating the Analytic Hierarchy Process (AHP) with fuzzy comprehensive evaluation enables quantitative grading of substation operational status. Using a 220kV smart substation as the experimental subject, a digital twin simulation platform was constructed. Through normal operating condition and fault simulation experiments, the system demonstrated: 98.7% accuracy in monitoring data, 96.3% consistency between state assessments and actual operating conditions. This effectively enhances substation operation and maintenance efficiency alongside fault early warning capabilities, providing technical support for the full lifecycle management of smart substations.
