title:
Terahertz Spectroscopic Analysis of Boson Peak and Elastic Heterogeneity in Glassy LiCl·6H
                    <sub>2</sub>
                    O
authors: Soo Han Oh, Dan Kyotani, Suguru Kitani, Yasuhiro Fujii, Shinji Kohara, Tatsuya Mori
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: We present a terahertz (THz) spectroscopic investigation of the vibrational density of states (VDOS) in glassy LiCL6H2θ, revealing a distinct boson peak (BP) near 1 THz and additional spectral features at frequencies above the BP. The BP behavior was successfully analyzed using heterogeneous elasticity theory (HET), providing insights into the nanomechanical properties of the system. The spectral response at higher frequencies originates from the bending vibrations of hydrogen- bonded water molecules. Additionally, we explored the interaction between BP and terahertz light. The frequency dependence of the infrared light-vibration coupling coefficient was found to be nearly linear, which is not typically expected in glassy materials and indicates the need for refinement in current theoretical descriptions.

title: Driver Driving Monitoring System Based on STM32
authors: Tong Fu, Guanbo Ding, Yusheng Li
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Automation, Electronics and Electrical Engineering (AUTEEE)
abstract: Based on cutting-edge technologies such as single-chip microcomputer technology, sensor technology, and wireless communication technology, this design proposes a driver driving monitoring system based on STM32, which consists of two parts: software and hardware. It serves as a key breakthrough to solve the technical bottleneck of "real-time perception - accurate tracking - timely alarm". Experimental results show that the system features low power consumption and high stability. It can accurately sense the driver's safety status, track the position, and determine potential safety hazards in various simulated scenarios. In emergency situations, it can adopt improvement and early warning plans to ensure vehicle safety and accurately respond to urban governance pain points. The results indicate that this design has practical application value.

title: Real-time Transmission and Remote Intelligent Diagnosis of Oscillation Wave Detection Data for Dry-Type Reactors Based on 5G+MEC
authors: Minhu Xu, Chengnan Cui, Hang Zhang, Hongda Yang, Zhen Zhang, Chenyang Ma
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Automation, Electronics and Electrical Engineering (AUTEEE)
abstract: To address the poor real-time data transmission performance of oscillation wave detection in dry-type reactors and the insufficient diagnostic capabilities of traditional algorithms using small sample sizes, a diagnostic solution combining a 5G+MEC real-time transmission system and an improved temporal convolutional network (ITCN) is proposed. The transmission system utilizes a "one-station-one-node" MEC deployment, combining Kalman filter preprocessing with LZ77 compression (reducing data volume by 60%). A dedicated 5G slice (uplink/downlink bandwidth of 20/10 Mbps) and HARQ+LDPC security are designed, resulting in end-to-end latency of ≤50ms and packet loss rate of ≤0.5%. The ITCN embeds a channel-temporal dual attention mechanism, adds three-scale parallel branches (K=3/5/7), and uses depthwise separable convolution for lightweighting (reducing the number of parameters by 68.3%). A 10,000-set data set (split 7:3) was constructed based on a 10kV reactor platform. Simulations showed that 5G+MEC achieved a latency of 22ms (a 74.1% reduction compared to 4G) and a 1.1% packet loss rate for 25MB of data (compared to 8.7% for 4G). The ITCN test set achieved an accuracy of 98.7%, representing improvements of 6.2%, 10.5%, and 8.3% over traditional TCN (92.5%), CNN (88.2%), and LSTM (90.4%), respectively. The recall rate for mild inter-turn short circuits reached 96.5%, and the inference time was 18ms, meeting the real-time diagnostic requirements of the project.

title: Correction of the thermal phase shift for precise assessment of material parameters in terahertz time-domain spectroscopy
authors: Makoto Okano, Kota Suyama, Atushi Wada, Satoshi Tanaka
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: One of the most essential applications of terahertz time-domain spectroscopy (THz-TDS) is the material parameter characterization. To assess the material parameters precisely, accurately determining the time origin of time-domain waveforms is indispensable. Here, we propose and demonstrate an analytical method for correcting the shift of the time origin due to temperature change in the fiber-laser-based THz-TDS. Based on the simple criterion that the complex refractive index spectra should be smoothest, the degree of thermal phase shift can be evaluated successfully. Using the proposed method, we can determine the dispersive complex refractive index of poly(lactic) acid thin film. Because our method has no complicated assumptions, the presented method is also applicable to the phase-resolved spectroscopy based on the time-domain measurement in other frequency regions.

title: Towards an ICT-Enabled Framework to Support Market Access for Rural Farmers in Lanao del Sur
authors: Nor-Aliah M. Omar, Ahmad Sodais E. Unos, Jasmin Jeanette C. Mama, Jogie A. Vistal, Johaira R. Isra
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Digital Transformation and Applications (ICDXA)
abstract: The agricultural sector is a cornerstone of many rural economies, which provides livelihood mainly to local communities, and perhaps to nearby regions. However, in regions like Lanao del Sur, where socio-economic challenges prevail, the ability of farmers to access markets remains a significant barrier to economic growth and development. According to the World Bank (2020), market access is defined not only by physical access to trading centers but also by the ability to meet market demands, access relevant information, and engage in competitive trade practices. This study examines what digital marketplaces must be included in a digitalization framework to support market access for rural farmers, as well as identify the digital marketplaces and related technologies that must be considered in the framework. The research employs mixed methods design to comprehensively explore the experiences, perceptions, and challenges faced by rural farmers in the region. Key findings of the study suggest that farmers in the region need a dedicated digital marketplace tailored specifically for agriculture. Moreover, it also highlights the importance of mobile apps and e-payment tools. Likewise, the framework must address the digital skills gap, connectivity issues, and trust barriers. To ensure the successful implementation and long-term impact of digitalization, the study suggests that policy makers and government agencies must invest in rural internet infrastructure and support technologies like offline-access platform and SMS-based systems. Overall, the framework provides a digitalization model that addresses the real needs of rural farmers in the region.

title: Research on GNN-based UV Unwrapping Method for 3D Ceramic Models
authors: Chao Li, Xunxi Xiao, Yu Nie, Yilai Zhang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Digital Society and Intelligent Systems (DSInS)
abstract: Currently, 3D models generated by AI often exhibit texture fractures and severe distortion when UV unwrapping. Manually unwrapping and editing textures proves both laborintensive and inefficient. This paper proposes a GNN-based UV unwrapping method. The approach first simplifies the mesh using a quadratic error metric algorithm with feature weighting. Then, GNN is employed to precisely locate optimal cutting lines based on 3D model features, ensuring UV coordinate continuity. Finally, texture mapping distortion is corrected through inverse deformation of the warping field. The experiment uses daily-use ceramics such as ceramic mugs and vases as objects to compare the traditional algorithm with the manual unwrapping method. The results show that the UV distortion rate of the unwrapping method in this paper is close to the manual method, the unwrapping time is comparable to the traditional algorithm, and the texture secondary editing restoration degree reaches 92.1 %.

title: 3D FeNAND Array Interface Circuits for Compute-in-Memory Applications
authors: Young-Jun Yu, Jihoon An, Ik-Jyae Kim, Byungsub Kim, Jang-Sik Lee, Dong-Woo Jee
abstract: This paper presents interface circuits for 3D FeNAND based compute-in-memory (CIM) arrays, supporting both high-voltage memory operations and low-voltage CMOS logic compatibility. High voltage driver with coarse/fine control ensures wide and fine voltage range control. The source line driver is designed to handle ultra-low current (100pA-100nA) and interface with CMOS circuits safely. All interface blocks were implemented in a 180nm BCD process and validated through measurement and post-layout simulation.

title: Give Me a Secure Ride: TEE-Blockchain Enabled Privacy-Aware and Verifiable Ride Sharing Services
authors: Jucai Yang, Haiqin Wu, Boris Düdder, Chen Xiao, Xiaolei Dong, Zhenfu Cao
abstract: The proliferation of mobile internet and sharing economy has catalyzed the emergence of Ride-Sharing Services (RSSs) as a paradigm of spatial crowdsourcing in intelligent transportation. Compared with ride-hailing, RSSs present heightened challenges in security and service quality management due to bidirectional disclosure of trip plans and complex matching logic. Existing secure RSS solutions predominantly operate under semi-honest threat models or suffer from prohibitive computational complexity in service composition. However, ensuring public verifiability of matching outcomes is equally critical to prevent manipulation and ensure accountability in decentralized environments. Moreover, achieving a harmonious trade-off among privacy preservation, public verifiability, and matching efficiency remains an open challenge in RSS systems. This work proposes TBRS, a novel TEE-Blockchain powered privacy-aware Ride-Sharing framework, which innovatively addresses three core challenges in service computing: (1) formalizing an inclusive matching model that extends traditional identical matching through trajectory region overlap analysis and direction alignment verification; (2) designing an Index-Preserving Bloom Filter (IP-BF) coupled with Hilbert R-tree spatial indexing, achieving $O(\log n)$ matching complexity through computational geometry optimization; (3) implementing a hybrid trusted execution environment via SGX-enhanced consortium blockchain with private smart contracts, ensuring verifiable service operations management under malicious threats. The framework demonstrates significant advancements in service performance management through systematic experiments: 2${\times }$ $\sim$ 11${\times }$ acceleration in on-chain service composition, 6× $\sim$ 33× improvement in off-chain computation efficiency, while maintaining over 99% service matching accuracy. These results signify that TBRS effectively breaks the efficiency bottleneck of existing privacy-preserving RSS solutions, making decentralized ride-sharing practical for deployment.

title: Local Low-Rankness and Double Autoregression: A Tensor Completion Framework for Space-Based Radio Environment Mapping
authors: Yufei Niu, Youchen Fan, Shuli Ma, Shunhu Hou, Yuhai Li, Shengliang Fang
abstract: In the field of spectrum situation monitoring, space-based spectrum mapping can overcome the limitations of ground-based monitoring, such as restricted coverage, environmental constraints, and difficulties in equipment deployment. However, current research on radio map reconstruction methods based on space-based satellite data is insufficient. Traditional methods mostly set missing patterns based on the type of data collected on the ground, such as random sampling or strip sampling. These methods can meet the needs of generating spectrum maps for local spectrum monitoring on the ground, but they are hardly adaptable to the task of space-based global spectrum mapping. To address this challenge, we have designed a tensor reconstruction method for radio maps based on local low-rankness. Before conducting global completion, we first identify local regions in the map with more prominent low-rank characteristics for completion. This enables the method to handle radio map reconstruction in the context of space-based wide-area coverage. During the reconstruction phase, targeting the two-dimensional spatial completion problem of space-based spectrum maps, we extend the autoregressive process from the temporal dimension in classical spatiotemporal models to the spatial domain, proposing a low-rank tensor completion model based on dual autoregression (LRTCDAR). By incorporating a dual autoregressive structure to capture spatial correlations and combining it with the inherent low-rank property of radio maps, the model achieves high-precision reconstruction of incomplete radio maps. Extensive experimental results demonstrate that, compared to state-of-the-art methods, the proposed approach effectively reconstructs radio maps under various conditional backgrounds. Notably, LRTCDAR exhibits greater advantages when applied to satellite data acquisition scenarios.

title: Effective Respiratory Sound Event Detection Using Dynamic Random Stitching and SpecAugment with ResNet-50 and Transformer
authors: Chia-Yu Yeh, Sing-An Chiu, Wai-Chi Fang
publish: 2025 IEEE Biomedical Circuits and Systems Conference (BioCAS)
abstract: Accurate detection of respiratory sound events is essential for the screening of pulmonary diseases; however, it remains a challenging task due to data imbalance, temporal characteristics, and the complexity of respiratory sound feature classification. In this study, we propose a data augmentation strategy that combines dynamic random stitching and SpecAugment to improve model generalization. We employ ResNet-50 as the model backbone and adopt the encoder-decoder architecture introduced by SEDT and DETR to enhance classification performance under class imbalance. Evaluation on the SPRSound dataset shows that our method improves the F-score to 0.4985 and effectively reduces the Error Rate to 0.92. These results demonstrate that the proposed approach significantly improves the accuracy of the detection and classification of respiratory sound events.

title: Distributed Observer-Based Control for Consensus in Nonlinear Fractional-Order Multi-Agent Systems
authors: Mohammad Fiuzy, Stefan Rass
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: The consensus problem among agents has long intrigued researchers in the field of coordination control. This study investigates a nonlinear fractional-order system with 0 < α < 1. A controller based on distributed observers is designed to assist agents in achieving consensus within a multi-agent nonlinear fractional-order system. The primary strategy for addressing the nonlinear term involves feedback linearization. The controller is developed with a stability proof, and the resulting observer-based controller is applied to an example of a nonlinear fractional-order multi-agent system. Additionally, a nonlinear example is solved analytically in this context. The estimation error is thoroughly analyzed, demonstrating notable convergence to zero based on the Lyapunov stability synthesis.

title: Multiobjective Multitask Optimization With Manifold Structure-Driven Knowledge Transfer
authors: Tingyu Zhang, Xinyi Wu, Yanchi Li, Shuijia Li, Wenyin Gong
publish: IEEE Transactions on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics: Systems
abstract: Evolutionary multitasking (EMT) endeavors to solve multiple optimization tasks simultaneously via knowledge transfer (KT) among tasks. While several EMT algorithms have obtained promising results, they still encounter uncertainties and challenges in the complex field of multiobjective multitask optimization (MO-MTO). A key limitation of existing approaches is the insufficient attention to manifold structures of the Pareto set (PS), which represent the local regularities of multiobjective optimization problems. Ignoring these structures prevents the algorithm from capturing local features, thereby limiting the efficiency and accuracy of KT. To alleviate this issue, this article proposes a new EMT algorithm for MO-MTO with manifold structure-driven KT, namely EMT-MSKT. EMT-MSKT aims to improve optimization performance by leveraging both global and local structural information. In particular, KT in EMT-MSKT consists of two key strategies: global structure learning (GSL) and local structure learning (LSL). GSL exploits global structural similarity to provide population-level directional information that drives broad exploration across tasks. LSL exploits local structural similarity to support fine-grained exploitation based on manifold features. To implement these two strategies, the global and local search directions are extracted as knowledge, reflecting how solutions evolve within these structures. Moreover, to further enhance transfer efficiency in the LSL process, a local source selection (LSS) strategy is developed to identify relevant knowledge sources based on local manifold similarities. Comprehensive results on four benchmark suites (including a newly constructed suite for complex problems) and three real-world applications demonstrate that EMT-MSKT consistently outperforms other state-of-the-art algorithms.

title: An Intelligent IoT-based Water Management System for Efficient Distribution and Leakage Mitigation
authors: Gowtham M, Nivedha M, Abin Andrew, Jagan P, Logavarathan B, Saran S
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Automation, Computing and Renewable Systems (ICACRS)
abstract: Water supply networks are essential in supporting efficient water delivery in urban and rural regions. However, problems related to monitoring, leak detection, and optimization of resources have resulted in large water losses due to leaks, unauthorized use, and inefficient distribution and water quality. Conventional water management systems rely on methods and manual inspections, leading to time lags in identifying anomalies and wasting resources. This proposed system offers an intelligent IOT -driven water management system for efficient distribution and leakage mitigation in the cites based on smart flow sensors, water level sensor, and microcontrollers that boost real-time monitoring and control of data. Sensed data is transferred to a focal point or transmitted to controller to detect leaks, predict maintenance needs, and control the division of water. It streamlines functions by transmitting precise data on usage patterns in the water supply and auto-initiating measures against known irregularities. Proposed system achieved 30% reduction in water losses, 93.75% improvement in maintenance response times, and 97.1% system reliability compared to 75% for traditional approaches.

title: FDSPOAF-lncosh: Efficient Frequency Domain Adaptive Filtering under Heavy-Tailed Noise
authors: Ruiqian Liao, Wenyan Guo, Xiaotong Liu, Guisheng Liao
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Big Data, Artificial Intelligence and Internet of Things Engineering (ICBAIE)
abstract: Adaptive filtering under heavy-tailed non-Gaussian noise remains a challenging task due to the poor robustness of conventional algorithms and the high computational burden for long filter taps. Recently, the spline prioritization optimization lncosh adaptive filter (SPOAF-lncosh) has shown promising robustness by combining spline-based optimization with the lncosh cost function. However, its implementation still suffers from significant complexity when dealing with long adaptive filter taps. To overcome this limitation, we propose a frequency domain variant, termed FDSPOAF-lncosh, which reformulates the SPOAF-lncosh algorithm in the frequency domain. The proposed method leverages the fast Fourier transform (FFT) to reduce the per-iteration complexity from $\mathrm{O}\left(\mathrm{N}^{2}\right)$ to $\mathrm{O}\left(\mathrm{Nlog}_{2} \mathrm{~N}\right)$ with $\mathrm{N}=2 \mathrm{M}$, while maintaining the heavy-tailed noise suppression capability of the original algorithm. Theoretical analysis demonstrates that the FDSPOAF-lncosh algorithm achieves comparable convergence properties and steady-state performance to its time-domain counterpart. Simulation results under various impulsive noise conditions confirm that FDSPOAF-lncosh significantly shortens runtime for long filter taps.
