authors: Meng Zhou, Haolong Li, Jing Wang
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: This paper presents an H<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">−</inf>/L<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">∞</inf> fault detection observer for the activated sludge process in wastewater treatment plants. First, the nonlinear mass balance model of the activated sludge process is transformed into a Takagi–Sugeno (T-S) fuzzy system. Due to the presence of unmeasured premise variables, the errors resulting from these variables and external disturbances are treated as a whole in the observer design. Subsequently, an observer is developed to achieve high fault sensitivity while effectively attenuating disturbances. Finally, the effectiveness of the proposed method is demonstrated through simulations and compared with a conventional L<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">∞</inf> observer.

title: A receding horizon control for multi-robot navigation under LiDAR-driven graph updates
authors: Antonello Venturino, Francesco Tedesco, Alessandro Casavola, Giuseppe Franzè
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: In the context of Industry 5.0, where environments are subject to unpredictable changes, achieving real-time adaptability and robust collision avoidance is essential for safe navigation and timely task execution. This paper introduces a Robust Grid-Based Receding Horizon Control scheme tailored for multi-robot logistics, designed to address dynamic obstacles and bounded multiplicative disturbances in unicycle-type robots. The method employs a single grid graph, continuously updated in real time using LiDAR data. A distributed robust set-theoretic model predictive control strategy leverages the grid graph to ensure safe and efficient navigation. The proposed approach is validated through realistic simulations in ROS/Gazebo, demonstrating its effectiveness in complex and dynamic scenarios.

title: Automated Detection of Neurological Disorders and Alzheimer's Disease using AI and Image Processing
authors: K.S. Neelu Kumari, P. Durggashre, A. Archana, J. Darshana, M. Devadharshini
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Automation, Computing and Renewable Systems (ICACRS)
abstract: The diagnose of neurodevelopmental and neurological conditions like Rett syndrome, Alzheimer's disease, Pitt-Hopkins syndrome, Angelman syndrome and MECP2 duplication syndrome because the clinical signs related to these conditions are often subtle and manifestations can overlap. In order to manage, treat and intervene, early and accurate identification of the neurological condition is essential. This paper presents an integrated hybrid detection framework that combines bio signal-based monitoring and in-the-wild facial feature recognition, using Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN) and Cat Boost as state of the art machine learning approaches. To distinguish between these neurological disorders, facial images are analyzed using a deep CNN-dense architecture, trained on a large data set. At the same time, hardware sensors provide physiological data in real-time, including heart rate (BPM), oxygen saturation (SpO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>), infrared (IR) signals and motion using an MPU6050. Fusing bio signal and image data improves accuracy and reliability in the system. Results are displayed through an interactive web application, allowing for the remote tracking of patients, as well as clinical decision-making. The system proposes a non-contact, scalable and efficient solution for the early identification and ongoing monitoring of neurological disorders. The proposed system ultimately aims to improve outcomes for patients and quality of life through timely diagnosis and intervention. The algorithms shows the accuracy of 98.9%.

title: Privacy-Preserving Student Activity Classification in E-Learning using Hybrid Federated Learning
authors: Vaishnavi N, Devi A
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Automation, Computing and Renewable Systems (ICACRS)
abstract: The merger of the Fourth Industrial Revolution with a universal internet penetration has launched online education (e-learning) into an exponential growth phase. Although digital devices provide learning flexibility that is not location-bound, it create one significant problem: students research with the same devices as it recreationally do. The reason is that there has been a high possibility of time wastage and reduced efficiency of resources in the academic environment due to the easy accessibility of time-squandering distractions (including social media). This is one of the challenges that should be addressed considering that digital learning environments are set to be prevalent in the future. There is a significant research gap when it comes to the techniques which will find the right way to detect and categorize student behavior on screen and at the same time maintain the privacy of users. To address this problem, the proposed method presents a new privacy-saving scheme based on Federated Learning based on a Particle Swarm Optimization Algorithm (FLPSO). The design of this structure is aimed at efficiently ascertaining whether the student is using his/her computer time in a productive manner or it is going to waste. An over 4,000 screen shots of various activities of students were used to train and validate the FLPSO model. A comparative analysis was made on the proposed FLPSO approach with many previously pre-trained classification algorithms and it proved to be superior. The method scored well on all the critical measures of assessment such as accuracy, precision, recall and F1-score and proved to be a safe and efficient measure in sensitivity and optimization of student interest in e-learning.

title: Application of the Projective Geometry Principle to Describe the Dynamics of Smart Grid Modes*
authors: E. Sosnina, R. Bedretdinov, A. Ivanov
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: When designing a managed electric distribution network (Smart Grid) with renewable energy sources and the elements of Flexible Alternative Current Transmission System (FACTS), it is necessary to take into account the level of distortion of the voltage and current curve when assessing the quality of electricity supplied to consumers. The article is devoted to the search for an approach to describing the dynamics of Smart Grid modes, which enables to study the qualitative influence of FACTS devices on the parameters of the electrical network, including non-sinusoidal voltage and current. The analysis of possible approaches and methods for describing the dynamics of the parameters of Smart Grid modes has been carried out. The approaches based on metric geometry and affine geometry have been considered. It has been established that the classical methods used to analyze static processes are not applicable in the Smart Grid. The use of the principles of projective geometry is proposed as a promising approach. The features of the application of projective geometry are shown on the example of a Smart Grid section. The proposed approach based on projective geometry allows to qualitatively describe the dynamics of Smart Grid modes.

title: Dynamic Video Security using yolo object recognition
authors: S. Jhansi Naga Laxmi, S. Aruna Deepthi, K. Deepthi, E. Srinivas Rao
publish: 2025 5th IEEE International Conference on Applied Electromagnetics, Signal Processing, &amp; Communication (AESPC)
abstract: This paper is a real-time video surveillance system designed to enhance security through proactive object detection. The system leverages the YOLO object detection algorithm within the Open CV library to analyze live video feeds. Upon identifying unattended objects, the system triggers multichannel alerts, including audible alarms, email notifications, and SMS messages, to notify authorities of potential security threats. This system incorporates a user-friendly web interface allowing convenient interaction and monitoring providing users with a seamless experience for visualizing detected objects and system status, promoting efficient security management offering a comprehensive surveillance solution for various applications, including public spaces, transportation hubs, and commercial facilities. By enabling real-time object detection, abandoned object tracking, and multi-channel alerting, the system facilitates faster response times to security incidents, ultimately contributing to the prevention of security breaches and maintaining a safe environment.

title: Ultra-Sensitive LWIR QWIP FPA with Sub-5 mK NETD and Exceptional Dynamic Range for Advanced Thermal Imaging
authors: Xiaohao Zhou, Ning Li, Xiangyang Li, Wei Lu
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: This paper presents a 320x256 LWIR QWIP FPA (Long-Wavelength Infrared Quantum Well Infrared Photodetector Focal Plane Array) that achieves a NETD (Noise Equivalent Temperature Difference) of less than 5 mK and a dynamic range exceeding 100 dB. QWIP detectors, based on the GaAs/AlGaAs material system, are commonly used for LWIR FPA, but their performance is often limited by the charge capacity of conventional CMOS readout circuits, resulting in NETD values typically ranging from 20 mK to 30 mK. The FPA described here utilizes a pixel-level DROIC (Digital Readout Integrated Circuit) to overcome this limitation, enabling high temperature resolution and a wide operating temperature range of 40 K to 80 K. The proposed FPA offers a new route for high-performance thermal imaging systems.

title: Improved Yolo Petrochemical Equipment Detection Based on Multi-Order Gated and Channel Aggregation
authors: Zhenqiang Wei, Zhixun Cao, Xinyi Cao
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Digital Society and Intelligent Systems (DSInS)
abstract: Petrochemical equipment detection is a critical task for intelligent monitoring and maintenance in industrial environments, yet it remains challenging due to low image resolution, complex backgrounds, and large variations in object scales. To address these issues, this article proposes YOLO-PEMA, a onestage, attention-enhanced YOLOv8 network designed for robust detection of petrochemical equipment. The proposed model integrates Multi-Order Gated Aggregation (MOGA) and Channel Aggregation (CA) blocks to enhance multi-scale feature extraction and channel attention. Furthermore, a series of ablation studies were conducted to evaluate the individual and combined contributions of these components. Experimental results in a self-constructed petrochemical equipment image dataset demonstrate that YOLO-PEMA achieves a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{mAP} {@} 0.5$</tex> of 98.7 %, outperforming state-of-the-art detectors including Faster R-CNN, SSD, RetinaNet and EfficientDet by up to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{2. 9 \%}$</tex>. The ablation study confirms that both MOGA and CA blocks significantly improve detection accuracy and their combination yields the best performance. These results highlight the effectiveness and practicality of YOLO-PEMA for real-time petrochemical equipment detection, providing a promising foundation for intelligent industrial inspection and safety management.

title: A 24Gb/s 0.39pJ/b PAM-3 Single-Ended Receiver Summer Merged TIA for Memory Interface
authors: Yoonsang Lee, Gyuwon Jeon, Jongchan An, Gwangmyeong An, Songi Cheon, Junyoung Song
abstract: This paper presents a 24-Gb/s single-ended (SE) 3-level pulse amplitude modulation (PAM-3) receiver (RX) based on a summer-merged transimpedance amplifier (SMTIA). The proposed RX eliminates the need for a single-to-differential converter (S2D) by utilizing a reference voltage and a static current source, resulting in significantly lower power consumption compared to a conventional decision feedback equalizer (DFE). Additionally, the proposed DFE enhances RX reliability by effectively mitigating inter-symbol interference (ISI). The proposed RX achieves -6.55 dB channel attenuation at 8 GHz with 0.39 pJ/b energy efficiency, based on post-layout simulation results from a prototype chip fabricated in the 28 nm CMOS process.

title: A Two-Phase BLS Multi-Signature Backed Transaction Propagation Mechanism for Blockchain-Enabled Multi-Access Edge Computing
authors: Xijia Lu, Xingwei Wang, Bo Yi, Qiang He, Jie Li, Min Huang
publish: 2025 IEEE 31th International Conference on Parallel and Distributed Systems (ICPADS)
abstract: Blockchain is increasingly integrated in Multiaccess Edge Computing (MEC) to coordinate secure and lowlatency resource provisioning and service orchestration among resource-constrained embodied AI devices. However, conventional blockchains perform costly transaction verification during propagation, which can be exploited by spam transaction attacks and overload resource-limited edge devices. To mitigate the substantial overhead of verification, we propose a two-stage BLS multi-signature backed transaction propagation mechanism for blockchain-enabled MEC: a small-scope random-walk phase with deep verification and signing, followed by a large-scope propagation phase with probabilistic verification. In the first stage, nodes conduct deep verification and sign valid transactions using the BLS multi-signature, then forward the signed transaction to a small and randomly sampled subset of neighbors to rapidly accumulate valid signatures. In the second stage, transactions whose aggregated signature count exceeds a threshold will be broadcast throughout the entire blockchain network and undergo deep verification with a specific probability, relieving edge nodes' verification burden. Moreover, verifiers record signers associated with failed deep verifications. Signers whose failures exceed a system threshold are quarantined to restrain the spread of spam transactions. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed mechanism reduces energy consumption by at least 60% and 18.6% compared with the original and benchmark mechanisms respectively, while maintaining nearly identical transmission performance and ensuring that the proportion of invalid transactions propagated to honest nodes does not exceed 14%.

title: Dissecting Ethereum Staking at Scale: A Comprehensive Measurement and Analysis
authors: Quanbi Feng, Yinan Mi, Hanzheng Lyu, Jianbin Zou, Jianyu Niu
publish: 2025 IEEE 31th International Conference on Parallel and Distributed Systems (ICPADS)
abstract: Decentralization is a critical security property for blockchain systems. Ethereum adopts a protocol design with multiple incentive mechanisms to encourage validators to contribute to decentralization. However, little empirical evidence exists on the actual effectiveness of Ethereum's incentive mechanism. In this paper, we collect and analyze data on validator rewards from Ethereum's consensus and execution layers, examining both the distribution of rewards and the degree of decentralization in the current network. Our findings show that Ethereum's reward allocation exhibits a relatively balanced distribution, with neither staking pools nor exchanges earning disproportionately higher returns simply due to their larger stake. These findings reveal the effectiveness of Ethereum's incentive design and the current state of decentralization, providing a foundation for future improvements in mechanism design and exploration.

title: KGSC-SAT: Key-Gated Semantic Communication Enhanced by Steganography Adversarial Training for Secure Transmission
authors: Xin Wang, Xiulong Liu, Xin Xie, Kaixuan Zhang, Qixuan Cai, Xinyu Tong, Zheng Gong, Keqiu Li
publish: 2025 IEEE 31th International Conference on Parallel and Distributed Systems (ICPADS)
abstract: End-to-end semantic communication paradigms demonstrate substantial potential in reducing network load and compressing data redundancy. However, their inherent openness introduces significant security risks, such as unauthorized access that enables attackers to camouflage themselves among legitimate users. Moreover, legitimate users may exploit input-output data pairs to conduct model stealing attacks. Existing defense strategies generally lack user access control mechanisms and fail to provide targeted countermeasures against model inversion attacks from internal users. To address this gap, we propose KGSC-SAT, a Key-Gated Semantic Communication framework enhanced by Steganography Adversarial Training for Secure Transmission. The framework employs a key-based feature modulation method to identify authorized users, while adversarial steganography training facilitates deep feature-level masking. Experimental results demonstrate that KGSC-SAT effectively mitigates both unauthorized access and insider model inversion threats, while delivering reliable communication performance.

title: Enhancing Mental Workload Prediction through LightGBM during Multitasking
authors: Syed Saad Azhar Ali, Maged S. AL-Quraishi, Sami El Ferik, Aamir Saeed Malik
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: Multitasking is an essential aspect of daily life; however, it significantly increases mental workload (MWL), which can affect cognitive performance, decision making, and overall effectiveness. Thus, accurately assessing MWL is significant in various fields, including human-computer interaction, aviation, and healthcare, where cognitive overload can lead to unsuitable decisions. The brain computer interface (BCI) based on electroencephalography (EEG) presents a viable, non-invasive option for real-time monitoring of MWL, allowing an adaptive system to improve performance and user experience. However, because EEG patterns vary widely among individuals, it is still challenging to develop a generalized MWL prediction model. Therefore, Light Gradient Boosting Machine (LightGBM) with manually extracted features is proposed. Our analysis was based on the "STEW" dataset, which includes two task conditions: "No task" and a multitasking activity using the SIMKAP framework. The proposed model achieved an average accuracy of 84.0% (±14.4%) and an average F1-score of 83.1% (±18.2%), showcasing its strong predictive performance while maintaining computational efficiency compared to deep learning methods. These results highlight LightGBM’s potential as a fast, subject-independent MWL classification tool, therefore enabling the design of scalable and flexible cognitive monitoring systems for practical use.

title: FedPce: Prompt-Based Federated Cross-Domain Recommendation
authors: Zhi Liu, Xuyuan Hu, Xiaohua He, Zhaolin Deng, Guojiang Shen, Xiangjie Kong
publish: 2025 IEEE 31th International Conference on Parallel and Distributed Systems (ICPADS)
abstract: Recommendation systems can establish vital connections between users and information. But they are still facing data sparsity and cold start issues. Cross-domain recommendation improves performance via knowledge transfer, yet often depends on data sharing, conflicting with privacy needs. Federated learning offers a privacy-preserving alternative, but still struggles with knowledge transfer and communication overhead. In this paper, we propose FedPce, a Prompt-based Federated Cross-domain Recommendation. FedPce improves cross-domain recommendation and promotes knowledge transfer by leveraging item description texts and prompt learning, while reducing communication overhead and accelerating convergence through low-rank gradient compression and elastic aggregation strategies. Experimental results show that FedPce performs well on multidomain recommendation tasks, balancing recommendation effect and privacy protection.

title: Design and Development of a One-Legged Hopping Robot Based on a Spring-Mass Template
authors: Ahmet Safa Ozturk, Ömer Morgül, Ismail Uyanik
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: This work introduces a modular experimental platform for studying legged locomotion, constructed using the template-anchor methodology, which allows the generalization of designed applications to the broader spectrum of legged robots. A finite state machine governs the operation logic, enabling reliable phase-specific coordination within a hybrid dynamical system. Active hip torque control is integrated to stabilize trajectories and support continuous running, enhancing the dynamic capabilities of the platform. The experimental platform enables advanced system identification, forward prediction, and closed-loop control applications.

title: FedGuard: A Two-Stage Defense Framework Against Model Poisoning in Federated Learning via Verifiable Training Dynamics
authors: Boyun Zhang, Chenyang Xu, Hao Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE 31th International Conference on Parallel and Distributed Systems (ICPADS)
abstract: Federated Learning (FL) is vulnerable to model poisoning, where adversaries submit malicious updates to compromise the global model. A key challenge for defenses is the ambiguity between malicious updates and benign outliers from clients with non-identically distributed (Non-IID) data, forcing a trade-off between security and utility. We propose FedGuard, a novel defense framework that verifies the integrity of the local training process. FedGuard requires clients to submit a privacy-preserving proof of their training, encapsulated in a loss trajectory. A two-stage defense at the server filters updates with invalid dynamics and then uses a trajectory-aware anomaly detection algorithm to distinguish attacks from benign Non-IID outliers. Evaluations against backdoor attacks on MNIST and CIFAR-10 show FedGuard reduces the attack success rate to near-zero, significantly outperforming traditional defenses while maintaining high main task accuracy.

title: Robust Entanglement Generation in Bipartite Quantum Systems Using Optimal Control
authors: Nahid Binandeh Dehaghani, A. Pedro Aguiar, Rafal Wisniewski
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: Quantum entanglement is a key resource for quantum technologies, yet its efficient and high-fidelity generation remains a challenge due to the complexity of quantum dynamics. This paper presents a quantum optimal control framework to maximize bipartite entanglement within a fixed time horizon, under bounded control inputs. By leveraging Pontryagin’s Minimum Principle, we derive a set of necessary conditions that guide the design of time-dependent control fields to steer a two-qubit system toward maximally entangled Bell states. The entanglement is quantified using concurrence, and the control objective is formulated as maximizing this measure at the terminal time. Our approach is validated through numerical simulations of Liouville–von Neumann dynamics. The results demonstrate the effectiveness of switching-based control strategies in achieving robust entanglement, offering insights into practical implementations of quantum control for entanglement generation in quantum networks.

title: A Variable Structure Approach for Finite-Control-Set Model Predictive Current Control of a Household Appliance
authors: Eleonora Brasili, Luigi Fagnano, Gianluca Ippoliti, Giuseppe Orlando
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: A finite control set model predictive control (FCS-MPC) strategy is investigated for the speed regulation of permanent magnet synchronous motors (PMSMs). A cascaded control structure is implemented, consisting of an inner FCS-MPC current loop, enhanced by a variable structure (VS) approach, and an outer discrete-time VS control (DTVSC) speed loop. The adoption of FCS-MPC for current regulation in industrial PMSMs is driven by its inherent fast dynamic response, ability to enforce constraints, and the potential for modulator-less operation. Furthermore, DTVSC has proven to be an effective PMSM control strategy, particularly valued for its robustness in the face of model inaccuracies and external disturbances. The proposed control methodology, compared to the industry-standard PI cascaded control implemented by Whirlpool in domestic appliances, provides an improvement in control performance and robustness characteristics.

title: Metasurface-Enhanced Terahertz Attenuated Total Reflection Spectroscopy for Ultrasensitive Aqueous Solution Detection
authors: Hongshun Sun, Yunhao Cao, Yusa Chen, Liye Li, Lijun Ma, Jinwen Zhang, Wengang Wu
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: Terahertz (THz) spectroscopy is widely used in biomedical and security applications, yet strong water absorption poses challenges for aqueous solution detection. This study presents a THz metasurface-enhanced attenuated total reflection (ATR) sensor by directly placing metallic rod arrays onto a silicon prism. The hybrid configuration significantly improves detection resolution by combining metasurface resonance with ATR technology. Experimental results demonstrate a notable 36 GHz resonance frequency shift when detecting 10 μL of 0.5 mol/L NaCl solution. This approach effectively overcomes water's strong THz absorption, offering a highly sensitive, non-destructive solution for biomedical testing and concentration monitoring of aqueous samples. The compact design achieves high sensitivity while maintaining measurement simplicity, showing great potential for practical applications in liquid analysis.

title: Image Binary Classification Research Based on Convolutional Neural Network and Random Forest
authors: Yichen Yang, Jiayuan Du
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Automation, Electronics and Electrical Engineering (AUTEEE)
abstract: This paper proposes a machine learning-deep learning hybrid image recognition scheme, focusing on the construction and performance comparison of feedforward neural networks, 1D CNNs, and random forest models. First, a feedforward neural network is constructed. Data are converted into PyTorch tensors, and a binary classification model is designed—comprising an input layer, a 64-neuron hidden layer, and a single-neuron output layer. Binary cross-entropy loss and the Adam optimizer are employed, with parameter optimization via multiple iterations to achieve image classification. Second, a 1D CNN model is built. Built on the Keras Sequential framework, it incorporates 1D convolutional, max-pooling, and fully connected layers. The sklearn library is utilized to compute evaluation metrics, with ROC curves, loss variations, and confusion matrices visualized for model performance analysis. Finally, a random forest model is established. The image data is standardized and labels are encoded; hyperparameters are optimized using grid search, and the model's performance is evaluated through learning curves, confusion matrices, and other means. This scheme can accurately realize binary image classification. The combination of multiple models and multiple evaluation methods improves the reliability and generalization ability of recognition, and can adapt to image recognition needs in different scenarios.

title: Propagation Control of Ultrashort Plasmon Wavepacket in Graphene
authors: K Yoshioka, G. Bernard, T. Wakamura, M. Hashisaka, K. Sasaki, S. Sasaki, K. Watanabe, T. Taniguchi, N. Kumada
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: We demonstrate on-chip excitation, velocity and amplitude modulation, and time-domain detection of ultrashort graphene plasmon wavepacket using THz electronics. The plasmon velocity can be tuned in the range of 10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">6</sup> to 10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">7</sup> m/s by changing the carrier density and the surrounding dielectric environment. The minimum wavepacket duration is 1.2 ps, corresponding to a spatial extent of 4 <inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">µ</inf>m. Unlike optical excitation, electrical excitation of plasmons does not require momentum matching, and the conversion efficiency from an electrical pulse in a coplanar waveguide to graphene plasmons can reach 35%.

title: Measurement of Low-Loss Resins by Terahertz Time-Domain Spectroscopy in the Millimeter-Wave Region
authors: Hideaki Kitahara, Aito Tamura, Takashi Furuya, Masahiko Tani
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: A terahertz time-domain spectrometer is developed to accurately measure the dielectric loss tangent of low-loss resins in the millimeter-wave region. The scanning speed of the optical delay line is shortened to 6-s for a 200-ps time-window and a highly efficient photoconductive spiral antenna is introduced. A low-loss resin, cyclo-olefin polymer, is measured and its dielectric loss tangent in millimeter-wave region is precisely determined on the order of 10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">-4</sup>.

title: Performance Analysis of EfficientNet and ResNet-50 with Different Classifiers for the Identification of Eye Diseases
authors: Janmejay Pant, Hitesh Kumar Pant, Vikas Bhatt, Devendra Singh, Arvind Kumar, Megha Upreti
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Automation, Computing and Renewable Systems (ICACRS)
abstract: Retinal diseases need to be recognized early and precisely in order to avoid unnecessary blindness. The paper is a comparative analysis of two popular deep learning architectures, EfficientNet and ResNet-50, which are used as feature extractors with four additional classifiers: Neural Network, Logistic Regression, Gradient Boosting, and Random Forest. Experimentation was done on a dataset of 4,217 fundus images (4 eye conditions, Normal, Cataract, Glaucoma, and Diabetic Retinopathy). The deep features were extracted and they were used to train the classifiers and their performance measured by using accuracy, F1-score, AUC and MCC. It is observed that EfficientNet with a Neural Network gives the best results with an AUC of 0.980 and a precision of 0.888. Logistic Regression and Gradient Boosting also score well with the Random Forest always scoring the lowest points. The same tendency is observed in ResNet-50 features, as once again, the Neural Network works better than the rest of the classifiers. The results indicate the significance of a proper choice of a classifier alongside a powerful feature extractor, and reveal how the hybrid deep feature-classical classifier methods can be used to improve the diagnosis of retinal diseases to a considerable degree.

title: CGAN based data generation for process monitoring
authors: Jing Wang, Tingting Liu, Meng Zhou, Yanzhu Zhang
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: The normal data are sampled from the industrial process far more than fault data. Due to the existence of unbalanced data, the traditional learning method are difficult to classify the fault correctly. This paper designs a generation network to effectively augment the fault data and obtain the balanced industrial dataset. Conditional Generative Adversarial Network (CGAN) is constructed to generate a large amount of new fault data which has similar distribution with the original real fault data. The time series data are first transform into matrix format in order to adapt the input of CGAN. Then convolutional neural network (CNN) is used for fault diagnosis. The proposed method is applied in an actual gas-solid fluidized bed equipment to verify its effectiveness.

title: A Lightweight SSH Honeypot for Intrusion Logging
authors: Ramesh Babu Pittala, Naga Himansri, Nuguru Rudradev, Sai Ranjan, Niteesha Sharma, Medikonda Asha Kiran, Manyam Thaile, Manasa Nemmani
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Automation, Computing and Renewable Systems (ICACRS)
abstract: In a time of increasing cyber threats, proactive defence is an increasingly important issue. This paper introduces a Python-based honeypot which can be utilized as a decoy. The system functions as a real network service, quietly logging information about attempted access that has not been authorised including IP addresses, time stamps and entered credentials without risking operational systems to any danger. The honeypot, which has been developed with the use of barebone socket programming and logging tools, offers an environment to view the dynamics of intrusion in real time, with a secure and controlled environment. In addition to detection, the project has optional IP geolocation, thus providing an understanding of the location of attacks. Finally, this honeypot is aimed at generating awareness of the present-day intrusion methods as well as proving that deception is a simple though effective protection mechanism in network security.

title: FUPS: Fusion-Based Parallel Structured Pruning for Large Language Models
authors: Shouyuan Qin, Guixia Wang, Xuhui Xiong
publish: 2025 IEEE 31th International Conference on Parallel and Distributed Systems (ICPADS)
abstract: Model pruning is an effective technique to reduce the dependency of neural networks on hardware resources while maintaining their performance, especially for Large Language Models(LLMs) with ever-increasing parameter scales. However, existing structured pruning methods often struggle to retain satisfactory performance under high sparsity ratios and exhibit inefficiencies when applied to ultra-large models. To address these limitations, we propose a novel structured pruning algorithm, Fusion-Based Parallel Structured Pruning (FUPS), which is simple, efficient, and easy to deploy. Its effectiveness stems from two key innovations: (1) a block-wise mechanism that partitions matrices into smaller sub-blocks to enable finer-grained redundancy identification and enhance parallel processing across accelerators; (2) a fusion mechanism that mitigates the adverse impact of knowledge space fragmentation introduced by the block mechanism, thereby enhancing the robustness and generalization capability of the matrix representation. We conduct extensive experiments on various models, and the results show that FUPS consistently preserves model performance across different sparsity settings and outperforms existing methods such as LLMPruner, Wanda, and FLAP on multiple benchmark tasks. The code is released at https://github.com/Qsiny/FUPS.

title: Energy Optimization in WSNs: Simulation-Based Analysis of Six Routing Protocols
authors: Ayyapa Reddy, Jaya Chetan, Lakshmi Priya P., Baba Ameer Shaik, Thangam S.
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Automation, Computing and Renewable Systems (ICACRS)
abstract: Wireless Sensor Networks (WSNs) face significant challenges in energy consumption optimization and network lifetime management, as conventional routing protocols often fail to balance energy efficiency with network connectivity and performance requirements. The lack of comprehensive comparative assessment of contemporary energy-efficient routing protocols hinders optimal protocol selection for specific WSN applications. This research presents a comparative simulation-based study of six prominent routing protocols: LEACH, Modified LEACH, TLEACH, E-DEEC, Multi-Chain PEGASIS, and MGEAR across various network infrastructures and application environments. Performance analysis employs realistic constraints including energy consumption patterns, network latency measurements, and active round counts to evaluate protocol performance. The comparative study reveals significant performance trade- offs between network connectivity and energy efficiency, with specific protocols demonstrating superior performance under different network conditions. This research provides quantitative performance metrics that enable network designers to make informed protocol selection decisions based on specific WSN constraints and requirements.

title: A 28-nm 16-Channel SiP-Based ASIC with AFE, ADC and DSP Integrated for Ultrasound Imaging
authors: Chenhui Zhou, Xinwei Yu, Tianyu Zhai, Fan Ye, Junyan Ren
publish: 2025 IEEE Biomedical Circuits and Systems Conference (BioCAS)
abstract: This paper proposes a $\mathbf{1 6}$-channel ultrasound imaging application-specific integrated circuit (ASIC) designed in 28-nm CMOS technology, targeting low-noise high-resolution large-dynamic signal receiving. An analog front-end (AFE) equipped with two-stage time-gain compensation (TGC), a 14bit $\mathbf{1 5 0 ~ M S}$ /s analog-to-digital converter (ADC) adopting pipelined-SAR structure, and a digital signal processing (DSP) have been integrated in a compact system-in-package (SiP) architecture. For analog domain on this chip, each channel includes a low-noise amplifier, voltage-controlled attenuator, programmable gain amplifier, and anti-aliasing filter, offering up to 80 dB voltage gain and sub- $3 \mathrm{nV} / \sqrt{ } \mathrm{Hz}$ input-referred noise (IRN). The fabricated ASIC features an AFE with large TGC range of 66 dB and low IRN of $2.2 \mathrm{nV} / \sqrt{ } \mathrm{Hz} \text{@} 5 \mathrm{MHz}$, combined with a 9.14-bit ENOB after ADC processed and a $\mathbf{1 5 0 ~ M H z}$ DSP core delivering 1.67 ns delay precision.

title: With a Little Help From My Friends [President's Message]
authors: Luis Magdalena

title: LISLLM: Long Context Inference of Large Language Models with Short KV Cache
authors: Tielong Liu, Gang Li, Zeyu Zhu, Zitao Mo, Xingting Yao, Jian Cheng
publish: 2025 IEEE 31th International Conference on Parallel and Distributed Systems (ICPADS)
abstract: Large Language Models (LLMs) have demonstrated remarkable performance across various language tasks. However, in the process of generating long texts, the linearly increasing keyvalue (KV) cache imposes a large volume of memory footprint on HBM, resulting in significant time and energy consumption during inference. By retaining only the initial and recent tokens, existing methods ignore the intermediate tokens and the effect of the distance between current tokens and those in the KV cache, which causes significant accuracy degradation and limits the potential for KV cache compression. To overcome the above problems, we propose LISLLM, a KV cache compression mechanism that takes both the difference in importance and the distance between tokens into consideration for efficient inference of LLMs in long-context settings. Compared to the state-of-theart method, our method achieves compression ratios of up to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1.91 \times$</tex> and speedup of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1.20 \times$</tex> with better accuracy.

title: Investigation of Optimal Parameters for PLA Printed Details
authors: Kliment Georgiev
abstract: Additive printing methods are becoming increasingly widespread in the production of prototypes and functional elements. It is imperative to acknowledge the significance of expertise in the domain of additive printing systems, as it plays a pivotal role in ensuring the precision and accuracy of the final product's geometry. This report presents the findings of an experimental study of some fundamental technological factors. The present study investigates the influence of nozzle temperature, table temperature, layer height, and infill type on the geometric accuracy of a selected part. The findings indicate that the nozzle temperature and the mass exert the most significant influence on the geometric parameters. The layer height and the type of filling have been shown to have a significantly weaker influence on the geometric accuracy of the part.

title: Assessing the Feasibility of Time-Series Integration for Large-Scale Forest Monitoring
authors: Boonyarit Changaival, Panruthai Tangprasert, Kittichai Lavangnananda, Jiranan Thammakosit
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: Deforestation is a key contributor in reduced carbon sequestration and intensifying environmental impacts such as flooding and heat waves. This study explores the potential of incorporating time-series data into a forest monitoring system to enhance deforestation detection. The work utilizes the freely available Sentinel-2 satellite imagery. The effect of temporal information are analyzed in its influences in the classification and monitoring. The work focuses on the northern part of Thailand, Chiang Mai province, as the area was affected by severe flooding in 2024. Random Forest is adopted as the classifier of choice to monitor over a one-year period. The classifier implemented is proven satisfactory and is evaluated by known metrics such as Accuracy, F1-score, Precision and Recall. The study provides insights into the feasibility of time-series integration for largescale, near real-time forest monitoring.

title: FPGA-Based Integer-Only Hardware Accelerator for YOLOv3-Tiny Model
authors: Jonghyun Kim, Jaemyung Kim, Jin-Ku Kang, Yongwoo Kim
abstract: YOLO-based networks are frequently employed in object detection tasks due to their outstanding performance. In this work, we integrate the YOLOv3-tiny network with depthwise convolution, which excels at capturing spatial features, thereby maintaining high accuracy with a reduced parameter count. We also design an FPGA-based CNN accelerator using High-Level Synthesis (HLS) that supports line buffer and plane buffer computation schemes. Trained on the Pascal VOC dataset, the proposed network's 8-bit integer model achieved a mAP@0.5 of 65.7%, while using 74% fewer parameters than the original YOLOv3-tiny network. The accelerator is implemented on Xilinx ZC706 board, utilizing 345 BRAM18k blocks, 306 DSP slices, 25.5k FFs and 17.9k LUTs.

title: Graph Neural Network Based on Local Attention for Diagnosis of Alzheimer's Disease
authors: Maochang Huang, Yihao Guo, Chaoqi Lv, Feng Chen
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Digital Society and Intelligent Systems (DSInS)
abstract: In recent years, machine learning-based and deep learning-based methods have been widely applied in the diagnosis of Alzheimer's disease (AD). Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) can provide brain structural information; however, most existing deep learning methods are limited to imaging features and rarely incorporate non-imaging data (subjects' clinical phenotypic information) for multimodal research. This study demonstrates how to integrate imaging features with non-imaging data to improve model performance, instead of relying solely on a single modality to construct predictive models for AD diagnosis. In this research, we propose a Local Attention Graph Convolutional Network (LA-GCN) based on a few-shot learning strategy, which aims to address the challenges of insufficient training data, fixed graph structures, and high computational complexity. The results show that compared with traditional GCN models, the proposed training strategy can better handle scenarios with extremely limited data, while enhancing model flexibility and reducing computational complexity.

title: Exceptional points generated from bound states in continuum
authors: Lei Wang, Caihong Zhang, Kebin Fan, Huabing Wang, Biaobing Jin, Jian Chen, Peiheng Wu
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: Bound states in the continuum (BICs) and exceptional points (EPs) are two unique types of physical singularities characterized by complex eigenfrequencies in non-Hermitian systems. Both have been extensively studied and clearly defined in recent years, owing to their relevance in applications such as high-sensitivity sensing and lasing. In this study, we explore the transition between EPs and BICs through perforated dielectric metasurfaces operating in the terahertz regime. Within this framework, the EP emerges as the coalescence of a quasi-Friedrich-Wintgen (FW) BIC. The findings offer meaningful insights for the development of compact sensor devices grounded in non-Hermitian physics.

title: Real-time release testing of amorphous drug by terahertz time-domain spectroscopy
authors: Chi Ki Leung, Lisa Kuchler, J. Axel Zeitler
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: Terahertz time-domain spectroscopy (THz-TDS) offers a rapid and non-destructive method for differentiating between amorphous and crystalline phases in pharmaceutical formulations, a critical factor given the enhanced solubility and bioavailability of amorphous drugs. However, the inherent thermodynamic instability and recrystallisation risk of these amorphous forms necessitate robust monitoring. This study establishes THz-TDS as a powerful at-line process analytical technology for real-time release testing of salbutamol amorphous solid dispersion tablets. We developed and validated two distinct, spectral-based methodologies for unequivocally confirming the absence of crystallinity. These methods demonstrate the potential of THz-TDS to ensure the quality, stability, and consistent performance of amorphous drug products, enabling more efficient and reliable pharmaceutical manufacturing.

title: Write-Once, Prove-Once: A Reusable Framework for Secure Boot Verification in Rocq
authors: Minjie Fan, Qiyu Wu, Kuai Yu, Gaosong Xu, Xiaoyang Wang, Jiwu Shu
publish: 2025 IEEE 31th International Conference on Parallel and Distributed Systems (ICPADS)
abstract: Secure boot is a fundamental mechanism for establishing a hardware-rooted chain of trust in modern computing systems. While formal verification using interactive theorem provers like Rocq offers strong correctness guarantees, existing approaches are often tightly coupled to specific hardware configurations and cryptographic algorithms, making them brittle and difficult to reuse when system components change. In this work, we present a flexible and modular framework for formally verifying secure boot processes in Rocq. Our approach introduces a three-layer abstraction model-Feature, Axiom, and Theorem-that decouples high-level security properties from lowlevel implementation details. We abstract critical components such as storage media and cryptographic primitives (e.g., encryption, signatures, hash functions) as interfaces with welldefined operators and axiomatic correctness properties. All highlevel proofs are conducted based on these axioms, without depending on concrete implementations. When specific algorithms or hardware are chosen, the axioms become proof obligations to be verified locally. This separation ensures that changes in implementation-such as switching cryptographic primitives or storage types-do not invalidate existing proofs, enabling significant proof reuse. We demonstrate the applicability of our framework in modeling a realistic secure boot chain. Our work lays the foundation for scalable and maintainable formal verification of trust-sensitive system initialization processes.

title: Adaptive Min–Max Mutual Information Graph Contrastive Learning
authors: Jiejin Gao, Yongli Wang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Digital Society and Intelligent Systems (DSInS)
abstract: Graph contrastive learning (GCL) has emerged as a powerful self-supervised approach for graph representation learning. However, traditional GCL methods often suffer from representation redundancy due to unconstrained mutual information maximization. To address this issue, we propose Adaptive Min-Max Mutual Information Graph Contrastive Learning (AMMI-GCL), which dynamically balances information consistency and diversity through an adaptive optimization mechanism. AMMI-GCL introduces a min-max mutual information objective that simultaneously maximizes semantic alignment between original and augmented views while minimizing redundancy among augmentations. Experiments on multiple benchmark datasets demonstrate that AMMI-GCL consistently outperforms state-of-the-art baselines in both unsupervised and semi-supervised settings, achieving superior representation diversity and robustness. This work provides new insights into redundancy reduction and paves the way for integrating graph contrastive learning with advanced deep learning architectures in future research.

title: Optimal Hovering Control Strategy for UAVs Using PPO
authors: Yutong Luo, Jianing Xu, Yongzhou Chen, Yinuo Yang, Tianyao Zheng, Hao Liu
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Machine Learning, Big Data and Business Intelligence (MLBDBI)
abstract: Hovering stability is a fundamental requirement for unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) in missions such as surveillance, inspection, and precision delivery. Conventional controllers, such as PID and model-based methods, often face performance degradation under environmental disturbances, sensor noise, and model uncertainties. To address these challenges, this paper presents an optimal hovering control strategy for UAVs using Proximal Policy Optimization (PPO). A comprehensive state-action representation of UAV dynamics is constructed, and a reward function is designed to jointly encourage precise position holding, energy-efficient control, and disturbance rejection. The proposed policy is trained iteratively in a high-fidelity simulation environment until convergence. To validate its effectiveness, extensive experiments compare the PPO-based controller with two state-of-the-art deep reinforcement learning baselines—Deep Deterministic Policy Gradient (DDPG) and Soft Actor-Critic (SAC). Results show that the proposed method achieves higher hovering accuracy, improved robustness under wind gusts and sensor noise, and reduced control effort compared with both conventional and DRL baselines. These findings demonstrate the potential of PPO for high-performance autonomous UAV hovering control and provide a solid foundation for real-world deployment and extension to more complex flight tasks.

title: Terahertz complete time domain spectroscopic ellipsometry
authors: Robin Silber, Jiaming Liu, Jakub Toběrný, Pierre Koleják, Lukáš Halagačka, Kamil Postava
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: Terahertz complete time-domain spectroscopic ellipsometry (THz-cTDSE) provides several advantages and opens a wide range of applications in optical metrology. We demonstrate the measurement of complete complex polarization response in terms of the Jones or Mueller matrix based on polarization switching by using a spintronic THz emitter (STE), which enables stable and efficient measurement. The general method is demonstrated on anisotropic crystal of Mercury Chloride.

title: Optoelectronic Hybrid Concept for Widely Tunable, Frequency- and Phase-Locked Continuous-Wave Optical Terahertz Beat Signals by Four-Wave Mixing
authors: M. Kocybik, A. Theis, F. Friederich, G. von Freymann, M. Bauer
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: Highly stabilized terahertz frequency signals are required in VNA concepts, e.g., for the precise frequency characterization of devices for future 6G communication applications. In this contribution, we present the extension of a recently demonstrated, optoelectronic hybrid locking scheme for the generation of widely tunable phase-locked laser beat signals in the terahertz range by a four-wave mixing approach. We use an optical phase-locked loop (OPLL) to stabilize the difference frequency of two continuous-wave lasers. The laser signals are amplified in tapered semiconductor optical amplifiers (SOAs) to induce four-wave mixing contributions. By selecting the optical signal frequencies in a filter setup, we obtain a wide range of frequency-locked beat signals which can be further employed for the optoelectronic generation and detection of highly stabilized terahertz photomixing signals.

title: A Multi-policy Approach Based on Clustering for Minimizing the Damage on a Falling Ballbot
authors: Giulia Buzzetti, Michel Aractingi, Davide Zappetti, Giovanni Iacca
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: Fall resilience remains a significant challenge for robots capable of locomotion. In the case of humanoid robots, arms can be utilized to mitigate impact damage, thereby improving resilience to falls. Although previous work has primarily focused on damage reduction strategies for legged robots, the question of minimizing fall damage in humanoid ballbots remains largely unexplored. In this paper, we introduce a novel multi-policy approach, combining clustering on the initial pose and Reinforcement Learning, to reduce damage resulting from a fall in a commercial humanoid ballbot. We conduct simulations to compare our method against three baselines: (1) a curriculum learning policy, (2) a single-policy approach enhanced by clustering information, and (3) a standard single-policy baseline. Experimental results demonstrate that our approach achieves higher success rates and greater damage reduction compared to existing alternatives.

title: Addressing Climate Change and Port Emissions : An In-Depth Analysis and Optimization of Maritime Trajectory Reconstruction using Hybrid AI Methodologies
authors: Boutheina Jlifi, Senda Sellami, Claude Duvallet, Khaled Guesmi, Marc-Arthur Diaye
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: The maritime transportation sector is as important as air and land transportation and must operate sustainability, minimizing waste and negative environmental impact. The optimization of vessel trajectories can achieve decarbonization and sustainability in this sector. This research supports climate finance goals by using data and information to make better decisions that reduce pollution and promote an environmentally friendly approach that improves shipping efficiency. In this methodological study, we review current research on vessel trajectory reconstruction, analyzing their strengths and limitations. We propose a novel approach that combines these current methods with advanced Artificial Intelligence (AI) techniques for better accuracy and efficiency in trajectory reconstruction. It is composed of four main steps; First, denoising the Automatic Identification System (AIS) data using Geohash-based Dynamic Time Warping (DTW) then applying U-Net for refining the trajectory grid. Second, extracting the most relevant trajectory features using Ant Colony Optimization (ACO). Third, reconstructing the trajectory using Geohash-DTW for long gaps and kinematic interpolation for short gaps. Finally, applying a temporal refinement using Bidirectional Gated Recurrent Unit (BiGRU) and optimizing the hyperparameters by applying a Genetic Algorithm (GA). Keywords : Trajectory reconstruction, maritime transportation, decarbonization, AI techniques, computational intelligence, energy transition, climate change, AIS data, Dynamic Time Warping (DTW).

title: Transforming Evacuation Simulations into Human-Understandable Narratives via LLMs and Multimodal RAG
authors: Yuto Hirahata, Fumihiro Sakahira
publish: 2025 IEEE Cyber Science and Technology Congress (CyberSciTech)
abstract: In agent-based evacuation simulations, results are typically presented using macro indicators such as "number of evacuees who completed evacuation" and "average evacuation time." However, these indicators do not adequately convey the individual evacuation processes of evacuees, making it difficult for residents and nonexperts to understand and empathize with evacuees’ situations. To address this, this study proposes a method that uses simulation log data as external data and combines large language models (LLMs) with search-enhanced generation (RAG) to automatically generate "evacuation stories," which are intuitive narratives in natural language that represent the individual action histories of each evacuee. When this method was applied to a tsunami evacuation simulation targeting a specific school district in Sakai City, Osaka, Japan, it was confirmed that the LLM could accurately interpret movement histories and delay points based on log data and generate coherent narratives. This method enables the intuitive communication of the background and congestion factors of the evacuation process to residents and nonexperts without specialized visualization literacy and is expected to serve as a new tool for enhancing understanding and presenting scenarios in disaster-prevention education and training.

title: A Dual-Pixel Photoconductive Antenna for Accurate Polarization Measurements
authors: H. Ou, M. Semtsiv, W. T. Masselink, E. Pickwell-MacPherson, J. Lloyd-Hughes
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: We proposed and fabricated a new design of multi-pixel photoconductive antenna to improve the performance of polarization-resolved THz spectroscopy and ellipsometry. The scheme is the combination of separated photoconductive stripes with an integrated, but spatially distinct, polarizer. The overall performance of the detector is evaluated in terms of polarization crosstalk, polarization sensitivity, signal-to-noise ratio, measurement accuracy, measurement repeatability and data acquisition efficiency. The dynamic range and bandwidth of THz spectra reach up to 80 dB and 6 THz. In addition, we demonstrate that the absolute error of the measured angle of linear polarization is less than 0.5˚. The devices facilitate a new approach to achieve rapid, high-accuracy and high-precision terahertz polarization-resolved measurements.

title: CyberShield: A Proposed Model for Building Cyber Resilience in Secondary Education
authors: Mia Amor C. Tinam-Isan, January F. Naga, Haron Hakeen Lua, Lomesindo Caparida
publish: 2025 IEEE Cyber Science and Technology Congress (CyberSciTech)
abstract: This study investigates the cybersecurity knowledge and risk perception of 767 high school students from grades 7 to 10, utilizing the Theory of Planned Behavior (TPB) framework for the survey questionnaire. Findings reveal that students are often in social media sites, and generally possess an average level of cybersecurity knowledge. Notably, lower-grade exhibits weaker skills in handling email messages, while higher-grade students show a lack of interest in educating themselves about social engineering. Additionally, students are often hesitant or reluctant to report incidents, even when they experience cyberattacks. Based on these insights, this study proposes a cybersecurity awareness framework incorporating the NIST Cybersecurity Framework 2.0 aiming to enhance students’ resilience against cyber threats. The proposed framework aims to bridge the gaps in cybersecurity education in the future, adopting a more proactive and security-conscious digital students.

title: A LASSO-Regularized Machine Learning Framework for Robust Multiclass Classification of Pediatric Leukemia using Gene Expression Data
authors: Samundi R, Vijayarani J
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Automation, Computing and Renewable Systems (ICACRS)
abstract: High-dimensional genomic data pose significant challenges for automated leukemia subtype classification due to redundant gene expressions, noisy features, and the risk of model overfitting. Pediatric leukemia diagnosis demands accurate and early subtype identification to support precision treatment. In this study, a leakage-free machine learning framework is proposed using Least Absolute Shrinkage and Selection Operator (LASSO) for genomic feature selection. The CuMiDa leukemia microarray dataset containing 64 samples with 22,283 gene features was used. The dataset was preprocessed using Min–Max normalization and evaluated using an 80/20 stratified train–test split. LASSO reduced the dimensionality to 701 informative genes, mitigating noise and improving model interpretability. Nine classifiers were trained and evaluated using 5×10 Repeated Stratified Cross-Validation, with performance assessed using Balanced Accuracy (BA), macro F1-score, and Matthews Correlation Coefficient (MCC), which is reliable for imbalanced data. Treebased ensemble models such as Gradient Boosting and XGBoost achieved strong and stable results across folds, while neural networks struggled due to limited samples. Although Random Forest achieved a perfect score on the test set, nested crossvalidation and permutation testing revealed that such results may be affected by dataset size, highlighting a risk of optimistic bias. Overall, the framework demonstrated strong generalization capability with MCC values above 0.90 for top-performing models, confirming reliable subtype separability. Future work will focus on increasing dataset size, incorporating biological pathway relevance, and applying explainable AI to strengthen clinical interpretability.

title: PeriGuru: A Peripheral Robotic Mobile App Operation Assistant based on GUI Image Understanding and Prompting with LLM
authors: Kelin Fu, Yang Tian, Kaigui Bian
publish: 2025 IEEE Cyber Science and Technology Congress (CyberSciTech)
abstract: Smartphones have significantly enhanced our daily learning, communication, and entertainment, becoming an essential component of modern life. However, certain populations, including the elderly and individuals with disabilities, encounter challenges in utilizing smartphones, thus necessitating mobile app operation assistants, a.k.a. mobile app agents. With considerations for privacy, permissions, and cross-platform compatibility issues, we endeavor to devise and develop PeriGuru in this work, a peripheral robotic mobile app operation assistant based on GUI image understanding and prompting with Large Language Model (LLM). PeriGuru leverages a suite of computer vision techniques to analyze GUI screenshot images and employs LLM to inform action decisions, which are then executed by robotic arms. PeriGuru achieves a success rate of 81.94% on the test task set, which surpasses by more than double the method without PeriGuru’s GUI image interpreting and prompting design. Our code is available on https://github.com/Z2sJ4t/PeriGuru.

title: Research on Predictive Control of Solar Heat Pump Heating Systems Based on Machine Learning
authors: Yan Wang
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Machine Learning, Big Data and Business Intelligence (MLBDBI)
abstract: To address nonlinearity and uncertainty in solar heat pump heating system operation, a machine learning-based predictive control framework is established. Methodologically, a multi-step predictive model is employed for dynamic forecasting of load and irradiation, combined with constrained model predictive control to optimize scheduling of compressor frequency, valve opening, and thermal storage tank state. The experimental platform operated under multiple typical conditions. Results show the prediction error RMSE was controlled within 0.42−0.68 kW. Compared to traditional methods, the proposed control strategy reduced energy consumption by over 16%, decreased room temperature deviation by approximately 56%, and significantly lowered the number of start-stop cycles. Conclusions indicate this method exhibits high stability and energy efficiency in complex environments, providing a feasible technical pathway for intelligent heating system operation.

title: AESPC 2025 Cover Page
authors: N/A
publish: 2025 5th IEEE International Conference on Applied Electromagnetics, Signal Processing, &amp; Communication (AESPC)

title: Developing a Method for an Optimized Static Vehicle Function Distribution
authors: Jan Ruhnau, Steffen Becker
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: The design of automotive electric/electronic (E/E) architectures has become increasingly complex due to the integration of numerous software-controlled functions. To address this complexity, we present a generic method for developing and implementing a vehicle function distribution optimization process. Our approach involves defining the design space, gathering relevant information from various sources, solving the optimization problem, and displaying the best configurations. Two processes are described for firstly developing, and successively using a method for the optimization. The resulting method is validated through two use-cases from the series development of current Mercedes vehicles. Validation runs show that our method can effectively optimize function distributions, reduce overhead costs, and improve system quality criteria in general, therefore providing a solid foundation for enhancing the design and development process of automotive E/E architectures.

title: A High Input Impedance AFE IC for Multi-channel Fetal ECG Detection with Dry Electrode
authors: Lisen Zhu, Piotr Dudek, H. B. Jayawan Wijekoon
publish: 2025 IEEE Biomedical Circuits and Systems Conference (BioCAS)
abstract: As fetal electrocardiographic (fECG) monitoring plays a crucial role in non-invasive prenatal diagnosis, the demand for accurate and reliable fECG acquisition systems is increasing. The dry electrode provides an ideal solution for the wearable fECG monitoring system design. However, input impedance matching and common-mode noise rejection remain significant challenges in the practical implementation of dry electrodes. This paper presents an analog front-end (AFE) integrated circuit specifically aimed at improving the quality of fECG signals detected by the wearable system with dry electrodes. The AFE utilizes bootstrapping circuits and an instrumentation amplifier to achieve high accuracy and stability. A driven-right-leg circuit is incorporated to effectively suppress electromagnetic interference. The AFE is designed and verified using 180 nm CMOS technology. The results demonstrate a high input impedance of $319 \mathrm{G} \Omega$ and a high CMRR of 106 dB. Furthermore, the proposed design offers a suitable gain, low power consumption, and high reliability, making it a promising solution for fECG monitoring with dry electrodes.

title: Research on Discharge Characteristics of Flexible Dielectric DBD in Porous Media Structures
authors: Song Jiang, Xin Yu, Chuwen Lin, Zhonghang Wu
abstract: Dielectric barrier discharge (DBD) can generate low-temperature plasma with a simple structure and has been widely studied in the field of plasma. In this article, a porous flexible DBD (PF-DBD) device composed of polyimide and soda-lime glass (SLG) is designed. Driven by a pulse power supply, the discharge characteristics of PF-DBD are similar to traditional DBD discharge; two discharges occur within one pulse cycle. As the voltage increases, the discharge gradually spreads from the edges of the hole toward the center, eventually covering the entire hole. An equivalent circuit model of PF-DBD is established, and plasma discharge power, charge transfer, and discharge efficiency are calculated. As the aperture increases, the plasma distribution at the center of the hole gradually becomes uniform, and the discharge morphology changes from filamentous discharge to glow discharge. Correspondingly, the transfer of charge and discharge efficiency also increased. As the number of holes increases, the electric fields between adjacent holes interact through mutual shielding and cancellation effects, resulting in a more uniform overall electric field distribution. The uniformity of discharge, discharge efficiency, and transfer of charge also increase accordingly. Finally, the emission spectrum at different apertures is analyzed and it is found that the emission spectrum intensity is highest at 14-mm aperture. The molecular vibration stability and rotational temperature are obtained by fitting the emission spectrum. The vibrational temperature under small apertures is significantly higher than that under large apertures, while the rotational temperature remains relatively stable.

title: Hisui: Unlocking Tiered Memory Efficiency for FaaS Workloads
authors: Seonggyu Han, Sangwoong Kim, Minho Kim, Daehoon Kim
abstract: Modern tiered-memory architectures are increasingly adopted in cloud servers with extensive physical capacity. Realizing their full performance potential, however, requires effective page management. Existing systems, tuned for long-running workloads, primarily rely on access-count-based promotion. Yet this policy is ill-suited to the short-lived, event-driven model of Function-as-a-Service (FaaS) workloads. The resulting workload-architecture mismatch yields poor page placement and severely degrades architectural efficiency. We present Hisui, a FaaS-aware tiered-memory management system tailored to FaaS workloads. It stages pages with high expected reuse using two mechanisms: an FMem admission filter and an invocation-frequency-weighted valuation that promotes pages by descending gain. Hisui delivers up to 1.57× higher throughput than access-count baselines and consistently lowers latency on real workloads.

title: Repetition-rate Scaling Of Two-color Air-plasma THz Sources Up To 100 kHz
authors: Robin Löscher, Malte C. Schroeder, Tim Vogel, Alan Omar, Adam Hasso, Claudius Hoberg, Martina Havenith, Clara J. Saraceno
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: Two-color air-plasma THz sources are a unique tool for THz time-domain spectroscopy applications calling for ultrabroad bandwidths. Achieving high dynamic ranges (DR) at these bandwidths in coherent detection schemes are significantly challenging. One attractive option for enhancing DR and thus the possible applications of such ultra-broadband systems is the use of high repetition rate driving lasers, enabling for fast averaging methods. This can be achieved by increasing the driving average power using Yb-based sources. However, the generation mechanisms in plasmas are expected to change at high repetition rates due to the short temporal separation of the driving pulses and corresponding accumulation effects. In this study, we investigate repetition rate scaling of these sources up to 100 kHz, and present new ultra-broadband transient measurements spanning up to 23 THz at these high repetition rates using EOS in organic crystals. A maximum average power of 2.8 mW is reached at 100 kHz, and we observe only a moderate loss in optical-to-THz conversion efficiency (19 %) as the repetition rate increases from 1 to 100 kHz. The decrease is consistent with a stationary gas density depression at the filament caused by air hydrodynamics at these high repetition rates, which we confirm by interferometry.

title: Research on real-time obstacle avoidance algorithm for UAV swarm based on lattice Boltzmann
authors: Minheng Yu, Yujun Li, Chaofeng Liu, Shengcong Li
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Big Data, Artificial Intelligence and Internet of Things Engineering (ICBAIE)
abstract: Obstacle avoidance for unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) swarms in complex, dynamic environments is still challenged by sudden obstacles. Existing approaches fall into two categories: rule-based methods (e.g., artificial potential fields, velocity obstacles), which respond quickly but are sensitive to parameters and prone to local minima; and optimization-based methods (e.g., RRT* and genetic algorithms, GA), which offer global feasibility but typically require costly replanning after environmental changes, limiting real-time performance. To address these limitations, we propose a flow-field-driven avoidance algorithm based on the lattice Boltzmann method (LBM). By embedding obstacles as boundary conditions in the flow field, each UAV follows the local flow direction and uses PD control to update its heading continuously, without recomputing a full path. Two-dimensional simulations with both static and sudden obstacles compare the proposed method against RRT* and GA. Results show that all three methods avoid obstacles in static settings; however, under sudden obstacles, RRT* and GA collide unless replanning is invoked, whereas the LBM method immediately reroutes and maintains smooth, collision-free trajectories, demonstrating superior real-time responsiveness and robustness. This study provides a new avenue for online safe flight of UAV swarms in complex dynamic environments.

title: Assessing the Effectiveness of ChatGPT for Enhancing Programming Skills Among SecondYear Computer Science Students in Tunisia
authors: Noureddine Aissa, Hédia Sellami Mhiri
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: The integration of Artificial Intelligence (AI) into everyday life, including education, is rapidly expanding but faces challenges, particularly in aligning AI tools with educational theories and roles. This study investigates ChatGPT’s use for learning programming in Tunisian secondary schools, using qualitative and quantitative methods. The research assessed AI’s impact on students’ coding and logical thinking. An experiment with three schools divided students into an AI-assisted group and a traditional instruction group, with pre-tests and post-tests measuring the impact. Results showed ChatGPT positively influences programming skills and logical reasoning. Despite limitations like small sample size and technical constraints, the study opens new research avenues. Future research should explore larger samples and various educational levels, examining long-term effects on problem-solving, emotional engagement, and readiness for complex challenges. Tailoring AI tools to specific contexts could enhance their effectiveness, marking a step toward integrating AI in education.

title: A Gift from the Integration of Discriminative and Diffusion-based Generative Learning: Boundary Refinement Remote Sensing Semantic Segmentation
authors: Hao Wang, Keyan Hu, Xin Guo, Haifeng Li, Chao Tao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Pattern Analysis and Machine Intelligence
abstract: Remote sensing semantic segmentation must address both what the ground objects are within an image and where they are located. Consequently, segmentation models must ensure not only the semantic correctness of large-scale patches (low-frequency information) but also the precise localization of boundaries between patches (high-frequency information related to boundary components). However, most existing approaches rely heavily on discriminative learning, which excels at capturing low-frequency features, while overlooking its inherent limitations in learning high-frequency features for semantic segmentation. Recent studies have revealed that diffusion generative models excel at generating high-frequency details. Our theoretical analysis confirms that the diffusion denoising process significantly enhances the model's ability to learn high-frequency features; however, we also observe that these models exhibit insufficient semantic inference for low-frequency features when guided solely by the original image. Therefore, we integrate the strengths of both discriminative and generative learning, proposing the Integration of Discriminative and diffusion-based Generative learning for Boundary Refinement (IDGBR) framework. The framework first generates a coarse segmentation map using a discriminative backbone model. This map and the original image are fed into a conditioning guidance network to jointly learn a guidance representation subsequently leveraged by an iterative denoising diffusion process refining the coarse segmentation. Extensive experiments across five remote sensing semantic segmentation datasets (binary and multi-class segmentation) confirm our framework's capability of consistent boundary refinement for coarse results from diverse discriminative architectures. The source code is available at <uri xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">https://github.com/KeyanHu-git/IDGBR</uri>.

title: Multi-Modal Spatiotemporal Behavior Recognition and Visualization in Classroom Environments
authors: Chunyan Yu, Lan Gao, Meiling Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE 31th International Conference on Parallel and Distributed Systems (ICPADS)
abstract: The automatic analysis of student behavior in classroom environments poses substantial challenges in computer vision, encompassing fine-grained action recognition, long-term multi-object tracking, and the integration of heterogeneous video data sources. In this paper, we propose a novel multi-modal framework for the spatiotemporal recognition and visualization of student behavior in technology-enhanced classrooms. Our system processes two synchronous video streams: a primary classroom video feed and a secondary screen capture of the instructor's computer screen. The core of our method is a dual-stream processing pipeline. The visual stream performs student detection, classifies seven distinct behaviors using Stu-B-YOLO, an enhanced YOLO-based model, and maintains consistent student identities across 2,700 frames via a coordinate-based tracking algorithm. Simultaneously, the screen analysis stream employs an optical character recognition (OCR) module to detect and temporally localize interactive learning phases, which are identified by specific on-screen elements from the “Rain Classroom” platform. A key contribution is our context-aware fusion module, which dynamically recalibrates the semantic interpretation of certain behaviors—for instance, reclassifying “smartphone usage” as active participation—during these identified interactive intervals. We construct a dataset of 9,000 annotated images to train and evaluate our Stu-BYOLO. Experimental results demonstrate that our framework achieves robust performance in behavior recognition and generates powerful, interpretable visualizations of classroom dynamics, thereby offering a valuable tool for automated educational analytics.
