title: Bend Stress Isolation Structure on the PCB: Fourfold Crab-Leg Stabilize Accelerometer Bias
authors: Keitaro Ito, Teruhisa Akashi, Hirofumi Funabashi, Shota Harada, Hiroyuki Wado
abstract: Assembly-induced stresses such as PCB warpage and clamp loads propagate through the package to the MEMS die and perturb accelerometer bias. This letter presents a PCB-integrated stress-relief structure: a planar, fourfold-symmetric crab-leg (folded-beam) flexure that forms an “IMU island” via through-slots, attenuating stress transmission regardless of load direction while preserving four-sided routing. Finite-element analysis of a molded IMU package on a clamped–clamped PCB under mid-span deflection shows that the area-averaged von Mises stress at the MEMS anchor interface is reduced to 0.23× compared with a plain PCB. A clamped–clamped bending fixture with a recessed loading pin, load sensing, 3D surface profiling, and a calibration–inference procedure maps measured displacements to a Plain-PCB-equivalent surface stress, enabling fair comparison across layouts over an approximately ±40 MPa range. Measurements confirm that, relative to the plain PCB, accelerometer bias change decreases from 4.9 mG to 1.6 mG on X (0.32×) and from 48 mG to 8.4 mG on Z (0.18×), with no clear reduction on Y. These results demonstrate that board-level flexures reduce assembly-induced bias drift and provide a practical, user-implementable approach to stabilize MEMS IMU accelerometers without altering the device or package.

title: Terahertz Spectroscopy of GaN Quantum Wells on AlN Substrates
authors: Verdad C. Agulto, Shuang Liu, Kosaku Kato, Thanh Nhat Khoa Phan, Yu-Hsin Chen, Chuan Chang, Joseph Dill, Jimy Encomendero, Debdeep Jena, Huili Grace Xing, Jia Wang, Haitao Wang, Hiroshi Amano, Makoto Nakajima
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: We investigated the transport properties of polarization-induced carriers in AlN/GaN/AlN and GaN/AlN heterostructures using terahertz spectroscopy. These heterostructures are uniquely designed to host a two-dimensional electron gas (2DEG), a 2D hole gas (2DHG), or both. By comparing their terahertz spectral responses, we experimentally confirm the presence of a 2DHG channel that is theoretically predicted to coexist with the 2DEG in AlN/GaN/AlN quantum well structures.

title: Development of microwave SQUID multiplexer for readout of transition-edge sensor array
authors: Zhi-Fa Feng, Xian-Feng Zhou, Wen Zhang, Zheng Wang, Qing-Xiao Ma, Pei-Zhan Li, Jia-Qiang Zhong, Wei Miao, Yuan Ren, Qi-Jun Yao, Valery Koshelets, Lyudmila Filippenko, Michael Fominsky, Jing Li, Sheng-Cai Shi
abstract: Superconducting transition-edge sensors (TESs) with high sensitivity can detect electromagnetic wave radiations from millimeter/submillimeter, optical to x/γ rays, and have been successfully used in many fields. To improve detection efficiency and sensitivity, large-scale TES arrays are required in combination with multiplexing readout electronics. Compared to other multiplexing schemes, microwave SQUID multiplexing (μMUX), consisting of high-quality microwave superconducting resonators and RF SQUIDs, is most suitable since it provides a wider bandwidth (GHz) and consequently higher multiplexing factor. We designed two types of circuits with different mutual inductances (MT) between the resonator and the RF SQUID: 2.3 pH for the weak-coupling channel and 6.5 pH for the strong- coupling channel. The resonator and RF SQUID washers made of 150 nm Nb are first fabricated by magnetron-sputtering and reactive ion etching (RIE), followed by deposition of Nb/Al-AlOx/Nb trilayer and definition of the Josephson junctions of the RF SQUIDs. This work presents a μMUX demonstration chip with five channels with Q1 values of 787 and 3626, and the measured frequency shifts (Δfpp) of ∼500 kHz and 4 MHz for the weak- and strong-coupling channels, respectively. The open-loop equivalent noise current, obtained from the measured phase noise and resonator responsivity, is ∼80 pA/ √Hz with the strong-coupling channel.

title: Proof of Reasoning for Privacy Enhanced Federated Blockchain Learning at the Edge
authors: James Calo, Benny Lo
abstract: Consensus mechanisms are the core of any blockchain system. However, the majority of these mechanisms do not target federated learning directly nor do they aid in the aggregation step. This paper introduces Proof of Reasoning (PoR), a novel consensus mechanism specifically designed for federated learning using blockchain, aimed at preserving data privacy, defending against malicious attacks, and enhancing the validation of participating networks. Unlike generic blockchain consensus mechanisms commonly found in the literature, PoR integrates three distinct processes tailored for federated learning. Firstly, a masked autoencoder (MAE) is trained to generate an encoder that functions as a feature map and obfuscates input data, rendering it resistant to human reconstruction and model inversion attacks. Secondly, a downstream classifier is trained at the edge, receiving input from the trained encoder. The downstream network’s weights, a single encoded datapoint, the network’s output and the ground truth are then added to a block for federated aggregation. Lastly, this data facilitates the aggregation of all participating networks, enabling more complex and verifiable aggregation methods than previously possible. This three-stage process results in more robust networks with significantly reduced computational complexity, maintaining high accuracy by training only the downstream classifier at the edge. PoR scales to large IoT networks with low latency and storage growth, and adapts to evolving data, regulations, and network conditions.

title: Biologically Inspired EEG Encoding Using Spiking Neuron Models: Comparative Study of LIF, Izhikevich, and AdEx
authors: R Vasanthi, V Asha, Binsu J Kailath
publish: 2025 IEEE Biomedical Circuits and Systems Conference (BioCAS)
abstract: Accurate and efficient encoding of EEG signals is critical for neuromorphic computing and braininspired systems. This work investigates three spiking neuron models-Leaky Integrate-and-Fire (LIF), Izhikevich, and Adaptive Exponential Integrate-and-Fire (AdEx)-for converting raw EEG signals into spike trains while preserving temporal and amplitude features. Each model is systematically tuned and evaluated for encoding fidelity, spiking dynamics, and hardware efficiency. The Izhikevich model offers a balance between dynamic range and implementation complexity but exhibits saturation in certain regimes. AdEx achieves the highest temporal fidelity and adaptive modulation, making it most suitable for EEG encoding. Hardware synthesis at 10 kHz in 45 nm CMOS reveals that LIF consumes the least power $(27.5 \mathrm{nW})$ and area ($0.00117 \mathrm{~mm}^{2}$), while AdEx provides the best trade-off between accuracy and resource use (186.9 nW, $0.0073 \mathrm{~mm}^{2}$). These findings guide the design of lowpower, spike-based EEG processing systems for real-time neuromorphic applications.

title: Enhanced Zeroing Neural Network for Kinematic Control of Surgical Manipulator Under RCM Constraints
authors: Jing Guo, Kaiyao Luo, Yinlu Gan, Weixing Wu, Xi Yuan, Haohui Huang, Zhan Li, Chenguang Yang, Haifang Lou
publish: IEEE Transactions on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics: Systems
abstract: In minimally invasive surgery, surgical instruments are typically inserted through small incisions in the patient’s body, which serve as the remote center of motion (RCM). In robot-assisted minimally invasive surgery, developing control algorithms that comply with RCM constraints is highly challenging due to the nonlinear nature of robot motion models and the stringent precision requirements necessary for patient safety. This article introduces an enhanced zeroing neural network (EZNN) model for controlling redundant manipulators while maintaining RCM constraints. The proposed model eliminates the need for pseudoinverse matrix computations and features an explicit dynamic form. It guarantees finite-time convergence and demonstrates robustness through the application of nonlinear activation functions (AFs). These properties are rigorously validated using Lyapunov theory. Simulation and experimental results indicate that the EZNN model surpasses Jacobian-based algorithms and recurrent neural networks (RNNs) in terms of efficiency and stability, all while ensuring adherence to RCM constraints.

title: Medical Microwave Imaging Using Physics-Guided Deep Learning Part 2: The Inverse Solver
authors: L. Guo, A. Bialkowski, A. Abbosh
abstract: Deep learning has the potential to address the bottleneck of conventional medical microwave tomography, which is ill-posed and has a high computation cost. However, current physics-guided deep learning methods may fail to capture the imaged object's salient regions, resulting in misdiagnosis. A deep neural network inspired by the distorted Born iterative method (DBIM) is proposed to address this challenge. This method, which avoids using Green’s function, provides a theoretical explanation of why current deep learning methods guided by iterative physics algorithms fail in detecting abnormal tissues, making them unsuitable for real-life clinical applications. The proposed method consists of two main components: a set of forward neural network solvers and a series of inverse neural network blocks for updating the dielectric contrast of the imaging domain. The training of the network, designed to emulate the DBIM framework, is regularized by a hybrid loss function composed of two supervised and one self-supervised function. Each iteration in DBIM is performed using a neural network block with parameters different from those of other blocks, forming a sequential iterative approach. By calculating the perturbations in the electrical properties’ profiles at each iteration, the proposed network can accurately reconstruct abnormal tissues associated with signals masked by those from healthy tissues. Assessments of the proposed method using the relative error, structure similarity index measure, Dice similarity coefficient, and Hausdorff distance show significant enhancements (19%, 18%, 40%, and 72%, respectively) compared to two recent deep learning-based microwave medical imaging algorithms.

title: Low-Temperature THz spectroscopic study on SMS single crystal: Evidence of Orientation-Dependent phonon behavior
authors: Yamuna Murtunge, Vibhavari Parkar, Snehal Haldankar, S.B. Kulkarni, S.S. Prabhu
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: We report the angle-dependent THz-TDS to study the low-temperature behavior of SMS crystals. No phonon modes were observed for the 0° oriented crystal(a-axis) at room temperature; however, it emerged at three different frequencies at low temperatures. At the same time, there is a blue shift in phonon mode for the 50° oriented crystal. We analyzed the optical constants at both orientations relative to THz polarization for 10K and room temperature.

title: Boosting Hyperspectral Image Classification with a 3D CNN and Vision Transformer Hybrid Architecture
authors: Ghazala Hcini, Imen Jdey
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: In recent years, Vision Transformer (ViT) models for hyperspectral image (HSI) classification have increased popularity due to their excellence in modeling long-range spatial-spectral dependencies, which have achieved state-of-the-art performance in classification, object detection, and segmentation tasks. However, ViTs are likely to miss local spatial features with fine granularity, while convolutional neural networks (CNNs) excel at extracting local patterns but cannot model long-range dependencies. We propose a hybrid framework that combines a 3D Residual CNN and a ViT module to counter these limitations. The CNN component possesses the ability to extract fine-grained local spectral and spatial information, which is passed through the ViT for extracting global contextual dependencies. Experimental evaluation on three benchmark HSI datasets, Indian Pines (IP), Pavia University (PU), and Salinas (SA), confirms the superiority of our approach. Experimental results show that our method outperforms the state-of-the-art methods in Hyperspectral image classification tasks, demonstrating good performance and potential application prospects.

title: Comparative Analysis of Traditional and VR-Based Learning in Schools: Results and Challenges
authors: Elitsa Bakalova
abstract: The present study presents a comparative analysis between traditional and VR-based learning in schools, aiming to evaluate the effect of virtual reality on students’ knowledge, motivation, and concentration. The study involved 50 students from grades 8–10, divided into a control group (traditional learning) and an experimental group (learning through VR simulations using the Mozaik platform). The learning content covered three thematic areas—biology, physics/technology, and history—presented through 3D scenes.The methodology included pre- and post-tests to measure knowledge, survey questionnaires to assess motivation and concentration, as well as measurements of time and accuracy in performing learning tasks. The results showed that students in the VR group achieved nearly twice the knowledge gain (+35.8% compared to +18.4% in the control group), higher scores for motivation (4.5 vs. 3.2) and concentration (4.6 vs. 3.4), as well as better performance in terms of speed and accuracy.The conclusions of the study confirm that VR-based learning supports the acquisition of complex and abstract concepts, enhances emotional engagement, and stimulates active learning. The contribution of the research lies in providing new empirical data from the Bulgarian school context, validating the applicability of VR as an effective educational tool. (Abstract)

title: SASet: A Unified Approach for Modeling and Interaction of Multiple Architectures in Large Software Applications
authors: Hristo Hristov
abstract: This paper introduces the concept of the Software Architectures Set (SASet) as a logical and organizational unit designed to integrate and coordinate multiple architectures within one or more large-scale applications. Beyond architectures, SASet may also incorporate additional extended elements (EEs) such as patterns, technologies, frameworks, standards, methodologies and etc., forming a comprehensive architectural ecosystem. As a result, SASet can be regarded as a composite architecture, where the combined behavior of its elements defines the system-level qualities. A methodology for constructing and applying SASet is proposed, including phases of initialization, architecture (or EE) selection, relation definition and interaction mechanisms. The proposed concept has the potential to make a substantial contribution to the evolution of architectural engineering especially toward large scale software systems. The primary objective of SASet is to replace the notion of a single architecture in methodologies, tools and analytical frameworks, thereby enabling them to address systems composed of multiple architectures and EEs.

title: Low-Power Integrated Circuit for Bipolar Driving of Piezoelectric Resonant MEMS Scanners with up to 100 Vpp and Energy Recovery
authors: Leon Pohl, Wjatscheslaw Galjan, Andreas Bahr
publish: 2025 IEEE Biomedical Circuits and Systems Conference (BioCAS)
abstract: Augmented Reality (AR) glasses are gaining traction in biomedical applications such as surgical navigation, diagnostics and rehabilitation. These use cases benefit from compact, lightweight and energy-efficient AR systems. A promising projection technology for such glasses is laser beam scanning based on piezoelectrically driven resonant MEMS scanners. However, these require high-voltage and preferably rectangular actuation signals with voltages up to $\mathbf{1 0 0} \mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{pp}}$. Conventional drivers easily consume tens of milliwatts, which is unacceptable as it prevents further reduction of the battery size of AR glasses. The demonstrated ASIC reduces power consumption for driving a piezoelectric structure or capacitive load by up to 82% compared to a conventional ideal half bridge driver, resulting in a power consumption of only 5.8 mW when driving a two-dimensional MEMS with a total frequency of approximately 60 kHz and diagonal scan angle of 30° optimized for high quality AR projections.

title: MRAM In-Memory Computing with Periodic Margin Boost and INL Cancellation
authors: Shuyu Wang, Zhenghan Fang, Haoran Du, Hao Cai
abstract: This paper presents a spin transfer torque magnetic random access memory (STT-MRAM) in-memory computing (IMC) proposal. A periodic voltage margin boost scheme is proposed to enhance the readout margin of current accumulation and a novel integral non-linearity (INL) cancellation scheme based on complementary current mirrors (CMs) is adopted. An IMC macro is proposed for binary multiply accumulate (MAC) operations. The proposal is simulated using 28nm CMOS process and MTJ compact model. Compared to conventional current accumulation scheme, the proposed scheme achieves 2.05× margin boost and 16× INL reduction. The overall energy efficiency of binary MAC operation reaches 15.6-36.3TOPSIW.

title: Positive Matching Benefits Fusion: A Novel Contrastive Learning Framework for Hyperspectral and LiDAR Data Classification
authors: Hui Liu, Chenjia Huang, Tao Xie, Wei Bao, Ning Chen, Jun Yue, Leyuan Fang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Recent advancements in contrastive learning have led to significant progress in multi-modal remote sensing data classification, such as hyperspectral and LiDAR data, particularly in scenarios with limited labeled samples. However, these methods primarily rely on the contrast between positive and negative pairs, which makes them susceptible to interference from negative sample selection, thereby impairing effective multi-modal fusion and ultimately affecting classification accuracy. To address this issue, this paper introduces a novel framework for the joint classification of hyperspectral image (HSI) and LiDAR, termed the multi-Positive Matching-enhanced Contrastive Learning (mPMCL). The proposed framework facilitates contrastive training by matching multiple positive pairs across different modalities and hierarchical features of the same object, hence effectively enhancing multi-modal fusion and improving classification performance. Specifically, the HCIF module performs hierarchical and consistency-aware fusion by using a bidirectional cross-attention mechanism to integrate low-level, cross-modal interaction, and high-level semantic features from HSI and LiDAR data. This process gradually aligns heterogeneous representations across stages and captures complementary spectral–elevation cues, leading to more stable and discriminative multimodal features. Additionally, a multi-Positive Matching Strategy (mPMS) is develpoed to construct multiple positive pairs by matching high-level semantic features of the same object with low-level- and cross-modal fusion features from different modalities. By performing contrastive training on these positive pairs, the proposed method avoids the sensitivity of traditional approaches to negative sample selection, while further enhancing the effectiveness of multi-modal information fusion. The pivotal contribution of the proposed framework lies in demonstrating the importance of positive matching enhanced contrastive learning strategies for effective multi-modal information fusion. Experimental results on several publicly available datasets show that the proposed framework outperforms existing state-of-the-art methods. Our code is publicly available at https://github.com/HoppouCJ/mPMCL.

title: A clustering based bi-objective optimization of the location of electric charging stations in Tunis
authors: Amira Mzita, Wassila Aggoune-Mtalaa, Hend Bouziri
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: With the increasing adoption of electric vehicles (EVs) in urban areas like Tunis, the strategic placement of charging stations is paramount. This paper presents a novel approach to optimize the placement of EV chargers in Tunis using a clustering-based bi-objective evolutionary algorithm. This algorithm simultaneously minimizes two objectives which may be conflicting: the costs of the chargers installation and the coverage of the charging infrastructure. By considering these objectives concurrently, the proposed method aims to strike a balance between minimizing the deployment costs and ensuring a sufficient coverage to meet the users demands. Through simulations conducted on a benchmark example in Tunis, we assess the algorithm’s effectiveness in generating Pareto-optimal solutions that offer trade-offs between cost and coverage. The findings underscore the potential of the bi-objective algorithm in proposing new interesting solutions for the placement of EV chargers, thereby contributing to the development of a sustainable transportation infrastructure in Tunis.

title: Stability Control Strategy of Nonlinear Transportation Cyber-Physical System Based on Interval Type-2 Fuzzy Model
authors: Muzhe Gan
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Automation, Electronics and Electrical Engineering (AUTEEE)
abstract: Aiming at the problems of nonlinearity and uncertainty in transportation cyber-physical systems (TCPSs), this paper proposes an elastic control strategy based on interval type-2 (IT-2) fuzzy model for TCPSs with external disturbances. Firstly, considering the suspension system as a key link between the vehicle and the road, which is selected as the main object of study. According to IT-2 fuzzy rules, a fuzzy suspension system model is established to characterize its nonlinearity and uncertainty. Then, an elastic controller based on IT-2 model is established, and sufficient conditions are derived by Lyapunov function. Finally, the advancement and feasibility of the proposed theory are verified by simulation.

title: Design of a Control System for Small Unmanned Aerial Vehicles in Single-Person Operation Scenarios
authors: Yufan Du
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Automation, Electronics and Electrical Engineering (AUTEEE)
abstract: This paper presents the design of a control system for small unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) tailored to single-person operation scenarios. The system emphasizes flexibility, multi-tasking capabilities, and environmental adaptability. It employs a collaborative architecture using DSP and FPGA, integrating various communication protocols (TTL, CAN-FD, RS-422, Ethernet, etc.) to interface with devices such as radar, attitude sensors, data radios, and actuators. The system implements a highly reliable task control state machine, parameter injection, and task reconfiguration mechanisms, along with low-latency communication protocols between the upper and lower computers. This paper provides an in-depth analysis of the system structure, communication mechanisms, ground station functions, and task processes. MATLAB/Simulink simulations of discrete control laws validate the system's stability, control accuracy, and multi-task adaptability, offering a robust control system architecture suitable for widespread applications of small UAVs in civilian sectors.

title: Exceptional Point in a Metamaterial-Cavity Coupled System
authors: Elham Talvari, Lei Cao, Fanqi Meng, Hartmut G. Roskos
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: An Exceptional Point (EP) is a unique spectral singularity in a non-Hermitian system, where both eigenvalues and their corresponding eigenvectors coalesce. Unlike degeneracies in Hermitian systems, EPs exhibit a range of intriguing features, such as loss-induced transparency and enhanced sensitivity. EPs have been demonstrated in various coupled systems, including coupled metamaterials (MMs) and coupled whispering-gallery-mode cavities. In this work, we investigate the coupling between a C-type complementary MM and a polarized photonic cavity. Both components are polarization-sensitive, and the coupling strength can be tuned by varying their relative orientation. As the coupling strength is gradually reduced, we observe the coalescence of two polariton modes, indicating the presence of an EP. Remarkably, when monitoring the polarization orthogonal to the cavity mode, the EP reveals itself through a transition from two Fano resonances to an electromagnetically-induced-transparency-(EIT-)like feature. This tunable coupled system offers a promising platform for highly sensitive sensing applications.

title: Roadmap to a Panchromatic Heterodyne Receiver System Stretching from 85 to 700 GHz
authors: Cheuk-Yu Edward Tong, Garrett Keating, Raymond Blundell
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: A panchromatic heterodyne receiver system stretching from 85 to 700 GHz will open new frontiers in both radio astronomy and remote sensing by providing diverse observational data over a decade of frequency. In this paper, we examine the various technological advances which can be exploited to create such a receiver system. These include the concept of a Zero-IF receiver together with a low-loss optical multiplexer based on dielectric stacks. Furthermore, the use of a superconducting reflectionless diplexer will be key in the development of a dual channel receiver system with a wide spectral coverage.

title: Probing water librations by optical-pump mid-IR probe spectroscopy
authors: Meera Ramachandran, Claudius Hoberg, Fabio Novelli, Martina Havenith
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: Librational motion, which involves the restricted rotational movement of water molecules, plays a crucial role in water's molecular dynamics. These motions are significant in the relaxation of the hydrogen bond network and energy transfer mechanisms. In order to explore the ultrafast dynamics of water's librational band (12 – 21 THz), we designed a time-resolved optical-pump mid-IR probe spectroscopy. Here, we present the details of the experimental setup in this challenging frequency range and first results.

title: Dashboards for Learning Analytics to Encourage Advisor–Student Communication
authors: Sana Jabeen, Ravi Uyyala, Padmavathi Vurubindi, R Ravinder Reddy
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Automation, Computing and Renewable Systems (ICACRS)
abstract: Learning analytics dashboards (LADs) are now very effective tools for turning raw academic data into meaningful information that can help advisers and students talk to each other better. This paper proposes a comprehensive technique that integrates visualization, predictive modeling, and feedback analytics to bridge the divide between data-driven performance analysis and qualitative academic advice. The intended system’s key goals are personalized academic planning, early intervention, and getting people involved. The paper illustrates the potential impact of advisor-centric dashboards on academic decision-making processes, identifies research deficiencies, and provides a critical evaluation of existing systems. The results reveal that advisors are better at organizing academics, acting quickly, and communicating more clearly.

title: Algorithmic Efficiency in Rubik’s Cube Solving: A Study of Timeout Rates, Solution Quality, and Heuristic Limitations
authors: Miguel Angel Garcia Higuita, Shan Faiz, Rand Kouatly, Loubna Ali, Meerah Karunanith
abstract: Solving the Rubik’s Cube represents a classical benchmark for evaluating search algorithms in artificial intelligence due to its well-defined state space and computational complexity. The application of search techniques to this problem offers insights into algorithmic efficiency and practical performance in constrained environments. Despite extensive research on heuristic search methods, comparative studies involving uninformed and informed search strategies applied to different cube sizes remain limited. This study addresses that gap by evaluating Depth-First Search (DFS), Breadth-First Search (BFS), and A* Search in solving the NxN Rubik’s Cube. The experiment involves a facelet-based representation of the cube and simulates randomized scrambles of increasing complexity. Each algorithm is implemented in C++ and evaluated on performance metrics including solution length, execution time, and completeness under varied depth limits and cube sizes. Results show that A* Search consistently outperforms both DFS and BFS in terms of execution speed and reliability, achieving optimal or near-optimal solutions without timeouts. BFS demonstrates optimality but suffers from scalability, while DFS offers flexibility with higher time costs. This study provides a practical and measurable comparison of search strategies, highlighting A* as the most balanced approach for real-time puzzle solving within smart systems.

title: Anomaly Detection of Vehicle Data Stream Based on LSTMAM
authors: Jinfeng Zhang, Yuezhong Zhang, Yabing Peng, Zhen Zhang, Yupeng Zhang, Shaoxun Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE 31th International Conference on Parallel and Distributed Systems (ICPADS)
abstract: During the transmission of Controller Area Network (CAN) data streams in intelligent connected vehicles, security risks such as non-compliant data reporting and cross-border data leakage inevitably arise. Traditional anomaly detection methods based on statistics and machine learning often fail to comprehensively identify irregularities in the content of transmitted data. To overcome the limitation, this paper proposes an anomaly detection approach for CAN data streams that integrates a heterogeneous Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) model with an Attention Mechanism (AM). First, periodic characteristics at the byte level within CAN message fields are statistically analyzed, revealing distinctive inter-byte feature variations. Based on the periodicity of each byte-level data stream, a heterogeneous LSTM model incorporating varied parameters-such as time step size and network width-is designed. A corresponding detection framework leveraging heterogeneous LSTM with AM (LSTMAM) is introduced. Furthermore, a fusion strategy between LSTM and the attention mechanism is developed to weight the influence of different hidden states on prediction outcomes. Finally, comparative experiments under various attack scenarios were conducted utilizing publicly available and vehicle-collected CAN message datasets. Comparative results demonstrate that the proposed method significantly improves detection accuracy over existing approaches, validating its effectiveness at identifying anomalies in CAN data streams.

title: A Multi-dimensional Data Lineage Construction Method Based on BERT Semantic Fusion and Structural Characterization
authors: Mengqi Lu, Xiaoli Ren, Yong Cheng, Xiaolong Xu, Xiang Zhu, Chengcheng Shao, Xiaoyong Li, Maowen Li
publish: 2025 IEEE Cyber Science and Technology Congress (CyberSciTech)
abstract: Against the backdrop of digital transformation, issues such as metadata fragmentation, data silos, and low-quality data from inconsistent data standards across business systems have hindered the release of data value. However, traditional data lineage analysis methods struggle to meet precise governance needs due to high computational complexity, semantic understanding biases, and high implementation costs. To address these, we propose a multi-dimensional lineage identification framework integrating BERT-based domain semantic modeling, weighted Levenshtein dynamic programming edit distance, and quantitative analysis of table structure field intersections. The framework captures deep semantic associations between data entities via a domain-specific fine-tuned BERT model, optimizes table name matching accuracy using an edit distance algorithm with a common prefix compensation mechanism, and balances evaluation biases from field quantity differences by incorporating core field overlap metrics. Experimental results show this scheme significantly outperforms traditional methods in lineage relationship identification accuracy (F1-score of 95.38%) and cross-domain adaptability, providing a solution with theoretical innovation and engineering practicality for data traceability and quality control in metadata governance.

title: Col-TEEs: Secure and Efficient Collaborative Inference Framework in Heterogeneous TEEs
authors: Xu Liu, Tao Li, Zhaolong Jian, Xueshuo Xie, Mulin Li, Gang Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE 31th International Conference on Parallel and Distributed Systems (ICPADS)
abstract: Deep Neural Network (DNN) inference is a key enabler of edge intelligence, but its high computational demands and the imperative to protect the intellectual property of pretrained models present substantial challenges. Although recent research has started using Trusted Execution Environments (TEEs) for secure DNN inference, their limited memory and computational resources make it highly challenging to find an optimal balance between performance and security. To address this challenge, we propose Col-TEEs, a secure and efficient collaborative inference framework for heterogeneous TEEs. Col-TEEs strategically partitions the DNN inference process into device-side TEE and cloud-side TEE execution, aiming to maximize inference efficiency while ensuring model and data security. We first propose an optimal secure range determination method, which defines a secure interval by simulating model extraction and input reconstruction attacks, ensuring the confidentiality of pre-trained models and the privacy of user inputs. Furthermore, within this secure range, Col-TEEs employs an adaptive partitioning method that comprehensively evaluates the characteristics of heterogeneous TEE platforms. By combining a precise inference latency prediction model with heuristic algorithms, Col-TEEs dynamically selects the optimal partition point to balance security and inference performance. Additionally, Col-TEEs incorporates an integrity verification mechanism to secure intermediate data during network transmission. Extensive experiments demonstrate that Col-TEEs effectively balances performance and security, achieving an average <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{2. 9 8}$</tex>-fold increase in inference speed and a 63.54 % reduction in power consumption. Compared to collaborative inference without TEE protection, Col-TEEs introduces only a 4.65 % additional performance overhead.

title: LunaISS: A RISC-V Simulator for Branch Predictor Validation and Interval-Based Profiling
authors: Yi-Teng Zhuang, Pei-Shan Hsiao, Chung-Ho Chen
abstract: We present LunaISS, a lightweight RISC-V simulator enabling commit-time validation of branch predictor metadata in lock-step co-simulation with RTL. LunaISS supports full-system workloads, rapid predictor integration via a minimal API, and interval-based profiling via system calls (syscalls). It reveals subtle RTL predictor bugs, offering practical validation beyond accuracy metrics.

title: Millimeter-Wave Phased Array with Wide and Stable Scan Range Based on IEP Gain Predistortion
authors: Yu-Qi Ma, Zhi-Hong Tu, Fu-Chang Chen
publish: IEEE Transactions on Antennas and Propagation
abstract: Scan impedance mismatch inevitably results in gain loss, which significantly affects scanning performance of phased arrays. In this paper, a theoretical framework that relates the Array Beam Envelope (ABE), Isolated Element Pattern (IEP) and scan reflection coefficient is proposed. This framework provides guidance for shaping element radiation pattern and quantifying the impact of scan impedance mismatch, thereby enabling optimization of array scanning performance. Building upon it, a design method based on IEP gain predistortion technique is proposed to achieve a wide and stable scan range across the operating band. To validate the design method, an antenna with ultra-wide beamwidth of 224° and highly flexible beam shaping capability is proposed. Two phased arrays based on it are designed. The first phased array (Array I) achieves a flat-gain ABE, realizing a scan range of up to ±76° with only 1.0 dB gain fluctuation. The second phased array (Array II) achieves an ABE with a scan range of over ±81° throughout the operating band. A prototype of Array II is fabricated and measured, and the measured results agree well with simulations.

title: Heart Rate Estimation from FMCW Radar Using CNN Autoencoder–Transformer for Motion Artifact Mitigation
authors: Shin-Chi Lai, Shang-Sian Wu, Szu-Ting Wang
abstract: Photoplethysmography (PPG), a non-invasive optical method, is hindered by motion artifacts from random movements. This study presents a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) Autoencoder-Transformer model that integrating frequency-modulated continuous wave (FMCW) radar and PPG signals to effectively mitigate motion artifacts. Data were collected using a BGT60TR13C radar (1 TX, 3 RX) on the left arm, which captures both static and dynamic conditions to record motion-induced artifacts, and a MAX86177 PPG sensor on the stationary right wrist. The model targets 0.5-3.0 Hz range, filters noise, and selects the radar phase and the PPG channel with the highest signal-to - noise ratio (SNR). The reconstructed PPG-derived heart rate achieved a mean absolute error (MAE) of 3.21 bpm during motion and 1.11 bpm in static conditions, which demonstrates robust noise reduction and accurate heart rate estimation.

authors: Vasanthi A, Harish Kumar B, Karanraj R

title: Energy-Saving Approaches for 5G and Beyond: New Classification and Analysis
authors: Hasna Fourati, Rihab Maaloul, Lamia Chaari, Mohamed Jmaiel
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: The evolution of 5G and Beyond (B5G) networks requires innovative solutions to address the growing complexity of network management and enhance Energy Efficiency (EE). Sleep Mode (SM) has emerged as an essential strategy for minimizing energy consumption in densely deployed networks, particularly in Base Stations (BS), significantly improving Energy Saving (ES) in 5G/B5G network. By dynamically deactivating underutilized BS components, SM can be effectively applied across various 5G infrastructures. In addition, the application of Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Self Organizing Networks (SON) provides advanced tools for automatic and intelligent system reconfiguration, further enhancing ES in B5G networks. This paper explores ES approaches centered on SM, providing an overview of their application in 5G architectures and the role of AI algorithms and the SON paradigm in improving ES. Finally, we discuss potential ES advancements for future networks, including the transition to 6G, highlighting the importance of intelligent and adaptive energy management in next-generation networks.

title: A New Capacitive Pressure Sensor with a Dual-Layer Microstructured Dielectric
authors: Zihan Wang, Jiaming Zhang, Qiangju Xu, Kexue Sun
abstract: To address the issue that the sensitivity and operating range of traditional single-layer dielectric flexible pressure sensors are difficult to be compatible, we propose a flexible capacitive pressure sensor with a dual-layer dielectric. This dielectric is composed of polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS) conical microstructures and a polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) electrospun fiber layer. In this study, PDMS conical microstructures were fabricated via photosensitive stamp-assisted masking technology, and the PVDF fiber layer was constructed using the electrospinning process. Meanwhile, the finite element analysis software (COMSOL Multiphysics) was employed to conduct a steady-state analysis of the pressure sensor model. The results show that when the electrospinning injection rate is 0.2 mL·min<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">-1</sup> and the operating voltage is 17.5 kV, our sensor achieves a sensitivity of 5.921 kPa<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">-1</sup> within the pressure range of 0-14 kPa, exhibiting both high sensitivity and a wide linear range. The proposed sensor demonstrates application potential in the field of wearable health monitoring.

title: Research on the Control Method of Automatic Water Jet Device Based on Binocular Vision and 3D Object Estimation
authors: Zijing Wan, Yuqiao Li, Bing Han, Tingting Dong
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Big Data, Artificial Intelligence and Internet of Things Engineering (ICBAIE)
abstract: This paper addresses the issue of three-dimensional fire point localization and water cannon control in firefighting scenarios by proposing a 3D target detection method based on binocular stereo vision and an improved Pseudo-LiDAR technique. By incorporating dynamic time sequence modeling and multi-scale time series analysis, the dynamic features of flames and smoke are effectively extracted, solving the problem of insufficient detection accuracy in dynamic scenes typical of traditional methods. Furthermore, a jet trajectory correction method based on an incremental PID control algorithm is introduced. Combined with a water pressure-parameter adaptation strategy, stable control is achieved under varying water pressure conditions. The results of this research provide a complete technical solution for the field of fire automation, achieving a closed-loop control system from fire point detection to water cannon control by integrating binocular vision with deep learning, which holds significant engineering application value.

title: Monolithic single-mode Nd-doped fiber laser operated at 915 nm with 37% slope efficiency
authors: Danila Davydov, Svetlana Aleshkina, Vladimir Velmiskin, Alexey Lobanov, Mikhail Yashkov, Denis Lipatov, Dmitry Przhiialkovskii, Oleg Butov, Mikhail Likhachev
abstract: We report a highly efficient, Nd-doped all-fiber laser operating based on the three-level transition at 915 nm. A key feature of the laser is a novel active fiber with cladding-embedded absorbing rods that suppress parasitic amplified spontaneous emission (ASE) at 1060 nm. The laser demonstrates 37% slope efficiency, which is, to the best of our knowledge, the highest reported value among all-fiber lasers with near-diffraction-limited beam quality (M² < 1.2). Strong ASE suppression with a signal-to-ASE ratio exceeding 50 dB was achieved. Further output power and efficiency scaling can be reached by optimization of fiber components used in the laser cavity.

title: CNN Compression via Channel-Wise Variance-Based Filter Pruning
authors: Jinse Kwon, Jemin Lee, Sihyeong Park, Hyungshin Kim
abstract: In recent years, the focus on lightweight convolutional neural networks has led to extensive research in pruning techniques to reduce model size and inference cost while maintaining accuracy. Traditional structured pruning methods that rely on magnitude-based metrics, such as L1/L2 norms or geometric median, often produce similar filter rankings. This raises concerns about the uniqueness and informativeness of the resulting importance scores. In this study, we introduce a variance-based pruning method that diverges from conventional magnitude-based approaches by evaluating filter importance through the variance distribution of weights within convolutional layers. Our theoretical analysis shows that weighted variance captures complementary information overlooked by norm-based methods, distinguishing our criterion from existing approaches. To validate the effectiveness of our approach, we conduct comprehensive experiments with the ImageNet dataset. We compare our method against multiple baseline pruning techniques – including L1-norm pruning, L2-norm, geometric median, HRank, RASP, AutoSlim, and Taylor-approximation-based pruning. Notably, our approach achieves up to 76.2% Top-1 accuracy with only 2G MACs, which is less than half the computational cost of the ResNet-50 baseline.

title: Efficient All-dielectric Terahertz Metasurface with Arbitrary Polarization Selection and Wavefront Shaping Simultaneously
authors: H. Zhang, Y. Mao, X. Hao, J. Han
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: Here, we propose and experimentally verify highly efficient all-dielectric wavefront shaping devices with simultaneous polarization selectivity in the terahertz band. The molecular unit of the metasurface consists of a pair of subwavelength high-resistivity silicon pillars. By reasonably designing the geometric sizes and orientation angles of the silicon pillars, arbitrarily polarized terahertz wave can be obtained. At the designed operation frequency of 1THz, the power ratio of the metasurface polarizer is around 97%. Compared with the traditional terahertz polarizer implementation method, the selective transmission of arbitrary polarization is achieved only through a single-layer all-dielectric structure. Further studies show that by adjusting the geometric parameters of the two silicon pillars in the cell structure, continuous 2π phase coverage can be achieved, enabling functional integration of polarization selection and wavefront shaping. The monolithic integration of polarization generation and phase modulation achieved in this study has great potential application value in ultra-compact optical systems.

title: Federated Learning with Dynamic Pruning for Efficient Model Aggregation in Heterogeneous Environments
authors: Lin-Huang Chang, Jian-Wei Huang, Tsung-Han Lee
abstract: With the widespread adoption of 5G networks, Federated Learning (FL) has gradually become an important paradigm for distributed artificial intelligence. However, clients in FL environments often exhibit significant heterogeneity in computational resources and data distributions, and under Non-Independent and Identically Distributed (Non-IID) scenarios, such heterogeneity not only slows model convergence but also affects the final accuracy. To reduce the computational burden on clients, this study adopts structured pruning by trimming filters in convolutional neural networks (CNNs) and dynamically adjusting pruning ratios according to client resources. Nevertheless, variations in model structures resulting from different pruning ratios make it difficult for traditional FL aggregation to maintain consistency. To address this issue, we propose FedCHAP (Federated Customized Heterogeneous Aggregation with Pruning), which integrates dynamic pruning with a heterogeneous aggregation mechanism. FedCHAP enables clients to flexibly adjust pruning ratios based on their available resources while ensuring the feasibility of aggregation through padding weight and structural alignment. Experiments conducted on a network traffic classification dataset under multiple Non-IID scenarios demonstrate that, in the most extreme case of quantity-based label imbalance, FedCHAP reduced the overall FL runtime by 8.1% and improved global accuracy by 4% compared with applying a fixed 30% pruning ratio to all clients. Furthermore, we benchmark the performance of FedCHAP against state-of-the-art FL methods and demonstrate its generalizability across various application domains. Overall, the findings validate that FedCHAP can effectively lower resource consumption while preserving model performance and stability.

title: FPGA-Based VAE for Unsupervised Intrusion Detection System in Network Flow Features
authors: Najmi Azzahra Feryputri, Azita Nadiya Noorazlina, Elisabeth Frenata Situmorang, Sinekar Lintang, Infall Syafalni, Nana Sutisna, Trio Adiono
abstract: The rise of IoT and cloud technologies has intensified cybersecurity threats, increasing the need for efficient Network Intrusion Detection Systems (NIDS). This paper proposes a Variational Autoencoder (VAE)-based NIDS implemented on an FPGA to leverage parallelism and reduce computational overhead. The system uses flow-based features from the CIC-IDS2017 dataset and comprises multiple Forward VAE cores, each targeting a specific attack type. Experimental results show that the FPGA-based system achieves up to 0.97 recall and 0.884 F1-score, outperforming software implementations, especially in detecting DoS, PortScan, DDoS, and Patator attacks. Although precision slightly decreases (e.g., 0.8003 vs 0.9605 for DoS), the improved recall leads to a better trade-off between false positives and false negatives. These results highlight the potential of FPGA-accelerated VAE for real-time, energy-efficient intrusion detection.

title: Optimization of Packet Scheduling using Modern Recurrent Neural Networks
authors: Duraichi Natarajan
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Automation, Computing and Renewable Systems (ICACRS)
abstract: In 5G network access, Internet of Things (IoT) resource management is expected to meet extremely strict packet loss and delay requirements, particularly for massive data-driven and delay-sensitive applications. Under highly erratic network conditions and dynamic traffic patterns, standard scheduling rules often fail to satisfy advanced Quality of Service (QoS) demands. To ensure precise, efficient, and collision-free information transmission in deployed IoT networks, a scheduling window is utilized. In this context, the packet scheduler becomes crucial as it allocates user data packets at predetermined intervals, enabling efficient use of resource in constrained environments. Intelligent packet scheduling plays a vital role in reducing consumption of network resources while improving reliability. Although machine learning (ML)-based optimization methods assign higher priority to critical IoT nodes, they risk permanently blocking low-priority communication paths, potentially causing important events to go undetected. To address this, a weight-optimized packet scheduling (WOPS) approach based on recurrent neural networks (RNN) is introduced to improve enhance energy efficiency. The model represents each incoming packet using a temporal feature vector and employs a Gated Recurrent Unit (GRU) to learn sequential patterns, while a dense layer generates priority scores for ranking. For communication paths with limited information, the proposed method minimizes unnecessary packet transmission, contributing to energy consumption reduction and supporting long-term conservation of IoT device power. Simulation results demonstrate that the approach can reduce overall energy consumption by approximately 20%, highlighting its effectiveness in improving both efficiency and sustainability in IoT scheduling.

title: Multi-Purpose Optimization of the Turning Process on CNC Machines with Robotic Loading
authors: Irina Aleksandrova, Hristo Metev, Nikolay Kolev
abstract: The paper presents a methodology for multi-purpose optimization of the turning process on CNC machines with robotic loading and its specific implementation for turning hardened steel 42CrMo4, using carbide inserts from various manufacturers. To optimize the process, models of the arithmetic mean utility function with weighting coefficients have been developed. The models are obtained as a result of a research and modelling of the main response variables (production rate, cutting tool life and surface roughness) of the CNC turning process depending on the cutting conditions. The optimal conditions for implementing the process of CNC turning have been determined, under which the generalized utility function has a maximum for each of the cutting tools used. The determined optimal solutions guarantee the best combination of process production rate, cutting tool life and roughness of the machined surfaces.

title: Investigating Local Search Strategies in Variable Neighborhood Search for Patient Admission Scheduling Problem
authors: Imen Oueslati, Moez Hammami, Issam Nouaouri, Lamjed Ben Said, Hamid Allaoui
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: Efficient patient admission scheduling is a key challenge in hospital management, as it directly impacts resource utilization and the quality of care. The Patient Admission Scheduling Problem (PASP) involves assigning patients to hospital beds over a planning horizon while considering medical constraints and hospital capacity. Due to its complexity, heuristic and metaheuristic approaches are often used to find high-quality solutions within a reasonable time. In this work, we propose a Variable Neighborhood Search (VNS) metaheuristic to solve the PASP. VNS systematically explores different neighborhoods to escape local optima and improve solution quality. To assess the impact of local search strategies, we implement four versions of VNS, each using a different method for modifying patient assignments. The proposed approach is evaluated on benchmark instances, where we conduct parameter tuning and analyze computational performance. Experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness of the method, showing that the appropriate choice of local search strategies significantly impact the quality of the results.

title: Research on Digital Economy Resource Allocation Optimization Integrating Machine Learning
authors: Dongxu Guan, Yaru Cai, Shiyao Yin, Zhao Wu
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Machine Learning, Big Data and Business Intelligence (MLBDBI)
abstract: Resource allocation in the digital economy faces explosive data growth and complex market dynamics. Machine learning provides a new optimization paradigm through deep data mining and pattern recognition. Principal Component Analysis enables feature dimensionality reduction, LSTM networks predict demand trends, and Deep Q-Networks dynamically adjust strategies. Empirical research shows integrated algorithms significantly improve resource utilization and reduce costs in cloud computing, e-commerce inventory, and shared mobility scenarios.

title: Hybrid Wavelet-Based Image Compression with Zigzag Scanning, RLE, and Huffman Coding
authors: Sohon Sen, Somsubhra Datta, Jhilam Jana, Sayan Tripathi, Jaydeb Bhaumik
publish: 2025 5th IEEE International Conference on Applied Electromagnetics, Signal Processing, &amp; Communication (AESPC)
abstract: Image compression is essential for storing and sending digital images efficiently. The key challenge lies in balancing compression ratio, computational cost, and image quality. This study introduces a hybrid image compression approach that integrates Discrete Wavelet Transform (DWT), adaptive thresholding, quantization, zigzag scanning, Run-Length Encoding (RLE), Huffman coding, and entropy optimization. The system leverages wavelet-domain sparsity, RLE for redundancy reduction, and perception-based quantization to enhance efficiency. Experiments on standard images (Lena, Pepper, Mandrill, Cameraman) achieved an average compression ratio of 2.36-about $119 \%$ higher than traditional Huffman coding (1.076)-while maintaining good visual quality (PSNR: 30.38 dB, SSIM: 0.8122, NCC: 0.9898). Overall, the proposed method significantly improves compression performance, making it ideal for multimedia and low-storage applications prioritizing compactness over nearlossless quality.

authors: Xiaoli Guan, Qiwu Shi

abstract: MXenes, as an emerging class of layered materials, show promising potential in electrochemical energy storage and optoelectronic applications. A fundamental understanding of charge transport in MXenes is crucial for such applications; however, the influence of carrier-phonon coupling on carrier dynamics remains insufficiently explored. In this study, we used the optical pump-THz probe technique to investigate the carrier dynamics in Ti<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf>C<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>T<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">x</inf> MXene films. We compared the thickness-dependent lifetimes of quasi-equilibrium carrier relaxation and lattice cooling. The results revealed that the carrier relaxation time closely matched the lattice cooling time, indicating strong carrier-phonon coupling in Ti<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf>C<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>T<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">x</inf>, which governs the carrier lifetime.

title: SecFinder: An IoT Device Identification System Based on Flow-level Traffic in Smart Home
authors: Ning Zhang, Suning Chen, Shenghao Liu, Xianjun Deng, Yuanyuan He, Wei Xiang, Meng Li
publish: 2025 IEEE 31th International Conference on Parallel and Distributed Systems (ICPADS)
abstract: Due to the rapid increase of heterogeneous IoT devices in smart home, it is a challenge to model the communication behaviors of IoT devices for identify and protect vulnerable devices. Recently, much researches focus on identifying IoT devices with traffic feature extraction and machine learning algorithms. However, existing methods typically design complex features involving packet payloads for high identification accuracy, which leaks user privacy and leads to large computational overhead. In this paper, we propose SecFinder, a privacy protection-based system for fine-grained IoT device identification in smart home. First, SecFinder analyzes the characteristics of network traffic from IoT devices and uses the statistical information of packet size from the traffic flow to characterize various devices in order to protect privacy. To reduce computational overhead and improve recognition accuracy, SecFinder divides traffic with fixed-size time window and extract only six statistical features from each flow. Then a multi-stage classifier is applied to identify IoT and non-IoT devices, IoT device types and the detailed information of each IoT device. SecFinder is evaluated with traffic from a public real-world device dataset and five classifiers. The results validate that SecFinder can achieve higher accuracy and lower latency in identification than existing methods.

title: A Lightweight Secure Appliance for Database Encryption and Authentication Using Quantum Key
authors: Cuiling Liu, Zhen Yao, Haoyu Hou, Jiali Sun, Cuicui Zhang, Qi Cao
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Big Data, Artificial Intelligence and Internet of Things Engineering (ICBAIE)
abstract: This paper presents a lightweight secure appliance for database encryption and authentication, leveraging quantum random number generator (QRNG) keys. The appliance functions as an integrated and transparent layer between application servers and relational databases, enabling fine-grained, field-level encryption and access control without requiring changes to existing systems. By integrating lightweight symmetric encryption, mutual authentication with digital signatures and ephemeral key exchange, and true quantum entropy for all key material, the solution achieves strong data confidentiality and integrity with minimal computational overhead. The modular architecture is suitable for edge, embedded, and enterprise environments, and supports seamless upgrades to post-quantum cryptographic algorithms, ensuring long-term data security in the quantum era.

title: Optimization of AI-Enabled Health Monitoring Equipment Configuration for Rescue Personnel
authors: Rongxuan Zhao, Shuanghong Yang, Zhen Liu, Qian Zhang
publish: 2025 IEEE Cyber Science and Technology Congress (CyberSciTech)
abstract: This paper presents a data-driven, machine- learning framework to optimize the allocation of consumable firefighting equipment at the grassroots level. By leveraging historical incident data, unit-specific parameters, and intrinsic equipment covariates, we formulate a supervised regression model to predict two-year cumulative attrition volumes for various equipment categories. The proposed model derives evidence-based allocation standards, transitioning from coarse-grained, experience-based procurement to precise, predictive resource optimization. Descriptive and visual analytics reveal significant geographical imbalances and misalignments between current provisioning strategies and actual operational demand. Among six evaluated algorithms, Bayesian Ridge Regression (BYS) and Ridge Regression (RID) achieve the lowest mean squared error, outperforming linear, ensemble, and non-parametric alternatives. The framework reduces fiscal waste, mitigates premature equipment degradation, and enhances operational readiness. Future work will extend the model to non-consumable assets, integrate real-time IoT maintenance data, and validate its applicability across diverse jurisdictional contexts.

title: Real-Time Network Traffic Anomaly Detection with a Multi-Task Learning-Based Hybrid LSTM-Transformer Model
authors: Wei Chen, Jindian Lu, Hengwei Ouyang, Huafeng Jiang
publish: 2025 IEEE Cyber Science and Technology Congress (CyberSciTech)
abstract: With the increasing complexity and diversification of network attack methods, traditional network anomaly detection approaches demonstrate significant limitations when processing high-dimensional, non-linear network traffic data. This paper proposes a hybrid LSTM-Transformer real-time network traffic anomaly detection framework based on multi-task learning, aimed at improving the accuracy, real-time performance, and robustness of network anomaly detection. The framework innovatively combines the temporal modeling capabilities of Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks with the global dependency modeling capabilities of Transformer through a cross-attention fusion mechanism, achieving deep integration of the advantages of both architectures. Experimental results on the CIDDS-002 dataset demonstrate that the proposed hybrid model achieves 99.97% accuracy in traffic classification tasks, representing a 0.33 percentage point improvement over traditional machine learning methods and a 0.46 percentage point improvement over single deep learning methods. Ablation experiments validate the effectiveness of each component, and confusion matrix analysis shows that the model achieves 99.99% accuracy in normal traffic identification, effectively reducing false positive rates. The smooth convergence of loss curves during training indicates the model's stability and efficient learning capability. This research provides an effective technical solution for real-time network anomaly detection, with significant theoretical importance and practical value.

title: Enabling Role of Post-Quantum Secure Multi-Party Private Intersection Protocol in Federated Learning
authors: Xihan Zhao
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Automation, Electronics and Electrical Engineering (AUTEEE)
abstract: With the rapid development of quantum computing technology, traditional encryption methods face severe security threats in multi-party privacy intersection protocols in federated learning. In this paper, we propose a new protocol based on post-quantum cryptography. Firstly, lattice-based homomorphic encryption and zero-knowledge proof technology are used to achieve key generation and parameter initialization against quantum attacks. Secondly, ciphertext data encoding is carried out to support homomorphic operations. Next, a zero-knowledge proof is used to verify the correctness of the ciphertext intersection calculation. Finally, the protocol is embedded into the federated learning workflow, adaptively adjusting the parameters. Experimental results show that the protocol achieves the NIST (National Institute of Standards and Technology) security level 3, and the privacy leakage rate is less than 1.2%, the communication and computational costs are controllable, and the protocol does not bring great influence to the accuracy of the federated learning model. The experimental results verify that the protocol can provide a reliable protection for the privacy of federated learning data in the quantum era.

title: Federated Learning Algorithm Based on Latency-Aware Hierarchical Clustering
authors: Yue Li, Chaocen Tang, Xueying Ren, Luohao Zheng, Yiting Yan
publish: 2025 IEEE 31th International Conference on Parallel and Distributed Systems (ICPADS)
abstract: Federated Learning (FL) is frequently hampered by systemic latency heterogeneity, where client computation and communication speeds can form distinct clusters. Traditional FL approaches, often oblivious to this underlying structure, may struggle to manage stragglers from slower client clusters, potentially leading to notable decreases in training efficiency and model performance. To address this challenge, we propose Federated Learning with Latency-Aware Hierarchical Clustering (FedLAHC), a novel framework designed to identify and leverage these latent client groupings. FedLAHC employs a hierarchical clustering algorithm that groups clients based on latency profiles, followed by a stratified model aggregation process that respects this clustered structure. This design aims to accelerate convergence by mitigating the impact of slower clients on faster ones, while still enabling all clients to contribute to the global model. Our extensive experiments on MNIST and CIFAR-10 datasets indicate that FedLAHC can accelerate convergence by up to 15.3 % and improve final model accuracy by up to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{2. 3 \%}$</tex> compared to structure-agnostic baselines. We provide a rigorous theoretical analysis of FedLAHC's convergence and formally connect its potential performance gains to the quality of the discovered latency clusters. This work suggests that by recognizing and adapting to the clustered nature of client latency, it is possible to build more efficient and effective federated learning systems.

title: An Improved A-Star Path Planning Algorithm for Logistics Handling Robots
authors: Jianjun Zhu, Shuai Wang, Longlong Fan
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Automation, Electronics and Electrical Engineering (AUTEEE)
abstract: In the context of logistics handling robot applications, this paper proposes an improved A-Star path planning algorithm to address the limitations of the traditional A-Star algorithm, such as long computation time, excessive path length, and unsmooth trajectories, thereby enhancing the operational efficiency of the robot. First, a bidirectional search strategy is adopted, in which the search is simultaneously initiated from both the start and goal points. During node expansion, a dynamic five-neighborhood search strategy and a direct-connection mechanism are introduced. Second, the evaluation function is enhanced by integrating a hybrid dynamic weighting mechanism and a dynamic angle-based heuristic function. Finally, a forward optimization strategy combined with a reverse greedy strategy is employed to optimize the path, and the resulting route is refined by applying a cubic uniform B-spline method. Through multiple simulation experiments, the results demonstrate that the proposed algorithm reduces the average number of search nodes by 74% and the number of turning points by 55.2%; the average path length is shortened by 13.75%, and the average planning time is reduced by 66.5%. These experimental results verify that, compared with the traditional A-Star algorithm, the improved algorithm achieves significantly higher path planning efficiency and demonstrates promising applicability and practical value in logistics handling environments.

title: Towards Generalizable Pneumonia Detection: A Federated Multi-Modal Explainable Deep Learning Approach
authors: Marvin Mathew, Angelin Jeba
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Automation, Computing and Renewable Systems (ICACRS)
abstract: Pneumonia is still a big health problem around the world, especially in places where there aren’t many doctors or medical supplies. Fast and accurate diagnosis is important, but many clinics have to rely on chest X-rays because they don’t have regular access to expert radiologists. This can lead to delays or wrong diagnoses. Artificial intelligence shows promise as a way to automatically analyse X-ray images to find pneumonia, but using it in healthcare settings is difficult because of privacy concerns, the need for clear explanations, and the need for efficient models. Federated learning lets hospitals work together to make AI models stronger without having to share private patient information. This keeps patient information private while still improving performance. Trust is still very important, so this framework also has explainability features. For example, it uses heatmaps to show clinicians which parts of an image affected predictions, which helps to connect AI and human reasoning. Lightweight neural network designs make sure that the models can run on any computer or portable device that is used in a variety of healthcare settings, making them easier to access. By integrating clinical background information such as age, gender, or other health indicators into the diagnostic process along with image data, the AI system can provide more tailored and accurate results. This paper presents an all in one approach that blends privacy-preserving learning, explainable artificial intelligence, computational efficiency, and multi-modal input, with the goal of making robust, trustworthy pneumonia detection more widely available in real-world healthcare settings.

title: Integrating Machine Learning and Evolutionary Algorithms for Optimized Scheduling and Routing in Home Healthcare Logistics
authors: Zayd Elbassri, Khalil Bouramtane, Said Kharraja, Omar El Beqqali, Jamal Riffi
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: In this paper, we introduce a global framework integrating predictive analytics and multi-objective optimization for the purpose of home healthcare logistics optimization. First, several machine learning approaches such as Multinomial Logistic Regression, Support Vector Machines, Random Forest, AdaBoost, and Gradient Boosting are implemented to predict and classify patients' care requirements. This categorization not only separates professional-grade nurses from primary-grade nurses but also decides whether one caregiver or two caregivers are to be deployed depending on the condition of the patient (bedridden or semi-dependent). Secondly, we create a Multi-Objective Vehicle Routing Problem with Time Windows (MOVRPTW) to schedule the caregivers efficiently and reduce transport costs. Since the corresponding optimization problem is NP-hard, we take two advanced genetic algorithms Non-dominated Sorting Genetic Algorithm II (NSGA-II) and Strength Pareto Evolutionary Algorithm 2 (SPEA2) to find good-quality solutions. To solve the problems of bedridden patient care with multiple visits per day, our model incorporates synchronization constraints to ensure continuity of care and coordination among single-caregiver teams in case dedicated double teams are not possible. By combining predictive analytics with strong optimization techniques, our framework not only improves resource allocation effectiveness and facilitates timely service delivery but also decreases operating expenses, thus providing a holistic solution to the changing needs of home healthcare logistics.

title: Consortium Blockchain-Based Node-Sharded Storage Model for Intellectual Property Transactions
authors: Yunhong Li, Wenlong Feng, Mengxing Huang, Siling Feng, Zheng Wang, Shilong Mo
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Digital Society and Intelligent Systems (DSInS)
abstract: To address the issues of insufficient storage scalability, high storage overhead, and low storage efficiency in intellectual property storage, this study proposes a node-sharded storage model for intellectual property transactions based on a consortium blockchain. First, the overall architecture of the storage model is constructed, and the storage process is established. Second, the workload relationship among nodes is defined, a node information density update strategy is developed, and based on nodes' activity level, load balance, throughput, and communication delay,the global optimal solution for the node group is sought through iterative methods to achieve network optimization of the nodes. Third, based on each node's business category, the degree of interaction between nodes and the similarity of their work, a similarity sharding algorithm is created to enhance sharding accuracy and storage capacity, resulting in efficient data storage for the model. Finally, the model is evaluated for performance and compared with existing models. Analysis shows that this model effectively increases the storage efficiency of intellectual property transactions by 15% and the blockchain capacity by 17%, effectively solving the problems of low storage efficiency, high node communication delay, and limited blockchain scalability during the intellectual property storage process.

title: Research on Intelligent Perception and Inference Mechanisms for Embedded Virtualization in Edge Devices Under Heterogeneous Computing
authors: Zhen Li, Huijing Yuan
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Big Data, Artificial Intelligence and Internet of Things Engineering (ICBAIE)
abstract: With the development of IoT technology, the intelligent application is gradually extended to the edge, and the intelligent perception and inference faced with edge devices face great challenges due to the resource constraints. This paper focuses on designing an intelligent perception and inference mechanism for edge devices, which includes lightweight embedded virtualization architecture, edge-aware data processing technology, model optimization and deployment strategies, heterogeneous hardware acceleration framework and distributed inference mechanism. The mechanism can significantly improve the performance and reliability of edge intelligent system and provide a feasible solution for the application of AI in edge devices with limited resources.

title: Message from General Chairs
authors: N/A
publish: 2025 IEEE 31th International Conference on Parallel and Distributed Systems (ICPADS)
abstract: Welcome to the 31<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">st</inf> IEEE International Conference on Parallel and Distributed Systems (ICPADS 2025) sponsored by the IEEE Computer Society, held on December 14-17, 2025. On behalf of the Organizing Committee of ICPADS 2025, we would like to express our sincere and warm welcome to all participants!

title: Dual Attention and Convolutional Transformers for Multi-Scale Scene Text Detection
authors: Hong Wang, Shujing Wang
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Big Data, Artificial Intelligence and Internet of Things Engineering (ICBAIE)
abstract: Detecting text within natural environments presents a considerable computer vision challenge due to the wide variations in text scale, orientation, and shape. Many current methods are hampered by this diversity, primarily because of two key shortcomings: suboptimal fusion of multi-scale features and inadequate modeling of global context. These issues often lead to compromised detection accuracy. To overcome these problems, this paper introduces a novel network for scene text detection. Firstly, a Channel and Coordinate Attention Module (CCAM) is introduced into the feature pyramid to mitigate information loss during feature fusion by synergizing channel-wise feature selection with precise, direction-aware positional information. Additionally, we design a Shifted Convolutional Transformer Block (SCT-Block) that replaces conventional self-attention with an efficient multi-scale convolutional architecture. This module captures long-range dependencies and learns robust, spatially-invariant representations through a novel feature shifting mechanism, enhancing the model’s ability to distinguish text from complex backgrounds.The effectiveness and robustness of our method are validated by experimental results on public bench-marks, where F-measures of 86.1% and 87.6% were achieved on ICDAR2015 and MSRA-TD500, respectively.

title: Characterizing Modulation Depth of Optically Induced THz Patterns for Single-Pixel Imaging
authors: Adolphe Ndagijimana, Iñigo Ederra, Miguel Heredia Conde, Jose Manuel Pérez Escudero
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: Terahertz (THz) single-pixel imaging (SPI) is a cost-effective alternative to detector arrays, enabling faster acquisition than traditional mechanical scanning. However, its performance depends heavily on the precise implementation and modeling of modulation patterns. This study examines discrepancies between ideal and measured modulation depths in optically induced THz SPI using a phase-only patterned Liquid Crystal Near-Infrared Spatial Light Modulator (NIR SLM). Under 50mW/cm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> NIR illumination and with antireflection-coated silicon wafers, we generated THz patterns with an expected ideal modulation depth of 46%. Experimentally, we observed a reduced depth of 25.95% using pixel-to-pixel patterned mask analysis, mainly due to NIR pattern imperfections and carrier diffusion. Accurate modulation depth estimation is crucial for selecting optical power and, more importantly, for modeling the sensing matrix used in signal reconstruction. Inaccurate modelling can result in noisy or failed reconstructions. We also observed frequency-dependent modulation depth, varying from 19% to 36% for the 25.95% case for WR 2.2 band. This highlights the potential to enhance SPI performance by selecting an optimal operating frequency.

title: Slit Capacitor-Based SIW Sensor with Dual Sensitivity for Non-Invasive Glucose Detection
authors: Prabir Ghosh, Avinash Nayak, Abhik Gorai
publish: 2025 5th IEEE International Conference on Applied Electromagnetics, Signal Processing, &amp; Communication (AESPC)
abstract: This paper introduces a slit capacitor-based substrate integrated waveguide (SIW) sensor designed for noninvasive glucose detection, offering dual-sensitivity through frequency and phase measurements. The sensor features slits etched in the center conductor, generating fringing electric fields that interact with surrounding materials. Variations in the dielectric properties of glucose solutions alter these fields, resulting in measurable shifts in capacitance and impedance. The slit dimensions are carefully optimized to maximize sensitivity. The sensor’s performance is evaluated by measuring frequency and phase changes in the reflection coefficient for glucose concentrations compared to pure water.
