publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: We present a homodyne-based technique for the characterization of absorption and reflection properties of CMOS-based sub-THz detectors. In order to identify the reflection contribution from the sub-micrometer-sized devices, we apply gate bias modulation and lock-in detection techniques in a 250 to 380 GHz frequency range. The results reveal a correlation between optimal reflection and absorption points, demonstrating the approach’s effectiveness for compact, cost-efficient detector evaluation and optimization.

title: PackLoc: Fine-Grained Tag Ordering for Anti-Counterfeiting in Packaged Products
authors: Xuanyang Huang, Yachen Mao, Huiyong Lu, Yubo Yan
publish: 2025 IEEE 31th International Conference on Parallel and Distributed Systems (ICPADS)
abstract: Counterfeiting and product tampering pose significant challenges in high-value packaged goods, leading to brand value degradation, regulatory violations, and potential public health risks. Although radio-frequency identification (RFID)-based authentication technologies have been widely adopted for item-level verification, existing systems struggle to precisely locate anomalous items within densely packed packages, often necessitating manual inspection. This paper presents PackLoc, which achieves high-precision RFID-based item ordering entirely using commercial off-the-shelf (COTS) hardware. PackLoc recovers the ordering and spatial layout of tags in dense packaging through a fixed multi-antenna configuration. By combining RSSI clustering, phase recovery, and linear fitting, the system overcomes technical bottlenecks such as low-dimensional observations, hardware-induced phase offsets, and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\pi$</tex>-radians phase jump. Experimental results show that PackLoc achieves over 90% ordering accuracy in dense layouts without requiring mechanical motion or environment-specific calibration, enabling rapid, noninvasive detection of counterfeit or misplaced items.

title: Development of a lower limb robotic exoskeleton for mobilization of pediatric users
authors: Adriana Cruz-Cortes, Mariana Ballesteros, David Cruz-Ortiz
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: This work describes the development and control of a robotic lower limb exoskeleton (LLE) for the mobilization of pediatric users. The structural design of the LLE considers the anthropometric dimensions aside from the range of motion required to execute a normal gait cycle of pediatric users. The proposed system considers six degrees of freedom, three for each leg, corresponding to the flexion/extension of the hip, flexion/extension of the knee, and dorsiflexion/plantar flexion on the ankle. The system’s manufacturing materials include aluminum profiles, aside from 3D printing segments of polylactic acid. Regarding the electronic instrumentation of the LLE, a set of six brushless motors was considered to provide movement of each joint. All the actuators are controlled by a Texas Instrument LAUNCHXL-F28379D microcontroller in which a first-order sliding mode control is embedded to regulate the trajectory tracking of the LLE. The results showed that the LLE can perform trajectory tracking considering an RMSE less than 0.0863 rad.

title: Location Matters: LLM-Guided Joint Optimization of In-Network Aggregation Placement and Routing for DML Workloads
authors: Long Luo, Yanan Huang, Xixi Chen, Yongsheng Zhao, Hongfang Yu, Schahram Dustdar
publish: IEEE Transactions on Network Science and Engineering
abstract: In-network aggregation (INA) accelerates gradient aggregation in distributed machine learning (DML) by alleviating communication bottlenecks, but its effectiveness crucially depends on two location decisions: where to deploy INA functions and where to aggregate gradient flows. Most existing methods optimize INA placement and gradient flow routing independently, missing the advantages of joint optimization. This paper presents LLMINA, which leverages Large Language Models (LLMs) to automate the heuristic design for joint INA placement and gradient aggregation, aiming to minimize makespan (i.e., the total time required for all DML jobs to complete gradient aggregation). Directly using LLMs to generate end-to-end solutions is infeasible due to problem complexity and LLM limitations. Instead, LLMINA uses LLMs to generate heuristics for INA placement through an evolutionary process, and then applies an optimization-based heuristic for gradient routing that takes into account DML workload characteristics. Experiments across diverse network topologies and workloads show that LLMINA can significantly reduce makespan compared to state-of-the-art baselines. These results underscore that location matters for both INA deployment and aggregation, and highlight the potential of LLM-guided heuristic design for complex network resource optimization.

title: Digital Twin for Real-Time Monitoring of Transformer Performance and Line Faults
authors: M. Ishwarya, Velan K, Vicshiya Sherin V
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Automation, Computing and Renewable Systems (ICACRS)
abstract: In contemporary electrical power networks, continuous condition assessment and intelligent fault identification are critical for ensuring the reliable and efficient functioning of transformers and distribution infrastructures. This work proposes a Digital Twin (DT) enabled monitoring architecture that performs real-time performance evaluation and fault diagnosis for transformer systems. The framework incorporates multiple sensing units such as temperature, oil level, overload, voltage, and current sensors to capture essential operational variables from the physical transformer. The collected data is processed through a microcontroller and synchronized with a Digital Twin representation that models the transformer’s dynamic behavior in a virtual domain. An Augmented Reality (AR)- based interface is integrated to deliver intuitive visualization of transformer health conditions. Deviations in sensor readings or detected faults initiate a color-coded alert mechanism within the AR environment, providing rapid identification of irregularities. Furthermore, MATLAB Simulink is employed to simulate line fault conditions and transformer responses under fluctuating loads, supporting predictive diagnostics and early alert generation. By combining DT technology, AR visualization, and real-time data analytics, the proposed system significantly improves predictive maintenance, enhances fault localization, and elevates situational awareness across power distribution networks. The integrated classification model demonstrates a final accuracy of 98% in health index categorization, ensuring highly reliable diagnostic outcomes. This high accuracy further validates the robustness and effectiveness of the proposed monitoring architecture. This holistic approach contributes to reduced equipment downtime, strengthened system reliability, and proactive fault handling, ultimately promoting safer and more sustainable energy operations.

title: Dual-functional quantum cascade laser and detector utilizing photonic crystals
authors: Shinji Saito, Masatoshi Hirono, Rei Hashimoto, Kei Kaneko, Tsutomu Kakuno, Shinji Okuma, Yuanzhao Yao, Naoki Ikeda, Takaaki Mano, Keisuke Watanabe, Takashi Kuroda, Kazuaki Sakoda
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: We demonstrate photonic crystal-based devices with dual functional surface-emitting quantum cascade lasers (QCLs) and quantum cascade photodetectors (QCDs). We have already reported surface-emitting quantum cascade lasers. In this paper, we will focus on QCDs. QCDs have low efficiency for surface detecting due to the photoelectric conversion mechanism. By using photonic crystals, the receiving efficiency has been improved. Furthermore, the selectivity of wavelength and receiving angle characteristics make it possible to reduce background noise, which is an issue in the mid-infrared range.

title:
Finite-Time Synchronization of Master-Slave Chaotic Systems with Constant Time Delays
                    <sup>*</sup>
authors: Pallov Anand, A. Pedro Aguiar
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: This paper presents a finite-time synchronization framework for a class of nonlinear systems with constant delays. The control strategy utilizes the backstepping technique to design a control input that drives the synchronization error between the master and slave systems to zero within finite time. This framework ensures fast convergence while accounting for the challenges posed by the time delays. The structure of the generalized nonlinear system enables the application of this approach to a wide range of chaotic systems. In particular, in this paper, the Genesio-Tesi chaotic system and Sprott Circuit system are employed to validate the proposed methodology through simulation. The resulting simulations clearly demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed control strategy, confirming its capability to achieve finite-time synchronization.

title: Balancing Accuracy and Efficiency: Navigating The Trade-off Between Machine-Readable Code Detection and Data Size Reduction
authors: Imen Jegham, Ons Loukil, Besma Guesmi, David Moloney
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: Detecting machine-readable codes in industrial manufacturing is a critical yet challenging task, as it directly impacts both defect detection and broader visual anomaly detection. The complexity of visual data, coupled with high-speed production processes generating vast volumes of information, makes accurate and efficient detection essential for ensuring product quality and operational efficiency. This paper takes significant steps toward addressing these challenges by identifying and categorizing key issues related to machine-readable code defect detection, introducing the first publicly available and challenging dataset as a benchmark for future studies, and exploring techniques to enhance both detection performance and data storage efficiency. Experimental results demonstrate that leveraging the YUV color space, combined with data compression, significantly improves detection accuracy while minimizing storage requirements. This work highlights the importance of balancing data complexity, storage optimization, and detection reliability, laying a strong foundation for future advancements in defect detection, anomaly identification, and cost-efficient industrial automation.

title: Finite Element Analysis-Based Electromagnetic Modeling and Performance Evaluation of Asynchronous Motors under Controlled Operation
authors: Yuyang He, Liang Yin, Dayuan Liu, Chang Geng, Baitong Chen, Changhai Sun
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Automation, Electronics and Electrical Engineering (AUTEEE)
abstract: As a core component of high-speed train traction drive systems, asynchronous motors require excellent dynamic performance and reliability under harsh operating conditions. However, existing research mainly focuses on control algorithms but pays insufficient attention to the coupling between internal electromagnetic and external structural responses. To fill this gap, this study proposes a finite element-based electromagnetic modeling method for asynchronous motor controlled operation. First, a control model simulating sudden speed changes is established, which shows excellent dynamic responsiveness with 12% three-phase current harmonic distortion during speed regulation; two 3D models including stator-rotor winding electromagnetic analysis and bearing structural stress models, are also developed. Simulation results show that at steady speed, magnetic energy concentrates in the rotor core, electromagnetic forces are periodic dominated by 150 Hz fundamental frequency, and external stresses are anisotropic. This study clarifies the electromagnetical-structural coupling mechanism during controlled operation, providing a theoretical basis for traction motor structural optimization and operational stability enhancement.

title: Low-Power SC Bit-Serial DAC with Positive and Negative Polarity Output
authors: Nobukazu Tsukiji, Eito Minami, Yuki Koshi, Jianglin Wei, Haruo Kobayashi
abstract: This paper presents a low-power configuration and switching procedure for a switched-capacitor (SC) bit-serial digital-to-analog converter (DAC) capable of producing an output with positive and negative polarity. Unlike the previous design, which dissipates a certain amount of charge during operation, the proposed approach minimizes charge disposal, thereby improving power efficiency.

title: Retraction Notice: A Survey on Data Placement Strategy in Big Data Heterogeneous Environments
authors: Anilkumar Ambore, Udaya Rani V.
publish: 2019 3rd International Conference on Trends in Electronics and Informatics (ICOEI)
abstract: In the present computerized world the extent of the information is expanding at an arbitrary speed. Simultaneously, need to process and examine huge amounts of information likewise expanded. In a few challenge commercial enterprise and logical programs, there's a want to technique petabytes of information in productive way day by day. Hadoop is most popularly used in data intensive applications. The current Hadoop usage accept that computing are homogeneous in nature. The capacity of tremendous amount of information in Hadoop is done using Hadoop Distributed File System (HDFS). HDFS employments block placement arrangement to part a really expansive record into pieces and place them over the cluster in a distributed way. In the present era of social networking, we cannot imagine having a cluster of homogeneous nodes only. Information region has not been taken under consideration for propelling theoretical outline assignments, since it is expected that the most mappings are data-local. To bargain with this Hadoop has usefulness to duplicate the information square where mappers are running. This makes a part of execution corruption particularly on heterogeneous cluster due to I/O delay or organize congestions In this survey we first brief introduction to the Big data, Hadoop and MapReduce. Later several data placement strategies in heterogeneous environment are studied.

title: Multi-Dimensional Approximate MAC Architecture for Energy-Efficient Deep Learning Accelerators
authors: Jiaxu Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Automation, Electronics and Electrical Engineering (AUTEEE)
abstract: With the increase in the complexity of deep learning models, the need of energy-efficient hardware, in particular multiple multiply accumulate (MAC) units, has grown urgently. The present paper presents a multidimensional approximate MAC architecture that unites a number of approximation methods, such as truncated multiplication, Lower-Part OR Adder (LOA), Skip-Add and probabilistic gating in a single register-transfer level (RTL) of architecture. The design implements a core control strategy which seeks to configure approximation modes flexibly to trade off accuracy and energy savings according to task demands. The CIFAR-10 experiments demonstrate that the implemented design is capable of causing a maximum reduction of switching activity (86.5) with a tolerable accuracy in a conservative setting. More detailed analysis is done with Pareto frontiers and error quantiles. It indicates that in spite of ellagic approximation saving greater amounts of power, there are indeed instances of it causing significant errors. The architecture provides reconfigurable RTL implementations that can be helpful with deep learning accelerators, particularly with edge artificial intelligence (AI) applications.

title: An IoT-Enabled Smart Irrigation Framework for Efficient Water Management
authors: Suresh C, Subathra S M
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Automation, Computing and Renewable Systems (ICACRS)
abstract: Using water resources efficiently is a major problem in agriculture since conventional methods of irrigation frequently result in overwatering, energy waste, and decreased agricultural yields. In this research, a smart IoT-based irrigation system with sensors for soil moisture, temperature, humidity and water level is presented. This framework automates water management. The proposed setup that processes sensor data by using an ESP32 microcontroller and employs a relay to regulate a water pump, ensuring the irrigation is only used when necessary. Through a smartphone or dashboard, farmers can remotely see their field conditions, the availability of water and pump status thanks to the framework's connection to a cloud based IoT platform. There are choices for both manual and automated operation, offering flexibility for various farming requirements. According to experimental findings, the equipment provides precision irrigation, which lowers water waste, conserves energy and increases crop yield. This cheap and scalable modern technology supports resource efficiency in agricultural practices and ethical farming.

title: Advanced Terahertz Spectroscopy Techniques for Microscopic and Sub-Milligram Quantities of Lactose Powder with Tapered Parallel-Plate Waveguide
authors: Sung-Woo Cho, Tae-In Jeon
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: This study demonstrated the effectiveness of the TPPWG technique in analyzing the THz characteristics of α-lactose monohydrate powder, addressing key limitations of the traditional pellet-based method. The TPPWG method reduced base absorbance by up to 14 times compared to the pellet method, further demonstrating its superiority in THz spectroscopy.

title: Personalized Federated Learning with Partial Model Sharing and Client-Customized Aggregation
authors: Yitang Huang, Jun Xu, Dejun Yang
publish: 2025 IEEE 31th International Conference on Parallel and Distributed Systems (ICPADS)
abstract: Personalized federated learning (PFL) addresses the limitations of traditional federated learning (FL) in statistically heterogeneous scenarios, where diverse client data distributions reduce model applicability. However, many PFL methods compromise client privacy or depend on external client information. This paper proposes a novel PFL method that enhances privacy and autonomy by enabling each client to share only partial model components and adaptively optimize local aggregation weights to align with its local objective. This approach minimizes reliance on other clients' information while ensuring robust personalization. Comparative experiments on three real-world datasets against seven baseline methods demonstrate that our method achieves higher or comparable accuracies, validating its effectiveness in non-IID settings.

title: Dual-Mode E-Band Mixer for 6G mmWave Front-Ends: Simple structure with reconfigurable PT/Resistive Operation for Optimized Gain and Linearity
authors: Mubasher Ali, Edward A Ball, Sumin David Joseph, Timothy O’Farrell, Mohammad Reza Anbiyaei
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: A dual-mode E-band mixer with a novel yet simple FET-based structure is designed and simulated using a 100 nm pHEMT PH10 process. The mixer employs a switchable impedance network and reconfigurable DC biasing to enable two distinct operational modes: a pump transconductance (PT) mode for higher conversion gain and a resistive mode for enhanced linearity. The results show that the mixer achieves a conversion gain of -4.2 dB in PT mode and -15.9 dB in resistive mode. In PT mode, with a 5 dBm LO drive, the input third-order intercept point (IIP3) is 1 dBm, and the input 1-dB compression point (IP1dB) is -4 dBm. In resistive mode, with a 2.6 dBm LO drive, the mixer achieves an IIP3 of 6 dBm and an IP1dB of 4 dBm. These results highlight the potential of the proposed design for 6G mmWave front-ends that require dynamic performance optimisation, such as balancing the trade-off between gain and linearity.

title: BFTChain-Net: A Blockchain-based Federated Transformer Network for Cross-Organization Accounting Fraud Detection
authors: Jian Lin
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Automation, Computing and Renewable Systems (ICACRS)
abstract: With the accelerating digitalization and automation of cross-institutional financial transactions, accounting fraud is exhibiting typical and widespread characteristics of concealment, intelligence, and cross-domain correlation. Traditional detection methods based on centralized data have significant limitations in terms of data privacy, model generalization, and traceability. To address these issues, this paper proposes a blockchain-based federated Transformer cross-institutional fraud detection system, named BFTChain-Net. This system integrates the Byzantine Fault-Tolerant Blockchain (BFT) consensus mechanism, federated learning (FL), and Transformer coding networks for joint modeling. This algorithm achieves high-precision, traceable, and interpretable fraud detection while protecting the data sovereignty of each institution. In terms of model design, BFTChain-Net establishes a trusted parameter synchronization and anti-counterfeiting verification mechanism through an improved iPBFT consensus protocol. This mechanism ensures the integrity and robustness of the cross-institutional model aggregation process. The federated Transformer sub-network is deployed locally by each participant, using a multi-head self-attention mechanism to model time-series transaction features. This operation achieves global semantic association of heterogeneous features across organizations. Furthermore, the model introduces a graph contrastive learning module. This module combines node attention clustering and anomaly relationship prediction. The experimental section uses data subsets from three independent institutions, and conducts joint validation using the European credit card fraud dataset and the IEEE-CIS fraud detection dataset. Results show that BFTChain-Net achieves an average improvement of 3.4%–6.8% in F1-score and AUC compared to the comparison models. Simultaneously, it reduces the parameter convergence error to 0.014 in cross-institutional consistency detection. Through t-SNE visualization analysis, the model can significantly distinguish between normal transactions and anomalous samples. The detection performance of independent institutions is improved by 1.5%, 2.2%, and 3.7%, respectively. These results comprehensively validate the effectiveness and generality of cross-institutional collaborative learning.

title: A Spiking Convolutional Neural Network Algorithm Based on Piecewise-Linear Complementary Leaky Integrate-and-Fire (PCLIF) Neurons and Hybrid Surrogate Gradient Training
authors: Zong-Zhe Wu, Yi-Wen Chuang, Kea-Tiong Tang
publish: 2025 IEEE Biomedical Circuits and Systems Conference (BioCAS)
abstract: Spiking Neural Networks (SNNs) offer energyefficient computation but still face challenges such as training instability, gradient vanishing, and inefficient hardware deployment. We propose a spiking convolutional neural network (SCNN) framework that integrates three key innovations. First, a Parameterized Sigmoid Gradient with Softplus (PSGS) enables adaptive gradient shaping to enhance early stability and late convergence. Second, a Hybrid Surrogate Gradient Training (HSGT) method dynamically switches between smooth and sharp surrogate functions over time. Third, we propose a PiecewiseLinear Complementary Leaky Integrate-and-Fire (PCLIF) neuron that employs piecewise linear activation and simplified memory updates to reduce inference cost. Our model achieves 97.57% accuracy on DVS128 Gesture and 80.40% on CIFAR10-DVS using only 10 time steps. Compared to CLIF, PCLIF reduces area and power by 44.8% and 70.9%, respectively, while maintaining competitive accuracy. These results demonstrate that our co-design of training strategy and neuron architecture enables training effectiveness and efficient deployment in low-power neuromorphic systems.

title: Low-Light Image Enhancement of Coal Mine Underground Based on Zero-RLDD
authors: Qin Xuebin, Chao Mengyao
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Automation, Electronics and Electrical Engineering (AUTEEE)
abstract: Due to the special environment of low light in the coal mine underground, the photographs taken suffer from low clarity and loss of color, and texture. Traditional image enhancement methods face the problem of difficulty in acquiring image-pairing datasets. To address this, this paper proposes an enhancement method based on the Zero-RLDD models, which is applied to coal mine underground image enhancement. The model replaces some of the convolutional layers of the benchmark model Zero-DCE with residual modules, mitigates the gradient disappearance through jump connections, enhances the deep feature extraction capability, and retains more detailed information; proposes a lightweight hybrid attention module (LC-SAM) and introduces a cascading channel-space dual attention mechanism at the jump connections of the shallow, middle, and deep layers, which can focus on the key features and suppress the background noise to solve the problem of localized contrast under non-uniform illumination and the problem of localized contrast under non-uniform illumination. The local contrast imbalance problem under non-uniform illumination is solved; at the end of the model, the discrete wavelet transform Bior6.8 wavelet basis is used to soft-threshold the high-frequency subbands, which effectively suppresses the noise while preserving the integrity of the low-frequency information. The experimental results show that the proposed model is overall better than the typical enhancement model in five indices: MSE, PSNR, SSIM, NIQE, and VIF. Compared with the benchmark model Zero-DCE, MSE is reduced, PSNR is improved by 2.28dB, SSIM is improved by 8.09%, NIQE is reduced by 1.33%, and VIF is improved by 5.25%. The image visualization is significantly improved, preserving the detailed texture while enhancing the image brightness, and the noise reduction effect is outstanding.

title: Analysis and Design of Intelligent Electricity Consumption Information Acquisition System Based on Big Data
authors: Jing Gao, Yunxing Xiang, Jing Zhu, Jun Wang, Xiaohui You
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Automation, Electronics and Electrical Engineering (AUTEEE)
abstract: With the rapid development of smart distribution networks, there has been a significant increase in both the data collection dimensions and frequency of user electricity consumption information, resulting in massive big data. How to analyze and process this massive amount of electricity consumption information to obtain useful information is a problem worth studying in depth. This paper proposes an intelligent electricity consumption information analysis system architecture based on the Hadoop big data ecosystem cluster, and constructs a parallel computing network composed of three physical machines. The intelligent electricity consumption information analysis system consists of the distributed computing framework Spark, Map Reduce, distributed storage mechanism HDFS, distributed management YARN, and distributed service framework Zookeeper, realizing data collection, data storage, data management, and data analysis of electricity consumption information. Then, a big data user electricity consumption information analysis system is constructed, and the data collection, data analysis, and data processing of user electricity consumption characteristics are realized using big data Hadoop and Spark technologies. The parallel DeepFM shortterm load forecasting algorithm is adopted to improve the accuracy of short-term load forecasting, which has great practical application value and broad application prospects.

title: Haina Storage: Large-Scale and Secure Decentralized Storage for Files in Private Cloud
authors: Zijian Zhou, Caimei Wang, Xiaoheng Deng, Hairong Lin, Jianhao Lu, Shaohua Wan
publish: 2025 IEEE 31th International Conference on Parallel and Distributed Systems (ICPADS)
abstract: With growing interest in secure storage, decentralized storage systems (DSSs) have attracted attention due to their strong data integrity but remain limited by restricted capacity, low efficiency, and weak security guarantees. These shortcomings make existing DSSs unsuitable as practical file storage platforms, particularly in private cloud scenarios where performance bottlenecks are easily exposed. To address this, we present Haina Storage (HNS), a decentralized storage system redesigned for scalability, efficiency, and security in private clouds. HNS introduces a bi-directional circular linked chain structure in which each file forms an independent chain, eliminating inter-file dependencies and enabling parallel retrieval. We further propose a lightweight consensus mechanism, Proof of Resources, that accounts for both storage capacity and network conditions, ensuring fair and timely data placement. Security is strengthened through dynamic access control, confidential block distribution, and decentralized key protection without trusted third parties. Extensive experiments on both public cloud servers and local clusters demonstrate that HNS achieves performance comparable to IPFS while offering significantly stronger security, theoretical scalability advantages, and an efficient and fair resource-based consensus mechanism. title: GAN-based feature representation and data augmentation for tool wear classification
authors: Seulki Han, George M. Bollas
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: Tool wear monitoring is critical for maintaining machining efficiency, product quality, and cost-effectiveness in manufacturing. Traditional data-driven approaches rely on manually engineered features, which require extensive preprocessing and domain expertise, and often lead to information loss and limited adaptability. This study proposes an alternative method that uses wavelet transform (WT)-based scalogram images and a conditional generative adversarial network (cGAN) for feature representation and data augmentation. Scalograms retain the full time-frequency structure of raw signals, eliminating the need for handcrafted features. The cGAN model synthesizes realistic scalograms, expanding dataset diversity and improving model generalization. Compared with FFT-based numerical features, the proposed method preserves more wear-related information and improves classification performance. Experimental results demonstrate that the cGAN-based approach effectively captures tool wear progression, enhances training robustness, and improves accuracy under limited data conditions. These findings highlight the potential of integrating cGAN-generated features into tool wear monitoring frameworks.

title: Measurement of water properties of perfluorinated sulfonic acid membranes using humidity-controlled terahertz time-domain spectroscopy
authors: George A. H. Ludlam, Mozhdeh Mohammadpour, Riccardo Degl’Innocenti, Massimo Peruffo, Hungyen Lin
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: Humidity controlled terahertz time-domain spectroscopy (THz-TDS) has previously been demonstrated to quantify water uptake and states of perfluorinated sulfonic acid (PFSA) membranes across a range of humidities. Here we demonstrate the robustness of the technique by applying it to a selection of different membranes for comparisons against complementary dynamic vapor sorption.

title:
Enhancing Digital Continuity and Interoperability in Building Energy Management: A Digital Twin Approach with Large Language Models
                    <sup>*</sup>
authors: F. Ababsa, Z. Zheng, E. Yahya, E. Farazdaghi, R. El Meouche, S. Marie
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: In the field of building energy management, the heterogeneity of data arising from the coexistence of multiple standards and ontologies, such as Building Energy Management (BEM) and Building Management Systems (BMS), presents a critical obstacle to achieving efficient, interoperable, and continuous digital twins (DTs). These systems produce disparate and often semantically incompatible data, impeding seamless integration and hindering the realization of holistic energy management strategies. To overcome these challenges, advanced data structuring and AI-based strategies are imperative to ensure semantic interoperability and uninterrupted data continuity across heterogeneous systems. This paper introduces a novel approach for constructing a unified ontology that harmonizes BEM and BMS standards, enabling the seamless fusion of their datasets within a digital twin architecture. By leveraging the capabilities of Large Language Models (LLMs), we enrich the semantic structuring process, facilitating automated and precise reconciliation of heterogeneous data sources. Experimental results underscore the viability and efficacy of the proposed methodology in maintaining robust interoperability and ensuring digital continuity, thereby enhancing the operational efficiency of digital twins for smart building energy management.

title: Learning Insertion Heuristics for the Traveling Salesman Problem via Neural Networks and Black-Box Optimization
authors: Mariusz Kaleta, Tomasz Śliwiński
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: This paper introduces a novel neural-based method for solving the Traveling Salesman Problem (TSP) by learning adaptive, single-pass construction heuristic within the Insertion heuristic framework. We design a simple feed-forward neural network that dynamically evaluates candidate cities based on multi-dimensional distance properties, allowing flexible handling of varying problem sizes. The network is trained using a black-box optimization approach with Covariance Matrix Adaptation Evolution Strategy (CMA-ES), bypassing the need for gradient information. To further improve solution quality, we propose a lightweight local refinement technique that perturbs the trained network’s weights, effectively exploring nearby heuristic landscapes without restarting the search process. Computational experiments on synthetic datasets with 50, 100, and 200 cities show that our approach consistently outperforms classical Insertion heuristics and generates solutions within 0–2.4% of optimality. The proposed method combines high computational efficiency with adaptability, demonstrating strong potential for extension to more complex TSP variants and practical logistics optimization tasks.

title: Role of Signal Amplification Stage in THz Frequency Upconversion Detection
authors: Na Ming, Shuzheng Fan, Xingyu Zhang, Zhongming Yang, Dechun Li, Liyuan Guo, Binzhe Jiao, Jiasheng Yuan, Shiwu Wang, Kaiyu Wang, Naichang Liu, Xutao Dai
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: This paper investigates the role of the signal amplification stage in terahertz wave frequency upconversion detection based on RbTiOPO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">4</inf> crystal. The experimental exploration and theoretical analysis are used to answer why the signal amplification stage can achieve smaller minimum detectable terahertz energy besides higher detection sensitivity, and to what extents the minimum detectable terahertz energy can be reduced and the detection sensitivity can be enhanced.

title: Trace determination of uric acid based on double C-type five-frequency resonant metamaterial sensor
authors: Zhen Sun, Yong Du
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: In this paper, a novel double-C-type multi-resonant metamaterial sensor based on aluminum and polyimide materials is designed for rapid trace detection of uric acid (UA) content. With five resonant peaks in the frequency range of 0.1-1.0 THz and a maximum sensitivity of 208 GHz/RIU (refractive index unit), the sensor can be used for high-sensitivity trace detection. The results showed that the minimum detection limit of the sensor was 0.001 mg/mL, which is lower than the minimum level of UA in healthy humans. It is expected to be used in biomedical and other fields.

title: A Computational Framework for Indicator Detection Based on GBRT-LightGBM: Research on Multi-Factor Modeling and Intelligent Decision Optimization
authors: Tenghui He
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Automation, Electronics and Electrical Engineering (AUTEEE)
abstract: For complex detection and decision tasks, this paper proposes a lightweight computational framework that tightly integrates Gradient Boosting Regression Trees (GBRT) with K-means clustering to address sample heterogeneity and efficiency constraints simultaneously. The approach first performs unsupervised stratification on key covariates via K-means, then trains cluster-specific GBRT sub-models whose outputs are unified as a common decision score. To reduce computational complexity and stabilize generalization, this paper employ feature engineering with mutual information filtering and sequential forward selection, together with Bayesian hyperparameter optimization and early stopping; inference is accelerated via feature binning and quantization to achieve near constant-time computation. On a held-out test set, the method attains an ROC-AUC of 0.934, improving over single global models (GBRT or logistic-regression baseline) at 0.863 by +0.071; the average gain over five-fold cross-validation is +0.066. Training time is reduced by ≈38%, and per-sample inference latency is <10 ms. These results indicate that the unified GBRT × K-means design improves both discriminative accuracy and computational efficiency without increasing deployment burden.

title: Solar-Powered Dynamic Wireless Charging for Sustainable EV Mobility
authors: S. Karthika, S. Rithanya, V. Balaji Prabhu, S. Suba Shree
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Automation, Computing and Renewable Systems (ICACRS)
abstract: The rising need for eco-friendly transportation has led to the innovation of solar-powered dynamic wireless charging systems for electric vehicles (EVs). These systems employ wireless power transfer (WPT) technology to recharge EVs while they are moving, with solar energy serving as the primary source. Solar panels installed along highways or specific lanes generate electricity, which is either directly transmitted to coils embedded in the road or stored in batteries. As EVs pass over these coils, receiver units capture the energy wirelessly, enabling battery charging on the move. This approach reduces reliance on the power grid, cuts downtime, and boosts the driving range.However, several challenges hinder the widespread adoption of this technology, including high infrastructure costs, the need for precise alignment, and efficiency limitations in power transfer. Solutions like maximum power point tracking (MPPT) and high-frequency resonant converters are employed to optimize energy delivery, while factors such as coil design, vehicle speed, and operating frequency impact WPT efficiency. Additionally, concerns about electromagnetic safety and overall system reliability must be addressed. For broad implementation, strong government support, clear regulatory guidelines, and cost-effective materials are essential. Nonetheless, integrating adaptive control strategies, machine learning, and IoT-based monitoring systems could significantly improve performance and speed up the transition to sustainable EV transportation.

title: Hierarchical Analysis of Influencing Factors of Information System Engineering Supervision Effect Based on ISM Model and TRIZ Theory
authors: Wei Ning, Zewen Xiang, Xinyue Zhang, Jiancheng Zhang, Xiaohong Ma, Jiyang Chen
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Digital Society and Intelligent Systems (DSInS)
abstract: To effectively enhance the supervisory effectiveness of the information system, firstly, this article analyzes the factors that influence the effectiveness of information system engineering supervision, identifies these key influencing factors, and constructs a corresponding set of evaluation indicators. Secondly, using the ISM model, a hierarchical analysis of the identified factors is conducted, delineating them into three structural levels: direct factors, indirect factors, and fundamental factors. Finally, the technical contradictions within TRIZ theory are applied to address and analyze the factors across these three hierarchical levels, and the 40 invention principles are matched accordingly. Combined with the practical context of information system engineering supervision, specific and actionable solutions are proposed.

title:
Optimal Coverage-based Cooperative Guidance for Inferior Vehicles Against a Maneuvering Target
                    <sup>*</sup>
authors: Yijing Wang, Tao Song, Hong Tao, Zeliang Wu, Wenbo Li
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: An optimal cooperative guidance law for multiple vehicles with weak maneuverability against a superior target is studied in this paper. Firstly, the range of zero-effort-miss distance under the relative-frame-based optimal guidance law is derived by considering the acceleration limitation. Secondly, by adopting the concept of a joint maneuver domain that encompasses the escape area, the reachable sets with bias for each vehicle are devised through the establishment of time-varying virtual aiming points. Then, the guidance command for is obtained by minimum energy consumption optimization. Moreover, the relations among the number of vehicles, the coverage area of the target’s large maneuver and the coefficient of guidance law are analyzed by designing a non-overlapping coverage strategy. Finally, simulation results demonstrate the feasibility and performance of the proposed method with bias term, which can realize the perfect interception of the weak multi-vehicles against the strong maneuvering target.

title: Real-Time Adaptive Attitude Control of Lynx Helicopter with Hybrid LQR-Neural Network Architecture
authors: Ahmet Kara, Mehmet Önder Efe
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: This paper presents a comprehensive implementation of a multilayer Neural Network (NN) controller for trajectory tracking in a 6 Degrees of Freedom (DoF) Lynx Helicopter Model, combining a passivity-based approach with real-time weight tuning and an inner-loop Linear Quadratic Regulator (LQR) for stability augmentation. The NN controller replaces traditional integral control, minimizing steady-state errors, enhancing reference tracking accuracy, and regulating off-axis states with a robust architecture that integrates filtered error signals, passivity-based terms, and system states. Using a forward pass for control generation and a backward pass for real-time weight adjustment via gradient descent, the controller ensures stability and convergence through adaptive gains and tuned learning rates. Time-domain simulations demonstrate precise tracking performance across diverse reference commands with minimal overshoot, smooth transients, and steady neural network weight convergence, validating the hybrid controller’s reliability under varying operating conditions.

title: A Framework for Digital Intelligent Anomaly Control in High-End Equipment Design and Manufacturing
authors: Ruoyi Sun, Yuxiang Ma, Shiduo Ning, Jing Ma, Chao Wei, Yanjun Shi
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Big Data, Artificial Intelligence and Internet of Things Engineering (ICBAIE)
abstract: High-end manufacturing sectors such as aerospace, marine vessels, rail transportation, energy power, and information electronics impose extremely demanding requirements on manufacturing technologies, and face challenges including multi-variety production, small batch sizes, high reliability, high consistency, and complex manufacturing processes. Meanwhile, production anomalies occur throughout the entire manufacturing flow, and traditional anomaly management methods—plagued by data fragmentation, delayed feedback, and inflexible scheduling—are increasingly inadequate to meet the practical needs of high-end equipment manufacturing. To address this bottleneck, a framework of digital-intelligent anomaly control in the design and manufacturing of high-end equipment is proposed. This framework establishes a key technological system for a collaborative closed loop of “design-scheduling-control” tailored to complex manufacturing requirements, which includes: a large language model(LLM)-driven design approach; a knowledge- and data-fusion driven proactive-reactive scheduling method for smart workshops; and a cloud-edge-device collaborative digital twin control method. By reshaping conventional anomaly management processes through digital-intelligent technologies, this model effectively supports flexible production and high-precision control in multi-variety, small-batch manufacturing scenarios, thereby enhancing the batch production capability of complex products.

title: Sequential Physically Consistent Dynamic Parameter Identification in Parallel Robots_supp1-3653379.mp4
authors: Ye Ding
abstract: Parallel robots have been widely applied because of their high stiffness and dynamic responsiveness. Advanced model-based control of such systems requires the accurate identification of dynamic parameters. This paper proposes a physically consistent dynamic parameter identification method enforced by a sequential identification procedure. Observable dynamic parameters in each actuator are first identified independently in sequence. These results are then incorporated as prior knowledge, represented as Gaussian distributions. A criterion considering sequential identification performance is also proposed to generate excitation trajectories. The experiments are conducted on a 3-degree-of-freedoms parallel robot of type 2RRU-1RRS. According to the experimental tests, the proposed method improves the accuracy of torque estimation even under insufficient excitation. It validates the effectiveness and robustness of the proposed method.

title: All-silicon 90-degree hybrid coupler for the WR3.4 band
authors: Harrison Lees, Bryce Chung, Withawat Withayachumnankul
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: In recent years, substrateless silicon waveguides have emerged as a broadband and exceptionally low-loss option for constructing integrated terahertz systems. One missing component is a 90-degree hybrid coupler, essential for realizing broadband transceivers and mixing architectures. Here we present this coupler based upon a trench coupler architecture. In simulation, the 3-dB bandwidth exceeds the WR3.4 band, with insertion loss less than 2 dB. In addition, the magnitude imbalance does not exceed 1 dB while the phase difference between the two output ports remains within 10 degrees of 90 degrees across the 110 GHz operating band. With acceptable performance, we foresee this component being readily employable in terahertz transceivers and IQ mixing modules.

title: Isolation Forest as a Tool for Entangled Photon Detection
authors: Dmytro Babets, Zbigniew Opilski, Volodymyr Hnatushenko, Kashtan Vita, Agnieszka Michalczuk, Olena Sdvyzhkova, Erwin Maciak, Krzysztof A. Cyran
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: Entangled photon detection is essential for advancements in quantum communication, cryptography, and fundamental quantum mechanics experiments. This study introduces a novel application of unsupervised machine learning for identifying potential entangled photon events by analyzing voltage signals recorded from Silicon Multiplier Amplified Detectors (SiMPs). By framing photon detection as an anomaly detection problem, we employ the Isolation Forest (iForest) algorithm to isolate rare and distinctive signal patterns within large, noisy datasets without requiring labeled training data. This is the first application of iForest in the context of entangled photon detection. The method enables automated identification of anomalous events exhibiting time correlations across multiple measurement channels, offering a scalable and computationally efficient solution for real-time processing of experimental data in quantum optics.

title: Joint Optimization of Generation and Maintenance for Large Cascaded Hydropower With Complex Operational Requirements
authors: Yushu Wu, Jianjian Shen, Zixuan Xu, Mingbo Wang, Chuntian Cheng, Le Li, Yuanyuan Han
abstract: The generation and maintenance of cascade hydropower face strong spatiotemporal coupling under multiple power grids’ flexible regulation demands, manifested by capacity competition, time mismatch, and nonlinear constraint interactions. This article proposes a joint optimization model for generation and maintenance, based on China’s largest mainstream cascade hydropower system. A mapping between daily average and peak generation is established to identify feasible maintenance windows, enable long-term daily scheduling, and meet hourly load-following requirements. This mapping is incorporated into a 730-days panoramic model which considers critical constraints including cross-year maintenance continuity, seasonal energy allocation, monthly generation trends, maintenance restrictions during peak supply periods, and transmission limits. The model’s complex logic constraints are reformulated by the Big-M method, becoming a tractable mixed-integer linear programming formulation. Case studies show that the proposed approach substantially alleviates current coordination difficulties, increases hydropower generation by 36 million kWh, and eliminates downtime during peak-demand hours. Sensitivity analysis further reveals that tighter peak-shaving requirements significantly reduce maintenance flexibility and increase reserve pressure.

title: Performance Comparison of QoS Metrics in TDEEC and LEACH Protocol in Wireless Sensor Networks
authors: Srinivasan S. R, Poovizhi D, Sahana K, Rajkumar G, Karthikeyan S, Gayathri Devi T
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Automation, Computing and Renewable Systems (ICACRS)
abstract: Wireless Sensor Networks are key components in modern applications, from monitoring the environment to health-related activities. Because the battery power available to sensor nodes is limited, it is important to reduce the amount of energy used to maintain maximum network performance. Clustering-Based routing protocols have developed over time and have proven to be a viable method of conserving energy and extending the life span of Wireless Sensor Networks. A common and uncomplicated clustering routing protocol was the Low Energy Adaptive Clustering Hierarchy (LEACH) protocol, which has cluster heads (CHs) rotated periodically, but was problematic because, although the original design was uncomplicated, it falsely assumed that all sensor nodes consume energy evenly. The Threshold Distributed Energy-Efficient Protocol (TDEEC) addresses this flaw by filtering CHs to assess the residual and average energy spent, which means that the nodes left with higher-energy potentials are more likely to become CHs, thus providing lower energy consumption among them to more evenly distribute energy loads and extend network lifetime. This paper investigates LEACH and TDEEC support through key Quality of Service (QoS) parameters, goodput, network lifetime, residual energy, and throughput to compare both protocols. Simulation results shown that the TDEEC outperforms LEACH with a residual energy of 90.5 percent and has a network life span of 60 percent.

title: Supply-Noise-Tolerant Signaling Scheme Using Inter-Lane-Referenced Common-Mode NRZ and Differential PAM-4 for Die-to-Die Interfaces
authors: Yoona Lee, Woo-Seok Choi
abstract: To achieve 3-bit encoding per UI, a signaling in which an NRZ signal is embedded in the common-mode voltage of a differential PAM-4 signal (CMDM-8) can be used. However, since the common-mode NRZ signal is transmitted in a singleended manner, it is more susceptible to power supply noise compared to the differential PAM-4 signal. This paper proposes a novel multi-lane CMDM-8 architecture, in which the commonmode voltage of one lane is fixed to address the limitations of conventional single-ended NRZ signal. Although the encoding efficiency slightly decreases-as one of the lanes transmits 2 bits instead of 3-the proposed architecture demonstrates strong tolerance to supply noise. When supply noise is injected, conventional designs using single-ended NRZ exhibit completely closed eyes, whereas the proposed scheme maintains eye openings, showing improved noise immunity.

title: Game-Based Generation of Binary Data for Use in Bell Inequality Experiments
authors: Anna Daniłowicz, Piotr Bartosz, Maja Wolak, Jakub Sarno, Agnieszka Michalczuk, Kamil Wereszczyński, Krzysztof A. Cyran
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: The game industry is wide and diverse, and the same can be said about the focus of games, as not all of them have entertainment in their core design. Many focus on pragmatic matters like education or science; such games are called serious games. One specific implementation of a serious game involves generating pseudo-random binary sequences (0 or 1) by observing the behavior of human players during gameplay for quantum research. Notably, the data collection process is often embedded subtly within the gameplay mechanics, potentially without the user’s explicit awareness. In our case, these humansourced bits are intended for use in quantum experiments testing Bell inequality, where unpredictable input plays a key role in addressing the freedom-of-choice loophole. The game serves as a covert interface between intuitive human decision-making and the controlled conditions of a quantum experiment. It is specifically designed to preserve the randomness and independence required for such foundational tests. This paper presents three serious game prototypes and explores how their core mechanics enable the extraction of behaviorally grounded binary sequences suitable for Bell experimental use as well as practicality of their deployment.

title: Autonomous Terrain Leveling Using a multi robots System: A formal framework for architecture and motion planning
authors: Thanh Binh Do, François Guerin
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: Autonomous terrain leveling operations significantly impact project timelines, cost efficiency, and environmental sustainability within earthworks, which constitute a substantial portion of the public works market. This paper introduces the Optimal Transport Planner Framework(OTPF), an innovative framework for multi-robot systems designed to automate material transport and surface leveling tasks by leveraging the online Multi-Agent Pickup and Delivery (MAPD) problem paradigm. OTPF addresses critical operational layers, specifically an optimal transport (OT) layer for task modeling and a Task Allocation Layer employing heuristic and consensusbased algorithms for efficient agent coordination. To effectively manage dynamic task assignments and collision-free motion, we propose a hierarchical task allocation and motion planning approach. OTPF integrates strategies inspired by MAPD methodologies to dynamically assign robotic agents to tasks, balancing operational efficiency with conflict resolution.

title: RADAR: Reliable Aligned Decoding and Resampling for Semi-Supervised Node Classification with Graph Contrastive Learning
authors: Weixin Wei, Donghai Guan
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Machine Learning, Big Data and Business Intelligence (MLBDBI)
abstract: Graph contrastive learning (GCL) leverages semantic consistency as contrastive signals and has shown strong performance in semi-supervised node classification. However, real-world graphs often exhibit class imbalance, and contrastive methods typically lack mechanisms to enhance representations for minority classes. Existing oversampling approaches like GraphSMOTE rely heavily on limited labeled nodes and their local neighborhoods, underutilizing informative unlabeled data. To address these issues, we propose RADAR (Reliable Aligned Decoding And Resampling), a framework with a dual-decoder design that produces reliable pseudo-labels via alignment between a supervised decoder and a momentum-driven auxiliary decoder. These labels guide adaptive oversampling to generate semantically consistent nodes for minority classes, improving decision boundaries and representation quality. The original and synthetic nodes are then jointly encoded through a graph contrastive learning backbone. Experiments on imbalanced graph datasets show that RADAR consistently outperforms prior methods across multiple metrics.

title: Bell Pepper Leaf Disease Detection Using Preprocessing and Machine Learning Technique
authors: Sushreeta Tripathy, Sutapa Chand, Rasmita Raul, Jyotirmayee Upadhyaya, Isha Sahu
publish: 2025 5th IEEE International Conference on Applied Electromagnetics, Signal Processing, &amp; Communication (AESPC)
abstract: Bell pepper (Capsicum annuum) is a widely cultivated vegetable crop whose yield is negatively affected by various foliar diseases. Accurate and early recognition of these conditions is vital for effective crop supervision and improved agricultural productivity. This study investigates the use of machine learning techniques(ML) for the automated detection of bell pepper leaf diseases, focusing on convolutional neural networks and the YOLO object detection framework, supported by essential image preprocessing methods. The investigation was conducted in two phases. In the first phase, a CNN-based model was developed to classify healthy and diseased leaf images. In the second phase, image preprocessing approach, such as noise diminution, contrast improvement and segmentation were applied to improve visual feature clarity, followed by disease localization using the YOLO model. Experimental results demonstrate that the combination of preprocessing, CNN and YOLO significantly improves disease detection performance, as measured by accuracy, precision, recall, and $\mathbf{F 1}$-score. The findings emphasize the effectiveness of integrated machine learning and preprocessing approaches in plant disease diagnosis. This work contributes to the development of intelligent agricultural systems, enabling early detection and management of plant diseases. Future directions include expanding the dataset and implementing real-time deployment for in-field disease monitoring. The designed algorithm yields 99.39% accuracy after preprocessing and YOLO-based detection.

title: Instrument Recognition in Polyphonic Music with Multimodal Feature-Assisted Deep Convolutional Neural Networks
authors: Shiyu Liu, Yi Zhou, Hui Wu
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Digital Society and Intelligent Systems (DSInS)
abstract: Instrument recognition plays a vital role in many fields such as music, education, artificial intelligence and cultural preservation. Among the instrument recognition tasks, polyphonic music instrument recognition is the most challenging. Most of the existing research on polyphonic music instrument recognition uses a single feature as input data for deep learning. This paper discusses the application of deep convolutional neural network in polyphonic music instrument recognition with the assistance of multi-modal features. Experiments show that compared with the traditional research using a single feature Mel Cepstral Coefficient (MFCC) to train the deep convolutional neural network. With the help of multi-modal features concatenating chroma features, spectral contrast and constant <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$Q$</tex> transform used in this paper, the F1 scores of deep convolutional neural networks increase from the original microscopic and macroscopic F1 scores of 0.688 and 0.642 to 0.767 and 0.729. The multi-modal feature assisted way enhances the accuracy and precision of model recognition.

title: Adaptive Roll Autopilot Design for Interceptor Missile
authors: Shivendra N. Tiwari, Ketan P. Detroja
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: Tactical missiles are designed to target a variety of aerial and ground objects, which can be stationary or moving. To effectively intercept these targets with minimal miss-distance, tactical missiles require a highly efficient control system. Obtaining a high level of accuracy in the aerodynamic characterization of the missile is notably challenging. In addition, the difficulty in modeling external disturbances complicates the autopilot design. As a result, there is a significant need for a robust control system that can handle parametric uncertainties and unmodeled external disturbances. This paper presents a robust roll autopilot based on the ${{\mathcal{L}}_1}$ adaptive technique. The proposed roll autopilot is designed to handle uncertainties, external disturbances, and unmodeled sensor delays. This approach treats both external disturbances and parametric uncertainties within the roll loop as composite disturbances. A state observer is used to estimate the composite disturbance, and the system states in a unified manner. The estimates obtained from the inner loop uncertainties are used to calculate the adaptive roll control input, which enhances the baseline control input designed for nominal operating conditions. Simulation results are provided to demonstrate the effectiveness of the adaptive roll autopilot in achieving the specified design objectives.

title: Two Phase Gas-Liquid Detection using Terahertz Imaging System
authors: Kabilan K, A. Mercy Latha, G S Ayyappan
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: Two-phase flow detection, particularly gas-liquid flow, is critical in various industrial applications such as oil and gas pipelines, chemical processing, and biomedical systems. Conventional techniques, including ultrasonic, optical, and microwave-based methods, often face limitations in terms of resolution, penetration, and sensitivity. Terahertz (THz) imaging systems offer a promising non-invasive alternative due to their high spatial resolution, ability to penetrate non-metallic materials, and sensitivity to variations in refractive index and dielectric properties. This study explores the feasibility of using a THz imaging system for detecting and characterizing gas-liquid two-phase flow. A continuous-wave (CW) THz imaging system has been employed to capture high-resolution images of flow channels within transparent and semi-transparent conduits. By analyzing the THz image acquired from the reflected signals, distinct phase distributions and flow patterns have been identified. The experimental setup includes a controlled test rig with varying gas-to-liquid ratios to simulate different flow regimes, namely, slug, discontinued slug, etc. Image processing techniques have been applied to enhance phase differentiation and improve detection accuracy. Preliminary results demonstrate that THz imaging can effectively distinguish gas and liquid phases based on their absorption and reflection characteristics. The proposed method provides a non-intrusive, high-precision approach to monitoring two-phase flow, offering significant advantages over traditional sensors. Future work will focus on real-time implementation, optimizing imaging parameters, and extending the methodology to optically-opaque pipelines. This research contributes to advancing flow diagnostics in industrial and scientific applications.

title: Set-theoretic Time-based Trajectory Synchronization Approach for Skid-Steered Robotic units subject to Constraints, Uncertainties, and External Disturbances
authors: Alessia Ferraro, Claudio De Capua, Valerio Scordamaglia
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: This paper presents a set-theoretic time-based trajectory synchronization method to coordinate the skid-steered units subject to slippage phenomena of a multi-robot system. The closed-loop trajectory tracking error dynamics are expressed in the form of an uncertain system subject to external disturbances and actuation constraints. Collision avoidance and coordination are achieved through synchronization of robot trajectories by imposing delays on platform departures. The procedure exploits the trajectory’s feasibility property by solving optimization problems involving Linear Matrix Inequalities (LMIs) constraints. The algorithm operates in separate offline and online phases. In the offline phase, the time delay intervals useful for synchronization are calculated based on the planned feasible trajectories. Then, in the online phase, the actual delay is calculated by solving an optimization problem that minimizes the occupancy time of the shared operational space. The results of several numerical simulations are presented and discussed to demonstrate the proposed solution’s effectiveness.

title: Terahertz Birefringence Study of 2-Amino-5-Nitropyridinium L (+) Tartrate Single Crystal
authors: Snehal Haldankar, Vibhavari Parkar, Fathimath Faseela, Atheena Pramod, Anurag Kumar Singh, Yogendra Kumar Lodhi, R Nagalakshmi, Shriganesh Prabhu
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: Terahertz Time-Domain Spectroscopy (THz-TDS) was employed to investigate the anisotropic optical properties of ANPT crystal. The studies revealed polarization-dependent transmission, confirming its anisotropic and birefringent nature. These characteristics indicate potential utility in THz devices requiring polarization control.

title: Construction and simulation of cloud edge collaborative task offloading algorithm
authors: Zhengdong Li, Yuan Huang, Jiaqiang Zhang, Xin Wu, Zheng Hong
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Big Data, Artificial Intelligence and Internet of Things Engineering (ICBAIE)
abstract: In the Internet of Things (IoT) system, terminal devices have a huge amount of data and local computing power is insufficient. Cloud computing has fast computing speed but there are transmission delays and network disturbances. To solve the above problems, this paper constructs a three-tier model consisting of terminal devices, edge computing servers, and cloud computing servers, and models the optimization of computing offload strategy as a comprehensive model to optimize task delay and device energy consumption. In terms of algorithms, the performance of three classic evolutionary algorithms, namely genetic algorithm (GA), differential evolution algorithm (DE), and particle swarm optimization algorithm (PSO), in solving continuous optimization problems is analyzed, and the influence of different parameters on performance is analyzed. The simulation results show that when the delay consumption and energy consumption are 1:1, the classical evolutionary algorithm reduces the computational complexity by about 36% to 43% compared to the fully local offloading strategy algorithm in terms of minimum system consumption, and by about 18% to 30% compared to the random strategy algorithm, effectively improving computational efficiency.

title: Multi-UAV-Assisted Wireless Federated Learning in Dynamic Environments: An AIRDO-based Multi-Agent RL Approach
authors: Luo Chen, Ruyan Wang, Dapeng Wu, Yaping Cui, Peng He, Ang Duan
abstract: In dynamic wireless environments, fluctuations in user distribution and channel conditions challenge the stability and efficiency of federated learning (FL) systems, especially in multi-UAV-assisted scenarios. UAV-assisted wireless FL has drawn great attention for its flexible deployment and distributed computing capabilities. However, centralized aggregation faces the risk of single-node failure at aggregation nodes, which can severely impact system reliability in dynamic environments. To address these issues, we propose a Decentralized Aggregation in UAV-assisted wireless Federated Learning (DAUFL) framework, which replaces centralized aggregation with a multi-node model aggregation mechanism to maintain stable operation and enhance system reliability under node failures. Furthermore, we develop an Adaptive Interference-aware Resource allocation and Deployment Optimization (AIRDO) algorithm. It first employs Constrained K-means for efficient UAV coverage, then applies Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning (RL) for dynamic interference-aware resource allocation and UAV deployment optimization. Simulation results show that DAUFL achieves strong robustness and model performance under both Independent and Identically Distributed (IID) and Non-IID data distributions, maintaining over 90% and 80% accuracy even under a 50% node failure rate. The AIRDO algorithm further accelerates convergence, reduces training latency, and maintains stable performance with large-scale users.

title: Live Demonstration: A Wireless RemotelyControlled Rat Cyborg Based on a 65 nm CMOS BMI Chip Featuring 4.5V Neuromodulation
authors: Tianying Fang, Wei-Chin Lin, Yikai Xu, Junhong Sun, Zhiyu Wang, Changgui Yang, Yunshan Zhang, Haoze Xu, Chaonan Yu, Kedi Xu, Gang Pan, Bo Zhao
publish: 2025 IEEE Biomedical Circuits and Systems Conference (BioCAS)
abstract: Micro-robots are envisaged to show great potential in various applications such as post-disaster rescue. However, it’s difficult for the current micro-robots to go across the complex terrains, and the lifetime is significantly constrained by the power-hungry mechanical actuators. In comparison, rat cyborgs leverage biological locomotion instead of mechanical actuation, exhibiting much longer lifetime in navigating narrow or irregular environment that are inaccessible for conventional wheeled or tracked robots [1]. This work presents a 4 G -remotely-controlled rat-cyborg system driven by a brain-machine interface (BMI) chip featuring a novel unipolar biphasic switched-capacitor (UBSC) stimulator. Fabricated in standard 65 nm CMOS process for low-power consideration, the chip integrates an 8-channel neural-signal acquisition unit [2], a 4-channel electrical stimulator, and a 4channel optical stimulator. Measurement results show that the proposed UBSC stimulator enables $\pm 4.5 \mathrm{~V}$ stimulation by only $243 \mu \mathrm{~W}$ power consumption (neural-signal acquisition and stimulation), despite the supply voltage constraints of the 65 nm process. The system achieves reliable remote control over a 35 km operator-to-cyborg distance via the 4 G network, demonstrating the movement along various routes of the rat cyborg.

title: A Two-electrode Bio-impedance Readout IC with Current Mismatch Cancellation and 60-Hz CMI Rejection Loop
authors: Seyeong Kim, Hoyoung Gong, Haidam Choi, Dong-Hwi Choi, Song-I Cheon, Minkyu Je
publish: 2025 IEEE Biomedical Circuits and Systems Conference (BioCAS)
abstract: Two-electrode bio-impedance (BioZ) sensing suffers from a large baseline caused by electrode impedance and 60-Hz common-mode interference (CMI). We propose a BioZ readout architecture that performs baseline cancellation using a differential difference current-balancing instrumentation amplifier (DDCBIA). This architecture enables baseline cancellation without requiring a connection to the current generator, thereby allowing the integration of a bias control loop to cancel current mismatch. By eliminating the need for large off-chip high-pass filters, this approach enhances the miniaturization and user comfort advantages inherent to two-electrode systems. However, the combination of the bias control loop and the DD-CBIA structure causes 60-Hz CMI to convert into a differential signal. To address this issue, a 60-Hz CMI rejection loop is introduced. Simulation results demonstrate a 97.9% reduction in 60-Hz differential signal and a 33.5 dB improvement in common-mode rejection ratio. The current generator consumes $10.1-242.9 \mu \mathrm{~W}$ when delivering a current input of $3-100 \mu \mathrm{~A}$, while the BioZ sensing front-end consumes only $14.98 \mu \mathrm{~W}$.

title: Adaptive Performance-Guaranteed Control with Safety Constraints for Continuum Robots: A 6-DoF Elephant Trunk Robot System
authors: Dong Zhang, Haoping Wang, Yang Tian
abstract: This paper presents an integrated adaptive control framework for continuum robots that ensures precise trajectory tracking while guaranteeing operational safety. This paper propose a synergistic approach combining Ultra-Local Model (ULM) formulation for model-free control, Adaptive Time-Delay Estimation (ATDE) for real-time disturbance compensation, Pre-scribed Performance Control (PPC) for bounded tracking errors, and Control Barrier Functions (CBFs) for safety constraint enforcement. The ULM eliminates dependence on complex dynamic models, while ATDE handles lumped uncertainties. PPC confines tracking errors within user-defined boundaries, and CBFs ensure satisfaction of joint limits and collision avoidance constraints. Lyapunov analysis establishes exponential convergence to a bounded residual set with formal safety guarantees. Simulations on a 6-DOF continuum manipulator demonstrate superior tracking accuracy and constraint satisfaction, validating the framework’s effectiveness for safety-critical applications requiring both precision and robustness.

title: Design of Photon-assisted Terahertz Signal Transmission System
authors: Wei Shao, Zhongbo Zhu, Bochao Kang, Sheng Li, Caixia Wang, Shengxiao Jin, Chongdi Duan
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: This paper proposes and designs a photon-assisted terahertz (THz) signal transmission system and method. A multi-line optical comb is generated by a Mach-Zehnder Modulator (MZM) and a wavelength division multiplexer is used for frequency band selection. Then, a multi-band terahertz signal is generated by coherent optical beat frequency. Combined with the advantages of long-distance low-loss transmission about optical fiber, the long-distance transmission of THz signals can be finally realized. Through simulation calculation, dual-band THz signal transmission with the communication rate of 16Gbps can be achieved under the 16QAM modulation mode, and the signal’s error vector magnitude (EVM) is less than 8.6%, providing a new idea for the development of new communication technology.
