title: A Dual-Core Wide Bandwidth and High Accuracy Fluxgate Current Sensor
authors: Kun Wang, Zhiwen Cui, Jiafu Wang, Chuansheng Li, Haiming Shao
abstract: A novel fluxgate current sensor scheme based on a dual-core configuration is proposed in this study. By integrating a direct current (DC) zero-flux detector, an alternating current (AC) zero-flux detector, and a secondary compensation coil module, a unified design of multi-coil and multi-signal processing circuits is achieved. Compared with conventional three-core fluxgate designs, the proposed approach offers a simplified structure while maintaining high bandwidth and high-accuracy measurement capabilities. A prototype was developed based on the proposed principles, which was subsequently evaluated through experiments. The results demonstrate that the sensor achieves a -3dB bandwidth exceeding 1.6 MHz. Within the frequency range of 10 Hz to 100 kHz, the amplitude response variation remains below 2%, and the phase deviation is within 2°. When benchmarked against a precision shunt resistor, the measurement error of 100 kHz AC current is maintained within 3%. The sensor also exhibits a step-response rise time of approximately 300 ns. These findings indicate that the proposed dual-core fluxgate sensor is well-suited for wideband current measurement applications demanding high dynamic performance and accuracy.

title: Real-Time, Non-Invasive Eye Pressure Monitoring using Embedded Scleral Imaging and Feature Analysis
authors: Jeyakumar P, Ranjith Kumar R, Rohith M, Sabareesan K S, Sachin K
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Automation, Computing and Renewable Systems (ICACRS)
abstract: Glaucoma is a leading cause of irreversible blindness, with early detection and continuous intraocular pressure (IOP) monitoring being essential for effective management. Traditional tonometry methods, though accurate, require direct corneal contact, anesthetic use, and clinical supervision, limiting accessibility and patient compliance. This paper presents a portable, non-invasive, and IoT-enabled device for real-time IOP monitoring using scleral image analysis. The system captures high-resolution images of the sclera through a digital microscope and processes them using grayscale conversion, contrast enhancement, edge detection, and morphological operations to extract vascular features. Vessel density and structural parameters are then analyzed using an embedded algorithm to estimate IOP without physical contact. Designed for both clinical and home-based use, the device features a built-in display for instant feedback and wireless connectivity for remote monitoring. It provides accurate IOP readings in the 10–30 mmHg range, with validation against Goldmann applanation tonometry showing high correlation and low error. The contact-free design improves hygiene, comfort, and usability, especially for rural populations and patients requiring frequent monitoring. By integrating real-time imaging, embedded processing, and telemedicine compatibility, this system offers a cost-effective and scalable solution for early glaucoma detection and preventive eye care.

title: Field Robot for Precision Seed Distribution and Crop Care
authors: T. Vijay, C. Infant Vinoth, B. Tharani, G. Sundar, R. Karthileyan, K. G. Gokulraj
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Automation, Computing and Renewable Systems (ICACRS)
abstract: Tractors and other cutting-edge agricultural equipment are either unavailable or extremely expensive, which presents serious difficulties for small-scale farmers in isolated communities. Conventional tractors are not practical for smaller plots and are better suited for large-scale farming in cities or medium-sized villages. This project offers a cutting-edge, reasonably priced agricultural kit made especially to meet the demands of small farmers. Important farming tasks like plowing, seed feeding, and insecticide spraying are carried out by the suggested system. Because of its easy-to-use design, even people with little technical expertise can use it effectively. Farmers can set instructions like distance, direction, and specific tasks with the kit, which is controlled by a mobile phone. Internet access is not necessary for the system to function automatically based on these inputs. Using a specialized app and positioning the mobile device close to the unit, data is transferred over Wi-Fi. An integrated water pump is included for consistent insecticide application to help farmers even more. This minimizes manual labor and enhances crop care by guaranteeing efficient coverage, even in hard-to-reach places like the underside of leaves. Basic obstacle detection and auto-stop capabilities are also included in the system to improve usability and safety in erratic field conditions. It is perfect for places with little road infrastructure because of its portability and simplicity of deployment. This project provides a scalable way to increase rural agriculture's sustainability and productivity by lowering the cost and increasing access to modern farming equipment. It encourages improved crop management techniques, boosts operational efficiency, and gives farmers more technological power. In the end, the kit helps underprivileged farming communities have better livelihoods and more food security.

title: A novel RX-RZ Entangled Feature Map Kernel for Fraud Detection using Quantum Support Vector Machine Classifier
authors: Jaydeep Rath, Priya Das, Amit Kumar Mishra
publish: 2025 5th IEEE International Conference on Applied Electromagnetics, Signal Processing, &amp; Communication (AESPC)
abstract: This study proposes a quantum-kernel framework based on a Quantum Support Vector Machine (QSVM) with a novel XYZ feature map integrating RY and RZ rotations for encoding, full all-to-all CX entanglement, and an additional RX rotation layer to obtain higher-order information. The performance of the proposed method is evaluated using a publicly available dataset and benchmarked this embedding against standard Z, ZZ, and Pauli feature maps under matched circuit depth and resource budgets. Across settings, the suggested XYZ map yields the highest performance with accuracy of 93.2%, precision of 0.934, recall of 0.925 and G-mean of 0.93. These results indicate that fully entangling quantum embeddings can enhance the approximation capacity of quantum-kernel for real-world anomaly detection and provide a path toward quantum-assisted fraud analytics.

title: Terahertz Resonance Imaging of Skin Response to Stinging Nettle Exposure
authors: Pouyan Rezapoor, Aleksi Tamminen, Juha Ala-Laurinaho, Dan Ruan, Zachary Taylor
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: Conventional terahertz time-domain spectroscopy (THz-TDS) systems lack the frequency resolution necessary for accurate assessment of ultra-thin skin layers such as the stratum corneum (SC) below 30 μm. We introduce a Fabry–Pérot resonance-based technique, implemented with the high-resolution Telecentric Offset Reflective Imaging System (TORIS), which enables precise detection of spectral perturbations in a window-tissue multilayer geometry. This approach facilitates non-invasive, real-time mapping of epidermal thickness and hydration. In this study, we employ the validated TORIS system to investigate the dynamic epidermal response following exposure to stinging nettle, highlighting the method’s capability to detect rapid physiological changes in skin properties.

title: NIKI: Neighbor Interfering Knowledge Injection for Large Language Models
authors: Guiyang Ji, Yuchen Jiang, Peiyan Wang, Danqingxin Yang, Yuxun Xia
publish: 2025 IEEE 31th International Conference on Parallel and Distributed Systems (ICPADS)
abstract: Efficiently injecting knowledge into large language models (LLMs) continues to pose a significant challenge. Current approaches, such as supervised fine-tuning (SFT) and retrieval-augmented generation (RAG), bear their own limitations. SFT requires substantial computational resources, while RAG is heavily dependent on the availability of high-quality knowledge bases. This paper introduces an innovative method for efficient knowledge injection, providing a balanced trade-off between resource utilization and performance. It extracts knowledge from domain-specific LLMs by storing the context representations and their corresponding target tokens in a datastore and injects it into another LLM by neighbor interfering with the LLM's decoding process. Experimental results with four LLMs reveal that our proposed method yields average gains of 33.1 in ROUGE-L and 16.3 in BLEU-4 on manufacturing specification datasets, and 7.7 in ROUGE-L and 4.5 in BLEU-4 on medical consultation datasets. We believe this method offers a novel direction and insight for LLM knowledge injection.

title: Early Detection of Diabetic Retinopathy using Hybrid Deep Learning Model
authors: Mynavathi R, Rajendran P, Vismita A, Naveena S, Subhika C
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Automation, Computing and Renewable Systems (ICACRS)
abstract: Diabetic retinopathy is a complication arising from prolonged diabetes that affects the eyes and can result in significant loss of vision. Existing diagnosis by ophthalmologists is time-consuming and is likely to miss early signs of the disease. This research proposes a hybrid deep learning model intended to improve the reliability and effectiveness of diabetic retinopathy identification. Retinal fundus images are pre-processed to reduce noise and improve visualization, ensuring better feature extraction. The model includes a convolutional neural network and ResNet-50. ResNet-50 was chosen due to its ability to cope with the problem of vanishing gradients, allowing to extract more accurate features in depth. The most representative features extracted by CNN and ResNet-50 will be used as input for a Support Vector Machine classifier, which will determine the different stages of DR. This approach eliminates manual diagnosis, which will enable faster, scalable, and accurate early detection of DR and ultimately lead to superior patient care.

title: Time-Domain Reflection THz Spectroscopy of Heated c-Si for Radiometric Applications
authors: L. F. E. Beijnen, M. D. Huiskes, A. Neto, P. Sberna
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: THz time-domain reflection spectroscopy experiments of crystalline Si samples of different doping and heated to temperatures up to 475 K have been performed to measure their electric permittivity, absorptivity and resistivity dispersion spectra. Free charge carrier volume concentration and scattering time have also been extracted from the measurements, as a function of temperature, to best fit the Drude model to the complex resistivity spectra. The dependence of these microscopic parameters to the temperature resembles the curves from the unified model for the carriers mobility, based on past dc measurements. The high-frequency data acquired with these measurements constitute the fundamental information and parameters, necessary for the characterization of crystalline Si thermal radiation emission.

title: Research on Software Defect Detection Method Based on Changing Location Lightweight Map Data
authors: Jingdong Wang, Guiwen Ta, Fanqi Meng
publish: 2025 IEEE 31th International Conference on Parallel and Distributed Systems (ICPADS)
abstract: Aiming at the problems such as large memory occupation and slow speed caused by excessive data usage when using the graph-based representation method to detect defects in the software source code during the software update and maintenance process, a lightweight defect detection method for graph data based on the source code change position is proposed. The innovation point lies in that during the data preprocessing process, after fully extracting the dependency relationships between source code statements and the semantic information of the statements by constructing the program dependency graph through extracting source code data, the content and location of the source code changes in one submission are determined, thereby inferring the parts that have an impact on the source code in one change. Ultimately, the amount of data is reduced by pruning the dependency graph to remove the parts that do not participate in the change and are not affected by the change, thereby reducing the computational overhead. The processed data is more suitable for defect detection during software update and maintenance, overcoming the problem of excessive quantity caused by the original graph-based preprocessing method, and thus optimizing the effect of the model. Through experimental verification, this method reduces the data volume by approximately <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$58.91 / \%$</tex> on the dataset constructed with jmeter, lowers the runtime memory usage by approximately 35.89 %, and increases the speed by approximately 41.87 %. And verified through the log information of the libgdx software, there are obvious changes in the above three aspects.

title: Terahertz Optical Properties of Ti-based Metal Organic Frameworks
authors: Reehab Jahangir, Filip M. Podjaski, Ashish Kumar, Georges Mouchaham, Christian Serre, James Durrant, Mira Naftaly
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: Metal-Organic-Frameworks (MOFs) are a relatively novel and versatile material class that blends organic and inorganic properties, while yielding highly porous and crystalline structures with broad applications in renewable energies. Two chemically robust and photocatalytically active MOFs, NH2-MIL-125(Ti) and MIL-177(Ti)-LT are investigated and compared, both incorporating titanium oxoclusters as the active inorganic building units, albeit with different sizes and linker geometries. Using THz-TDS, the intrinsic complex refractive index of both these materials is extracted for a better understanding of their property-function relationship on time scales of light-driven charge generation. Both MOFs show higher refractive index than their parent TiO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> (n ~ 2.32, rutile), with NH<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>-MIL-125(Ti) being 2.4 times higher, indicating that molecular coordination of inorganic material clusters using organic linkers can enhance a key material property. The THz conductivity of NH<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>-MIL-125(Ti) (578 ± 2 S/m) is found to be 10 times higher than MIL-177(Ti)-LT, which indicates that the strong electronic interactions between the titanium metal nodes and amino linkers, along with the ordered crystalline structure, promote efficient electron transport.

title: Collimating metalens antenna with high directivity for integration into compact terahertz continuous-wave sources
authors: Kaito Ebisawa, Kento Sato, Kazuisao Tsuruda, Takehito Suzuki
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: Next-generation wireless communication systems are expected to adopt recently developed compact terahertz continuous-wave (CW) sources manufactured using nanotechnology. The directivity control of terahertz waves emitted from terahertz CW sources, including resonant tunneling diodes (RTD) and quantum cascade lasers (QCL), is essential to enhance radiation power in the far-field region. Furthermore, achieving radiation power in the 1-W class with a compact volume requires integrating high directivity planar optical elements into a terahertz CW source array. However, terahertz flat optics based on metasurfaces has yet to be commonly adopted in terahertz CW sources because there are few manufacturing methods suitable for metasurfaces composed of multiple meta-atoms in the order of a few hundred micrometers. Here, we fabricate a collimating metalens antenna composed of meta-atoms on both the front and back of a thin dielectric substrate using single femtoliter inkjet printing technology. We also demonstrate that the fabricated collimating metalens antenna enhances the directivity of a single RTD oscillating at 0.312 THz 2.28 times. The collimating metalens antenna converts approximately spherical terahertz waves emitted from the RTD into plane waves with high directivity. Our results suggest that single femtoliter inkjet printing technology offers a powerful method for fabricating planar optical elements based on terahertz flat optics. Integrating high directivity planar optical elements, including our original collimating metalens antennas presented here, into a terahertz CW source array would be pivotal for enabling 6G and beyond wireless communications.

title: MM-3DAttNet: Multi-Modal 3D Attention Network for MGMT Methylation Prediction
authors: Gayathri Ramasamy, Tripty Singh, Xiaohui Yuan, Ganesh R Naik
publish: IEEE Open Journal of the Computer Society
abstract: The methylation status of the <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$O^{6}$</tex-math></inline-formula>-methylguanine-DNA methyltransferase (MGMT) gene promoter is a well-established prognostic and predictive biomarker in glioma, particularly for assessing responsiveness to alkylating agents such as temozolomide. However, current radiogenomic approaches for MGMT status prediction are limited by reliance on invasive biopsy, 2D slice-wise modelling, suboptimal exploitation of multi-modal MRI, and weak model interpretability, all of which hinder robust clinical adoption. To address these gaps, we introduce a multi-modal 3D attention network (MM-3DAttNet) for non-invasive prediction of MGMT promoter methylation status from pre-operative multi-parametric brain MRI. The architecture comprises four modality-specific 3D CNN encoder branches for T1, T1ce, T2, and FLAIR, which are fused via a cross-modality attention mechanism to capture complementary diagnostic information.The model was trained and validated on the BraTS 2021 cohort, including 585 glioma cases annotated with MGMT methylation labels, and achieved an average accuracy of <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$91.6\%$</tex-math></inline-formula>, an F<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$_{1}$</tex-math></inline-formula>-score of <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$89.9\%$</tex-math></inline-formula>, and an area under the ROC curve of 0.925 across five-fold cross-validation. Model interpretability was enhanced through Grad-CAM-based saliency maps, which consistently highlighted clinically meaningful regions, including enhancing tumour margins and peritumoural oedema. A comprehensive ablation study confirmed the importance of both multi-modal integration and the attention-based fusion: removing individual modalities reduced performance relative to the full four-modality model, with the largest drops observed when T1ce or FLAIR was excluded, underscoring their dominant contribution to MGMT-related signal. Taken together, these results demonstrate the efficacy and robustness of MM-3DAttNet as an interpretable radiogenomic framework for MGMT methylation assessment and motivate its prospective evaluation in multi-centre studies and integration into MRI-based decision-support pipelines for glioma management.

title: Photonic Integrated Terahertz Spectrometer with Kilohertz Measurement Rate at Discrete Frequencies
authors: Lauri Schwenson, Florian Walter, Konstantin Wenzel, Alexander Jäckel, Simon Nellen, Lars Liebermeister, Cornelius Mach, Enrique Castro-Camus, Martin Koch, Martin Schell, Robert B. Kohlhaas
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: We present a photonic integrated circuit (PIC) designed for high-speed terahertz (THz) spectroscopy, operating at kilohertz repetition rates. This PIC integrates all components to generate and modulate the optical beating signals, enabling continuous wave THz generation and coherent detection. We implement an innovative sparse sensing approach with a discrete frequency sweep across 735 GHz in less than 1 ms and achieve a peak dynamic range exceeding 90 dB within a measurement time of less than 1 second. We apply this approach to a multi-layer thickness evaluation and validate the acquired amplitude and phase information, yielding a standard deviation below 2 µm across all three layers. Our experimental evaluation is the first demonstration of spectroscopic THz measurements utilizing a PIC operated at kilohertz repetition rates. This innovative spectrometer is ideally suited for industrial applications, including in-line monitoring and material characterization, showcasing the potential of photonic integration to advance THz spectroscopy.

title: Digital Twin of a Two-Tank System: A Bond Graph Modeling Approach
authors: Amal Ben Maiz, Mahdi Boukerdja, Belkacem Ould Bouamama, Achraf Jabeur Telmoudi
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: Digital Twin (DT) technology has recently gained significant attention in both industry and academia. By improving efficiency, reducing costs, and enabling predictive maintenance, DT plays a crucial role in control, diagnostics, prediction, and optimization. However, at the definition level, the rapid growth of research has led to a variety of definitions and inconsistent terminology, underscoring the need for a clearer and more unified understanding of the DT concept. At the design stage, two major challenges remain. The first is to develop models that are both accurate and dynamic, capable of supporting optimization and real-time supervision, including control and diagnosis. The second lies in ensuring a reliable link to the physical system through online identification, which is particularly challenging due to the non-stationary nature of real-world processes. This study addresses the definition level and the first challenge at the design level by offering a comprehensive overview of the DT concept, including its definition, development phases, and an illustration of its design carried out in a two-tank system. The research consists of using the Bond Graph (BG) tool as a multi-physical graphical tool for designing a DT not only for dynamic modeling but also for online supervision, including diagnosis and recovery decisions. The results first show the effectiveness of BG in constructing the DT using 20Sim software for dynamic modeling and fault detection and isolation. This BG tool enables DT to monitor the state of the system and provides the health indicators necessary to reconfigure the system controller.

title: Development of a Multi-Lens Quasi-Optical Imaging Spectrometer for Ground-Based Astronomy
authors: Shahab O. Dabironezare, Leon G. G. Olde Scholtenhuis, Louis H. Marting, Yuri Nishimura Shiino, Arend Moerman, Wouter Gregoor, Cor Meijneke, Jochem Baselmans, Akira Endo
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: Achieving a wide instantaneous bandwidth and wide scanning capabilities are essential for development of (sub)millimeter imaging spectrometers for astronomical observations. Such an instrument can be realized using complex quasi-optical (QO) systems. In this work, we propose a QO architecture based on refractive components to reduce the overall size and volume of the instrument. This compact design is optimized using a sequential Geometrical Optics based technique. The performance of the preliminary design is reported in terms of the aperture efficiency over an octave of bandwidth and the field of view of the telescope hosting the instrument exhibiting less than 1dB of scan loss. The finalized design of the instrument, its performance, and realization approach will be discussed at the conference.

authors: Aaron Grapentin, Christian A. Hans, Jörg Raisch
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: In this paper, we present an advanced wind turbine control scheme for power maximization as well as for active power control, which is designed using ℋ<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">∞</inf> loop-shaping. Our approach involves the synthesis of two separate controllers for two different operating modes. To ensure smooth transitions between these modes, we implement a bumpless transfer strategy that reduces transient effects. A comprehensive case study demonstrates the efficacy of our control scheme, showing significant improvements in power tracking accuracy and a reduction in mechanical wear. Moreover, our control strategy comes with robust stability guarantees.

title: Ultrafast Photoconductors for 1030 nm Excitation based on MBE-Grown, Transition Metal-Doped InGaAlAs
authors: Tina Heßelmann, Steffen Breuer, Alexander Kleinkamp, Alexander Dohms, Shahram Keyvaninia, Adam T. M. Wood, Terng Junn Keat, Michael B. Johnston, Martin Schell, Robert B. Kohlhaas
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: While the predominant excitation wavelength for terahertz time-domain spectrometers systems is 1550 nm, it is interesting to expand the range of usable laser sources, particularly by harnessing advanced, high-power laser technologies. Accordingly, we explore the suitability of the quaternary photoconductor InGaAlAs in combination with iron (Fe) and rhodium (Rh) doping for the 1030 nm wavelength range, for the first time. Our findings demonstrate that both Fe and Rh doped InGaAlAs exhibit exceptional electron mobility, >1500 cm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>/Vs, coupled with an order of magnitude higher resistance compared to the InGaAs material system for the 1550 nm range. Additionally, the InGaAlAs:Fe/Rh photoconductors possess sub-picosecond charge-carrier lifetimes. Consequently, this photoconductive material holds significant promise for future applications in photoconductive antennas.

title: Terahertz Spectroscopy of Hydrogen Storage in Porous Materials
authors: Katharine Bancroft, Johanna Kölbel, Michael T. Ruggiero, Daniel M. Mittleman
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: Porous materials such as clathrates and metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are of great interest for capture and storage of hydrogen gas, but the gas capture dynamics are not yet fully understood. With a unique high pressure cell which allows in situ terahertz time-domain spectroscopy measurements throughout the gas capture process, we produce hydroquinone-hydrogen clathrate (β-HQ-H<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>). The spectrum we find is distinct from previously studied hydroquinone clathrates such as β-HQ-Ar and β-HQ-CO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> and can be differentiated from them based on peak locations and amplitudes.

title: MedViMamba: A Hybrid State Space and Convolutional Network for Multi-Modal MRI-Based IDH Mutation Status Classification in Gliomas
authors: Yuehui Liao, Yu Chen, Panfei Li, Qun Jin, Xiaobo Lai
publish: 2025 IEEE Cyber Science and Technology Congress (CyberSciTech)
abstract: Deep learning has significantly advanced medical image classification; however, mainstream architectures such as Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) and Vision Transformers (ViTs) exhibit notable limitations—CNNs struggle to effectively model long-range dependencies, while ViTs suffer from quadratic computational complexity due to their self-attention mechanisms, which restricts their applicability in computationally sensitive scenarios. Accurate classification of isocitrate dehydrogenase (IDH) mutation status, a critical prognostic and therapeutic biomarker in glioma, requires the simultaneous extraction of local fine-grained features and understanding of global contextual relationships from MRI scans. To address these challenges, we propose MedViMamba, a state space model (SSM)-based visual backbone network specifically designed for IDH mutation status classification in glioma. MedViMamba incorporates a novel SS-Conv SSM hybrid module that combines the local feature extraction capability of convolutional operations with the global contextual modeling advantages of selective SSMs, achieving linear computational complexity while maintaining strong representational power. Furthermore, the introduction of grouped convolution and channel shuffling mechanisms reduces parameter overhead and enhances computational efficiency. We evaluated MedViMamba on a multi-center MRI dataset consisting of 562 glioma patients, and experimental results demonstrate that our method achieves competitive or superior accuracy compared to state-of-the-art approaches while significantly improving the efficiency-accuracy trade-off. This work provides new insights into SSM-based medical visual modeling and offers a robust framework for resource-efficient biomarker classification in glioma.

title: Low cost and highly efficient THz waves using chaotic supremacy
authors: Fumiyoshi Kuwashima, Mona Jarrahi, Semih Cakmakyapan, Kenji Wada, Masanobu Haraguchi, Yuki Kawakami, Takeshi Moriyasu, Osamu Morikawa, Kazuyoshi Kurihara, Hideaki Kitahara, Takashi Furuya, Makoto Nakajima, Masahiko Tani
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: Low cost, compact, highly efficient, and highly stable THz wave using chaotically oscillating laser diode is investigated. Compared it to conventional continuous wave multi-mode semiconductor laser excitation system, about ten times output radio frequency power is increased because of chaotic supremacy.

title: AI-Augmented risk mitigation framework for legacy healthcare applications lacking SAST compatibility
authors: Arpna Aggarwal, Harikrishnan Muthukrishnan, Rahul Bhatia
publish: 2025 IEEE Cyber Science and Technology Congress (CyberSciTech)
abstract: In today’s regulated and digitized healthcare environment, securing legacy applications remains a critical challenge. Static Application Security Testing (SAST) tools are indispensable in modern DevSecOps pipelines; yet many healthcare systems still rely on outdated platforms that cannot integrate with these tools. This incompatibility creates blind spots that expose sensitive data and critical operations to breaches.This research addresses the urgent gap in risk assessment and mitigation where SAST integration is infeasible. We propose a fallback security framework that combines AI-augmented, human-in-the-loop vulnerability scoring with behavior-based anomaly detection, offering adaptive protection for legacy applications. Our framework also includes a comparative matrix of SAST tool compatibility with legacy technologies and compensating controls tailored to healthcare environments.Through analysis of healthcare compliance requirements, such as the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA), case studies from payer and provider systems, and mapping of control gaps, we demonstrate how legacy incompatibility amplifies exposure to cyberattacks, downtime, and regulatory failures. The findings highlight that while modernization is essential, organizations can mitigate risk through the implementation of layered governance, staff training, and phased deployment of security controls.This framework operates transformer-based code translation models and machine learning-driven behavioral anomaly detection, enabling legacy risk remediation to move from theoretical to actionable in real-time DevSecOps pipelines.

title: Meta-Imaging Enabled Infrared Target Detection: Aberration Correction and Weak Signal Enhancement
authors: Hezhi Sun, Xiang Li, Yanwang Zhai
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: To address the challenges of optical aberrations and low energy efficiency in large-aperture, high-resolution imaging for distant faint target detection, this study proposes an infrared meta-imaging-based light field reconstruction method. A 0.125rad optical aperture experimental system with 12k×12k resolution was constructed. Comparative experiments on reconstructing 2×2-pixel point targets in cloud (SBR=5:1) and snow (SBR=2:1) backgrounds demonstrated that meta-imaging significantly outperforms conventional wide-field imaging in signal-to-clutter ratio (SCR) and energy concentration while eliminating edge-field aberrations. This method overcomes the limitations of multi-lens aberration correction systems, substantially improving optical energy utilization, and provides a novel solution for large-field-of-view faint target detection.

title: Research on Path Planning of Path-Finding Robot Based on a GA-ACO Hybrid Algorithm
authors: Lixiang Feng, Jie Wang, Sida Wang, Yao Fu, Zhiye Li, Chao Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Automation, Electronics and Electrical Engineering (AUTEEE)
abstract: To address the problems of long computation time, low efficiency, and poor path quality in the autonomous path planning of path-finding robots in complex environments, a path planning method (GA-ACO) based on the fusion of Genetic Algorithm (GA) and Ant Colony Optimization (ACO) is proposed. This method leverages GA's strong global search capability to generate high-quality initial path populations and integrates ACO's positive feedback mechanism for local path refinement, forming a "global exploration-local refinement" two-stage collaborative optimization framework. Comparative simulation experiments were conducted in a 100×100 grid environment with 11 mixed rectangular and circular obstacles, using traditional ACO, Rapidly-exploring Random Tree (RRT), and Artificial Potential Field (APF) as comparison algorithms. The simulation results show that the GA-ACO algorithm exhibits significant advantages in key performance indicators: its collision-free success rate reaches 100%, while traditional ACO and RRT achieve 0%; the average path length is 118.46 units, which is 58.8% shorter than traditional ACO (287.54 units), 79.8% shorter than RRT (585.40 units), and 78.6% shorter than APF (553.82 units); the safety margin is 0.68 units, 33 times higher than APF's 0.02 units. Although its computation time (4.35s) is slightly longer than the contrast algorithms (0.2-0.3s), this minimal cost is fully compensated by the substantial improvements in path quality and safety. The proposed algorithm provides a reliable technical solution for path planning of path-finding robots in complex static obstacle environments.

title: Dynamic Inspection Path Planning and Defect Recognition Method Based on Adaptive Reinforcement Learning
authors: Shuying Cheng, Afeng Tan, Congyou Lin, Han Ye, Jianming Xu
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Automation, Electronics and Electrical Engineering (AUTEEE)
abstract: In complex, dynamic industrial environments, traditional pre-programmed inspection path planning methods suffer from low detection efficiency and high missed detection rates. Therefore, this paper proposes an integrated approach for dynamic inspection path planning and defect recognition based on adaptive reinforcement learning. Methodologically, a hybrid state representation is constructed by fusing lidar point clouds and visual images, and feature extraction is performed. A hierarchical proximal policy optimization algorithm framework is then designed. Finally, a model-based meta-reinforcement learning algorithm is introduced. Results show that in path planning efficiency experiments, the proposed method completes the task in only 41.7 seconds. In defect recognition accuracy experiments, the final measured average approach (MAP) reaches 0.90. In policy adaptation speed experiments, near-optimal performance is achieved with only approximately 100 training steps. These results demonstrate that the proposed framework can effectively address dynamic uncertainty and provide solid support for the practical application of intelligent autonomous inspection systems.

title: Analysis of the Differences in Stroke Techniques between Amateur tennis players with and without formal tennis education background
authors: Hang Yi, Bo Wu, Changlong Xu
publish: 2025 IEEE Cyber Science and Technology Congress (CyberSciTech)
abstract: Most tennis studies have focused on elite or professional athletes and have been conducted in highly controlled laboratory environments. In contrast, research on amateur tennis players is seriously lacking. There is a notable paucity of research on experienced amateur tennis players, particularly regarding the quantitative comparisons between individuals with a formal tennis education background (hereinafter referred to as the "tennis-major group") and those without such a background, which remains extremely limited. To address this research gap, we propose a single-camera-based, non-contact, and markerless analytical approach in which the collected video data are processed using Media Pipe, followed by the application of Mann–Whitney U and Welch t-tests Test to examine differences in forehand and backhand strokes between Amateur tennis players with and without formal tennis education background. Based on these data, we computed and analyzed the differences of four crucial kinematic metrics (hip - shoulder axial rotation, shoulder angle at the instant of impact, elbow angle at the instant of impact, Torso Rotation-Based Kinematic Symmetry Index (°) on experienced amateur players with and without formal tennis Education. The results of Mann–Whitney U and Welch t-tests Test indicate that in the case of forehand strokes, the group with tennis education background exhibits greater rotation amplitudes of the hip and trunk, more notable elbow extension, and more prominent asymmetry between the preparation phase and the follow - through phase. Conversely, for backhand strokes, the results of statistical analysis do not reveal any significant differences. This method can offer amateur tennis players timely feedback for future self-practice, thus contributing to the improvement of their sports performance.

title: Research on Internet Data Security Optimization Algorithm Based on Artificial Intelligence
authors: Xuanyi Li
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Automation, Electronics and Electrical Engineering (AUTEEE)
abstract: This paper proposes an optimization algorithm based on artificial intelligence to address the problems of insufficient detection accuracy and high response delay in the data security protection of the Internet. The algorithm introduces intelligent encryption and adaptive detection mechanisms on the basis of feature extraction, builds a collaborative structure of encryption and detection through the minimization theorem of the security cost function, and combines the algorithm convergence theorem to ensure that the model has global stability and controllable convergence during the iterative process. The experimental results show that this algorithm outperforms the traditional methods in the three indicators of security, efficiency and stability. The detection accuracy rate has increased to 96.5%, the average encryption time consumption has decreased to 0.61 seconds, and the performance volatility has dropped to 0.046. The results verified that the algorithm has high efficiency and robustness in complex network environments, and proved that it achieves collaborative optimization of performance under multi-dimensional constraints. The research provides theoretical support and technical paths for building an intelligent and scalable network security protection system.

title: A Fault Diagnosis Method Based on Belief Rule Base With Multielement Knowledge Transfer for Complex Electromechanical System
authors: Xinzhi Yao, Changhua Hu, Zhichao Feng, Xiangyu Kong
abstract: This article proposes a fault diagnosis method based on information transfer and a belief rule base (BRB) to address the challenges in the diagnosis of complex electromechanical system faults under parallel test conditions. These challenges include extremely imbalanced samples, individual parallel test differences, and knowledge scarcity concerning the target individuals. This article also proposes a transfer evolution coefficient calculation method. A new transfer learning-based BRB (T-LBRB) model which considers the transfer evolution coefficient is established, and the transfer of multiple elements such as knowledge, rules, and optimization parameters is achieved. To analyze the impact of multielement transfer on the resulting diagnostic accuracy quantitatively, a sensitivity analysis of the transfer coefficient was conducted on the basis of the modeling transparency and traceability of the T-LBRB model. An experimental study is conducted on a simulation platform for a certain type of rocket subsystem to verify the effectiveness of the proposed method.

title:
Fiber-based distribution of terahertz signals with noise cancellation at the 10
                    <sup>-17</sup>
                    Level
authors: Brendan M. Heffernan, James Greenberg, William F. McGrew, Antoine Rolland
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: We present and characterize a fiber-noise-cancellation scheme for distributing terahertz signals over optical fiber using two optical wavelengths. Fractional frequency instabilities of less than 10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">-17</sup> are achieved at 10,000 seconds for the evaluated frequencies of 150, 300, and 600 GHz over a 38 km link. The effect of temperature changes on the distributed signal frequency is systematically studied, along with the phase noise added by the link under laboratory conditions.

title: Listening to Nature: Automated Bird Species Identification for Biodiversity Monitoring
authors: Vencel Bódi, Márk Mitrenga, Bálint Kővári, Szilárd Aradi
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: Bird populations are important bioindicators, as the diversity of their habitats and their outstanding mobility make them sensitive to ecosystem changes. They also contribute to ecosystems by providing valuable services such as pest control, seed dispersal, and pollination, which are vital for maintaining ecological balance. Hence monitoring the composition of bird populations is essential for assessing ecosystem health and guiding conservation efforts. However, traditional observer-based surveys are expensive, time-consuming, and impractical for large-scale and hardly accessible applications. Our study proposes an approach by integrating automated acoustic monitoring with machine learning applications to develop a system that achieves high identification accuracy while keeping the pipeline simple. Our model design emphasizes a balance between efficiency and scalability, enabling deployment in resource-constrained environments. We provide a tool for low-complexity ecological monitoring by prioritizing lightweight and simple architectures. This work bridges the gap between ecological research and practical, scalable conservation technologies.

title: Constructing a Transformer Multi-Source Data Fusion Diagnosis Model Using Attention Mechanism
authors: Minhu Xu, Hang Zhang, Yubo Shen, Yun Guo, Zhongyuan Li, Liwei Li
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Automation, Electronics and Electrical Engineering (AUTEEE)
abstract: To address the heterogeneity and noise interference of multi-source transformer monitoring data (electrical quantities, dissolved gas in oil, and vibration signals), a four-stage closed-loop diagnosis model consisting of "data preprocessing - feature extraction - attention fusion - fault classification" is proposed. The preprocessing stage optimizes data quality through spatiotemporal weighted interpolation, improved wavelet threshold denoising, and improved Z-score normalization. The feature extraction stage designs dedicated subnetworks for each data set (1D-CNN for vibration, MLP for gas, and GRU for electrical quantities). The attention fusion stage dynamically aggregates key features through cross-attention. The classification stage outputs fault categories using a fully connected network. Simulation experiments were conducted based on 3500 sets of measured data (including five types of faults) from a provincial power company from 2019 to 2023. The data was partitioned into training, validation, and test sets with a 7:2:1 ratio. Results show that the model achieved a 98.2% accuracy on the test set, a 6.9% improvement over the optimal single-data model (MLP-G, 91.3%) and a 3.6% improvement over the optimal traditional fusion model (Ada-Weight, 94.6%). The recall rate for minor partial discharges reached 96.3%, effectively addressing the traditional model's lack of sensitivity to early faults.

title: AING-SLAM: Accurate Implicit Neural Geometry-Aware SLAM With Appearance and Semantics Via History-Guided Optimization
authors: Yanan Hao, Chenhui Shi, Pengju Zhang, Fulin Tang, Yihong Wu
abstract: In range-based SLAM systems, localization accuracy depends on the quality of geometric maps. Sparse LiDAR scans and noisy depth from RGB-D sensors often yield incomplete or inaccurate reconstructions that degrade pose estimation. Appearance and semantic cues, readily available from onboard RGB and pretrained models, can serve as complementary signals to strengthen geometry. Nevertheless, variations in appearance due to illumination or texture and inconsistencies in semantic labels across frames can hinder geometric optimization if directly used as supervision. To address these challenges, we propose AING-SLAM, an Accurate Implicit Neural Geometry-aware SLAM framework that allows appearance and semantics to effectively strengthen geometry in both mapping and odometry. A unified neural point representation with a lightweight cross-modal decoder integrates geometry, appearance and semantics, enabling auxiliary cues to refine geometry even in sparse or ambiguous regions. For pose tracking, appearance-semantic-aided odometry jointly minimizes SDF, appearance, and semantic residuals with adaptive weighting, improving scan-to-map alignment and reducing drift. To safeguard stability, a history-guided gradient fusion strategy aligns instantaneous updates with long-term optimization trends, mitigating occasional inconsistencies between appearance/semantic cues and SDF-based supervision, thereby strengthening geometric optimization. Extensive experiments on indoor RGB-D and outdoor LiDAR benchmarks demonstrate real-time performance, state-of-the-art localization accuracy, and high-fidelity reconstruction across diverse environments.

title: A sampled observer for a three-branch supercapacitor model: voltages estimation for SOC under NEDC and WLTP cycles
authors: I. Belghazi, E. Magarotto, T. Ahmed-Ali, M. Haddad
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: In this paper, we propose an online estimation method for the internal voltages of a three-branch super-capacitor model. The main goal is to provide a fast and accurate estimation of these voltages, which are crucial for assessing the state of charge (SOC) for the management system. To achieve this, we design a decoupled continuous nonlinear observer, whose outputs are discretized using a zero-order hold (ZOH). Simulation results demonstrate that the observer delivers high-performance estimation, even under fast dynamic input conditions, such as those encountered in WLTP cycles.

title: Ramanujan Periodic Transform for Automated EEG Anomaly Detection
authors: Soumyajit Banerjee, Proloy Chatterjee, Manshi Jhingon, Priti Kumari, Adyasha Rath, Ganapati Panda
publish: 2025 5th IEEE International Conference on Applied Electromagnetics, Signal Processing, &amp; Communication (AESPC)
abstract: This paper offers a thorough framework that combines dual statistical scoring and multi-transform feature extraction to identify brain abnormalities using 256 -channel electroencephalography (EEG). A 640 -dimensional feature vector is produced for each EEG sample using the discrete Fourier transform (DFT), the discrete wavelet transform (DWT), and the Ramanujan periodic transform (RPT) to extract complementary features. The RPT is highlighted here because of its exceptional ability to isolate integer-valued periodicity and reveal subtle, noise-robust rhythmic signatures in EEG that frequently elude Fourier and wavelet methods. We used two channel-level anomaly detectors on a dataset of 5,000 samples: the Median Absolute Deviation (MAD) approach and the Z-score method. Although the MAD detector offered more reliable outlier detection that is less susceptible to extreme values, the $\mathbf{Z}$-score detector identified 25,388 aberrant channel events throughout the sample. Comparative tests show that the multi-transform feature space performs significantly better than single-transform baselines, providing increased resilience against noise and artifacts, as well as enhanced sensitivity to anomalies.

title: Gap-Coupled Circularly Polarized SIW Filtenna for S-Band Applications
authors: R Ramya, Shilpi Gupta, K. Deepthi
publish: 2025 5th IEEE International Conference on Applied Electromagnetics, Signal Processing, &amp; Communication (AESPC)
abstract: The proposed Substrate Integrated Waveguide filtenna gives circular polarization S-band applications. The filtenna consists of a HMSIRC followed by a parasitic patch that radiates to give circular polarization. The HMSIRC filter passes the desired band which acts as feed to the followed parasitic patch. Additionally, generation of circularly polarized wave is done with the help of truncation at the corners. The proposed filtenna exhibits an impedance bandwidth of $\mathbf{1 6 0 ~ M H z}$, spanning $2.46-2.62 \mathrm{GHz}$, while achieving an axial-ratio bandwidth of 20 MHz within the $2.49-2.51 \mathrm{GHz}$ range. At the center frequency of 2.5 GHz, the antenna produces right-hand circular polarization (RHCP) with a peak realized gain of 6.85 dBi. These results confirm the antenna's suitability for compact, integrated wireless systems requiring simultaneous filtering and circularly polarized radiation characteristics.

title: AI-Driven HR: Revolutionizing Human Resource Management
authors: Anil Kumar Meher, Deepti Mishra, Tania Mishra, Abhaya Kumar Sahoo
publish: 2025 5th IEEE International Conference on Applied Electromagnetics, Signal Processing, &amp; Communication (AESPC)
abstract: In today’s rapidly evolving technology environment, the integration of artificial intelligence (AI) into various industries has become a significant driver of innovation. In the context of human resources, artificial intelligence is defined as a wide variety of software algorithms that enable a computer to perform human resource management activities that would normally require human cognition and intervention. This includes data-driven decision making, behavioral analysis, trend prediction and much more. One area that is experiencing a profound impact from AI is human resources management (HRM). By incorporating an AI system into the HR department, the company’s employees will gain increased productivity and experience. AI can assist HR departments in every phase of their professional work, from timely candidate selection to performance evaluation. Integrating artificial intelligence into human resource management can then help a business achieve overall efficiency and gain an edge over its competitors. By leveraging AI technologies, organizations can improve employee’s performance, their productivity, and decision-making processes. AI will eventually have a noticeable and longlasting effect on HR. Since technology is always evolving, AI framework must be adaptable enough to update itself and make adjustments as needed. We can use AI to take away most of the monotonous employee’s tasks, analyze vast amounts of data to make tangible decisions, and create a holistic impact on the organization and its people. According to 76% of HR directors, companies would fall behind in organizational performance if they do not integrate and apply AI technologies like generative AI within the next 12 to 24 months. To effectively decide whether to use new AI solutions for HR, CHROs must evaluate technological trends in an organized manner.HR workers may now employ machine learning and algorithms to expedite work processes, lessen biases, and enhance analysis and decision-making thanks to advancements in AI technology, which has completely changed the HR department. Still, some companies are delaying the use of AI for additional use cases due to existing limits and threats.. Artificial intelligence needs proper data storage and maintenance to function effectively. It collects and analyzes all the necessary data and enables the HR department to make data-based decisions. HR manager can make data-driven decisions that are sustainable and impactful. We’ll discuss in this article and explore the role of AI in HR practices and its implications for the future of work.

title: MobileNetV4 Optimization for Edge Devices: Dynamic UIB Selection and Resource-Constrained Decisions
authors: Tianxiang Zhang, Jing Chen, Chuanfu Zhang, Tonglin Fu, Mingchao Ji, Shengnan Li
publish: 2025 IEEE 31th International Conference on Parallel and Distributed Systems (ICPADS)
abstract: This work proposes a resource-aware adaptive framework for MobileNetV4 that dynamically balances accuracy, latency, and memory under edge device constraints. A Dynamic Universal Inverted Bottleneck (UIB) module architecture is designed with hierarchical decomposition into Perception Block (PB), Semantic Aggregation Block (SAB), and Decision Block (DB). Through dual pruning and reinforcement learning-based variant selection, the framework achieves superior accuracy-efficiency trade-off across diverse hardware. Experiments show up to 30% inference speedup and 67% memory usage compared to the baseline, with <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$<5 \%$</tex> accuracy drop.

title: New Approach to Optimize Vulnerabilities Management of Smart Contract in Blockchain Network
authors: Z. H. Randriamiarison, H. Razafimahatratra, N. R Razafindrakoto, Y. Rhazali
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: Blockchain technology is gaining popularity today, replacing centralized data storage on a central server with a decentralized network of ledgers, thus ensuring secure information exchange. A smart contract is a program written on the blockchain that runs autonomously within the Ethereum virtual machine: a transparent and secure program, but once deployed on the blockchain network, it cannot be modified. Despite its advantage over other technologies, smart contract has become a prime target for hackers, making it difficult for developers to eliminate all vulnerabilities before its deployment. In this paper, we propose a static analysis approach aimed at reducing vulnerabilities in smart contract. Our method builds upon PASO (Parser for Solidity) and MSmart approaches: we developed a test lifecycle model for smart contracts and created a tool based on ANTLR4's G4 grammar. It involves both syntactic and lexical analysis to effectively detect bugs and vulnerabilities in smart contract. To validate our method, we used FDR (False Discovery Rate) and FNR (False Negative Rate) as evaluation metrics, data collected from SmartBugs and Etherscan. We validated our approach compared with MSmart and SmartCheck. We got higher FDR and improved FNR, indicating enhanced detection capabilities. After thorough analysis and extensive testing, our tool has proven to be both specific and high-performing.

title: Automated Construction Cost Estimation Framework with AI-Driven Reinforcement Learning
authors: Vaisnave I M, Mythily M, Stewart Kirubakaran S
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Automation, Computing and Renewable Systems (ICACRS)
abstract: Residential and commercial renovation projects always face the problem of accurate and smooth cost estimating, or rather manual quoting, fragile contractor experience, and scattered data. The present research introduces a system that takes advantage of AI-powered Reinforcement Learning— improved Random Forest Estimator which is combined with a conversational React interface and that allows users to receive instant project cost predictions by means of natural language communication. The combination is made up of multi-turn natural language understanding (NLU), Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) for contextual grounding, along with a Random Forest regression model that has been trained on well-curated construction cost datasets. A reinforcement feedback loop works on model accuracy and it does so in a dynamic way, alongside the confirmed contractor cost submissions that are coming in, it computes reward values and, when the sampling thresholds are reached, it triggers the automated retraining. The experiment, wherein the performance of various regression models (Random Forest, XGBoost, Support Vector Machine, and Artificial Neural Network) was compared, pointed out the Random Forest model as the best, with the following scores: MAE = 121,377.66, RMSE = 196,474.80, and R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> = 0.9957, besides that, it also beat the other algorithms in terms of predictive stability and efficiency of retraining. The system utilizes MongoDB to support feedback logging, track projects, and govern versioned models, thus guaranteeing continuous improvement and transparency.

title: Enhanced Correlation Graph based Web APIs Composition Recommendation for Mashup Creation
authors: Hualing Sun, Sheng Wang, Yuxuan Han, Qinghe Yan, Zheng Cong, Peihai Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE Cyber Science and Technology Congress (CyberSciTech)
abstract: With the success of web APIS for data communication, the number of Web APIs has grown rapidly. While this proliferation affords developers a wide array of APIs, it simultaneously heightens the challenge of selecting the most suitable ones. Recommendation methods based on correlation graphs aim to help developers discover relevant and compatible Compositions of APIs for mashup creation. However, existing API Composition recommendations suffer from problems such as low recommendation accuracy and significant time overhead when dealing with a large number of keywords. To address this challenge, this paper proposes an extension to traditional correlation graph-based API Composition recommendation algorithms by introducing an Semantic-Integrated Correlation Graph API Composition Recommender (SCGACR) algorithm. This algorithm significantly reduces the algorithmic time and space overhead and improves the recommendation performance to some extent. Experimental results on real-world datasets show that the SCGACR method exhibits lower time overhead and improved recommendation accuracy compared to competing methods.

title: Investigation and Comparative analysis of SRAM Architectures
authors: Niroj Kumar Patra, P Sai Pavan, Umakanta Nanda, G Venkateswarlu
publish: 2025 5th IEEE International Conference on Applied Electromagnetics, Signal Processing, &amp; Communication (AESPC)
abstract: T) SRAM cell. The techniques evaluated include Multi-Threshold CMOS (MTCMOS), Gated VDD, Dynamic Threshold MOSFET (DTMOS), Dual-Threshold CMOS (DTCMOS), and Transistor Stacking. These methods utilize various mechanisms to minimize both dynamic and static power dissipation. All designs were modelled and simulated using Cadence Virtuoso at the 45 nm CMOS technology node under standard operating conditions. Leakage power, dynamic power, delay, and power-delay product were measured and benchmarked against a baseline 6T SRAM cell. Simulation results indicate that MTCMOS achieves the highest leakage reduction of up to 85% with minimal impact on performance. Gated VDD and DTCMOS offer effective standby leakage control, while DTMOS and Transistor Stacking reduce leakage to the picowatt range, albeit with trade-offs in area and speed.
