title: Attack Detection in UAV Networks Based on Graph Convolutional Networks and Residual Channel Attention
authors: Liu Jiayu, Ke Xu, Lu Xinyu, Wang Zechen, Wang Yuyang
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Automation, Electronics and Electrical Engineering (AUTEEE)
abstract: To address the cybersecurity threats faced by unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) networks, this paper proposes an attack detection method that integrates graph convolutional networks (GNNs) and residual channel attention mechanisms. This method utilizes the k-nearest neighbor algorithm to construct a traffic graph structure, extracts topological features through a GNN, and introduces a residual attention module to adaptively enhance key features. On the UAV cybersecurity dataset by Hassler et al., the proposed method achieves accuracy, precision, recall, and F1 score of 89.52%, 90.01%, 89.68%, and 89.49%, respectively, demonstrating significant advantages over existing improved models and validating the effectiveness of the proposed method in UAV network attack detection.

title: A Novel Terahertz Integrated Antenna Technology Using Silicon and BCB Process
authors: Yumeng Chen, Peng Wu, Fanqi Meng, Junchen Min, Peng Yue
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: Terahertz (THz) integrated antenna is an important part of THz front-end systems. There exist several main challenges in THz integrated antennas, such as bandwidth, efficiency and assembly process. In this paper, a novel integrated antenna is proposed based on silicon and BCB process. The antenna radiation elements are etched in silicon wafer and fed by grounded coplanar waveguide in the BCB layer on the other silicon side. Both radiation elements and feeding network can be fabricated by the silicon-based BCB process simultaneously, which can bring advantages of simplified assembly process and reduced feeding loss. The fabrication process of the silicon-based BCB antenna will be introduced in the session. To demonstrate the proposed scheme, an improved 2×2 integrated silicon dielectric array is designed. In the frequency range from 211 GHz to 231.5 GHz, the return loss is better than-15 dB, antenna gain is higher than 9 dBi and radiation efficiency is higher than 83%. The proposed antenna scheme is suitable for integrating with active devices and also realizing larger-scale antenna arrays.

title: Voltage and Rectification Timing Control for Start-Up Current Overshoot Suppression in Dynamic Wireless Power Transfer Systems
authors: Yuya Deguchi, Sakahisa Nagai, Osamu Shimizu, Hiroshi Fujimoto, Masaya Takahashi, Hayato Sumiya
abstract: In dynamic wireless power transfer (DWPT) systems for electric vehicles, maximizing the power output from each transmitter (Tx) coil is essential for minimizing installation costs. However, in series-series (SS) type DWPT systems, applying a large step voltage in low-coupling regions causes a Tx-side current overshoot, which consequently requires increased equipment capacity. This study proposes a control method that simultaneously minimizes the current overshoot and settling time by combining bilateral voltage control with receiver (Rx)-side rectifier timing control, employing an active rectifier. The conventional current envelope model is extended to an SS-type DWPT system by approximating the time variation of mutual inductance using a polynomial. It is theoretically shown that voltage trajectories that eliminate oscillatory components while maintaining a constant steady-state current exist, and these trajectories are implemented through voltage control on both the Tx and Rx sides, along with Rx-side rectification timing control. The proposed method was experimentally validated on an 8kW-scale DWPT test bench operating at 20km/h. The results confirm that the proposed method reduces the Tx current overshoot from 207% to 5% and shortens the settling time to 0.14 ms. Consequently, under a 50A current limit, the received energy increased from 22.47 J to 115.8 J.

title: Reducing Lumbar Extensor Exertion in Lifting Tasks with a Powered Back Exosuit
authors: Ian Cullen, Christoph Nuesslein, Aaron Young
abstract: OBJECTIVE: The study seeks to determine whether a powered, cable-driven exosuit has the potential to lower the lumbar muscle activity and overall metabolic expenditure of symmetric and asymmetric lifting tasks. METHODS: A lightweight, cable-driven back exosuit, using a three-state impedance controller, was developed to provide variable assistance based on user posture. Experimental electromyography (EMG), metabolic cost, and user preference data were recorded for ten participants evaluated wearing the powered back exosuit versus the backX, a commercially available passive back support exoskeleton, and a no exo baseline. RESULTS: Both exoskeletons significantly reduced (p<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$< $</tex-math></inline-formula>0.05) muscle activation of certain lumbar flexor and extensor muscles when compared to a no exo condition across all conditions tested, though neither significantly reduced the metabolic cost associated with lifting. Users tended to prefer lifting with the powered device as opposed to the passive or no exo condition. CONCLUSION: Despite the increased mass of powered back support exoskeletons, these devices can reduce lumbar muscle activity to a similar degree as passive exoskeletons, and are favored by users over their passive counterparts. SIGNIFICANCE: While current powered back support devices tend to incur the cost of being heavy, rigid, and inconvenient for certain lifting postures, these results show that cable-driven powered devices may minimize these factors to the point that they are favored over the currently popular passive devices on the market.

title: Comparison of Coaxial Magnetic Gears Using Rare Earth and Nonrare Earth Permanent Magnets
authors: Byeong-Cheol Bae, Seung-Hun Lee, So-Yeon Im, Myung-Seop Lim
abstract: Coaxial magnetic gears (CMGs) enable contactless torque transmission, addressing the noise and maintenance drawbacks of mechanical gears. However, the heavy reliance on rare earth permanent magnets (PMs) presents a challenge owing to their unstable supply and fluctuating costs. To mitigate dependence on rare earth PMs, this study proposes and evaluates four CMG configurations combining NdFeB and Ferrite. Each configuration is optimized using two-dimensional finite element analysis (FEA), with axial leakage considered by an equivalent magnetic circuit model instead of three-dimensional (3D) FEA. The suitability of bridge geometry for each PM combination is first assessed, revealing that irrespective of the PM material, the inner bridge provides superior torque density. Comparative analyses of the electromagnetic performance and active material costs were then conducted to evaluate the feasibility of each PM configuration. The results indicate that the difference in residual flux density between the inner and outer rotor PMs influences torque density, material costs, peak-to-peak torque, and efficiency. This difference was also observed in an appropriate gap between the active part and the end cover, at which end cover loss becomes negligible. Ferrite-Nd CMG showed the highest efficiency and lowest price among the combinations of nonrare earth PMs. Finally, electromagnetic performance comparisons of NdFeB-based and Ferrite-Nd CMGs using 3D FEA and experimental validation show that while the Ferrite-Nd CMG has a lower torque density than the NdFeB-based CMG, it offers promising advantages in terms of reduced rare earth dependency, negligible housing loss, and high efficiency.

title: UFORank:Unified Framework of Unsupervised Keyphrase Extraction for Long Documents
authors: Doyoon Kim, Pilsung Kang
abstract: Keyphrase extraction involves automatically identifying key phrases that represent the core content within a document. Recent advancements have improved unsupervised methods for keyphrase extraction, enabling efficient operation without requiring labeled training data. As document length increases, effective keyphrase extraction becomes increasingly crucial for information summarization and retrieval. However, existing methods often struggle with long documents due to challenges in capturing global context and semantic relationships across extended text. In this paper, we propose UFORank, a unified framework for unsupervised keyphrase extraction specifically designed for long documents. UFORank integrates three key components: (1) topic importance derived from clustering semantically similar phrases, (2) position-biased weights that consider both relative positions and frequencies of phrases within the document structure, and (3) phrase-to-topic similarity measures for enhanced relevance scoring. Additionally, UFORank employs Glow, a flow-based generative model, to improve the semantic representation quality of both phrases and documents in the embedding space. Experimental evaluations on three benchmark datasets for long document keyphrase extraction demonstrate that UFORank achieves competitive performance compared to existing state-of-the-art methods, including PromptRank and Attention-Seeker. Specifically, UFORank achieves F1-scores of 17.66%, 20.73%, and 13.17% on the respective datasets. Comprehensive ablation studies validate the individual contributions of each framework component to the overall performance gains.

title: Broadband Linear-Phase Metasurface for Full-Polarization Cloaking With RCS-Reduction Capability
authors: Chengcheng Li, Weiwen Li, Longfang Ye
publish: IEEE Antennas and Wireless Propagation Letters
abstract: Traditional co-polarized metasurface cloaks suffer from limited bandwidth, polarization sensitivity, and mismatched operating bands between near-field (NF) and far-field (FF) responses. To overcome these limitations, this work proposes a linear-phase metasurface cloak whose phase response follows the linear law required for broadband cloaking. The cloak is realized using anisotropic unit cells with an 8-mm periodicity and 4-mm thickness, both determined through systematic parametric studies. Surface-current analysis and multi-frequency NF simulations validate its wideband performance. A spin-decoupling strategy is further introduced to enable joint cloaking under both linear and circular polarizations (LP/CP). Multi-frequency experiments under normal incidence demonstrate efficient LP/CP cloaking over a 6.5–10.5 GHz band (47% fractional bandwidth), with a flat 4 dB FF RCS reduction under representative LP excitation across the same frequency range, exhibiting well-aligned NF and FF operating bands without performance trade-offs.

title: s-SNOM Visualization of Plasmon Polariton Waves Traversing the Channel of a Graphene Field-effect Transistor
authors: Andrei Bylinkin, Elham Talvari, Edoardo Vicentini, Florian Ludwig, Juan A. Delgado-Notario, Rainer Hillenbrand, Hartmut G. Roskos
publish: 2025 50th International Conference on Infrared, Millimeter, and Terahertz Waves (IRMMW-THz)
abstract: Field-effect transistors (FETs), monolithically equipped with antennae, are by now well established as rectifying detectors of terahertz radiation (TeraFETs). At such high radiation frequencies, the charge carriers in the channels of the TeraFETs can no longer respond in a quasi-static manner, but instead plasmon polariton waves (electromagnetically coupled charge oscillations in the gate electrode and the two-dimensional chargecarrier gas) are launched at the electrodes which are connected with the antenna. The waves decay rapidly with the momentum scattering time of the charge carriers. But as the speed of the waves is high, one expects for sufficiently short channels that the waves can reach the end of the channel and are reflected back, leading to the formation of a standing wave and possibly giving rise to a Fabry-Perot-like resonance. Indeed, evidence for standing-wave formation was found in the low-temperature responsivity of some TeraFETs. Recently, such standing-wave signatures were observed for the first time even at room temperature. The measurement were performed on graphene TeraFETs exhibiting a very high mobility of the charge carriers. Here, we present s-SNOM measurements, taken at room temperature on a similar graphene TeraFET, but now with a buried channel which allows for the near-field probing of the plasmon polaritons. We report the observation of underdamped polariton waves, propagating all the way through the transistor’s channel and returning after reflection at the end of the channel.

title: Graph-based Optimization for Assembly Line Balancing Incorporating Metabolic Restrictions
authors: Joana R. Almeida, Ana Moura, João R. Almeida, José L. Oliveira
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: Manual assembly processes remain a fundamental aspect of the manufacturing industry, primarily due to the dexterity and adaptability of human workers. However, the repetitive and physically demanding nature of these tasks highlights the need for an ergonomic and well-balanced workload, as poor ergonomics can also contribute to errors. This paper aims to automate the assembly line balancing process for a real-world case study. A new multi-objective Assembly Line Balancing Problem (ALBP) formulation is proposed, minimizing both workload variance and variance in workers’ energy expenditure across workstations while accounting for daily fluctuations in the number of operators. The proposed metabolic and time-sensitive assembly line balancing method integrates caloric considerations to reduce long-term risks of Work-Related Musculoskeletal Disorders (WMSDs). Using a graph-based approach, the framework ensures that precedence constraints are met while optimizing task assignments to minimize cycle time and metabolic cost per operator. To improve accuracy in estimating energy expenditure, this study employs the Methods-Time Measurement - Universal Analyzing System (MTM-UAS), which decomposes tasks into standardized motion elements. The methodology is validated through a real-world case study at Bosch Thermotechnology in Portugal, assigning tasks while minimizing the trade-offs between worker fatigue and production goals. The code to validate this study is publicly available at https://github.com/joaorafaelalmeida/line-balancing-algorithm.

title: Information and Communication Technologies in Education: Challenges and Opportunities for the Classroom System
authors: Julia Doncheva, Tzvetomir Vassilev
abstract: This paper examines the importance of information and communication technologies (ICT) in modern education, and in particular in the context of classroom work. With the increasing level of digitalization and the integration of new technologies in the educational process, teachers, students, and parents are faced with a number of challenges and opportunities. In addition to the challenges and opportunities, an analysis of a survey conducted among user groups of teachers, students and parents was made. The conclusion is that the successful integration of information and communication technologies in education requires strategic approaches that address the challenges, while at the same time taking advantage of the opportunities provided. The need for ongoing teacher training and ensuring equal access to technologies is a key to realizing the potential of ICT in the classroom system.

title: Exploring Neuromorphic Computing for Reinforcement Learning: A Survey and Review
authors: Sai Deepa Kadaru, Rohit Buccapatnam, Chang Liu
abstract: This survey explores neuromorphic computing within the context of reinforcement learning (RL), covering developments in neuromorphic hardware and architectures that support RL algorithms. We analyze the integration of RL frameworks with spiking neural networks (SNNs) on neuromorphic hardware platforms such as Loihi, DYNAP-SE, BrainScaleS, and SpiNNaker, examining their approaches to RL implementation through various architectures and learning mechanisms. This paper also discusses key software frameworks that facilitate the development of RL applications on the neuromorphic hardware. While recent studies demonstrate promising results in areas such as robotics, gaming, and autonomous systems, challenges persist in scalability, hardware constraints, and training efficiency. The conclusion addresses critical challenges, such as balancing energy efficiency with robustness, offers insights on potential solutions, and identifies directions for future research in this area.

title: Software Base for Interconnection, Intercommunication and Interoperability of Heterogeneous Models
authors: Baoran An, Qiang Ren, Bing Yu, Shicao Zhao, Tao Lei
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Big Data, Artificial Intelligence and Internet of Things Engineering (ICBAIE)
abstract: To tackle the challenge of interconnection, intercommunication and interoperability of heterogeneous model, this paper establishes formal definitions of their conceptual essence and requirements. The meta-model-based cross-domain framework has been proposed for heterogeneous model, capable of reducing technical complexity from multiplicative to additive. Furthermore, four core technologies demanding focused breakthroughs in software base development are delineated, with corresponding implementation pathways. Finally, the feasibility of the software base has been demonstrated through a case study on interconnection, intercommunication and interoperability of component models.

title: Quasi-Passive Vertical Compensation for Accurate 6-DOF Physical Simulation of Microgravity Collision During Landing on Small Celestial Body_supp1-3648356.mp4
authors: Wei Jiang
abstract: Exploring small celestial bodies, such as asteroids, opens new avenues for space exploration, complementing lunar and Martian missions. However, the microgravity environment (∼10−5g) presents significant challenges, particularly for landing. Accurate prelaunch testing of mechanical and control systems is crucial to ensure mission success. Therefore, the ground-based microgravity physical simulation is essential, particularly for accurately replicating its microgravity collision response. However, existing microgravity simulations fail to accurately replicate landing collision response, particularly in the vertical direction. In this article, an air-bearing simulation system with quasi-passive vertical compensation is presented, enabling 6-DOF simulation. The vertical compensation integrates a quasi-zero stiffness unit for passive gravity compensation, complemented by an active following mechanism for extended compensation stroke. The controller is specifically adjusted to generate the vertical virtual mass, ensuring equal added mass in all three directions and eliminating systematic errors. Vertical tests confirm that the system effectively simulates free-floating conditions for the lander simulator up to 1 ton and accurately responds to forces as small as 1 N. The proposed 6-DOF physical simulation system provides a novel technical approach and has been implemented in the ground verification of the Tianwen-2 exploration mission.

title: Performance Evaluation of Integer and FractionalOrder Controllers for an Automobile Cruise Control System
authors: Shashikanta Kerketta, Tusar Kumar Pati, Jiten Dash, Sonalika Mishra, Biresh Kumar Dakua
publish: 2025 5th IEEE International Conference on Applied Electromagnetics, Signal Processing, &amp; Communication (AESPC)
abstract: Automobile Cruise Control (ACC) systems are designed to automatically regulate vehicle velocity at a desired setpoint, thereby minimizing driver workload while improving ride comfort and fuel economy. In this study, the ACC problem is addressed through a control engineering perspective, where the objective is formulated as an error-function minimization problem. Three different controllers, such as the Proportional Integral Derivative (PID), Tilt Integral Derivative (TID), and Fractional Order PID (FOPID), are investigated for their ability to deliver accurate and robust speed regulation. The tuning of these controllers is carried out using modern metaheuristic optimization techniques, namely the Artificial Rabbit Optimizer (ARO), Arithmetic Optimization Algorithm (AOA), and Supply-Demand Optimization (SDO). A statistical analysis is performed to evaluate the effectiveness of each controller-optimizer-cost function combination. Additionally, robustness testing under parameter variations is performed to ensure the practical viability of the control strategies. Simulation findings highlight the superior time domain performance of the FOPID controller, demonstrating its enhanced robustness and precision in meeting the ACC objectives.

title: Compression and Acceleration of Transformer-based Multi-Channel Speech-to-English Translation Models for Edge Devices
authors: Xinyuan Fan
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Automation, Computing and Renewable Systems (ICACRS)
abstract: In recent years, with the growing demand for scenarios such as multilingual voice interaction, intelligent conference recording, and real-time translation, end-to-end speech-to-English translation (S2ET) models have become a key research direction. However, the traditional cascaded ASR-NMT architecture is prone to error accumulation in noisy environments and suffers from high computational complexity and excessive energy consumption on edge devices. This research provides a Transformer-based multi-channel speech-to-English translation model compression and acceleration framework for edge devices in order to overcome these obstacles. Three approaches are used in the methodical construction of this model: structural compression, attention optimization, and signal modeling. A multi-channel observation model based on the short-time Fourier transform (STFT) is first built during the signal modeling phase. This approach improves the spatial representation of speech signals by achieving combined feature modeling of amplitude and phase through the use of a complex-domain convolutional network. Second, a dynamic covariance recursive update technique is paired with a minimal variance distortionless response (MVDR) filter in the voice enhancement step. This mechanism ensures distortion-free speech in the target direction while suppressing background noise. Third, we propose an Importance-Guided Aggregation Module (IAM). This substantially reduces redundant attention calculation and improves cross-channel information fusion capabilities by introducing a region-saliency selection technique into the Transformer attention computation. Lastly, we develop a three-phase compression technique that includes distillation, quantization, and pruning. Effective model deployment on platforms with limited resources is made possible by this tactic. The Qujing Multi-Channel Speech-to-English Translation Dataset (QJ-MCT), a proprietary dataset with a variety of environmental noise and reverberation circumstances, is what we experimentally create. Performance tests are conducted on Raspberry Pi 4 and Artix-7 FPGA platforms. Results show that the proposed model significantly reduces model size and latency while maintaining high translation accuracy. In particular, the compressed model is just 68 MB and the inference latency is decreased to 1820 ms, which represents reductions of roughly 85.8% and 56.7%, respectively, when compared to the uncompressed multi-channel Transformer baseline model (480 MB, 4200 ms). Knowledge distillation successfully makes up for the performance loss brought on by compression in terms of BLEU indicators, leading in a compressed model with BLEU 29.0 that is just 0.4 less than the original model. Additional ablation experiments showed that 8-bit quantization is the most consistent between performance and computational overhead, and that a better balance can be reached when the pruning intensity is between 20% and 40%.

title: Wearable and Ultra-Low-Power Fusion of EMG and A-Mode US for Hand-Wrist Kinematic Tracking
authors: Giusy Spacone, Sebastian Frey, Mattia Orlandi, Pierangelo Maria Rapa, Victor Kartsch, Simone Benatti, Luca Benini, Andrea Cossettini
publish: 2025 IEEE Biomedical Circuits and Systems Conference (BioCAS)
abstract: Hand gesture recognition based on biosignals has shown strong potential for developing intuitive human-machine interaction strategies that closely mimic natural human behavior. In particular, sensor fusion approaches have gained attention for combining complementary information and overcoming the limitations of individual sensing modalities, thereby enabling more robust and reliable systems. Among them, the fusion of surface electromyography (EMG) and A-mode ultrasound (US) is very promising. However, prior solutions rely on power-hungry platforms unsuitable for multi-day use and are limited to discrete gesture classification. In this work, we present an ultra-lowpower (sub- 50 mW) system for concurrent acquisition of 8 channel EMG and $\mathbf{4}$-channel A-mode US signals, integrating two state-of-the-art platforms into fully wearable, dry-contact armbands. We propose a framework for continuous tracking of $\mathbf{2 3}$ degrees of freedom (DoFs), $\mathbf{2 0}$ for the hand and $\mathbf{3}$ for the wrist, using a kinematic glove for ground-truth labeling. Our method employs lightweight encoder-decoder architectures with multitask learning to simultaneously estimate hand and wrist joint angles. Experimental results under realistic sensor repositioning conditions demonstrate that EMG-US fusion achieves a root mean squared error of $10.6^{\circ} \pm 2.0^{\circ}$, compared to $12.0^{\circ} \pm 1^{\circ}$ for EMG and $13.1^{\circ} \pm 2.6^{\circ}$ for US, and a $\mathbf{R}^{2}$ score of $0.61 \pm 0.1$, with $0.54 \pm 0.03$ for EMG and $0.38 \pm 0.20$ for US.

title: Control-Informed Neural Network for Controller Selection
authors: Dániel Fényes, Tamás Hegedűs, Péter Gáspár
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: This paper proposes a reinforcement learning (RL)-based approach for dynamically selecting the most suitable control method according to changing operating conditions. Using the nominal model of the actual system, several feedback controllers are developed, each offering different levels of performance depending on the scenario. The RL algorithm is employed to determine and apply the optimal control strategy within a given operational range. Four control methods are investigated: Linear Parameter Varying (LPV), Ultra-local Model-based (ULM), Linear Quadratic Regulator (LQR), and a kinematic model-based controller. The performance and effectiveness of the proposed approach are assessed through three test scenarios using the high-fidelity vehicle simulation platform, CarMaker.

title: Dispenser: Hierarchical KV Cache Management for Efficient LLM Generative Inference
authors: Beiquan Cao, Kaigui Bian, Guojie Luo, Joongheon Kim
publish: 2025 IEEE 31th International Conference on Parallel and Distributed Systems (ICPADS)
abstract: As context windows expands, Large Language Models (LLMs) are being more capable of handling long-context tasks. However, long-context inference is hindered by high latency and memory usage due to the linearly growing Key-Value (KV) cache. Prior work has shown that a dynamic subset of the KV cache dominates attention outcomes and selectively loads these subsets instead of the full cache. These methods partition the KV cache into segments (block-wise and token-wise) and identify critical ones for recall. However, for block-wise ones, their recall accuracy is often compromised by semantic inconsistencies among consecutive tokens, and for token-wise ones, they suffer from inefficiency in memory management and offloading. To these ends, we propose Dispenser, a hierarchical KV cache management algorithm inspired by multi-level page tables. Dispenser organizes the KV cache based on token semantic similarity and partitions it into pages and blocks, which enables straightforward integration into modern serving engines such as vLLM. It employs a two-level lookup mechanism to identify and load the most relevant blocks for the current query. Experimental results demonstrate that Dispenser achieves up to a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$5.75 \times$</tex> speedup in self-attention, reducing inference latency by <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2.1 \times$</tex> on tasks with long dependencies with negligible accuracy loss.

title: TimeGPT-inspired Temporal Convolutional Networks with Cross-Attention layers for Glucose Forecasting in Artificial Pancreas
authors: Deepjyoti Kalita, Hrishita Sharma, Khalid B. Mirza
publish: 2025 IEEE Biomedical Circuits and Systems Conference (BioCAS)
abstract: Blood glucose algorithms for forecasting provide a crucial role in the advancement of decision-making in diabetes. Decisions can range from glucose forecasts being used for insulin dosing to dietary decisions. As closed-loop diabetes management applications require sensor data from continuous glucose monitoring wearable sensors and physical activity monitoring devices, it is crucial to compile data from different devices and use this data as for forecasting glucose levels in advance. Previous works have explored the use of different deep learning approaches owing to their high forecasting accuracy compared to traditional machine learning based forecasting methods. However, these models suffer from high time lag and an inability to handle missing time series data points. In this paper, we propose a novel model which is based on generative pre-trained transformer (GPT) models for timeseries forecasting, where, temporal convolutional network (TCN) layer is used at the beginning, followed by an exogenous fusion block consisting of cross attention layer to enable forecasting with minimal loss. The model is validated on the OhioT1DM dataset, with incorporation of physical activity data, for benchmarking, and the model demonstrates a mean absolute relative difference (MARD) of $7.56 \pm 1.49$ and root mean squared error (RMSE) $17.98 \pm 2.78$ for $\mathbf{P H}$ of $\mathbf{3 0 ~ M i n}$ and MARD of $13.76 \pm 3.98$ and RMSE $30.59 \pm 6.33$ for PH of $\mathbf{6 0 ~ M i n}$.

title: Finger Force Decoding from Motor Units Activity on Neuromorphic Hardware
authors: Farah Baracat, Giacomo Indiveri, Elisa Donati
publish: 2025 IEEE Biomedical Circuits and Systems Conference (BioCAS)
abstract: Accurate finger force estimation is critical for nextgeneration human-machine interfaces. Traditional electromyography (EMG)-based decoding methods using deep learning require large datasets and high computational resources, limiting their use in real-time, embedded systems. Here, we propose a novel approach that performs finger force regression using spike trains from individual motor neurons, extracted from highdensity EMG. These biologically grounded signals drive a spiking neural network implemented on a mixed-signal neuromorphic processor. Unlike prior work that encodes EMG into events, our method exploits spike timing on motor units to perform low-power, real-time inference. This is the first demonstration of motor neuron-based regression computed directly on neuromorphic hardware. Our results confirm accurate finger-specific force prediction with minimal energy use, opening new possibilities for embedded decoding in prosthetics and wearable neurotechnology.

title: A Scale-Enhanced and Attention-Guided Network for Automatic Detection of Polyester Yarn Spool Surface Defects
authors: Chunyu Wang, Yangguang Zhao, Jiarui Feng, Yang Yuan, Jianguo Zhu, Jianpei Xu, Xiaofen Shen, Haiqiang Zhang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Digital Society and Intelligent Systems (DSInS)
abstract: During polyester yarn spool production, surface defects such as waste yarn carry-over, snagging-induced fuzz, and tail yarn carry-over often occur, significantly affecting subsequent usage. Currently, the detection of such defects mainly relies on manual visual inspection, which is inefficient and prone to subjective judgment, heavily dependent on the experience of the operators. The development and application of automated recognition systems have become an urgent need. This paper builds upon the YOLOv11 model by introducing the scale enhancement module (SEM) and the channel and position attention module (CPAM), resulting in the YOLOv11-SEMCPAM model. This model enables effective detection of the three typical defects, achieving an <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{mAP}_{50-95}$</tex> of 0.498, which significantly outperforms the baseline YOLOv11 model's 0.488 and the YOLOv11-SEM model's 0.490.

title: On Advancements of the Forward-Forward Algorithm
authors: Mauricio Ortiz Torres, Markus Lange, Arne P. Raulf
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: The Forward-Forward algorithm has evolved in machine learning research, tackling more complex tasks that mimic real-life applications. In recent years, it has been improved by several techniques to perform better than its original version, handling a challenging dataset like CIFAR10 without losing its flexibility and low memory usage. We have shown in our results that improvements are achieved through a combination of convolutional channel grouping, learning rate schedules, and independent block structures during training that lead to a 20% decrease in test error percentage. Additionally, to approach further implementations on low-capacity hardware projects, we have presented a series of lighter models that achieve low test error percentages within (21±3)% and a number of trainable parameters between 164,706 and 754,386. This serves as a basis for our future study on complete verification and validation of these kinds of neural networks.

                    Filtering for a Giant Cavity System with Two Coupling Points
authors: Guangpu Wu, Yuting Zhu, Tian Tang, Shibei Xue
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: In this paper, we present an H<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">∞</inf> filter for a giant cavity system which couples to a single-mode waveguide at two spatially separated points. The dynamics of the cavity is described by a time-delay Langevin equation in the Heisenberg picture whose time-delay term results from the non-local interactions to a waveguide. The input-output relation with a time-delay feature is also derived. In addition, we design an H<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">∞</inf> filter for estimating the evolution of the mode in the cavity using a quadrature representation state-space representation and Linear Matrix Inequality (LMI) approach. Finally, the efficacy of our method is numerically demonstrated in an example.

title: Study about a Multi-start metaheuristic approach for the SALB3PM
authors: Thiago G. Araujo, Matthieu Py, Laurent Deroussi, Nathalie Grangeon
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT)
abstract: With growing emphasis on sustainable manufacturing, we address the energy-aware Simple Assembly Line Balancing Problem with Power Peak Minimization (SALB3PM). We propose a metaheuristic to solve the SALB3PM. Our metaheuristic combines (1) a multi-start framework with three neighborhood operators (insertion, swap, delay incrementing) and (2) a dynamic penalty mechanism for handling cycle-time infeasibility. We designed and compared four algorithm variants to evaluate the impact of components. We conducted computational experiments on benchmark instances. The results show that our best variant achieves an average optimality gap of 2.38% when considering known optima, and optimal solutions were achieved in all runs for over 50% of instances. The approach contributes to sustainable manufacturing through energy-efficient production line design.

title: Proctonix AI - Smart Exam Proctoring using AI and Webcam
authors: Vishnu Priya, A Govardhan Naidu, I Mukesh Manikanta, Ch Santosh Kumar, B Issac Preetham, S.Muthumeena
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Automation, Computing and Renewable Systems (ICACRS)
abstract: Globally, the integrity of online examinations is a paramount concern with the widespread adoption of remote learning and digital assessments. Ensuring fairness and preventing academic misconduct presents a significant challenge for educational institutions, training centers, and certification bodies. Traditional proctoring methods are often resource-intensive or limited in their detection capabilities, leading to potentially inaccurate or insufficient monitoring. This paper introduces Proctonix AI, an intelligent online exam monitoring system designed to enhance academic integrity through real-time, AI-powered surveillance. Leveraging modern web technologies and computer vision techniques, the system captures and processes live webcam feeds and screen activity to detect suspicious behaviors. Key functionalities include face and presence detection, gaze tracking for distraction assessment, and voice activity monitoring. By employing Flask for backend web server and route handling, HTML/CSS/JavaScript for a responsive user interface, and OpenCV with Media Pipe Face Mesh for robust facial and eye landmark detection, Proctonix AI aims to provide a robust framework for identifying potential cheating instances. The system also integrates custom heuristics for behavioral analysis and browser APIs for user alerts, facilitating a more secure and reliable online examination environment. The objective is to offer a streamlined, accessible solution that supports educators in maintaining the credibility of online assessments.
